description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Less than two weeks after President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said he would travel to the United States for medical treatment and to calm tensions in his country, officials in his government said he had reversed course and would not travel because of escalating turmoil at home.

title: Cuomo Vows New Push to Improve Education
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says he is taking on a second job: lobbyist for students.

title: Egypts Rulers Are Threatening the Gains of Tahrir Square
description: Cairo

title: Full Album Sales Showed a Little Growth in 2011
description: For the beleaguered music industry, any positive news about sales is cause for celebration. And in 2011, the numbers were slightly up.

title: Keeper Scores Goal to Upstage Donovans Encore
description: It was supposed to be Landon Donovan doing the headlining on his return to the English Premier League on Wednesday, but clearly Tim Howard did not get the memo.

title: Facebook Aside, Market for I.P.O.s Stays Cool
description: It will take more than Facebook to heat up the tepid market for initial public offerings.

title: Factory Orders Increase 1.8%
description: Orders to American factories rose in November by the most in four months, showing that gains in manufacturing will help the economy grow.

title: Hailing the Wrong Taxi
description: WHEELCHAIR users have long been deprived of a quintessential New York City experience: riding in a taxi. So after years of discussion, litigation and experimentation, the governor and the mayor of New York last month announced a deal to put 2,000 wheelchair-accessible cabs on the streets, setting aside up to $54 million in subsidies and loans to retrofit vehicles for wheelchair use or buy new wheelchair-accessible vehicles.

title: Basketball Is Reborn at an Old Bronx Gym
description: Opulent sunlight filtered through the windows at one end of Rose Hill Gym in the Bronx on Wednesday, a fitting picture after one of the brightest moments the Fordham mens basketball team had experienced in decades.

title: Iowas Republicans, Divided by Gym Partitions and Conservative Ideologies
description: ALTOONA, Iowa

title: In New Strategy, Panetta Plans Even Smaller Army
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has concluded that the Army has to shrink even below current targets, dropping to 490,000 soldiers over the next decade, but that the United States should not cut any of its 11 aircraft carriers, according to Pentagon officials and military analysts briefed on the secretarys budget proposals.

title: On Stage, an Awkward Reminder of Personal Rifts in G.O.P.
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Everybody went by the script during a highly choreographed endorsement Wednesday at a school gymnasium here. Mitt Romney called Senator John McCain a hero and a great friend. In supporting his once-bitter rival for president, Mr. McCain called on Joe Louis for inspiration and said that President Obama can run from Mr. Romney, but he cant hide.

title: At Delhi Auto Expo, Upscale is the New Cheap
description: Just a few years ago, the buzz word in the Indian auto world was cheap.

title: Brooklyn Legislator Pleads Not Guilty in Latest Bribery Case
description: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., a Brooklyn Democrat who was indicted on charges of soliciting and accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from undercover federal agents, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday before a federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: Lobbyist Pleads Guilty to Paying Bribes to a State Senator
description: Over three decades, Richard J. Lipsky built a reputation as a staunch lobbyist for the underdog, even though his side did not always win and his clients were sometimes more establishment than mom-and-pop.

title: With the Wind at His Back, Santorum Flies Into New Hampshire
description: BRENTWOOD, N.H.  Rick Santorum flew into New Hampshire late Wednesday afternoon with a tailwind of fresh momentum following his unexpectedly strong challenge to Mitt Romney in the Iowa caucuses.

title: After a Red-Eye, Gingrich Reloads
description: LACONIA, N.H.  As Newt Gingrich stepped into the Barley House pub opposite the State Capitol to meet Republican lawmakers on Wednesday, a protester held a blowup of a famous cartoon portraying him in diapers as a crybaby.

title: Talking With the Taliban
description: The Talibans announcement that they plan to open an office in Qatar and possibly begin peace negotiations deserves a close look and a full draught of skepticism.

title: Romney Takes a Victory Lap as Santorum Plays Catch-Up
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney flew here Wednesday, displaying his financial and organizational muscle in New Hampshire against the upstart candidacy of Rick Santorum, who was seeking to use his near-victory in the Iowa caucuses to become the standard-bearer of a conservative insurgency.

title: A Bit of a Balancing Act for Republicans Critical of Paul
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Republicans who were alarmed by the strong performance of Representative Ron Paul in Tuesdays Iowa caucuses must tread carefully as they deal with his rise: he has legions of supporters and could mount an independent bid should be fail to get the partys nomination.

title: Mr. Cuomos New Year
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo spent a good part of his State of the State address congratulating himself and lawmakers for ending the dysfunction of state government. He made real progress, but Albany still has a long way to go.

title: Oil Price Would Skyrocket if Iran Closed the Strait of Hormuz
description: HOUSTON  If Iran were to follow through with its threat to blockade the Strait of Hormuz, a vital transit route for almost one-fifth of the oil traded globally, the impact would be immediate: Energy analysts say the price of oil would start to soar and could rise 50 percent or more within days.

title: After a Childs Death, a Religious Politician Became a Cultural Warrior
description: WASHINGTON  As a teenager growing up in Butler, Pa., Rick Santorum spent Sunday mornings as an altar boy, taking wheelchair-bound veterans to Roman Catholic Mass. In the ninth grade, he announced his intention to hold elective office. Im going to be governor of Pennsylvania, he declared, according to his brother Dan.

title: Quiet Excellence of Saints Colston
description: With all the late-season record chasing by Drew Brees, Darren Sproles, Jimmy Graham and the Saints offense as a whole, wide receiver Marques Colston remained under the radar, as usual. But when Colston, the quiet Hofstra alumnus, passed 1,000 yards receiving for the season Sunday against Carolina, it was the fifth time in his six years that he had accomplished the feat.

title: A Convention Center at Aqueduct Is Urged
description: One of Manhattans most desirable real-estate assets was at the center of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos proposal Wednesday to build the countrys largest convention center at a racetrack-casino in Queens.

title: Defense Had Big Role in Rise of the Broncos
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  Despite what fan adulation and ceaseless television chatter indicated, the 52-year-old N.F.L. team at the eastern base of the Rockies did not change its name to Tim Tebow and the Denver Broncos this season.

title: U.S. Announces Proposals to Clean Gowanus Canal
description: The toxic cocktail that is the Gowanus Canal took a century to mix. Now plans for the federal government to transform it in 10 years from an environmental blight into a healthy urban waterway are taking shape amid optimism from neighbors and frustration from City Hall.

title: Crackup at Radio City
description: Will the party from the psychiatric wing of New York University Hospital please come to the front desk?

title: Lottery Numbers
Giants Go From Facing Rex Ryan to Rob Ryan to Matt Ryan
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  By the end of the day Sunday, the Giants will have faced a number of notable opponents on their quest for a Super Bowl: the New England Patriots, the San Francisco 49ers, the New Orleans Saints, the Green Bay Packers and three guys named Ryan.

title: Night in a Baghdad E.R.
description: Now that the United States military has left Iraq, the long-term legacy of two decades of war and sanctions will become clearer over the coming months and years. Not only through violence, but also in the emergence  or otherwise  of civil institutions and their ability to provide basic services. Here, one Iraqi doctor writes about how her hospital is coping.

title: Devices to Keep Track of Calories, Lost or Gained
description: When it comes to New Years resolutions, year after year the No. 1 spot is most likely occupied by lose weight. Its persistence probably has something to do with the fact that most people have trouble actually succeeding.

title: Olbermann in a Clash at New Job
description: The broadcaster Keith Olbermann is famous for estranging himself from his bosses, be it at ESPN, Fox or MSNBC.

title: Sorting Out an Avalanche of iPad Apps for the Best of 2011
description: Like owners of iPhones and Androids, users of iPads faced a surge of new apps last year, to the point where it was easy to miss great ones. Heres my list of 10 favorites from 2011, along with a few runners-up. Note: as with 2010s Top 10, seasonal sensations like MLB.coms At Bat arent included, nor are games, which Ill cover separately online.

title: Role of Monitors in Syria Comes Under Scrutiny
description: The Qatari foreign minister, Sheik Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani, consulted on Wednesday with Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, about enhancing the performance of the Arab League monitors in Syria. The monitors have tried their best, Sheik Hamad said, but they lack any previous experience, so could benefit from United Nations technical help. The protocol that Syria signed with the Arab League demands that the government, not the monitors, halt the violence, the minister said, so forging a regional solution and avoiding a referral to the Security Council requires that Syria respect that agreement.

title: The Consumer Bureau Gets a Chief
description: Nearly six months after it opened its doors, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau finally has a director, after President Obamas recess appointment of Richard Cordray, a former attorney general of Ohio who served as the bureaus chief of enforcement.

title: From Dreams of Reality-Show Stardom to Accusations of Tough-Guy Extortion
description: The alleged Genovese crime associate was the owner of one of Staten Islands most popular catering halls, and he came to believe that his life had the makings of a reality television drama. He produced slick promotional videos for the show that he conceived and hoped to star in, Banquet Boyz, and posted them on YouTube.

title: How a Retired Officer, Trying to Stop a Robber, Shot an Agent Doing the Same
description: A woman ran into the deli screaming that a pharmacy three doors down was being robbed. The deli owner, a retired Nassau County police lieutenant, took off running, as did a customer, a young off-duty New York City police officer. Both had guns.

title: The March of the Non-Mitts
description: PETERBOROUGH, N.H.

title: Walker Returns to Garden, Site of Big East Glory
description: When Kemba Walker was last in Madison Square Garden, he was the best player on a Connecticut team that was beginning a roll that would carry it to the N.C.A.A. championship.

title: Thursday: Shells of Shells
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Most people who get into crossword puzzle constructing start out with an early-week, simply-themed grid. Once in a while, however, we see someone debut with a theme thats slightly trickier or a bit more clever, and thats just what we have today.

title: Internet Access Is Not a Human Right
description: Reston, Va.

title: Productive and Popular, but Facing a Challenge in Remaining So
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo knows he is bound to come back to earth.

title: Road Work Ahead, Forever
description: Wilfredo Torres spotted the pothole ahead of him. He knew that if he swerved, he would veer into the next lane and cause an accident. If he slowed, he would probably be rammed from behind by a tractor-trailer.

title: Covering America the Beautiful
description: Mitt Romney has done a swell job memorizing the words to America the Beautiful. Especially since that awkward afternoon in 2008 when he had trouble reminding a houseful of Iowans about our beautiful land and our mountains and  and  and our waving, or, uh, what is it, lets see, waving filled  no, how does it  and uh  amber waves of grain!

title: Appointment Clears the Way for Consumer Agency to Act
description: WASHINGTON  Payday lenders, money transfer agencies, credit bureaus and debt collectors, take notice: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is coming after you, and quickly.

title: Charges Against Journalists Dim the Democratic Glow in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A year ago, the journalist Nedim Sener was investigating a murky terrorist network that prosecutors maintain was plotting to overthrow Turkeys Muslim-inspired government. Today, Mr. Sener stands accused of being part of that plot, jailed in what human rights groups call a political purge of the governing partys critics.

title: Stoudemire and Shumpert Return, but Knicks Still Fall
description: On a night of reunions, returns and letdowns at Madison Square Garden, the emotions jerked from elation to anxiety to anger on Wednesday.

description: LOS ANGELES  Many a company has tried to burnish its image by basking in the Sundance Film Festivals cultural heat. Will it work for Yahoo?

description: The reassuring thing about Mitt Romney is that for most of his life he probably wouldnt have voted for todays Mitt Romney.

title: Prosecutor in Brooklyn Investigates Hospital
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office has been looking into management practices at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center, a money-losing hospital serving mostly poor patients, several hospital trustees said Wednesday.

title: Texas Prisoner Burials Are a Gentle Touch in a Punitive System
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  Kenneth Wayne Davis died at 54 as not so much a man but a number: Inmate No. 327320.

title: The Rites of a Prison Cemetery
description: In a state known for being tough on criminals, a cemetery has been a little-known counterpoint to the mythology of the Texas penal system.

title: Harder for Americans to Rise From Lower Rungs
description: WASHINGTON  Benjamin Franklin did it. Henry Ford did it. And American life is built on the faith that others can do it, too: rise from humble origins to economic heights. Movin on up, George Jefferson-style, is not only a sitcom song but a civil religion.

title: Egypt Leaders Credibility Stumbles on His Words
description: CAIRO  To those Egyptians eager to fulfill their revolutions promise of democracy, Prime Minister Kamal el-Ganzouri asks: What is the rush?

title: Right to Work Republicans Deprived of a Quorum in Indiana
description: CHICAGO  On what was to be the first day of a new lawmaking session in Indiana, most Democratic state representatives stayed away from the House floor on Wednesday, preventing the Republican majority, which has made right to work legislation a top priority, from doing business.

title: Depleted Nets No Match Against Celtics
description: BOSTON  On at least two occasions before Wednesday nights game against the Celtics, Coach Avery Johnson flatly stated that the Nets were, in fact, a real N.B.A. team composed of real, live N.B.A. players. He even sounded as if he believed it.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared
description: How the auto industry, automakers and the most popular cars and trucks fared in December.

title: Charles W. Bailey, Journalist and Political Novelist, Dies at 82
description: Charles W. Bailey, who edited The Minneapolis Tribune for most of the 1970s, when it was among the most polished of the nations midsize daily newspapers, after earlier winning renown as a co-author of the best-selling cold war novel Seven Days in May, died on Tuesday in Englewood, N.J. He was 82.

title: Methods in a Cat-Litter Ad Dont Pass a Judges Smell Test
description: In a television commercial for Fresh Step cat litter, two laboratory beakers sit side by side and swirl with a green mist, which represents a particular, acrid odor. It is a sanitized dramatization of an indelicate topic: cat droppings.

title: Perry, Perry, Quite Contrary
description: Youre not going to lose a lot of bets by inferring that a candidate who says he is suspending his campaign is in fact about to drop out. But Rick Perrys reconsideration of his role in the Republican nomination race appears to have been genuine and he is pressing forward for the time being.

title: Explosions Across Iraq Kill Dozens Amid Political Crisis
description: BAGHDAD  Insurgents unleashed a fierce string of bombings against Iraqs Shiites on Thursday, attacking pilgrims marching through the desert and neighborhoods in Baghdad, in an attempt to stir sectarian violence. The attacks come amid a political crisis that has brought the government to a halt less than three weeks after American troops withdrew.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 5, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: 15 Kidnapped Pakistani Soldiers Executed by the Taliban in a Retaliatory Gesture
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Taliban insurgents executed 15 security soldiers who had been recently kidnapped and dumped their bodies on a hilltop in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, in retaliation for the killing of a militant commander by government forces, government and military officials said.

title: Jan. 5, 1914 | Henry Ford Implements the $5-a-Day Wage
description: On Jan. 5, 1914, Henry Ford, head of the Ford Motor Company, introduced a minimum wage scale of $5 per day, more than doubling the wages for most employees. He also offered profit sharing to employees who lived a clean lifestyle, reduced the daily workers shift to eight hours from nine and declared that no employee would be discharged except for proved unfaithfulness or irremediable inefficiency.

description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Los Angeles Police Arrest Suspect in Car Arsons.

description: Editors note: Were resurfacing this 2012 magazine article for Smarter Living so you can feel a little less guilty about skipping that yoga class.

title: On the Trail of an Intercontinental Killer
description: A little after 9 a.m. on Sept. 15, 1990, the owner of a steel-products company pulled up to her office in Vinegar Hill, near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and spotted a black garbage bag sitting on the sidewalk out front. She parked her car and went to move the bag when she noticed it leaking blood. The woman called 911. Within the hour, Ken Whelan, a homicide detective from the 84th Precinct, peered into the bag. It was full of human body parts.

title: Sculpting a Photograph With Light
description: For more than 20 years, the fine art photographer Harold Ross has been making images using a technique known as painting with light, which involves casting light on and around subjects in the dark during a time exposure. Mr. Ross, who also does commercial and studio photography, prefers to call the process sculpting with light. Using a Phase One Back on a Hassleblad for still life photographs and a Cambo Wide RS for landscapes, he spends hours creating his images, which look like oil paintings,rich in color and depth.

title: Ron Paul and the Banks
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Do Your Teachers Use Technology Well?
description: The Times is running a series of articlesabout the ways in which technology is changing the American classroom. Many teachers are now incorporating digital tools into their lessons, via interactive whiteboards, social media, class blogs and wikis, devices like cellphones or video cameras, or programs on computers or tablets.

title: Fiat Increases Stake in Chrysler
description: The Italian automaker Fiat agreed on Thursday to increase its stake in Chrysler to 58.5 percent from 53.5 percent.

title: Former Israeli Premier Is Indicted on Bribery Charge
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Olmert, who resigned as prime minister of Israel in 2008 amid corruption charges, was indicted Thursday and charged with taking bribes in the construction of a huge residential complex while he was the mayor of Jerusalem.

title: Tom Brady Isnt Broken Up Over Jets Fall
description: Tom Brady, who once said that he hated the Jets, is having happier thoughts about them these days.

title: JustShareIt Enters Suddenly Crowded, and Wary, Car-Sharing Market
description: Peer-to-peer car-sharing services, which allow owners to rent their vehicles directly to other drivers, scored some notable successes in 2011, as well as some embarrassing failures. A new service is counting on a robust security apparatus and the variety of vehicles, not just cars, that it offers to distinguish it in this crowded start-up segment.

description: Once winter arrives in full force, with wind whipping down the Bosporus from the Black Sea, and the snow flurries gathering atop minarets, Turks start to take refuge in seasonal drinks like sweet sahlep, or hearty boza, to help them fortify against the elements.

title: Pork and Apples
description: It is a classic  really killer  combination, but one most people dont play around with much. Once I started to think about it, though, the possibilities for pork and apples seemed myriad: obviously, you can cook chops and chunks in a cast-iron skillet, maybe with a little bacon and onions . . . an easy vision. Bacon-wrapped apples, skewered and roasted or broiled (or grilled, for you warm-climate people) is another. A B.C.A.  bacon, cheese (soft, mild, brie-ish cheese, especially) and apple  is a fine sandwich, especially when cooked as you would a grilled cheese.

title: Defined by a Smile and a Drawl
description: IN the premiere of the new season of Justified, beginning Jan. 17, a dashing psychopath makes a casual reference to this Kentucky crime dramas signature prop, the Stetson worn by the protagonist, United States Marshal Raylan Givens.

description: Aaron Schwartz founded his three-person watch company last year with an unusual slogan: Were not craftsmen, were just good listeners  listeners to customers, that is.

description: Last year, Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry,avoided a showdown with a Canadian mutual fund operator at its annual meeting by agreeing to study the relationship between its management and its directors. Like other investors, Northwest and Ethical Investments  was concerned that James L. Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, RIMs co-chief executives, also serve as co-chairmen.

title: Rules May Help Parolees Avoid Jail for Small Errors
description: Brendan Cochrane had been, by and large, a model parolee. After serving 10 years for attempted murder, he started a video production business, moved into an apartment in Manhattan, got engaged and abstained from drugs and alcohol.

description: Within days of going on sale online, the 2,500 rupee (about $47) Aakash computer appears to be sold out, according to the tablets official Web site.

title: For Seal Pups on Thin Ice, a Short Childhood
description: For a mother harp seal, timing is everything. Pups are born and nursed on seasonal sea ice during a brief window before the spring sun melts the ephemeral nursery. After only 12 days, the mother weans her pups and the family slides into the ocean together.

title: Does McCains Endorsement Really Help Romney?
