description: To the Editor:

title: How Options Are Taxed
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanctions on Iran, and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man Has Never Lost an Election, and Bowing Out Now Is Not an Option
description: No phrase sums up Rick Perrys political DNA better than this one: He has never lost an election. Yet after an awful fifth-place showing in Iowa and top aides telling him he should consider pulling out of the presidential race, the specter of a first defeat has come into focus.

title: Mayo Clinics Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: One Thing Hasnt Changed: Banks Have the Money
description: A year ago, the New York Police Department pulled its six detectives from the Joint Bank Robbery Task Force, the combined F.B.I./Police Department unit that for more than 30 years had handled armed bank robberies in the city.

title: Boston Globe Endorses Huntsman
description: NEWPORT, N.H.  The Boston Globe has endorsed Jon M. Huntsman Jr. for the Republican nomination, the candidate announced Thursday night at a rally at a high school here.

title: Karzai Calls for Coalition to Cede Control of Afghan Prisoners
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai abruptly demanded on Thursday that the American-led coalition hand over all Afghan prisoners in its custody and cede control of its main prison in Afghanistan within a month. He said that his government had evidence that Afghan law and prisoners human rights were being violated at the prison.

title: More of States Species May Be Endangered
description: BASTROP  Near a glade of blackened pines, a Ph.D. student at Texas State University used microchip technology to search for an endangered Houston toad. Her device beeped as she held it over a carpet of pine needles, and after a bit of digging, a live toad emerged, half-buried in dirt.

title: Perrys Political Obituary Has Not Yet Been Written
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: For One Goalkeeper, a Moment of Shame
description: A lot of people who have tried to play goalkeeper in soccer have come to know the sinking feeling of allowing a long-distance goal. Im one of them.

title: Parting Glance: Eve Arnold
description: She was the first woman to become a full member of the storied Magnum Photos cooperative  not quite a feminist, but someone who believed that women saw the world through a different lens. Petite but powerful, she will be remembered for her generous spirit and her compassionate eye.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Iran Responds With Anger to Proposals by Europe
description: Iranian officials struck a defiant posture on Thursday in response to a proposed oil embargo by the European Union, calling the intensified efforts to halt Irans nuclear program, including new sanctions by United States, tantamount to an economic war.

title: Where to Go in 2012
description: From Myanmar to Panama to Finland, some ideas on where to go this year.

title: Benefits of Good Teachers
description: A new study found that students who had elementary- and middle-school teachers who helped raise their standardized-test scores were affected positively later in life.

title: Is It a Conflict of Interest? Yes, but Its Legal
description: In most states and municipalities, government officials who vote to spend taxpayer dollars on proposals that also put money in their own pockets as lobbyists could be accused of illegal conflicts of interest. Not in Illinois.

title: Fisher Begins Talks With the Rams
description: Jeff Fisher is interviewing for the St. Louis Rams coaching job after previously meeting with the Dolphins. The team said that initial interviews were taking place in Denver, with the owner Stan Kroenke an active participant. Kroenkes family also owns the Denver Nuggets and the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Nook From Barnes & Noble Gains More E-Book Readers
description: When the iPad hit the market, some predicted that it would wipe out e-reader devices like the Amazon Kindle.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,846 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Private Chens Family Learns More About Hazing by Fellow G.I.s
description: The officers in command of the battalion of Pvt. Danny Chen, who the Army says committed suicide in Afghanistan in October after being hazed by fellow soldiers, were aware of the harsh treatment he had repeatedly received, his family said Thursday.

title: Indiana: Absent Democrats Hold Up House Session
description: Refusing to appear on the State House floor, Democrats prevented the start of a scheduled lawmaking session for a second day in a row on Thursday, as pressure over right to work legislation mounted in Indianapolis. Republicans say a law prohibiting union contracts at private-sector workplaces from requiring workers to pay union dues or other fees would attract businesses to the state, while Democrats say the measure would weaken unions and harm benefits for workers. Scores of labor union members and supporters chanted Kill the bill! outside the State House chamber as Republican leaders twice on Thursday tried to call lawmakers to order only to find that too few Democrats were present; at least seven of them needed to appear to meet a quorum requirement.

title: Private Equity Firm Sees a Future in Flatware
description: ONEIDA, N.Y.  Some local residents, when eating out, instinctively turn their utensils upside-down to look for a telltale sign: the word Oneida, stamped into the back of the handle.

title: After Santorum Left Senate, Familiar Hands Reached Out
description: In the years before he lost his Pennsylvania Senate seat in 2006, Rick Santorum worked hard to win hundreds of millions of dollars in additional Medicare money for hospitals in Puerto Rico.

title: Students Jeer Santorum on New Hampshire Blitz
description: CONCORD, N.H.  As Rick Santorum sprinted Thursday through New Hampshire, a state with fewer social conservatives than Iowa, his views on social issues like same-sex marriage were quickly challenged.

title: Californians Are Asked for $6.9 Billion in New Taxes
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown called on California voters Thursday to approve $6.9 billion in temporary new taxes, including a surcharge on big earners, as part of yet another bad-news budget proposal, this one for 2012. He warned that without those tax increases, California would be forced to impose severe cuts in public schools that could reduce the school year by three weeks.

title: Romney Facing Risks Left and Right
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney casts himself as the guardian of American opportunity, who would stop President Obamas attempt to replace our merit-based society with an entitlement society.

title: Recent Fights in Congress Could Be Just Warm-Ups
description: WASHINGTON  Remember the first session of the 112th Congress, how things were rancorous, partisan and at times somewhat apocalyptic?

title: Stadium Video Screens Offer Football Players a Live Advantage
description: There has been constant advancement in football equipment over the years, from lighter shoulder pads to safer helmets. Shoes can be custom-designed to fit a players cleat preference. Undergarments wick away sweat while still keeping the player warm.

title: Migrants New Paths Reshaping Latin America
description: SANTA MARA ATZOMPA, Mexico  When the old-timers here look around their town, all they see are new arrivals: young Mexican men working construction and driving down wages; the children of laborers flooding crowded schools; even new businesses  stores, restaurants and strip clubs  springing up on roads that used to be dark and quiet.

title: Joan of Arc: Enduring Power
description: JOAN OF ARC was born 600 years ago. Six centuries is a long time to continue to mark the birth of a girl who, according to her family and friends, knew little more than spinning and watching over her fathers flocks. But type her name into Amazons search engine and you get more than 6,000 results. Frances national archives include tens of thousands of volumes about her. She has been immortalized by Shakespeare, Voltaire, Twain, Shaw, Brecht, Verdi, Tchaikovsky and Rubens; more recently, her life was fodder for the CBS television series Joan of Arcadia.

title: San Diego
description: With breweries and brewpubs, a sunny heaven for suds lovers.

title: New Charges Possible in Insider Case Against Gupta
description: Federal prosecutors said Thursday that they were likely to file a new indictment against Rajat K. Gupta, possibly adding new criminal charges in the insider trading case against the former head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company.

title: Newts Shop of Horrors
description: There must be a Greek tragedy, a Shakespeare play or a Daily Show parody to explain the exquisite irony of Newt Gingrich being destroyed by the very forces he unleashed  a smack-down that sets up 2012 as the year the moneyed elite learn to use the limitless power granted them by the Supreme Court.

title: Obama Takes Aim at Congress to Hurt His G.O.P. Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  Just three hours after President Obama announced that he was defying Congressional Republicans to fill a high-level regulatory position while lawmakers were out of town, Mitt Romney sent out the obligatory news release ripping the president. Chicago-style politics at its worst, Mr. Romney fumed, accusing the president of circumventing Congress.

title: From Soccer to Lacrosse, Goalkeepers Get In on the Act
description: The ball, kicked routinely by the goalkeeper for the Everton soccer team, soared through the night sky at Goodison Park in Liverpool, England, bounced once  and weirdly  and landed in the oppositions net. From roughly 100 yards, a goalkeeper had scored a goal. In a soccer game. In one of the worlds best professional leagues.

title: Top 1% of Mobile Users Consume Half of Worlds Bandwidth, and Gap Is Growing
description: The worlds congested mobile airwaves are being divided in a lopsided manner, with 1 percent of consumers generating half of all traffic. The top 10 percent of users, meanwhile, are consuming 90 percent of wireless bandwidth.

title: When Office Holders Also Represent Clients, Collisions Are Likely
description: Elected officials who lobby face conflicts of interest when matters coming before them as office holders also affect their paying clients.

title: Quinns Coffers Reach Goal for Mayoral Primary
description: Twenty-two months before New York City chooses its next mayor, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democrat, has become the first candidate to surpass a key threshold: She has raised all the money she is allowed to spend in the primary under the citys public financing system.

title: Games and Gimmicks in the Senate
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Voters Without a Party Splinter New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  For Emily Renfer, a 21-year-old college student from Nashua, voting is like a triple bank shot.

title: In Act of Defiance, Democrat Stalls Obama Choice for Court
description: When a Democratic president nominates a federal judge from a state with two Democratic senators  and the Senate itself is controlled by Democrats  a speedy confirmation hearing typically follows.

title: Knicks Defense in a Word: Offensive
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Bullying Not Yet Ruled Out in a Suicide
description: The police said on Thursday that they were still investigating whether bullying played any role in a Staten Island girls suicide.

title: Penn State Is Said to Hire Patriots Assistant
description: Bill OBrien, the New England Patriots offensive coordinator, has agreed in principle to become the new Penn State coach, according to multiple news media outlets.

title: An Automaker Promotes Its Tagline to Its Slogan
description: BMW of North America will introduce its new brand advertising on Saturday, reinforcing its image as the ultimate driving machine as it introduces 14 new models in the United States this year.

title: Holding a Spot for Stigma in the Citys Food Stamp Lines
description: Angela Sesma sped down a flight of stairs two steps at a time, then made a quick left out the front door of a city office building, onto Jerome Avenue in the Bronx. It was nearly 12:30 Thursday afternoon, and Ms. Sesma had been shifting from line to seat since 9 in the morning to straighten out a problem with her food stamps. She had to get to work. She also had her child to attend to. So she was in a hurry.

title: Washington Outpost Draws Those Hungry for Slap of Sea Spray
description: MAKAH INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash.  There are more remote outposts in America than this one. There are places where the wind can be more brutal, the rain more relentless and the sea, maybe, mightier. There are points farther from major airports and Interstates, places that have changed even less than this one has over the millennia since people somehow first found it.

title: Raising Her 3 Children, While Coping With Seizures
description: When Keyanna Rice goes to bed every night, she does not know if she will wake up the next day disoriented, incapacitated or in excruciating pain. Ms. Rice is afflicted by grand mal seizures, violent muscle contractions, and has been dealing with them since she was 8.

title: Bain, Barack and Jobs
description: Americas recovery from recession has been so slow that it mostly doesnt seem like a recovery at all, especially on the jobs front. So, in a better world, President Obama would face a challenger offering a serious critique of his job-creation policies, and proposing a serious alternative.

title: In New Control Over Diamonds, Smugglers Pay in Mozambique
description: ESPUNGABERA, Mozambique  The last time Mike Phiri was on his hands and knees, clawing through the rough rock of the diamond fields just across the border in Zimbabwe, he dared a soldier to shoot him.

title: Massachusetts Health Plan Extended to Immigrants
description: BOSTON  Massachusetts cannot bar legal immigrants from a state health care program, according to a ruling issued Thursday by the states highest court, a decision that edges the state closer to its goal of providing near-universal health care coverage to its residents.

title: Lawsuit Is Latest Clash Over Giving Retired Transit Workers Free Rides
description: It is a longstanding arrangement for the men and women who work on New York Citys transportation system: devote decades of work and labor to the upkeep of bridges, roads and railways, and receive a lifetime of free rides in return.

title: A New Social Agenda
description: Im to Rick Santorums left on most social issues, like same-sex marriage and abortion. Im also put off by his Manichaean political rhetoric. He seems to imagine Americas problems can best be described as the result of a culture war between the God-fearing conservatives and the narcissistic liberals.

title: A Leaner Pentagon
description: With his new defense strategy, President Obama has put forward a generally pragmatic vision of how this country will organize and deploy its military in the 21st century, while also addressing its deep fiscal problems.

title: Curiosities Abound in the Playoffs First Round
description: The most extraordinary thing about the N.F.L.s first-round playoff games this year is that the presence of the Detroit Lions is not one of the most extraordinary things.

title: Doofy? Casper? Scarface Would Cringe
description: They had nicknames that seemed more at home at a cartoon theme park: there was Doofy and Casper, Sonic and Lobo.

title: Friday: Place For a Plug
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Is David Steinberg trying to hit for the cycle at his young age?

title: In a Second Career, Working to Make a Difference
description: At the Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change, a public school on West 135th Street in Harlem, every one of the 82 members of the senior class is expected to apply to college. At a suburban or private school, or at a wealthier city school, these seniors would have all the help they need. They would have been raised in families where going to college is a given. They would have advisers who know about a wide range of colleges and have contacts in admissions offices. They would take test-prep courses and rewrite their personal essays numerous times with the help of a savvy editor. They would have a list of deadlines to meet and be constantly pushed to meet them by parents and school advisers.

title: MF Global Inquiry Turns  to Its Primary Regulator
description: Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have expanded their inquiry to include the actions of the CME Group, the operator of the main exchange where the commodities brokerage firm conducted business, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: A Coal-Fired Plant That Is Eager for U.S. Rules
description: BALTIMORE  As operators of coal-fired power plants around the country welcome a court-ordered delay on tighter pollution rules, the owner of a retrofitted plant here says that the rules cannot come too soon.

title: Dakhla, Morocco
description: In Moroccos south, an arty hideaway.

title: A Young Kennedy Considers a Campaign
description: BOSTON  It seems increasingly likely that a Kennedy will once again jump into Massachusetts politics.

title: Judicial Ethics and the Supreme Court
description: Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. tried to address growing concerns about ethical behavior and conflicts of interest on the Supreme Court in his annual  report on the federal judiciary. But he skirted the heart of the problem: the justices are the only American judges not bound by a code of ethics.

title: Abraham Lincolns Audacious Plan
description: Abraham Lincoln is remembered by some as a thoughtful, often cautious leader. But in late 1861 he began to develop a plan that, even during that most unusual of times, was audacious in the extreme: the federal government would buy out Delawares entire slave population.

title: Donors, Secrecy and That Loophole
description: The Federal Election Commission ended another abysmal year with its three Republican commissioners blocking an attempt to unmask the secret donors flooding the 2012 hustings with unlimited special-interest money.

title: Eve Arnold, a Photographer of Bold and Illuminating Images, Dies at 99
description: Eve Arnold, who fell in love with photography after a boyfriend gave her a camera and who came to be regarded as a grande dame of postwar photojournalism for her bold, revealing images of subjects as diverse as Marilyn Monroe and migratory potato pickers, died on Wednesday in London. She was 99.

title: The New Universal Language of Plants
description: When Linnaeus standardized the system of species description in the 18th century, Latin was the language of science. So it has remained, if only in a highly technical sense. The binomial names used by Homo sapiens are Latin, and for years botanists, unlike zoologists, were still required to use a page or two of Latin to describe the distinctive characteristics of a newly named species  the attributes that made it different from any other. But no more. As of Jan. 1, diagnostic botanical descriptions may be written in Latin or English, and the electronic publication of new names is accepted.

title: Paraty, Brazil
description: Putting Brazils Costa Verde on the cultural map.

title: In Credit-Card-Number Case, Identity-Theft Victims Finally Get Some Respect
description: You would ditch your credit cards and just carry cash if you knew the tale of Annette Sandoval, April Hicks and Sean Vanderhack, all of Chicago.

title: Hundreds Tortured in Syria, Human Rights Group Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government said Thursday that it had released more than 500 prisoners who were not involved in terrorist acts. A human rights group said, meanwhile, that it had compiled evidence that thousands of other detainees were languishing in government prisons and secret detention centers where, the group said, torture was routine.

title: Rangers, Coming Off Winter Classic Win, Start Slowly but Win in Overtime
description: Shaking off the Winter Classic hangover, the Rangers beat the Florida Panthers, 3-2, on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden on a goal by Marian Gaborik at 3 minutes 29 seconds of overtime.

title: Foreign Money Swaying U.S. Voters?
Leaving the Citys Music Scene, but Staying, Too
description: In recent years, Nicole Mitchell, an enterprising jazz flutist, modernist composer and leader of several inventive ensembles, has been a celebratedsuccess story in Chicago music.

title: Study Says Looks Matter as TV Covers Congress
description: Maybe looks arent everything, but new research suggests that more physically attractive members of Congress get more coverage on network television.

title: Ex-Chief of Turkish Army Is Arrested in Widening Case Alleging Coup Plot
description: ISTANBUL  In an unprecedented move, a civilian court ordered the arrest of Turkeys former head of the army, the highest-ranking officer so far to be charged with leadership of an illegal network accused of seeking to overthrow the government, news outlets reported late Thursday.

title: Chilo Island, Chile
description: A new look for an island on the edge of South America.

title: Fear of a Serial Killer Sends the Homeless to Shelters in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Skittish even at the best of times, homeless people in Orange County have been running to shelters this week in search of a safe place to sleep after the separate stabbing deaths of three homeless men. The authorities believe there is a serial killer stalking the homeless.

title: Fillmore District Audit Shows Little Oversight
description: Emmit Powell hesitated when he was asked to talk about the City of San Francisco s efforts to promote his popular barbecue restaurant as the anchor of a showcase redevelopment project in the Fillmore district. The venture led to his financial ruin.

title: In Death as in Life, Knut the Polar Bear Demands Attention
description: BERLIN  Whether one bear needs three memorials in a single city is debatable. For Knut the polar bear, that unusual, some might be tempted to say excessive, distinction is on the verge of becoming a reality.

title: Lottery Numbers
Water From Yosemite Is Still Cheap, for Now
description: The going rent for a one-bedroom apartment in San Francisco is about $2,500 a month. Thats the same amount the city pays to use eight miles of Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park as a reservoir.

title: Accounts Emerge in South Sudan of 3,000 Deaths in Ethnic Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 3,000 villagers were massacred in the recent burst of communal violence in South Sudan, local officials said Thursday, with the fledging South Sudanese government, which just won its independence six months ago, seemingly unable to stem the bloodshed.

title: After Disastrous Year, Ballet Tries to Regain Balance
description: Like a dancer careening wildly to the edge of the stage, Ballet San Jose, one of the most respected arts institutions in Silicon Valley, was on the brink of chaos last year.

title: Unreported Cases of Food Poisoning Reflect a Gap in Food Supply Safety Net
description: The Mission Districts Italian eatery Delfina has been considered one of the Bay Areas best restaurants for more than a decade; Craig Stoll, its co-owner and chef, won a coveted James Beard award in 2008.

title: Corrections: January 6
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Mets Hire Financial Firm With Bankruptcy Savvy
description: The Mets said in a statement Thursday that they had hired CRG Partners, a firm known as a turnaround specialist and bankruptcy consultant, to provide services in connection with financial reporting and budgeting processes.

title: New York City Marathon to Be Shown Live Nationally
description: The New York City Marathon will be broadcast live and across the nation for the first time in nearly two decades, the most significant feature of a new television deal that is expected to be announced by New York Road Runners as soon as Friday.

title: Students of Online Schools Are Lagging
description: The number of students in virtual schools run by educational management organizations rose sharply last year, according to a new report being published Friday, and far fewer of them are proving proficient on standardized tests compared with their peers in other privately managed charter schools and in traditional public schools.

title: Big Study Links Good Teachers to Lasting Gain
description: WASHINGTON  Elementary- and middle-school teachers who help raise their students standardized-test scores seem to have a wide-ranging, lasting positive effect on those students lives beyond academics, including lower teenage-pregnancy rates and greater college matriculation and adult earnings, according to a new study that tracked 2.5 million students over 20 years.

title: Word of the Day | squabble
description: squabble \skw-bl\ noun and verb

title: Report Finds Most Errors at Hospitals Go Unreported
description: WASHINGTON  Hospital employees recognize and report only one out of seven errors, accidents and other events that harm Medicare patients while they are hospitalized, federal investigators say in a new report.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/06/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/06/2012

title: Tweak in Rule to Ease a Path to Green Card
description: Obama administration officials announced on Friday they are proposing a fix to a Catch-22 in immigration law that could spare hundreds of thousands of American citizens from prolonged separations from illegal immigrant spouses and children.

title: Britain: Government Will Review Murder Sentences
description: The government said Thursday that it would review the sentences imposed on two men convicted Tuesday in the 1993 murder of Stephen Lawrence, an 18-year-old black youth whose killing on a south London street, and the lapse of nearly two decades in bringing any of the white teenagers involved to justice, caused outrage across Britain. Judge Colman Treacey, who sentenced the two men on Wednesday to 15 and 14 years in prison, said that he was barred from imposing harsher sentences because the killers were juveniles at the time of the attack, and because tougher sentencing guidelines for racially aggravated crimes were introduced after the killing. The attorney general, Dominic Grieve, said he would consider whether the terms were too lenient and whether to appeal them.

title: William Duell, Puckish Character Actor, Dies at 88
description: William Duell, a diminutive character actor whose puckishness and understated comic flair enlivened Broadway shows, television series and Hollywood films, died at his home in Manhattan on Dec. 22. He was 88.

title: Republicans Campaign in New Hampshire and South Carolina
description: Mitt Romney campaigned with Senator John McCain and Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina on Thursday, while The Boston Globe endorsed Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

title: Gingrich Campaign Defends Remarks on Food Stamps
description: MEREDITH, N.H.  Newt Gingrichs campaign was pushed to defend remarks he made about food stamps that some bloggers and news Web sites interpreted as racially offensive.

title: Positively Newt
description: Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney have now established themselves as the id and the ego of the Republican Party. Romney represents the ultra-organized, overly measured and methodical aspect of the Republican establishment, while Gingrich is hyper-instinctual and visceral, the untrammeled raw impulses of the conservative movements emotional core incarnated. (For those of you keeping track at home, that makes Rick Santorum the partys demanding and moralizing super-ego and Ron Paul, perhaps, its super-id.)

title: A Final Flourish for the American Wing
description: Several curators narrate an interactive tour of the renovated second-floor galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: The Caucus | Independent Voices
description: Katharine Q. Seelye reports from New Hampshire on the role of independent voters in New Hampshire, who can participate in the Republican primary on Tuesday.

title: Whats R.A. Dickey Climbing For?
description: An American baseball player scaling an African mountain for an Indian charity might seem an odd way to draw attention to human trafficking.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 6, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Outside in Cold, Warm Memories
description: When the band Van Halen played in a cramped basement club in Greenwich Village on Thursday, a couple dozen fans clustered around the back door, listening to the slightly muffled strains of hard-rock songs like Panama and Hot for Teacher like children eavesdropping on an adult conversation in the next room.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 6, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The Year When Rock Just Spun Its Wheels.

title: Jan. 6, 1919 | Theodore Roosevelt Dies
description: On Jan. 6, 1919, Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, died in his sleep at his home in Oyster Bay, N.Y. He was60. The New York Times reported that, though Mr. Roosevelt had had inflammatory rheumatism, his death took by surprise his physicians. The immediate cause of death was listed as a clot of blood which detached itself from a vein and entered the lungs.

title: Pop Pioneers
description: WHO is Nicole May, and WHO are the Me N Ma Girls?

title: Striking on the Modern Matchbook
description: No one knows what exactly prompted Joshua Pusey, a lawyer and the inventor of the modern toboggan, to patent a folded piece of cardboard carrying matches and a striker in 1892. Though legend suggests it had more to do with vanity than with safety. I heard that he was a patent attorney and always wearing suits and vests, explains Mark Bean, president of the match division of New Hampshires D. D. Bean & Sons Company, which has been in the trade since 1938. And that the box of wooden matches was bulky and awkward to carry around.

title: Anonymous Tributes to Anonymous People
description: Around noon yesterday, the Twitter user @Twiiitooo took to a keyboard  most likely on a smartphone  and, as hed done 11 times already that morning, shared a thought with his more than 400 followers.

title: What Would Your Personal Mascot Be?
description: Mr. Met, the mascot for the New York Mets baseball team, is a popular team mascot and symbol. If a mascot were designed for you, what would it be, and why?

title: An Israeli in Iowa
description: DES MOINES, Iowa  On Tuesday, at 6:55 p.m. sharp, I come to the school gym that serves as Precinct 025 to meet Adam (Just call me Adam Adam), torchbearer of the Rick Perry for President campaign. Where are you from? he asks. Israel, I say. You mean the nation of Israel? Both the nation and the land but mostly the State of Israel. His candidate, Texas Governor Perry, keeps talking about how important it is to defend Israel, to stand with Israel. Adam will make his contribution to this important cause by defending the visiting Israeli journalist from whatever menace caucus night might hold.

title: Q&A: Improving Call Quality After a Skype Update
description: Q.

title: In Prague, Traditional Dumplings Take Over a Menu
description: Most Czechs cant live without their dumplings, or knedliky. The dish, which is akin to sliced bread, usually accompanies a pork or another meat entre and is a staple on almost all restaurant menus, or at least all the ones offering original Czech cuisine in Prague.

title: What Price Pluralism in Health Insurance?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Aakash: The View from the Ministry of Human Resource Development
description: India Ink, like many other publications, has been following the low-cost Aakash tablet with great interest. We asked the Ministry of Human Resource Development, led by Kapil Sibal, who has spearheaded the project, for his view of how it is going. The Ministrys full reply is below:

title: Daily Report: Barnes & Noble Considers Spinning Off Its Nook Unit
description: Barnes & Noble, the nations largest book chain, said on Thursday that it was considering spinning off its Nook e-reader division in an effort to help the nascent  and expensive  digital business grow, report Julie Bosman and Michael J. de La Merced in The New York Times.They write that while the company has made quick work of capturing almost 30 percent of the e-book market in two years, the rise of digital reading has increased the pressure on it to devise a winning long-term strategy against Amazon, which still dominates e-book sales.Sales of Nook devices for the nine-week holiday period ending Dec. 31 were up 70 percent over the same period a year earlier, Barnes & Noble said Thursday, while all Nook-related sales, including devices, accessories and digital content, were up 43 percent.Brian X. Chen, technology reporter for The Times, writes in an accompanying article that the Apple iPad has yet to wipe out the e-readers like the Nook, though that was the popular prediction. He also reports that I.H.S. iSuppli, a research company, estimates that Barnes & Noble has 13 percent of the e-reader market after two years in the business, versus 67 percent for Amazon.The Epicenter blog noted:

title: Criticism of Mark Sanchez and Bill Polian
description: A links roundup this morning in which people dont have much nice to say:

title: Iowan Casts Doubt on Winner of Caucus
description: 4:46 p.m. | Updated At just before 2 a.m. on Wednesday, Matt Strawn, the Iowa Republican Party chairman, addressed reporters who had spent the night following the historically close Republican caucus race between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum. The margin separating the candidates was small  eight votes  but he was prepared to declare a victor. Congratulations to Governor Mitt Romney, the winner of the 2012 Iowa caucuses, Mr. Strawn said.

title: Bomb Kills Dozens in Damascus, Stoking Suspicions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A bomb tore through a crowded neighborhood in Damascus on Friday, killing 26 people and wounding dozens more, unleashing scenes of chaos and underlining the growing confusion and complexity of the Syrian uprising, officials and residents said.

title: Paved, but Still Alive
description: THERE are said to be at least 105 million and maybe as many as 2 billion parking spaces in the United States.

title: Archbishop Dolan Is Named a Cardinal
description: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, who has led the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for nearly three years, will be named a cardinal by Pope Benedict XVI, the Vatican announced on Friday.

title: Portovenere, Italy
description: Stepping in while the Cinque Terre rebuilds.

title: Moganshan, China
description: Luxury in the former mountain hideaway of Shanghai gangsters.

title: Illegal Fishermen 4, Enforcement 0
description: Illegal fishing is a problem pretty much everywhere that regulations meet fish. As I noted in September, the United States government puts the global cost of illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing at up to $23 billion in lost income for legal fishermen and coastal communities. And thats before the larger environmental costs are considered.

title: An Arena Rock Preview, Minus the Arena
description: As news briefings go, it rocked. On Thursday night Van Halen took to the stage of the venerable Cafe Wha? on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village, capacity 250.

title: In Malacca, Malaysia, Vibrant Multiculturism
description: The city is becoming increasingly accessible as it welcomes a handful of hotels and millions of international visitors a year.

title: A Pakistani Spring?
description: KARACHI  While I was living in Washington on a research fellowship last year, Pakistanis often urged me to use the opportunity to promote Pakistans positive aspects to Americans. With the country steeped in ethnic and sectarian violence and regressing along the Human Development Index, this seemed like a challenge, and Id struggle to muster compelling examples.

title: Amazon Kindles: Easy Come, Easy Go
description: For a couple of months now, Amazon has practically begged you to buy a Kindle Fire. Maybe you did. And maybe you are insanely happy that you can now spend hours on the couch playing Angry Birds rather than reading some boring old book, which is all you could do on your old Kindle.

title: With Olympus Managers Still Entrenched, an Ousted Chief Drops His Sword
description: TOKYO  Michael C. Woodford had been an audacious challenger to the staid ways of corporate Japan: a British chief executive, fired after exposing extensive fraud at Olympus  one of Japans vaunted blue-chip companies  who took his evidence public and started a proxy fight to win back his job.

title: Spotlight Shines on Santorum, Rough Edges and All
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Two different Rick Santorums campaigned across this state on Thursday.

New Study Likely to Roil Teacher Value Debate

Jailed Ukrainian Leaders Husband Seeks Asylum in Czech Republic
description: MOSCOW  The Czech Republic granted political asylum on Friday to the husband of the jailed Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who said he sought refuge to prevent the authorities from putting pressure on her through her family.

description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MF Global Inquiry Turns to Its Primary Regulator | Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have expanded their inquiry to include the actions of the CME Group, the operator of the main exchange where the commodities brokerage firm conducted business, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: The Early Word: Strategy
description: In Todays Times:President Obamas recent agency appointments and his campaigns presence at the Iowa caucuses were two tactics in an aggressive re-election strategy aimed at tying his Republican rivals to the unpopular Congress, Helene Cooper reports.

title: U.S. Economy Gains Steam as 200,000 Jobs Are Added
description: Maybe it is time to start calling the glass half full.

title: Friday Reading: Good Teachers Have Big Impact Beyond Classroom
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Fill-In | Space Tourism
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in several paragraphs in this article from the Science section, Booking a Flight to Space, With Travel Insurance.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Spin Off the Nook to Save It? Ab/Fab and Van Halen Return
description: The Nook, the Barnes & Noble e-reader, has sold well and drawn praise from reviewers, but has yet to make a profit. It is a tricky situation, with investors anxious about the future costs tied to the product and the company convinced that investments of as much $200 million to $250 million a year will pay dividends, DealBook reports. The company is considering a way out by spinning off the Nook division.

title: Face Time | Patrick Wilson
description: I reached Patrick Wilson by phone as he was on his way to the set of his CBS series A Gifted Man, in which he appears as Dr. Michael Holt. Wilson is on camera a great deal, with a lot of close-ups, and of course the series is filmed in high definition so he and his makeup artist, Anita Gibson, pay close attention to his skincare regimen (especially since he has to shave daily). I got the whole grooming scoop for you gentlemen. And ladies, I think youll find something of interest here, too!

title: Anna Hazares Team Seeks Your Advice
description: As the dust fades after Parliaments heated debate over the anti-corruption Lokpal Bill many are examining what, exactly, the anti-corruption activist Anna Hazare contributed to Indias political landscape.

title: Bridesmaids Rolls Along, but Will It Roll Toward a Sequel Without Kristen Wiig?
description: On the heels of all sorts of statuette attention for Bridesmaids came word that its blockbuster success  it grossed $288 million worldwide  might not be repeated: Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo were not interested in writing a Bridesmaids 2.

title: How Do You Teach the Civil Rights Movement?
description: Updated | Jan. 27, 2012 Thank you to the many who wrote in. We have now sorted and compiled your answers in our post Reader Ideas | Teaching the Civil Rights Movement.

title: Clijsters May Be Out of Australian Open After Injury in Brisbane
description: Defending Australian Open champion Kim Clijsters took a significant hit in her bid to defend her title at Melbourne Park later this month after she was forced to retire from her semifinal match at the Brisbane International after suffering a left hip flexor injury.

title: Leading Off: Penn State Gets a Coach; the Badgers Get Another Year from Montee Ball
description: It will be a slightly less dismal day in Still Trying to Be Happy Valley on Saturday when Penn State gets to announce that someone wanted to be its new football coach. The introduction of Patriots offensive coordinator Bill OBrien will come with all the usual pronouncements of a bright future and a new start, but the overarching emotion will be relief. The sighs come because Penn States tortured search found someone willing to don protective gear and enter college footballs version of a SuperFund site.

title: Rethinking the Effects of Aerosols
description: When you hear the word aerosol, a can of hairspray, spray paint or whipped cream may come to mind.

title: New Yorks Next Cardinal
description: IT is not a good time for the Roman Catholic Church in America, but Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the cardinal-designate of New York, has made it his mission to remind people that there is more to the church than scandal. Taping his weekly radio show last month, he praised the beauty of a recent church service in Yonkers and recounted an emotional visit to the solitary confinement wing at Rikers Island.

title: Tolkien Snubbed by Nobel Prize Jury, Papers Reveal
description: J. R. R. Tolkien may have been the creator of one of the most popular fantasy series of the modern era, but nearly 40 years after his death the author of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings is still receiving some of the toughest reviews of his career. Tolkiens latest detractor, according to a report in a Swedish newspaper, is the jury for the 1961 Nobel Prize in literature, which dismissed him as a candidate for the honor, saying Tolkien wasnt up to snuff.

title: Art Directors Weigh in With Their Picks
description: All those fake books paid off for Hugo. It earned a nod from the Art Directors Guild, which announced its nominees for excellence in production design this week. The hopefuls are broken up into three categories: period, fantasy and contemporary film, and this year there was a lot of overlap with likely Oscar contenders.

title: Everyone Should Use the Overnight Test
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, The Behavior Gap, was published this week, and well be running excerpts all week long. Meanwhile, his sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

title: Caucus Video: Independent Voices
description: Katharine Q. Seelye reports from New Hampshire on the role of independent voters in New Hampshire, who can participate in the Republican primary on Tuesday.

title: Market Response Tepid To U.S. Labor Report
description: Stocks on Wall Street were mixed on Friday, showing little reaction to a generally positive report on the United States labor market for December.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: An almost 300-pound bluefin tuna was sold in Tokyo for $736,700.  Nick Fox

title: At Hopman, Americans Are Eliminated Early
description: PERTH, AustraliaThe fourth-seeded American contingent of Bethanie Mattek-Sands and highest-ranked American male Mardy Fish was the first team in Group A to be mathematically eliminated from qualifying for the final of the Hyundai Hopman Cup, winning only one match out of their first six to fall out of contention for the title.

title: Through the Cameras Eye in Halong Bay, Vietnam
description: A photojournalist on assignment gets the tourists perspective.

title: Citigroups Deal to Sell OneMain Collapses
description: Citigroups effort to sell a consumer-lending business has collapsed in recent days, as wobbly markets and a lackluster economy shut down hopes for a deal, a person with knowledge of the matter said.

title: Pressed by U.S., Asian Countries Look for Ways to Reduce Purchases of Iranian Oil
description: HONG KONG  Under growing pressure from the United States, some of Asias largest economies are reluctantly looking for options to reduce the amount of oil they buy from Iran, a move that would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.

title: Mother in Custody After Death of Girl, 2, in Brooklyn
description: 10:21 p.m. | Updated  Officers responding early Friday to a call of a jumper on the roof of a four-story building in Brooklyn found a blood trail leading down to Apartment 4A. The door was ajar, and when they walked in, the police said, the picture got even worse: A young mother was sitting on a couch in the living room, babbling and cradling her fatally wounded 2-year-old girl.

title: British Regulator Fines PWC $2.2 Million
description: LONDON  British authorities announced on Friday that they had fined the accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers 1.4 million, or $2.2 million, for failing to safeguard client assets at JPMorgan Chases securities business in London.

title: Koh Rong, Cambodia
description: A string of islands recalls an undiscovered Asian paradise.

title: The Worst Field Since
description: Dan McCarthy takes exception to my description of the 2012 Republican field as the worst in a generation:

title: Nick Denton, Relentless Seeker of Online Traffic, Turns Sentimental About Writing
description: Nick Denton, chief of Gawker Media, has been both praised and vilified for his relentless focus on user traffic in running Gawker, Deadspin, Jezebel, Lifehacker and other sites he owns. But in a year-in-review/preview message to his staff, Mr. Denton spends a fair amount of pixels on the pure virtues of well-turned narratives, traffic be damned. (He also opens with a quote from Steve Jobs, which seems surprisingly corporate and conventional, but Jobs-mania apparently has no bounds.)

title: Maybe It Should Be Called The Artists
description: LOS ANGELES  For all the bridesmaids in Bridesmaids, and all the housemaids in The Help, the most actor-packed film in the race for the ensemble cast award from the Screen Actors Guild on Jan. 29 might be the one about a supposedly solitary silent movie star  that is, The Artist.

title: The Saints Go Marching On
description: When Preservation Hall opened in 1961, its purpose was to save traditional jazz. It was probably a decade late.

title: Preservation Halls Legacy
description: Fifty years after Preservation Hall opened, the instruments and the repertory have barely altered. (Correction: An earlier version misspelled Mark Brauds surname as Brand.)

title: The End of Girl Land
description: My father was one of those charismatic professors who forever have a coterie of graduate students pressed around them. My mother was a nurse who left work to raise children. It was along these broad strokes of character that the general story of their marriage was understood: the absent-minded intellectual who never learned to drive and his capable wife who managed the practicalities of their lives. He was respected; she was loved.

title: Nothing Shocks Carrie Fisher
description: In your book Shockaholic, you write that youve been receiving electroconvulsive shock therapy to treat your chronic depression. I gather you had a treatment this morning. How do you feel?  Great. Theres no convulsions anymore. They shouldnt even really call it electroshock. Youre put to sleep, they give you a medication like the one Harrison Ford used in What Lies Beneath when he put his wife in the tub and she cant move a muscle.

title: These American Lives
description: Thank you for The Lives They Loved. Every photo and supporting sentence did what you asked, told a love story. It made me sad to know we did not get to see many other beautiful lives because of space constraints. Please expand this section in 2012.

title: A Dogs Right to Life?
description: I am a veterinarian, and one of my clients is an elderly woman who loves her 8-year-old Pomeranian dearly but has no family or friends who might inherit it. She wants me to sign a legal document stating that I will euthanize it if she dies before the dog does. What should I do? NAME WITHHELD, BOSTON

title: European Banks Stash Extra Cash With Central Bank
description: LONDON  Concerns about Europes debt crisis are prompting the Continents banks to safeguard money with the European Central Bank instead of lending capital to each other.

title: Hes Taking the Hood to the 1700s
description: WHY hasnt anyone done a hip-hop version of Alexander Hamiltons life? Lin-Manuel Miranda wondered aloud recently. Its a hip-hop story. Its Tupac.

title: End of the Line
description: In 2008, General Motors announced the closing of its metal-stamping plant in Wyoming, Mich., and 1,500 workers lost their jobs. Austin Bunn, a playwright and professor, chronicled the experience and what came after in a nonfiction play. Bunn, in collaboration with the Working Group Theater, spent two years trying to understand exactly what happened to the people and the town that relied on the factory. He recorded hundreds of hours of conversations with dozens of workers, managers, historians, bartenders, city consultants and others. Their words (edited and condensed for dramatic purposes) became the documentary play Rust, adapted here. (Some characters have had their names changed; one is a composite.) Rust had its premiere in Grand Rapids, Mich., in September.

title: An Asian-American Veteran Reflects on When Discipline Becomes Hazing
description: The deaths of Army Private Danny Chen and Marine Lance Corporal Harry Lew have sent shock waves through Asian-American communities. Eight U.S. Army service members have been charged with hazing-related crimes against Private Chen, a Chinese-American soldier and, like me, the son of Chinese immigrants.

title: Tobys Estate Bringing More Coffee to Williamsburg
description: In the last few years, the coffee scene in New York City has been something of a land rush, with some notable out-of-town companies setting up shop and teaching us a thing or two about how to roast, brew and correctly steam milk for a cappuccino. Some of them opened coffee shops (La Colombe Torrefaction, of Philadelphia; Gimme! Coffee, of Ithaca, N.Y.). Some opened training labs (Counter Culture Coffee, of Durham, N.C.; Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea, of Chicago), and some opened roasting facilities and coffee bars (Blue Bottle Coffee, of San Francisco and Oakland, Calif.; Stumptown Coffee Roasters, of Portland, Ore.).

title: Arsenal and Red Bulls Complete Henry Loan Deal
description: The Red Bulls of Major League Soccer announced Friday morning that they had completed the terms of an agreement that will send striker Thierry Henry to Arsenal of the English Premier League through the middle of February.

title: Iraqs Government Responds to Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheelies: The Third Way Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Cohort of Married Roman Catholic Priests, and More Are on the Way
description: On New Years Day, the Vatican announced the formation of a nationwide ordinariate  kind of a diocese without borders  for Episcopal priests and their congregations who want to move together into Roman Catholicism. The big news is not that some Episcopalians will have a zippier express lane into Catholicism, but that there will soon be even more married Catholic priests in America.

title: Parental Quandary: Grandma Gives Girly Gifts to a Tomboy
description: Grandparents, and in particular the grandparents on the in-law side, can provide a nearly endless series of quandaries for some parents. The lucky ones among us have two charming sets who support us in all things parental and offer our children the best grandparenting going. Most of us (among those fortunate enough to have our parents around at all) would name at least one or two areas where were not quite sure how to navigate all these familial relationships. Gretchen (her name, and her daughters, have been changed) falls into that category.

title: Bookshelf | 100 Years of L.L. Bean
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Marijuana Use Most Rampant in Australia, Study Finds
description: SYDNEY  A study published Friday in a British medical journal may have finally uncovered the secret behind Australias laid-back lifestyle, and it turns out to be more than just sun and surf: The denizens Down Under, it turns out, consume more marijuana than any other people on the planet.

title: A Tenuous Trend in Obamas Favor
description: Fridays jobs report, after weeks of other good data, makes it reasonable to wonder whether the economy may turn out to be less of a drag on President Obamas re-election campaign than has long been expected.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A wide selection of treats from Stuffed Artisan Cannoli will invade Park Here, the pop-up park at Openhouse Gallery, 201 Mulberry Street (Kenmare Street), in NoLIta, from Friday through Sunday. The pop-up is open from noon to 8 p.m. through Feb. 15.

title: East 62nd Street, 10:02 a.m.
description: Firefighters leaving the scene on Friday after responding to reports of smoke smells from a building on East 62nd Street between Madison Avenue and Park Avenue.

title: Romney Keeps Steady Lead in New Hampshire
description: Mitt Romney remains the front-runner among Republican primary voters in New Hampshire, while Rick Santorum continues to gain following his strong showing in the Iowa caucuses.

title: 8 NATO Service Members Killed in Afghan Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO said eight of its service members died in three attacks in southern Afghanistan, and an Afghan official on Friday identified four of the dead as American soldiers.

title: Producing Partnership Behind Rent and Avenue Q Comes to an End
description: Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Broadway producing team behind the Tony Award-winning musicals Rent, Avenue Q and In the Heights, said on Friday that they were ending their 21-year business partnership to produce independently.

title: Bold but Undersung Talents
description: SOMETIMES, for whatever reason, artists who are enormously respected by their peers do not develop the extensive careers and public following that their talents and accomplishments merit. This could be said of the violinist Henri Temianka and the pianist Leonard Shure. Though they did not appear regularly as a duo, Temianka, who died at 85 in 1992, and Shure, who died at 84 three years later, performed Beethovens 10 sonatas for violin and piano at the Library of Congress in Washington in three programs over five days in 1946.

title: Hes Back, Just as Curious as Ever
description: THAT didnt last long. Just 20 months after retiring his PBS series Bill Moyers Journal, Mr. Moyers was back in the studio on a Wednesday morning in December, deep in conversation about moral political psychology with the author Jonathan Haidt.

title: How About Some More New Stuff?
description: THE applause was warm last month when Alan Gilbert was presented with the 2011 Ditson Conductors Award at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Jazz Valedictorians, Cyberpunks and Country Troubadours
description: Charlie Haden and Hank Jones

title: Charles Barkley: Live and Uncensored, Sort of
description: 5:58 p.m. | Updated Ah, Charles Barkley. In a video posted to YouTube that captured him chatting with the other TNT announcers during a commercial break of Thursdays game between the Miami Heat and the Atlanta Hawks, Barkley called his new gig as a spokesperson for Weight Watchers a scam, and had some harsh words for the Hawks. It is definitely worth a watch. (Or, it was worth a watch until the video was pulled down due to a copyright claim by the N.B.A. )

title: The 45 Places to Go in 2012
description: 1. PanamaGo for the canal. Stay for everything else.

title: Where to Go to Understand the World in 2012
description: If you want to understand the world, you need to understand Asia. That, in turn, means setting foot in China and India.Together, those two countries account for one-third of humanity and much of the worlds recent economic growth. They reflect two of our richest civilizations, two broad religious traditions and a vast share of the worlds artistic heritage  and its future.

title: Where to Go to See Art in 2012
description: I find that art is a great starting point for exploring the world. Of course, my own travel is often determined by art exhibitions and projects. I love L.A., and Ive been thrilled by the international attention to  Pacific Standard Time,  a huge, multi-institution exhibition showing art of California in the most inspiring and groundbreaking way. From the L.A. County Museum of Art to the Hammer Museum to the California African American Museum and many, many more, Pacific Standard Time is a whole new way to experience a vast range of significant art and artists and a great moment for the city.

title: Where to Go to Shop in 2012
description: I have been buying vintage clothing for textiles and inspiration since I was 10 years old, so anywhere I go I try to find a thrift shop or vintage shop. I just love it. I remember filming a movie as the costume designer in 1995 in Pennsylvania and drove from Pittsburgh to Niagara Falls just to find vintage trinkets!

title: Where to Go to Hear Music in 2012
description: Ive traveled all over the world  Europe, Africa, South America, Asia  and music is everywhere. People are full of music in Cairo, and music is on every street corner and temple in India.

title: Where to Go to Eat in 2012
description: Ive eaten sushi around the world, and the best in Tokyo is at Sushi Sawada. In the kitchen, its just the chef, Koji Sawada, and his wife. And theres nothing there except charcoal and a box of rice. As old-school as you can get. I found it to be a breath of fresh air.

title: Henry Alford on How to Behave
description: Henry Alfords breezy guide to manners begins promisingly with a fact-finding trip to Japan, the Fort Knox of the World Manners Reserve. He hires a Japanese etiquette coach and learns that its rude to point with your fingers or sneeze in public. Alford wisely wastes no time trying to see the logic of Japanese dos and donts, which often make no more sense than our own. We dont have to know why its rude not to slurp your noodles in Tokyo. Why is beside the point. Wherever were strangers, even if its in Morocco in Cell Block 6, all we need are the rules  the etiquette manual. Manners, Alford explains, are principles, and etiquette is the specific acts of these principles.

title: Symantec Confirms Segment of Source Code Was Stolen
description: Hackers have stolen some of the programming code for two of Symantecs antivirus products for businesses.

title: The Morning After Mourning
description: Emily Dickinson wrote: After great pain, a formal feeling comes

title: How to Be an Avant-Garde Publisher
description: In the winter of 1954 my wife, Barbara, and I spent a few weeks in a grand, gloomy Paris apartment amid scratched and faded 18th-century furniture and silken walls at 35 Rue de la Faisanderie, off Avenue Foch, a chic address. The apartment belonged to Doubleday & Company, my employer, and was used by the occasional sojourner from the New York office, though there was no Doubleday business in Paris to justify such luxury. At the age of 25 I was such a sojourner, rewarded for having created a successful new paperback format that would become the industry standard. In Paris I visited the offices of the great French publishing houses Gallimard, Plon and Hachette, and in the evening Barbara and I were treated to Krug and La Tche at Le Grand Vfour and Chez Allard, where we chatted with our hosts about the Sartre-Camus quarrel, the emerging cold war and the calamity of Senator Joseph McCarthy. If Paris was the scene of a postwar literary revival, no one we met had heard of it. The writers I saw were displaced European intellectuals, former leftists now working secretly for the C.I.A.

title: Himmler and Heydrich: Hitlers Lieutenants
description: In June 1942, Thomas Mann, who was living in exile in California, delivered a commentary on a German-language BBC radio program that decried the sanguinary actions of the Third Reich in avenging the assassination of the leading SS official Reinhard Heydrich in Prague. After Heydrichs elaborate funeral ceremony at the new Reich Chancellery in Berlin, Hitler screamed at the Czech president, Emil Hacha, Nothing can prevent me from deporting millions of Czechs if they do not wish for peaceful coexistence. It wasnt an idle threat. Since the violent death of Heydrich, Mann lamented, terror is raging everywhere, in a more sickly, unrestrained fashion than ever before. . . . An entire town, that supposedly sheltered the perpetrators, is massacred and razed. Indeed, to honor Heydrich and help create what Hitler referred to as Germanys Garden of Eden in the East, the Nazis chose the code name Aktion Reinhard for the extermination of two million people, most of whom were Jewish, in the General Government of Poland by the end of 1943.

title: The Evangelical Brain Trust
description: The central question of the culture wars that have raged since the 1970s is not whether abortion is murder or gay marriage a civil right, but whether the Enlightenment was a good thing. Many evangelical Americans think the answer is no, according to The Anointed, a field guide to the evangelical experts you havent heard of  but should.

title: Living Above the Stove
description: THE five boroughs of New York have more than 23,000 restaurants. The restaurants themselves draw the obsessive attention of critics, foodies, diners and health inspectors. But what of the tenants who live above them, the unsung army of city residents who associate home with the smell of sauted clams and garlic, baking bread, lamb vindaloo?

title: Ozark Justice
description: After eight novels centered mainly on the poor and criminal in his native Missouri Ozarks, including the much lauded Winters Bone, Daniel Woodrell has published his first story collection, The Outlaw Album, and for readers of both crime and literary fiction, there is much to celebrate. Woodrell writes about violence and dark deeds better than almost anyone in America today, in compact, musical prose that doesnt dwell on visceral detail. An unerring craftsman, he can fully describe a murder in one rich sentence: The first time he killed the man, Jepperson, an opinionated foreigner from Minnesota, he kept to simple Ozark tradition and used a squirrel rifle, bullet to the heart, classic and effective, though there were spasms of the limbs and even a lunge of big old Jeppersons body that seemed like he was about to take a step, flee, but he died in stride and collapsed against a fence post. Every story is loaded with gems like that.

title: Copernicuss Last Act
description: Few scientists die secure in the knowledge that their greatest discoveries will outlive them, but some of those who missed out make you wince. Gregor Mendel and Johann Friedrich Miescher discovered, respectively, genes and DNA in the 1860s, yet both died obscure and unappreciated. Alfred Wegeners fundamental theory of plate tectonics drew scorn until the 1950s  two decades after he died. Last year, the biologist Ralph M. Steinman died just three days before winning a Nobel Prize.

title: How Robert Louis Stevenson Can Change Your Life
description: Im partial, I confess, to a book with exclamation points in its title. Its the excitement, the urgency, the exuberance they bring to a page. Imagine if other people had used them: War and Peace!!! The Breast!!! Youd expect a completely different book.

title: Politics as Blood Sport
description: What really matters in a Sara Paretsky mystery are the crimes behind the crimes  the corrupt politics, the class divisions, the economic inequities, the dirty business practices and all the other injustices that incite the wicked deeds we love to read about. BREAKDOWN (Putnam, $26.95) takes its first crack at a soft target: a cult series of lurid vampire novels that sends a group of impressionable preteenage girls into a graveyard to perform a giddy initiation ritual for their book club. But once V. I. Warshawski, the intrepid private eye who sees herself as a street fighter, a product of the mills and ethnic wars of Chicagos Steel City, has rescued the girls from the trauma of discovering a murder victim, the true villains come into sharper focus.

title: Hedys Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Clintons Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: As Romney Jabs at Obama, His Rivals Swing at Him
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Mitt Romney on Friday slammed President Obama for failing the American people and accused him of dragging the soul of America toward a European-style welfare state.

title: Beyond the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: What Does Unesco Recognition Mean, Exactly?
description: WORLD HERITAGE is big business, bringing hordes of tourists to poor countries that can use the jobs and the cash. It can also overwhelm the very sites it is designed to protect with all the less-savory aspects of mass travel, from chain hotels and restaurants to the impact of thousands of sport-shoed feet treading on fragile ground.

title: On Bass, Tina Weymouth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: SARGE: The Life and Times of Sargent Shriver, by Scott Stossel (Other Press, $19.95.) Idealistic and indefatigable, R. Sargent Shriver (1915-2011) created, among other organizations, the Peace Corps, Head Start and, with his wife, Eunice Kennedy Shriver, the Special Olympics. And he did so while steering a difficult course between independence and loyalty to the Kennedys. Stossels authorized biography marches through the 20th century  the Depression, World War II, the assassination of John F. Kennedy  tracing Shrivers maturation from a young naval officer to a political and social figure who touched the lives of millions.

title: Editors Choice
description: HAITI: The Aftershocks of History, by Laurent Dubois (Metropolitan/Holt, $32.) Foreign meddling, the lack of a democratic tradition, a humiliating American occupation and cold-war support of a brutal dictator all figure in a scholars well-written analysis.

title: Up Front
description: Four years after a presidential election that looked, briefly, as if it might put an end to Americas partisan warfare, we find ourselves further embroiled in it, as reports from the run-up to the Iowa caucuses reminded us almost daily. Only now what once seemed disagreements over solutions have grown, or deteriorated, into profound differences over just what the problems are.

title: Inside the List
description: GOD OF WINE: She could always go to Bacchus and bury her face against his big, thick neck and cry, and he would nuzzle her hair and breathe his warm, velvety breath on her neck, and she would feel comforted. Reading that sentence from Tami Hoags new suspense novel, Down the Darkest Road, which enters the hardcover list at No. 11 this week, its easy to recall that Hoag got her start as a romance writer before turning to the grisly mysteries that made her famous. Its not what you might think, though. Bacchus is a horse, not a bare-chested hunk, and the 15-year-old girl crying into his neck is about to risk her life facing down the villain who abducted her sister. (Spoiler alert: the climax involves a hoof pick as a weapon.) Whats more, Bacchus isnt even fictional. In her nonwriting life, Hoag is a championship dressage rider  shes set novels in the equestrian world before  and Bacchus is the horse shes competed with since a 2006 accident broke her back and led to the death of her previous riding partner, Coco Chanel. Schooling my horses is like meditation to me, Hoag writes on her official Web site. This is the one time of day my mind is not occupied by my fictional characters.

title: A Mini-Eden for Endangered Orangutans
description: All life is precious, but the demise of the orangutan hits especially close to home. One of our closest relatives  human and orangutan genomes are 97 percent identical, a study published last year in Nature found  their population has dwindled to somewhere around 50,000.

title: On the Far West Side, Mega Is the New Norm
description: THE far west side of Midtown, once notable mostly for being home to the Javits Center and the citys few remaining stables, is quickly becoming known for huge residential projects like Silver Towers, with 1,360 units; MiMA, with more than 800 units as well as a hotel; and Mercedes House, with 850 units.

title: How Scientists Came to Love the Whale
description: Whale Carpaccio  130 Kroner.

title: A Childrens Story
description: When I first met Hayley Parker-Barker, in 2007, she was just Hayley Parker, a sweet, level-headed senior at F.I.T. and an intern at Narciso Rodriguez. She acquired Barker when she married her husband, Cameron, whom she has known since they were toddlers. And now they have a child of their own, Ender, and live near Salt Lake City, where Cameron is studying computer programming.

title: The Rise of the American Oligarchy
description: Thomas Frank is the thinking persons Michael Moore. If Moore, the left-wing filmmaker, had Franks Ph.D. (in history from the University of Chicago), he might produce books like this one and Franks previous best seller, Whats the Matter With Kansas?

title: The Strange Death of the Republican Moderate
description: Half a century ago Republicans were a respectable but slightly boring presence on the political scene. Wary of excessive government, they were nonetheless reconciled to its expansion under Franklin D. Roosevelt and were mainly concerned with keeping it lean and solvent. Their beau idal was Dwight D. Eisenhower, who in 1952 became the first Republican in 24 years to be elected president. His principal opponent for the nomination, Senator Robert Taft of Ohio, had opposed the New Deal and was a staunch isolationist who opposed supporting Britain in the first years of World War II. Eisenhower represented a more pragmatic strain of conservatism, internationalist when it came to foreign policy and willing to accept a larger government role at home. He called it modern Republicanism. With Eisenhowers landslide re-election in 1956, his gospel looked like the future, at least for the G.O.P.

title: Artifacts | The Pendulum Swings
description: Ever wonder how it might feel to be a wrecking ball? The heavy, concrete sphere freely swinging through an empty TriBeCa alley in Pendulum, a Super 8 film short by the artist James Nares, could tell you: kind of blissful.

title: Resolution: Resign as Family Chief Financial Officer
description: I got married in 2010 to a law student. We entered the marriage with different financial circumstances: Id been working for a few years, paying taxes, saving for retirement and building credit. He was in school, focused primarily on covering his tuition. So when we merged our finances, it made sense based on our differing positions (and my fascination with personal finance) that I would continue to manage the money for us both.

title: Forget War; Romance Is in the Air
description: That second, irresistible slice of chocolate cake is almost always too much. It tastes good, of course, but the pleasurable surprise has dissipated. A sated palate turns discerning  the frosting seems a little too sweet, the base too rich.

title: A Bold Vote of Confidence
description: WHEN the first tower was hit on the blue-sky morning, Nancy Sheppard had just dropped off her 8-year-old son, Benjamin, at first grade and was hurrying down Hudson Street on her way to the offices of Viking Press, where she is vice president for marketing.

title: Off the Charts: Similar Cycles for Stocks
description: The total return, after inflation, of stocks over 15-year periods seems to be repeating the pattern it mapped out decades ago. The compound annual total real return of the Standard & Poors 500-stock index peaked at more than 15 percent in 1999, and has since fallen to just 3 percent. That peak was similar to the earlier peak, reached in 1964. After that 1964 peak, the stock market lost momentum and then entered a bear market. By 1979, the market had failed to keep up with inflation over the previous 15 years.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Ice Pick Pain Solved!
description: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a middle-aged woman with a pulsating whooshing sound in her head and a sharp stabbing pain on the left side of her neck and head. Nearly 400 readers wrote in with some very thoughtful assessments of this patients problem.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $6,900,000
description: A three-bedroom TriBeCa penthouse with a 22-foot-high wraparound loggia offering open river and Midtown views that sold for $6.9 million was the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

title: Race and Politics, Revisited
description: A post in my blog on Tuesday, about the undertone of racism in American politics, drew a great deal of angry e-mail and critical commentary, most recently from the Bill OReilly program on Fox News. I thought the subject was worth another visit.

title: Under Obama, a Record Decline in Government Jobs
description: When Barack Obama ran for president four years ago, he appalled some Democrats by saying Ronald Reagan had been a transformational president.

title: Why Authors Tweet
description: Since the 19th century, the common conception of the author has gone something like this: A young man, in his garret, writes furiously, crumpling up papers and throwing them on the floor, losing track of time, heedless of the public, obsessed with his own imagination. He is aloof, elusive, a man whom you know only by his writing and the portrait in his book.

title: Morris: Pure Fantasy, Pure Conjecture
description: Part 3: The filmmaker recalls his past as a private detective, and explains which of his projects hes most proud of.

title: Morris: Advertisements for Humanity
description: Part 9: The filmmaker talks about his continuing relationships with the subjects of his films, and reflects on the proper role of a documentary filmmaker.

title: Morris: Sabrina Harman and Abu Ghraib
description: Part 8: The filmmaker debunks what he sees as the biggest misconception about the infamous Abu Ghraib photographs.

title: Morris: 100 Miller High Life Commercials
description: Part 10: The filmmaker talks about his extensive work in advertising and recalls the first commercial he ever made.

title: Morris: The Umbrella Man
description: Part 2: The filmmaker talks about his side career as a writer for The New York Times, and introduces his short film, The Umbrella Man.

title: Morris: The Nub Club and the Nubbies
description: Part 11: The filmmaker explains the genesis of his 1981 film Vernon, Florida.

title: Morris: Cannonballs and the Elephant
description: Part 6: The filmmaker details his investigation into Fentons Valley of the Shadow of Death photograph, and explains what the project taught him about the nature of photography itself.

title: Morris: What Makes It a War Crime?
description: Part 13: The filmmaker reflects on the interview sessions with former defense secretary Robert S. McNamara that led to his film The Fog of War.

title: TimesTalks | Errol Morris: Preview
description: The celebrated documentary filmmaker talks about his side careers as a private detective and a writer for The New York Times, and explains why he does what he does.

title: Errol Morris: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the filmmaker Errol Morris.

title: Morris: A World in Which Things Happen
description: Part 7: The filmmaker talks about his film Standard Operating Procedure and explains why he wanted to make a film about Abu Ghraib.

title: Morris: Cannonballs and Collodion
description: Part 5: The filmmaker recalls how he became fascinated by Roger Fentons 1855 photograph, Valley of the Shadow of Death.

title: Morris: Going Deeper and Deeper
description: Part 4: The filmmaker talks about the writing projects he has in the works.

title: Morris: Stop Reading, Its Very Bad
description: Part 12: The filmmaker recalls the best thing he ever said to his wife.

title: U.S. Navy Rescues Iranians Held by Pirates
description: Updated | 6:33 p.m. In the middle of a tense standoff between Iran and the United States, the crew of an American destroyer patrolling the North Arabian Sea rescued 13 Iranian fishermen who had been taken hostage by Somali pirates more than a month ago, the Pentagon announced on Friday.

title: Tip of the Week: Make Your Own Shortcuts in Word
description: Microsoft Word, for both Windows and Mac OS X systems, is full of keyboard shortcuts to help speed things along as you work. Although the Web has plenty of pages listing the shortcuts (like Microsofts own collection for Word 2010), you can also generate your own chart right from the Word program itself  which can be handy if you want to print it or edit the list to add your own custom key commands.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Zombies Continue Their Reign
description: It has become old hat to see The Walking Dead, the series about human survivors in a world overrun by zombies, on our best-seller lists. This week, two more collected editions join the lists. On the hardcover list, the second omnibus of the series, which reprints issues 24 through 48 of the series, written by Robert Kirkman and illustrated by Charlie Adlard, arrives at No. 4. On the paperback list, vol. 15, which reprints issues 85 through 90, lands at the top spot. Its in good company, with a compendium edition including the first 48 issues at No. 2, and vol. 1, which contains the first six issues, at No. 9.

title: Baffling Reader Correspondence of the Week
