description: In this past weeks Ethicist column, Edith Palmer of Brooklyn explained why her political differences with David Koch kept her from taking her granddaughter, Rachel, to see a production of The Nutcracker that he sponsored.

title: TimesCast | January 6, 2012
description: A bomb kills at least 25 people in a Damascus neighborhood | The United States adds 200,000 new jobs in December.

title: In Winters Chill, Vegetable Risotto Adapts
description: A RECENT ski trip with friends allowed me to transport the City Kitchen philosophy to the slopes. Our little group gets together annually to enjoy the invigorating and rejuvenating process of speeding downhill on fresh powder. We also spend a lot of time eating, drinking, making merry  and cooking.

title: Megan Fox and Josh Duhamel, but No Optimus Prime
description: The Academys tagline for this years Oscars is Celebrate the movies in all of us, and with its first promo for the Feb. 26 show, to be broadcast on ABC, the movie they would most like to celebrate is  Transformers. Megan Fox and Josh Duhamel star in the spot, which pokes gentle fun at the dust-up over the ouster of Brett Ratner and Eddie Murphy as producer and host, and features cameos from William Fichtner (correctly cast as a version of the telecasts new producer, spiky-haired Brian Grazer), Robin Williams and others. To be fair, the promo, made with the imprimatur of FunnyOrDie, also has shades of Mission: Impossible and The Princess Bride, at least in Mr. Crystals hair and makeup (although he looks more like Carol Kane). If its a sign of the kind of telecast well see next month, we can bet on highly referential, high-production-value montages and familiar humor.

title: The Myth of Japans Failure
description: Tokyo

title: Giving Turnips a Second Look
description: Last fall, I was speaking with the Meatball Shop chef, Daniel Holzman, and the conversation turned to one of his favorite side dishes: Smashed Turnips With Fresh Horseradish.

title: Fox News Hires Liz Cheney as Analyst and Substitute Host
description: Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, is joining Fox News Channel as a paid contributor and substitute host, the channel confirmed Friday.

title: A Risotto in Winter
description: The trick with risotto is learning how to cook it right, which takes a certain amount of repetition. A proper risotto is made by adding hot broth, in increments, to a particular kind of short-grained Italian rice (arborio or carnaroli) and cooking it, uncovered, over a brisk flame. Ideally its best to learn at the elbow of someone who knows how, because the process can be a bit difficult to describe. Risotto is not so much about a recipe as it is a technique. Once mastered, it is a joy to make.

title: Channel Surfing: Portlandia
description: The second season of Carrie Brownstein and Fred Armisens rigorously lo-fi comedy Portlandia arrives on IFC on Friday night riding a relentless wave of hype. Not many shows this small-bore  six half-hour episodes in the first season, expanded to 10 for Season 2  get this kind of attention, with late-night guest spots, a red-carpet New York premiere (for the second season!) and a tour, which comes to Brooklyn and Manhattan on Jan. 20 and 21.

title: Filmmakers Take Dual Roles in Quest for Truth
description: WHEN the Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three were released from prison this summer, it was a momentous occasion not only for those convicts, who had each spent nearly 20 years behind bars for murders they say they did not commit, but also for the people who had followed their case and become convinced of their innocence.

title: Romney and Santorum See Bounce in South Carolina Poll
description: Now that Iowas caucus is over, the candidates standings are rolling in from the next set of states in the primary lineup. And more poll results are expected before the day is over.

title: Romney Leads South Carolina Polls
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The first South Carolina polls in more than two weeks are out, and they show a lead for Mitt Romney but with Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich in a competitive position.

title: A Historical Cycle Bodes Ill for the Markets
description: AT the turn of the last century, it was widely accepted that American stocks were virtually certain to be good long-term investments. Now, far fewer people are confident of that.

title: Dean & DeLuca Baking Its Own Breads
description: Nearly 35 years after Dean & DeLuca opened its first shop, on Prince Street in SoHo, this specialty-food chain has made another big leap. It has started baking its own bread, in a kitchen on West 28th Street, instead of selling only a collection of breads from companies like Sullivan Street Bakery and Amys Bread. The baker is Louis Volle, above, a 28-year-old New Yorker who grew up in France and worked at Fauchon before returning to bake bread at Per Se and Bouchon Bakery. He has introduced a basic baguette and a fine round sourdough at Dean & DeLuca, as well as some less-common standouts. In Mr. Volles hands, pain de mie, a dense French white bread meant for slicing, has a beautifully fluted crust and is delicious as a substitute for brioche, with a slab of pt. His dark chestnut bread has a deep earthiness. Several other loaves are studded with fruits and nuts.

title: The View From L.S.U.: Its Jordan Jeffersons Team Now
description: Finally, the day is near.

title: The View From Alabama: A Rematch Is the Right Thing
description: Alabama Crimson Tide players sat at their team banquet on Dec. 4 awaiting the final B.C.S. standings to see if they would get a second chance against the Louisiana State Tigers.

title: S.E.C. Changes Policy on Firms Admission of Guilt
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a fundamental policy shift, said Friday that it would no longer allow defendants to say they neither admit nor deny civil fraud or insider trading charges when, at the same time, they admit to or have been convicted of criminal violations.

title: In the City, but Not of It
description: THE grand houses of Fieldston  about 260, all single-family  are mostly generations old, devoid of the uniformity in other parts of the city and in suburban subdivisions. Nearly a century after it was conceived, this flowing suburban community in the northwest corner of the Bronx retains its dash of country, as well as its easy access to city life, having kept faith with its developers original vision.

title: On Radio, Mayor Shares Wide-Ranging Thoughts on Politics
description: An unusually analytic Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday reflected on the political landscape, describing in a radio interview why he tries to support Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, revealing an interest in the presidential candidacy of Jon Huntsman, and theorizing that the rise of air travel has contributed to the decline of bipartisanship in Washington.

title: With 3.8 Million Passenger Cars, Honda Leads All Manufacturers in Recalls for 2011
description: 5:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Economists Take Solace (but Only a Little) in Jobs Report
description: Economists viewed the latest jobs numbers as at least moderately encouraging, although some of them warned, as usual, against reading too much into the results of any single month  especially December.

title: Notes Hover a Moment, Speed-Land the Next
description: The pianist Steven Beck has become a mainstay at Bargemusic over the last decade and has been heard there in an enormous range of repertory, including a complete Beethoven sonata cycle; plenty of Bach, Brahms and Debussy; and a goodly amount of chamber music, both familiar and unusual. But he has become best known as an eloquent and persuasive performer of contemporary works.

title: City Warns Against Scam Training Schools
Its Nice That . . .
Brooklyn's Rube Goldberg
description: Joseph Herscher builds Rube Goldberg machines in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. In this video he constructs his newest contraption, called Page Turner.

title: Gleeful Sounds From Memories of Childhood
description: THE success of Glee and American Idol in the last few years would seem to make Hollywood particularly amenable to the work of Todd Graff, a writer-director who describes himself as a big old musical theater queen from way back. His rsum is eclectic, but the films that are nearest to his heart involve characters making music in one form or another.

title: Jenna Miranda and Mitch Meyers
description: HANGING out with her girlfriends and dating fun-loving men was the norm for free-spirited Jenna Gayle Miranda, who grew up in Miami. So when Mitchell Douglas Meyers approached her at a sports bar in Bloomington, Ind., seven and a half years ago while they were students at Indiana University, she was game for a friendly conversation.

title: U.S. to Ban New Uranium Mining Near Grand Canyon
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is expected to announce on Monday that he has approved a 20-year moratorium on new uranium mining claims in a million-acre buffer zone around the Grand Canyon.

title: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About Word Becomes Flesh
description: This years Under the Radar festival will be a homecoming for Marc Bamuthi Joseph. His 2003 spoken word piece, Word Becomes Flesh, a one-man show told as a series of letters from fathers to their unborn sons, returns to the festival lineup after being presented at the first Under the Radar in 2005. (It also had a run at the former Dance Theater Workshop in 2004.)

title: HTCs Decline Is Samsungs Gain
description: Samsung Electronics on Friday posted record fourth-quarter profits, citing high sales of its Android devices, while HTC, another major Android player, reported a drop in profits, its first decline in two years.Samsung, based in Seoul, South Korea, said its profits increased 73 percent compared to 2010s fourth quarter. It cited record-breaking sales of its smartphones, as well as the sale of its hard drive business to Seagate.

title: The Jets, the Colts, and More Jets: Judy Battista Answers Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: The Caucus Click: Huntsman Waiting for Airtime
A Chicken That Will Appeal to Your Beak
description: CHICKEN in a pot conjures images of rustic French or Italian country kitchens, with a fire blazing in the stone hearth, purple-tinged garlic braids on the wall and bunches of homegrown herbs drying in baskets.

title: Finley Helps Yi, Prepping Own Comeback?
description: Former Mavericks forward Michael Finley hasnt played pro basketball for a year, stepping away due to ankle injuries. But that could possibly change soon, according to ESPN.com.

title: A Chicken in Other Pots
description: As I mentioned in this weeks column, there are a lot of ways to flavor a chicken in a pot recipe. Here are some of my favorite combinations, all of which reflect a more European sensibility:

title: TimesCast | Unemployment Rate Falls
description: January 6, 2012 - The U.S. economy adds 200,000 new jobs in December, raising hopes for an economic recovery.

title: TimesCast: Unemployment Rate Falls
description: Motoko Rich reports on the latest jobs report and the effect it will have on the campaign trail.

title: Who Says Machines Must Be Useful?
description: ON the roof of a small row house in Brooklyn, a black powder fuse flared brightly against the gray sky. Hissing and sparking, it burned through a platform installed inside a repurposed Ikea bookshelf, sending four colored balls into action, lighting camp stoves, swinging fly swatters and knocking over books in a frenetic burst of organized chaos. In less than a minute, the final ball had dropped to the ground and was pocketed by Joseph Herscher, 26, the kinetic artist behind this real-world Rube Goldberg machine.

title: What Are You Paying More for in 2012?
description: The new year is a time for rebirth and renewal. Its also a time for businesses to squeeze a few more pennies out of their customers.

title: Ghosts and Goblins Haunt Tale of Young Lovers
description: In the preface to his 1598 opera The Peony Pavilion, Tang Xianzu wrote of love: The living may die of it, by its power the dead live again.

title: At Western Kentucky, a Weird Loss and a Firing
description: Not much has been going according to plan at Western Kentucky recently, but things took a turn for the downright weird in the past day.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 6
description: Subjects include New Years Eve celebrations, renovations at the State Capitol, and the funeral for three sisters killed in a Christmas morning fire.

title: In Rome, Bending Joints but Limiting the Budget
description: The true star of The Devil Inside, the latest addition to the fake, hand-shaky documentary horror subgenre, is a flexible little miss with the fabulous name Pixie Le Knot. That performer, whose name appears fairly low in the credits, surely deserves a higher berth, given the visceral impact her shoulder popping and back bending had on the audience I saw the movie with. The men around me all went, Ew  me, I wanted to head straight to yoga class.

title: NBC Entertainment Head Weighs In on Community, 30 Rock and House
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Robert Greenblatt, who runs entertainment for NBC, acknowledged here that the fall had been brutally difficult for his networks prime time schedule, worse than I hoped for, but about what I expected.

title: White House to Propose Pay Raise for Federal Workers
description: The White House will propose a 0.5 percent pay raise for civilian federal employees in the 2013 budget, an administration official said on Friday.

title: 24/7 Episode 4: A Final Salute
description: There were so many story lines woven into the Winter Classic between the Flyers and the Rangers, you had to wonder how HBO could possibly do it justice. Sean Avery was waived. Ilya Bryzgalov was benched (and went straight to the news media). Marc Staal was cleared to play. Questionable calls were followed by questionable reactions.

title: Duck Versus Duck: Pitting Ssam Bars Duck Lunch Against Wongs Duckavore Dinner
description: DUCK really is the other pork, isnt it? a friend observed last week. And of course, shes right. The two animals meander around the barnyard, grazing and grunting and generally acting like hungry teenagers. But all the while they are building up a formidable cushion of sweet fat that has the miraculous quality of improving just about any food it touches.

title: On Our Radar: Road Checks for Invasive Species
description: For the first time, state officers in Minnesota will conduct random road checks this year for invasive species that could be hitchhiking on trailers, boats and other vehicles. [Duluth News Tribune]

title: Victor Cruz Decides Not to Go Dancing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Part of the reason Giants receiver Victor Cruzs popularity has exploded this season  beyond his franchise-record 1,536 receiving yards  is his trademark salsa dance, which he has done after most of his 9 touchdowns.

title: Perseverance in a Collapsing World
description: IN Meg Stuarts Blessed a white-clad man in sandals  picture a Brazilian hippie passing a lazy day at the beach  traverses a stage that resembles a storybook island. His flattened movement gives him the two-dimensional air of Nijinsky on holiday. But theres something not quite right about this strange scene: the set, which features a palm tree, a hut with a chair and an enormous swan, is made entirely of cardboard. Soon enough it begins to rain. Theres trouble ahead.

title: The Soft Bigotry of Low Employment Expectations
description: A brief note while in transit, about todays jobs report.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 8
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Democrats See Hopes Rise in Battle to Control Congress
description: WASHINGTON  While most of the political worlds attention has been focused on the presidential primaries, Democrats who took a beating in the midterm elections say they have slowly but steadily gotten back in the game when it comes to the battle for control of Congress.

title: Remembering an A.T.F. Officer Killed While Trying to Stop a Robber
description: A funeral service was held Friday in Seaford, N.Y., for John Capano, a federal agent, who was shot by a retired Nassau County police officer during a confused situation last Saturday while trying to detain a man who had robbed a pharmacy, according to law enforcement officials.

title: House Democrats Ask, Where Are the Republicans?
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats took to the floor of an empty House chamber on Friday to mock Republicans who they said were taking a vacation rather than buckling down to work on legislation to create jobs, cut taxes and extend unemployment benefits for millions of Americans.

title: Lev Zhurbins Ljova: Lost in Kino, a CD of Movie Scores
description: LJOVA: LOST IN KINO

title: Gingrich Pushes Back Against Charges of Racism
description: NEWPORT, N.H.  Newt Gingrich charged that remarks he made about food stamps and African-Americans were taken out of context and twisted to sound racially insensitive.

title: With Nook Plan, Barnes & Noble Readies Another Shake-Up
description: Barnes & Noble is trying to shake up its business by potentially spinning off its fast-growing Nook business. This is yet another effort by the bookseller to rejigger its operations, amid a history replete with spinoffs and attempted deals.

title: Prostate Cancer Screening Shows No Benefit
description: Updated findings from one of the largest studies of prostate cancer screening show that the commonly used P.S.A. blood test did not save lives, although questions remain about whether younger men or those at very high risk for the disease might benefit.

title: C.D.C. May Lower Threshold for Lead Poisoning
description: A federal advisory committee has recommended that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lower the threshold for diagnosing lead poisoning in children, the first recommendation of its kind in 20 years and one that would mean hundreds of thousands more kids meet the standard for lead poisoning.

title: The Good Wife: Intro
description: Part 1: Lorraine Kostiw Dziepak of The New York Times introduces the cast and creators of of The Good Wife.

title: Good Wife: How Its Gonna End
description: Part 10: The cast and creators of The Good Wife explain where the show is headed, and talk about how the actors get to participate in determining what happens to their characters.

title: Good Wife: Not a Liberal Wet Dream
description: Part 8: The cast and creators of The Good Wife talk about how Republicans react to the show.

title: Good Wife: A Go-Go Dancer in a Cage
description: Part 7: The cast of The Good Wife reminisce about how they became actors, and reveal the hardest thing about TV acting.

title: Good Wife: Diane Is the Moral Center
description: Part 9: The cast and creators of The Good Wife talk about how CBS has tried to change the show.

title: Good Wife: Horrible Press Conference
description: Part 2: The creators of The Good Wife talk about how the show has evolved and moved away from its original vision.

title: Good Wife: Kalinda Sharma
description: Part 5: The cast and creators of The Good Wife talk about Archie Panjabis character on the show.

title: Good Wife: Cook County Fashions
description: Part 6: The cast and creators of The Good Wife discuss the costumes on the show, and Julianna Margulies explains why she walked away from a lucrative seventh season of ER.

title: TimesTalks | The Good Wife: Preview
description: The cast and creators of The Good Wife discuss how the show has evolved from its original vision, where its going, and what Republicans think of it.

title: Good Wife: Checking for Eye Rolls
description: Part 11: The cast and creators of The Good Wife discuss the professional relationships between the female lawyers on the show.

title: Good Wife: Landing on Chumhum
description: Part 4: The cast and creators of The Good Wife talk about why so many actresses over 40 are suddenly doing so much groundbreaking and important television work.

title: Good Wife: Slapped Awake
description: Part 3: The cast and creators of The Good Wife discuss the changing relationships among the main characters and how that defines the show.

title: Good Wife: Has He Phoned Yet?
description: Part 13: The cast and creators of The Good Wife reveal why everyone said phone instead of call in the shows first season.

title: Good Wife: Accommodating Broadway
description: Part 12: The cast and creators of The Good Wife explain why the Chicago-set show shoots in New York.

title: Good Wife: Another One of Our Failures
description: Part 14: The cast and creators of The Good Wife talk about Alicias relationship with Cary on the show, and why it isnt what they intended it to be.

title: Another Crowd Confronts Santorum
description: DUBLIN, N.H.  Rick Santorum faced a semihostile crowd of students here Friday afternoon at the Dublin School, a small, private high school. They challenged him on gay rights, contraception and what one questioner called his warmongering while he professes to be a man of faith.

title: Primed for a Celebration, but Restraint Still Prevails
description: AS final touches are applied to carmakers displays ahead of the opening of the 2012 North American International Auto Show, the auto industry has good reason to celebrate.

title: Romney Adviser Faulted Bain While at Labor Board
description: It is has become a staple of Mitt Romneys campaign stump speech: the claim that appointees to the National Labor Relations Board are labor stooges whose anti-business approach has impeded economic growth.

title: A Preview of the Show Cars
description: Automakers have reason for optimism in 2012, but the effects of several years of cutbacks can still be seen in the mostly modest offerings slated for this years Detroit auto show. Here are a few of the models scheduled to be shown.

title: Can Students Be Required to Join Facebook?
How the Spurs Can Survive Without Ginobili
description: San Antonios Manu Ginobili will miss six weeks of action as he recovers from surgery on his left hand, but so far the Spurs have been just fine without him. That wont last; although San Antonio has pulled off a comeback win and a dominant blowout victory over the last two days, this team is unquestionably lesser without Ginobili in the lineup.

title: Gonzalez Loan Ends Quickly
description: Omar Gonzalez will not get to test himself in the German Bundesliga, and may not have the opportunity to play in Major League Soccer this season.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Ford Is Covering Seats in Soda Bottles
description: According to Shopautoweek.com, an automotive information site and shopping portal, more than 70,000 bottles of soft drinks will be consumed and discarded during the Detroit auto show this month. But one mans trash is apparently anothers seat cover for a $40,000 hatchback.

title: Jan. 8  14
description: Art

title: Perry and Santorum Head to South Carolina on Sunday
description: 6:03 p.m. | Updated DUBLIN, N.H.  Rick Santorum and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas are joining the crowd and heading to South Carolina even as the New Hampshire primary heats up.

title: More Time to Buy in Italy, but Is That a Good Thing?
description: ROME  The first days of the new year have heralded a subtle revolution in Italy: the deregulation of operating hours for commercial venues like shops, bars and restaurants. And as revolutions tend to go, the measure has aroused praise in some corners and howls of protest in others.

title: Bjork Bringing Biophilia to New York
description: Bjork said on Friday that she would perform her Biophilia show for 10 nights in New York in February. The residency will mark the first time the Icelandic singer and songwriter has brought the elaborate stage performance of her recent compositions about nature to North America. Six performances will take place at the New York Hall of Science in Queens, starting on Feb. 3, and four shows will be staged at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, beginning on Feb. 22. No other performances have been scheduled in the United States. The show had its premiere at the Manchester International Festival in England and has received ecstatic reviews from critics. Performed in the round, it features a 24-woman choir, a giant Tesla coil and several large custom-built instruments that Bjork and her collaborators invented: a portable pipe organ, four 10-foot pendulums that play harp notes as they swing, a gramophone-like contraption called a Sharpsichord and another piece called a gameleste, which is a fusion of a celesta and a gamelan. The songs are eerie and convoluted, with unusual melodies and fluctuating meters, meant to capture the patterns in natural phenomena like those of gravity, lunar cycles, DNA and crystals.

title: Laid Off, With Retirement Almost in Sight
description: Achieving financial security in retirement is hard enough for most working Americans. But for those who lost their jobs just as the finish line was within sight, the whole notion may now seem out of reach.

title: Just One Look | Lanvin
description: This collection is about fabric, technology and volume, Alber Elbaz said at the start of his prefall presentation earlier today. Citing innovations in fabricfirst, with the incorporation of metals into knits and wovens, and now with things that have been bonded, plastified and waxedas his muse, Elbaz went on to show a collection full of texture (felted wool and fox), shine (sequins and coated cotton so glossy it looks wet) and stunning proportions (fly-away jackets and exaggerated, egg-shaped shoulders). Here, a romantic all-emerald look that illustrates all three of Elbazs points is anchored by a giant cameo pendant.

title: At Risk, the Core of a Cars Identity
description: Berlin

title: Some Tips for Unemployed Older Americans
description: Though the latest jobs report provided some reason for tempered optimism, older Americans who find themselves unemployed are typically out of work much longer than their younger peers. And that can make the road to retirement much more challenging.

title: Tributes That Leave Hollywood Speechless
description: HOLLYWOODS collective fascination with the silent-film era is hitting a peak with Hugo and The Artist, each a homage to a bygone time. The tributes continue with Film Forums series of MGM silent features, complete with live piano accompaniment (through Feb. 6); an exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts (through Feb. 25); and a new DVD release of the recent restoration of the only known color copy of the 1902 Georges Mlis masterpiece A Trip to the Moon, which is featured in Hugo.

title: The Panamera Family Show-Off
description: TESTED 2012 Porsche Panamera Turbo S

title: Its Electric. Should It Look Electrifying?
description: A CENTURY ago, when electric cars were popular  especially in cities and among women drivers  they looked discernibly different from gasoline-powered automobiles. In the age of the horseless carriage, the transportation historian James Flink wrote, electric cars looked even more like carriages.

title: Outside the Electric Box
description: Electric car manufacturers are adopting one of two overriding design philosophies: make it exciting, or make it familiar.

title: Humphries, the Boo-Birds New King
description: 3:38 p.m. | Updated As much as the Knicks early season struggles have put fans into fits of hand-wringing, at least one can take solace in the fact that one of the most disliked players in the league doesnt suit up for New York. Hes so unpopular that hes being soundly booed in arenas across the country if he dare sets foot on the court. In Toronto the other night, fans mocked him by waving large posters.

title: For a Team Called Soft, Falcons Run With Ferocity
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  The Atlanta Falcons, who play their home games in the living-room comfort of a domed stadium, began practice outdoors here Wednesday morning in a 38-degree chill, but without topcoats. A national radio sports talk host labeled the Falcons a finesse team that will capitulate in the kind of chilly, sloppy weather the Giants occasionally play in, which made Falcons running back Michael Turner laugh.

title: British Clarification on Implant Scandal Leaves Women Only More Confused
description: LONDON  The British government said on Friday that there was still not enough evidence to recommend routine removal of breast implants made by a now-defunct French company using silicone of dubious quality. But it also said that it would allow about 3,000 women who received the implants under the National Health Service to have them taken out and replaced free of charge if they and their doctors decided it was right to do so.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom riverfront cape in Fairfield, Conn., and a two-bedroom condo in White Plains, N.Y.

title: Readers and Experts Weigh In on a Site Owner vs. Google
description: Malware may be the digital equivalent of bedbugs: suddenly ubiquitous, hard to treat and a real menace for those infested. That might explain why a Bits post on Thursday, One Mans Fight With Google Over a Security Warning, stoked such impassioned responses.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Chelsea condo, a Morningside Heights co-op and a Columbia Street Waterfront condo.

title: Stimulating Job Growth
description: Stephen Case, the co-founder of AOL, speaks with Catherine Rampell on job creation and entrepreneurship.

title: City Warns Struggling Schools Against Spending
What Makes a Good Teacher? Ask a Student
Book Review Podcast: Bipolar America
description: In this Sundays Book Review, three new books are reviewed that respectively examine the rise of the American oligarchy, the decline of moderate Republicans and the Tea Partys core beliefs about government. The polemic among them is Thomas Franks Pity the Billionaire, about which Michael Kinsley writes:

title: Web Comic Draws Inspiration From a Twitter Spammer
description: Spam bots tend to be a source of annoyance, flooding the Web with automated nonsensical messages in the hopes of tricking people into clicking on links.

title: TimesCast | Explosion in Damascus
description: January 6, 2012  A bomb kills at least 25 in a densely populated neighborhood in the Syrian capital.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, Iraq, the Philippines and South Carolina.

title: U.S. to Expand Its Definition of Rape in Statistics
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government is changing its longstanding definition of forcible rape in compiling national crime statistics  expanding both the definition of victims, to include males, and the types of sexual assault that will be counted in the Federal Bureau of Investigations Uniform Crime Report.

title: Cyberattack Exposes 20,000 Israeli Credit Card Numbers and Details About Users
description: JERUSALEM  The credit card details of more than 20,000 Israelis were exposed on the Internet in two waves this week by a hacker or team of hackers who said they were Saudis.

title: A Short Career in Lurid Hollywood
description: DOROTHY MACKAILL may be having her moment. When this British-born actress, a star in silent films and early talkies, died in 1990 at 87, she merited only a 153 word obituary in The New York Times. And the unsigned article didnt even mention the movie most responsible for her current revival: Safe in Hell, a 1931 melodrama that seems remarkably lurid and sordid even by the loose standards that prevailed before Hollywood began enforcing the production code with vigor in 1934.

title: Michelle Obama and the Evolution of a First Lady
description: Michelle Obama was privately fuming, not only at the presidents team, but also at her husband.

title: The F.D.A.s Token Gesture
description: My column last week described how the Food and Drug Administration is declining to regulate the use of antibiotics in animal agriculture. After withdrawing its own 34-year-old request/promise to restrict the routine use of penicillin and tetracyclines in farm animal feed, the F.D.A. made it crystal clear that, despite the increasingly common threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in supermarket meat, it would leave the regulating up to industry itself.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 8
description: More Photographs

title: Lumire | The Koan of Joan
description: Today is the 600th anniversary of the birth of Joan of Arc, the cross-dressing, teenage virgin-warrior-martyr-saint. So what better way for President Nicolas Sarkozy  three months away from an election and mired in Europes economic crisis  to feel good about France than to make a pilgrimage to her birthplace?

title: A Search for a Child, or Maybe Her Moms Marbles
description: Theres something perhaps inadvertently timely about Bunny Lake Is Missing, now at the Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. This stage noir, about a single mothers desperate search for her 3-year-old daughter after she disappears from nursery school, speaks to parental anxiety in an age when child abuse seems rife. The play  based on Evelyn Pipers 1957 pulp mystery (the source for Otto Premingers 1965 screen adaptation)  derives tension from its resonant, inescapable subtext.

title: BMW ActiveHybrid 5
description: Overview of the car.

title: 2012 Detroit Auto Show: Photo Gallery
description: Highlights from the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

title: Comedies Top Writers Choices
description: Is this the year that funny finally gets its due?

title: 2012 BMW 3 Series
description: Overview of the new car.

title: Whats R.A. Dickey Climbing For?
description: Our colleague at the India Ink blog, Sruthi Gottipati, reports on Bombay Teen Challenge, the charity that Mets pitcher R.A. Dickey is raising money for with his attempt this month to climb Mount Kilimanjaro. The Mets pitcher is writing about the climb for the Bats blog. India Ink reports that the money will be used to build a fully equipped clinic in Kamathipura that would offer health screenings, antiretroviral drugs, and counseling to sex workers. Read more here.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Sonic RS
description: Overview of the car.

title: On Shale Gas, Warming and Whiplash
description: Jan. 19, 4:00 p.m. | Updated below |If you scan back youll see whats becoming a pretty long series of headlines here dealing with a phenomenon Ive noted since 2008 or so  a feeling of whiplash in tracking the flow of climate science and related news coverage. (One example is On Plankton, Warming and Whiplash.)

title: Remembering the Fever, and Fun, of the Basement
description: WERE it not for Filenes Basement, I would have gone to my proms in a potato sack.

title: Sailing a Sea Teeming With Sonic Treasures
description: When Mahlers 80-minute Ninth Symphony is presented as the only work on an orchestra program, most people in the audience feel they have gotten their moneys worth. Especially if the performance of this turbulent and, by the end, sublimely moving symphony is as well played and resolute as the one Alan Gilbert conducted with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Temp Workers Too Twitchy to Engage in Office Politics
description: Everybody dances to his or her own drummer in the plays of Toshiki Okada, and its a lonely, spastic beat each of them hears. The characters who appear in Hot Pepper, Air Conditioner, and the Farewell Speech  a triptych of short plays at Japan Society, directed in hypnotic style by Mr. Okada  may be the most gracefully graceless people in town.

title: Man Wins Web Squatting Suit Involving His Name
description: A New York man on Friday won a lawsuit against a woman whom he accused of registering Web addresses incorporating his name and demanding $1 million for each of them.

title: Caterer Tied to the Mob Is Convicted
description: Frank DiMattina, a suspected Genovese family associate who had dreams of reality television stardom, was convicted Friday of extortion and a related firearms charge.

title: Paramount Claims Box-Office Bragging Rights. Warner Claims Bragging Rights II
description: Its box-office bragging rights season in Hollywood. On Monday Paramount Pictures claimed its prize, noting in a press release that it sold $5.2 billion in tickets worldwide in 2011, enough to end Warner Brothers No. 1 reign.

title: Land Leveled in Divorce Awaits Economys Return
description: It seems that Dr. Nicholas Bartha got what he apparently wanted: If he could not live in the town house on East 62nd Street, no one could.

title: Always Be Closing: The Fast, Hard Times of Corporate Consultants
description: Preparing a television series about management consultants? Youll need to consult some consultants. A stripper, for one. A linguist schooled in corporate double-speak. Someone familiar with the challenges of having sex in a restaurant bathroom. Someone familiar with the challenges of having sex in a minivan. A child psychologist with a gender-identity specialty.

title: Previewing the 2012 Detroit Auto Show
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett looks ahead to the 2012 Detroit auto show, where press previews begin Sunday evening and continue through Tuesday.

title: Chic in Review | Justin Bieber, Ink
For Evangelicals Wary of Romney, Time Runs Short
description: Dismayed by the prospect of Mitt Romney as the Republican presidential nominee, conservative Christian leaders are intensifying discussions about jointly backing an alternative candidate from a field reshaped by Rick Santorums strong performance in Iowa.

title: Boys and Girls at Play: How Toys Reflect Society
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lawyer Leaves Witness Protection Because Everythings Fine Now. Right?
description: Should you watch The Firm, the 1993 movie, before watching The Firm, the 2012 television series?

title: Diet Pepsi and Dr Pepper Roll Out Aggressive New Campaigns
description: The soft-drink category is one of the most competitive in marketing, and the major players in the industry are wasting no time in wooing consumers in the new year.

title: A Hawks Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Woody Guthrie
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Speech, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing to Scrutinize Medicaid Reimbursement to Schools
description: The New York City Council will hold a public hearing next month to scrutinize the Education Departments system for collecting Medicaid reimbursements for services it provides to special-needs students, after a report in The New York Times last week about the citys failure to recover many millions of dollars in reimbursements in recent years.

title: Super Night Shot
description: Scenes from the show from the British-German troupe Gob Squad.

title: Romney Times Four
description: FOUR of Mitt Romneys five sons  Tagg, 41; Matt, 40; Josh, 36; and Craig, 30  were sitting in a hotel room in Des Moines on the eve of the Iowa caucuses last week, debating which of them was most likely to carry the Romney mantle of politics and public service. The verdict was Mr. Romneys oldest son, Tagg, or maybe Josh. But thats where things got tricky.

title: Labor Board Backs Workers on Joint Arbitration Cases
description: The National Labor Relations Board ruled on Friday that employers could not prevent workers from filing work-related group or class actions, essentially banning employment agreements at many companies that require workers to pursue all claims individually through arbitration.

title: Hey, You, Would You Mind Being in Our Movie?
description: Disposable fame is sweet in Super Night Shot, the collective title for the instant films being shown at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival. The mission of this project from the British-German troupe Gob Squad is to wage the war against anonymity. Now that is something you might argue that the United States has been doing quite well on its own, thank you, what with all those hungry reality TV shows that require regular feeding.

title: Bill Cunningham | Ice Pack
description: It was 13 degrees out! Collars were pulled up, caps were pulled down, scarves were twisted round and round, and eyes peered out of narrow slits.

title: Feminine Truth, Pursued in Breathing Exercises
description: You dont have to judge anything.

title: Turning a Page, the Joseph Herscher Way
description: A step-by-step visual detailing one of Mr. Herschers Rube Goldberg machines.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 6
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Years Eve celebrations, renovations at the State Capitol and the funeral for three sisters killed in a Christmas morning fire.

title: Film About the Hunt for Bin Laden Leads to a Pentagon Investigation
description: LOS ANGELES  When the movies get real, moviemakers can count on real headaches.

title: 2012 BMW 3 Series
description: 2012 BMW 3 Series slide show

title: Juan Rivera Goes Free
description: Juan Rivera, the subject of Andy Martins Nov. 27 article, The Prosecutions Case Against DNA, was released this evening from the Stateville Correctional Center near Joliet, Ill., 19 years after being convicted of the murder of 11-year-old Holly Staker. Martin wrote about (and discusses in this video) the states attorneys office in Lake County, Ill., and their novel theories to explain away exculpatory DNA evidence in Riveras case and others. Michael Mermel, the prosecutor quoted extensively in Martins article, was asked in early December to leave his position. Michael J. Waller, the Lake County states attorney, said: The comments attributed to Mike Mermel do not reflect my views on the role of the Lake County states attorneys office. Nor do they reflect the manner in which my staff has conducted themselves over the last 21 years.

title: Mets Sign Ronny Cedeno
description: The Mets agreed to terms with the Venezuelan infielder Ronny Cedeno on a one-year contract worth $1.1 million with extra performance bonuses based on playing time in the event he becomes a regular player.

title: Anticipating M.L.K. Day
A Very Good Year for Nicki Minaj
description: The rapid rise of the hip-hop star Nicki Minaj within the fashion world.

title: More Polls Cement Romneys Lead in New Hampshire
description: Echoing Friday mornings Suffolk University tracking poll, two new statewide polls in New Hampshire show Mitt Romney firmly in place as the front-runner, with Rick Santorum and Ron Paul gaining support in the wake of their strong finishes in the Iowa caucuses.

title: The Mod Classicist in the Mirror
description: We now come to the analogy part of the exam. Please assess the following as true or false.

title: Where You Can Pull Your Own Guinness
description: I STILL remember the first time I had a Guinness properly poured and at the optimal (not too cool) temperature. It was in a small pub in a small town in Ireland, and it was like nothing Id ever tasted  thick and rich and full of flavor. I wanted to drink it slowly, almost eat it with a spoon. I had dinner that night, too, but I couldnt tell you what I had: The experience was all about the beer.

title: My Back Pages: Digital Diary Traces Memories
description: LIKE many 29-year-old Web designers from Brooklyn, Kelsey Rahn spent part of New Years Day hung over, poring over a list of resolutions. Make more time for myself. Make soup in my Crock-Pot twice a month. Join the gym by Friday.

title: Ambience Is Gothic, but Flavor Is Mexican
description: UNLIKE most Mexican restaurants, Red Lulu Cocina and Tequila Bar, in South Norwalk, favors clubby gothic over cactus and sombrero. Its ornate chandeliers, some adorned with black birds, are set to a dim luminescence. Capacious booths, with privacy draperies, surround a cruciform communal table decked out with a super-elongated candelabrum. There is a surfeit of red throughout  from the velour curtains by the entrance to the lights strung along the railing of the upstairs balcony. And films projected onto one of two brick walls add to the sense of hyperactivity.

title: Sitting and Drinking and Flirting and Pondering Life With Your Multiple Selves
description: Outside the curtained door are two lights, one green and one red. When the green light comes on, you pass one of your allotted cards between the curtains and into an unseen hand. When the red light comes on, you enter. Inside you meet yourself.

title: Steelers Assistant Sustains Burns in a House Fire
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers running backs sensed something was wrong when they arrived at work on Friday for an early-morning film session in preparation for their Sunday playoff game against the Denver Broncos and their coach, Kirby Wilson, was not there.

title: 2013 Scion FR-S
description: 2013 Scion FR-S slide show

title: Obama Has Lunch With Contest Winners  From Swing States
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama dined for the second time with four winners of the quarterly Dinner With Barack contest, and for the second time, all four winners were from states that the Obama campaign considers battlegrounds that could help determine whether Mr. Obama is re-elected.

title: In H.P. Tale, a Question of Truth or Titillation
description: Ms. Fisher was scared. She was a nervous wreck but attempted to appear relaxed. She sat down on one of two love seats in the sitting room. She was worried when you came over and sat directly next to her and put your arm on the back of the love seat. As you did so, your hand brushed across her breast. ... It happened a second time and Ms. Fisher said you know that you are touching my breast, right? You said, Oh, sorry, sorry and then laughed it off.

title: Indian Cuisine With a Glossy Finish
description: MINT makes a good first impression. The restaurant, a seven-month-old Garden City branch of an Indian restaurant in Manhattan, is a beauty.

title: Why Islamism Is Winning
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: A Long History of Political Brawling for Santorum
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Rick Santorum loves professional wrestling, and has been thrilled to meet savage icons of the squared circle like Bruno Sammartino, Gorilla Monsoon and Hulk Hogan. He even lobbied for the World Wrestling Federation for a while.

title: John Paulsons Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Year
description: The pain of 2011 has finally ended for John A. Paulson, the billionaire founder of the hedge fund Paulson & Company.

title: A Taste of Old Beirut, With Quirks All Its Own
description: THERE is no shortage of worthy Middle Eastern restaurants sprinkled throughout northern New Jersey, from mom-and-pop falafel joints to white-tablecloth establishments, but few offer quite the same array of offbeat charms as Kamils Lebanese Cuisine.

title: Morgan Stanley Discloses Stakes in Zynga and LinkedIn
description: Morgan Stanley, as of late the go-to underwriter for tech initial public offerings, disclosed its stakes in Zynga and LinkedIn on Friday, according to securities filings.

title: Big Payday for Yahoos New Chief
description: Scott Thompson is getting a very friendly welcome to Yahoo.

title: Illinois: Inmate Cleared by DNA Is Freed
description: A man who has been convicted three times in the 1992 murder of an 11-year-old baby sitter in suburban Chicago was released from prison on Friday after a local prosecutor decided not to challenge an appellate courts ruling that reversed the last conviction. The man, Juan Rivera, 39, had been incarcerated at the Stateville Correctional Center in the far southwest suburbs of Chicago. The Lake County states attorney, Michael Waller, in a statement defended his offices prosecution of Mr. Rivera, whose case was featured in an article in The New York Times Magazine. I am mindful that for Mr. Rivera and some others, this decision will be viewed as too late in coming, Mr. Waller said. Though there was no physical evidence linking Mr. Rivera to the crime, he was convicted of raping and murdering the baby sitter, Holly Staker, based largely on his confession. In 2005, DNA testing determined that Mr. Rivera was not the source of semen found inside Holly, and he was awarded a new trial, his third. Mr. Rivera was convicted again. In its reversal order last month, the appellate court suggested that Mr. Riveras confession was coerced. The investigation into Hollys murder has been reopened.

title: Council Member Resigns and Pleads Guilty
description: Harry Thomas Jr. pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that he stole from programs receiving federal money and filed a false tax return. Mr. Thomas resigned from the Council of the District of Columbia on Thursday night. Judge John D. Bates of Federal District Court said that Mr. Thomas could spend up to 47 months in prison and that the sentence would determined at a hearing on May 3.

title: For Iranians Waylaid by Pirates, U.S. to the Rescue
description: ABOARD THE FISHING VESSEL AL MULAHI, in the Gulf of Oman  Senior Iranian military officials this week bluntly warned an American aircraft carrier that it would confront the full force of the Iranian military if it tried to re-enter the Persian Gulf.

title: Don Carter, First Big Star of Golden Era of Bowling, Dies at 85
description: Baseball had Babe Ruth, boxing had Jack Johnson, and, during its golden age in the 1950s, bowling had Don Carter.

title: A Billionaire Lends Haiti a Hand
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Almost two years after an earthquake ravaged this city, some half a million people are still living in filthy tents, cholera has infected a similar number across the country and the president works from a flimsy prefab structure behind the still crumpled Presidential Palace.

title: At a New Theater, Ambitious and Varied Beginnings
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y.

title: A Tie for Players of the Year
description: Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City scored a trifecta at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan at the end of December. They won the two main events, the Truscott Board-a-Match (with their teammates, R. Jay Becker and Chris Willenken of New York City) and the Goldman Pairs. And these victories gave them enough points to tie as the Greater New York Bridge Associations Players of the Year and Team Players of the Year. They were well ahead as Players of the Year, but won the Team Player by only one point from Willenken.

title: Senator Says His Concerns With Nominee Arent Personal
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey denied Friday that he was blocking an Obama administration nominee to a federal judgeship because of a grudge against her longtime companion, who led a corruption investigation of the senator during his tough election fight of 2006.

title: A Filmmaker Walks a Line Between Artistic Acceptance and Official Approval
description: BEIJING

title: It Takes a Santorum
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.

title: Bahrain Rights Activist Says He Was Beaten During Attack on Protest
description: Updated | Saturday | 10:57 a.m. A prominent human rights activist in Bahrain was briefly hospitalized on Friday night after the security forces attacked a protest in the capital, Manama.

title: Penn States Choice of Coach Displeases Former Players
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The news that Bill OBrien would become Penn States first new football coach in almost a half century upset some former Nittany Lions players, left some observers wondering why the search took nearly eight weeks, and moved fans here and afar to ask: Who?

title: EMI Label Sues ReDigi, the Used Digital Music Store
description: Another day, another lawsuit over digital music.

title: A Tough Question for Mitt Romney
description: At a town hall in Tilton, a New Hampshire voter cited Mr. Romneys personal wealth in a question about tax cuts.

title: Lululemon Athleticas Founder Takes a Step Back
description: Lululemon Athletica, the yoga wear retailer, said on Friday that Dennis J. Wilson, its founder and former chief executive, would leave his remaining executive role as chief innovation and branding officer at the end of January. The company, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, offered no explanation about the move. He will remain as chairman. Christine Day, a former Starbucks executive, has been the companys chief executive since 2008. Mr. Wilson, who is known as Chip, has said that he was greatly influenced by Ayn Rand and has used her books, which promote the idea of people living for their self-interest, to guide his business. Last November, Lululemon provoked an outcry from some customers after it used the opening line from Rands Atlas Shrugged on its shopping bags.

title: L.S.U. Cornerback Is Overshadowed, but Not Overlooked
description: NEW ORLEANS  There is no Vince Young, Cam Newton or Tim Tebow in the Bowl Championship Series title game this year. The most recognizable star in Mondays game between Louisiana State and Alabama is the flamboyant L.S.U. defensive back Tyrann Mathieu, who said Thursday that he researched the names of his opponents mothers in order to talk trash to them.

title: N.C.A.A.s Justice System
description: I stand corrected.

title: The Capital of Sports
description: NEW ORLEANS  On Friday, players from Alabama and Louisiana State answered questions on the field at the Superdome, where S-A-I-N-T-S spread across the end zones and the B.C.S. national championship game logo decorated midfield. Such is life here, at the center of the American sports universe.

title: Wall Street Braces for Dismal 4th Quarter
description: For most Wall Street bankers, 2011 was a year they would rather forget. Investors will soon find out just how bad that year was for the countrys biggest financial institutions.

title: Santorum Concedes He Is Unlikely to Win in New Hampshire
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Rick Santorum conceded Friday night that he was unlikely to win the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, but said he was proud of the progress he had made.

title: Paul, After Texas Detour, Gets Back to the Campaign
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Representative Ron Paul made his first presidential campaign appearance Friday at the rather leisurely hour of 2 p.m.  his first stop in New Hampshire since finishing third at the Iowa caucuses three days before.

title: Celebrating Fluxus, a Movement That Didnt Create by the Rules
description: Last year was a big one for Fluxus, despite the fact that this international network of artists, composers and poetic pranksters has been defunct for several decades. Attention in art history is often bestowed posthumously, however, and because 2011 was the 50th anniversary of Fluxuss first New York project  an exhibition in book form of performance-related materials  half a dozen shows have been mounted locally to commemorate the groups existence. One of them is at/around/beyond: Fluxus at Rutgers University at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick.

title: One Bad Energy Subsidy Expires
description: Now that the most polarized and paralyzed Congress in memory has managed to kill one of its most resilient boondoggles  the three-decade-old, multibillion-dollar subsidy for corn ethanol  we hope it has not exhausted its resolve and will take a hatchet to other harmful energy subsidies, chiefly those it gives to fossil fuels.

title: U.S. Navy Intercepts Pirate Attack
description: The aircraft carrier John C. Stennis broke up a high-seas pirate attack on a cargo ship in the Gulf of Oman, freeing 13 Iranian hostages who had been held captive by pirates for more than a month.

title: Waiting for Recovery
description: In its broad strokes, the December employment report is an upbeat finish to a difficult year. Job growth accelerated, the workweek expanded modestly, wages ticked up and the unemployment rate declined.

title: Another Step Up for a Bronx Native Who Led the Archdiocese in Baltimore
description: The other American elevated to cardinal by the Vatican on Friday is a Bronx boy who exercises regularly on a treadmill, roots ardently for the Yankees and, according to friends, is so devoted to the idea of doing what he asks others to do that he learned how to parachute before serving as a military chaplain in Vietnam.

title: Haitians in Brazil
description: Fleeing misery, Haitians head to Brazil in search of work and a better life.

title: For Father Working Three Jobs, a Startling Diagnosis
description: The morning of March 31, 2009, is stamped on Jose Perezs brain. He woke up with stabbing pains in his legs. His wife called an ambulance, and he was taken to Staten Island University Hospital. A nurse ran a blood test. Half an hour later, five doctors walked into his room.

title: Haitians Take Arduous Path to Brazil, and Jobs
description: BRASILIA, Brazil  Of the odyssey that delivered him to this town in the Brazilian Amazon, Wesley Saint-Fleur could muster only a look of exhaustion and bewilderment.

title: Lax Security, Stacks of Cash: Robbers Easy Pickings
description: The first robbery occurred on July 29. Or maybe not. At MetroPCS cellphone stores, it is hard to keep count, and five months later, a manager in Brownsville, Brooklyn, could not remember if that was the day he himself was held up at gunpoint, or if someone else was.

title: Giants Say Captains Earn Respect
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Not many Giants watched the boiling point moment in the Jets season-ending defeat last weekend, when an in-the-huddle fracas banished wide receiver Santonio Holmes to the sideline and a solitary seat on the bench. But the Giants knew what had happened or had seen televised video of it.

title: Dolan Elevated as Pope Names New Cardinals
description: Pope Benedict XVI named 22 new cardinals on Friday, including Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, in a set of appointments that reflected the popes reliance on Italians and Vatican insiders at a time when the churchs population base has shifted to the Southern Hemisphere.

title: A Shrinking Military Budget May Take Neighbors With It
description: WASHINGTON  Military spending has transformed the faded farmlands of northern Virginia into a land of glass-block office parks, oversize homes and sleek cars. Average household incomes there are among the highest in the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Common-Sense Immigration Move
description: The Obama administration is taking a major step toward bolstering legal immigration and protecting families  while removing some of the arbitrary cruelty from the workings of the immigration bureaucracy. It announced on Friday that it would change a notorious process to avoid separating families when immigrants apply to become legal permanent residents.

title: In New Hampshire, Fiscal Anxiety Despite Relative Economic Health
description: PITTSFIELD, N.H.  Karen Eastman has worked at the same small manufacturing company for 18 years and makes a solid living stitching sleeves for firefighter coats, but the economy is still her foremost concern heading into this states presidential primary voting next week.

title: Plenty of Sun, but Few Stars, on Opening Day in Hawaii
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii

title: Romney Advantages Could Prove Disadvantageous
description: TILTON, N.H.  The advantages for Mitt Romney are abundant in the Republican presidential primary here, but there is one obstacle that stands far taller than Rick Santorum, Newt Gingrich or any rival: The inclination of New Hampshire to knock a front-runner down to size.

title: Shaky Knicks Rally to Keep Wizards Winless
description: WASHINGTON  The desperation was spelled out on the scoreboard, across the Knicks bench and finally in their lineup. They were teetering on the edge of disaster before finding momentary salvation from sources both obvious and unexpected.

title: Finding Beauty in Land
description: Americans were not in the forefront of advanced art in the 19th century, but they did have one thing going for them: an interest in the novel and innovative. And so they embraced Impressionism  a radical, anti-academic movement at that time, though today it has come to seem like a tasteful and slightly saccharine idiom (think of Thomas Kinkade, the mass-market painter who has trademarked himself as a neo-Impressionist Painter of Light).

title: Relax, if You Want, but Dont Put Your Feet Up
description: William D. Peppers recalled how empty the subway car was. It was not yet 4 a.m. on a Friday, so most of New York was still asleep, but he was already late for his job at a Bronx bakery. As his train passed through Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Peppers stretched out, closed his eyes and nodded off.

title: Living Amid the Violence in Iraq
description: The boom and shudder of numerous explosions woke me. It was my first morning in Baghdad in nearly five years, and, coincidentally, only days after the withdrawal of the American troops from Iraq.

title: Saturday: One Whose Head Is Turned
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Now thats a fairly wide open grid, isnt it? Joe Krozel has used that grid before (Across Lite, Solution, blog), and hes back today with another 64-word puzzle that builds what looks to me like the beginnings of a log cabin: we have those double stacks of 15s crossing each other near the edges of the grid. And they are some pretty nifty 15s, I must say.

title: Occupy Protesters in New Hampshire Seek Visibility Ahead of Primary
description: Occupy New Hampshire has a full slate of events ahead of the states primary on Tuesday, but many members of the group are distancing themselves from some of the tactics that saw members of Occupy the Caucus arrested last week in Iowa.

title: Inspector at Fire Dept. Took Bribes, Officials Say
description: A longtime Fire Department employee who oversaw safety inspections of day care centers in New York City was charged on Friday with accepting thousands of dollars in bribes for ignoring or playing down safety violations.

title: Chinese News Agency Warns Against U.S. Moves
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas state-run news media warned Washington on Friday not to recklessly practice militarism or engage in war mongering, a day after the Obama administration outlined a new military strategy with an increased focus on China.

title: Michelle Obama as Critic and Advocate
description: Mrs. Obamas adjustment to the White House  including, at times, severe tension with her husbands staff  illuminates some of President Obamas central challenges.

title: Mets, in Hiring Financial Firm, Insist Its Not About Bankruptcy
description: CRG Partners lists as its special talents financial advisory work, restructuring and reorganization, and turnaround management  polite descriptions of services needed by companies in distress. The firms Web site names a long list of clients, from Kmart to Popeyes Chicken to Sunbeam Products.

title: Recharging Body and Soul
description: Michael G. Grimm, a freshman United States congressman representing Staten Island, has been a Marine, an undercover F.B.I. agent and the owner of a health food restaurant in Manhattan called Healthalicious. After a week in Washington, Mr. Grimm, 41, a Republican, spends his Sundays in the Heartland Village neighborhood of Staten Island, where he lives on the top floor of a multifamily house with his puppy, Sebastian, a Yorkshire terrier. The dog is a regular presence in his office in the Capitol.

title: China to Release More Data on Air Pollution in Beijing
description: SHANGHAI  China said on Friday that it would begin to publish more detailed air quality data on Beijing later this month, following a public outcry over official government readings that critics said underestimated the severity of the air pollution problem in the smog-filled capital.

title: You Say You Made a Resolution
description: The urge to eat virtuously is one of those things that come around each January  like cold weather and the Rose Bowl  only, for most people, inevitably to pass. At Candle 79, however, a fine-dining organic vegan restaurant on 79th Street and Lexington Avenue, diners can preserve their culinary purity the year round, with dishes like the seitan piccata with creamed spinach or spaghetti and wheat balls, and drinks from the eco-friendly bar. (Who knew the Makers Mark distillery had a low-carbon footprint?) While there were no self-announcing resolution-makers in the crowd the other night, there was  by coincidence  a Stanford University psychologist,  Kelly McGonigal, celebrating the publication of The Willpower Instinct, her scientific study on the nature of self-control.

title: The G.O.P.s Black People Platform
description: That didnt take long.

title: The Run and Bump
description: During the past four-plus decades of football, since a Giants receiver slammed the ball to the turf and invented the end-zone spike, the touchdown celebration has been subject to countless fads and elaborate variations. When viewers tune in to the first round of the N.F.L. playoffs on Saturday, they will most likely see the latest trend, which, however simple, is lacking in one critical way: it does not have a name.

title: Planting a Park
description: Q. Theres a tiny, thin park in the West Village bounded by West Houston and Bedford Streets and Avenue of the Americas. The only name I could find was a parks department sign that said, Greenstreets. Why is the park called that?

title: Church Hints It May Serve as Mediator in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A senior official of the Russian Orthodox Church has indicated that the church is moving toward a middle position between the government and opponents who staged two huge demonstrations last month, warning that if the authorities do not respond to peoples concerns they could be slowly eaten alive.

title: In M.T.A. App Contest, Many Buttons Worth Pushing
description: HOW do you create public-service software? Run a contest.

title: A Salsa Dance That Isnt as Stellar as the Score
description: When you are devoted to a marginalized art form like dance, you tend to look for it in everything as a way of justifying its importance to the world. I like to imagine that the Knicks are really just dancers and that the fall dance season actually begins at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Indiana Labor Measure Is Expected to Progress
description: INDIANAPOLIS  House Democrats brought state lawmaking to a halt in Indiana for much of this week, refusing for a third straight day on Friday to come out to their chamber floor in a procedural effort to stop right to work legislation at the center of a mounting battle over unions here.

title: Increasingly Isolated, Iranian Leader Set to Visit Allies in Latin America
description: When President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran begins a four-nation tour of Latin America on Sunday, showcasing his support in the region against a backdrop of international tensions over his nations nuclear program, he is set to visit some of the United States most ardent critics: Venezuela, Nicaragua, Cuba and Ecuador.

title: U.S. to Block New Uranium Mines Near Grand Canyon
description: The Obama administration is set to announce on Monday that it will block new uranium mining on one million acres in northern Arizona near the Grand Canyon, lobbyists and Interior Department employees who had been informed about the decision said on Friday.

title: Crowned New King of Kong
description: ON Feb. 26, 2010, a snowstorm canceled Dr. Hank Chiens surgery schedule, allowing him to sleep in, and the world of competitive Donkey Kong would never be the same.

title: Corrections: January 7
description: WEEKEND

title: Like Phillips, Texans Defense Steadies and Toughens
description: HOUSTON  Exhaustion hits Wade Phillips about 5 p.m. each day as if he had set an alarm clock. He no longer has a gallbladder, removed during an operation that also involved a kidney, and less than a month ago was watching from the hospital as the Houston Texans limped toward the playoffs.

title: Michigan Puts the Foot in Football
description: NEW ORLEANS  In the Michigan locker room, just before the Wolverines set out to play Virginia Tech in the Sugar Bowl on Tuesday, one friend reassured another.

title: Peru: American Returns for Parole
description: Lori Berenson, the New Yorker who served more than 15 years in prison in Peru for aiding a rebel group, returned to Lima on Thursday night after a court-sanctioned holiday visit to see her family in Manhattan. Ms. Berenson, who traveled with her young son, Salvador, was required to return to continue serving her parole, which calls for her to remain in the country until the end of her 20-year sentence in 2015. Many in Peru, where she is seen as a symbol of a bloody period of violence and terror, had questioned whether she would come back from the trip and were surprised when she returned well ahead of a Jan. 11 deadline.

title: Exxon and Salazar in Settlement on Offshore Leases
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Kenneth Salazar, the interior secretary, agreed to settle a lawsuit in which Exxon, the worlds largest publicly traded oil company, challenged the governments decision to cancel offshore leases that may yield billions of barrels of oil, according to a court filing. The accord will allow Exxon Mobil to develop this very large, but technically challenging, resource as quickly as possible using a phased approach, Patrick McGinn, a spokesman for Exxon, said in an e-mail. Exxon sued on Aug. 12 over a ruling by the department that canceled Gulf of Mexico leases for the so-called Julia unit. The company and the government entered into a settlement agreement on Dec. 30, according to a filing Friday in United States District Court in Lake Charles, Louisiana. Exxon said in its complaint that it sought a suspension for its Julia leases in 2008 because of drilling complexity. It cited federal regulations that allow oil oil producers to suspend production in their fields, partly to facilitate proper development of a lease. The Interior Department denied the request in 2009, stating that the companyhad not demonstrated a commitment to production according to court papers. Unsuccessful appeals followed.

title: Mitts Young Republican, Up From the Streets
description: A Republican presidential candidate choosing a campaign chairman in New York City is essentially looking for the least-enfeebled arthritic to climb Everest. New Yorkers may elect Republican mayors, and even members of Congress, but we do not contribute to the victories of Republican presidents. Failure here is preordained.

title: China: TV Limits May Hit the Web
description: Restrictions on the broadcasting of television historical dramas in China that went into effect on Jan. 1 may soon also extend to Web sites, according to a report released this week by Marbridge Consulting, a business analysis company. The report said that the agency regulating film and television, commonly known as Sarft, had said that as of Jan. 1, at least half of any satellite television networks dramas must be set in the modern day. Last year, the agency expressed disapproval of time-travel shows, which often involve a modern-day protagonists being propelled back into a dynastic era. The Marbridge report said that of more than 50 dramas in production at Hengdian World Studios in Zhejiang Province, more than 30 historical costume dramas had halted because of the new restrictions. Sarfts clampdown on historical dramas is occurring at the same time that it is limiting reality television programs, which it considers vulgar. The actions are part of a much wider push to better control culture that was announced last October by Communist Party leaders.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Omus Hirshbein, Classical Music Impresario, Dies at 77
description: Omus Hirshbein, a colorful, headstrong arts administrator who directed important concert series at Hunter College and the 92nd Street Y, founded the New York Chamber Symphony and held posts at the National Endowment for the Arts, died on Dec. 31 in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 6
description: The day in sports included Arkansas defeating Kansas State in the Cotton Bowl and another outdoor hockey game at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia.

title: Anne Tyng, Theorist of Architecture, Dies at 91
description: Anne Tyng, an architectural theorist who worked with the celebrated modern architect Louis I. Kahn and had a daughter with him, died on Dec. 27 at her home in Greenbrae, Calif. She was 91.

title: Republicans Gear Up for New Hampshire Primary
description: Republican candidates have, combined, attended dozens of campaign events in New Hampshire since leaving Iowa on Wednesday, fighting for a respectable finish in the top three.

title: A Conviction After Vancouver Riot
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Ryan Dickinson, a 20-year-old from suburban Coquitlam, accepted a plea bargain Friday in Vancouver Provincial Court and will be sentenced Feb. 7. His charges include participating in the June 15 riot after the Canucks lost Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals and breach of recognizance. He has been in jail since his arrest last month for violating a court-ordered curfew connected with a previous assault charge.

title: Japan: New Limits on Reactors
description: Japan said Friday that it will set more stringent age limits on nuclear reactors and require operators to prepare for severe accidents as part of legal changes in the wake of the nuclear crisis at Fukushima. The age limit could also be a step toward fulfilling a government promise to eventually phase out nuclear power in the quake-prone nation. Japan already requires utilities to conduct safety checks on reactors at 30 years, and again at 40 years, to stay in operation. Fresh legislation will set the legal lifespan of reactors at 40 years, though the government will still approve extensions on a case-by-case basis. Excluding the six damaged reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, 13 others in Japan will hit the 40-year limit in the next decade, according to the Ministry of Trade.

title: Fiji Lifts Martial Law, but Installs New Regulations
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Fijis military rulers on Saturday officially lifted a state of martial law that has been in place since 2009, setting the stage for public deliberations on a new constitution and a promised return to democratic elections within the next two years.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood in North America Edition
description: Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khans newest film, Don 2, has surpassed the 2011 record for the highest-grossing Bollywood movie in North America.

title: Its Nickis World
description: PERHAPS it was the brightly colored surgical mask that covered Nicki Minajs pout at the MTV Video Music Awards last August. Or maybe it was the neon puffball tunic, which made her look as if shed fallen into a bowl of Dippin Dots, that she wore to Carolina Herreras spring 2012 show in September. But few in 2011 could take their eyes off Ms. Minaj, the Technicolor Barbie with the big voice and an elastic smile.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Businesses including independent shops and banks in Kashmir Valley shut down Jan. 6 to protest power outages and the killing of a student during a protest. The strike was called by the Kashmir Economic Alliance, the areas business trade group (Greater Kashmir).

title: The Early Word: Optimism
description: In Todays Times:

title: A Prophet for a New Workplace
description: The business world is embracing social networks, both as work enablers and as products. Sites like LinkedIn keep people up on job opportunities, while professional friends on Facebook can keep us abreast of advances in our fields.

title: The Onion Spoofs Ryan and Sanchez
description: Why was so much chatter devoted to Rex Ryan and the Jets in these parts during a week when the Giants were preparing for the playoffs? Josh Levin put it well at Slate:

title: For the D-League, Improving Grades
description: The D-League has long been the path of choice for fringe prospects trying to prove themselves worthy of an N.B.A. roster spot, but over the last two seasons, a new demographic has emerged on the Ds call-up scene. While misfits and castoffs have always been D-League staples, the latest minor league trend has brought longtime N.B.A. players to the D-League to enact their comeback plans.

title: Slowed by Age and Injuries, Steelers Still Have an Iron Grip
description: PITTSBURGH  The obituary for a defense was swift and stinging.

title: Inside Dirt on the N.F.L. in 2012: Mayans, and Others, Get It Wrong
description: From the combine to the draft to the end of the 2012 season, our N.F.L. crystal ball has provided inside information on every transaction, touchdown and scandal.

title: Haitians Find Hope in Brazil
description: Hundreds of Haitian nationals seeking a better life in Brazil find themselves trapped at the Bolivian border.

title: New Hampshire Debates: Five Things to Watch
description: Mitt Romneys rivals are looking for a way to rattle him. They want a chance to slow his march toward the nomination before Tuesdays vote in New Hampshire. And they want to do it without giving him time to recover afterward.

title: Wary of Energy Drinks in an Adrenaline Sport
description: Bryan Fox and Austin Smith have watched the number of snowboarders  and companies that profit from them  balloon in the last decade. Realms where a snowboarder can carve clean, remote lines are shrinking. But Fox and Smith, close friends and professional snowboarders, recently found themselves alone on the front lines against energy drinks.

title: Far From the N.H.L., a League That Survived Hopes to Grow
description: In recent years, the Northeast has been fertile ground for hockey dreamers, with new, independent minor leagues striving to take root. Yet time and again, reality has stamped out hope. The five-team Mid-Atlantic Hockey League did not complete its inaugural season in 2007-8. The four-team Eastern Professional Hockey League lasted one year in 2008-9. The next year, the North East Professional Hockey League started with four teams, was down to three at the seasons start and lasted only 15 games.

title: Falcons Matt Ryan Doesnt Want Playoff Rerun
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Televisions at Matt Ryans house in nearby Duluth, if not turned off, have been locked lately into nonsports channels.

title: Tensions Run High in Australia
