Though certain looks from this prefall collection, like the tall black and white riding boots paired with a belted drop-waist dress, felt quite Courrges-like, the slouchy pants, padded biker jacket, animal print intarsias and singular column dress (white, floor-length, with a tiny peplum high on the waist) kept things from going too retro. Here, the aforementioned boots (key) are worked into a look that slips as easily into the designers oeuvre as it does alongside the labels classic box bag. The front piece on the sweater is mink and the skirt is leather with suede pockets.

Along with the chains original smashed four-ounce burger, pressed on the griddle to be thin and crisp, the new shop has a six-ounce Signature Steakburger made with organic beef and only gently pressed. His menu will offer smoked baby octopus salad, marinated charred mackerel and also chicken for two baked in salt with spaetzle. The approach in this intimate space is European; the room is accented with vintage pieces.The wine and beer lists emphasize Europe, too.

title: A Primer on the Many-Layered Fugue
description: Bach put everything he knew about writing fugues, which was everything there is to know about the matter, into The Art of Fugue, as he titled his collection of 14 fugues and 4 canons. Though Bach worked for years on the project, he never completed it: the final four-voice fugue was left unfinished at his death at 65 in 1750.

title: All the Colors of a Scriabin Rarity Thats Meant to Be Seen as Well as Heard
description: NEWARK  No hard, fast rule dictates that an orchestra has to engage in elaborate sleight of hand when presenting an unfamiliar work; still, there is something to be said for creating a useful context. A uniting theme, however basic, can provide a starting point for appraising a new or uncommon piece. Surrounding it with familiar music that is in some way related allows the audience to discover and apply its own connections.

title: A Last-Minute Substitution for Faust
description: The tenor Roberto Alagna is stepping in for an ailing Joseph Calleja in the title role of Faust, by Gounod, at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening, the Met said Monday afternoon. title: Deadly Viruses: Pro or Con?
description: Thanks so much to all who contributed to our lively  if somewhat technologically challenged  discussion about the scientists who made bird flu take wing. Responses reflected an unusually wide array of ideas, from the conviction that nothing in the world could justify experiments like those in question to the equally impassioned conviction that nothing should get in their way. Similarly, some argued that the data these experiments produced are of only marginal usefulness, while others felt they would prove as invaluable as Galileos discovery. But what, as Andrew S asked, is the most appropriate ethical framework for sorting through these claims? For those who might have more to say, well keep the comments open for a while longer. Readers, have at it!

title: Smart Tries Out a Pickup Line for Sunny Days
description: Introduced Monday, Jan. 9: Smart For-Us concept.

title: Finding a Way to Put a Zebra in Your Tank
description: NEW ORLEANS  Prowling the animal cages at the Audubon Zoo with tweezers and sandwich bags was an unusual and somewhat disconcerting experience for David A. Mullin and his graduate students.

title: Giving Windows on an iPad a Boost
description: LAS VEGAS  The iPad seems to be doing pretty well among business customers already. There could be even more of them, though, who would buy iPads if software like Microsoft Office and Windows ran well on the devices.

title: Spotlighting a Choreographer Through Some Classic Works
description: The mission of Taylor 2, the six-member budget version of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, is to bring Mr. Taylors works to places that may not be able to afford the main troupe. Its an honorable mission, which one group of dancers after another has been fulfilling admirably since 1993. But at the Pace University Schimmel Center for the Arts on Saturday (the second of two programs), the current crop looked decidedly junior varsity.

title: Painting Bold Promises at CBS With Bright Morning Colors
description: The news is back in morning news is the promise splashed across promos for CBS This Morning, but on CBS this Monday morning it was hard to find.

title: Herpes Vaccine Falls Short in Clinical Trial
description: The search for a vaccine to prevent infection with two types of herpes simplex, or H.S.V., is under way, but success is proving elusive. A new vaccine, previously thought to protect uninfected women who have infected partners, has now been found useless against one form, H.S.V.-2, in a double-blinded placebo-controlled trial.

title: His Story: A Writer of Words and Music
description: When the poet, novelist, piano player and spoken-word recording artist Gil Scott-Heron died unexpectedly last May, at 62, he left behind a prickly and galvanizing body of work. His best songs  The Revolution Will Not Be Televised, Whitey on the Moon, We Almost Lost Detroit  are rarely heard on classic-rock radio; theyre too eccentric and polemical and might kill a workingmans lunchtime buzz. But theyll still stop you in your tracks.

title: Nicotine Patch Helps Against Cognitive Impairment in Study
description: A nicotine patch worn for six months can improve attention, memory and mental processing in people with mild cognitive impairment, a clinical trial has found.

title: More Health Clinics Pop Up Inside Retailers
description: The growth of health clinics inside retail stores rebounded in 2011 and is poised for a second spring this year, driven by well-capitalized retailers and grocers, according to a new report.

title: Awards Lists Keep Em Guessing
description: LOS ANGELES  Youre nobody till somebody snubs you. Especially when it comes to this years film awards.

title: Remembering Tony Blankley
description: This is a personal note about a longtime friend to whom I owe so much.

title: Traffic Agent With Unpaid Tickets Is Arrested Over Tow
description: Updated, 6:42 p.m. | A traffic agent who owed more than $450 in parking tickets was arrested Monday morning in Brooklyn, accused of trying to stop her S.U.V. from being towed, the authorities said.

title: Ackman Plans Proxy Fight at Canadian Pacific
description: OTTAWA  The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman said Monday that he would wage a proxy battle to replace the directors and the chief executive of the Canadian Pacific Railway after it rejected his plan to bring in a former rival to run the company.

title: Where Outlandish Meets Landish
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  It may be best to stop reading this review right now. Otherwise you will know what to expect at the Museum of Jurassic Technology. And then, when you look through a magnifying glass and see a painted sculpture of Disneys Goofy standing on the head of a needle, or learn how the stage machinery of Baroque theaters created the illusion of flowing water, or are told that some South American bats seem to fly through solid objects, you wont have the same mixture of shock, marvel, delight and confusion as I did.

title: With Its 2-Seat Roadster, Mini Picks Up Where MG Left Off
description: Shown on Monday, Jan. 9: 2012 Mini Roadster.

title: After Long Gestation, Scion FR-S Makes Auto Show Debut
description: What is it? The name says it all, according to Toyota: FR-S stands for front-engine, rear-wheel-drive, sport. The 2-plus-2 coupe measures nearly a foot longer than a Corolla and carries decidedly sportier pretensions. Its Toyota-branded equivalent, the FT, was displayed at the Tokyo auto show in December, but Toyota clearly wants Scion to get a dose of performance cred, which was previously available only from the tC. The FR-S was previewed as a concept at the 2011 New York auto show.

title: Nicotine Gum and Skin Patch Face New Doubt
description: The nicotine gum and patches that millions of smokers use to help kick their habit have no lasting benefit and may backfire in some cases, according to the most rigorous long-term study to date of so-called nicotine replacement therapy.

title: A Night When All the Worlds Onstage
description: The world was fused at Globalfest on Sunday night. The sold-out event at Webster Hall was the ninth-annual world-music showcase, timed to coincide with the Association of Performing Arts Presenters annual convention: 12 acts from 5 continents. At Globalfest the old image of world music as ethnomusicological finds  pure local styles directly imported from out-of-the-way places  has given way to a more worldly music, played by artists who self-consciously decide what to mix. They select from their own heritage and countless other possibilities; after all, theyve got Internet connections themselves. Globalfest was recorded for NPR.

title: The C.E.S. No-Shows
description: Thousands of companies come to Las Vegas each year for the Consumer Electronics Show. But it is becoming interesting to see who skips it.

title: Acura ILX Concept: Honda Enlists Civic for Entry-Level Luxury Duty
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 9: 2013 Acura ILX design study.

title: Using Modern Tools to Reconstruct Ancient Life
description: ASHKELON, Israel  To the naked eye, the white, powdery substance appeared to be plaster. Thats what the professional and volunteer archaeologists at a dig in Israel concluded.

title: In Japan, a Rebuilt Island Serves as a Cautionary Tale
description: OKUSHIRI, Japan  On the night of July 12, 1993, the remote island of Okushiri was ripped apart by a huge earthquake and tsunami that now seem an eerie harbinger of the much larger disaster that struck northeastern Japan last March. Islanders still recall with horror how a wall of frothing black water raced out of the darkness to consume entire communities, leaving almost 200 people dead.

title: Tensions Resolved, Olbermann Plans Campaign Coverage on Current
description: Keith Olbermann will be absent from his nightly Countdown on Monday night, and the rest of this week, too.

title: New Cookbooks From Paula Deen
description: Paula Deen, below, the superstar Southern chef whose extravagant use of butter has inspired rants from fellow food celebrities like Anthony Bourdain, is going to be a busy woman over the next two years. In 2013 and 2014 she will release three e-books focusing on seasonal entertaining and two new cookbooks, her new publisher said. Ballantine Books, part of Random House, has lured back Ms. Deen after losing her to Simon & Schuster more than a decade ago. (Pamela Cannon, now an executive editor at Random House, discovered Ms. Deen in 1997 while dining at her restaurant, The Lady & Sons, in Savannah, Ga., and edited her first two cookbooks.) Gina Centrello, the president and publisher of the Random House Publishing Group, said in a statement, As her Random House family, we are especially thrilled to welcome Paula Deen back home where together we will build upon and expand her singular and remarkable brand.

title: Scientists Online Interviews Draw His Peers Out of Lecture Mode
description: The physicist Csar Hidalgo is not a late-night TV host, but he plays one on the Internet.

title: Rebirth of the Acura NSX?
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 9: Acura NSX concept.

title: For Huntsman, Mandarin Proves a Draw
description: HENNIKER, N.H.  Untold numbers of New Hampshire voters have tried to get a few words with the Republican presidential candidates barnstorming their state. But its likely that Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is the only one with whom some have conversed in Chinese.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,853 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Rescuers and a Hot Tech Job
description: Interesting things that New York Times reporters and editors found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: In Brazil, Officers of the Law, Outside the Law
description: NITERI, Brazil  Patrcia Acioli, a judge known for imprisoning corrupt police officers, pulled into the driveway of her home one August night in this city across the bay from Rio de Janeiro. Her pursuers arrived at the same time. Then they did their work, shooting her 21 times until her body lay crumpled in the seat of her car.

title: A Rising Tide of South Korean Golfers
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  On Wednesday nights before a tournament, K. J. Choi visits the Korean Baptist church closest to the course he is playing, a practice that dates to when he was the PGA Tours first and only full-time player from South Korea. In the familiar hymns, sung in his native tongue, Choi experiences a connection, a communion, that he struggled at first to forge on the tour, where the courses and the language were foreign to him.

title: Public vs. Private on the Campaign Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: Discouraging Start for Williamss Hall of Fame Prospects
description: Bernie Williams was the first homegrown core Yankee from the recent championship seasons to appear on the Hall of Fame ballot. The election results announced Monday were not encouraging.

title: Giants Find Missing Part for Rematch: Confidence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Early Monday afternoon, as the rookie cornerback Prince Amukamara was addressing a group of reporters in the Giants locker room, the veteran Jimmy Kennedy sneaked up behind the pack.

title: The London Olympics, Coming in 3D
description: LAS VEGAS  Panasonic and NBC announced on Monday that the network will broadcast the London Olympic Games in 3D. Of course, viewers need a 3D television to enjoy the show, but Panasonic undoubtedly hopes sports fanatics will feel compelled to buy new sets.

title: Maryland: Former Soldier Charged With Trying to Aid Terrorism
description: A former soldier from Maryland was charged Monday with trying to provide material support to a terrorist organization in Africa. Federal authorities say the soldier, Craig B. Baxam, 24, flew to Kenya last month with the goal of joining the militant terrorist group Al Shabab in Somalia. He converted to Islam shortly before dropping out of the United States Army in July, after four years of service, including in Iraq, federal authorities said. Mr. Baxam planned to donate money to Al Shabab, a violent militia group that opposes the Somalian government, authorities said. He faces a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison.

title: New Rental Service Focuses on Indie Film
description: If you have a new business that involves indie film, this is your moment to hustle  or at least to hire a publicist to hustle on your behalf. Sundance starts next week, and its a make-or-break moment for glom-on marketing.

title: Disney Movie Marketer Resigns After 20 Months
description: LOS ANGELES  M T Carney, Walt Disneys president of global movie marketing, resigned late Monday after a difficult 20 months on the job.

title: Optimism, but Mixed Results, at the Vanguard
description: DULUTH, Ga.  As Grace Mins eyes followed the flight of her serve toss, about two dozen spectators in folding chairs formed a single row at courtside. Most were friends and extended family, lending support.

title: Need a Mattress to Go With That TV? Youre in the Right Place
description: AFTER seeing countless wireless gadgets at the annual International Consumer Electronics Show, which begins Tuesday in Las Vegas, attendees may be surprised to encounter the Schick booth, where men in barbershop chairs will have their faces wrapped in hot towels and be shaved by barbers.

title: No Longer Starting, Lee Set Up Tigers Big Finish
description: NEW ORLEANS  During Jarrett Lees time at Louisiana State, he has had plenty of occasions to be mad and had plenty of opportunities to be ecstatic. Through them all, he has been stoic, even as his roller-coaster ride of a career has made him the focus of frequent criticism for many Tigers fans.

title: Alan Hatch
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Recession Holds Down Health Spending
description: WASHINGTON  National health spending rose a slight 3.9 percent in 2010, as Americans delayed hospital care, doctors visits and prescription drug purchases for the second year in a row, the Obama administration reported Monday.

title: TripAdvisor Abandons List of Dirtiest Hotels
description: EACH January in recent years, the online travel review site TripAdvisor.com has kicked up storms of publicity and protests by releasing its scathing lists of the dirtiest hotels in the world.

title: A Fine for Not Using a Biofuel That Doesnt Exist
description: WASHINGTON  When the companies that supply motor fuel close the books on 2011, they will pay about $6.8 million in penalties to the Treasury because they failed to mix a special type of biofuel into their gasoline and diesel as required by law.

title: N.F.L. Divisional Matchups: What the Film Says
description: Andy Benoit, who has contributed weekly film reviews for The Fifth Down this season, analyzes next weekends matchups:

title: Video: The Changing Nature of the Consumer Electronics Show
description: LAS VEGAS  The International Consumer Electronics Show has long enjoyed a central role in taking the pulse of the tech industry. But Microsoft recently announced that it would no longer exhibit at the show after this year. Other tech giants like Hewlett-Packard, Google and Facebook are keeping a low profile at the show, if they bother to show up at all. It all reflects shifts in the tech industry, as Nick Wingfield reported in Mondays New York Times.

title: Susan Patteson
description: Interviews from voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Pentagon Tries to Counter Cheap, Potent Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas new military strategy has focused fresh attention on an increasingly important threat: the use of inexpensive weapons like mines and cyberattacks that aim not to defeat the American military in battle but to keep it at a distance.

title: Where Are the Liberals?
description: Why arent there more liberals in America?

title: In South Carolina, Hopes of Passing a Crucial Test
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  The capacity crowd gathered to meet Rick Santorum at Chiefs Wings and Firewater Restaurant on Sunday night had squeezed Kerry Wood, the Santorum campaigns South Carolina state director, into the chilly rain near the parking lot.

title: Rusty McLear
description: Interviews from voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Oil Sands Foes Are Foes of Canada, Minister Says
description: In an unusual open letter released on Monday, Canadas natural resources minister charged that environmental and other radical groups used funding from foreign special interest groups to undermine Canadas national economic interest.

title: Jeanne Tofts
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: With Protesters on the Sidewalk, Gingrich Skips an Appearance
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  With a loud crowd of protesters amassed on the sidewalk, Newt Gingrich skipped an appearance at his campaign headquarters in New Hampshire, where about 100 volunteers and supporters waited for him on the eve of primary day.

title: Recovered Body Could Be Packers Assistants Son
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The 21-year-old son of the Green Bay Packers offensive coordinator was missing Monday, the same day that a body was recovered from a river in Oshkosh, where the man was last seen.

title: I.R.S. Renews Disclosure Program for Offshore Assets
description: After collecting $4.4 billion in two previous so-called voluntary disclosure programs for offshore accounts, the Internal Revenue Service said Monday that it would revive the program. Participants will pay as much as 27.5 percent of their most valuable offshore assets or their biggest overseas bank account. They also must disclose the banks and advisers that helped them escape United Sates tax laws.

title: Santorum Supporter Gets a Taste of the Big Leagues
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Rod Olsen, a stay-at-home father who lives in California, always wanted to work on a political campaign in New Hampshire. For him, the state was the Wrigley Field of politics, the iconic place where political junkies have to go at least once in their lives.

title: David Oliver
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Rob Glassett
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Josh McDaniels, Key Figure for the Broncos, Is Now a Patriot
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  Coach John Fox, though in his first year with the Broncos, has been around the N.F.L. long enough to view success with an appropriately gimlet eye. In the moments after Denver upset the Pittsburgh Steelers in the weekends most improbable playoff game, Fox was asked what he would have thought if someone had told him at the start of the season that he would be in this position now.

title: Peace Talks Are Discussed in a Session in Jordan
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian officials met in the Jordanian capital on Monday, their second session in less than a week, after peace talks had been stalled for more than a year. The encounter was kept at such a low profile, however, that it was almost as if it had not happened at all  attesting to the fragility of the contacts and the apparently minimal expectations each side has for progress.

title: The Digital Humanities and the Transcending of Mortality
description: This is a blog. There, Ive said it. I have been resisting saying it  I have always referred to this space as a column  not only because blog is an ugly word (as are clog, smog and slog), but because blogs are provisional, ephemeral, interactive, communal, available to challenge, interruption and interpolation, and not meant to last; whereas in a professional life now going into its 50th year I have been building arguments that are intended to be decisive, comprehensive, monumental, definitive and, most important, all mine.

title: Health and Home Field Are Two More Advantages for the Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  It may seem counterintuitive, but the Green Bay Packers  the defending Super Bowl champions, with a 15-1 record and a leading contender for the N.F.L.s Most Valuable Player award at quarterback  think they are being overlooked.

title: Chuck Clement
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: After Beyonc Gives Birth, Patients Protest Celebrity Security at Lenox Hill Hospital
description: The couple were visiting their twin daughters in the neonatal intensive care unit at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan on Friday night, as they have done daily since the babies premature birth on Dec. 28. But when they tried to leave the sixth-floor unit to go home to Brooklyn at about 11 p.m., the new mother, Rozz Nash-Coulon, recalled, a burly security guard suddenly blocked their way.

title: Linda Twombly
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Iraq: 16 Killed in Multiple Attacks
description: At least 16 people were killed across Iraq on Monday in car bombings, assassinations, roadside bomb blasts and attacks on security forces. The rash of seemingly unconnected attacks stoked fears that disparate insurgent groups from around Iraq are trying to sow sectarian violence by exploiting the uncertainty and instability of the countrys political crisis. On Monday, two car bombs exploded in Shiite areas of Baghdad  one near a mosque, the other near a market  killing 12 people and wounding 50. Earlier in the day, a bank manager was assassinated outside her home in a middle-class Baghdad neighborhood. In the oil-rich city of Kirkuk, two Kurdish security forces were killed in a checkpoint attack.

title: A Merger Once Scoffed At Bears Fruit in Detroit
description: DETROIT  The unlikely union of Chrysler and its Italian parent, Fiat, is beginning to produce new vehicles that combine the talents of both companies.

title: Steve Guertler
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: BP Makes Amends
description: Today, Im going to say some nice things about BP and some not so nice things about the lawyers who are suing BP. Please dont spill your coffee.

title: Wanted or Not: Alternative-Fuel Cars Flood Auto Show
description: DETROIT  In the race to claim ever-higher fuel-economy numbers and keep up with government regulations, automakers are rolling out hybrids and electric cars aplenty at this weeks Detroit auto show.

title: Ad Battle Heats Up for Contest in South
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Campaigns and the super PACs that support them are signaling where they think the real primary fight is, and it is not here.

title: A Jet Lag Cure New to Airport Security
description: IM a proud dad, and I hate missing my childrens sporting events because of travel. But I do try to get updates, no matter where I am.

title: The Knife in the Carry-On
description: For most business travelers, the post-Sept. 11 restrictions on carrying sharp objects onto planes are minor inconveniences. But for those who work in an industry focused on sharp or dangerous objects, business trips can be prone to problems without proper planning.

title: Paying a Price, Long After the Crime
description: IN 2010, the Chicago Public Schools declined to hire Darrell Langdon for a job as a boiler-room engineer, because he had been convicted of possessing a half-gram of cocaine in 1985, a felony for which he received probation. It didnt matter that Mr. Langdon, a single parent of two sons, had been clean since 1988 and hadnt run into further trouble with the law. Only after The Chicago Tribune wrote about his case did the school system reverse its decision and offer him the job.

title: Andreas Reif
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: UniCredits Weak Share Offering a Poor Omen in Europe
description: LONDON  UniCredit, Italys largest bank, is undergoing a trial by fire in the stock market, underscoring the challenges that European banks face in trying to right themselves.

description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Lottery Numbers
Coachella Festival Announces Lineup
description: The Black Keys, Radiohead, Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre will headline the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April, according to the events Twitter page.

title: Voting in N.H. Opens as Romney Fends Off Attacks
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Mitt Romney fought to keep an upper hand in the Republican presidential race on Tuesday as his rivals sought to slow his march to the nomination and raise doubts about his electability by branding him as a job-killing corporate villain.

title: Egypts Women Find Power Still Hinges on Men
description: CAIRO  At first Samira Ibrahim was afraid to tell her father that Egyptian soldiers had detained her in Tahrir Square in Cairo, stripped off her clothes, and watched as she was forcibly subjected to a virginity test.

title: Laugh During Wartime
description: Americans remember the Civil War for the carnage it caused, the people it liberated and the nation it rebuilt. Rarely do they remember it for the comedy it inspired.

title: A Peek at Easier Travel at Kennedys Terminal 4
description: Passengers traveling through Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport in recent months could be excused for confusing it with a maze under construction.

title: U.S. Strategy Points to Threat of Cheap but Potent Weapons
description: President Obama and his national security team are drawing attention to what they see as a growing threat to the American military. In an article in Tuesdays issue of The Times, Thom Shanker reports on the administrations prediction that security challenges in the coming decade will be defined by the use of relatively inexpensive weapons to keep American forces at a distance, rather than defeat them outright.He writes:

title: Alexis Weissenberg, Pianist of Fire and Ice, Dies at 82
description: Alexis Weissenberg, a charismatic Bulgarian-born pianist known for his thundering aggressiveness and rational detachment at the keyboard, and for his unapologetic defense of those traits in interviews, died on Sunday in Lugano, Switzerland. He was 82.

title: With Lumia 900, Nokia and Microsoft Bid for Smartphone Relevance
description: LAS VEGAS  What is it with Jan. 9 and smartphones?

title: The Corporate Candidates
description: The more Mitt Romney pretends to empathize with the millions of Americans who are struggling in this economy, the less he seems to understand their despair. And the rest of the Republican field seems to have no more insight into the concerns of most voters than he does.

title: Olympus Sues Executives Over Covering Up Losses
description: The scandal-tainted Olympus Corporation said it was suing 19 current and former executives over their roles in a $1.7 billion cover-up of losses after an independent panels report into management involvement in the fraud.

title: A Paradox of Smaller Wall Street Paychecks
description: Is Wall Street cutting bonuses enough?

title: Drilling Critics Face a Divide Over the Goal of Their Fight
description: With a deadline looming this week for the public to weigh in on gas drilling in New York State, the antifracking movement itself has become divided over what its goal should be: securing the nations toughest regulations, or winning an outright ban?

title: Renewed Sparring Over Scottish Independence Movement
description: LONDON  The smoldering issue of Scottish independence has ignited again, this time in a political context that appears to give Scottish nationalists at least an outside chance of gaining popular support for the end of Scotlands constitutional ties with Britain in a referendum among Scottish voters within the next two or three years.

title: Nigerians Protest Rise in Oil Prices
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Tens of thousands of Nigerians took to the streets in cities across the country on Monday to protest a sudden sharp rise in oil prices after the government abruptly ended fuel subsidies. At the same time, a national strike over the oil price increase shut down much of the country.

title: A Big Check, and Gingrich Gets a Big Lift
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  For weeks this winter, as Newt Gingrichs presidential hopes faltered under the weight of millions of dollars in attack ads paid for by backers of Mitt Romney, a small group of Gingrich supporters quietly lobbied for help from one of the richest men in America: Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner and Mr. Gingrichs longtime friend and patron.

title: Violence Continues in Syria
description: The Arab League is failing the Syrian people. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria grudgingly agreed to the leagues peace plan last month, but his brutal 10-month crackdown against mostly peaceful protesters shows no signs of easing. To have any chance of stopping the bloodshed, the league  backed by the international community  needs to get tougher with the butcher in Damascus.

title: Mr. Menendezs Missing Blue Slip
description: Senator Robert Menendezs decision to hold up President Obamas nomination of Patty Shwartz, a well-regarded federal magistrate judge, to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, has the unsavory flavor of political revenge.

title: Mormon Churchs Plans for Land Upset Harlem
description: The wider world does not often glimpse the internal disputes of the Mormon Church. Formally known as the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the fast-growing religion is expanding in places as far-flung as Africa and Latin America, but most big decisions are still made centrally by a church hierarchy in Salt Lake City.

title: Gov. Gregoire Comes Around
description: Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington showed her admirable political evolution last week when she urged her state to legalize same-sex marriage. Eight years ago, she was wary, saying the state was not ready to support such historic change. Four years ago, she said she would leave it to the churches to make that call.

title: Sawa and Messi Are FIFAs Players of Year
description: Martas five-year run as the top female player in the world came to an end Monday in Zurich when FIFA awarded its Ballon dOr to midfielder Homare Sawa, who helped Japan win the Womens World Cup last summer in Germany.

title: A New Race of Mercy to Nome, This Time Without Sled Dogs
description: NOME, Alaska  In the winter of 1925, long after this Gold Rush boomtown on the Bering Sea had gone bust, diphtheria swept through its population of 1,400. Medicine ran dangerously low, and there was no easy way to get more. No roads led here, flight was ruled out and Norton Sound was frozen solid.

title: U.S. Inquiry of MF Global Gains Speed
description: The investigation into MF Global is intensifying as federal authorities unearth new details and confront potential obstacles in their hunt for roughly $1.2 billion in customer money that disappeared from the brokerage firm.

title: Tuesday: Cordial Relations
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I already know what youre thinking. Youre thinking that TOILET PAPER would have made a spiffy theme entry. I agree. Unfortunately, the long theme entries here are 10s, not 11s, so Im guessing the bathroom tissue got flushed (sorry).

title: Ground Game Determines Candidates Strength
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The 2012 primary campaign has been by far the most volatile on record, with one candidate after another surging to the front of the pack and then falling back again.

title: Where Is Europe?
description: Where is Europe? You might as well ask: What is Europe? For it is a concept as well as a continent, and the borders of both oscillate wildly. For the ancient Persians, it was that small stepping stone separating them from Greece. In the Middle Ages, it became virtually synonymous with Christendom. A relatively recent and generally unaccepted theory sees Europe spanning half the globe, from Iceland to the Bering Strait, nearly touching Alaska.

title: Please Hold the Cheese
description: A charge of pious baloney from the king of sanctimonious salami: that was the taste of Debate Weekend, during which Newt Gingrich of all people called out Mitt Romney for larded self-aggrandizement. Takes one lunchmeat to know another.

title: Theres No Letting Go of the Girl He Stole
description: Joseph Incognito had the scare of his life seven months ago. Returning home one afternoon, he was told by residents of the apartment building that his wife had just died. He arrived on his floor to see a stretcher and emergency services workers in the hallway. He said he felt as if he was about to have a heart attack  until he realized that the dead person was not his wife, but a next-door neighbor.

title: A Developer Between Legal Clouds
description: This is corruptions high season in New York.

title: Daley Stepping Down in Rare White House Shake-Up
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced Monday that the White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, was stepping down, jolting the top ranks of his administration less than a year before he faces a difficult re-election. Mr. Daley will be replaced by Jacob J. Lew, the budget director and a seasoned Washington insider with ties to Capitol Hill.

title: Inspectors Say Iran Is Enriching Uranium at Mountain Site
description: Atomic inspectors in Vienna confirmed Monday that Iran has begun enriching uranium at a new plant carved out of a mountain, an act of defiance that comes amid rising tensions between Washington and Tehran over oil revenues and global sanctions.

title: Guantnamo, 10 Years Later
For Comptrollers Allies, a Day Without an Award Is a Rarity
description: In New York City, most city officials, a couple times a month, honor community organizations with special suitable-for-framing commendations, praising them for distinguished leadership or dedicated service.

title: Barbara Bishop
description: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Russian Child Disappears Into Pipe After Falling Into a Sinkhole
description: MOSCOW  A woman pushing her child in a baby stroller suffered a horrific accident in a provincial Russian city over the weekend when a section of sidewalk suddenly opened into a yawning crater under her feet, the result of a sinkhole from a broken pipe.

title: Plan for Trump to Run a Bronx Golf Course Has Critics
description: The dream seemed readily attainable: take 222 acres of blighted parkland in the Bronx and convert it into the citys first championship golf course, one capable of playing host to the United States Open on the banks of the East River.

title: A Struggle for Anthony and the Knicks, but Also a Third Straight Win
description: Carmelo Anthony was burdened with foul trouble, turnover trouble, shot-making trouble and, most likely, achy body trouble, although that was the one difficulty that was neither listed nor confessed on an anxious Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Iran Calls Video Games Part of C.I.A. Plot
description: According to Iranian state television, a former United States marine who was convicted of spying on Iran and sentenced to death on Monday was also involved in a nefarious plot to brainwash the youth of the Middle East using an unlikely tool: video games.

title: From Boardwalk to Barrio, Los Angeles Cracks Down
description: LOS ANGELES  On the boardwalk of Venice Beach, the trinkets seem endless. There are glass pipes, copper necklaces, feather earrings and painted wooden skulls.

title: Confirmed: U.S. Will Play Italy in February
description: U.S. Soccer on Monday confirmed the worst-kept secret about its national team, announcing that the United States would play Italy in Genoa on Feb. 29. That is the last official FIFA match date for friendlies before June, when the Americans start World Cup qualifying and the Italians begin play in the European championship.

title: Microsoft Leaves C.E.S. on a Quiet Note
description: LAS VEGAS  Microsoft created low expectations for its keynote speech at this years International Consumer Electronics Show, when it announced that it would stop exhibiting at the show and that Steve Ballmer, its chief executive, would no longer speak at the event. It did not disappoint.

title: Taking the Rematch, and the Title
description: NEW ORLEANS  With distinctively bland uniforms, a defense loaded with stalwarts and an offense predicated on smash-mouth football, Alabama remains one of the quintessentially old-school programs in college football.

title: Miguel Terekhov, Dancer With Ballets Russes, Dies at 83
description: Miguel Terekhov, a dancer with the two leading Ballets Russes troupes of the 1940s and 50s and a co-founder, with his wife, of the School of Dance at the University of Oklahoma, one of Americas leading university dance programs, died on Jan. 3 at the home of a daughter in Richardson, Tex. He was 83 and lived in Oklahoma City.

title: Crimson Tide Receive Big Performance From McCarron, an Unlikely Source

description: Lawyers for a Manhattan man charged with plotting terrorist bombings are negotiating a plea agreement with prosecutors, though the defense characterized the discussions as routine in criminal cases.

description: Hey, I get it: Republicans have to reject and condemn virtually everything President Obama proposes, no matter how noble, to satisfy their base. This is our political predicament.

title: Chinese Exports Grow, but Imports Show Signs of Weakening
description: BEIJING  Exports from China rose 13.4 percent in December compared with a year ago, while import growth unexpectedly slowed to 11.8 percent because of lower prices and moderating domestic demand, government data released Tuesday showed.

It started like most news conferences do, in that key figures were there to answer questions and reporters were there to ask them.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 10, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Jan. 10, 2000 | AOL and Time Warner Announce Merger
description: On Jan. 10, 2000, the Internet service company AOL and the media giant Time Warner announced that AOL would buy Time Warner for more than $160 billion in the largest merger in corporate history.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 10, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article With This Torch, I Thee Weld.'

title: Aung San Suu Kyi Confirms She Will Run for Parliament
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, confirmed on Tuesday that she would run for a seat in the countrys new Parliament in a by-election scheduled for April in which her party, the National League for Democracy, will enter the new political structure for the first time.

title: North Korea Announces It Will Release Prisoners
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Tuesday that it would release prisoners in its first special amnesty in seven years, a day after soldiers paraded in the capital, Pyongyang, vowing to become rifles and bombs to defend the countrys new leader, Kim Jong-un. The military rally in Pyongyang on Monday and the special pardon, effective from Feb. 1, came as North Korea escalated a campaign to consolidate support for Mr. Kim.

title: Photographing Politics in Changing Times
description: Jim Wilson started at The New York Times in 1980, working primarily as a staff photographer and a photo editor. Covering politics over the decades, he has seen tremendous changes  both in the style of the campaigns and the technology he has used to photograph them. In recent weeks, hes been covering the Republican presidential campaign in Iowa and New Hampshire, focusing almost entirely on Mitt Romney. He spoke with James Estrin from Manchester, N.H. Their conversation had been edited.

title: On Lens: Times Photographer Jim Wilson in New Hampshire
description: Jim Wilson covered his first presidential primary in 1976, shooting for The Charlotte Observer. Covering politics over the decades, he has seen tremendous changes  both in the style of the campaigns and the technology used to photograph them.

title: Pakistani Judges Press Premier to Defy President
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The political and legal crisis in Pakistan took a new turn on Tuesday when the Supreme Court threatened to dismiss Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani for failing to comply with court orders to reopen corruption cases against his political boss: President Asif Ali Zardari.

title: What if Your Parent Ran for President?
description: Four of Mitt Romneys five sons are actively engaged in helping their fathers campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, as are the adult daughters of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. If one of your parents were to run for president, would you work on his or her campaign? Would you want your role to be highly public and visible, or would you prefer to stay behind the scenes?

title: Olympus Sues Executives Over Cover-Up, but Does Not Dismiss Them
description: TOKYO  Olympus said on Tuesday that it was suing 19 current and former executives and board members, including its current president, for around $50 million over an accounting scheme to hide losses going back more than a decade.

title: From Rebels to Rulers
description: JOHANNESBURG  Africas oldest liberation movement, the African National Congress (A.N.C.), held a lavish birthday bash last weekend to celebrate its founding 100 years ago. More than 40 heads of state gathered in the small church in the small city of Bloemfontein, the A.N.C.s birthplace, to celebrate the partys role in defeating white-minority rule and apartheid. And deservedly: the A.N.C.s accomplishments as a liberation movement are extraordinary.

title: The Early Word: Replaced
Tattoos, Through Time: A New Museum for Amsterdam
description: In Amsterdam, which claims to have the greatest number of museums per square mile in the world, few topics are left unexplored. There is a museum that delves into sex, another on war (or at least the Dutch resistance), and a museum dedicated, of course, to marijuana. Last fall, a museum opened with a focus on another topic that rarefied institutions generally avoid: tattoos.

title: Packers on Top in  Total Passing Value
description: The Packers, the Saints and the Patriots have three of the best passing offenses in N.F.L. history.

description: Now that the holiday season is history, it is clear that the Kindle Fire did substantially better than many forecasts.

title: A Brooklyn Tea Company Backed by a Socialist President
description: Forget its mild-mannered reputation: tea is not for the faint of heart. Last year, the United States tea industry brought in $6.5 billion thanks to a roster of heavy hitting, fiercely competitive brands, ranging from Honest Tea to Tazo and old-time stalwarts like Lipton.

title: Is Mark Wahlberg the Greatest Actor of His Generation?
description: While undertaking my extensive research in order to compose five haiku poems on the career of Mark Wahlberg, I came across this surprising (to me) fact: Wahlberg, the 40-year-old actor, successful producer, onetime rapper, loquacious friend to animals and former Calvin Klein model, has not one but two Oscar nominations to his credit. One is for Best Supporting Actor for The Departed in 2007, and one came in 2011 for his role as a producer of the Best Picture-nominated The Fighter, in which he also starred.

title: In New Ads, Health Department Offers Super-Sized Warnings
description: The latest ads from New York Citys health department warning against the dangers of sodas and fast food may not be as arresting as its previous public-service admonitions, but they are not too subtle.

title: Voters Voices: In New Hampshire
description: The Times asked voters in New Hampshire who they were planning on voting for prior to Tuesdays primary.

title: Syrian Leader Vows Iron Fist to Crush Conspiracy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In his first public address in months, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria lashed out on Tuesday at the Arab League for isolating his country, mocked Syrian rebels as traitors and vowed to subdue what he said was a foreign-backed plot against his country.

title: Given Room, Tottenham Runs Toward the Top
description: LONDON  In a sense, Englands soccer season and Tottenham Hotspurs rise toward the top of the Premier League are two strands of a nation trying to get back what seemed lost.

title: From India, the $1 Doctors Visit

description: LONDON  Jasjit Bhattal, chief executive of Nomura Holdings wholesale banking division, retired on Tuesday after less than a year in the position.

description: LAS VEGAS  A feature added to the Cobra iRadar detector may make your smartphone smart enough to help you avoid a ticket.

description: A judge in Belfast on Tuesday rejected an attempt by Sean Quinn, once considered Irelands richest man, to declare bankruptcy in Northern Ireland rather than in his home country, where terms are tougher.

title: Kirchners False Positive
description: BUENOS AIRES  Last week, I took a look at President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchners cancer diagnosis and how she has personalized power far too much. On Saturday, Argentinians were stunned to learn that, after removing the presidents thyroid gland, doctors discovered she didnt have cancer after all but rather a benign tumor. Following the initial relief, doubts quickly set in: despite assurances that such misdiagnoses can happen, many Kirchner critics cited the episode as another example of why the governments words cant be trusted.

title: Bentley Continental V-8s Trace Family Ties to Germany
description: Shown Monday, Jan. 9: 2012 Bentley Continental GT V-8 and Continental GTC V-8.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: 3-D Olympics and Clearing the Way for Blue Ivy
description: NBC will broadcast the 2012 Olympics from London in 3-D, the network and Panasonic announced at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The companies did not announce which pay-TV providers would offer enhanced Olympics coverage, Multichannel News reported, but presumably Comcast  which owns NBCUniversal  will be in the mix, along with DirecTV, which has aimed to be the leading provider of 3DTV in the U.S.

description: Shown on Monday, Jan. 9: Volvo XC60 Plug-In Hybrid concept.

description: New Hampshire voters began casting ballots in the nations first primary.

title: Daily Report: Nokia and Microsoft Unveil an Ambitious Phone
description: Monday was a big day for smartphones at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. AT&T talked about new smartphones that would run on its fast 4G network, including the Titan II from HTC. And Nokia, as expected, unveiled the Lumia 900, Nick Wingfield reported from the show. That phone, which runs Microsofts Windows Phone operating system, represents a bid by Microsoft and Nokia to return to relevance in the smartphone market, after being marginalized by Apple and Googles Android system.

title: WebMD Takes Down For-Sale Sign
description: The online health company WebMD said on Tuesday that it had taken itself off the auction block, after failing to attract satisfactory offers from potential buyers.

description: Overview of the new model.

title: Questioning a New Perspective in Times Square
description: Over the weekend, Chinas state-run news agency, Xinhua, wagged a stern finger at the United States, warning it not to recklessly practice militarism or resort to war mongering in its new defense strategy of expanding the American presence in Asia and the Pacific.

title: Google Adds Posts From Its Social Network to Search Results
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Googles popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google  conversations and photos posted by their friends.

title: Snoop Dogg Busted at Same Border Crossing That Snared Willie Nelson
description: If its your job to plan the touring schedule of rebellious rock, hip-hop and country musicians, you might consider organizing future itineraries to avoid the Sierra Blanca highway checkpoint near El Paso. It was there, The Associated Press reported, that the rapper Snoop Dogg was arrested on Saturday for a misdemeanor drug charge, which might not be newsworthy in and of itself, except that Willie Nelson was busted at that same border crossing in 2010.

title: Songbirds as  a Casualty of Warming
description: As the United States experiences a snow shortage, researchers have released a study showing that declining snowfall in the mountainous regions of Arizona is causing a cascading series of effects that are proving devastating to songbirds .

description: Republican presidential candidates in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

title: Somber Tribute in Trenton After Assemblys Top Republican Dies
description: The frenzy had run long into the night at the New Jersey State House on Monday as lawmakers hurried to squeeze through final bills before the clock ran out on the last day of the legislative session.

title: Times errors: Irans nukes, SFs voting
description: The Times published 3,500 corrections last year, a huge volume that in itself requires a great deal of work to shepherd into print. I usually agree with its decisions about what to correct and not correct, although there are sometimes cases where The Timess judgment call and mine are not the same. Here are a couple of recent instances:

title: A Tighter Leash on Exotic Pets
description: MACON, Mo.  The man raised a tawny ball of fluff above his head, its black button eyes seeming to widen as it took in the audience surrounding the ring.

title: With Romney Under Attack, Private Equity Fights Back
description: It was a long-held fear of Wall Streets private equity titans. If Mitt Romney won the Republican nomination in 2012, the industry would come under intense scrutiny and withering attacks from his opponents.

title: Skiers, Take Heart! There Is Snow if You Know Where to Look
description: A LACK of snow across much of the United States has ski resorts from Lake Tahoe to Vermont scrambling to make enough on their own.

title: A Rare Glimpse Inside the Ivy Leagues Academic Index
description: In an article published on Christmas Day in The New York Times, I described specific elements of the mysterious Academic Index, a tool used by Ivy League institutions  and increasingly other colleges and universities  to measure the basic academic qualifications of recruited athletes. The Academic Index, created in the 1980s and never disclosed publicly by the institutions themselves, uses a formula that assigns each recruit a number based on his or her standardized tests scores and high school grade point average.

title: Fatal Stampede in South Africa Points Up University Crisis
description: JOHANNESBURG  They lined up well before dawn, some driving from the deep countryside with bags of fluffy blankets and neatly packed sandwiches, to wait for the gates to a new life to open. They hoped for a shot at a coveted spot at one of South Africas public universities, and with it a chance to escape the indignity of joblessness that afflicts more than a third of the nation. By morning, the line was more than a mile long.

title: Dispatches From the Annual Designers Party
description: DETROIT  In addition to the teeming variety of car paintings, neon Porsche signs, race-car parts and other automotive bric-a-brac arranged throughout Camilo Pardos loft on Woodward Avenue, there were two notable newcomers.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Hudson Independent: In Tarrytown, N.Y., an award-winning coffeehouse, Coffee Labs, fights for the right to let dogs hang out.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Big City Book Club: A Walker in the City
description: I am usually suspicious of memoirs produced by writers who have not yet reached middle age, but Kazin, like so many of his provenance and generation, seemed to possess a voice of centenarian authority as a young man. At 26, he had audaciously established himself as a significant literary critic with On Native Ground, his magnum opus on American letters of the first half of the 20th century. His writing hardly betrayed a tentative hand.

title: Who Fires Whom?
description: Aaron Carroll has an excellent analysis of Mitt Romneys faux pas on firing people. No, Romney didnt actually say that he enjoys firing people  but what he really did say, that competition works in health care because you can fire your insurance company, was actually worse. Carroll:

title: MKZ Concept Is the Next Step in Lincolns Reinvention
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 10: Lincoln MKZ Concept.

title: Doing His Best De Niro Impression, in Front of the Real De Niro
description: Moments before Robert De Niro sat next to him, Jean Dujardin was trying out his De Niro impression. Mr. Dujardin, the handsome, elastic-faced French star of The Artist, was at the New York Film Critics Circle awards dinner on Monday night, where The Artist won best director and best film. The event capped off a whirlwind day that included a lunch with the publicist Peggy Siegal and the taping of an appearance on Charlie Rose.

title: Other Voices: The Night it Snowed Grebes in Utah
description: Suzie Gilbert, a friend and neighbor, has for many years been a hard-working bird rehabilitator, a career described beautifully in her recent book Flyaway. She also recently launched a blog, The Crooked Wing, and alerted me to a post on a remarkable occurrence last month in Utah, when thousands of migrating eared grebes, evidently disoriented by a storm, began crash landing on roads, parking lots and the like  surfaces they apparently mistook for water. They can only take flight from water, making such landings a death sentence for those that survived the impact.

title: Just One Look | Givenchy
description: This prefall collection is all about the best of Givenchy, the house designer Ricardo Tisci said at yesterdays presentation. Inserting a mix of what Tisci named American 1950s housewife and French 70s style into the best of our mens, womens and couture, he delivered a look that is all tough and refined and, literally, ready to wear now and for seasons to come. Hits include pieces featuring a subtle paillette print, a herringbone and cashmere suit, wool jackets stiffened with mens fabrications, then wrapped in places with the softest organza, and this expertly tailored croc-trimmed tuxedo. Worth noting also are the collections elongating boots, furry baseball caps and sharp talon ear studs (see: editors swooning).

title: Businessmen and Economics
description: A brief thought on something Ill try to expand on later. Leaving aside all the questions about what Mitt Romney did or didnt do at Bain  and about his self-aggrandizing double standard  theres an even broader question: why does anyone believe that success in business qualified someone to make economic policy?

title: The Keys to the Cos
description: Here is a series of vignettes from Bill Cosbys 50-year television career, showcasing examples of what has made him so good for so long.

title: Leading Off: Bad Season Ends Worse
description: If you were trying to get the college football system torn up and thrown out, you couldnt have orchestrated the end of this season any more persuasively. Yes, Alabama took all the drama out of who should be No. 1 with its 21-0 victory over thought-to-be-unbeatable Louisiana State Monday night, but what a small victory that turned out to be. It capped the year of Jerry Sandusky and Joe Paternos fall, of Ohio States probation forming the other big rapids in a raging river of ethical failures and misplaced priorities. It came at the end of a string of uninspired, made-for-bad-TV bowls, played so far after the season ended that even the major players needed name tags. And the finale was a conference rematch about as attractive as a Kris Humphries-Kim Kardashian reunion.

title: Mining Cosbys Golden Past
description: For a while now, Bill Cosby has been at the point in his career where people just want to shower him with accolades. A Kennedy Center honor in 1998. The Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2002. The Mark Twain Prize for American Humor in 2009.

title: Gingrich Goes Negative in Anti-Romney Ad
description: Newt Gingrich has officially done away with the shades of gray in his anti-Mitt Romney ads.

title: Toyota NS4 Concept

title: What if Insurers Didnt Pay for Crashes Caused by Texting?
description: Last month, the National Transportation Safety Board called for a nationwide ban on the use of cellphones and other portable electronic devices while driving.

title: The Bright Spot in Tech I.P.O.s: Enterprise
description: When it comes to initial public offerings of high-tech companies, maybe low profile is better.
