Geithner pressed Chinese senior leaders on Wednesday to join an American-led campaign to reduce sharply Irans lucrative oil exports because of its nuclear program. title: The Breakfast Meeting: The Spielberg Exception and Whos Illin?
description: That Mitt Romneys victory in the New Hampshire primary was considered all but assured even before the voting began on Tuesday didnt stop the news coverage from going into overdrive, Brian Stelter reports. But the operation appeared to be running on fumes. Once a winner was crowned  at 8 p.m., precisely when all polls were closed  the topic turned to second place. That, too, was over early, with Ron Paul declared the runner-up in that same hour. The focus then turned to South Carolina, and how Mr. Romney would fare in a state that would test his conservative credentials: CNN had already assembled a group of undecided Republicans there, Mr. Stelter writes, while Fox News promoted its debate there on Monday.

title: Icahn Drops Bid for Commercial Metals
description: Carl C. Icahn struck out in his effort to buy the Commercial Metals Company, announcing on Wednesday that he was withdrawing his $1.7 billion bid to take over the metal recycler.

title: Feel the Expansion
description: The WaPo has a heartrending story on the suffering being imposed on ordinary Greeks. So much for the doctrine of expansionary austerity.

title: Image of the Day: January 11
Twenty-Two Is Quite Enough: Comprehensive James Bond Boxed Set Is Planned
description: If you had to limit yourself to just one James Bond-related purchase for your Q-approved high-end home entertainment system, which would you pick? An early Sean Connery classic like Goldfinger? A contemporary Daniel Craig reboot like Casino Royale? Or what about a boxed set of nearly every Bond film thats been released over the last half-century? If you fall into that last category (and, presumably, have the financial backing of Her Majestys government) there will soon be a DVD collection to suit your refined tastes. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and 20th Century Foxs home entertainment division announced that they are planning to sell a boxed set called Bond 50, celebrating 50 years of the spy-movie franchise and containing Blu-ray versions of the 22 canonical James Bond films that have so far been released, starting with Dr. No (1962).

title: Albert Brooks Finds a New Use for His Characters Backstory
description: One of the scene-stealers at the New York Film Critics Circle dinner on Monday was the best-supporting-actor winner, Albert Brooks, whose kudos began with an impromptu shout-out from Aaron Sorkin.

title: Face Time | Hannah Ware
description: If you are not yet familiar with the actress Hannah Ware, I highly suggest you read on. Hailing from England, where she modeled for a while, she recently discovered her true callingacting. I met up with her at her Brooklyn apartment while she was on hiatus from shooting Boss, a dark drama on the Starz network in which she plays Emma, the estranged daughter of Chicagos mayor (Kelsey Grammer). The show is up for a Golden Globe this weekend, and Ware is looking forward to joining her castmates on the red carpet. She will no doubt be sporting a stylish ensemble, and her makeup will be fresh and modern, because, as you will see, this lady has great taste!

description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Turn on the local news or a country music station and you cannot miss them: political ads insisting why one candidate (probably Mitt Romney or Newt Gingrich) is a political charlatan. Then there are the more flattering ones that compare candidates to lionized figures of the conservative movement like Ronald Reagan.

title: In Mexico, Violence Scars the Game
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  The Mexican league restarted last weekend after its winter break, and it may have also reached a point of no return in violent incidents associated with, but peripheral, to the sport. The incidents also may help Mexicans overcome their reluctance to discuss unpleasant subjects, especially when it comes to soccer, previously a refuge from the countrys all-too violent reality.

title: Daily Report: Enterprise Computing at C.E.S.
description: While the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is for, well, consumer electronics, a number of items were displayed that will be making their way into the workplace. title: Leading Off: Have the Raiders Gone Sane?
description: At first blush, the news that the Raiders have fired a coach is hardly notable. Firings in Al Davisland were such an annual event it was probably printed on the team calendars. Heck, if they fired one in the middle of training camp, most of the N.F.L. would simply sigh. The Raiders have been the leagues unintentional reality show for so long, the shock value had run out on crazy.

Behind the scenes, atomic insiders have long told horror stories of risky practices and security flaws that might let the crucial ingredients for nuclear weapons fall into the wrong hands.

title: Set Faces to Stunned: William Shatner Is Coming Back to Broadway
description: The last time William Shatner was featured on a Broadway stage, the original productions of The Sound of Music and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying were still playing nearby and a star trek was not much more than a gleam in the eye of President John F. Kennedy (or maybe Gene Roddenberry). Now, 50 years after he played Paul Sevigne in the 1961 staging of A Shot in the Dark and went on to a fairly prolific acting career, Mr. Shatner, 80, is making a return voyage to Broadway in a one-man show that will begin performances next month.

description: Terrence Duffy is the executive chairman of the CME Group.

description: Michael Lewiss book about the 1996 presidential election, Trail Fever (since republished as Losers), includes this description of the attendees at a banquet for Republicans in New Hampshire: Every ounce of being they have left over after pledging allegiance to the United States and singing the national anthem goes into despising the United States government.

description: Mondays Complaint Box reader submission from Bill Stoller, of Pleasantville, N.Y., touched on the most delicate of subjects  death.

title: Economic Woes Loom Larger as G.O.P. Heads South
description: NORTH, S.C.  The grim just gets grimmer here at the Edisto Grocery, where all day long people with not enough work come to eat $2.25 fried bologna sandwiches, pick up some horse feed and complain about the price of diesel.

title: Thorny Creatures
description: Tomi Ungerer has long advocated elevating representatives of the horrid-creature class to the esteemed role of picture-book hero. Every human being has something the others dont have, that makes him an individual, he explained. This is why I often use animals that everyone hates  a snake, a vulture, a bat  in my books: all those animals are redeemed by the fact that they had appendages or qualities the others didnt have. In the end, they become the heroes.

title: Low-Carbon Car Leather? Bridge of Weir Makes Its Case at Lincoln Stand
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company was among the first clients of the Bridge of Weir Leather Company, whose hides appeared after 1911 in the Model T.

title: Romney Says N.H. Results Show Attacks on Him Failed
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  A triumphant Mitt Romney prepared to enter the crucible of South Carolina politics on Wednesday with a warning to his Republican rivals already waiting for him there: your attacks on me have failed.

title: Financial Planning Calculators for Those with Special Needs
description: Families with children who have special needs or disabilities face even bigger hurdles than most people when it comes to planning for their financial futures. Merrill Lynch Wealth Management has introduced a free online special needs calculator to help parents and guardians get started in evaluating their situation.

title: How Ricky Gervais Deals With Fame and the Famous
description: Since his much discussed performance as host of the 2011 Golden Globe Awards  one that forever put Charlie Sheen, Hugh Hefner and the Sex and the City 2 poster in their places  Ricky Gervais has had a reputation as a comedian unafraid to tell harsh truths to a room full of famous people. But Gervais, a creator and star of the British version of The Office, has been having it both ways: as I write in an article in this weekends magazine, his true achievement is being irreverent enough to titillate audiences but reverent enough to his distinguished targets for them to invite him back to zing them yet again.

title: A New Law for the Mobile Computing Era
description: The new gadgetry at the International Consumer Electronics Show this week owes a lot to the crisp articulation of ever-increasing computer performance known as Moores Law. First proclaimed in 1965 by Intels co-founder Gordon Moore, it says that the number of transistors that can be put on a microchip doubles about every two years.

title: Just One Look | The Row
description: The Row, known for sticking to a predominantly neutral palette (black, gray, navy; spring 2012 was all white), added pops of two lively new colors  maroon and blush pink  to its repertory for prefall. True to the brands ethos, the collection was stocked with exquisitely tailored, wearable separates: leather jackets, T-shirts and skirts; cozy turtleneck sweaters; and crisp button-down shirts. Wow factor arrived in the form of alligator bags (new shapes include a flat shopper and a bucket, shown here), fox fur scarves and graphic fox fur coats, like this one.

title: Goggles That Take Your iPhone Under the Sea
description: LAS VEGAS  Strap on these goofy goggles and you can videotape your adventures under the sea with your iPhone.

title: Multimedia Dance Shows Coming to Hammerstein Ballroom
description: A young entrepreneur from Long Island announced plans on Wednesday to stage a series of dance-music concerts at the Hammerstein Ballroom this year that will feature surreal projections on the walls of the Manhattan Centers ornate room.

title: The Faux Insurgent Versus the Faux Conservative
description: MANCHESTER, N.H. If you want to get a good measure of the confused state of the Republican Party, consider these two things.

title: The Dardennes Have an Idea About the Selection Process
description: Every year there is at least one movie whose absence from the competition for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film causes critics and fans to question the selection process. Last year it was Frances critically acclaimed submission, Of Gods and Men, which won the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival and many other European awards, but did not get an Oscar nomination or even a spot on the earlier shortlist of nine films.

title: In Rare Public Appearance, Assad Addresses Rally in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria appeared in public on Wednesday for the first time since the uprising against his rule began 10 months ago, addressing a rally in Umayyad Square in Damascus. He thanked the crowd for its support and pledged to defeat what he said were conspiracies against his country.

title: Supreme Court Decision: Hosanna-Tabor Evangelical Lutheran Church and School v. E.E.O.C.
description: In a major religious liberty decision, the Supreme Court for the first time recognized a ministerial exception to employment discrimination laws.

title: Corporate Parent Lost, a Franchisee Starts Over
description: WILLIAM BURRIS invested about $100,000 in 2009 to purchase three of the first Rent Your Boxes franchises in the United States. The parent company had been founded in 1998 by an Australian entrepreneur to help people rent boxes when moving.

title: Video From Iran Shows Bombing Aftermath
description: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone report, an Iranian nuclear scientist was said to be killed in a bomb attack on his car in Tehran on Wednesday.

title: New Assistant Reflects What Jets Want to Be
description: The University of New Havens football team was in Pennsylvania to play a game the next day, and its head coach, Tony Sparano, had just made a disturbing discovery: he had forgotten to pack his pants. Sparano wore the same pair  tan and polyester  for every game, and he was not about to stray from routine. His wife, Jeanette, drove back to Connecticut to collect the pants at the cleaners, then rushed back to Pennsylvania to present them to Sparano.

title: What Can a Franchisee Do When the Chain Fails?
description: Weve just published a case study that profiles the bind faced by William Burris, the owner of a box-rental franchise in Washington, D.C., who learned that his franchisor had gone bankrupt.

title: Winter Wonders | Night Moves
description: Last weeks freeze out transitioned into a springlike weekend, inspiring women to leave calf-skimming coats unbuttoned over their dresses. Here, the actress Rooney Mara wears a robelike piece in all black; the actress Emma Stone embraces winter white in a double-breasted trench with extra-large lapels; and the actress Keira Knightley chooses a long, ladylike take on the peacoat to pair with lace.

title: New Rules on Swaps Will Protect Big Traders

title: Religious Groups Given Exception to Work Bias Law
description: WASHINGTON  In what may be its most significant religious liberty decision in two decades, the Supreme Court on Wednesday for the first time recognized a ministerial exception to employment discrimination laws, saying that churches and other religious groups must be free to choose and dismiss their leaders without government interference.

title: The Outlook in South Carolina
description: A look at South Carolina before the Jan. 21 primary.

title: MSG and Time Warner Continue to Face Off
description: Since New Years Day, many local sports fans have lived with a disturbing reality: they cannot watch the Knicks, the Rangers, the Devils and the Islanders play on the MSG and MSG Plus networks.

title: On Our Radar: The Nations Greenhouse Gas Culprits
description: The Environmental Protection Agency releases an interactive online tool for identifying major sources of greenhouse gas emissions in the United States. The database and map allow residents and governments to learn about the biggest polluters in their neighborhoods and get the broad picture as well. [Environmental Protection Agency]

title: A Dangerous Challenge  and the Summit in Sight
description: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, is climbing Mount Kilimanjaro this month to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

title: European Body Threatens to Sue Hungary Over Its Policies
description: COPENHAGEN  The European Commission warned the Hungarian government on Wednesday that it would face legal action unless it modified by Tuesday policies that undermined the national central banks independence and threatened to tip the country toward authoritarianism.

title: The Cool Kid From Joplin, Mo.
description: ON a drippy Friday last September, a varied lot of fashion designers, downtown night-crawlers and uptown socialites gathered in a raw warehouse space on Walker Street, a forlorn street bordering Chinatown.

title: Pac-12 Conference Hires a Veteran of Media Agencies
description: Bill Cella, an executive well known in the world of media, is joining the Pacific-12 Conference as it gears up to introduce its own television networks to cover league games.

title: The View from L.S.U.: Next Season Starts Now
description: Mondays B.C.S. title game could not have gone worse for Les Miles vaunted Tigers.

title: More Dullness, Please
description: Gail Collins: Wow, David, big night in New Hampshire. Mitt Romney broke the critical one-third barrier!

title: Blogging Makes New Moms Happier
description: Blogging may make new mothers feel happier. Fellow mothers, do you remember that feeling of isolation that came with staying at home, alone, with that tiny, needy, crying, confusing baby they handed you at the hospital? Fathers, if you took on the primary caregiving role solo, for months or years, you cant possibly have forgotten that sense of being stranded on an island of Cheerios and Raffi music. If your experience was within the last decade, you know the Internet helps. A small research study, conducted by a new father from Brigham Young University, suggests that blogging  creating a space of your own within the online space  helps even more.

title: An Interactive Project With No Reservations
description: Before reading further, please visit the interactive Web site for Canadas National Film Board, which hosts Gods Lake Narrows.

title: Exercise Hormone May Fight Obesity and Diabetes
description: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be turning peoples white fat brown, a groundbreaking new study suggests, and in the process lessening their susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems. The study, published on Wednesday in Nature and led by researchers at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School, provides remarkable new insights into how exercise affects the body at a cellular level.

title: Adele Tops Charts for 15th Time
description: Adeles 21 (XL/Columbia) is officially the fastest-selling record in seven years, so its not a surprise that this week the album tops Billboards chart for the 15th time. What is notable  and a relief for the music industry  is that it continues to rack up significant sales at a time of year that has been embarrassingly slow in recent years.

title: When Road Hazards Go From I.E.D.s to Sunday Drivers
description: Do combat veterans experience distinctive driving problems as a result of being exposed to improvised explosive devices and highway ambushes in Iraq and Afghanistan? A number of researchers believe they do, as my article in todays Times points out.

title: Flexible Computers Make Smarter Credit Cards
description: LAS VEGAS  Miniature, flexible computers can act as credit cards that offer more control over payments.

title: Maybe It Fits Better in a Tweet?
description: As readers may have noticed, I wrote here this week about CleanEdge Power, FlexEnergy, SolarReserve and BrightSource. Is there a corporate branding consultant somewhere who specializes in energy companies and doesntlikespaces?

title: Gingrich Brings Bain Criticism to South Carolina
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Broadening his controversial assault on the source of Mitt Romneys personal fortune, Newt Gingrich on Wednesday linked the kind of corporate takeover deals Mr. Romney specialized in to the 2008 financial crisis that brought misery to people on Main Street.

title: TimesCast | January 11, 2012
description: An Iranian nuclear scientist was killed in a bomb blast in Tehran | Campaigns and super PACs prepare a big media push in South Carolina.

title: Over-the-Air TV to Your Phone  Again
description: LAS VEGAS  For about three years there has been talk about bringing over-the-air TV to hand-held receivers like phones and mini-TVs, but it looks as if the idea is finally gaining some traction. Thats not because of a technological breakthrough so much as because of a business breakthrough, although a bit of both is involved.

title: Mascaras With Innovative Wands
description: What goes with bedazzled lids? Mascaras with innovative wands promising secret powers. Here, some of the best on the market.

title: Quiet Rooms? Like the Quiet Car on the Acela?
description: I guess Mitt Romney, who managed to win the first two Republican presidential nominating contests despite saying some pretty strange things, must think hes onto a good thing. So hes saying more bizarre things.

title: Twinkies Troubles Inspire Some Sweet Memories
description: As Dealbook reported this morning, Hostess Brands, the baking company founded in 1930 that gave us Twinkies, Ding Dongs and Ho Hos, has filed for bankruptcy protection. Its treats have been by turns associated with a certain brand of sweet American sunshine, as well as the pitfalls of industrial food and the obesity epidemic that many have pegged to the increasing ubiquity of high-calorie snack foods.

title: Southern Without the Comfort
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Vast Vote Fraud Nullifies Hawk-Name Contest
description: You guys.

title: Bounce Sporting Club
description: A SPORTS bar that doubles as a disco? Nightmarish as it may sound, the concept may, in fact, be a stroke of genius, if the crowds at the downtown Bounce Sporting Club are any indication. Opened in September, Bounce is the rare place where onetime fraternity brothers and the women who love them can gather for happy hour (or on weekends for the Big Game), become sufficiently inebriated and eventually commence dancing without having to migrate to the meatpacking district.

title: Cinematographers Give Dragon Tattoo a Lift but Overlook War Horse
description: There is more bad news for War Horse, which was left off the list of nominees by the American Society of Cinematographers today. Instead the guild chose The Artist, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, Hugo, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy and The Tree of Life.

title: Leap of Faith Hopes to  Land  on Broadway This Spring
description: The producers of the new musical Leap of Faith are hoping to bring the show to Broadway this spring, instead of in fall 2012 as previously announced, according to one of the producers, Daryl Roth. In a newsletter sent to friends and colleagues and some journalists on Tuesday night about her current projects, Ms. Roth wrote that there should be news shortly on Leap of Faith and that hopefully it will open in the spring. The musical, which is expected to star four-time Tony Award nominee Ral Esparza as an evangelical con man, has been rumored recently as the next tenant for the St. James Theater, given the possibility that its current musical, On A Clear Day You Can See Forever, will close soon. On A Clear Day, starring Harry Connick Jr., opened in December to mostly negative reviews and has been selling modestly at the box office.

title: New Prime Minister Surprises Moroccans With Support for Abortion
description: CASABLANCA  Less than two months after winning power in Moroccos elections, the moderate Islamic party of Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane is surprising opponents by moving to relax the countrys strict abortion laws.

title: Reading Club | Violence in Hockey
description: For the third installment of the Learning Network Reading Club, the content is a gripping article in the series Punched Out, about the violence that takes place among hockey players serving in the role of enforcer, reported by The Timess John Branch.

title: Kepler Finds More Planets Orbiting Two Stars
description: In the Star Wars movies, Luke Skywalkers home planet, Tatooine, orbits two suns, giving it two sunsets and two sunrises every day. In September, scientists discovered the first planet in our galaxy that orbits two stars; now they have discovered two more and suggest that there are probably millions of these so-called circumbinary planets in the Milky Way.

title: IPhone Recording: Mikey Likes It
description: LAS VEGAS  Blue Microphones has just improved your iPhones hearing.

title: Red Hot Chili Peppers Delay Tour After  Kiedis Has Surgery
description: The Red Hot Chili Peppers have postponed the start of their tour this year until late March because Anthony Kiedis, the groups lead vocalist, has undergone surgery to repair a broken foot, according to the bands Web site. The cause of the injury has not been made public, but surgeons operated on Mr. Kiediss right foot to remove a crushed sesamoid bone  a small bone in the ball of the foot at the base of the big toe  and to reattach a flexor tendon, the statement said. The 49-year-old front man is expected to recover fully.

title: Apple Aims to Take On the Textbook Market
description: Apple is expected to begin a much-anticipated foray into the textbook market at an event in New York next week.

title: Survey Finds Rising Perception of Class Tension
description: Conflict between rich and poor now eclipses racial strain and friction between immigrants and the native-born as the greatest source of tension in American society, according to a survey released Wednesday.

title: Lexus LF-LC Concept and Ford Fusion Win EyesOn Design Awards
description: DETROIT  Jack Telnack, the former Ford design chief who led this years committee for the EyesOn Design Awards, said that voting was facilitated by the iPads that judges could be seen tapping throughout Cobo Center on Tuesday.

title: At Australian Open, a Busy Qualifying Day
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Highlights and updates from the first day of mens singles qualifying at the 2012 Australian Open, an unseasonably brisk summer day in Melbourne.

title: With Recent Criticism, Romneys Rivals Bring a Smile to the White House
description: WASHINGTON  For months David Axelrod, President Obamas senior strategist, has argued with evident anticipation that Mitt Romney offers a glass jaw when he boasts that his business record sets him apart as a presidential candidate. Now Mr. Romneys Republican rivals have beaten the Obama team to the punch, and Democrats could hardly be more pleased.

title: Iranian Nuclear Scientist Is Killed
description: An Iranian nuclear scientist was killed in a bomb blast in Tehran, the fourth such attack in two years.

title: Tensions Between the Rich and Poor
description: Results from a Pew Research Center poll about tensions between the rich and poor.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 11
description: A view of the day in sports, including Olympic gymnastics qualifying in London and the Dakar Rally in Chile.

title: Can I Help You? Irks the Web-Savvy Customer
description: ON a Friday morning last autumn, a reporter walked into a Gap store at the Grove, a shopping mall in Los Angeles. A young, bright-eyed woman in jeggings and a side ponytail bounded over with a warm greeting.

title: Big Banks Struggle to Help Customers on Twitter
description: Updated / 6:20 p.m., adding Wells Fargo comment.

title: Ron Pauls Victory Speech
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The numbers say Ron Paul came in second in the New Hampshire Republican primary on Tuesday, but the Republican party is just a convenience for Mr. Paul, through which he spreads his other-worldly message. He is not really a member of the party in its current form, and more importantly, neither are many of his supporters.

title: Below the Line: The Effects of The Tree of Life
description: A family drama usually isnt the first kind of movie to come to mind when one thinks about visual effects. But The Tree of Life, Terrence Malicks film that incorporates the formation of the universe into the tale of one Texas family, has awards prognosticators taking notice of its nontraditional visual techniques. The film is on the Oscar shortlist for best visual effects and is likely the only film listed there to have used computer-generated imagery, space photography, drops of colored dyes and splashes of half-and-half in tanks of water to generate its effects.

title: South Carolina Media Deluge
description: January 11, 2012  In South Carolina, campaigns and super PACs have already committed to spending more than $5 million on TV ads.

title: Aid Coast to Coast for Injured Brooklyn D.J.
description: The strangest thing about the accident, friends say, was not the blood-soaked victim  a disc jockey from Brooklyn, traveling in Portland, Ore., for a spell.

title: Monti, in Berlin, Calls for Growth Policies in Europe
description: BERLIN  Italys technocratic prime minister, Mario Monti, arrived in Germany on Wednesday with a sharp message for Chancellor Angela Merkel that austerity alone was not the answer to Europes sovereign debt crisis, and that the political and economic situation in Italy could deteriorate rapidly without more assistance from European institutions.

title: 2 Securities Heads Are Latest to Leave Goldman
description: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Olympia Dukakis to Play Prospero for Shakespeare & Company
description: Olympia Dukakis will play a female version of the magician Prospero in a production of The Tempest this summer at Shakespeare & Company, based in Lenox, Mass., the theater announced on Tuesday. She will be joined on stage by her brother, Apollo Dukakis, who will play Gonzalo, and Rocco Sisto as Caliban.

title: Pistons, Prince Frustrated by Poor Start
description: Pistons starting small forward Tayshaun Prince has seen just about everything in his nine seasons with the team. Hes been part of a championship team in 2004, one that came so close to repeating in 2005, and has made six trips to the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Carey Mulligan and the Play That Is Shame
description: In the last year, Carey Mulligan appeared in two much-admired movies, Drive and Shame, and gave an acclaimed performance in Through a Glass Darkly, a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergmans 1961 film. But before that run, she hadnt worked for nearly a year, disatisfied with the scripts she was receiving. Everything seemed exactly the same as stuff Id been doing, she told the Bagger recently.

title: New York Philharmonic Interrupted by Chimes Mahler Never Intended
description: The end of Mahlers Ninth Symphony contains some of the most spiritual and peaceful music ever written. So when a cellphone began ringing  and ringing, ringing, ringing without cease  during a performance by the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday evening, Alan Gilbert did something conductors virtually never do. He stopped the performance.

title: How to Use an iPod Underwater
description: LAS VEGAS  The most astonishing products here at the International Consumer Electronics Show are often the ones you cant buy yet, like a process called WaterBlock from the company HzO. In a demonstration, an iPod with the WaterBlock treatment  not enclosed in any kind of case or covering  was dropped in a fish tank while playing, and it played on undisturbed  for hours.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 12
description: Kate Middleton shows how to look good and stay warm with a sweater dress; Motilo.com launches; and cloche hats make a comeback.

title: On a Gay Hockey Blog, Posts About the Meaning of the Game
description: Puck Buddys, the gay hockey blog that recently celebrated its one-year anniversary as the site for boys who like boys who like hockey, has begun a new series of posts that exemplify why it has become an important trailblazer in the games cybersphere.

title: What Is the State of Your Block?
description: Thursday at 1 p.m., Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will give his annual State of the City Address. He can be expected to tout the years successes and promote his administrations policies and plans going forward. City Room will cover it live with a video feed and tweets from our reporters and editors.

title: Bowl Ratings: Dip or Trend?
description: It is mildly amusing to read the two different takes on the pitifully low television ratings garnered by Monday nights Bowl Championship Series title game. While the cable industry prefers the headline ESPN Scores Cables Second-Largest Audience Ever, everyone else has been quick to point out that it drew fewer viewers than any B.C.S. championship game ever.

title: Warren Raised $5.7 Million for Senate Bid
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts in November, announced Wednesday that she had raised $5.7 million in the last three months of 2011.

title: As Economy Grows, Jobs Are Still Scarce, Fed Says
description: Economic expansion improved last month across most of the country while hiring was limited and housing remained stagnant, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

title: Another Player Enters New York's Advocacy Arena
Americas Drinking Binge
description: Excessive drinking isnt just for college kids anymore. New research shows that four times a month, one in six Americans goes on a drinking binge, knocking back an average of eight alcoholic beverages within a few hours.

title: For Europe, Few Options in a Vicious Cycle of Debt
description: Europe has a $1 trillion problem.

title: Cline Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Clines pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Imagining a World Without Twinkies
description: For many, the alert on Wednesday that Hostess Brands Inc. is seeking bankruptcy protection provoked not shock, dismay or celebration but, rather, nostalgia for its primordial product, the Twinkie, the snack cake with a shelf life possibly sufficient to survive nuclear war.

title: Carnegie Hall to Establish National Youth Orchestra
description: Ireland has one. Norway has one. Sweden has one, and it will be at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 26. Even Iraq has one.

title: The Secrets of Quail Whispering
description: Jennifer Gee, a biologist at the Claremont University Consortium and the University of California, Riverside, writes from the tropical dry forest near lamos, Mexico, where she and Jennifer Calkins are studying Callipepla quail.

title: Stella McCartney Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Stella McCartneys pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Nina Ricci Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Nina Riccis pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Blanket Statement | Quilting for a Cause
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: From Coughlin, Condolences for the Philbin Family
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was upbeat and energetic throughout most of his news conference Wednsday, but when a reporter asked about Joe Philbin, the offensive coordinator for theGreen Bay Packers whose 21-year-old son died earlier this week, Couglins face turned ashen.

title: Former President Jimmy Carter on Egypt
description: Former President Jimmy Carter discusses the popular perception among Egyptians is that the United States back Egyptian dictators in order to maintain peace with Israel.

title: Prabal Gurungs Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Prabal Gurungs pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Eight Campuses in Georgia University System to Combine
description: The board of regents of the University System of Georgia has approved a plan by the chancellor, Henry Huckaby, to consolidate 8 of the systems 35 colleges and universities.

title: Chlo Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Chlos pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Carter Says Egypts Military Is Likely to Retain Some Political Powers
description: CAIRO  Former President Jimmy Carter said Wednesday that after meeting with Egypts military rulers he doubted they would fully submit to the authority of the civilian democracy they had promised to install.

title: Offstage, Simulators Take Up Their Positions at Detroit Auto Show
description: DETROIT  With so many new vehicles vying for attention during press previews at the auto show, its no longer sufficient to roll a car onstage through a fog bank. Automakers are turning to side exhibits that incorporate some aspect of virtual reality, usually involving driving simulators, to keep people interested in its products long after the fog machine is switched off.

title: Are We Almost Out of the Liquidity Trap? (Wonkish)
description: Aha. Greg Mankiw tells us that when you apply the coefficients for his suggested simple Taylor rule (a rule for setting the Fed funds rate), it shows the desired rate closing in on zero from below, suggesting that the end of the liquidity trap may be near.

title: Thomas Quasthoff, Celebrated Bass-Baritone, Is Retiring From Performing
description: Thomas Quasthoff, 52, the celebrated German bass-baritone renowned for his sensitive, expressive performances and deep artistic intelligence, says he is retiring from the concert stage.

title: Choice Romney Lines, Packaged for Opponents
description: Newt Gingrichs positive-message campaign seems but a distant memory.

title: Religious Groups Greet Ruling With Satisfaction
description: Among the more or less predictable reactions from legal adversaries to the Supreme Courts finding that ministers may not bring employment discrimination suits against their churches, there is a pious sentiment to be found here and there  an appeal to an even higher law.

title: Beyond Siri: Voice Recognition Pops Up in More Gadgets
description: Is the technology industry finally finding its voice?

title: Melinda Gates Answers Questions, Part II
description: Ms. Gates, of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, recently returned from a three-day trip to Bangladesh. She, along with Nick, agreed to answer readers questions about development issues focusing on that part of the world. Here is the second of three installments.

title: Sacklers Widow Gives Smithsonian Galleries $5 Million Endowment
description: Many philanthropists donate money to found an institution and then leave it up to officials to worry about the operating costs. Not Dame Jillian Sackler. On Tuesday, officials at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery and the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington announced that Ms. Sackler had donated $5 million to establish an endowment to fund the directors post and programs at the galleries that are named, in part, after her husband.

title: For Kodak, Business as Usual at C.E.S.
description: LAS VEGAS  Business was brisk at Eastman Kodaks expansive booth at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, even as the company was reportedly weighing a bankruptcy filing.

title: Looking at Education as a Civil Right
Givenchy Pre-Fall 2012
description: Looks from Givenchys pre-fall 2012 collection.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, the Philippines, Taiwan and Brazil.

title: The Pre-Autumn Leaves Start Changing Color
description: WOULD you buy a Cline suede jumpsuit?

title: Market Ready
description: Q. The tile in my bathroom is in good shape, but its brightly colored and may not appeal to everyone. Should I replace it before selling?

title: French Journalist Killed in Syria as Observer Mission Frays
description: As my colleague Nada Bakri reports, a French television journalist was killed on Wednesday in the Syrian city of Homs in a rocket attack on a pro-government rally that left at least seven others dead.

title: For Giants, Memories of a Bad Trip That Wouldnt End
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  While some players on the Giants, and plenty of their fans, have found inspiration in the teams upset victory over the Green Bay Packers in the N.F.C. championship game in 2008, the majority of the Giants have a slightly different association with Lambeau Field.

title: Funny, You Dont Look Stereotype-ish
description: Its one of my favorite comedy club memories: a pint-size, under-age Rob Schneider being called onstage by the headliner  Will Durst? at the Holy City Zoo?  and absolutely killing with a few minutes of Elvis on a hook. (Fat Elvis tries to sing while being moved around the stage by an invisible crane. If you can find it on YouTube, please let me know.)

title: From Romanticism to the Bold and New
description: Is there another orchestra that seems to be having as much fun when it plays as the Knights do?

title: Present at the Countercultures Creation
description: Testifying at the Chicago Seven trial in 1970, Ed Sanders identified himself to Judge Julius Hoffman as a poet, songwriter, leader of a rock-and-roll band, publisher, editor, recording artist, peace-creep. He lived in the East Village, which, as he writes in his great-souled memoir of the 1960s, was a Do-It-Now zone. The bookportrays him doing many things. Which was the most interesting?

title: An Aerie in the Heart of the Riviera
description: A two-bedroom apartment on the top floor of an elegant 1900s building retains many of its original rococo features.

title: House Hunting in ... Monaco
description: AN APARTMENT IN A 1900s BUILDING IN MONACO

title: Prostitution at Age 52: Questions Linger
description: In a recent Character Study column, Corey Kilgannon wrote about Barbara Terry, 52, a prostitute still working the streets in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. Readers responded via e-mail to the article. Below is a sampling of their comments.

title: Comedy and Drama, Lost and Found
description: Walter Sherman, the main character in the new Fox series The Finder, has a knack for locating people and things that have gone missing. Maybe he should look for the chemistry that he and his pals had last year when this premise was first introduced in an episode of Bones.

title: What Is College For? (Part 2)
description: In a recent column, I argued that colleges and universities are primarily vehicles for the preservation, development and transmission of our intellectual culture (scientific, humanistic and artistic). Otherwise, I claimed, there is no sense to building these institutions around faculties devoted to this intellectual culture.

title: Where the Racks Hold Ghosts of Our Youth
description: THE item of clothing shoved in the very back of my bedroom closet is one I havent worn in 15 years, and probably wont ever wear again. Its a Tommy Hilfiger hockey jersey, made from a thick beige cotton, with heavy burgundy embellishments and an outrageous crest. Ol Dirty Bastard wore it in the video for the Fantasy remix he did with Mariah Carey  you know the one, with O.D.B. in his lecherous, unhinged prime, and Mariah radiant as a new galaxy.

title: The Story of America, Founding to Foreclosure (Singing and Dancing, Too)
description: Mission Drift, a sprawling musical epic about five centuries of American expansion and destruction, is the kind of frisky theatrical adventure that would be twice as much fun at about half the length. Presented at the Connelly Theater in the East Village as part of the Coil Festival organized by Performance Space 122, the show is a freewheeling collage critiquing the countrys devouring ambition as seen through the glittering prism of Las Vegas, that great neon mirage that sprang from the Nevada sands to seduce and betray innumerable dreamers of big dreams.

title: Principal Accused of Faking Hours
Boutique Music Publisher Invests in Six Early Beatles Songs
description: In most corners of the music business, a deal to administer the music publishing rights for six songs half a century old wouldnt be very remarkable. But when it involves the Beatles, theres no such thing as a minor deal.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Homes for $675,000
description: A four-bedroom Tudor in Nashville, Tenn., a three-bedroom house on a wooded lot in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and a 3-bedroom stucco house in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: What You Get for ... $675,000
description: NASHVILLE, TENN.

title: Life Triumphs in Rural England
description: Anglophiles, historians, intellectuals and aesthetes will embrace the Anthology Film Archives retrospective of the filmmaker Patrick Keiller, running through Wednesday. Since 1981 Mr. Keiller, a leading light of Britains art cinema, has been making shorts and film essays with a formal, academic rigor influenced by the French avant-gardist Chris Marker (La Jete). Mr. Keiller is best known for the Robinson Trilogy  London (1994), Robinson in Space (1997) and Robinson in Ruins (2010)  which is the centerpiece of Anthologys overview.

title: The Last Day of a Tournament Boasts Some Notable Playing
description: On the last day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, held at the end of last year, the Swiss Teams was won by Sylvia Moss, Migry Zur-Campanile and Pietro Campanile of New York City, and Alex Ornstein of Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Upon Reflection, New M.T.A. Chief Says He Likes Smart Cards for the Subway
description: It was a marquee proposal by Jay H. Walder, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority during the relatively flush times of 2009: Replace the MetroCard with a computer chip-enabled smart card that would speed up boarding times and save the agency millions of dollars a year.

title: A Put-Upon Toll Booth Operator in Turkey
description: Toll Booth is a slow burn of a movie  so slow, in fact, that it bravely gambles with our attention. Painstakingly written and directed by Tolga Karacelik, this Turkish character study places us inside the head of Kenan (Serkan Ercan), a simmering 35-year-old toll booth attendant whose meticulous grooming signals a desperate need for control.

title: Putting Action Cameras Onto Wi-Fi
description: LAS VEGAS  At the International Consumer Electronics Show, the helmet camera makers GoPro and Contour have both demonstrated products that can put all of your plummeting, hurtling and rocketing adventures on the air live through a Wi-Fi connection.

title: Third Film on Killings Shows Toll of Time
description: Watching Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory, Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofskys third documentary for HBO about the 1993 murders of three children in West Memphis, Ark., you can feel the weight of more than 18 years bearing down. It sits on the shoulders of the filmmakers just as it does on parents, judges, law enforcement officials and the West Memphis Three, the men who spent those years in prison, convicted of the murders, before being freed last summer.

title: Are Tablets Expensive Toys? Not This One
description: LAS VEGAS  Many children pick up an iPad and figure out how to use it right away  swiping and poking the screen in a way that just seems to come naturally to them. One Laptop Per Child, a nonprofit organization that produces low-cost computers for developing countries, wants to take the tablet experience to poor children as well. It showcased its XO 3.0 tablet at the International Consumer Electronics Show this week.

title: Superhero Mimicry Arrives in China
description: First there was the Chinese Redbud Woman.

title: Scene City: Cheers for Darren Criss of Glee
description: Susan Sarandon, Parker Posey, Alan Cumming and others toast a young heartthrobs debut.

title: The Comedy Gatekeeper Who Makes Letterman Laugh
description: When Eddie Brill walked onstage at the Upright Citizens Brigade in October, he immediately stood out. Besides being about twice the age of most in the audience, Mr. Brill, 53, was the only one in the room wearing a sports jacket.

title: A Road to Success, Lined With Friends
description: Is it possible to succeed in show business without really trying?

title: New Hampshire Barely Moves the Ratings Needle
description: Watching TV, it can sometimes seem as if the whole country is transfixed by the Republican presidential primary race.

title: Jazzs Annual Reunion Celebration, With Honors for Five Masters
description: The National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Fellowship, which comes with $25,000, is possibly the highest honor for jazz musicians given in the country that cultivated them. Over 30 years 124 of those fellowships have been given out.

title: Bank of America Puts Its Advertising Account in Review
description: The new year is beginning with a bang on Madison Avenue as a big, blue-chip marketer, Bank of America, places in review its advertising account.

title: Rap Cameos That Pack Some Electric Punches
description: Its been so long since the once-legendary rapper Nas lived up to the promise of his early albums that the base expectation for his new music is disappointment. So its been jarring recently to hear him on Hot 97 (97.1 FM in New York), on a new song, sounding like the rapper he was in the mid-1990s: wise, with a sharp eye for detail; pouring phrases together in dizzying jumbles; and showing off the pain that throbs beneath the calluses formed by years of exposure to the streets.

title: The Buzz
description: PREVIEWING the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: And Now, the Awards for Awards
description: At our house we call this time of year the convention,Frances McDormand announced from the stage at the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday night. Addressing the assembled famous faces  the Clooneys and Rooneys, Tildas and Martys  Ms. McDormand, the Oscar-winning star of Fargo, added, You are going to be seeing a lot of each other.

title: Living Up to Apples Standards
description: LAS VEGAS  Apple does not exhibit at C.E.S. and its executives havent deigned to speak at the event for years. Yet the companys shadow looms large.

title: No Holiday Cheer for PC Makers  Except Apple
description: The year-end holiday sales season typically produces a bounce in personal computer sales, but not this time.

title: Man-on-the-Move Modern
description: A 525-square-foot walk-up in Greenwich Village made to feel like a luxury hotel.

title: In Greenwich Village, a Place to Rest in Luxury
description: FRANK CARFARO is a 41-year-old bachelor of such varied and impressive accomplishments that merely hearing about them wears one out, and he enjoys a long soak in a hot bath now and then. But when he renovated his small Greenwich Village apartment, he ripped out the tub because it didnt evoke the right mood.

title: Zoom In, Zumba Away
description: WHENEVER I read about people who are in thrall to a dance craze, my world suddenly seems too small. Oh, to dance the mazurka until my footmen are forced to carry me home on a makeshift gurney at dawn; oh, to spurn a dinner invitation to Scott and Zeldas because I literally cannot stop doing the Charleston.

title: Digital Notes: Shazam Tries to Do More, and Pandora Hits 125 Million
description: Daily updates on the business of digital music:

title: A Droid With Better Battery Life
description: LAS VEGAS  The most nagging complaint from people who own Android phones has been short battery life. The reason? Its ability to run apps in the background drains battery life.

title: Gingrich Denies Hes Backing Off Attacks on Romney
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Newt Gingrichs campaign on Wednesday denied a report that he was backing away from attacking Mitt Romney over his career as a corporate takeover specialist at Bain Capital.

title: Bang for the Buck
description: ALBANY

title: The Dollar-Store Home
description: Inside a cheerful apartment filled with objects that cost $1 a pop.

title: Shopping for Kettles
description: Stephanie Goto, an architect who has helped shape the interiors of a number of notable restaurants in Manhattan, shopped for good-looking kettles.

title: Dressing Up Ironing Board Covers
description: Pottery Barn has introduced a line of ironing board covers, perhaps for those whose New Years resolutions involve staying on top of household chores. Or for the growing number of people who believe that everything in the home, no matter how pedestrian, should be attractive.

title: Digital Dcor From a New Web Site
description: Stephanie Pesakoff, who founded the illustration division of the agency Art Department, has started a new Web site called Stampa to sell limited-edition prints by artists. The site is currently offering works by Bo Lundberg (Manhattan, pictured), Sara Singh, Sirichai, and Alli Arnold, and a new artist will be introduced every week. Each image will be available for four weeks, framed or unframed, in four sizes.

title: Chairs Wrought From a Heavy Weight
description: Kevin Busta, a 33-year-old Cleveland boilermaker-turned-designer who uses scrap metal and industrial castoffs in his work, is introducing a new custom-made chair, the Zinc sling ($750). And theres always a story behind Mr. Bustas furniture, which he builds in a cavernous warehouse, so we asked him where he got the zinc.

title: At a Miami Hotel, 1960s-Style Glamour
description: Anyone familiar with the work of Yabu Pushelberg, the Toronto-based duo known for quiet, minimalist spaces, might be surprised to hear they designed the new St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort, in Miami Beach, which is notable for the liberal use of mirrors and crystal.

title: Kettles
description: STEPHANIE GOTO has a special interest in food. An architect with a practice in New York, she not only designs private homes and cultural and commercial projects, but has also helped shape the interiors of a number of notable restaurants in Manhattan, including Morimoto, Aldea, Corton and, most recently, La Mar Cebicheria Peruana.

title: Sales at the Future Perfect and Jonathan Adler
description: Seasonal tableware, pillows and decorative accessories are up to half off at C. Wonder, through Jan. 30 (a toile pillow cover, usually $28, is about $20); 72 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (212) 219-3500, cwonder.com.

title: Obama Practices the 2012 Two-Step
description: Since President Obamas return from Hawaii last week, the White House has labored to dispel any notion that he is plunging into his re-election campaign. Mr. Obama, his press aides say, did not watch the New Hampshire primary returns, nor did he schedule a jobs event at the White House on Wednesday as a riposte to Republican charges that he hasnt created enough of them.

title: Pardons by Haley Barbour
description: Gov. Haley Barbour granted 203 full pardons over his two terms, including 17 to convicted murderers. He also granted 19 other criminals lesser degrees of clemency, like conditional suspensions of their sentences.

title: Peru: Suspect in Holloway Case Pleads Guilty in Lima Murder
description: Joran van der Sloot, the Dutchman who became notorious as the prime suspect in the disappearance of an 18-year-old Alabama woman in Aruba in 2005, pleaded guilty in a Lima courtroom on Wednesday to the 2010 murder of a Peruvian woman he met at a casino. The case of the American woman, Natalee Holloway, who vanished during a senior class trip, remains unresolved despite being the subject of several books and television programs, as well as many lurid tabloid headlines over the years. The Peruvian woman, Stephany Flores, 21, was strangled in a Lima hotel room five years to the day after Ms. Holloways disappearance. I am truly sorry for this act, Mr. van der Sloot told the judges on Wednesday, according to The Associated Press. He bowed his head as his lawyer argued that he had killed Ms. Flores in a state of extreme psychological trauma brought on because he was persecuted during the Holloway investigation. Prosecutors have asked for a 30-year sentence.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Statistics Quants and Some Frisky Books
description: Interesting things that New York Times reporters and editors found on the Web on Wednesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Straight Talk: A New Breed of Fashion Bloggers
description: NOT every fashion blogger is a 15-year-old girl with an unhealthy obsession with Rei Kawakubo. Some are older. And some are men.

title: Everything Old Is New Again
description: REMEMBER the paperless office, that dream of perfect organization that was peddled by tech companies years ago as a way to sell computers?

title: A Lisbon Architect Brings His Skills to MoMA
description: Pedro Gadanho, a 43-year-old Portuguese architect, may represent the future of the profession, in that he doesnt do much actual building. Instead, he has fashioned a gadfly-like career as a curator, writer, blogger and teacher, while finding time to squeeze in an architecture project or two each year, like Baltasar House, a boldly colored residence he designed in 2007 in Porto, Portugal, and the Torres Vedras house, which he designed in 2010 outside Lisbon.

title: Tips on American College Admissions Essays, From a Veteran Dean
description: Seth Allen is vice president and dean of admissions and financial aid at Pomona College in California, a liberal arts college. He was previously dean of admission and financial aid at Grinnell College in Iowa. This is the second post in a regular series on India Ink providing advice to prospective Indian applicants to American colleges and universities.

title: The TVs That Ate Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Struggling to make a profit and distinguish themselves from competitors, television manufacturers are going big. Really big.

title: The World of Xtreme Taxidermy
description: The Ross family, the subjects of the television show American Stuffers, specializes in freeze-drying pets to preserve them.

title: Warm Hearts and Freeze-Dried Pets
description: ROMANCE, Ark.

title: Ex-Fund Manager Gets Prison Term in Insider Trading Case
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: What You Can Get for $1 or Less
description: The items that Jesse McKinley, a reporter for The Times, bought at the dollar stores he frequented as he shopped for his apartment:

title: Oxycodone Prescriptions Rose Sharply in New York
description: In a stark depiction of the rapid spread of prescription drug use and abuse in New York State, a new report shows that prescriptions for oxycodone, a widely prescribed narcotic painkiller, rose by 82 percent from 2007 to 2010.

title: The Landscape After New Hampshire
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Calls for Tax Breaks to Return Jobs From Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Wednesday that he would propose tax incentives for companies to bring home manufacturing jobs they had moved overseas, and curtail tax breaks for those that keep relocating jobs abroad.

title: When You Are Disabled and Need a Taxi
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats a Smoker to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Subsidies to Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt: Anti-Mubarak Uprising to Be Honored With Holiday
description: Egypts military rulers on Tuesday declared Jan. 25 an official holiday to celebrate the anniversary of the uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak last year. The day will also recognize the roughly 800 demonstrators who were killed during the 18 days of protests. But that date already honors the police, and earlier this week the minister of the interior suggested that it was possible to integrate the two occasions, leading political activists to quip that such a dual holiday would celebrate both the victims and the perpetrators.

title: The Next Immigration Challenge
description: Los Angeles

title: A Mining Law Whose Time Has Passed
description: IN 1872, President Ulysses S. Grant signed a mining law to spur the development of the West by giving hard-rock mining precedence over other uses of federal land. But the law has long since outlived its purpose, and its environmental consequences have been severe.

title: After Losing a Lawsuit, Taking Their Appeal to God
description: They have tried letter-writing, petitions and a lawsuit, all to no avail. So now the Christian congregations that are weeks away from expulsion from New York Citys public schools are focusing on more-religious tools in their arsenal: prayer, fasting and repentance.

title: The Primary Primer
description: I am feeling totally cheated. The New Hampshire primary is over, and none of the Republicans went away.

title: Yankees Add Another Mattingly
description: The Yankees signed the free-agent minor league outfielder Preston Mattingly, the son of the former Yankees first baseman Don Mattingly, to a minor league contract.

title: Eight Men In: A Trip to Lambeau
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the playoffs, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotels and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men  they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee  have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

title: If Youre Mad for Downton, Publishers Have Reading List
description: The British melodrama Downton Abbey is already the darling of American public television. Now it has become a marketing tool for booksellers and publishers hoping to tap into the passion of the shows audience.

title: Pakistans Besieged Government
description: Pakistans civilian governments are typically short-lived and cast aside by military coups. This disastrous pattern could be repeating itself as the current civilian government comes under increasing pressure from the army and the Supreme Court.

title: A Camera Phone, Sans Phone
description: LAS VEGAS  Every year the camera manufacturers set up huge booths at C.E.S., where they display an impressive array of tiny, powerful cameras. And every year this exercise seems a bit more quaint.

title: A Blurring of the Lines in the Populist vs. Capitalist Debate
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  In the sour, fearful mood that economic setbacks have produced, American voters loathe both major symbols of the forces squeezing their pocketbooks and life savings.

title: Slower Growth in Health Spending
description: Health care spending in the United States increased at the slowest rate in half a century in 2009 and 2010, essentially keeping pace with the growth of the economy, according to the latest federal data.

title: Latter-Day Dig of Great Escape Tunnels Humbles Modern Engineers
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  For scale, they were no match for the Great Pyramids of Giza or the Panama Canal. The labor took months rather than years and a work force of barely 100 men. As for materials, there were none, beyond what the captured Royal Air Force fliers who built them could scavenge, scrounge or improvise.

title: Unemployed Mortgage Holders Get Extension on Payments
description: Although home foreclosure rates appear to be stabilizing and unemployment is slowly coming down, there are still millions of jobless borrowers who are at risk of losing their homes because they cannot afford their monthly payments.

title: Walgreen Is Firm on End of Express Scripts Deal
description: CHICAGO  The chief executive of the Walgreen Company defended the chains decision to end its relationship with the prescription benefit manager Express Scripts, even as rivals have stepped up their efforts to attract pharmacy customers covered by Express Scripts plans.

title: Romneys Hard Line
description: Mitt Romney, who used to try to sound like a moderate on immigration, has dropped the pretense. On Wednesday, he proudly accepted the endorsement of the anti-immigrant activist Kris Kobach, architect of the nations most radical immigration crackdowns, including the unconstitutional show-your-papers laws in Arizona and Alabama.

title: At Hotel of Artists, Skepticism Over a Show
description: You know that times have changed at the Chelsea Hotel  when a planned private concert by one of its famed former tenants, the punk songstress Patti Smith, evokes grousing and doubts.

title: Burning Time
description: In October, 45 degrees feels like a reason to start a fire in the woodstove. Less so in January, when 45 degrees feels unseasonably mild.

title: Mary Ellen Avery, Premature Babies Savior, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Mary Ellen Avery, a medical researcher who helped save hundreds of thousands of premature infants with a single, crucial discovery about their ability to breathe, died on Dec. 4 in West Orange, N.J. She was 84.

title: Once a Top Prospect, Martinez Is Headed to Houston
description: When Fernando Martinez signed with the Mets on July 11, 2005, there was great excitement surrounding a 16-year-old from the Dominican Republic who was projected to become an elite outfielder.

title: Voting in Plain Sight
description: Of all the domestic policy differences between the Bush and Obama administrations, just about the sharpest and most telling may be their opposite responses to the drive by Republican-dominated states to require voters to present photo identification at the polls. The Bush administration thought photo ID was a dandy idea. The Obama administration recognizes it for what it is: a cynical effort to insure that fewer young people and members of minority groups (read, likely Democratic voters) are able to cast a ballot.

title: Safeguarding a Childs Mobile Device From Pornography
description: Many teenagers recently opened a new iPhone, Android or iPod Touch, immediately downloaded textPlus, a popular free texting app, and headed for their bedrooms.

title: Mexico Updates Death Toll in Drug War to 47,515, but Critics Dispute the Data
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican government updated its drug war death toll on Wednesday, reporting that 47,515 people had been killed in drug-related violence since President Felipe Caldern began a military assault on criminal cartels in late 2006.

title: Crocs Campaign Nods to Its Clog
description: THE original Crocs clog was introduced in 2002 by three boating enthusiasts who developed its lightweight material because, along with being waterproof, it was slip-resistant.

title: Packers Prepare Without Coordinator
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Howard Green took his usual seat at Green Bays team meeting Wednesday morning. But for Green, the Packers 340-pound defensive lineman, normalcy was not possible.

title: University Suspects Fraud by a Researcher Who Studied Red Wine
description: A charge of widespread scientific fraud, involving 26 articles published in 11 journals, was leveled by the University of Connecticut today against Dipak K. Das, one of its researchers, whose work reported health benefits in red wine.

title: Struggling, Perry Finds Place Where His Message Sticks
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Jack Boyers father died when Mr. Boyer was 8. Raised by a single mother, he lived a wicked life, married at 19 and, two years later, after she and the Lord straightened me out, accepted Jesus Christ as his personal savior. Almost four decades later, he is pastor of a Baptist church in the northwest part of this state.

title: Adversaries of Iran Said to Be Stepping Up Covert Actions
description: WASHINGTON  As arguments flare in Israel and the United States about a possible military strike to set back Irans nuclear program, an accelerating covert campaign of assassinations, bombings, cyberattacks and defections appears intended to make that debate irrelevant, according to current and former American officials and specialists on Iran.

title: As Wage Concerns Ebb, Bronx Armory Push Is Revived
description: Two years after Bronx leaders helped defeat a plan to develop the Kingsbridge Armory into a retail mall, citing concerns over wages, they are supporting a new push by the Bloomberg administration to develop the massive red-brick castle.

title: New York City Charter School Finds That a Grade of C Means Closing
description: For the first time, New York City is closing a charter school for the offense of simply being mediocre.

title: Sampling the Future of Gadgetry
description: LAS VEGAS  If you just peek into the huge International Consumer Electronics Show, you might think that its mostly a deafening showcase for tablets, thin TV screens, superthin laptops and Android phones.

title: The Value of Teachers
description: Suppose your child is about to enter the fourth grade and has been assigned to an excellent teacher. Then the teacher decides to quit. What should you do?

title: When the Fire Hydrant Was the End Zone
description: Steve Murphys living room was a harsh turf. There was no rug, only a slice of cold linoleum glued to a concrete floor  hard as Lambeau Field, the Green Bay Packers tundra, on an icy afternoon. We wore elbow pads and kneepads and kept the windows wide open to minimize the chances of breaking one. When the football sailed through one after a bad throw, it was a beautiful thing to watch  the spiraling ball taking a sweet, long ride. Wed hang from the second story windowsill and slip down to the street to get the ball. It was just another play.We got away with it because Mr. and Mrs. Murphy never got home before 6. Besides, where else could we go? We had no backyards, and it was the 1960s in New York City  we were barely allowed to ride the subways by ourselves, and grass fields were scarce. But I loved the sport. I carried my football everywhere, just in case anyone wanted to play catch. I slept with it to prevent fumbling. And even more important, I loved the New York Giants. The ny on their helmets was tattooed on my heart. Its no wonder that  35 years after the team moved to the Meadowlands in New Jersey  theyre still called the New York Giants.

title: Anna and the Librarian
description: A fervent Unionist from Baltimore, Anna Ella Carroll was an active pamphleteer who knew many of the Republican Partys leaders. As the months-old war intensified, Carroll embarked on a series of trips across the border states. At the time she claimed her trips were for family and social visits; later she claimed they were for the Union, declaring herself the spy who saved the country.

title: Against Odds, Path Opens Up for U.S.-Taliban Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Over the last year, Marc Grossman, a veteran but low-key diplomat, led a small team of American officials who met secretly from Doha, Qatar, to Munich with a shadowy representative of Afghanistans Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, in hopes of starting peace talks.

title: As Tottenham Heals, Spurs Keep Winning
description: LONDON  Out of the ashes of Londons summer riots, Tottenham Hotspur continues to rise. In August, as the rest of the English Premier League season began across the country, Spurs stadium in north London stood quiet, surrounded by police tape.

title: Freestyle Star Sustains Serious Head Injury in Training
description: The potential danger presented by the high walls and slick sides of supersize halfpipes has come to the fore again, two years after the champion snowboarder Kevin Pearce sustained a traumatic head injury.

title: Taiwan Vote Lures Back Expatriates in China
description: BEIJING  The only thing more striking than the $32,000 diamond-encrusted eyeglasses on display at the Baodao Optical department store here is the bronze statue of Chairman Mao that greets shoppers entering what is billed as the worlds largest eyeglass emporium.

title: Budget Cuts Hamper the I.R.S. in Efforts to Collect Billions in Taxes, Report Says
description: An expanding workload and cuts in funds have left the Internal Revenue Service unable to adequately perform either of its primary duties  collecting taxes and providing the public with reasonable service, according to a report released Wednesday by the I.R.S.s internal monitor.

title: Mississippi: Some Pardons by Barbour Are Halted
description: A Circuit Court judge in Jackson temporarily blocked the release of 21 inmates on Wednesday night who were among 215 convicts granted clemency by Gov. Haley Barbour in his final days in office. State Attorney General Jim Hood argued that granting clemency for some convicts was unconstitutional because the pardons had not been sufficiently publicized beforehand. Earlier Wednesday, Mr. Barbour, who left office Tuesday, issued a statement about the pardons, which have caused a storm of controversy. Of those granted clemency, 188 had already left prison, most of them years ago, it said, and the pardons were intended to allow them to find gainful employment or acquire professional licenses as well as hunt and vote. Of the 26 who were in custody, 13 were placed on indefinite suspension due to medical reasons because their health care expenses while incarcerated were costing the state so much money. The remaining number includes five inmates released on Sunday, including four men serving life sentences for murder, who had worked at the Governors Mansion. The judge ordered those five men to appear in court on Jan. 23.

title: Wisconsin Quarterback Opts for Football Career
description: After leading Wisconsin to the Rose Bowl during his lone season with the Badgers, quarterback Russell Wilson has decided to pursue a career in professional football over one in baseball.

title: A Blend of Politics and Pragmatism at the Auto Show
description: DETROIT  As the automotive industry rebounds, this years Detroit auto show features more dazzle, more optimism and more politicians winding their way through the exhibits.

title: In Missouri, as Levee Is Rebuilt, Signs of Rebirth Begin to Sprout
description: BIRDS POINT, Mo.  The dirt is back.

title: Republican Rivals Batter Romney in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  For the Republican presidential candidates who want to stop Mitt Romney in South Carolina, it comes down to this: How far are they willing to go?

title: Economic Growth Across the Country
description: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserves 12 districts.

title: Molotov Cocktail Thrown Into the Home of a Rabbi
description: Noise and a flash of light woke the rabbi before dawn on Wednesday, and when he looked down, his bed was on fire.

title: State Gets 20,000 Comments on Its Gas Drilling Rules by Deadline
description: After taking over 20,000 public comments, more than on any issue they have ever faced, New York environmental officials are getting ready for the final phase of work on their proposal to allow hydrofracking of natural gas in the state.

title: Lottery Numbers
Thursday: No Longer Bothered by Something
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Everyone rise, please, for the national anthem:

title: First-Place Rangers Are Wonders of Nurture
description: Glen Sather, the general manager of the team with the best record in the N.H.L., rarely says much for public consumption. Whether the Rangers win or lose, Sather abhors granting a self-evaluation of his performance.

title: Women in McDonalds Fight Seen Widely Online Plead Not Guilty
description: Before the mid-October night went horribly wrong, there was a dinner at Planet Hollywood. Then a trip to the Fat Black Pussycat bar. Five tequila shots later, the two women ended up at a McDonalds in Greenwich Village, about to become Internet stars of the worst kind.

title: Irans Leaders Shut Down Independent Film Group
description: Brushing aside protests by Iranian filmmakers and rights activists, Irans Culture Ministry on Wednesday formally dissolved the House of Cinema, the only domestic organization that supports independent film, and moved to replace it with a committee that would not deviate from strict Islamic guidelines and politically permissible topics.

title: Turning to Tech on the Road
description: LAS VEGAS  If Mercedes, BMW and Ford have their way, the new cars they build will be able to port apps, games, music and movies from a smartphone to a cars entertainment system.

title: Anywhere on Staten Island, Technology Shows Where Next Bus Is
description: Jasmin Dunn had gotten off her night-shift job and finished up a doctors appointment on Wednesday morning, and she desperately wanted to get home. But the B63 bus in Brooklyn was nowhere in sight.

title: A Credit Nightmare, but Coming Out Better in the End
description: Sitting on her living room sofa, her knees together, her hands clasped tidily on her lap, Maria Ortiz was the picture of professionalism. Wearing a black suit, her hair pulled back, she was smiling confidently. It was the end of another long day, one that started at 6 in the morning, before the rest of her family had even hit the snooze button.

title: Where Did They Get the Money For That?
description: Over the past few weeks, voters in early primary and caucus states have been deluged by political advertising. Some of the ads are pure hagiography, while others are slashing. Disclaimers tell viewers which candidate or group with a soothing name is responsible in each case. But even as they choose from among the Republican presidential candidates, voters havent been able to find out who is really behind the spots  who has been putting up the big money it takes to make and air these messages.

title: Eyewitness Evidence Needs No Special Cautions, Court Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday refused to require courts to examine suggestive eyewitness evidence with extra care unless it was produced by police misconduct.

title: Knicks Beat Division Leader, With Defense
description: This was a test, only a test.

title: Assessing the State of the Schools
Online Map Shows Biggest Greenhouse Gas Emitters
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency for the first time is making available detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions, from the Mount Sinai Hospital heating plant in Manhattan to the nations largest coal-burning power plant in Georgia.

title: Healthy Running Back Has Saints Recalling Title Run
description: METAIRIE, La.  There went Pierre Thomas, on a screen pass in the Superdome late last Saturday. He maneuvered past one Detroit Lions defender, split two others, stumbled, regained his balance with one hand and continued to plow forward. It took three defenders to wrestle him to the turf.

title: Will Women Get Ahead by Going Back to School?
At a Crossroads for Peace With the Taliban
description: The road to creating lasting peace in the midst of war is often fraught with setbacks, and success is never guaranteed. Over the last year, Marc Grossman, a low-key diplomat, led a small team of American officials in secret meetings with Mullah Muhammad Omar, a representative of Afghanistans Taliban leader, in hopes of starting peace talks.

title: Obama Raises Money in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  Telling supporters that change may be hard but remains possible, President Obama received a warm welcome home here on Wednesday, bolstering his 2012 campaign coffers at three fund-raisers attracting an eclectic mix of wealthy donors and spirited college students.

title: John McWhinnie, an Expert in Rare Books, Dies at 43
description: John McWhinnie, a rare-book dealer and gallerist known as a champion of words and images on paper in an age of electronic reading, died on Friday in a snorkeling accident in the British Virgin Islands. He was 43.

title: Jan Groover, Postmodern Photographer, Dies at 68
description: Jan Groover, whose relentlessly formal still lifes of mundane objects brought a sense of Renaissance stateliness to postmodern photography, died on Jan. 1 in Montpon-Mnestrol, France, where she had lived since 1991. She was 68.

title: Excitement Around Donations by Text Message Fades
description: A new survey of donors who used text messages to send gifts to charities after the earthquake that crumpled Haiti two years ago finds that for most of them, it was an impulse decision with fleeting impact.

title: Mormons Uneasy in the Spotlight
description: A new poll of Mormons in the United States finds that while one of their own is making unprecedented progress in a bid for the presidency, many feel uneasy in the spotlight, misunderstood and unaccepted in the American mainstream.

title: Word of the Day | monolithic
description: monolithic \m-n-li-thik\ adjecitve

title: Corrections: January 12
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Colleges Slower to Branch Out Abroad
