description: After a decade of rapid growth, universities have slowed their pace of opening branch campuses abroad, and much of the activity has moved from the Middle East to the Far East, according to a survey by the Observatory on Borderless Higher Education, a private British research group, scheduled for release Thursday.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/12/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/12/2012

title: U.S. Halts Import of Orange Juice
description: The United States has temporarily halted shipments of imported orange juice from all countries while they are tested, and said it will destroy or ban products containing even low levels from a banned fungicide.

title: Indias Chronic Battle With Malnutrition
description: It is unrealistic to expect any major breakthroughs in dealing with the diets of impoverished Indians, a correspondent wrote in The New York Times in an article on Oct. 23, 1981.

title: On the Floor at C.E.S.
description: Sam Grobart, The Timess personal technology editor, hunts for the new and novel at the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Kim Jong-il to Go on Permanent Display
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Thursday that it would place the body of Kim Jong-il on permanent display in a Pyongyang mausoleum and install his statues, portraits and memorial towers across the country.

title: A Techie's Test Drive
description: Sam Grobart, The Times personal technology editor, test drives a car with a range of computer-assisted features.

title: Songs for Haiti
description: On the two-year anniversary of Haitis earthquake, members of the all-Haitian choir at the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in Manhattan reflect and heal through prayer and song.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 12, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Jan. 12, 1915 | Congress Votes Against Womens Suffrage Amendment
description: On Jan. 12, 1915, the United States House of Representatives voted, 204-174, to reject a constitutional amendment to give women the right to vote.

title: European Union Gives Hungary an Ultimatum
description: BUDAPEST  Faced with what critics say is an alarming drift away from democracy by one of its members, the European Union gave the Hungarian government a final warning Wednesday that it would face the start of formal legal action by next Tuesday unless it modified a series of measures that threaten the balance of power in the country.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 12, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from The Local blog post Local Legends: The French Girl.'

title: Satellite Plummets After Possible Attack
description: WHAT is the Phobos-Grunt?

title: Judith Clarks Radical Transformation
description: On Oct. 20, 1981, a band of militant zealots armed with automatic weapons tried to rob a Brinks truck in a shopping mall in Nanuet in Rockland County, N.Y. Before it was over, two armored-car guards were shot and two police officers  one black and one white  were gunned down at a roadblock. The crime was one of the last spasms of 60s-style, left-wing violence. To the militants, it was an expropriation for something they called the Republic of New Afrika, a place that existed mainly in their fevered dreams.

title: The Tea Partys Not-So-Civil War
description: I met Karen Martin, a few days before New Years, at a cafe in Greenville, the hub of conservative politics in South Carolina. A 54-year-old refugee from the North Shore of Massachusetts, Martin is the lead organizer of the nearby Spartanburg Tea Party. Another Tea Party leader described her to me as a grown-up, and in fact, Martin turned out to be the kind of activist  ideology notwithstanding  who makes you feel hopeful about the new age of political uprising. She recounted how she burst into tears at the moment she realized, watching the news in 2008, that children growing up today wouldnt have the economic opportunities that she did. She talked about how the Tea Party would need to mature and become more politically sophisticated in the years ahead. I think the movement is just too young and too emotional, she said.

title: Sweetheart of the Rodeo
description: Louise Serpa grew up as a New York debutante, but her heart belonged to the West. By day, she studied at Vassar, but some nights, she became a cowgirl, sneaking out of her dorm room to watch visiting rodeos in Manhattan. Her transformation was complete by her 30s, when she moved to Tucson, and pursued her passion for the sport.

title: Could Huntsman and the Democrats Ally on Bank Reform?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Whats Your Favorite (Printable) Slang Term?
description: A recent New York Times crossword attracted quite a lot of notice after a reader tried to school The Timess puzzle master Will Shortz on what she sees as the semantic differences between the hip-hop terms wack and illin. What slang term would you like to see used in a Times crossword?

title: Kia Chooses Las Vegas, Not Detroit, for E.V. Debuts
description: LAS VEGAS  Rather than at a traditional auto salon like the one running concurrently in Detroit, Kia Motors opted to introduce two electric vehicles at the Consumer Electronics Show here this week.

title: A Taste for Tidbits Best Served Cold
description: The Hamptons are no place for a friendless soul, but thats the lot of Nolan Ross, the character played by Gabriel Mann in ABCs breakout soap Revenge.

title: Part 4: Answers on the Fafsa, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid
description: All this week, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is answering questions on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of Secrets to Winning a Scholarship, published last February.

title: The Early Word: Romney Rising
description: In Todays Times:

title: At Prague Castle, Treasures of the Czars
description: A rare exhibition of gilded treasures from the Moscow Kremlin museums  some of which had never before left Russia  has been getting rave reviews since its opening at Prague Castle last month.

title: Bye Bye, Canada
description: A sketch on Montreals infrastructure troubles from Bye Bye 2011, a Qubcois comedy special. After the characters hear a radio report about 2012 potentially being the year of the worlds end, they survive crumbling roadways and joke about such chaos being attributable to the citys character, not the planets demise.

title: Burmese Government and Ethnic Rebel Group Sign Cease-Fire
description: BANGKOK  The government of Myanmar signed a cease-fire agreement on Thursday with ethnic Karen rebels, whose fight for greater autonomy is one of the largest of the brutal civil wars that has bedeviled the country since it gained independence from Britain more than six decades ago.

title: Q&A: Changing Google Calendar Notifications
description: Q.

title: Jets Still Arguing as Mangold Defends Sanchez
description: Another chaotic Jets day. The quotations from Wednesday tell the story:

title: Royal Bank of Scotland to Cut 3,500 Jobs
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it would eliminate 3,500 jobs in its investment banking division over the next three years in response to volatility in global financial markets.

title: The Bo Ssam Miracle
description: This weekends dinner is a slow-roasted shoulder of pig, a meal that can be picked apart by a table of friends armed only with chopsticks and lettuce. A tight and salty caramel crust sits on top of the moist, fragrant collapse of meat, and juices run thick to pool beneath it, a kind of syrup, delicious in its intensity. It is pork as pommes souffl.

title: The New Restaurant Will Be Chef Joes
description: Arthur on Smith is the name of our new restaurant in Brooklyn. It is a tribute to Chef Joes father, who passed away last year but whose spirit will be reborn at 276 Smith Street. Arthur also refers to la strada principale in the Italian section of the Bronx and will make naming any future restaurants a lot easier, like spreading ashes: Arthur on Bleecker, Arthur on Madison, Arthur on.  Wait, Im getting ahead of myself.

title: Murray Bets Future on Lendls Past
description: No man needs a Grand Slam title quite as much as Andy Murray. His new coach, Ivan Lendl, was once in the same awkward position.

title: Federer's Wife at the Center of His Game
description: His back, a chronic but manageable concern for years, has been troubling him again, but Roger Federer is in Melbourne with every intent of returning to the court and playing in his 49th consecutive Grand Slam tournament.

title: Haitian Choir Lifts Every Voice in Healing
description: Within days of the cataclysmic earthquake in Haiti in 2010, the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in Manhattan, like many houses of worship, responded with donations of food and water.

title: Europe Gets Some Reassurance in Auctions of Debt
description: BERLIN  Solid government debt auctions in Italy and Spain on Thursday indicated that efforts by the European Central Bank to avoid a regional credit freeze were continuing to show at least short-term benefits.

title: Foxconn Resolves a Dispute With Some Workers in China
description: SHANGHAI  Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to several electronics giants, said on Thursday that it had resolved a pay dispute with scores of workers at one of its factories in central China after a large protest that involved threats from some workers to commit suicide.

title: Carmakers Race to Add Tech Touches
description: As cars become ever more vibrant entertainment centers, automakers find themselves having to build safety features to prevent drivers from crashing their smartphone on wheels, Sam Grobart reports in The Times. And in a video from Las Vegas, he test drives a car with a range of computer-assisted features.

title: Obama Campaign Raises $42 Million in Fourth Quarter
description: Read the full report here.

title: Pogue on the Highlights of the Show
description: The Consumer Electronics Show displays a future of proliferating gadgetry, from the serious to the frivolous, David Pogue reports in his State of the Art column. He looks at televisions, tablets, smartphone control, ultrabooks and the weird and the wonderful.

title: The End of My Generations War
description: I wasnt alive when Vietnam ended. I remember being a little girl, and watching news reports in the years after Vietnam, but I never really understood why it was important until much later in life. As a soldier, I had no concept of what it would feel like to hear my generations war was over.

title: Getting Ready to React to Fukushima
description: Reacting to Japans Fukushima disaster, the nuclear industry is preparing to present regulators with a streamlined package of voluntary safety improvements that it says could be put into effect quickly  although they would not be certified as formal nuclear standards regarding specific threats.

title: Video: On the Floor at C.E.S.
description: Sam Grobart, The Timess personal technology editor, hunts for the new and novel at the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: N.F.L. Divisional Round Probabilities
description: Some statistical story lines for this weekends divisional matchups:

title: Video Inflames a Delicate Moment for U.S. in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A video showing four United States Marines urinating on three dead Taliban fighters provoked anger and condemnation on Thursday in Afghanistan and around the world, raising fears in Washington that the images could incite anti-American sentiment at a particularly delicate moment in the decade-old Afghan war.

title: Opinion Report: Romney Lurches Right on Immigration
description: From the editorial page

title: Hungary Update
description: Over the past month or so my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele has posted several times on this blog, reporting on the anti-democratic moves of the Hungarian government. When she started, there was near-silence from the news media on the story; but that has now ended, with extensive coverage in many newspapers.

title: The 99 Percent Get Sundance Support
description: LOS ANGELES  The Occupy movement is getting a Sundance spin.

title: Britain to Investigate Role in Claim of Torture by Libyans
description: LONDON  British officials announced on Thursday that they had ordered a criminal investigation into the role played by MI6, the countrys secret intelligence service, in operations that led to two Libyan opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi being delivered to Libyan jails, where, they said, they were tortured by Colonel Qaddafis secret police.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: For Europe, Few Options in a Vicious Cycle of Debt | As difficult as the last two years have been for Europe, 2012 could be even tougher. Each week, countries will need to sell billions of dollars worth of bonds  a staggering $1 trillion in total  to replace existing debt and cover current budget deficits.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Billionaires Backing and Digging Deeper on Downton
description: Politico profiles the three billionaires who could drag out the Republican presidential nomination process by nearly single handedly sustaining the advertising campaigns of Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon Huntsman Jr. Their role  writing large checks to PACs that back their candidate  has been aided by recent federal court decisions weakening checks on political spending. They are: Sheldon Adelson, casino magnate and patron to Mr. Gingrich; Jon Huntsman Sr., patron to his son; Foster Friess, patron to Mr. Santorum.

title: Be Vewy, Vewy Quiet
description: Andy Rosenthal gets a bit of a laugh out of Mitt Romneys insistence that the only reason anyone would talk about inequality is the politics of envy, and that if the subject is discussed at all, it should only be in quiet rooms.

title: Tougher Times for Charter Schools
Romney Treads Familiar Path Toward Nomination
description: With the first two Republican presidential primaries of the 2012 campaign now over, there are similarities to the 2008 contest  and lessons for Mitt Romney as he moves toward the general election.

title: Getting Patients to Take Charge of Their Health
description: One afternoon, I heard a colleague let out an exasperated groan in front of the hospital computers. His patient had been admitted. Again.

title: Bnter Turns Into Banters and Lets You Post via Text
description: Bnter, a New York start-up company that lets people artfully post their witty text, Twitter and instant-message exchanges online, has attracted just 60,000 users since it began inOctober 2010. So it is making some changes, updating its sites design and letting users post via text message, a feature designed with Siri in mind.

title: Out There | Michael Wangs Carbon Copies
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Out With the New, In With the Newer at DC Comics
description: A few months into a DC Comics initiative under which the superhero publisher restarted its long-running series at issue No. 1, some of those narratives will go no further: the company announced on Thursday morning that it is canceling six of its comic books and introducing six new ones, keeping the total amount of its continuing titles at the magic number of 52.

title: London Metal Exchange to Review Takeover Bids in February
description: LONDON  The London Metal Exchange, the worlds largest metal futures market, plans to review initial takeover offers at a board meeting on Feb. 23.

title: Improving the City With Vigilance for All
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in the Bronx on Thursday to give his yearly State of the City speech at a campus of small schools that used to be Morris High School. In case you wondered, the high school was named for Gouverneur Morris, one of the countrys founders. It had nothing to do with Philip Morris. Mr. Bloomberg is not the sort to be caught in a place that sounds like a cigarette.

title: Image of the Day: January 12
A North Korean Soldier Finds His Casablanca
description: North Korea, the Stalinist hermit kingdom and one of the worlds most backward and isolated countries, is also a realm where fiction making  state-sponsored storytelling, that is  reigns supreme. At least, thats how Adam Johnson depicts the dictatorial Communist state in his harrowing and deeply affecting new novel, The Orphan Masters Son, which recounts the picaresque adventures of its title character, Jun Do, a soldier turned kidnapper turned surveillance officer, who tries to stay alive as he stumbles his way through the government bureaucracy.

title: Touch-Screen Gorilla Glass Slims Down
description: LAS VEGAS  The screen on your smartphone or tablet is almost certainly made of a special class of glass known as Gorilla glass. Corning, a major glass maker, introduced the second generation of its Gorilla glass at the International Consumer Electronics Show this week.

title: A New Set of Awards, Courtesy of the Carpetbagger
description: It was inevitable: after years of covering awards season, the Bagger has come up with some prizes of our own. They are the Thursdays, in honor of the best moments from Oscar hopefuls thus far this week (and the fact that Thursday is also the day our column appears is just a coincidence, surely). The first round of winners are here. But as always there were still more worthy folks who deserved recognition. The Bagger is nothing if not generous with the praise.

title: Malicious Software Attacks Security Cards Used by Pentagon
description: Chinese hackers have deployed a new cyber weapon that is aimed at the Defense Department, the Department of Homeland Security, the State Department and potentially a number of other United States government agencies and businesses, security researchers say.

title: Yes, He Discovered the Titanic. No, He Doesnt Want to Talk About It.
description: Robert Ballard has made quite a few notable discoveries in deep waters around the world in the last 27 years. But most people still want to hear him use the T-word.

title: What Were Reading
description: MSNBC: The dodginess of third-party audits rather than government inspections has been highlighted by a Congressional investigation of a cantelope-borne listeria outbreak that killed 30 people last year. The auditor awarded Jensen Farms in Colorado, the source of the tainted fruit, a superior rating just before the outbreak.  Glenn Collins

title: ING Revises I.P.O. Plans
description: The ING Group is abandoning plans for an initial public offering of its combined Asian and European businesses, citing turbulence in the equity markets.

title: Poetry Pairing | January
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches W. S. Merwins January with a 2011 story about enjoying the season despite the cold  Snow Forecast? Set Up the Patio.

title: A Wintry Mix of Opinions on a Seasons Missing Snow
description: Where is the snow? That is the question swirling  unlike actual flurries  across New York City and its suburbs, where sidewalks have been relentlessly gray and yards stubbornly green this winter. After a decade of higher-than-average snowfalls, including last years snowiest January ever, nary a flake has fallen since the freak October storm.

title: Michigan Diary: Getting to Know the Boys
description: This Sunday at Progressive Field, home of the Cleveland Indians, the Wolverines of Michigan will be capping a weekend series with the Buckeyes of Ohio State in the Frozen Diamond Faceoff. With all the pressures of this series (the first game is Friday in Columbus), Im here to provide some comic relief about our team and past experiences of playing outdoors.

title: The Good News Bear
description: You have to hand it to Robert Griffin III. It was no small feat bringing joy to this college football season. He not only won a Heisman Trophy while lifting Baylor into a level of the sports atmosphere it hardly knew existed, he also made a lot of people happy just watching him play, equal parts glittering talent and spunk and an electrifying sense of occasion.

title: Thursday Reading: Americas Binge Drinking, on a Map
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Should The Times Be a Truth Vigilante?
description: Im looking for reader input on whether and when New York Times news reporters should challenge facts that are asserted by newsmakers they write about.

title: Californias Coastline Controversy
description: On January 1, 2012, a controversial series of marine reserves that restrict fishing went into effect in Southern California.

title: In South Carolina, Romney Defends Bain Record
description: GREER, S.C.  Before jetting off for a quick trip to Florida, Mitt Romney stopped by a motorcycle dealership here Thursday morning, where he defended his record at Bain Capital, which has recently come under attack by his Republican rivals, and sought to subtly play up his pro-life credentials.

title: In a Test, Target Plans to Add an Apple Store Inside 25 Stores
description: Target said on Thursday that it planned to test Apple centers at 25 of its retail locations this year.

title: Daily Report: The Struggle Over In-Car Tech
description: Sam Grobart, personal technology editor for The Times, reports that automakers are pursuing two tracks when it comes to technology in cars. They want to bring all the tools and entertainment from the drivers smartphone onto the dashboard. At the same time they want to add safety features that make driving almost foolproof  which could save a driver from the very distractions that the smartphone integration has created.

title: Perry Holds Back on Bain Attack Until Pressed
description: BLYTHEWOOD, S.C.  Rick Perry appeared to drop his attacks against Mitt Romney for practicing what Mr. Perry has called vulture capitalism. Until he didnt.

title: Red Carpet Campaign
description: It is the height of the campaign season, in politics and in Hollywood, and the red carpet gives actors, directors and producers a chance to practice their stump speeches and charm the press.

title: Romney Backers Release New Anti-Gingrich Ad
description: The Restore Our Future super PAC supporting Mitt Romney has unleashed a new ad against Newt Gingrich called Desperate that faults Gingrich supporters for attacks on Mr. Romney but then goes on the accuse Mr. Gingrich of having more baggage than the airlines, while saying that he has been fined for ethics violations and has been on Freddie Macs payroll.

title: Bolton Endorses Romney, Citing Strong Defense Posture
description: WASHINGTON  John R. Bolton, a neoconservative who served as President Bushs ambassador to the United Nations, endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Thursday.

title: Boys School Affiliated With Catholic Group Draws Conservatives in Washington
description: POTOMAC, Md.  Are your jackets on, boys? Joe Cardenas inspects his charges in a first-period freshman humanities class, sees that they are all appropriately blazered and standing tall, bows his head and begins the morning Hail Mary: Hail Mary, full of grace, the Lord is with thee ... Only when they have finished the prayer do they take their jackets off. They sit and open copies of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, the 14th-century English romance.

title: No-Fishing Rule Roils Southern California
description: When Californias then-governor, Gray Davis, signed into law the sweeping Marine Life Protection Act in 1999, state wildlife officials knew theyd have a fight on their hands.

title: Dear FloFab: Im Your Waiter, Not Honeybunch
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Oudin Saves Nine Match Points in Spirited Loss to Robson
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Melanie Oudins first Grand Slam qualifying match in more than two years looked like it would be over in a blur.

title: CVS Settles Prescription Price Case
description: After more than two years of investigation, CVS Caremark agreed on Thursday to pay $5 million to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission that the company had misrepresented the price of certain prescription drugs in one of its Medicare drug plans, causing many older consumers to pay significantly higher prices than advertised.

title: Asked & Answered | Joanna Neborsky

title: Start the Presses: Jeremy Jordan Will Star in Newsies on Broadway
description: Clyde died, but Jeremy Jordan will live again on Broadway as Jack Kelly, the rabble-rousing newsboy and leading role in the musical Newsies.

title: Up Front
description: Emma Gilbey Keller, who this week reviews Girl Land, Caitlin Flanagans take on adolescence, has a prime view of this developmental terrain as the mother of two girls, ages 14 and 9. But according to Keller, the world Flanagan describes  colored by passion and confusion and intensity and often difficulty  is strikingly different from the realm her own daughters inhabit. My girls talk much more about the exciting things they can do rather than the challenges, Keller wrote. I love that. Theyre both very gung-ho. They believe they can do anything they set their minds to. I wasnt brought up to believe that.

title: On Second Day of Qualifying, Success for American Women
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  News and notes from the second day of qualifying at the 2012 Australian Open, a day on which all women in qualifying took the court and rain-postponed mens first-round matches were completed.

title: Sundance Sued Over Opening-Night Documentary
description: LOS ANGELES  Its not unusual for the subjects of documentaries to dislike what they see on screen, sometimes resorting to defamation lawsuits. A Florida time-share developer, David Siegel, is taking the unusual step of suing not over the content of a film about his family but over a written description of it.

title: Megabytes From the Motor Show
description: DETROIT  Paper news releases were rare sights during media previews for the auto show, as automakers continued to give the novelty storage-device market plenty of commissions.

title: More About T.S.A.s Confiscated Cupcake
description: Like many Americans, I am a fan of the cupcake. Just saying the word makes me smile. (Go ahead, say it: cupcake. See?)

title: Jason Aldean and Nicki Minaj to Perform at the Grammys
description: The country music star Jason Aldean and the rapper Nicki Minaj will be among the first-time performers during the Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 12, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday. Mr. Aldean and Ms. Minaj are nominated for several awards. They will be joined by Kelly Clarkson, Foo Fighters, Bruno Mars and Taylor Swift.

title: Age Discrimination Takes Its Toll
description: Raise your hand if youve felt that people treat you with less respect or courtesy than others, that they act as if youre not smart, that you get poorer service in stores and restaurants than others  in short, if youve felt discriminated against because of age, gender, ethnicity, income, disability, appearance, even marital status.

title: Justice Department Memo on Recess Appointments
description: A previously secret legal memorandum concluded that President Obama had the power to lawfully consider the Senate to be on a lengthy break  even though Congress contended otherwise  and make recess appointments.

title: New York Plans Bigger Recycling Effort
description: The Bloomberg administration has set a goal of doubling the amount of garbage it diverts from landfills over the next five years.

title: 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico
description: With the citys street art scene, a mescal-fueled night life and one of Mexicos most exciting regional cuisines, Oaxaca is as cosmopolitan as it is architecturally stunning.

title: 36 Hours: Oaxaca, Mexico
description: WITH Oaxacas imposing Baroque churches, plant-filled courtyards and shady plazas perfect for people-watching, its tempting to see the city as a photogenic relic of Mexicos colonial past. But Oaxaca City, the capital of one of the countrys poorest states and a college town teeming with students, isnt quaint or stagnant; its a small but dynamic city, still emerging economically from the social unrest that put it in the international spotlight, and crippled its tourism industry, in 2006. That uprising  a protest by striking teachers that was met with police violence and led to a protracted conflict  is now history, but its legacy is everywhere in a streetscape of politically inspired stencil art, which has turned adobe walls and concrete sidewalks into a public gallery. Combined with the citys long-established studio art scene, a vibrant cafe culture, a mescal-fueled night life and one of Mexicos most exciting regional cuisines, Oaxaca is as cosmopolitan as it is architecturally stunning.

title: Strategies for Surviving the Red Carpet Rigmarole
description: The Bagger took a little tour of this weeks award shows (so far) and asked people how they prepare for the rigmarole of the red carpet.

title: Foursquare Wants to Plan Your Next Meal  and Vacation
description: Foursquare, the app that lets people share their locations with select friends, is moving beyond the check-in.

title: Praising God, for an Interception?
description: Why do athletes only thank God when something good happens on the field? If Tim Tebow thanked Jesus after throwing an interception, it would be more of a teachable moment, says William C. Rhoden.

description: Why do athletes only thank God when something good happens on the field? If Tim Tebow thanked Jesus after throwing an interception, it would be more of a teachable moment, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Morris Campus Students Welcome the Mayor
Hiring Freeze Hinders a Fight Against Police Misconduct
description: There were some head-spinning developments on Wednesday at the Civilian Complaint Review Boards first monthly meeting of 2012.

title: An Invisible Keyboard Aims to Improve Touch-Screen Typing
description: LAS VEGAS  A Jerusalem-based start-up is trying to eliminate a problem that you didnt know existed: the visibility of a keyboard.

title: The Sun, the Moon and the Quail
description: Jennifer Gee, a biologist at the Claremont University Consortium and the University of California, Riverside, writes from the tropical dry forest near lamos, Mexico, where she and Jennifer Calkins are studying Callipepla quail.

title: Justice Dept. Defends Obama Recess Appointments
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had the lawful power to consider the Senate to be on a lengthy absence  even though it considered itself to be meeting regularly  when he made a set of highly disputed recess appointments last week, the Justice Department concluded in a legal memorandum disclosed on Thursday.

title: Is Age Tipping the Balance in the N.B.A.?
description: Wednesday night a pair of games may have revealed four franchises headed in opposite directions. The nationally televised Dallas-Boston game should have been a power battle. In addition to being the defending champions, the Mavericks have won 50 or more games in 11 straight seasons. Meanwhile, in the last four seasons the Celtics have won a championship, an average of 61 games per season, and four straight division titles. Although the game was a close one  the Celtics tied the score with 25 seconds remaining before the Mavs scored the final five points  it appeared as if these teams arent as relevant as they once were.

title: What the New Dean at Pomona Looks for in an Essay
description: As part of our effort to pass along authoritative guidance on applying to American colleges to an audience of students and families in India, we have recently posted the second installment in a regular Choice series on The New York Timess India Ink blog.

title: A View From Russia, on Rails
description: David Gilkey had 16 days to shoot a photo essay aboard the Trans-Siberian Railway. More than two weeks with little to do other than to gaze out the window and catch glimpses of passing towns and people; smoke trailing high above factories and fields quilted with snow.

title: Colbert for President? Tune In Tonight
description: 5:00 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast | January 12, 2012
description: An interview with former President Jimmy Carter in Cairo | "Porgy and Bess" opens on Broadway.

title: Money in Politics
description: The night before the New Hampshire primary, at a rally in the town of Bedford, Mitt Romney confronted an Occupy protester holding up a get money out of politics sign. Mr. Romney asked the protester to explain her position, and she said more or less what shed written in magic marker.

title: Bloomberg Takes On Union With Education Proposals
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, doubling down on his efforts to improve the citys long-troubled schools, on Thursday outlined a series of proposals to reward the best teachers and, in some cases, to replace others.

title: Did Someone Say Tragedy? How About 7?
description: SEAN GRANEY knows its weird that his latest play is being produced.

title: Mayors State of the City Address
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave his State of the City address on Thursday. You can watch it in the player above, and read the full text of the prepared speech as provided by the mayors office.

title: Agencys Final Work for Target Involves Candy and Dog Treats
description: The swan song for the relationship between Target and its lead creative advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy, will come this spring.

title: Wheelies: The Eastern Promises Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Football and the Fear of Concussions
description: If football ever dies, writes Jonah Lehrer at Grantland, it will die from the outside in.

title: Iran Signals Revenge Over Killing of Scientist
description: Iran expressed deepening fury at Israel and the United States on Thursday over the drive-by bombing that killed a nuclear scientist in Tehran the day before, and signaled that its Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps might carry out revenge assassinations.

title: Bloomberg Unveils Ambitious Proposals for Schools
Spate of Self-Immolations Reported in Tunisia
description: More than a year after the self-immolation in Tunisia that incited the first revolution of the Arab Spring, Tunisians are setting themselves on fire at a disturbingly high rate, with at least four people doing so in the last week.

title: London Underground | A Room for London
description: A wonderfully surreal vision comes into view as you walk across Waterloo Bridge: a boat moored atop the Southbank Centres Queen Elizabeth Hall. And this is not just any boat. A collaboration between the architect David Kohn and the artist Fiona Banner, it is part sculpture, part micro-hotel. A Room for London, as it is known, is the result of a design competition run by two inspired clients  Living Architecture, which commissions and rents vacation houses designed by cutting-edge architects, and Artangel, which commissions contemporary art projects  to offer a unique, one-bedroom accommodation with some of the best views in London, and a program of live performances and events. (A Room for London has a one-night, two-person limit, and rates start at 120 pounds, or about $185.65.)

title: Havens Kitchen to Offer Classes, Catering and Retail
description: Alison Schneider, a food-loving, stay-at-home Manhattan mother of five, conducted some Greenmarket tours and taught informal cooking classes here and there. Then she wanted more. So she started pursuing a masters degree in food studies at New York University. And now she is opening Havens Kitchen, an elegantly designed shop, cooking school, catering kitchen and party rooms on two floors of a 19th-century carriage house in Chelsea.

title: Amid Crisis, President of Pakistan Visits Dubai
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari flew to Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, on Thursday on what an aide said was a short visit for a wedding from which he would return overnight. The move was surprising, coming as tensions between the civilian government and the countrys powerful military have risen sharply and drawn in the judiciary.

title: North Korean Television Reports Plan to Embalm Kims Body
description: As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, North Korea announced on Thursday that it would place the embalmed body of Kim Jong-il on permanent display in a Pyongyang mausoleum, alongside that of his father, Kim Il-sung, who died in 1994 but still holds the title of president.

title: Polls Show Gains for Romney  But Not in South Carolina
description: 3:36 p.m. | Updated I wrote on Wednesday that I expected Mitt Romney to expand his modest lead in the South Carolina polls once his victory in New Hampshire was reflected in the surveys there.

title: Born in Unity, South Sudan Is Torn Again
description: PIBOR, South Sudan  The trail of corpses begins about 300 yards from the corrugated metal gate of the United Nations compound and stretches for miles into the bush.

title: In South Sudan, a Descent into Violence
description: Bitter ethnic tensions that had largely been shelved for the sake of achieving independence have ruptured into a cycle of massacre and revenge that neither the American-backed government nor the United Nations has been able to stop.

title: For One Roaming Bird, Climate Change Is No Albatross
description: European researchers have identified a creature they say is benefiting from the effects of climate change: the wandering albatross of the Southern Ocean, which surrounds Antarctica.

title: Heart Attacks Uncommon During Marathons
description: About two million people participate in marathons or half marathons every year, and you might think that that kind of strenuous exercise involving so many people would lead to a lot of heart attacks. But you would be wrong.

title: Greek Yogurt a Boon for New York State
description: Sales of Greek yogurt are booming, benefiting from a perception that the food is healthier than regular yogurt and other snacks.

title: Plea Deal for Officer Accused of Civil Rights Violation
description: A white New York City police officer who was charged with violating the civil rights of a black man on Staten Island has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty, his lawyer said on Thursday.

title: The Return of Tony Melillos Ts
description: Longtime devotees of the sportswear designer Tony Melillo will be pleased to learn that, after roughly a three-year absence, his precision-cut T-shirts will be returning to stores next month through an exclusive arrangement with Barneys New York.

title: N.H.L. Announces All-Star Rosters, Including Three Rangers
description: The full N.H.L. All-Star teams were announced on Thursday, filling out the rosters after Ottawa fans stocked the top six vote-getters with four Senators (Daniel Alfredsson, Jason Spezza, Milan Mihalek and Erik Karlsson  and yes, Karlsson was the top vote-getter) in honor of the game being played Jan. 29 in lovely suburban Kanata, Ontario. The top six was rounded out with a Maple Leaf, Dion Phaneuf, and a Bruin, goalie Tim Thomas.

title: Suzan-Lori Parks on 'Porgy and Bess'
description: Suzan-Lori Parks, who wrote a reworked book for "The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess," now on Broadway, talks about some of the changes in the show and in the number "I Got Plenty of Nothing.

title: Gingrich Sees Wealthy Institutions Behind Bain Attacks Backlash
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Amid calls from Republican leaders to back off criticism of Mitt Romney for deals he made at Bain Capital, Newt Gingrich defended the attacks and called on Mr. Romney to provide more details about corporate buyouts that led to bankruptcies.

title: Have Australian Open Questions? Christopher Clarey Has Answers
description: Who is the favorite in the mens singles at the Australian Open? Will playing in her home country have any kind of effect on Samantha Stosur? Which under-the-radar players could do well this year? Christopher Clarey, who covers tennis for The Times and for The International Herald Tribune, will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear early next week on Straight Sets.

title: At Cinema Eye Honors, Documentarians Try to Understand New Oscar Rules
description: The brouhaha over proposed changes to the Academys rules for qualifying documentaries was a major topic of conversation at the Cinema Eye Honors, which recognize nonfiction film, on Wednesday night.

title: Some Lenders to Students Face Greater U.S. Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is stepping up its scrutiny of nontraditional lenders to students at profit-making colleges and trade schools that have high rates of default, the newly appointed director of the bureau said Thursday.

title: Goldman Lost 50 Partners Last Year
description: Goldman Sachs lost 50 partners in 2011, one of the biggest annual losses of senior executives in its 13 years as a publicly traded company.

title: MF Global Brokerage Trustee Meets Customers
description: More than 100 customers of MF Global gathered on Thursday to meet with the trustee liquidating the failed firms core trading operations, hoping to learn more about $1.2 billion in missing money.

title: Warming to U.S. Plea, Japan Pledges to Cut Oil From Iran
description: TOKYO  Japan pledged on Thursday to cut its oil imports from Iran, responding to a plea from the visiting United States Treasury Secretary, Timothy Geithner, who was rebuffed by China on the matter a day earlier.

title: Fte Accompli | T Party in Los Angeles
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Pink Tea Cup Owner Opens a Harlem Wine Bar
description: Auberge Laurent, an elegant, brick-walled wine bar with a lounge area in the back, serves an array of wines, mostly French, and a few beers by the glass and the bottle, along with a brief menu of cheeses and charcuterie. This newcomer to Harlem is owned by Lawrence Page and was supposed to have been the uptown location for his Pink Tea Cup. Mr. Page, who owns the Actors Playhouse in Greenwich Village, bought the original Pink Tea Cup, a venerable diner-style soul food spot on Grove Street, which had closed, and moved it to a larger space on Seventh Avenue South.

title: Teaching Dickens With The New York Times
description: Updated | Feb. 7, 2012

title: Cubs Seek to Re-Sign Wood
description: Theo Epstein has had a lot of tough decisions to make in the three months since taking over baseball operations of the Cubs and next up on Epsteins to-do list is determining if the Cubs should resign veteran relief pitcher Kerry Wood. The Chicago Tribune reports Thursday that Epstein wants to keep Wood, and a deal could be done soon.

title: Delta and TPG Said to Weigh Bids for American Airlines
description: 9:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Flagging Sales in Britain Raise Recession Worries
description: LONDON  A profit warning on Thursday from Britains largest retailer by sales was the latest sign that the British economy might be heading for a recession, or be in one already.

title: New Storage Device Is Very Small, at 12 Atoms
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Researchers at I.B.M. have stored and retrieved digital 1s and 0s from an array of just 12 atoms, pushing the boundaries of the magnetic storage of information to the edge of what is possible.

title: Billy Crystal Returns to Big Screen at South by Southwest
description: LOS ANGELES If youve been waiting to see Billy Crystal, last a movie lead nine years ago in Analyze That, back on the big screen, wait no more.

title: Lil Wayne, the Memoirist
description: Lil Wayne, the New Orleans rapper, has turned his experience at Rikers Island into a memoir that will be published in November, two years after his release, Grand Central Publishing announced on Thursday. The book, Gone Till November, is described as an internal monologue based on journals Lil Wayne kept during his eight-month stint at the New York City jail on a gun possession charge.

title: Bankruptcy Filings Declined in 2011
description: Bankruptcy filings fell nearly 12 percent in 2011 from the year before, according to statistics from Epiq Systems, which tracks the data.

title: Dead Voters in South Carolina? Maybe. Maybe Not.
description: Some readers have been calling my attention to a new report stating that the Department of Motor Vehicles in South Carolina found over 900 votes recorded in recent elections from dead people. These comments are intended, sometimes in a well-meaning way and sometimes not, to show me that what Ive written about voter fraud and voter ID laws is wrong.

title: Photo Replay: January 12
description: A collection of photos from the day in sports, including shots of World Cup downhill skiing in Switzerland and trampoline Olympic qualifying in London.

title: TimesCast | Video Inflames Afghans
description: January 12, 2012  An inflammatory video has surfaced showing four Marines urinating on three dead Taliban fighters. (Warning: Video contains graphic content.)

title: Hirst, Globally Dotting His I
description: Thanks to the Gagosian art empire, a ludicrous number of paintings by Damien Hirst are on display right now: 331 of Mr. Hirsts implacably cheerful spot abstractions spread among Gagosians 11 galleries in 8 cities on 3 continents.

title: On Our Radar: A Fracking Confrontation in Ohio
description: A crowd jeers at Ohio environmental officials as they take questions at a public forum about the relationship between fracking for a deep-injection well in Youngstown and 11 recent earthquakes there. A geologist told the audience that he did not believe the gas drilling caused the earthquakes. [Business Journal Daily]

title: Sunday Night Salon
description: The director Ed Sylvanus Iskandar hosts a theater salon in his Midtown Manhattan loft where young actors gather to read new plays and share a meal.

title: Tale of Sex and Class, Updated for Appalachia
description: Miss Julie comes to contemporary Appalachia with all her sexual and psychological baggage in tow in Cattywampus, a raw and raucous updating of August Strindbergs classic, written and directed by Robert Cucuzza.

title: Coming Soon | Steel Toes
description: The Fall 2012 European mens shows are underway here in Florence at Pitti Uomo, where a number of noteworthy items have already made multiple appearances. The metallic cap toe was first spotted on both a lace-up oxford and a boot at Grenson, a design leader in the very traditional world of English shoemaking. Its a slightly subversive, chic formal shoe for a daring guy, and also a denim-friendly basic with some extra kick.

title: The Mayor Has Spoken. What Do You Think?
Synthetic Windpipe Is Used to Replace Cancerous One
description: Surgeons in Sweden have replaced the cancerous windpipe of a Maryland man with one made in a laboratory and seeded with the mans cells.

title: Another California Republican Retires From the House
description: Representative Jerry Lewis of California, the Republican who has represented San Bernardino and the Redlands for 33 years in Congress, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of this term.

title: A Disco in Your Car
description: LAS VEGAS  If you have ever wished you could drive a dance club and have a DJ in your dashboard  and really, who hasnt?  Pioneer has your car stereo.

title: LeBron James and the Definition of Clutch
description: Lets begin with a fundamental premise, and one that seems particularly popular and relevant in light of the Miami Heats overtime letdown in Wednesdays game against the Los Angeles Clippers:

title: TimesCast | Carter in Cairo
description: January 12, 2012  Former President Jimmy Carter is in Cairo this week to help monitor the final round of parliamentary elections. He met with The Timess Cairo bureau chief, David D. Kirkpatrick.

title: Porsche Introduces a Brawnier Boxster for 2013
description: A substantially revised Boxster was unveiled by Porsche on Thursday, mere days after the German automakers executives packed up from the Detroit auto show media previews.

title: Court Martial Recommended in WikiLeaks Case
description: WASHINGTON  The military officer who presided over an evidentiary hearing on charges against Pfc. Bradley Manning, accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of confidential government documents to WikiLeaks, recommended on Friday that Private Manning face court martial.

title: Split Decision in Prime-Time Battle
description: The broadcast networks settled for a ratings split on Wednesday night with ABCs comedy block taking the top spot in the 18-to-49 demographic while the broadcast of the 38th annual Peoples Choice Awards drew enough total viewers (8.9 million) to give CBS the win in that category, according to Nielsen.

title: Parental Quandary Considered: Grandma Gives Frilly Gifts to a Tomboy
description: Teaching children tograciously receive a gift they are not thrilled with is a common etiquette question, but last week, a parenting quandary came in that took the problem just a little farther. What if those unwanted gifts also bring an unwanted message? Gretchens daughter Mia (all names have been changed) has always worn boys clothing  not just gender-neutral clothing, but emphatically boys clothes, right down to the skin. Shes always said she wished shed been born a boy. But Mias grandmother (Gretchens mother-in-law) sends boxes after boxes of fabulously frilly pink dresses, tights and bows.

title: As the Directors Make Their Documentary Picks, New Oscar Rules Take Effect
description: The Academys Board of Governors made it official today: to qualify for the documentary feature Oscar, a film must be reviewed in The New York Times and/or The Los Angeles Times, in addition to the previously required weeklong run in both New York and Los Angeles. Once a film qualifies, the entire Documentary Branch will vote in a process explained here and debated here.

title: Gulf Nations Aid U.S. Push to Choke Off Iran Oil Sales
description: WASHINGTON  Pressure on Iran mounted on Thursday, with the United States saying it was determined to isolate the countrys central bank, and three of Irans largest oil customers  Japan, South Korea and China  getting assurances that Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers would help make up any gap in supplies if they curtailed oil purchases from Iran.

title: Saving Wayward Souls With Pleasures of the Flesh
description: So what if hookers have hearts of gold? Porn stars, as it turns out, are angels.

title: WowWee Creates Games That Blend the Physical and Virtual Worlds
description: LAS VEGAS  At the International Consumer Electronics Show WowWee unveiled a previously announced line of toys it calls Appcessories, which are game pieces, collectable figures and toys that control games on Android or Apple devices.

title: China Case Reveals Risks of Investing in a Foreign Company
description: The management of the ChinaCast Education Corporation appears to have a novel response to board elections: ignore them.

title: Exit Left, Wordlessly
description: A STORY that haunts me involves a woman I know whose fianc went out to inspect a potential apartment for their married life and never came back. He wasnt dead in a ditch. He was just gone, without clarification.

title: Vain Glorious | Sontag: Reborn': the Makeup
description: Five years ago, in the Builders Association production of Super Vision, the makeup artist Dick Page  turned the actress Moe Angelos into a Sri Lankan grandmother. Now, for the multimedia show Sontag: Reborn, currently at the Public Theater, hes transformed the performer into a young (and old) Susan Sontag. It was an unusual mandate, because I dont normally get asked to make people look older,  Page said, referring to his usual beat: fashion photo shoots and runway shows.

title: Romney and the Bailout
description: Like a lot of people, I was fairly startled by Mitt Romneys new defense of his work at Bain: it was just like the auto bailout!

title: Digital Notes: New Facebook Tool Lets Users Listen Together
description: 5:32 p.m. | Updated Daily updates on the business of digital music:

title: Host Without the Most
description: I was recently at a dinner party and watched our 82-year-old host berate his 62-year-old wife at every turn. He told her he hated her outfit within five minutes of our arrival. From there, he seemed to criticize every step she took to make the evening pleasant. I was squirming in my chair and couldnt wait to leave. I dont know whom to confront about this abusive relationship. Whats a good friend to do? Anonymous

title: Do College Grads Earn Less Now Than 40 Years Ago?
description: On Wednesday I wrote about how a college degree has gotten more economically valuable in the last few decades. A number of readers wrote in asking whether the numbers might be skewed by incomes at the very top. After all, the top 1 percent has received huge raises in the last few decades, and that group is mostly college-educated.

title: Like Tebow, Patriots Sharpened Offense at Florida
description: Tim Tebow was still a high school phenomenon in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., not yet the prototypical quarterback for an offense that had begun to sweep college football, when the first phone call from Foxborough, Mass., was made to Gainesville, Fla.

title: Keith Urban Books First Post-Surgery Gig, at Grand Ole Opry
description: Keith Urban will return to the stage for the first time since undergoing surgery on his vocal cords late last year when he sings at the Grand Ole Opry in February, the Opry announced Thursday. Mr. Urban has been forced to rest his voice since doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center removed a benign polyp from one of his vocal cords. Left untreated polyps can bleed when a singer is performing, leading to scarring on the vocal cords that can alter a voices timbre.

title: Surprise! Israel Museum Is Receiving a Richter
description: The trouble with art-world gossip is that it is often wrong, yet it goes around and around so fast that speculation becomes fact. Heres a recent example: After the best of a group of abstract canvases by Gerhard Richter sold at Sothebys in November for $20.8 million, some spectators at the sale decided that the anonymous telephone buyer had been the French billionaire Bernard Arnault. It was an educated guess; Mr. Arnault is a big collector of contemporary art with deep pockets. He also happens to be planning to build a $200 million museum in Paris designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry.

title: In Victory, Baylor Women Recognize Deeper Loss
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: Summing Up Andy Rooney, Who Long Had the Last Word
description: He actually thought death did not apply to him, said Andy Rooneys son, Brian, which is a great way to go.

title: Online Suggestion Box a Peril for Putin
description: MOSCOW  It took only a few hours after its launch on Thursday for Vladimir V. Putins presidential campaign Web site to become an object lesson in the hazards that await him between now and the election on March 4.

title: Obama Advisers View of Unequal Opportunity
description: What Mitt Romney a few days ago called the bitter politics of envy, President Obamas chief economic adviser instead described Thursday as the basic economics of unequal opportunity.

title: Absolutely Nobody, Discovering Old Ceramics
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  Robert F. Doares Jr. and Barbara Myers Wood have no doctorates or institutional backing, just time on their hands for freelance ceramics scholarship. A married couple, they have shown up unannounced at the offices of venerable manufacturers, asking to rifle archives, and have then made major discoveries.

title: Deal Would Lead Letterman to a Late-Night Milestone
description: PASADENA, Calif.  It appears increasingly likely that David Letterman will extend his contract, pushing him past the 30-year run of his idol, Johnny Carson.

title: JPMorgan Shuffles Management Ranks
description: Jamie Dimon has again shuffled his senior management team.

title: Its the 60s; Detach Yourself
description: In a 1965 essay on postwar science-fiction films Susan Sontag noted a common ingredient: a depersonalization of the characters, a kind of emotionless zombie state that occurred when their minds were taken over by aliens or robots. Some of this, she wrote, reflected the basic conditions of modern life. But it also pointed toward something new in the nuclear era. Now humans had to contend not only with the fear of death but also the psychologically insupportable possibility of a collective incineration and extinction which could come at any time, virtually without warning.

title: One on One: Stephen Elop, Nokia Chief
description: Stephen A. Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker,has a difficult challenge ahead to restore the companys credibility in the American market, where Googles Android and Apples iPhone are thriving. Hes betting that using Microsofts Windows Phone operating system on its devices will help with a turnaround. The following are edited excerpts of an interview from earlier this week at the International Consumer Electronics Show after Mr. Elop introduced a new phone that will be sold by AT&T, the Lumia 900:

title: Neighborhood Joint | Brennan & Carr
description: In business since 1938, the restaurant has a menu that changes perhaps only once in a generation, and the regulars like it that way.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: MySpace Surprise and Intels Mobile Chip
description: Interesting things that The New York Times reporters and editors found on the Web on Thursday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Jaime King, Actress
description: A former fashion model born in Omaha, Jaime King plays Southern belle Lemon Breeland on the CW series Hart of Dixie. Now based in Los Angeles and married to Kyle Newman, a director, Ms. King, 32, is also directing her first feature film, a thriller titled Polar Seasons.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

description: Movies
