description: Theater

title: Ace x Beams, Beams x Ace
description: Today, the Ace Hotel unveils its latest collaboration with the Tokyo-based fashion house Beams.Founded in 1976, Beams is both a private clothing label and department store, as well as a major force within the Japanese retail scene. (The brand operates upwards of 100 locations throughout Japan and Hong Kong, offering music, furniture and art that caters to the ever-changing and expanding tastes of the youth demographic.) Finding something of a kindred spirit in the Japanese brand, the Ace Hotel, another purveyor of hipness, recently collaborated with the company on two one-off projects: a boxing-inspired collection produced with Canadas Wings + Horns and luggage accessories with the iconic Porter brand.

title: Theater Talkback: The Stage, the Screen and the Screen on Stage
description: 12:11 p.m. | Updated  Can film and theater live happily together in the same room? Its not as if they havent had a long relationship already, with each regularly borrowing stories and stars from the other. But now these separate but equal art forms are attempting to practice cohabitation.

title: Compiling a Wish List for the 2012 Tennis Season
description: Every year before the Australian Open, Christopher Clarey, who covers tennis for The Times and The International Herald Tribune, puts together his wish list for the year in tennis. This year his No. 1 wish is something to revive the womens game. He writes:

title: Fallout From Urination Video Spreads
description: Graham Bowley reports on the widening condemnation from American officials, the NATO authorities in Afghanistan and the Afghan government of a video showing four Marines urinating on three dead Taliban fighters.

title: What Does Homeland Security Read?
description: For the last year, the Department of Homeland Security has been routinely monitoring social networking sites like Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and even MySpace. It is an avid reader of The Huffington Post, Jihad Watch, Technorati and, oddly, TruckingInfo.com. But apparently it has no interest in Techmeme and TechCrunch.

title: Eight Men In: Vintage 2008
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men  they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee  have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

title: Raise a Glass and Flash a Smile
description: The Nocturnalist may have hung up her five gowns, but the party keeps rolling at Scene City.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 13-19
description: Pop

title: Travelers Tricks
description: To the Editor: Regarding Get Them to the Debate on Time: Reporters Tips (Practical Traveler, Jan. 1), on our honeymoon to New Zealand and Australia, we ended up with soft-sided bags and could not have been happier. Soft bags without wheels give you nearly twice as much packing space, and when packed right, they often fit under an airline seat (avoiding the nightmare rush for overhead space).

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 13-19
description: Jazz

title: PAC Deluges South Carolina Airwaves With Anti-Romney Ads
description: Some influential Republican voices have denounced Newt Gingrichs attacks on Mitt Romneys career in private equity, but that is not dissuading a super PAC supporting Mr. Gingrich from carpet-bombing the South Carolina airwaves with blistering ads about Bain Capital, Mr. Romneys former firm.

title: In Zurich West, Feeding the Hip and the Hungry
description: FOR much of the past century, the Zurich West neighborhood was best known for its industry, churning out water turbines, electric motors and even ships in the area between the Limmat River and the railway tracks behind the main train station. Then, as manufacturers moved away, contemporary art galleries, museums and design shops sprouted amid abandoned factories in the mid-1990s, creating a gritty haven for the citys creative class.

title: A Growing Risk in Haiti
description: The problem of human waste disposal has become impossible to overlook in Port-au-Prince, with the stench of decomposing bodies replaced by that of excrement.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Jan. 13-19
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 13-19
description: Dance

title: Orphanages in Haiti
description: Since the earthquake, chronic problems in Haiti's orphanages -- like inadequate services and overwhelming poverty -- have only intensified.

title: Hotel Review: St. Pancras Renaissance Hotel, London
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Hot Roast Beef and Close Ties on Avenue U
description: WHEN Eddie Sullivan was a boy, he could earn a dollar from his grandmother for folding the napkins and wiping down the salt and pepper shakers at Brennan & Carr, the restaurant his father, Russ, had just bought in the northeast corner of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. But his grandmother, who had been a waitress there in the 1940s and 50s, was a tough old Irishwoman, he said, and Eddie knew if she found any flaws, that dollar would disappear.

title: Risks: When Too Much Vitamin D Is Too Much
description: Too much vitamin D may be just as bad as too little, a recent study suggests.

title: Inside Flex Mussels
description: Flex Mussels on the Upper East Side, by way of Prince Edward Island, attempts to show off mussels as they've never been shown off before.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 13-19
description: Art

title: Restaurant Review: Little Bird in Portland, Ore.
description: Of all the dishes served at the Little Bird bistro in Portland, Ore., the charcuterie plate best encapsulates its spirit. On a recent evening there, the plate featured the typical chicken liver mousse, but it also included an unusual and seductive foie gras brle, a savory take on the dessert that is so packed with umami and conflicting textures that its memorable even without its delicious apricot-Sauternes jam pairing. That the platter has both elements reveals the ethos of Little Bird, where recognizable favorites are served along with more daring choices.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 13-19
description: Around Town

title: Nephew and Aunt, Like a Wistful Moth and an Enticing Flame
description: The good thing about mathematics is you dont have to talk; you create order without words, declares Nadia (Batrice Dalle), a haughty, self-destructive mathematician holding forth tipsily to her bohemian friends at a nighttime picnic in Domain. A formidable screen presence who suggests a sexy, gap-toothed hybrid of Sade and Fran Drescher, Ms. Dalle exudes a tortured erotic gravitas. This 47-year-old actress, who played a cannibal in Claire Deniss Trouble Every Day, struts through Domain like a restless queen of the night.

title: Can Wal-Mart Push Both Sustainability and Consumption?
description: When Wal-Mart launched its Green Room blog earlier this month, I posed an initial question via Twitter:

title: Santorum Cites a Local Legend
description: HILTON HEAD, S.C.  Rick Santorum is facing questions about supporting earmarks during his time in Congress. He offered up a decidedly South Carolinian response on Thursday, boiling down his defense to two words: Strom Thurmond.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Jan. 13-19
description: Zoem! New Dutch Theater

title: In Winter, Berkshires Culture Moves Indoors
description: FOR many, the Berkshire Mountains are inimitably tied to one season: summer, when the areas tandem blooms of high culture and cherished New England countryside draw a devoted global audience to this sparsely populated corner of Massachusetts.

title: Update to my Previous Post on Truth Vigilantes
description: I have appended a statement from Jill Abramson, the executive editor, responding to this post.

title: Church Choirs Dueling Divas Come Out Singin and Slingin
description: The saving graces of Joyful Noise, a flimsy movie musical whose parts are pasted together with chewing gum and Scotch tape, are its ornate gospel renditions of familiar pop tunes. When you put singers in choir robes and arrange the songs for chorus and soloists to give them big, churchy buildups, hits by Michael Jackson (Man in the Mirror), Paul McCartney (Maybe Im Amazed), Sly and the Family Stone (I Want to Take You Higher), and Stevie Wonder (Signed, Sealed, Delivered Im Yours) become sacred hymns. Thus transfused, higher means spiritually exalted, and yours means in Gods hands. To which I say hallelujah, sort of.

title: The New Lady Hawk Shall Be Called Rosie
description: The tamper-resistant re-voting process has been completed, and City Room readers have chosen a name for the female hawk of Washington Square Park, the soon-to-be leading lady of the ongoing Hawk Cam soap opera.

title: Unspoiled Beauty in Phu Quoc, Vietnam
description: The island has all the creature comforts of a luxurious getaway at relatively inexpensive prices.

title: In Japan, Ample Snowfall
description: The Niseko region sees plenty of snowfall in a breathtaking landscape.

title: In Bustling Vietnam, a Rare and (Still Untrammeled) Escape
description: IT was my first time operating a motorcycle, but I handled the Honda with the confidence of a veteran, zipping alongside my boyfriend, Caleb, through rain-filled potholes on red clay streets. The morning was overcast after a night of thunderstorms, but we were determined to spend as many daylight hours as possible on Sao Beach, the white sand haven rumored to be among the most beautiful spots on Phu Quoc, an island 30 miles off the west coast of Vietnam.

title: Patterns: Study Finds Problem Drinkers Get Bigger Endorphin Kick
description: Drinking alcohol causes a pleasant feeling because it releases endorphins, the brains natural opioids. But a new study has found that problem drinkers differ from social drinkers in the way alcohol affects one part of the brain. The report appeared Wednesday in Science Translational Medicine.

title: Putting the Hip-Hop in History as Founding Fathers Rap
description: Im not throwin away my shot.

title: A Labor Heros Route to Leading a Nation
description: Lula: Son of Brazil is an unabashed hagiography that follows the rise from poverty to national prominence of Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, who served as president of Brazil from 2003 through 2010. The film ends in 1980, the year his beloved mother died while he was in prison. In the same year he helped found the left-wing Workers Party, which stood up against the countrys right-wing military government.

title: Jess and Elizabeth Bishop: Objects and Apparitions
description: Tibor de Nagy

title: Another Good Reason to Tip Your Super
description: In The Divide, the residents of Fifth Avenue and 29th Street find hell in their apartment basement. Not unlike many New Yorkers, youre thinking, but this is worse. Saved and yet trapped by this refuge after a nuclear attack, they devolve into mental and physical depravity. Its well beyond Lord of the Flies: Im talking Kurtz in Apocalypse Now, if he had the energy and mindlessness of youth. Im talking filthy, horrific torture porn.

title: Shopping for the Best Rates
description: THE lowest interest rates in decades sound enticing enough, but they are often out of borrowers reach.

title: Pictures of the Day: Haiti and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Haiti, Indonesia, Russia and France.

title: Mary Raftery, 54, Dies; Irish Journalist Documented Child Abuse
description: Mary Raftery, a journalist whose television documentaries exposed decades of abuse of needy children in state-sponsored, church-run schools in Ireland, prompting an apology by the prime minister and a government investigation, died on Tuesday in Dublin. She was 54.

title: Audi Mounts Technology Blitz at C.E.S.
description: LAS VEGAS  The courtship of the electronics industry and the automobile industry has been a rocky one, with uncertain prospects for a happy marriage.

title: AI WEIWEI
description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: Jeff Wall
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: Niseko, Japans Own St. Moritz
description: I AM barefoot and naked padding along a stone path in the depths of Japanese winter, surrounded by snow-laden pine trees. I slip into a hot pool fed by natural underground springs. Huge, slow-moving snowflakes gently settle on my hair. In the dusk I can see just a few vague figures across the pond-size area  other women barely visible through the steam.

title: The Italo Calvino Soundtrack
description: This week, the Liverpudlian musician and composer Bill Ryder-Jones  known previously for his guitar work with the British rock band The Coral, and also for his boyish good looks  released his first solo effort, If (Domino). It is an album of mostly instrumental music, written as a kind of soundtrack to the Italo Calvino novel If on a Winters Night a Traveler. NPR is now streaming the entire record, which came out late last year in Britain to rave reviews.

title: Struggle and Song Define a Life
description: Its only fitting that Harry Belafontes big, bountiful life has inspired an expansive, understandably hagiographic documentary, Sing Your Song. Silky voiced and snake hipped, with a supernova smile that dazzled Americans and helped demolish racial prejudices, he remains perhaps best known for his lilting version of the Caribbean folk tune The Banana Boat Song (Day-O), a requiem for the exhausted working man. Given his decades of tireless globe-sprinting crusading  alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and African activists alike  its clear that Mr. Belafonte rarely embraced the plaintive refrain of Day-O: Daylight come and me wan go home.

title: A Wedding Dance Thats Also a Workout
description: ATTENDING Indian weddings and ending up the night sweaty and tired from hours of bhangra dancing have been regular parts of my weekend repertory since I was a child. The catchy music can entice even the most die-hard wallflower to move. But though my heart beats fast, and my legs end up sore, Ive never thought of bhangra as a workout.

title: Not Quite an Honest Days Work
description: The absurdity of the story in the largely thrill-free thriller Contraband, its hairpin twists and outrageous coincidences, may keep even hungry action fans away. Thats too bad because the story doesnt matter. (It rarely does.) If anything, the films adherence to implausibility as a defining narrative principle  a reliably winning Mark Wahlberg plays a New Orleans super-smuggler on a fast boat to Panama who faces a wolf, an armored truck and a drip painting  is part of its low-key kick, as is the director Baltasar Kormakurs fondness for industrial landscapes.

title: Strippers With a Plot; Audra McDonald and Sharon Van Etten
description: Gyms are packed with people who resolved to get fit in the new year, and while were all for getting healthy, nothing depresses us more than watching a roomful of hungry New Yorkers fight over free weights and climb Stairmasters to nowhere. The Miser is on vacation this week, living it up in the hedonists paradise of New Orleans, so we think its safe to assume that shed prefer to kick back with a martini and a dish of salted peanuts and watch women of all shapes and sizes get their (and their audiences) heart rates up the old-fashioned way: with stripping and high drama.

title: Q & A
description: When the Rent Arrives Late

title: Mayor Takes On Teachers Union in School Plans
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, directly confronting leaders of the teachers union, proposed on Thursday a merit-pay system that would award top performers with $20,000 raises and threatened to remove as many as half of those working in dozens of struggling schools.

title: Patti Smith Cancels Concert at the Chelsea Hotel
description: 9:48 p.m. | Updated  Patti Smith has canceled a private show she was going to perform for residents Thursday night at the Chelsea Hotel after some said they would not attend.

title: For Some Brokers, 2011 Was Tops
description: SINGLE-FAMILY home sales in Westchester were down about 4.5 percent in 2011 from the year before, and dollar volume was off about 6 percent  partly the result of the downward trend of house prices, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, who recently retired as chief executive of the Westchester-Putnam Board of Realtors.

title: Philadelphia Stories
description: In 2001 the artist Zoe Strauss came up with an unusual idea for an exhibition. It would take place under an elevated section of Interstate 95, in her home city, Philadelphia, and would consist of photographs mounted on the columns that supported the highway. It would be a recurring event, appearing yearly over a decade. It would be free and open to the public, with photocopies of the exhibited works available for purchase for $5 each. And it would take the form of an epic narrative about the beauty and struggle of everyday life, in Ms. Strausss words.

title: Rick Perrys Son Emerges, a Tweet Off the Old Block
description: Mitt Romney has a traveling band of look-alike sons. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has his ever-tweeting daughters. The latest addition to this political kids club is Rick Perrys son Griffin, 28, who has propelled himself into the headlines  and injected some much-needed energy into his fathers decidedly downtrodden candidacy with his Twitter missives from the campaign trail.

title: Blasts From the Feds Past
description: 6:43 p.m. | Updated with link to Times article.

title: Rural Areas Slower to Rebound
description: FOR whatever reason, homes sales picked up in New Jersey in the latter part of 2011. A new statewide market report shows contract signings increased in six of the seven months from May through November, compared with 2010.

title: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
description: The All-Star edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast with the Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta, Adam Rotter of SNYRangersBlog and Billy Jaffe of the NHL Network and MSG.

title: One Debut and One Farewell in an Opera at the Met
description: This seasons revival of Puccinis Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera features a beginning, an ending and everything in between: a young conductors debut, a cast filled with experienced Met singers and the final performances of a company stalwart.

title: All Lines Lead to a Circle In David Parsonss Orbit
description: Count on David Parsons to squeeze as much as he can from a single idea. His company, Parsons Dance, opened its season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with a new work called Round My World. Find the shape in the title and you have the idea.

title: Inside the Fed in 2006: A Coming Crisis, and Banter
description: WASHINGTON  As the housing bubble entered its waning hours in 2006, top Federal Reserve officials marveled at the desperate antics of home builders seeking to lure buyers.

title: Projects With Mass Appeal
description: THE island never seems to lack for grand building plans. But that is sometimes less obvious than it might be, because of what usually happens when plans meet reality. Years can go by before a shovel enters the ground, what with a tangled approvals process and a tough climate for financing.

title: A Bookish Teenager and a Wild Child Grow Up
description: Charmingly low-key, the British coming-of-age drama Albatross offsets slack plotting with creative casting and sensitive performances.

title: The Irresistible Allure Of Banned in Beijing
description: Nothing creates interest in a work like official displeasure, or so, at least, historical precedent suggests. When the British government tried to ban Strausss Salome in 1910, the conductor Thomas Beecham appealed successfully and led a London run that was the hottest ticket of the season. Time was when the label banned in Boston helped guarantee Broadway ticket sales. And after religious figures inveighed against the 1979 Monty Python film, Life of Brian, John Cleese said in a television interview that these people have made me a very rich man.

title: As Clear Day Clears Out, Leap of Faith Will Leap Onto Broadway
description: In a move unusual by Broadway standards, the producers of the new musical Leap of Faith said on Thursday that the show would begin performances on April 3 at the St. James Theater, now home to the Harry Connick, Jr., musical On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.

title: The Gershwins Porgy and Bess Opens
description: The Gershwins Porgy and Bess opens on Broadway.

title: Leaderless, A Hybrid Swings Forward
description: The drummer Terri Lyne Carrington put out an album last year called The Mosaic Project, with all female musicians and singers from different aesthetic areas and generations, swing and backbeats, melodic improvising and rapping, the whole thing loosely categorizable as jazz. It involved a revolving cast of more than a dozen musicians; its probably impossible to take the project on the road.

title: Seeing Spots
description: A look at some of Damien Hirsts spot abstractions on display in New York.

title: Jets Owner Offers Defense of Sanchez
description: The Jets owner, Woody Johnson, speaking publicly Thursday for the first time since the late-season collapse that exposed a splintered locker room, briefly addressed the problems that seemed to overtake the team over the last two weeks.

title: Brought to Us by the B. Q. E.
description: OF all our New York highways, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway under Brooklyn Heights is perhaps the most daring and ingenious, a cantilevered structure narrowly threaded between waterfront warehouses and mansions high above, incidentally creating one of New Yorks great parks, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.

title: A Studio With a Little Give
description: THOUGH David Kulla was never thrilled with his rental, the thought of moving was worse than the reality of remaining.

title: Dont Say We Didnt Warn You
description: Vincent DOnofrio can do crazy. Perhaps you know that from his intellectually tormented detective on televisions Law & Order: Criminal Intent. Or perhaps you know how far he can really take crazy, to brilliant and frightening effect in, say, Full Metal Jacket or The Salton Sea.

title: Juxtaposing Movement And Speech
description: In 2007, after Daniel Linehan unveiled his earnest solo Not About Everything, he didnt get my vote for most likely to succeed. In that piece, which he reprised at the Abrons Arts Center on Tuesday evening, he made a circle of reading material on the stage  along with a copy of Vogue, there was a book about the visual artist Francis Als and within that structure, he started spinning while reciting lines like, This is not about therapy.

title: Zoe Strauss: Ten Years
description: Photos from the exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and on billboards around the city.

title: Mysteries and Truths in Black and White
description: A look at five books by artists ranging from an 18th-century engraver to 20th-century photographers.

title: Free-Spirited Enclaves Reluctant Landowners Fear Capitalisms Harness
description: COPENHAGEN  Last summer, the Danish state offered to sell a good chunk of the 80-odd-acre former military base at the edge of downtown Copenhagen to Christiania, the alternative community whose residents had been squatting there illegally for four decades. For the residents, who fundamentally reject the idea of landownership, this presented an ideological quandary.

title: Major Pain, Minor Glory
description: The taunts in the ring may be make-believe, but the slams against the mat are agonizingly genuine in Robert Greenes vivid documentary Fake It So Real, which examines the weeklong preparations for a Saturday night independent-wrestling match in Lincolnton, N.C.

title: Much More Than Just Maintenance
description: IN New York, the cost of a co-op or condo can seem an impossible hurdle. But alongside the asking price is another figure that can induce sticker shock: the monthly maintenance fee  or, as its called in condos, the common charge.

title: Blasting Off as a Space Tourist
description: Man on a Mission, the most expensive home movie ever made, is one mans genial account of his trip into outer space. Whats odd about it is that while you can certainly sense the joy that this fellow, Richard Garriott, feels in achieving a lifelong dream, youre unlikely to be interested in imitating him. Cramped quarters, bulky wardrobe, unappetizing-looking food: it seems like a Worst Vacation Ever candidate.

title: Somewhere In Europe
description: The latest on Hungary from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, below the fold.

title: In the Fight Against Poverty, Its Time for a Revolution
description: Is it time to rethink our basic assumptions about the way we fight poverty?

title: The Car, a Coveted Piece of Consumer Technology at C.E.S.
description: This week, some of the most gee-whiz automotive technology was to be found not in Detroit, where media previews for the Detroit auto show concluded on Tuesday, but in Las Vegas, where automakers presented the latest thinking around telematics and infotainment systems.

title: Packers Jennings Is Ready for Giants
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  In the locker room after the short-handed Green Bay Packers defeated the Detroit Lions, 45-41, on Jan. 1, nose tackle B. J. Raji was marveling at what had just taken place.

title: Me, Myself and Yoga
Efforts Are Under Way to Tie College to Job Needs
description: Assaying the output of higher education in Texas, Michael Bettersworth evoked the image of a crippled Apollo 13 craft hurtling into space, its future uncertain.

title: This Inside Goldman Deal Comes Steamed, With Sauce
description: Kenny Lao has the kinds of credentials  a masters in business administration from New York University and a former job as a Wall Street analyst  that might come in handy when pitching business to Goldman Sachs.

title: Texans Anti-Piracy Bill Gets Home State Pushback
description: United States Representative Lamar Smith says online piracy is damaging the United States economy and putting American lives at risk. Foreign Web sites that distribute American-made entertainment and counterfeit products, like fake pharmaceuticals, are stealing our profits, theyre stealing our jobs and they may be endangering the health of Americans, said Mr. Smith, a Republican from San Antonio.

title: Somalia: Rebels Attack Kenya
description: Somali militants have attacked a Kenyan police post near the Kenya-Somalia border, killing at least six people and kidnapping several others, Kenyan officials said Thursday. The officials said that three police officers, a civil servant and a teacher were among the dead in the raid at Gerille on Wednesday, and that several government employees were missing. The Shabab militant group posted a message on Twitter saying its forces had seized Kenyan vehicles, communication equipment and a cache of weapons. Somali militants have staged several hit-and-run attacks inside Kenya since October, when Kenyan forces crossed into Somalia to fight the Shabab. The Shabab said Thursday that they were responding to aggressive Kenyan invasion against Muslims of Somalia.

title: Evangelicals Hope South Carolina or Florida Winnows Republican Field
description: Conservative Christian leaders have scaled back their goals for a meeting to be held in Texas on Friday and Saturday, acknowledging that they are unlikely to agree on a single alternative candidate to Mitt Romney until after the South Carolina primary on Jan. 21, if then.

title: Plans for Big Cuts in Military Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Stresses of Middle Age
description: To the Editor:

title: GTT
description: BEAUMONT

title: The State of Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Retired? Not Exactly
description: To the Editor:

title: Selig, Soon to Be Oldest Commissioner, Keeps Keys to Shop
description: The first baseball commissioner, Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, died in office in November 1944. He was 78 years and 5 days old. None of his eight successors has served at that age.

title: Obama Raised $42 Million in Last Quarter, Far More Than G.O.P. Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas campaign raised $42 million in the final three months of 2011, easily besting his Republican rivals and matching where President George W. Bush was at the same point in his re-election bid.

title: Citadel Pulls Off 20% Gain for 2011, Defying Industry
description: The gods of redemption are smiling on the hedge fund Citadel.

title: Parks Dept. Weighs New Rules on Permits to Free More Fields for Youth Sports
description: During football season, the young players of the Downtown Giants have three practices each week at three different parks: Chelsea Waterside Park, the Battery Park City Ball Fields and Hudson River Park at Pier 40. Games take place at East River Park on Saturdays.

title: Googles New Search Results Raise Privacy and Antitrust Concerns
description: Google set off a furor on Tuesday when it added posts, photos, conversations and profiles from its Google Plus social network to search results, a feature it calls Search Plus Your World.

title: U.S. Seeks Rollback of a Health Insurers Excessive Rate Increase
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Thursday that rate increases sought by a health insurance company were unreasonable, and it ordered the insurer to rescind them or justify its refusal to do so.

title: Patriots Take Away Much From First Meeting With Broncos
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The numbers are still mind-boggling.

title: Bringing Gang Members to God on a Rooftop
description: In the nearly two months since Corey Brooks, a little-known minister, began living, praying and preaching in a tent pitched on the roof of a vacant motel, politicians, hip-hop musicians and grieving mothers have traveled to the South Side for an audience with the rooftop pastor.

title: Vote Holds Fate of Nuclear Power in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  When voters here choose a president and a new legislature on Saturday, their decisions will also determine whether Taiwan pulls the plug on a state-backed nuclear power industry that provides the country with a fifth of its electricity.

title: Why Taiwans Future Matters
description: FOR most of its history, Taiwans destiny was determined by three great powers  China, Japan and America. Now, as the 18th-largest economy in the world and a thoroughly democratized nation, Taiwan is still perceived by some in Washington as a potential bargaining chip in crafting a new relationship with China. This is a mistake.

title: Kastor, After Pregnancy, Sees Trials as New Start
description: HOUSTON  Marathon training was out of the question. Still, Deena Kastor, the 2004 Olympic bronze medalist, figured she could run for 20 or 30 minutes a day during her pregnancy. She was wrong. Aching in her sides and her back grew so acute that even walking the dog around the block sometimes forced her to sit and rest.

title: Ringing Finally Ended, but Theres No Button to Stop Shame
description: They were baying for blood in the usually polite precincts of Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Sears Chairman Buys Shares, but His Reason Is Unclear
description: When big-name investors increase their personal stakes in stocks, the purchases can be a positive sign for the companies.

title: Toward a National Coastline Policy
description: The United States has thousands of miles of coastline, and more than half of its population lives in counties bordering oceans or the Great Lakes  areas administered by a hodgepodge of federal, state or other agencies, often with conflicting goals.For years, environmental groups and expert panels have called for federal oversight for these areas.

title: 4 Commissioners Skipped Taking Required Furloughs
description: Four Cook County commissioners failed to take off some or all of the required 10 unpaid days in the fiscal year that ended Nov. 30, according to a preliminary report by the county comptrollers office.

title: Vision for Affordable Energy Even if Indian Point Nuclear Plant Is Shut Down
description: If anyone, or any business, can get a good deal on electricity, it ought to be Consolidated Edison, which buys loads of it every year and then sells it to three million customers in New York City and the suburbs. Like most traditional utility companies, it has gotten out of the power generation business in recent years and is now a distribution company. It buys the electricity that it delivers from generators run by independent companies.

title: In New Ads, Stirring Memories of Commercials Past
description: AFTER decades of listening to a talking tuna, consumers are talking back.

title: For Priests Wives, a Word of Caution
description: Lafayette, La.

title: Turkish Official Says a Russian Ship, Perhaps With Munitions, Has Reached Syria
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish Foreign Ministry official said that a Russian ship thought to be carrying a cargo of munitions reached Syria on Thursday, in defiance of a European Union embargo, after stopping to refuel in Cyprus and receiving what the Turks said was inadequate scrutiny there.

title: A Murder at Paradise
description: PARKLAND, Wa.  The next time somebody mindlessly bashes a federal bureaucrat, as if the term itself were a parasitic disease, remember the bright young woman we said goodbye to here a few days ago: Margaret Anderson, a park ranger in a flag-draped casket.

title: The C.E.O. in Politics
description: There are two questions concerning Mitt Romneys service at the private equity firm Bain Capital. The narrower question is: Did Bain help ailing companies and add value to the economy or did it plunder dying firms? The larger question is: Does Romneys success in business tell us anything about whether he would be a successful president?

title: F.C.C. May Move to End N.F.L. Blackouts
description: The N.F.L.s television blackout policy dictates that for a home game to be shown in the teams market, it must be sold out 72 hours before kickoff. Teams in danger of a suffering such a fate frequently scramble to sell the necessary seats.

title: Colbert for President: A Run or a Comedy Riff?
description: If anyone can make a mockery of the newest campaign finance innovation, the super PAC, its Stephen Colbert.

title: America Isnt a Corporation
description: And greed  you mark my words  will not only save Teldar Paper, but that other malfunctioning corporation called the U.S.A.

title: Roy Ash, Powerful Budget Director for Nixon, Dies at 93
description: Roy L. Ash, who used tough-minded analytic acumen to build a multibillion-dollar conglomerate, Litton Industries, and to become a force in the Nixon White House, where he headed the creation of agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency, died on Dec. 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Before the Lights Go Out for Good
description: The playoff game on Saturday between the 49ers and the New Orleans Saints will be the most significant sporting event at Candlestick Park since 2003, when the Niners beat the New York Giants in a thrilling wild-card game.

title: Republicans Asked to Bash Obama, Not One Another
description: NEW ORLEANS  Republican National Committee leaders, meeting here on Thursday amid sharpening divisions in the race for the partys presidential nomination, implored fellow Republicans from around the country to unite around a message aimed at President Obama, not one another.

title: A Houseboat Tips Over, but All Onboard Escape
description: The two-story houseboat had been docked on a quiet creek in a hidden corner of the Bronx for a decade. It had withstood the strong winds of Tropical Storm Irene, and as far as its owner could tell, no serious repairs were needed.

title: Packers Fans Find a Home in Greenwich Village
description: New York, for all of its diversity, is also a city of defined communities, like the group of men who, for years, have gathered in the back of the Kettle of Fish in Greenwich Village. There, around a round oak table that is supposed to seat six but can be home to a few more, and not far from the gaze of a bobblehead Ray Nitschke doll, they watch their Green Bay Packers play  week after winter week, pleasant enough to other fans who share their allegiances yet protective of their small bit of turf deep inside the low-ceilinged bar.

title: Dangerous Tension With Iran
description: With tensions rising over Irans nuclear program,the Obama administration has now warned the countrys supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that Irans threat to close the Strait of Hormuz would provoke an American response. Earlier this week, international monitors confirmed that Iran has begun enriching uranium at a new underground plant. The United States and Europe are tightening sanctions to choke off Iranian oil revenues. On Wednesday, an Iranian nuclear scientist died in a bomb attack en route to work, and a government newspaper signaled that the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps might retaliate.

title: All the Worlds a Stage, Even a Motel, a Mint or a Bus
description: Tensions typically run high before a theater company performs a work for the first time, and working outside a traditional theater compounds the worries.

title: Bill Janklow, a Four-Term Governor of South Dakota, Dies at 72
description: Bill Janklow, a four-term governor of South Dakota with a colorful and brash persona whose political career ended abruptly when, as a congressman, he was convicted of manslaughter for killing a motorcyclist while speeding, died on Thursday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 72.

title: The Ministerial Exception
description: In the case of Cheryl Perich, a teacher fired by a church-run school, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the Constitutions protection of religious freedom bars her from suing the church under federal workplace discrimination law.

title: City Patches Stadiums Power, and Waits
description: Gambling that the lights will stay on at Candlestick Park during a nationally televised football playoff game this weekend, the City of San Francisco decided to punt on plans to replace two aging electrical switches that were blamed for blackouts during the 49ers final regular-season home game last month.

title: PACs Aid Allows Romneys Rivals to Extend Race
description: Under the old political rules, Mitt Romney arrived in South Carolina this week the prohibitive Republican front-runner: flush with cash, awash in endorsements from a party establishment starting to coalesce behind him and buoyed by victories in Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: Public Concern Over San Francisco Sheriffs Private Matter
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Bloomberg Suffers, Too, in Collapse of MF Global
description: The collapse of MF Global has wreaked havoc on farmers, ranchers and other investors who were clients of the brokerage firm, prompting a loud outcry over the disappearance of $1.2 billion in customer cash.

title: Back to the Robber Barons
description: With federal campaigns already knee-deep in a new era of laissez-faire money, the Republican National Committee has brazenly proposed the ultimate step  that the 105-year-old ban on direct corporation contributions to candidates and parties be scrapped as unconstitutional.

title: Bloomberg Backs Effort to Raise Minimum Wage
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, saying that wages for the poorest New Yorkers had not kept up with rising consumer costs, endorsed a proposal on Thursday by the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, to increase the states minimum wage above the federal level of $7.25 an hour.

title: Report Blames Safety Lapses for an Epidemic of Deaths at Wyoming Job Sites
description: DENVER  C. J. Moss was on the final day of his weeklong shift working in Wyomings oil fields when he died. A burnt cable electrocuted Mr. Moss, 26, while he was cleaning part of a motor for a drilling rig, killing him instantly.

title: No Rest (but Four Wins) for the Weary Bulls
description: CHICAGO  One of the brutal stretches that have become a signature of the condensed N.B.A. schedule ended Wednesday night at the United Center. An undermanned, gassed Chicago Bulls team took the floor for its third game in three nights and fifth in six, a grind that rendered legs rubbery and challenged everyones concentration.

title: Friday: Put the Finger On
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Allow me to tell you what I really thought about this puzzle: I loved it. No reservations.

title: A New Storms Brewing Down on Catfish Row
description: The hurricane thats said to be headed for Catfish Row has yet to arrive early in the second act of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess, which opened on Thursday night in a new, slimmed-down reincarnation at the Richard Rodgers Theater. The climate so far might be described as mostly cloudy and mild, as might this version of the show. But suddenly an elemental force takes possession of the stage, and its tremors course through the audience.

title: Swingman Sparks Seton Halls Unlikely Rise
description: NEWARK  At the beginning of the week, the Seton Hall mens basketball team found itself ranked in The Associated Press top 25 for the first time since 2001.

title: During Address, Murdoch Goes After Cuomo on Twitter
description: In his first year in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo became accustomed to the grumblings of a peevish and powerful Manhattan billionaire media mogul.

title: TimesTalks: Kristen Wiig & Paul Feig
description: The actress and screenwriter Kristen Wiig and the director Paul Feig discuss their film Bridesmaids.

title: Panel Chief Raises $450,000 as She Eyes Manhattan Post
description: In a robust showing from a political novice, the chairwoman of Lower Manhattans community board has raised more than $450,000 toward a likely bid for borough president in 2013.

title: Behind an Army of Lobbyists, an Instant Force in Gambling
description: In the summer of 2009, a Malaysian billionaire took an unexpected interest in a small town in the Catskill Mountains in New York. With little notice, he bought a stake in a racetrack casino where the owners had struggled for more than a decade to develop a gambling complex.

title: Can You Hear Him Now?
description: A symphony must be like the world, advised Gustav Mahler, who composed nine symphonies across a brilliant career. It must contain everything.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Sends Top Iranian Leader a Warning on Strait Threat
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is relying on a secret channel of communication to warn Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that closing the Strait of Hormuz is a red line that would provoke an American response, according to United States government officials.

title: Vow to Fight Police Misconduct Faces Skepticism
description: After a year that saw a steady drumbeat of police corruption cases and increased scrutiny of several New York Police Department practices, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pledged on Thursday to add four lawyers to the two-person legal staff at the agency responsible for monitoring the departments Internal Affairs Bureau.

title: The Narrow and Vulnerable Strait of Hormuz
description: The shipping lanes through the Strait of Hormuz are only six miles wide and are vulnerable to attack by Iranian missiles.

title: Fire Survivor and a Possible Olympian: A Horse Named Neville
description: AIKEN, S.C.  The horses straw beds were ablaze, with the rest of the barn, when two men rushed in against the flames and black smoke to try to save the 11 horses inside.

title: Grievances and Theatrics in a Lacrosse Lawsuit
description: There was the assistant lacrosse coach pressuring one of the girls head coaches to play his daughter and her friends more often. When the coach refused, the girls desiring more time would stop passing the ball to some of their teammates. They would besmirch them, repeating spiteful cracks other girls were supposedly making about them.

title: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Hunt for E-Mails
description: A federal judge in Manhattan directed the government on Thursday to conduct a deeper search for e-mails that an F.B.I. agent involved in a terrorism investigation in Nigeria said she had deleted from her computer because of a lack of storage space.

title: Shutout by Senators Ends Rangers 5-Game Streak
description: Each man in the Rangers locker room was disconsolate after their 3-0 loss to Ottawa Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. The players acted as if they were in the midst of a lengthy losing streak instead of having just lost for the second time in twelve games.

title: Woman Struck by a School Bus in Queens
description: A woman was in critical condition on Thursday after being struck by a small school bus in Jamaica, Queens. Five others, including two children on the bus, were injured in the crash, officials said.

title: Japan: Prime Minister Shuffles Cabinet
description: The Japanese cabinet resigned en masse on Friday, in a routine step that allows Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda to announce a new lineup later in the day. Such reshufflings are common in Japan when a leader wants to push a new policy initiative, and Mr. Noda apparently hopes to convince the opposition to join his push to raise the national sales tax. Mr. Noda, a fiscal conservative, has pledged to submit a bill to the next session of Parliament to raise the national sales tax, currently 5 percent, in an effort to rein in Japans ballooning national debt, one of the largest among developed nations. It is unclear how many of his 17 ministers he will actually replace, but local news reports said he was expected to leave about a dozen in place.

title: Uneasy Neighbors in a Southern Gothic Tale
description: LAURENS, S.C.  The Redneck Shop has been selling Confederate bikinis and white satin robes on the historic courthouse square in this former mill town for so long that most people have learned to ignore it.

title: Germany: U.S. Will Withdraw Combat Brigade
description: The United States will withdraw another Army combat brigade from Germany, leaving just two brigades in Europe as the military shifts to a new strategy that focuses on the Asia-Pacific region while sustaining a strong presence in the Middle East, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Thursday. He said the United States was not abandoning Europe, and would sustain sufficient forces there to maintain ties with allies. He described the changes in an interview on Thursday with American Forces Press Service, the Pentagons media branch. In 2004, the Bush administration ordered that the number of Army combat brigades in Europe be cut to two from four. Last year, the Obama administration decided to retain a third brigade in Europe, but now has decided to leave only one brigade in Germany and one in Italy. A brigade has about 4,000 soldiers.

title: A Horses Journey From Fire
description: Neville Bardos, a 12-year-old horse who competes in eventing, has managed a comeback from severe injuries sustained in a fire.

title: An Unlikely Comeback
description: After surviving a barn fire, Neville Bardos is now a top contender for the Olympics and a finalist for this years international Horse of the Year award.

title: A Pass That Changed Two Teams Paths
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: A Womans Struggles Unleash Memories of Trauma
description: For almost 30 years, Brendaly Moczo had a strategy for dealing with lifes darkest moments and the memories and emotions they evoked.

title: Skier Is Still in Critical Condition
description: The Canadian freestyle skier Sarah Burke remained in critical condition at the University of Utah Hospital in Salt Lake City, two days after sustaining a serious head injury in the 22-foot halfpipe in Park City, Utah, the hospital said. Burke, a 2014 Olympic favorite, hit her head while attempting to land a trick during training. She had surgery Wednesday to repair a tear to her vertebral artery. With injuries of this type, we need to observe the course of her brain function before making definitive pronouncements about Sarahs prognosis for recovery, said Dr. William T. Couldwell, who performed the operation.

title: With Robots, a New Way to Understand Strokes
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Anthony Sprains Ankle as the Knicks Struggle
description: MEMPHIS  The game was drifting away from the Knicks, lost in a haze of errant passes, ill-conceived jump shots and a general offensive malaise long before they watched their scoring leader stumble away in agony. Any hope they had for a revival Thursday night disappeared when Carmelo Anthony did.

title: Corrections: January 13
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Intraparty Attacks Could Be November Liability for Romney

title: Year of the Immigrant
description: Although everyone is talking about the presidential election this year, I am much more excited about the role of immigrants in the politics of 2012. Its not a year like 2009 when we waited anxiously for a new president and Congress to create a sensible solution for immigration reform. Those hopes are long gone. They have been replaced by new fears aroused by draconian laws that emerged from Alabama, Arizona and Georgia.

title: Longer School Day Brings Promise and Questions
description: Twenty hands shot into the air after Ashley Tam asked a question of her third graders during a math lesson on Tuesday morning. One boy threw his arm up with such force that his desk jumped off the ground with him.

title: Michigan: Bridge Owner Is Jailed
description: Manuel J. Moroun, the billionaire owner of the Ambassador Bridge connecting Detroit to Canada, was jailed Thursday for his companys failure to complete a project with the State Department of Transportation. A circuit judge found the company, the Detroit International Bridge Company, had avoided fulfilling its contract to help build ramps connecting two freeways to the bridge. The state partnered with the company in 2004 to build the ramps, spending $230 million on the project.

title: Louisiana: Gunman, 3 Others Killed
description: Police officers killed a gunman in a shootout on Thursday after a car chase and the discovery of shooting victims in a New Orleans home. The police said the chase ensued when a car fled a home in the eastern part of the city where five people had been shot, three fatally. After the car crashed, a man emerged, firing at the police. He was killed and two people with him were wounded, the police said.

title: How Super is the M.L.S. SuperDraft?

title: California: Burrito Used in Smuggling
description: A Los Angeles County sheriffs deputy has been charged with taking a heroin-laden burrito into jail. An indictment unsealed Wednesday said Deputy Henry Marin, 27, received the burrito from an unidentified conspirator while he was stationed in 2010 at a county courthouse, with the intention of helping transport the drugs into a jail. He pleaded not guilty.

title: Whos Afraid of FDI in Retail: An India Ink & Caravan Magazine Discussion
description: At the start of this month, India Ink collaborated with Caravan magazine to co-host a panel in Mumbai about foreign investment in Indias retail industry. The panel, made up of journalists, an economist and a banker, discussed the controversy surrounding the Indian governments proposal to allow companies like Walmart to set up stores here. Above is a video of the panel discussion.

title: U.S. Restores Full Ties to Myanmar After Rapid Reforms
description: WASHINGTON  The United States moved to restore full diplomatic relations with Myanmar on Friday, rewarding the sweeping political and economic changes that the countrys new civilian government has made, including a cease-fire with ethnic rebels and, only hours before, the release of hundreds of political prisoners.

One of the dozens of stray cats that call the hospital home reportedly walked into a neonatal ward, mounted a bed where a six-day-old girl was receiving phototherapy treatment for jaundice and tried to take her as prey. According to the Daily Star, the cat had pulled the newborn off her bed and onto the floor, and dragged her partway to the wards open door before anyone noticed.

Mr. Colberts lawyer explained: You cannot be a candidate and run a super PAC. That would be coordinating with yourself. Having a good friend run it, however, would be a different story, he said.

His answers will conclude Saturday. (Questions may have been edited).

title: Untruths, Wholly Untrue, And Nothing But Untruths
description: I was deeply radicalized by the 2000 election. At first I couldnt believe that then-candidate George W. Bush was saying so many clearly, provably false things; then I couldnt believe that nobody in the news media was willing to point out the lies. (At the time, the Times actually told me that I couldnt use the l-word either). That was when I formulated my views differ on shape of planet motto.

title: The Get | Tooshie + A.P.C. Bathing Suit
description: Tooshie, the Paris-based swimwear line devoted to making bums look beautiful, has now partnered with A.P.C., the Francophile favorite, to create an 11-piece capsule collection. Included in the offering are powder blue trunks for men and this psychedelic one-piece for women. I like the idea of an eccentric print on a very simple bathing suit, says A.P.C.s designer Jean Touitou. Often you see prints like this on terrible shiny materials. The idea was to find a nice matte one. As for the fit, Tooshies designer Natascha Sayn Wittgenstein took care of that: Its not about focusing on shapes  cover this, reveal that  but keeping it elegant with these small pieces of fabric, she says. Jump in!A.P.C + Tooshie swimsuit, $280. Go to apc.fr.

title: Kristen Wiig on the Sad Truth About Bridesmaids
description: Its deadline day for Oscar nomination ballots and the Bagger hopes there are still a few stray undecideds out there who might be swayed to vote in the Bridesmaids direction. The film picked up best comedy at the Critics Choice Awards on Thursday night and its producer, Judd Apatow, had an unprintable message for people who think that women cant be funny.

title: At Yokos Show, Funeral Pyres and Tributes to Mommy
description: Yoko Onos first exhibition in India, called Our Beautiful Daughters, at the Vadehra Art Gallery in New Delhi, could also be called Art Under Construction. All seven exhibits in the show, which opened Thursday night, ask the spectators to participate in them.

title: Living His Passion for Hip-Hop
description: A paint-flecked floor is Nelson Sedas stage. When the weather is too cold or wet, he clears the chairs from his bedroom, turns up the music and dances, his arms and legs a blur of impossibly graceful angles. An hour later, he may pick up his markers and draw  on canvases, old posters, shoeboxes, anything. And for good measure, he might end the day freestyle rapping.

title: Leading Off: Tebows Moment of Truth
description: One week into the N.F.L. playoffs, the most entertaining story of the season travels to the place where fun goes to die: the Tim Tebow phenomenon rolls into New England on Saturday. Its the hero versus the hoodie, an N.F.L. morality tale in four quarters. You thought last weeks Broncos victory over the Steelers was big? That was just a warm-up. It is possible, if the N.F.L. maneuvers the levers it has implanted in everyones heads just right, the entire universe will be watching the Broncos-Patriots game.

title: What Rhymes With Undead? Some Poets Know
description: Times may be tough, but if you happen to be a zombie, the future looks bright. Never have the undead seemed more alive.

description: It appears that Ronald W. Burkle isnt content to simply buy a membership for the Soho House line of luxury clubs. Instead, hes buying control of the company.

title: What Were Reading
description: Americas Test Kitchen: A good explanation of why we heat up the oil in a pan before cooking.  Julia Moskin

title: The Chinese-Takeout Container Is Uniquely American
description: The Chinese-takeout container, with its Japanese-influenced origami folds, is a uniquely American invention. On Nov. 13, 1894, in Chicago, the inventor Frederick Weeks Wilcox patented a version of what he called a paper pail, which was a single piece of paper, creased into segments and folded into a (more or less) leakproof container secured with a dainty wire handle on top. The supportive folds on the outside, fastened with that same wire, created a flat interior surface over which food could slide smoothly onto a plate.

title: Lets Start Paying College Athletes
description: I certainly agree with Joe Nocera that basketball and football players are treated like chattel in the present system. Denying players a basic stipend when coaches are making ridiculous amounts is the height of inequity. But paying football and mens basketball players isnt feasible, given Title IX regulations and politics. If you disconnect moneymaking sports, womens sports will very likely lose financing. Paying basketball and football players will not address the core problem of an unsustainable arms race in college sports. The proposition that the N.C.A.A. is in charge and can control college sports is a canard. If the N.C.A.A. pushes too hard, top conferences could create their own basketball playoff and challenge the N.C.A.A. tournament, which is currently a huge windfall for the N.C.A.A. Then the decentralization of power that began with the Supreme Court decision will only get worse. Your proposal offers an important contribution to the debate by arguing for stipends to players, the right to counsel and a defined scholarship term and the opportunity for lifetime health insurance. But getting there isnt going to be easy.

title: Why Write Novels at All?
description: Last year, I found myself mildly obsessed with a cache of YouTube clips, featuring the novelists Jeffrey Eugenides, Jonathan Franzen, Zadie Smith, David Foster Wallace and Nathan Englander at a 2006 literary conference in Italy called Le Conversazioni. Part of what interested me, in a gate-crashing kind of way, was the backdrop: midsummer on the Isle of Capri, with flora aflame and a sky the color of Chablis. Another part, inevitably, was watching Wallace with the knowledge that he would kill himself two years later. Mostly what I kept coming back to, though, was how lighthearted, how loose  how young  these writers seemed here. Its not that they werent already an accomplished quintet, with a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award to their credit. But in 2006 the gravitational center of Anglo-American letters still lay back on U.S. soil with Don DeLillo and Cormac McCarthy and John Updike and Toni Morrison and Philip Roth  those towering figures who, according to a Times survey released earlier that year, produced the greatest American fiction of the previous quarter-century. By comparison, Le Conversazioni might as well have been The Breakfast Club and Capri a weirdly paradisiacal high-school library.

title: Grills
description: A sampling of National Football League face masks

title: Wael Ghonim Has No Regrets
description: As a Dubai-based Google executive, you created a Facebook page that helped foment the Egyptian uprising. Your memoir, Revolution 2.0, recounts how you spent 11 days imprisoned during some of the most dramatic Tahrir Square protests. Major letdown, I imagine. Its not a matter of enjoying the process as much as looking forward to the result, which is actually why most of the people went down to the streets. When I was released on Feb. 7, I saw Egyptians had managed to stand up together. I felt like I had been jailed for 11 years, but I did not feel I really missed the whole thing.

title: The Fat Trap
description: Finally, some medical research on weight gain and the difficulty in losing it and keeping it off that does not blame, shame and condemn the person. Get this article to Oprah, Dr. Oz and those bullies on TVs Biggest Loser.

title: Must I Tell My Fianc?
description: As a very broke and self-supporting 20-year-old college senior, I donated my eggs in exchange for money. It was a horrendous experience, and I rarely speak about it. Although I assume that some children resulted, I regret my participation and do not wish to know the results. I am now 35, engaged and planning to start a family. Must I tell my fianc that there may be teenagers walking around with my genetic material? NAME WITHHELD

title: E.R.: Port-au-Prince
description: It was 2 a.m. when the Haitian National Police brought the rape victim to the emergency room. I was the physician covering nights. The E.R. had only two gurneys, and one was occupied by a gray-haired man receiving IV fluids, asleep despite the overhead fluorescents. I hadnt slept well in days.

title: Selling a 300-Year-Old Cello
description: On a cold day last winter, an ailing Bernard Greenhouse, wearing an elegant bathrobe and attached to oxygen, was wheeled into the living room of his Cape Cod home, which was festooned with paper cutouts of musical notes. Relatives and students, locals and caregivers had gathered to celebrate the 95th birthday of one of classical musics most respected cellists, a founding member of the famed Beaux Arts Trio and a beloved teacher. Young cellists performed for him, and then Greenhouse indulged in a martini and a plate of oysters. Thus fortified, he decided he wanted to play for the company. He picked up his cello and, though a bit wobbly, soulfully rendered Song of the Birds, a Catalan folk melody transcribed by Pablo Casals, with whom he studied many years ago.

title: On Our Radar: Reducing Soot and Methane
description: Reiterating that carbon dioxide need not be the only focus, an international team of scientists suggests 14 ways of controlling emissions of methane and soot, from cleaning up cookstoves to changing cultivation methods for rice paddies. If adopted more widely, the scientists calculate, these methods would reduce projected global warming by 0.9 degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2050. [Associated Press].

Spend the night in a sketchy Burmese border town? Sure! Eat my way through Bridgeport, Conn.? Loved it. Once, I even spent four consecutive Sunday nights in Geneva  in midwinter  an ordeal to which no rational adventurer would willingly submit.

Call (212) 645-5659 or go online to make reservations.

Soto: Paris and Beyond, 1950-1970 at New York Universitys Grey Art Gallery will not precipitate a run to revive his reputation, but it does open an interesting window on the mid-20th-century philosophical landscape of modern art.

Specializing In Spreading His Wings

Quick: shoot over to Meryl Streep, then zigzag to Michelle Williams! Ninety seconds left  can you make it over to Patton Oswalt? (The Bagger did. Were all back here getting wasted, he reported of his castmates at the Young Adult table, though they seemed pretty well-behaved to us.)

And when her husbands parents visit, suddenly, the topic of choosing a church home comes off the to-do list and into the midst of the conversation.

title: For Dr. King, Freedom and Education Were Intertwined
Writing About Radicals, Then and Now
description: Tom Robbins has a terrific story in the magazine on Sunday about the making  and unmaking  of the 60s radical Judith Clark. Clark drove one of the getaway cars during the Brinks holdup in 1981 when two police officers and an armored-car guard were killed. Furious at a system that she thought was unjust, Clark refused to be represented in court, trumpeted revolutionary action and ended up with a 75-year sentence that she is still serving. Over many visits and phone conversations, Robbins explored Clarks life behind bars and her slow transformation from unrepentant young radical to a reflective, deeply regretful model inmate. Clark talks a great deal about the importance of her relationship with her daughter  who was 11 months old at the time of the crime  in changing her. And the role her parents played in nurturing that relationship.

title: Brooklyn Awaits Nets, but Their Destination as a Team Is Unclear
description: NEWARK  The question of where the Nets are headed as an organization and as a basketball team leads only to a host of potential destinations that range from exhilaration to dread, with an occasional detour into comic relief. Technically, and temporarily, the Nets are in Newark, on their way to a new home next season in Brooklyn. By all other practical means of appraisal, their dateline should be limbo.

title: My Berlin Airlift
description: Smuggling Afghan heroin or women from Odessa would have been more reprehensible, but more logical. You know youre a fool when what youre doing makes even the post office seem efficient. Everything I was packing into this unwieldy, 1980s-vintage suitcase was available online. I dont mean that when I arrived in Berlin I could have ordered more Levis 510s for next-day delivery. I mean, I was packing books.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE VIEW FROM LAZY POINT: A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,  by Carl Safina. Illustrations by Trudy Nicholson. Maps by Jon Luoma (Picador/John Macrae, $18.) Safina, a marine ecologist, reflects on natures connectedness in a series of field reports from his home on the shore of eastern Long Island and his travels to the Arctic, the Antarctic, the Caribbean and the Pacific Islands.

title: Editors Choice
description: PITY THE BILLIONAIRE: The Hard-Times Swindle and the Unlikely Comeback of the Right,  by Thomas Frank (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) Frank entertainingly mocks powerful conservatives claims that they are victims of an all-powerful liberal establishment.

title: Everything Is an Afterthought
description: To the Editor:

title: A Good Book
description: To the Editor:

title: He Just Doesnt Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Deal | On Fifth Avenue, 1+1+1 = $25 Million?
description: When 907 Fifth Avenue was built in 1915, it was one of the first grand limestone apartment houses to open along Central Park, and it filled quickly with names that routinely graced the society pages.

title: The Legend of Camelot
description: To the Editor:

title: Carpentiers Kingdom
description: To the Editor:

title: William Gibsons Future Is Now
description: On one of his trips to New York, William Gibson stopped before an antiques shop that would end up haunting him. He tried the door. It was locked. Over the years, he searched for the shop window many times  it seemed to wander around SoHo and materialize on unpredictable streets. Whenever he peered through it at the treasures within, he felt as if he were glimpsing the props from a dream. There is no knowing what might appear there, Gibson writes in one of the essays collected in Distrust That Particular Flavor. Once, he spied a collection of toy-size missiles.

title: Strangers on a Plane
description: As much as teenagers and adults alike try to strategize over the search for love, in the end whether two people connect is a kind of elusive, slippery magic, up to the gods or to some unseen force, and it always comes down to one thing: timing.

title: Vain Glorious | Jo Malone London Gets a Style Editor
description: Charlotte Stockdales career is an inspired one. The British-born beauty is a multitalented success, having done everything from serving as a muse to her good friend Karl Lagerfeld to styling the Victorias Secret runway show and holding down the fashion director post at i-D. Today, Stockdale adds the title of style editor of Jo Malone London to her ever-evolving C.V.

title: Renovate Renovate Baby. Need Help?
description: LAKE WORTH, Fla.

title: You Must Go Home Again
description: Orphaning a protagonist adds a note of plangent depth to a childs tale, provides a motive for search or for revenge, and hustles meddling authority figures out of the way. Ann Hood, the author of novels for adults like The Knitting Circle and The Red Thread, updates this grisly fairy-tale motif by divorcing the parents of Maisie and Felix Robbins, the 12-year-old twins at the center of her new chapter book for children. In Angel of the Battlefield, the mother is not deceased but simply distracted, settling herself and the children in a new home and proving herself in a new job. Their father has not been killed in battle nor lost to the exploration of faraway lands. Hes a curator who has taken a position at a museum in Qatar.

title: Recess Appointments and Partisan Politics
description: Theres a lovely literary term for dramas in which there is a lot of excessive emotion and the main characters are driven to all kinds of irrational acts by motives such as revenge and greed. Its called sturm und drang and we saw a lot of it last week when President Obama made some recess appointments even though the Senate was holding pro-forma sessions (some of them lasting about 30 seconds).

title: Victories for American Women and Men
description: MELBOURNE, AustraliaSecond-round qualifying action from Melbourne Park saw more Americans find success in the continually brisk and breezy conditions.

title: Talks on Greek Debt Are Halted
description: LONDON  Talks between Greece and private sector creditors over a restructuring of the countrys crushing debt paused on Friday amid a continuing disagreement over how much of a loss banks and investors should take on their holdings.

title: The Jets, the Colts and Victor Cruz: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Yearning for a Nokia Windows Phone 7
description: The new Nokia Lumia 900sure is pretty.

title: With Subway Shutdown, Major Repairs and Irked Passengers
description: It was a bold experiment. For the first time in the century-long history of New York Citys 24-hour subway system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was going to shut down large sections of an entire train line from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. for four nights in a row to let workers scrub down and spruce up the tracks.

title: Digital Notes: Grooveshark Finds a Workaround
description: Daily updates on the business of digital music:

title: Deciding Whos Rich (or Smart) Enough for High-Risk Investments
description: OVER the holiday, the Securities and Exchange Commission revised one of the wealth requirements for people seeking to invest in private offerings that hold the allure of big returns. It was a small change, mandated by the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul law.

title: The Relaunch of Amanda Hocking
description: At the time of its first official paperback release, Switched, by Amanda Hocking, the much-celebrated darling of self-publishing, will already have sold more than a million copies.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Promises for Education: An Annotated  Scorecard
Zip! Looking Closely at a Strip Club
description: PARIS

title: Downgrade of Debt Ratings Underscores Europes Woes
description: PARIS  Standard & Poors downgraded the credit ratings of France, Italy and seven other European countries on Friday, a move that may have more symbolic than fundamental financial impact but served as a reminder that Europes economic woes were far from over.

title: The Tenacity of Hope
description: I am not a mathematician, but I know this, says Hazel Grace Lancaster, the narrator of The Fault in Our Stars, the latest novel by John Green, a Michael L. Printz medalist and author of several best-selling novels for young adults. There are infinite numbers between zero and one. Theres .1 and .12 and .112 and an infinite collection of others. The trouble, she says, is, I want more numbers than Im likely to get.

title: In the Shadows of Oklahoma City
description: Eileen Pollacks new novel, Breaking and Entering, takes place in rural Michigan in 1995  the epicenter and high point of the militia movement, before increased scrutiny and revulsion at the Oklahoma City bombing put some militia groups out of business and sent others underground. (Though not a militiaman, the bomber Timothy McVeigh attended their meetings and spent time on a Michigan farm with his fellow conspirator Terry Nichols.) The Oklahoma City attack comes about a third of the way through Pollacks book, a real-world event that informs and shadows the fictional ones.

title: India Grapples With Web Censorship
description: India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban The Satanic Verses by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivajis modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

title: Gil Scott-Heron: The Godfather of Rap
description: Gil Scott-Heron grew up surrounded by heroism. He distrusted empty promises and easy solutions. He also had a very hard time with himself. Whether you expect a memoir to explain how the third sentence relates to the first two will determine how you feel about this posthumous book.

title: What It Means to Be Middle Aged
description: An upbeat look at middle age? Patricia Cohen had her work cut out for her. Maybe theres a capitalist culture somewhere that doesnt make a blazing fetish of youthfulness and keep it stoked with huge amounts of commercial and medical hot air. If so, its not the one we live in. Yet nothing in the sometimes pathetic struggle of Americans over, say, 50 to claim a respectable place in the public consciousness puts Cohen in the grumpy mood she could so rightly claim after absorbing some 200 years of the history of middle age. Instead, shes delivered a lively, well-researched chronicle of the social and scientific forces that brought midlife America to its current befuddled state  better off by most measures than any previous generation, but miserably out of fashion.

title: Among the Adolescents
description: Gather around, ladies, Caitlin Flanagan is back. And this time shes after your daughters.

title: Adele Hints at a Grammy Performance
description: Adele is widely predicted to sweep the Grammy Awards next month. But the question on every tongue in the music industry is whether she will also perform.

title: Holding Fast to Old-Fashioned Ways
description: EVERY year about this time in Essex Fells, after the first wintry gusts have swept the leaves off the trees and residents have gathered around to watch the annual lighting of the boroughs Christmas tree, a large pond off Fells Road turns into the boroughs meeting place.

title: Perfectly Happy, Even Without Happy Endings
description: LOS ANGELES

title: What Friedrich Nietzsche Did to America
description: In 1889, when Friedrich Nietzsche suffered the mental collapse that ended his career, he was virtually unknown. Yet by the time of his death in 1900 at the age of 55, he had become the philosophical celebrity of his age. From Russia to America, admirers echoed his estimation of himself as a titanic figure who could alter the course of history: I am by far the most terrible human being that has existed so far; this does not preclude the possibility that I shall be the most beneficial. His origins were humble for the role. The son of a small-town Lutheran minister, he steeped himself in classical literature while growing up in eastern Germany. When he was 24, he secured a professorship in Basel, Switzerland, and a few years later published his first book, The Birth of Tragedy. Against the common view of the ancient Greeks as the epitome of serene equipoise, Nietzsche emphasized the Dionysian excess and frenzy that complemented the Apollonian virtues of clarity and repose. The books success was limited, and its author was mocked by one leading classicist as an atavist run amok who should gather tigers and panthers about his knees, but not the youth of Germany.

title: Michel Houellebecqs Version of the American Thriller
description: Michel Houellebecqs new novel is a weird air plant of a book: it feeds off atmosphere, rather than soil. The climate of The Map and the Territory is very still and very strange, as if something bad had just been detonated over it. The same bad thing may also have convulsed France, where the story is set, because Houellebecqs Paris exists in a state of flagrant social breakdown and the countryside has become an emptied theme park of itself. This was exactly what the world would look like, a character thinks on entering a picturesque French village that only second-home-owners can afford to buy into, after the explosion of an intergalactic neutron bomb.

title: Haunted by the Holocaust
description: Shalom Auslander is my kind of Jew  an unapologetically paranoid, guilt-ridden, self-loathing Diaspora kvetch, enraged by a God he cant live with or without. While others of his generation may mine the tradition for a fond retrieval of forgotten lore, Auslander throws stones at the fiddler on the roof. Hes a black comic whos alloyed the manic existential shtick of Lenny Bruce with the gallows humor thats been a staple of the repertoire since the Babylonian Exile. In his two previous books, Beware of God, a collection of wickedly funny if not just plain wicked stories, and Foreskins Lament, a memoir that torched the bridges to his strict Orthodox heritage, hes been relentlessly indicting the Hebrew God as a poor role model. In the process hes made himself both celebrated and notorious: he is patently not good for the Jews.

title: Current TV Finds a Good Number Within Its Tiny Ratings
description: Current TVs audience is small  very small. The channels executives freely admit that in conversations, and will probably say so again on Friday when they hold a news conference with TV reporters gathered in Los Angeles.

title: Kim Jong-ils Romantic Rival
description: The title of Adam Johnsons second novel is a bit misleading. Raised in the Long Tomorrows orphanage in Chongjin, North Korea, his protagonist believes himself to be the son of the Orphan Master rather than some kid dropped off by his desperate parents. But the primary evidence for this belief  the unrelenting way the Orphan Master singled him out for punishment  invites other interpretations. Like the rest of the boys, he is given a name from the list of the 114 Grand Martyrs of the Revolution that will mark him as an orphan for the rest of his life. Pak Jun Do (the given name Jun Do is a homonym of John Doe) is appropriate for a character with such a shifting identity, someone who will become both the perpetrator and the victim of countless crimes.

title: In the Crossfire of the Mexican War on Drugs
description: MEXICO CITY

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A three-bedroom Cape in Norwalk, Conn., and a five-bedroom turreted contemporary in Brookville, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Lenox Hill two-bedroom, a Flatbush Avenue co-op and a Tudor City one-bedroom.

title: Bookshelf: Presidents
