description: GEORGE WASHINGTONS BIRTHDAY  A Mostly True Tale.  By Margaret McNamara. Illustrated by Barry Blitt.  40 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

title: Seeking Wisdom From Jos Saramago
description: So much attention has been paid to Pina, Wim Wenderss 3D homage to the choreographer Pina Bausch, that its easy to overlook another documentary that is also competing for the Academy Award for foreign-language film. Jos and Pilar, directed by Miguel Gonalves Mendes, is Portugals submission, and it too comes with an impressive pedigree. Co-produced by the directors Pedro Almodvar and Fernando Meirelles (City of God), it examines the relationship of love and support that sustains Jos Saramago, the Portuguese novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1998, and his wife, Pilar del Rio, as Saramago battled to write one last novel before his death in 2010 at the age of 87. Mr. Gonalves Mendes, 33, is in the United States this month for festival showings of the film and spoke by telephone from Palm Springs. Here is an edited version of what he had to say:

title: Image of the Day: January 13
Inside the List
description: THUNDERING TYPHOONS: Growing up, my brothers and I passed many happy days working our way through the Tintin comic books, sprawled on our floors with no concern for the stories literary or cultural status. We werent hipsters; we were kids. But we were also, apparently, in some kind of vanguard. Now that the Belgian Tintin is having a genuine American moment  a Spielberg movie; a newly translated biography of his creator, Herg (reviewed next week); a place atop The New York Timess graphic books best-seller list  were hearing that nobody but the elect was in on the secret back then. Though beloved in most parts of the world, Charles McGrath wrote in The Times recently, Tintin is practically unknown in the United States. Huh. Its a little weird, finding out you were every bit as out of touch as you feared. While I wouldnt go as far as the British critic Nicholas Lezard, who compared Spielbergs film adaptation to a rape, it is disconcerting to see the icons of your youth being pawed at by the mainstream. Next thing you know, theyll make a movie of the Smurfs.

title: Mantle of Dreams Yields a Nightmare
description: GOGOLS short story The Overcoat is both compact and richly metaphorical: a humble government clerk becomes a new man when he spends his life savings on a fine coat, but is destroyed when it is stolen. Its a perfect combination for the movies, and the tale has been filmed many times, most notably by the Soviet experimental filmmakers Grigori Kozintsev and Leonid Trauberg in 1926, and by the Italian director Alberto Lattuada in 1952.

title: The State of the City, in Your Words
description: Crumbling curb cuts in Rego Park. Yellow rivers in the East 70s. A neighborhood-sustaining tamale vendor at a South Bronx subway stop. Seeking a more granular supplement to the mayors sweeping State of the City address, we asked you for the State of your Block.

title: Russian Tanker Within Miles of Alaska Town
description: Guided by a Coast Guard icebreaker, a Russian tanker carrying emergency fuel to the stranded Alaska town of Nome neared the coast on Friday, The Alaska Dispatch reported.

title: Video of Skirmishes at Apple Store in Beijing
description: Updated | 7:00 p.m. As our colleague Sharon LaFraniere reports, crowds of would-be shoppers threw eggs and brawled in front of Apples flagship store in a tony neighborhood of Beijing on Friday after the store did not open as planned. The company later said in a statement that it had decided to suspend sale of its new iPhone 4S at five of its mainland stores for the safety of customers and employees.

title: Jason Kidd on the Disappearing Triple-Double
description: On Jan. 1, Rajon Rondo of the Celtics had 18 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists in a win over the Wizards. Of the 158 games this season, that is the only triple-double recorded so far.

title: Gingrich Asks Super PAC to Address Errors in Ad Against Romney
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Newt Gingrich called on the super PAC supporting him to edit or take down a 28-minute pseudodocumentary attacking Mitt Romneys record at the investment firm Bain Capital after news media fact checkers found a number of inaccuracies.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers and the Return of The Unwritten
description: The manga list is in flux this week, with seven newcomers. They include regulars on the list, like the latest volume of Naruto, about the ninja in training, which lands at No. 1. The other series involve battles (Yu-Gi-Oh GX, at No. 2), pirates and treasures (One Piece, at No. 3), werewolves and vampires (Rosario+Vampire, Season II, at No. 4), a demon bridge (Black Bird, at No. 5), romance (Skip Beat!, at No. 6) and mourning (Dengeki Daisy, at No. 10).

title: India Wins the Battle Against Polio
description: Today marks the first full year in Indias history when no new polio cases have been recorded, a milestone that just a few years ago seemed India might not reach.

title: TimesCast | January 13, 2012
description: President Obama asks Congress for power to shrink government | Explaining "super PACs" | Previewing the Golden Globe Awards.

title: Romney Moves to Blunt Santorum Surge in South Carolina
description: WASHINGTON  Can Rick Santorum surge again, this time in South Carolina?

title: For the Warriors, Ellis Proves Essential
description: On Thursday night, the Hack-a-Dwight strategy became less of an occasional tactic and more of a general basketball philosophy. In desperation because of Kwame Browns injury and Andris Biedrins foul trouble, Golden State Warriors Coach Mark Jackson employed a game-long plan of intentionally fouling Dwight Howard, a notoriously poor free throw shooter who was otherwise destroying Golden States interior defense.

title: Kate Foster and Sean Hogue
description: AS freshmen at Missouri State University, Kate Foster and Sean Hogue had a whirlwind romance that quickly led to serious talk about marriage. They are still very young, Ms. Foster is 21 now and Mr. Hogue 22, yet their lives have been tempered by disaster  the tornado that devastated Joplin, Mo., last May and destroyed Ms. Fosters home.

title: Balotellis Pit Stop
description: Manchester Citys Mario Balotelli been called everything from mercurial to daft. One thing is for certain, he knows how to draw a crowd on and off the soccer field.

title: Ford Recalls 450,000 Vehicles in Two Separate Actions
description: According to documents filed earlier this week with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford is recalling about 450,000 minivans and crossovers in two actions.

title: Industrys Green Shoots Blossom Into Optimism
description: DETROIT

title: New Pro-Santorum Ad Touts His Conservative Credentials
description: COLUMBIA, S.C. A super PAC supporting the candidacy of Rick Santorum, whose presence was nowhere to be seen on South Carolina television until last week, is quickly catching up to many of its better-funded rivals.

title: In Iraq Cemetery, Living Among the Dead
description: BAGHDAD  The largest cemetery in the restive province of Diyala has more than 20,000 graves, some date back as far as 1600 A.D., and covers more than a mile and a half of land.

title: The Rise of the New Groupthink
description: SOLITUDE is out of fashion. Ourcompanies, our schools and our culture are in thrall to an idea I call the New Groupthink, which holds that creativity and achievement come from an oddly gregarious place. Most of us now work in teams, in offices without walls, for managers who prize people skills above all. Lone geniuses are out. Collaboration is in.

title: Attention: New Official Ed Board Position
description: Coming up with editorial positions for The New York Times is serious and arduous work. Board members agonize over the big issues and consult precedents that, unlike Chief Justice John Roberts, we cannot simply ignore.

title: Vintry Fine Wines Taps a Fabled Collection
description: A bottle of reasonably priced red to enjoy with dinner is stock-in-trade at most wine shops, including Vintry Fine Wines in Battery Park City. But this sleek, well-lighted new store, with eye-level displays of about 2,500 bottles, including 85 Champagnes and 24 kosher wines, goes well beyond the everyday.

title: Colbert to Advertise in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C. Real presidential candidates have real television ads. And now so does Stephen Colbert.

title: Hostess Has a Lot of Debt, but Few in Finance
description: Hostess Brands is back in bankruptcy again, arguing that its last filing did not really accomplish all that much, despite taking a rather long time.

title: 4 Marines in Video With Dead Taliban Are Identified
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Marine Corps has identified the four Marines shown in a video urinating on what appear to be dead Taliban fighters, without releasing any names, and has named a lead investigating officer to decide whether they should be charged, Marine officials said Friday.

title: Catfight Among Dog-Lovers
description: In this past issues Ethicist column, I featured two pet-related questions. And if theres one thing that the Most E-mailed List proves, time and time again, its that New York Times readers &#9829 pet stories. Accordingly, the column generated a bumper crop of reader comments and e-mails.

title: French Swimmers Fire Resurfaces in Alabama
description: AUBURN, Ala.  To find the athlete known as the French Mermaid, follow the trail of painted orange tiger paw prints. In this Southern college town, far from her French roots, Laure Manaudou, a triple medalist at the 2004 Summer Olympics, has rediscovered her passion for swimming.

title: Jan. 15  21
description: Theater

title: Romney Makes Appeal to South Carolina Evangelicals
description: As conservative Christian leaders struggle to coalesce behind a single candidate of the religious right, the Romney campaign has put out a radio ad in South Carolina that in essence asks the evangelical leaders, Why not me?

title: Just One Look | Alexander Wang
description: Its hard to believe that Alexander Wang, just 28 years old, is presenting his 19th collection. Building off of signature concepts  cutouts, cool-girl black and the use of technical fabrics  Wangs prefall collection is heavy on the separates; a study in wearable sportswear, akin to that of the 1990s. Pops of maroon (on a printed sheer dress) and a greenish mustard (on a ruched skirt dress) emerge among all of the black, white and gray, carrying over into accessories. A soon to be coveted pointy-toe heel with mesh detailing and tight ankle strap demonstrates Wangs ability to evolve ideas from one season to the next. (Have a look at his spring shoes and tell us there isnt a resemblance.) Clarity arrives in the form of a skirt suit bearing the collections defining trompe loeil plaid.

title: Federal Contractor Monitored Social Network Sites
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security paid a contractor in 2009 to monitor social networking sites  like Facebook, blogs and reader comments on a news article  to see how the residents of Standish, Mich., were reacting to a proposal to move detainees from Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to a local prison there, according to newly disclosed documents.

title: Defining Who Can Invest in Private Offerings
description: In the years before the financial crisis, private offerings of stock held much allure. They often offered outsize returns, but only to those who seemed to have the inside track.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $22,375,000
description: A town house on Central Park West that comes with its own 60-foot lap pool and that sold for $22.375 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city public records.

title: Photo Replay: January 13
description: A collection of photos from the day in sports, including shots from the Sydney International tennis tournament and World Cup downhill skiing.

title: TimesCast | Merging Agencies
description: January 13, 2012 - President Obama asks Congress for greater authority to shrink the federal government.

title: As a Broader Group Seeks Early Admission, Rejections Rise in the East
description: Early admission to top colleges, once the almost exclusive preserve of the East Coast elite, is now being pursued by a much broader and more diverse group of students, including foreigners and minorities.

title: Shells Arctic Drilling Plan Clears Hurdle
description: Royal Dutch Shell has been on a six-year crusade to drill in Arctic waters off Alaskas coast, and has spent about $4 billion on the effort so far without drilling a single well.

title: Warm Lentil and Smoked Pork Belly Salad
description: Time: About 1 hour

title: A Lentil, That Object of Desire
description: A FRENCH cook I know, who tends to be rather philosophical, is always saying that cooking (and everything else) is all about desire. And theres no explaining desire.

title: Procter & Gamble to Extend Mother-Centric Campaign at Olympics
description: Procter & Gamble, the giant marketer of household staples, will expand a popular advertising campaign around the world in connection with its sponsorship of the 2012 Summer Olympics.

title: Apple Lists Its Suppliers for 1st Time
description: Apple released a list of its major suppliers for the first time on Friday, bringing the company up to par with other big American corporations, including Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Nike, which have released similar lists.

title: Well Always Have Lentils
description: I spent a recent holiday in Paris appreciating some of the simple things the French do so well. No, not foie gras and Champagne, but rather humbler products, like cured pork and lentils. Nearly every butcher shop sells brined pork (called demi-sel or petit sal), ready to take home and simmer. On a shelf nearby is a box of lentils, usually the certified lentilles du Puy, arguably the best lentils in the world. Cooked together, they are a classic combination, not fancy at all but uncommonly good.

title: Save the Date, but Watch the Movie First
description: AT first, it looked like any other e-mail. But when friends and relatives of Katharine Wentz and Christopher Mazza clicked on the Vimeo video link inside the message, they were treated to a save the date show.

title: For 50/50s Writer, the Hardest Part Was the Drama
description: If the gang from Bridesmaids was dancing around the line between comedy and emotional honesty, the filmmakers behind 50/50 were stomping on it. The film, inspired by the screenwriter Will Reisers real-life story of being given a cancer diagnosis in his mid-20s, treats its subject matter as he did in real life: as dreadfully serious and dreadfully funny. It has been earning some nominations and prizes for its screenplay  and some good-natured ribbing from Mr. Reisers friend Seth Rogen, who starred as the best friend and served as a producer with his writing partner, Evan Goldberg.

title: Photographing Photographers
description: Abe Frajndlich turned the camera on celebrated subjects who were usually behind it.

title: Photographing Photographers
description: IN the fall of 1970 I arrived at Minor Whites house for a live-in workshop. My first task was to organize his photography library. I was mesmerized by the unforgettable images. Photography has had a relatively short history, and I was struck by the fact that most of the practitioners were anonymous and unknown except to a minuscule circle. Unconsciously I must have started to dream of changing that fact, and widening that circle. More than four decades later, this work is the fruition of that dream.

title: Top 5 | Pitti Uomo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Crosby Takes First Step in Second Concussion Comeback
description: Sidney Crosby skated Friday, his first time on ice since experiencing a recurrence of concussion symptoms after a game Dec. 5. After the Penguins morning skate in Sunrise, Fla., he skated for 27 minutes and sounded afterward like a player whose return to the lineup is far from imminent.

title: Ex-Official at S.E.C. Settles Case for $50,000
description: WASHINGTON  A former enforcement official for the Securities and Exchange Commission who was accused of blocking or closing at least three investigations into the activities of the Stanford Financial Group, which the authorities claim was a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, has settled civil charges brought by the Justice Department accusing him of violating conflict-of-interest rules by later representing Stanford before the commission.

title: Sweet, Gooey and an Icon
description: ON the list of happy childhood memories, the Hostess Twinkie occupies a lofty position. Since the 1930s, it has represented the summit of the pastry makers art for untold millions of American children seduced by its loaf-shaped golden sponge cake, soft yet springy, and voluptuous vanilla cream filling.

title: TimesCast | What's A 'Super PAC'?
description: January 13, 2012 - A viewer sent TimesCast a question via Twitter about the role of super PACs in the Republican primaries.

title: Beyond Apple Pie
description: This week Martha Rose Shulman encourages home cooks to get more creative with apples, taking her recipes beyond traditional dishes like applesauce and apple pie. She also encourages home chefs to leave the skin on when possible.

title: TPG Is Said to Consider $1 Billion Investment in Olympus
description: TPG Capital is weighing a potential investment in the Olympus Corporation of Japan, in which it would join with a strategic partner to invest as much as $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Financial Advice for Those With Small Nest Eggs
description: When Merrill Lynch recently discouraged its thundering herd of brokers from taking on new clients with under $250,000 in assets available for investing, it wasnt a big surprise.

title: Mourning in a Digital Age
description: I HAVE found myself in a season of loss. Every few weeks for the last six months, friends in the prime of life have suffered the death of a close family member. These deaths included a mother, a father, a sister, a brother, a spouse and, in one particularly painful case, a teenage child who died on Christmas morning.

title: Out of the Melting Pot and Into a Global Market
description: DETROIT

title: A Buffet of Canny Tweaks in Hot Pursuit of Mileage
description: DETROIT

title: TimesCast: Whats a Super PAC?
description: The Timess Nicholas Confessore answers a question about the role of super PACs in the Republican primaries.

title: Heart Surgery Is Planned for Edwards; Trial Delayed
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The criminal trial of former Senator John Edwards has been delayed until at least March because he has a life-threatening heart ailment that requires surgery, a federal judge said Friday.

title: Newt Gingrich Confronts His Super PAC
description: I have to give Newt Gingrich some credit for asking a super PAC that works on his behalf, Winning our Future, to correct or pull a documentary attacking Mitt Romney.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 13
description: Subjects include the expansion of Terminal 4 at JFK, an overturned houseboat in the Bronx, and the mayors State of the City address.

title: Kate Foster and Sean Hogue  Vows
description: The couples wedding, at the First Presbyterian Church in downtown Joplin on Dec. 30, could perhaps be seen as a symbol of the citys resilience.

title: Big-Dollar Estimates at Scottsdale
description: FOR several years, the collector car market has had a split personality. Great blue-chip cars have found eager bidders paying record prices at auction, while cars a notch below have often gone wanting. The gulf in dollars separating the best and the rest has continued to widen.

title: LearnVest, Merrill Edge and Financial Planning for the Middle Class
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I return to a topic that Ive come at in various ways in recent years: The question of how the merely middle class and semi-affluent among us can get good, ethical, reasonably priced financial advice without having to watch our backs and our wallets.

title: Wyoming Resort Will Take Ski Passes From Anywhere
description: While many North American ski resorts are suffering from a lack of early-season snowfall, some, like Grand Targhee in Wyoming, have enough to share.

title: Hes a Quarterback, Hes a Winner, Hes a TV Draw, Hes a Verb
description: On Saturday night in Massachusetts, a Jim Thorpe-Fabio hybrid in a New England Patriots uniform will emerge from the Foxborough shadows with all the confidence granted by good looks, athletic gifts and the home-field advantage: Tom Brady, the quarterback ideal. A three-time Super Bowl champion. Married to a world-famous model. So laserlike in his throws that he could hit the 11 bus in Boston, 30 miles away  in the numbers.

title: Evaluating Feedback on Fracking Rules
description: As I reported in Thursdays paper, New York State environmental regulators are sorting through more than 20,000 public comments as they develop the final rules for high-volume hydraulic fracturing, the much-debated process to extract natural gas from underground shale formations.

title: Walt Disney Studios Quickly Fills Chief Marketing Post
description: Walt Disney Studios on Friday named a Hollywood veteran to lead its worldwide marketing and publicity efforts: Ricky Strauss, the president of Participant Media, a progressive-minded production company with credits like The Help and the documentary An Inconvenient Truth.

title: A Return for a Noble, Promethean Climb
description: If one word could summarize the performance of Bruckners Eighth Symphony that the conductor Zubin Mehta delivered with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, the likeliest would be noble. For nearly as long as Mr. Mehta has been in the public eye  more than 50 years now  he has shown a clear affinity for Bruckner, whose Promethean symphonies require an intensity and focus that do not come easily to every conductor.

title: Previewing the Golden Globes and More
description: The workweek may be coming to a close, but with the Golden Globes on Sunday, Hollywood is clocking some overtime. Before then, we offer these awards odds and ends:

title: More Climate Messages from Beyond the Nerd Loop
description: Regular readers of Dot Earth will know Im a fan of Randy Olson, the author of Dont Be Such a Scientist and maker of offbeat, provocative films, including Sizzle. After my post the other day looking at a Norwegian effort to use a man walking a leashed dog to illustrate the difference between trend and variation, I got in touch with Olson afresh, both to get his reaction to that animation and talk more generally about ways to get beyond what he calls the nerd loop in climate communication. Heres the resulting Q&A:

title: Prince Fielder Leads the Unsigned All-Stars
description: Scott Boras does not get everything he seeks in every negotiation. But it is wise not to doubt him. This is the agent who persuaded teams to give seven-year, $126 million contracts to Barry Zito and Jayson Werth, and persuaded another to hand not one, but two player options to Rafael Soriano.

title: Links for the New Year
description: Theres something so inoffensive and old-fashioned about saying happy new year that makes it incredibly pleasurable. You can say it with warmth, genuine-ness, sincerity and with a profound lack of irony. I love it. So let me be the last to say happy new year everyone.

title: Defriending My Rapist
description: Facebook suggested I friend him. I guess our social networks overlapped. I guided the mouse toward his photo, and the little pointed hand hovered over his face. Fear and anger swelled up but curiosity won out and I clicked Add Friend. He accepted within minutes. Stunned, I wondered if he had forgotten raping me, or if he thought I had.

title: Seeking a Wider Audience
description: Many American-branded cars at the Detroit auto show reflected global design influences.

title: It Can Be So Hard to Save the World When Those Hormones Kick In
description: While the frenzy for Downton Abbey runs its course, two new series remind us that not all television imports from Britain and its former dominions are so genteel.

title: Avant-Garde Arts Space Inaugurates New Home, Finally
description: Four years ago Issue Project Room, an avant-garde arts space that has had several homes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, hit a kind of real estate jackpot: a 20-year, rent-free lease on 5,000 square feet in a McKim, Mead & White building in downtown Brooklyn. The catch: the tiny group would be responsible for $3.6 million in renovations and improvements.

title: Russian Ad Compares Putin Foe to Hitler
description: While Republican voters in South Carolina are being warned in a new ad not to trust Mitt Romney because, like John Kerry, he speaks French, politicking in Russia, where a new president will be elected in March, is a good deal less subtle.

title: Old School Logos
description: According to this definition of the term old school, I was a child when anything I could technically consider old school came into existence. Its certainly a part of everyones vocabulary, but for me its a word that especially permeates sports culture in regard to team logos and uniforms. It often means one thing: quality.

title: Former U.S. Diplomat Rattles Taiwan Before Election
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  In a closely fought election rife with verbal attacks and partisan rancor, the comments of a foreign academic with no official government position might normally be subsumed by the storm and stress of the campaign.

title: Lead Rajaratnam Prosecutor to Join Dechert
description: The lead prosecutor in the insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam is leaving the United States attorneys office in Manhattan and joining the law firm Dechert as a partner in its white-collar criminal defense practice.

title: A Fairy Tale Princess Who Takes Bathroom Breaks
description: The toying with expectations essential to an Ann Liv Young production starts before the show. Her reputation precedes her. Even if youve never witnessed the verbal abuse, vulgarity, nudity, masturbation, urination or defecation in her previous projects, youve almost certainly heard of her predilections. She assumes you have.

title: Canadiens Trade Cammalleri in a Flash
description: There are some strange things, and a lot of losing, going down in Montreal, and Canadiens fans are in an uproar.

title: Showtime Plans Cheney Documentary, as Producers Reach Out to Wyoming
description: Last month, ads started running in The Casper Star-Tribune in Wyoming asking for photographs and video of the former Vice President Dick Cheney, who represented the state in Congress and still maintains a home there.

title: Canadian Pacific Rival Warns Ex-Chief to Stay Away From Ackman
description: 6:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Antidepressant Use Linked to Increased Pulmonary Hypertension Risk in Infants
description: A study published in the British Medical Journal this week provides stronger evidence that taking some antidepressants during pregnancy doubles the risk of a baby developing pulmonary hypertension. Researchers have long suspected a link between the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.s, and the condition, but previous studies have been small and inconclusive (with results ranging from there being no link to a six times greater risk).

title: Motorcycle-Auction Tripleheader Comes to Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  A restored, fully operational 1920 Henderson Four Model K was the top sale Thursday at the Auctions America by RM event at the Rio Las Vegas Hotel and Casino, as a three-day, three-auction marathon kicked off at three locations here. Including a 12 percent sales commission, the Henderson changed hands for $50,960, slightly below its preauction estimate.

title: CBS Tramples the Competition
description: CBS once again managed to dominate prime time among the broadcast networks on Thursday night, easily taking first place in all ratings categories. According to Nielsen, a very large percentage of the 15.9 million people who watched Big Bang Theory stayed put and sampled the series premiere of Rob. Although that comedy has been poorly received critically, it drew 13.5 million viewers. The new drama Person of Interest also did well as it posted its best numbers ever and reached 14.7 million people.

title: Israel Says Sanctions Hurt Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said in an interview published Saturday that new economic sanctions aimed at stopping Irans contentious nuclear program appeared to be having an effect and, if combined with a threat of military action led by the United States, could succeed.

title: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton
description: The Louis Vuitton prefall collection is an absolute delight. Rounded silhouettes on coats, cap-sleeved baby-doll dresses in peach and yellow and a return of the beloved Stephen Sprouse leopard in blue/navy on a smart suit, all possess the same whimsy we saw at Marc Jacobss most recent spring collection. Star accessories include grommeted berets and sharp heels  kitten-height and higher  with shiny steel-toe tips. Fur is sprinkled liberally throughout, on coat pockets, collars and shoes (making feet look like puppy paws; its quite fun). Here, a dress with the collections signature Sgt. Peppers trompe loeil gets a pop of pretty pink.

title: Coney Island, Jan. 3, 1915
description: The Library of Congress has been gradually posting to Flickr its trove of more than 40,000 photos from the Bain Collection, comprising the surviving photos of the Bain News Service, a photo agency founded by George Grantham Bain that flourished in the early 20th century.

title: Eight Men In: Wearing Giants Blue, Ready for Green Bay
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  traveled to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men  they were joined by two pals in Milwaukee  agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes were to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

title: If They Had Their Choice
description: ITS anybodys guess which dresses will make a splash at the Golden Globes on Sunday night. But a handful of top Hollywood stylists weighed in with their nominations for the looks they would most like to see on the red carpet.

title: Another Weekly Roundup, as News Picks Up in F1s Off-Season
description: Early into the new year and the Formula One news is picking up again little by little, especially from Italy where the Ferrari team held its annual Christmas company event, called Wrooom, in Madonna di Campiglio, this week.

title: Another Weekly Roundup, as News Picks Up in F1s Off-Season
description: Early into the new year and the Formula One news is picking up again little by little, especially from Italy where the Ferrari team held its annual Christmas company event, called Wrooom, in Madonna di Campiglio, this week.

title: Hollywoods Power Stylists
description: As insiders see it, the investment is worthwhile: the right red-carpet turnout can help a performer change lanes.

title: Gingrich, Perry, Santorum and Huntsman Lose Virginia Ballot Fight
description: A federal judge in Virginia on Friday denied Rick Perry, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. spots on the states presidential primary ballot.

title: Under the Radar Festival: 5 Questions About The Past Is a Grotesque Animal
description: Ten years in the lives of three couples in Argentina spin, quite slowly, in El Pasado Es un Animal Grotesco (The Past Is a Grotesque Animal), from the Argentine writer and director Mariano Pensotti. The piece, making its U.S. premiere in a co-production of the Coil and Under the Radar festivals, features actors performing on a slowly rotating set to a soundtrack that includes music from the band Of Montreal.

title: Its Winter, So Here Come the Sneaker Ads
description: The early days of winter may seem an odd time to bring out new athletic footwear, but there are some good reasons: for one, millions of consumers have vowed to exercise more in the new year; for another, there are lots of sports events on TV that draw big audiences filled with shoe buyers.

title: Owner as Regulator, Like Oil and Water
description: Lets say youre the biggest owner of a global auto company. You take the companys flagship new vehicle, twist it, crash it, poke it and leave it outside in the elements for weeks until its battery catches fire. Then you generate a storm of publicity and watch the share price and the value of your ownership stake decline.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: The Power Stylists of Hollywood
description: EVERY red carpet has its head-turners, dresses that captivate, spark style trends, and celebrate turning points in a stars career. Much the same can be expected when the Golden Globes unfurl the crimson runner on NBC on Sunday night. In past seasons the looks on parade at this annual glam fest helped cement reputations and jump-start careers.

title: In France, the Pain of Rating Downgrade Is Especially Acute
description: Among the European countries that Standard & Poors declared less creditworthy on Friday, France stands out among the tarnished.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iran, Kuwait, Myanmar and New York.

title: Opening science and doing it yourself; plus the malaria medicine of Chairman Mao
description: Opening science and doing it yourself; plus the malaria medicine of Chairman Mao

title: Menendez Drops His Opposition to Obamas Pick for a Federal Appeals Court
description: Reversing himself in what had become an awkward intraparty stalemate for Democrats, Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey said Friday that he would no longer block President Obamas nominee to a federal appeals court.

title: A Crow Appears to Find a Source of Winter Sport
description: This video provides a calming capstone to a frenetic week. It is evidently a hooded crow*, apparently in Russia (post if you know for sure), and almost assuredly shows a bird at play (note the multiple tracks in the rooftop snow from earlier snowboarding trips):

title: Two People, One Identity
description: IN person, the identical twins Kirk and Nate Mueller are an uncanny sight. The neatly coiffed hair, the ASOS leather boots, the red lapel flowers from Hook & Albert, the brown wool Topman suits  everything about them is almost exactly the same. Even their jobs: designing sleek iPad apps and Web sites, which has made them overnight design celebrities.

title: Class Warfare
description: If Mitt Romney had his way, wed only talk about income inequality in quiet roomsIm picturing wood-paneling and cigar smoke. If Rick Santorum had his way, we wouldnt even use the term middle class since, apparently, there are no classes in America. Middle-income people, maybe, he says, but no middle-class people.

title: What Did You Expect? It Makes a Difference
description: MY father recently had his second knee operation in a year. The first time, things went poorly. His rehabilitation was difficult and months later, he still could not walk well or, even more important to him, play tennis.

title: Top Hops to Open, With 700 Beers
description: An arms race seems to have sprung up among the new breed of beer stores that specialize in imports and craft labels. If one offers 250 different brews, the next stockpiles 400. Now, Ted Kenny, a former beer salesman, is raising the ante with at least 700, including 20 on tap, at Top Hops Beer Shop, the new store he plans to open Saturday on the Lower East Side.

title: Some Teachers Skeptical of Merit Pay
Teachers Union Calls for Renewed Contract Negotiations
Uh, Uh, Uh ... Hes Nearly Got It
description: Keith Hennessy was quaking in his underwear, wobbling atop a tall stack of foam blocks when he said, Im doing this on purpose. It was near the end of Almost, his improvisational performance at the Abrons Arts Center on Thursday, part of the American Realness festival. A moment before, having ad-libbed his way into that precarious position, he had said, dryly, Theres a load of possibilities here.

title: Chic in Review | William and Kates +1
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Lynne Ramsay Is Back. Finally.
description: Back in 2002, Lynne Ramsay was a film director on the verge. Her second feature, the gorgeous, impressionistic drama Morvern Callar, made its debut at Cannes and grabbed the attention of serious moviegoers; in The Times, the critic Elvis Mitchell called it one of the most important pictures of the year. Meanwhile, a dark first novel that Ramsay was preparing to adapt and direct surprised the publishing world by landing at the top of The New York Times best-seller list.

title: Fighting Antipiracy Measure, Activist Group Posts Personal Information of Media Executives
description: The online activist group known as Anonymous, which has targeted opponents of the Occupy Wall Street movement and businesses that stopped providing services to WikiLeaks, has set its sights on a new adversary: media executives.

title: Latest Conservative No-No: Speaking French
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Newt Gingrich, parlez-vous franais?

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 13
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Trinidadian Gets Life Sentence in J.F.K. Bomb Plot
description: A Trinidadian man who was convicted of plotting to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced Friday to life in prison.

title: Anthony Roth Costanzo to Replace David Daniels at the Met
description: Anthony Roth Costanzo will step into the counter-tenor role of Prospero in the Metropolitan Operas production of The Enchanted Island on Saturday evening. He will replace David Daniels, who is ill, the Met said. Mr. Costanzo is cast as Ferdinand in the opera, and will be replaced in that part by Jeffrey Mandelbaum. The switch also occurred in Act II of Thursdays performance.

title: Council Leader Offers Compromise on Wage
description: After months of heated debate over whether New York City should mandate a so-called living wage for workers in city-subsidized projects, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, unveiled a proposal on Friday that would raise wages for some workers in such projects.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nietzsche Bewitches America and the Science of Middle Age
description: In this Sundays Book Review, Alexander Star reviews a new book about the reactions of Americans to the powerful and controversial work of the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Mr. Star writes:

title: Nine Euro Countries Ratings Are Cut
description: On Friday, Standard & Poors cut the ratings on nine of the 17 European countries that use the euro currency. France and Austria lost their coveted AAA ratings, which were lowered one notch to AA+, and Italy and Spain had their ratings cut by two notches. Germany, Finland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands all retained their AAA status, while the ratings of Portugal and Cyprus were cut to junk.

title: Reviewing the 2012 Detroit Auto Show
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich, Phil Patton and Paul Stenquist take the measure of the 2012 Detroit auto show, which is scheduled to open to the public this weekend, and where media previews concluded on Tuesday.

title: A Sacrifice Just May Reduce a Potential Loss
description: Weeklong regional tournaments take place several times a month around the country. The popular Orlando Regional ran from Jan. 2 to 8.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 13
description: More Photographs

title: An Artists Big, Big Plans for Red Hook
description: THE artist Dustin Yellin likes big things. The jawbone of a sperm whale hangs in his studio. His most recent sculpture weighs more than 12 tons. And in June, he became the owner of the former Time Moving and Storage building, a 24,000-square-foot Civil War-era warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn, for which he paid $3.7 million.

title: The Subjective Face of the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Past, Present and Future, All at Once
description: In proclaiming the emancipation of the dissonance in a 1926 essay, Arnold Schoenberg meant to justify in historical terms his move from functional harmony toward free atonality and, ultimately, a new 12-tone system of composition. Despite his radical innovations Schoenberg never forfeited his inheritance altogether; a dialogue among past, present and future is precisely what animates his work.

title: Brooklyn Billboard Topples Onto Expressway
description: Watch a video of the billboard collapse, taken by a security camera, on the Web site of the Polish-language newspaper Nowy Dziennik, about 25 seconds into the newscast.

title: They Came to Hear Mahler, Not an iPhone
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: Lazard Names Head of Restructuring
description: Lazard announced on Friday that it had named David Kurtz as its global head of restructuring, bringing new leadership to the investment banking industrys biggest corporate reorganization and bankruptcy team.

title: Japans Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Investing in Head Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocky Hollywood Road Leads Directors Back to Sundance
description: LOS ANGELES  Spike Lee is on the spot. Next week Mr. Lee, the celebrated director of movies like Shes Gotta Have It and Inside Man, will find himself in a situation he has never been in before: at the Sundance Film Festival, crossing his fingers along with more than 100 other directors hoping for a bite from a distributor.

title: Bluegrass That Takes the A Train Uptown
description: This is our first show north of 14th Street, the mandolinist Chris Thile announced as his bluegrass duo with Michael Daves on guitar started its American Songbook series concert on Thursday night at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Allen Room. Theyve been playing small club shows downtown, and they brought that informality to the Allen Room, punctuating dazzling virtuosity with bluegrass-aficionado banter and Fiddle Tune Request Time.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Victorian Human Skulls and a Plagiarism Problem
description: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: A Place Repurchased, and Recast
description: DINERS accustomed to the taste of sticky takeout stir-fry dishes thickened with corn starch and bludgeoned with soy sauce are in for a surprise when they visit Gem Cuisines of China. Here a menu of beautifully balanced dishes will remind them of the infinite variety and subtlety of this great cuisine. Whether peppery, bold, heady or delicate, the dishes offered at Gem reflect the latest in the evolution of Chinas culinary arts.

title: Did Hollywoods Home Viewing Revenue Fall Further Than First Thought?
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  In a report issued on Friday, the analysts at Nomura Equity Research take issue with an only somewhat downbeat assessment from the Digital Entertainment Group, an industry alliance, of United States home entertainment revenue in 2011.

title: Getting Their Picture Taken, and Taking a Few Themselves
description: LOS ANGELES  If you can judge someones star power by the quantity of greetings and congratulations they get at a party  and in Hollywood, you can  the folks from The Artist are riding high. At the Critics Choice Awards on Thursday and the American Film Institute luncheon today, they were inundated with well-wishers, from Brad Grey, chairman of Paramount, to Sacha Baron Cohen.

title: Shorter, Modern and Less Than Opera
description: The creative impetus behind The Gershwins Porgy and Bess, the adaptation of the classic 1935 opera that opened at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Thursday, was to make the work more accessible, fresh and realistic for todays musical theater audiences. In a New York Times article last August, before the production was introduced at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., Audra McDonald, who portrays Bess, said none of us wanted to do a Porgy and Bess where the audience would sit back comfortably and just, ahhhhhhh, soak in the big gems from the Gershwin score.

title: Forget About a Paper Moon: This Swans Cardboard
description: The man sits inside the dubious shelter of his little cardboard shack, staring out at strangers. The strangers stare back. His body makes little twitches. The palm tree and giant swan, also cardboard, are slowly wilting, as is his roof. It has been raining, and hard, for a long time now.

title: Films Oddballs Reunite for a Small-Screen Makeover
description: Has it really been only seven and a half years since Napoleon Dynamite was in theaters? It seems longer, perhaps because so many geeky antiheroes have followed Napoleon onto our screens, or perhaps because the films deadpan humor was so vaporous that it seemed to vanish as you watched.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 13
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the expansion of Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport, an overturned houseboat in the Bronx and the mayors State of the City address.

title: Breaching the Border Between Pop and Opera
description: To hear Paulo Szot apply his heroic baritone to If Ever I Would Leave You, Sir Lancelots oratorical love song from Camelot, is to hear a flowery list of sweet nothings transformed into sweet somethings by the sheer force of delivery. Its blandishments include a description of lips red as flame and a face with a luster that puts gold to shame. There was a time when such flattery might get a dedicated suitor well beyond first base. Nowadays, Alan Jay Lerners rhetoric sounds so artificial that a strikeout seems more likely.

title: Man Convicted in Terrorism Conspiracy Is Denied New Trial
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has refused to grant a new trial to a man convicted in 1995 of conspiring to blow up New York landmarks and of the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane.

title: It Needs a Good Beat, and a Stars Endorsement
description: The International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week offered thousands of novel gadgets and high-tech products like remote-controlled indoor helicopters, ultrathin computer glass and refrigerators that play Pandora.

title: How Dry We Arent
description: MAYOR Michael R. Bloomberg has made it clear that he wants New Yorkers to smoke less, eat healthier food, and now, according to The New York Post, also cut back on excessive drinking.

title: Mississippi: Barbour Defends Pardons
description: As the uproar over his last-minute grants of clemency continued, former Gov. Haley Barbour showed no sign of backing down on Friday, giving a news conference and appearing on Fox News. Mr. Barbour, a Republican whose second term ended this week, described himself as very comfortable with the decision to grant clemency, and mostly full pardons, to 215 convicts in his last days in office. He emphasized that 189 of the convicts were not in prison, and that half of the others were given suspended sentences for medical reasons. He said the tradition of granting clemency was rooted in the Christian idea of giving second chances.

title: Beneath a Deeply Silly Campaign, a Deeply Serious Performer
description: Stephen Colbert teasing South Carolina about a run for the presidency is becoming one of Americas great political traditions, right up there with awkward photographs of candidates eating corn dogs at the Iowa State Fair.

title: Decisions, Decisions
description: Ive played for many teams in my soccer career and won some significant championships, but it seems Im still searching for my home.

title: Super PACs Explained!
description: Earlier today, I wrote about Newt Gingrich and the super PAC supporting him that is running an attack documentary on Mitt Romney.

title: Fifteen Minutes Faster and Four Years Wiser
description: HOUSTON  At the 2008 Olympic marathon trials, Desiree Davila reached Mile 22 in fourth place, eight or nine seconds out of third, the final qualifying spot. When she attempted to hit the accelerator, though, she instead hit the brakes.

title: A Champion of Frances Downtrodden, With Limits of His Own
description: MONTPELLIER, France FIVE seat belts strapped Jean-Christophe Parisot to his seat in a van on his way to a desolate Roma neighborhood in this city in southern France. A home care aide carefully stabilized his head and held a telephone to his ear.

title: An Interview With Jeremy Langmead
description: The editor-in-chief of mrporter.com discusses how his site combines editorial content with commerce and the future of online retailing.

title: Reprehensible Behavior Is a Risk of Combat, Experts Say
description: Talk to almost anyone who has fought in combat, and chances are they can tick off a string of reasons why the YouTube video showing four Marines urinating on the bodies of dead enemy fighters in southern Afghanistan is horrible. Horrible for Americas image around the world. Horrible for its strategy of winning support from the Afghan people. Horrible for a professional military that believes its troops behave with the utmost decorum, even in the heat of battle.

title: Honoring the Struggles and Sacrifices
description: Jessica Ingram still recalls the summer day a decade ago when she stood at Court Square Fountain in Montgomery, Ala., taking in the details spelled out in historical markers. There, near the State Capitol, she read that the square was the site of the citys slave market. That none of the men, women or children had been given last names. How much they fetched.

title: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?
description: Back in the late-1950s there was a TV show called The Millionaire about a mysterious rich man, named John Beresford Tipton, who would anonymously give checks for $1 million to total strangers.

title: Defense Once Won Titles, but Score Has Changed
description: As the Pittsburgh Steelers, their top-ranked defense shredded by one of the N.F.L.sworst passers, trudged into the off-season and a cold Denver night last Sunday, it was tempting to wonder if they might someday be viewed as a relic from a fading era.

title: Marlene on the Phone
description: It was a bitter cold day on the end of Long Island. I was not alone out there; my two dogs and I had come in from a hike in the woods at the exact instant that the phone rang.

title: More N.C.A.A. Justice
description: Last weeks case study in N.C.A.A. injustice took place at the University of North Carolina, where every sport is big time. Today, we move north to a different kind of institution, St. Josephs University, a small Jesuit-run school in Philadelphia. With fewer than 5,000 undergraduates, St. Joes doesnt even field a football team, but its little-engine-that-could basketball team has long been a source of pride. During the 2003-4 season, for instance, it went 27-0 in the regular season and made it to the regional final of the N.C.A.A. championship tournament.

title: Being Garifuna
description: When it comes to being counted in the census, the Garifunas, who are part African, part Caribbean and part Central American, say they dont fit into any box.

title: Tenderizing the Tundra With Some Light and Heat
description: The frozen tundra is a myth. The ground at Lambeau Field, legendary home of the Green Bay Packers, is heated. It has not been frozen during a football game since it was dubbed the frozen tundra more than 40 years ago.

title: Friday Night Music, Defense Of Marriage Edition
description: A bit of a break from the usual  for some reason Ive been on a Mozart kick the past few days.

title: Lending Helps JPMorgan, but 4th Quarter Was Soft
description: Wall Street, more than three years after the financial crisis, has loosened its lending tap. Consumers, however, have yet to reap the benefits.

title: For Many Latinos, Racial Identity Is More Culture Than Color
description: Every decade, the Census Bureau spends billions of dollars and deploys hundreds of thousands of workers to get an accurate portrait of the American population. Among the questions on the census form is one about race, with 15 choices, including some other race.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A credit downgrade for several European nations, unexpectedly strong jobs numbers for December and the suspension of iPhone sales in Apple stores in China were among the top business news stories of the week.

title: Eclecticism by the Sea
description: SAMPLING the lobster roll at Oyster Club in Mystic is practically unavoidable. In one guise or another, it is one of the few constants on a menu that changes daily. Though not a big fan of this shore-side standby, I was converted at first bite. The version on the day I visited (a Saturday in December) combined fat chunks of succulent lobster meat with a delicate mix of truffle oil, parsley and parsley oil. The lobster was stuffed into a house-made potato roll spread with apple butter and topped with crisp-fried shallots; accompanying it were thick-cut fries sprinkled with a flavorsome mix of celery salt, paprika, homemade garlic powder and cayenne that made it easy to forgive the less-than-crisp fries.

title: No Parade in Hoboken to Celebrate St. Patricks
description: There will not be a St. Patricks Day parade in Hoboken, N.J., this year, but organizers say they may go elsewhere to march.

title: A Long Bleak Winter
description: The European Central Banks cheap lending to euro-area banks may have briefly stabilized the financial markets. But the respite wont last. The decision by Standard & Poors on Friday to downgrade the credit ratings of nine euro-zone countries, including France, Italy and Spain, should remind European leaders that their economic strategy based on austerity for all is just not working.

title: The Urination Video and Pressures of Battle
description: The United States Marine Corps has identified the four Marines shown in a video urinating on what appear to be dead Taliban fighters, and has named a lead investigating officer to decide whether they should be charged, Marine officials said. In an article in Saturdays issue of The Times, Elisabeth Bumiller and Matthew Rosenberg report that Marine officials were also attempting to identify the person who shot the controversial video.

title: Self-Inflicted Wound
description: Even after seven years, the photos of Army soldiers abusing detainees at the Abu Ghraib prison are an ugly black mark on the American presence in Iraq. Now there is a new scar on the countrys reputation. Four Marines were filmed urinating on what appear to be the corpses of three dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

title: In Extreme Cold, Accurate Passes Are the Least of the Bodys Worries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In addition to facing Aaron Rodgers, Greg Jennings and the rest of the Green Bay Packers on Sunday, the Giants will also be forced to battle paresthesia, bronchoconstriction and a persistent though not necessarily overwhelming sensation that they have to urinate.

title: W.P.S. Holds Its Draft, Just in Case
description: U.C.L.A. forward Sydney Leroux was the top pick in Fridays W.P.S. draft. Whether she  or anyone else  will get to play in the league this season is another question.

title: Fisher Picks Rams Over the Dolphins
description: Jeff Fisher, the most sought-after head coach this off-season, chose the St. Louis Rams and their franchise quarterback Sam Bradford over the Miami Dolphins on Friday, ending a nearly two-week waiting game for both teams. The Rams and Fisher were negotiating a contract on Friday afternoon.

title: A Piece of Thailand in an Inconspicuous Spot
description: IF you had never been to Savory Thai Cooking before, it would be easy to drive past it. It is set perpendicular to the road; on my two visits, its storefront looked dark except for the restaurants name and a small lighted Open sign; there were very few cars in the parking lot. Inside, though, is a kitchen turning out solid Thai fare.

title: Wanted by the F.B.I., but Still Popular With the Ex-Mother-in-Law
description: If the Federal Bureau of Investigation and some medical records are correct, a tough-looking mob associate named Jack Mannino robbed a Brooklyn bank two weeks ago while wearing an adult diaper.

title: News of the Wired
description: The advent of the Internet has prompted endless claims that we are living through an unprecedented revolution in communication, one that has annihilated the concept of distance. Yet the real revolution came with the arrival of the telegraph in the 19th century.

title: Richard Threlkeld, Award-Winning Journalist, Dies at 74
description: Richard Threlkeld, who in his 33 years as a correspondent for CBS and ABC News covered wars, presidential campaigns, assassinations and the collapse of the Soviet Union, died Friday morning in a car accident on Long Island. He was 74.

title: Death of Oxford Astrophysicist Evokes Echoes of a TV Drama for the British
description: LONDON  It has all the elements that have made the Inspector Morse detective series a popular success on both sides of the Atlantic: two Oxford University academics, friends and professional collaborators for decades, co-authors of a popular textbook on science mathematics, meet for a pub supper in a village outside the city.

title: 2 Smiths Add Up to Trouble for 49ers Opponents
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  In 2001, Justin Smith set the Missouri record for sacks in a season, with 11.

title: For Some Applicants, Another Tough Year on the Early Admission Front
description: The Times has posted an article on its Web site by Richard Perez-Pena and Jenny Anderson arguing that the early-admissions game was made much tougher this year for the group that has long dominated it: prep schools in New York and beyond where the vast majority of seniors apply to their top choices in November in hopes of avoiding the springtime scrum.

title: The Mayors To-Do List
description: With two years left in office, Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced ambitious plans this week to take on the citys powerful teachers union by pushing for extra pay for the best teachers and making other education reforms.

title: Tanker With Crucial Fuel Delivery Is Sighted Off Nome
description: A Russian tanker that has spent nearly a month making its way to Nome, Alaska, to deliver fuel appeared off the coast on the Bering Sea on Friday, apparently nearing the conclusion of an ocean odyssey that has been both criticized and celebrated.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,856 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Working Twice as Hard
description: In 2000, just two weeks after her fifth-grade graduation, Karla Mejia woke up with numbness on the right side of her body. The diagnosis was multiple sclerosis. She spent almost a year in the hospital, relearning to walk and to write, but her anger and depression over the years left her unable to concentrate on schoolwork.

title: A Future Sans Corkscrews
description: Long Island wines are increasingly sold from taps in restaurants on the Island and in New York City.

title: An Old-Fashioned Touch With Classic Italian
description: VERONA RISTORANTE, a five-year-old Italian restaurant in Farmingdale, is anything but trendy. Not only does it still serve patrons a free bread basket  a vanishing amenity  but it also includes a house-made focaccia and three additional breads from a local bakery. That basket is accompanied by butter, marinated olives and chickpeas, and a bowl of chopped tomatoes and onions for making do-it-yourself bruschetta.

title: Anthonys Injury Forces Knicks to Adjust
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Twenty-seven percent of the Knicks offense will be missing Saturday night, and maybe that will not be the worst thing for the team.

title: Rauf Denktash, Who Led Turkish Cypriots, Dies at 87
description: Rauf Denktash, former leader of the Turkish minority in Cyprus, who for decades successfully opposed reunification of that divided Mediterranean island in his resolute pursuit of a separate state for his people, died there on Friday at the age of 87.

title: Bitter Politics of Envy?
description: Youre just jealous. At least thats how Mitt Romney sees it. The millionaire who posed for a picture with the boys at Bain Capital with the long green clinched between their teeth and poking out of their collars and jackets now says that people who question what he did there, and what rich people do now, are just green with envy.

title: Like Woods Before, Tebow Becomes Must-Watch TV
description: Tiger Woods and Tim Tebow form an athletic pairing that pleases CBS Sports.

title: Ruth Fernndez, Singer and Senator in Puerto Rico, Dies at 92
description: Ruth Fernndez, a soothing and spirited singer known in her homeland as el alma de Puerto Rico hecha cancin  the soul of Puerto Rico made song  died on Monday in San Juan. She was 92.

title: Saturday: Nutty as Can Be
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Just because there is no theme to talk about on a Saturday doesnt mean we dont have things to discuss, right?

title: More E-Mails Released on Failed Solar Company
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has given House Republican investigators an additional 66 pages of internal correspondence relating to Solyndra, the solar equipment manufacturer that filed for bankruptcy after accepting a $535 million loan guarantee, and the e-mails reflect significant anxiety about the poor financial prospects of the administrations flagship choice to demonstrate how federal help could add to building a clean energy economy.

title: Sparano Hears Firsthand Where Jets Need to Improve
description: The philosophy espoused by Tony Sparano is, in his words, a little different from that of Brian Schottenheimer, his predecessor as the Jets offensive coordinator. When asked Friday to describe that philosophy, Sparano used the word physical in seven straight sentences. It was as if he were reading from cue cards held up by Coach Rex Ryan.

title: For a Lover of Traveling and Languages, Only One Place Can Be Called Home
description: When Alayne OReilly looks out the window of her 17th-floor apartment in Greenwich Village and watches the planes go by, she wonders where they are heading. She imagines she knows their destinations, excited by the thought of going to other countries and hearing the different languages.

title: Gingrich and Santorum Vie to Be the Conservative of Choice
description: DUNCAN, S.C.  Conventional wisdom dictates that for either Newt Gingrich or Rick Santorum to vault past Mitt Romney and win the South Carolina primary on Jan. 21, they must handily win the vote of upstate social conservatives, like the ones who packed a high school lunchroom here Friday night. But if the reactions of the 500 or so people here were any indication, these voters remain split.

title: Bloomberg Focuses His Legacy on Education Reform
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his first State of the City address in 2002, to a wounded city still shaken by the death and destruction of a terrorist attack, he vowed to rebuild Lower Manhattan, but he also trained his focus on the citys much-maligned school system.

title: Corrections: January 14
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Two Guitarists, as Heard in a Woody Allen Film
description: EARLY in 1998, the guitarist Howard Alden got a call from the pianist Dick Hyman, a longtime collaborator of Woody Allens, asking whether he would like to work on Mr. Allens latest movie, Sweet and Lowdown. All he would need to do, Mr. Hyman said, was lay down tracks in the style of the gypsy guitarist Django Reinhardt  a style with which Mr. Alden was deeply familiar.

title: Middle East Trip Suggests Change in Policy by China
description: BEIJING  Premier Wen Jiabao heads on Saturday to the oil-producing nations of Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, a six-day tour of Irans Persian Gulf neighbors that is the first Saudi trip by a Chinese premier in two decades, and the first ever to the other two states.

title: In Mayors State of the City Addresses, a Recurring Theme
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg devoted more than half of his State of the City address on Thursday to education. Throughout Mr. Bloombergs 10 years as mayor, it has been a consistent theme of the annual speeches. Following are excerpts:

title: In Two Deals, Yanks Trade Montero but Bolster Pitching
description: For weeks, people around baseball have marveled at the relative inactivity of the Yankees this off-season. Normally one of the most aggressive actors in baseball in terms of acquiring marquee players, the team was quiet almost to the point of drawing suspicion.

title: Organs and Pianos at Yale, but No Dueling Keyboards
description: SIMON PRESTON, an organist with a wit as dry as his talent is prodigious, had just concluded a solo concert in Yale Universitys Woolsey Hall last November when he was asked to draw a broad comparison between the halls monumental Newberry Memorial Organ  on which he had rendered Bach, Mozart, Liszt and Olivier Messiaen to sustained applause  and the other great organs he had played.

title: U.S. Faces New Challenge of Fewer Troops in Europe
description: WASHINGTON  With word that the Pentagon will bring two combat brigades home from Germany, the Obama administration faces a challenge to convince Atlantic allies that the militarys new orders to refocus on the Asia-Pacific region, while sustaining its role in the Middle East, will not mean abandoning Europe to fit shrinking budgets.

title: A Southern Town Highlighted by Romney Rivals
description: Gaffney, S.C., a small Southern town, has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Lottery Numbers
Putting Sociopaths Aside to Tackle Middle-Age Dreams
description: Huntington Bay, N.Y.

title: Town, Cast as Romneys Victim, Says, Huh?
description: GAFFNEY, S.C.  This small Southern town that once boomed with peaches and cotton mills has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Every Goes Low and Speaks Out
description: Matt Every, who carded a six-under-par 64, was perhaps best known for a three-month tour suspension he received in 2010 for conduct unbecoming a professional after he was arrested during a tournament in July on a misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession. All charges were later dropped.

title: In Breess Great Season, Reviews Have Been Muted
description: METAIRIE, La.  To grasp the grand scale of Drew Breess 2011 season, consider Thomas Morstead. He is the punter for New Orleans, and because Brees is the Saints quarterback, because he set three N.F.L. passing records, Morsteads workload, like that of a butcher at a vegan bistro, mostly ranges from light to nonexistent.

title: Romney Rolls Out the Big Guns in S.C.
description: HILTON HEAD, S.C.  Mitt Romney made an appeal to veterans here in what could be considered the political equivalent of the doctrine of overwhelming force.

title: Rocks Scientist Gets a Fittingly Small Tribute
description: MAHWAH, N.J.

title: Tom Ardolino Dies at 56; Drummer for NRBQ for Three Decades
description: Tom Ardolino, a self-taught drummer who for 30 years provided the impassioned but steady pulse for NRBQ, one of the longest-lasting and most beloved rock groups never to have a Top 40 single, died on Jan. 6 in Springfield, Mass. He was 56.

title: Twitter, Eggs and Mob Wives
description: The playwright Katori Hall, a self-described workaholic, is in the middle of a busy theater season: shortly after her play The Mountaintop, about the last hours of the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., closes on Broadway on Jan. 22, her newest play, Hurt Village, about a soldier returning from Iraq, will open at the Signature Theater Company on Feb. 7. Ms. Hall, 30, who was born in Memphis, lives in Washington Heights with her fianc, Alan Tumusiime, 28, a video editor and photographer. She spends Sundays avoiding writing, playing guitar and appreciating both reality television and Southern cuisine.

title: Inspiring Horse Honored
description: Neville Bardos, the horse who survived a barn fire last May, was named the international Horse of the Year for 2011 by the United States Equestrian Federation. Neville was among 11 horses in a barn in West Grove, Pa., when it caught fire in late May. Six of the horses died. Three months later, Neville is on a short list of Summer Olympics contenders.

title: China: Tibetans Ransack Police Station After Killing of Suspect, Group Says
description: Tibetans in Gansu Province protested the death of a Tibetan man whom the police had shot dead after suspecting him of being involved in stealing equipment from an airport construction site, according to a report released this week by International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based in Washington. The Tibetan man, Gurgo Tsering, in his mid-30s, was killed on Jan. 8 in a late night raid in Achok, in Xiahe County. The new airport in Achok was approved by officials in 2009, but locals have expressed concerns because it is being built near a sacred mountain. Tibetans ransacked the Achok police station after the fatal shooting, and the riot police were called in to put down the unrest, the report said.

title: Crime, Sage Remarks and Brooklyn Heights
description: SKEPTICS have suggested that New Yorks two-decade decline in major crime simply reflects a national pattern. Franklin E. Zimring, a Berkeley Law criminologist, says theyre dead wrong.

title: What Happened to Baby Annie?
description: THE lives of Li Hangbin and Li Ying were intertwined nearly from the start.

title: Russia: Billionaire Claims Signatures to Challenge Putin for President
description: The billionaire businessman Mikhail D. Prokhorov said Friday that he had collected the two million signatures needed to compete in the March 4 presidential election. He plans to submit the documents to Russias Central Election Commission next week, according to the RIA Novosti news agency. Mr. Prokhorov, in an opinion article in The Guardian this week, called for evolution not revolution and said Russias era of managed democracy had ended. He has reportedly put about $12.5 million toward his campaign, more than any other candidate, but is considered unlikely to defeat Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Julie Andrews to Direct Mousical Based on Her Childrens Book
description: Julie Andrews will direct a new musical, The Great American Mousical, based on the childrens book of the same name co-written with her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton. Goodspeed Musicals will put on a developmental production of the show on its second stage, the Norma Terris Theater in Chester, Conn.,, from Nov. 8 to Dec. 2, theater leaders are scheduled to announce on Saturday afternoon.

title: Germany: A Bear Will Dream in Bronze
description: Plans are now set for Knut the polar bears memorial. The Berlin Zoo and the association of its supporters announced the winning design on Friday for a bronze statue of the world-famous bear who died last year. The design, Knut  The Dreamer by Josef Tabachnyk, was chosen out of more than 40 proposals and depicts the young polar bear in repose, head on paws, lying on a slab of granite. The $19,000 cost of the memorial is being financed through donations. Knut became a worldwide media sensation as a cub in 2007 after his mother rejected him and zookeepers decided to raise him.

title: Iran: Acclaimed Director Protest Shutdown of Cinema Guild
description: A critically acclaimed Iranian film director has written a letter to the Culture Ministry challenging its order to close the House of Cinema, Irans umbrella guild for cinema professionals and the only domestic organization that supports independent film. The ministrys order, which has been widely protested by many of the organizations members, threatens to effectively silence Irans last remaining autonomous forum for free expression in the visual arts. The director, Asghar Farhadi, whose movie A Separation is favored to win the top honors at the Golden Globe awards on Sunday, told Ministry officials in the letter that If the decision to dissolve the House of Cinema is based on the idea that the majority of the film community and members of the guild are in agreement with your method, then I suggest that you take a vote on this decision among the few thousand members of the House of Cinema. An excerpt of the letter was published by the Web site of Shargh, an Iranian reformist newspaper that has often been shut down by the government. Mr. Farhadis film, about the breakup of a family, has shattered box-office office records in Iran and won nearly three dozen awards. The Culture Ministrys order was supposed to take effect this week, and it remains unclear whether House of Cinemas management committee will seek a way to nullify it.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: Pity Blue Ivy Carter. Her very birth upset many New Yorkers amid reports that her parents, Beyonc and Jay-Z, had unleashed a small security army on the maternity ward at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, hassling other parents.

title: In Reversal, Gingrich Calls for Withdrawal of Film Attacking Romney and Bain
description: Misleading and exaggerated claims in a film portraying Mitt Romney as a heartless job killer led Newt Gingrich to ask on Friday that the group behind it change or withdraw it, even though Mr. Gingrich is the intended beneficiary of the film.

title: Venezuela Closes Consulate in Miami
description: President Hugo Chvez said Friday that he would close his countrys consulate in Miami after the expulsion by the State Department of Venezuelas consul general there. Mr. Chvez said that he did not intend to expel any United States diplomats in retaliation. The State Department expelled the consul general, Livia Acosta Noguera, after a televised report accused her of having taking part in discussions, during an earlier posting in Mexico, about possible cyberattacks against the United States. The political opposition immediately criticized the move, saying that thousands of Venezuelans used the Miami consulate to vote in Venezuelan elections and that the migr population there was overwhelmingly anti-Chvez. Mr. Chvez is running for re-election in a vote scheduled for October.

title: He Just Cant Turn In the Badge
description: CHARLIE MURELLO still carries his gun and badge, still wears a detectives sharp suit and tassel loafers, still keeps his dress blue uniform hanging in his closet at home.

title: Riding the Bulls
description: For the sixth straight year, the Professional Bull Riders kicked off their season in Madison Square Garden, and the cowboys, and their bulls, were well received.

title: Where Optimism Feels Out of Reach
description: So many of the civic successes heralded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in his annual State of the City address on Thursday  the expansion of the High Line, a new East River ferry service, the luring of Cornell University to Roosevelt Island, groundbreaking on a new Whitney Museum  might have happened in Lithuania for all the effect they have had (or could have) on the lives of people in Brownsville, in northeastern Brooklyn.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Indias Courts Grapple With Web Censorship
description: India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban The Satanic Verses by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivajis modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: An inquiry commission headed by a retired Supreme Court judge began a probe on Thursday, into the custodial death of Syed Mohammad Yousuf, a worker of the ruling state party, the National Conference. The commission has been asked to complete the inquiry within six weeks. The death of Mr. Yosuf in September had raised political controversy in the state (Kashmir Live).

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Salman Khan: Ormax Media, a leading research and consulting firm for the entertainment business released key findings of Front Page, their annual report on movies and television. One of the key features of the report is the list of the top 10 male and female stars in Bollywood. Using a star tracking methodology, data was collected through the year from a sample of more than 30,000 moviegoers. The star rankings threw up a few surprises. Among the heroes, Salman Khan was, of course, the top choice for 2011. This is hardly unexpected since he single-handedly propelled two mediocre films  Ready and Bodyguard  to blockbuster status. But the surprise was how far ahead he is of the competition. He has a 47 percent share, which almost equals that of Shah Rukh Khan (27 percent) and Aamir Khan (22 percent) combined.

title: Blast Kills Dozens of Shiite Worshipers in Southern Iraq
