description: BAGHDAD  Insurgents mounted another attack against Iraqs Shiites on Saturday, as an explosion in the southern city of Basra ripped through a group of pilgrims headed to a mosque to commemorate one of the holiest Shiite holidays.

title: President of Taiwan Is Re-elected, a Result That Is Likely to Please China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  President Ma Ying-jeou was re-elected by a comfortable margin on Saturday, fending off a challenge from his main rival, Tsai Ing-wen, who criticized his handling of the economy but also sought to exploit fears among voters that Mr. Mas conciliatory approach toward China was eroding the islands sovereignty.

title: Last of 6 Parts: Answers on the Fafsa, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid
description: In the sixth and final round of responses to student questions about financial aid, Mark Kantrowitz, founder of the Web sites FinAid.org and fastweb.com, addresses studying abroad and whether a student paying for college on his own can avoid listing his parents assets.

title: Giants and Packers Linked by Lombardi
description: The Giants and the Packers share a long history in the N.F.L. and one everlasting link: Vince Lombardi.

title: Nobel Laureate Drops Bid for Presidency of Egypt
description: CAIRO  Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel-Prize winning diplomat who helped galvanize the demands for democracy here, said on Saturday that he was dropping his presidential bid in protest over the militarys continued hold on power nearly a year after the ouster of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

title: Sundays Divisional Playoff Matchups: The Good and the Boring
description: Texans (11-6) at Ravens (12-4)Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Ravens by 7.5

title: Among Small-Business Advocates, Reaction to Presidents Plan Is Mixed
description: Advocates for small business  including those in Congress  had near uniformly mixed reactions to President Obamas proposal Friday to temporarily elevate the Small Business Administration to a cabinet agency but then fold the S.B.A. into a super trade and commerce department. Uniformly mixed in that most people The Agenda contacted praised the decision to make the S.B.A. part of the cabinet but expressed caution about the consolidation proposal.

title: As Divers Search Cruise Ship, Reason for Crash Is Unclear
description: ROME  As shaken survivors spoke of a mad crush to flee a sinking cruise ship off the Tuscan coast of Italy on Saturday, raising questions about the crews preparedness, Italian authorities arrested the ships captain amid concerns that the megaship had steered dangerously off course.

title: Running Back on Rise and Linebacker in Career Twilight Become Friends
description: He is not the stereotypical N.F.L. running back. Start with Arian Fosters first name, an abbreviated version of Aquarians, chosen by his father and meaning holder of knowledge. After Foster scores a touchdown, he eschews aggressive celebratory displays and places his hands together and bows, a gesture of respect in India, in his case to the game he plays.

title: As Critics Howled, a Coach Didnt Curse His Lot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The most divisive figure among Giants fans this season has round glasses and a perpetual smile, and opts to use a code word  instead of cursing  to let his players know he is angry.

title: Cruise Ship Runs Aground in Italy
description: Survivors from a luxury cruise ship that ran aground and tipped over, leaving at least three dead and 69 people still unaccounted for, described a chaotic evacuation.

title: Cruise Ship Runs Aground in Italy
description: Survivors from a luxury cruise ship that ran aground and tipped over, leaving at least three dead and 69 people still unaccounted for, described Saturday a chaotic evacuation.

title: Tim Tebow and David Bowie Become One
description: The fascination with Tim Tebow in our pop culture has been particularly evident in recent weeks on late-night comedy television shows. A few weeks ago, Tebow was visited by Jesus on Saturday Night Live. David Bowie fans will appreciate the latest spoof from Jimmy Fallon, who used Bowies 1969 classic, Space Oddity, to poke fun at Tebow on Thursday night.

title: Hit Me? Maybe Not At This Las Vegas Resort
description: Las Vegas has diversified in the past decade, becoming a destination for tourists interested in culture and dining as well as gambling. A new resort is hoping to tap into an even broader tourist market: gun enthusiasts.

title: Now Screening | Burberry Fall 2012 Mens Collection
description: The Fall 2012 mens collection from Burberry at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Giants Tackles Are Guts Behind the Ends Glory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants defensive line may be best described using the metaphor of a home: the tackles are the concrete foundation, important but largely unnoticed, and the ends are the finished exterior, which is what typically draws attention.

title: No. 1 Everywhere but the Slam Events
description: PERTH, Australia  Caroline Wozniacki is hardly an anomaly.

title: China Forces Are Reported to Have Shot at Tibetans
description: BEIJING  Chinese security forces on Saturday fired into a crowd of Tibetans in a restive area of Sichuan Province after they tried to take away the body of a Tibetan man who had died after setting himself on fire that morning to protest Chinese policies in the Tibetan areas, according to reports from two Tibet advocacy groups and Tibetan officials in the exile government in India.

title: For Kudla, a Quick Qualification in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Before he could battle his own way through the qualifying draw of the 2012 Australian Open, the 19-year-old Denis Kudla needed some help from the rest of the field.

title: New President of Penn State Endures a Week Under Fire
description: Standing in a hotel ballroom packed with Penn State alumni Friday night, David Roush directed two rapier-sharp questions at the universitys new president, Rodney A. Erickson, that seemed to encapsulate the crowds simmering frustration over how the firing of the football coach Joe Paterno was handled.

title: S&P On Europe
description: S&Ps downgrade of a bunch of European sovereigns was no surprise. What was somewhat surprising  and which went unmentioned in almost all the news stories Ive read  was why S&P has gotten so pessimistic. From their FAQs:

title: Reams View at Old Trafford
description: Red Bulls defender (for now at least) Tim Ream was at Old Trafford on Saturday to take in Boltons Premier League match against Manchester United, a 3-0 victory for the Red Devils..

title: St. Johns Fights to Pass Course in Improvisation
description: Steve Lavin watched St. Johns defeat Cincinnati, 57-55, last Saturday from his SoHo apartment in Manhattan, sending text messages to his assistants and coaching his team from the couch as best he could.

title: Robsons Popularity Outpaces Ranking
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Although there was only room for eight chairs, at least 18 reporters had crammed into the closet-sized Interview Room 1 to talk to 17-year old Laura Robson of Britain.

title: Players to Watch: Six With Games Suited for Success
description: Geoff Macdonald, the womens tennis coach at Vanderbilt University, will provide analysis of the Australian Open throughout the next two weeks on this blog.

title: Things Were Supposed To Be Quiet About
description: Apologists for rising inequality often argue that since most Americans income has risen despite rising inequality, theres no reason to complain about inequality other than envy. So its worth remembering that we used to expect economic growth to deliver large increases in real income, not just a bit of a rise thats accomplished in large part through longer working hours; and that a major reason so many have seen such small gains is that a large part of growth has been siphoned off to the very high end.

title: Variety: A Dusty Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  The author of todays quote was one of the pre-eminent writers during the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920s and 30s. Her books, short stories, plays and essays heavily influenced many of the heavy hitters in literature, such as Alice Walker, Toni Morrison, Ralph Ellison and more.

title: Emlen Tunnell: The Giants Greatest Packer
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Emlen Tunnell, a star defender for the glittering, magnetic Giants, had been summoned to Green Bay. It was 1959, and the new Packers coach, Vince Lombardi, traded for Tunnell, ending his run of 11 record-setting seasons in New York.

title: Romney-Obama: No Popularity Contest
description: If Mitt Romney becomes the Republican presidential nominee, he will begin the general-election campaign with middling favorability ratings as compared with other recent standard-bearers.

title: Unit of Chinese Daily Plans I.P.O.
description: SHANGHAI  The online division of the Peoples Daily, the official mouthpiece of the Communist Party, won approval on Friday to go ahead with an initial public offering of stock.

title: Reaching the Summit of Kilimanjaro
description: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, climbed Mount Kilimanjaro to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts have appeared occasionally in Bats.

title: Bargaining for a Childs Love
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: In Pakistan, Talks Aim to Ease Split
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans civilian and military leaders met Saturday for the first time since the eruption of a bitter political and legal controversy that stoked rumors of a military coup and could still topple the precariously weak civilian government.

title: Zimbabwes Unsavory Path to Peace
description: ZIMBABWE is fast approaching a dangerous tipping point. Last month, its ailing octogenarian president, Robert Mugabe, angrily defied his critics, calling for early elections in 2012. If a political settlement with Zimbabwes security chiefs is not negotiated before the vote, Mr. Mugabe will no doubt rely on them to once again begin a campaign of intimidation and violence, leading to sham elections that could precipitate a regional crisis.

title: Traffic Jams With Eastwood and Pitt, Scorsese and Weinstein
description: LOS ANGELES  Aside from congratulations, this is my favorite event was probably the phrase heard the most often at Fridays American Film Institute luncheon on Friday. The annual program announces its winners for TV and film in advance  this year they included Bridesmaids, War Horse, The Tree of Life, Moneyball, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, The Descendants, Hugo, The Help, J. Edgar, The Artist and Midnight in Paris  and presents them all with prizes, no speechifying necessary. Instead, everybody schmoozes, lunches and watches clip reels. And because the honorees come from TV and film, there are double the opportunities for stars to rub shoulders.

title: Busy, Pain-Filled Comeback Pays Off as Keflezighi Wins to Make U.S. Team
description: HOUSTON  This time, Meb Keflezighi kept his breathing strip where it belonged  on his nose.

title: History vs. the Tea Party
description: FOR more than two years, conservatives have been riding a wave of Tea Party insurgency that has formed the most dynamic force in American politics, a protest movement that promised to slash taxes, close the federal deficit and remake Washington. And yet to judge from the results of the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, some of the most engaged Republican voters are inching closer to nominating Mitt Romney, the candidate they like least, a Harvard-educated technocrat who is in many ways a mirror image of the president the insurgents want to dislodge.

title: Despite Uproar Over Clemency, Barbour Finds Lucrative Nest
description: JACKSON, Miss.  But who will pardon the governor?

title: The Empires Strike Back
description: AS Egyptians and Tunisians vote to replace ousted despots and the Syrian government teeters on the brink, two old imperial powers are competing to exert their political influence over Arab countries in upheaval. And they are not America and Russia. After years of cold-war competition over the Middle East and North Africa, it is now France and Turkey that are vying for lucrative business ties and the chance to mold a new generation of leaders in lands that they once controlled.

title: Cruise Ship Runs Aground
description: At least three people are reported dead after a luxury liner tips over near the coast of Tuscany, Italy. (Courtesy of Reuters)

title: What They Dont Want to Talk About
description: Ever since Newt Gingrich and Rick Perry started criticizing Mitt Romneys actions at Bain Capital  and talking about the thousands of people laid off as a result of Bains investments  party leaders have essentially told them to shut up. That response is a pretty good indication of how deeply party elders fear the issue of economic inequality in the campaign to come.

title: Rights in the Workplace
description: As a condition of getting and keeping their jobs, millions of employees in the United States have signed agreements to take any disputes with their employers to arbitration rather than court. Typically, the agreements also prohibit the arbitrator from consolidating similar claims.

title: Good Immigration Policy, on Hold
description: Last summer the Obama administration announced an overdue change in the way it catches and deports illegal immigrants. The head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, John Morton, said the agency would focus more heavily on deporting convicted criminals and other high-risk offenders, making noncriminals a lower priority.

title: The Whirling Sound of Planet Dickens
description: In death, Charles Dickens still keeps his greatest secret to himself  the essence of his energy. None of the physical relics he left behind betray it. The manuscripts of his novels  like Our Mutual Friend at the Morgan Library  look no more fevered or hectic than the manuscripts left behind by other novelists.

title: Dueling Parties Before the Globes
description: LOS ANGELES  The Baggers whirlwind pre-Golden Globes party schedule on Friday night included stops at the Paramount lot and the roof of the Chateau Marmont, the perennial Hollywood hot spot. Attendance at both by Oscar hopefuls was a bit light  they were all at the Los Angeles Film Critics Association awards presentation.

title: Mitts Big Love
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.

title: Getting to Know You ...
description: Cairo

title: The Benefits of Bain Capitalism
description: THE debate over Mitt Romneys career at Bain Capital, in which several of his Republican rivals sound as if theyre auditioning for a production of Les Misrables, is at heart a debate about the last 30 years of American capitalism.

title: Unlocking the Secrets Behind Hydraulic Fracturing
description: Starting Feb. 1, drilling operators in Texas will have to report many of the chemicals used in the process known as hydraulic fracturing. Environmentalists and landowners are looking forward to learning what acids, hydroxides and other materials have gone into a given well.

title: Are We Really Monolingual?
description: AMERICANS are often told that in todays globalized world, we are at a competitive disadvantage because of our lazy monolingualism. For too long, Americans have relied on other countries to speak our language, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan said at the Foreign Language Summit in 2010. But we wont be able to do that in the increasingly complex and interconnected world.

title: Fruit Flies and Love
description: WHATS the quickest way to a mans heart? No, not through the chest wall with a knife.

title: Why Is Europe a Dirty Word?
description: PARIS

title: Sunday Dialogue: Mobility and Inequality in Todays America
description: Readers discuss how to reinvigorate the American promise that anyone can rise to success.

title: Richard Branson
description: Richard Branson is the leonine founder and chief executive of the Virgin Group, a conglomerate of more than 300 companies with 43,000 employees and global revenues reportedly of $21 billion. A dyslexic who dropped out of high school, Mr. Branson is known for making bold bets in travel (including space travel), telecommunications, health care and entertainment. He is also involved in several philanthropic ventures.

title: For Romney, Attacks on Bain Career Have Upside
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  Mitt Romney has spent days defending himself against accusations that he was a job-killing vulture capitalist.

title: Rivals on Ice
description: A preview in photographs of Sundays Michigan-Ohio State hockey game, which will be played outdoors at Progressive Field in Cleveland.

title: For Michigan and Ohio State, Hockey in the Image of Football
description: CLEVELAND  Even in snowy conditions, the helmets  Ohio States gray with a scarlet stripe, and Michigans blue with maize wings  will be recognizable. The Game, as matchups between these universities are known, will be played not on a football field but on an ice rink built over a baseball diamond.

title: Considering the Bulls and Their Point Guard
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Never Bet on a Bird in the Playoffs
description: In dissecting first-round playoff losses by the Bengals, the Lions and the Falcons, the N.F.L. analysts missed the key to the N.F.L. postseason. I learned it two years ago while staring into the comfortless swill at the bottom of my pint in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: The Great Wall
description: On the first Friday night of each month, a large wall of an Oakland office complex morphs into an outdoor theater. A projector on a nearby rooftop shows videos a hundred feet tall on the exterior of a building at the corner of West Grand and Valley Street. The spectators  most of whom also attend the monthly event called Art Murmur in nearby galleries  stand or perch on the curb to watch the show.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Running From Millions
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.

title: N.H.L.s Best at the Seasons Halfway Mark
description: In the days of the Original Six, the N.H.L. conducted two votes annually on major awards for individual players. The end-of-season winner was awarded the trophy and a bonus, and the midseason winner received a bonus, albeit a smaller one.

title: Foreclosure Auctions Show Raw Form of Capitalism
description: PHOENIX  To the unknowing, the few dozen people milling around the picnic tables in front of the Maricopa County courthouse here every day could be jurors on break or scofflaws finally coming to pay a ticket. They tug on cigarettes, sip from big cups of coffee and fidget with their cellphones, often speaking in whispers.

title: Sometimes, You Need to Blow the Fuses
description: This interview with  Bill Kling, founder and president emeritus of the American Public Media Group, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Man Held as a Fourth Homeless Man Is Found Dead
description: LOS ANGELESA possible serial killer has been arrested in Orange County following the Friday night stabbing death of homeless man in Anaheimthe fourth killing of a homeless man in Orange County over the past month.

title: Whats Race Got to Do With It?
description: Mitt Romney may not have officially clinched the Republican nomination, but his victory has never really been in doubt. Nor has his viability in November: the most fanatical Tea Partiers are not about to withhold their votes and risk allowing President Obama to be re-elected.

title: The Image Officer With a Lot to Fix
description: ITS show time for Anne M. Finucane.

title: Digitizing Health Records, Before It Was Cool
description: VERONA, Wis.

title: Its Still the Age of Anxiety. Or Is It?
Secrets of a Sales Machine
description: BACK in 1940, a popular book about Wall Street asked, Where are the customers yachts? Investment firms, it lamented, always seemed to win, even when their customers lost.

title: Letters: Governments Need a Culture Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Deal From Depth in Their Prospects
description: So this is why the Yankees stockpiled so many catchers in their farm system. Teams need only one starting catcher, after all. Yet on the Baseball America list of the Yankees top 10 prospects, they had four catchers  and only two pitchers.

title: Evangelicals, Seeking Unity, Back Santorum for Nomination
description: BRENHAM, Tex.  Evangelical leaders pursued a last-ditch effort on Saturday to exert influence in the Republican presidential primary race, voting to support the candidacy of Rick Santorum in hopes of undercutting Mitt Romneys march to the nomination.

title: European Leaders Use Debt Downgrades to Argue for Austerity, and for Stimulus
description: FRANKFURT  European leaders sought to limit damage from a ratings agencys downgrade of nine countries on Friday, or even turn the news to their advantage, saying that it showed the need to impose more austerity or else do more to stimulate growth.

title: What Percent Are You?
description: See how your household income ranks in 344 zones across the United States.

title: Dear Starbucks: A Penny for Your Thoughts
description: STRONG coffee gets me out of bed in the morning. I start gulping it at home, and after a train ride into Penn Station I usually stop at a Starbucks in Times Square for another jolt.

title: Countrywide V.I.P. Loans Linked to 2 Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON  Two longtime Republican congressmen have acknowledged that their names appeared on a list of House members who received special loans through a Countrywide Financial program that set off a Congressional inquiry into whether the disgraced mortgage firm granted special treatment to politically connected clients.

title: Yankees Finally Make an Off-Season Splash
description: If you thought things were way too quiet these past few months in the Bronx, you were right.

title: Spend, Spend, Spend. Its the American Way.
description: GRIDLOCK in Congress implies that there wont be any collective decision to spend more as a nation to get out of our slump. Increases in deficit spending seem unlikely, and so does the balanced-budget stimulus Ive been advocating in this column. For now, we must pin our hopes for a robust recovery on the willingness of millions of consumers to spend substantially more.

title: SAPs In-Memory Computing Catches On
description: SAP is based in Europe, which is supposed to be on the verge of a recession. So what accounts for its strong showing in the most recent quarter?

title: Once Hidden by Forest, Carvings in Land Attest to Amazons Lost World
description: RIO BRANCO, Brazil  Edmar Arajo still remembers the awe.

title: Wrapping Up in New Hampshire, Then Moving South
description: The Republican candidates finished campaigning in New Hampshire, where Mitt Romney received the most votes, and took their outfits to South Carolina, whose primary is Jan. 21.

title: When Youre the Worker Who Cant Say No
description: Q. Your plate at work is full, but your boss has asked you to take on yet another assignment. You say yes even though you know you dont have time for it. Why?

title: Cultural Matchmaking
description: MY family traveled the United States when my four siblings and I were young. My parents would give us history lessons about the places we visited, which fostered my love of travel and learning about other places.

title: An Election in Kazakhstan Will Offer Something New: A Multiparty System
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  This capital city has been abuzz for weeks with the latest political news: Soon there will be politics. After an election scheduled for Sunday, Kazakhstans Parliament will be guaranteed, under a new law, to consist of more than one political party.

title: The Caucus Click: Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from New Hampshire to South Carolina.  Go to the slide show.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 15
description: Heading into the South Carolina primary next week, Mitt Romney already has victories in Iowa and New Hampshire. Three of his opponents  plus one Comedy Central television host  join the Sunday talk shows to discuss their strategies for the South Carolina campaign.

title: A Wireless Road Around Data Traffic Jams
description: THE vast data centers that process information for the Facebooks and Amazons of the Web work at a brisk clip. But even so, they cant always keep up.

title: The Theological Differences Behind Evangelical Unease With Romney
description: The Rev. R. Philip Roberts, the president of a Southern Baptist seminary in Kansas City, Mo., is an evangelist with a particular goal: countering Mormon beliefs.

title: Backing of Evangelicals Could Resuscitate Santorum in South Carolina
description: Polling in the early stages of the nomination race can be extremely fluid, but ordinarily a candidate who is in fourth place with a week to go would have little chance of winning a state primary. This is why the FiveThirtyEight forecast model is skeptical about Rick Santorums chances of winning South Carolina, where his numbers have slumped since his near-victory in Iowa on Jan 3.

title: Joel J. Tyler, Judge Who Pronounced Deep Throat Obscene, Dies at 90
description: Joel J. Tyler, who as a Manhattan judge ruled, in a particularly explicit and colorful opinion, that the pornographic film Deep Throat was obscene and that the New York City theaters showing it were breaking the law, inadvertently helping it become perhaps the most popular X-rated movie of all time, died in Yonkers on Nov. 9. He was 90.

title: Californias Reputation Grows With New Events
description: It is not surprising that California is a center of chess in the United States. But in the last couple of years, there has been a burst of activity there, with a large number of international tournaments that have given players a chance to qualify for grandmaster and international master titles. Two groups are behind those events.

title: Sunday: Weather Report
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Everyone have their umbrellas out? Youre going to need one for todays delightful puzzle by the Columbia University student Finn Vigeland. The only warning I would give you is that these drops are likely to be a bit heavier than usual, so make sure that umbrella is reinforced. Concrete would probably be good.

title: Romney Offers Praise for a Donors Business
description: WASHINGTON  At a town-hall-style meeting in New Hampshire last month, listeners pressed Mitt Romney on the soaring cost of higher education. His solution: students should consider for-profit colleges like the little-known Full Sail University in Florida.

title: Frederica Sagor Maas, Silent-Era Scriptwriter, Dies at 111
description: She told of Hollywood moguls chasing naked would-be starlets, the women shrieking with laughter. She recounted how Joan Crawford, new to the movies, relied on her to pick clothes. Almost obsessively, she complained about how many of her story ideas and scripts were stolen and credited to others.

title: Among the Wealthiest 1 Percent, Many Variations
description: KINGS POINT, N.Y.  Adam Katz is happy to talk to reporters when he is promoting his business, a charter flight company based on Long Island called Talon Air.

title: Boehner Faces a Restive G.O.P. and New White House Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  For Speaker John A. Boehner and House Republicans, returning to the Capitol this week could have the awkward feeling of a couple waking up after a night of fighting.

title: A Winter Wonderland, No Matter What
description: Vail Mountain Ski Resort in Colorado, like so many others resorts in the United States, has been dealing with a smaller snowpack this winter.

title: In Defense of Europe
description: My Sunday column looks at the torrent of Republican accusations that President Obama is trying to the turn the U.S. into Europe. And basically I argue that that wouldnt be the worst fate.

title: In Israel, a Clash Between the Secular and Ultra-Orthodox
description: Israelis are turning inward and discovering that an issue they had neglected  the place of the ultra-Orthodox Jews  has erupted into a crisis.

title: Israelis Facing a Seismic Rift Over Role of Women
description: JERUSALEM  In the three months since the Israeli Health Ministry awarded a prize to a pediatrics professor for her book on hereditary diseases common to Jews, her experience at the awards ceremony has become a rallying cry.

title: At 20, Surviving Battle With Cancer on His Own
description: Michael Mercado, 20, has made a bargain with fate. He would finish school and find a good job working on cars if only, he says, the cancer stays away.

title: Final: Patriots 45, Broncos 10
description: Tom Brady tied a playoff record by throwing six touchdown passes Saturday night  including five in a dominant first half  and the New England Patriots pummeled the Denver Broncos, 45-10, in an A.F.C. divisional round playoff game at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass.

title: Fear of Civil War Mounts in Syria as Crisis Deepens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The failure of an Arab League mission to stanch violence in Syria, an international community with little leverage and a government as defiant as its opposition is in disarray have left Syria descending into a protracted, chaotic and perhaps unnegotiable conflict.

title: Putting Pieces Together in Decades-Old Cases
description: Mark Norwood will be led into a Georgetown courtroom Wednesday to face capital murder charges for a killing that took place more than 25 years ago.

title: Shopping Center Wars Mobilize Preservationists
description: Mimi Swartz wrote this column for Texasmonthly.com.

title: For Ted Cruz, a Biography Built to Let Voters Fill in the Details (Favorably)
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: A Push to Bar Lobbying Work by Lawmakers
description: Lobbying by Illinois lawmakers would be barred under a bill proposed by the Legislatures inspector general, who monitors ethical conduct by state representatives and senators.

title: My Head, Double-Talking
description: Just a heads up  Ill be on both Fareed Zakaria (talking with Ken Rogoff) and This Week (from New York! Yay!) tomorrow.

title: A Lifetime of Close Ties and Growing Influence
description: In Rahm Emanuels first public appearance after resigning as White House chief of staff in October 2010, he showed up in the Pilsen neighborhood accompanied by Juan Rangel, the community activist. Mr. Emanuel and Mr. Rangel had spoken for the first time only days earlier, yet Mr. Rangel soon would become a co-chairman of Mr. Emanuels successful bid for mayor.

title: Auto Industry May Want to Look at That Luxury-Car Plan Again
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Harris Out on a Limb on Mortgage Settlement
description: Four years ago, when most of the Democratic Party establishment stood firmly behind Hillary Rodham Clinton, Kamala D. Harris, then San Franciscos district attorney, spent a winter week in Iowa stumping for Barack Obama.

title: Facing Last Call, Fans Rally for a Storied Saloon
description: With its plush red couches, faux gold-leaf covered walls and $3.50 glasses of sparkling wine, the dimly lit Gold Dust Lounge is a holdout of old San Francisco in the midst of the upscale shopping district on Union Square.

title: California Leads Nation in Unaccredited Schools, and Enforcement Is Lax
description: Dibyendu Malakar needed a graduate business degree to advance his career, but he was working full time and could not afford $100,000 or more for a two-year M.B.A. program at Berkeley, Stanford or another accredited business school. So Mr. Malakar enrolled at Frederick Taylor University, an unaccredited school in Moraga.

title: Where the Italian Cruise Ship Ran Aground
description: A preliminary account of the final moments of the luxury cruise ship Costa Concordia, according to the Coast Guard.

title: Eight Men In: The Road Trip to Lambeau Takes Off
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men  they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee  have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

title: White House Says It Opposes Parts of Two Antipiracy Bills
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Saturday that it strongly opposed central elements of two Congressional efforts to enforce copyrights on the Internet, all but killing the current versions of legislation that has divided both political parties and pitted Hollywood against Silicon Valley.

title: Paterno Describes His Uncertainty Over Allegation
description: Joe Paterno, who was fired as Penn States football coach on Nov. 9 in the wake of allegations that his former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky had sexually abused boys, said in an interview published Saturday that he reported a suspected assault in 2002 to his superiors because he was unsure how to handle the matter.

title: Track Star Will Return to Olympics in Marathon
description: HOUSTON  After a slow, tactical start, the United States womens Olympic marathon trials began at 20 miles to distill itself to the three eventual qualifiers for the 2012 London Games: Shalane Flanagan (2 hours 25 minutes 38 seconds), Desiree Davila (2:25:55) and Kara Goucher (2:26:06).

title: Just Like in the Glory Days, 49ers Seize the Moment in the Playoffs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Like any 49ers team, this one cannot escape comparisons to the dynastic San Francisco teams of a generation ago. As if trying to fully recapture their gloried past, the 49ers had the 1980s pop icons Huey Lewis and the News sing the national anthem before Saturdays playoff game. A handwritten sign above the last row of seats of dilapidating Candlestick Park read, Were back! The sentiment in the Bay Area in the days before the game was that the resurrection went unnoticed by anyone east of the Sierra Nevada.

title: Defense, of All Things, Carries 49ers Just Far Enough
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The hit that changed momentum, that left New Orleans running back Pierre Thomas crumpled on the field, that made the Saints think twice when they ventured across the middle, came early into the first quarter Saturday afternoon.

title: Palestinian Authority Leaders Talk With Israel and Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian Authority leaders pursued dual tracks of reconciliation on Saturday, holding meetings both with Israeli negotiators in Jordan and with Hamas leaders in Gaza. The talks with the Israelis went late into the evening. The Gaza negotiations yielded some results.

title: Romney Gives Cash to Woman in Need
description: SUMTER, S.C.  After a campaign event here on Saturday, a woman told Mitt Romney that she was jobless and broke. In response, Mr. Romney reached into his pocket and handed cash to the woman, Ruth Williams, 55, of Columbia.

title: Midnight in Paris Gets a Globe Nod but Not a Seat for Hemingway
description: LOS ANGELES  You might think that being a star, writer or director of a Golden Globe-nominated movie automatically means you get a seat to the big show on Sunday. Nope.

title: Corrections: January 15
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
Concerned About Offense, Knicks See Defense Falter in a Demoralizing Defeat
description: OKLAHOMA CITY As many as 31 points separated the Oklahoma City Thunder from the Knicks on Saturday night, but the gap between them could be measured in so many vivid ways: in talent, depth, athleticism, chemistry or cohesion.

title: Smith, for Once, Is a Reason for San Franciscos Victory
description: San Francisco

title: Employee Is Stabbed to Death at a Cellphone Store in Brooklyn
description: An employee at a Sprint cellphone store in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was stabbed to death while working on Saturday afternoon after a dispute with a man who might have been a former Sprint employee, the police said.

title: With Spotlight on Tebow, Brady Stars
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  This season, and most especially in the days leading up to the New England Patriots playoff game against the Denver Broncos, Tim Tebow  the off-speed passer, the media phenomenon, the cultural touchstone  was at the center of an extraordinary, endless-loop conversation, about the nature of offensive football and, to the consternation of many, the convergence of sports and religion.

title: Into the Heart of Lightness
description: THE artist Doug Wheeler tells two stories, both having to do with light, that go a long way toward explaining why he is so revered by many fellow artists  as a visionary and a relentlessly stubborn perfectionist  and also why his work has been seen by so few American artgoers over the last few decades, particularly those in New York.

title: Ksenia Yachmetz and Bruno Nouril
description: Ksenia Anastasia Yachmetz and Bruno Howard Frederick Nouril were married Saturday at St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Bernard Panczuk, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony with Msgr. Kevin J. Nelan, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Bonnie Cole, Jonathan Salant
description: Bonnie Sue Cole and Jonathan David Salant are to be married Sunday at Bnai Israel Congregation in Rockville, Md. Rabbi Jonathan Schnitzer is to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Taxin and Craig Nemiroff
description: Elizabeth Jill Taxin and Craig Matthew Nemiroff were married Saturday evening at the Jumeirah Essex House Hotel in New York. Rabbi James Prosnit officiated.

title: Narda-Marie Newby and Malik Edwards
description: Narda-Marie Meiling Newby and Malik Kenyatta Edwards were married Saturday evening at the J. W. Marriott hotel in Washington by Annice M. Wagner, a senior judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

title: Sully Bonnelly and Robert Littman
description: Sully Osvaldo Bonnelly and Robert Roos Littman are to be married Sunday afternoon at the home of their friends Ellen Taubman and William S. Taubman in New York. John B. Koegel, another friend of the couple, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Anne Fleming and William Wright
description: Anne Wright Fleming, a daughter of Susan R. Fleming and Robert J. Fleming of Philadelphia, was married Saturday evening to William Stephen Wright, a son of Lauri S. Wright and Michael C. Wright of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Mark. R. Collins performed the ceremony at Christ & St. Stephens Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Jennifer Schlein, Derek Baumgarten
description: Jennifer Lynn Schlein and Derek Michael Baumgarten were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony. The Rev. Timothy Shugrue, another Roman Catholic priest, also took part.

title: Morgan Landau, Joshua Klein
description: Morgan Alyssa Landau and Joshua Seth Klein were married by Rabbi Elliot J. Cosgrove Saturday night at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York.

title: Regan Heysek, Scott Johnson
description: Regan Reddy Heysek and Dr. Scott Stuart Johnson were married Saturday evening at the Monterey Plaza Hotel and Spa in Monterey, Calif. Brian Hewitt, a friend of the couple who was named a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Sacramento County, officiated.

title: Linda Theung and Aleksander Tamm-Seitz
description: Linda Chou Theung and Aleksander Tamm-Seitz were married Saturday evening at the Fifth Floor, an event space at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Jason A. Wilcox, the brother-in-law of the bridegroom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Rebecca Marcus, Christopher Wheeler Jr.
description: Rebecca Lauren Marcus and Christopher Clark Wheeler Jr. were married Saturday at the Cheeca Lodge and Spa in Islamorada, Fla. Rabbi Brett Goldstein officiated.

title: Russell Plato, Joel Nolan
description: Russell Patrick Plato and Joel Monteith Nolan were married Saturday at Turner Hill Mansion on the Turner Hill Golf Club in Ipswich, Mass. Judge Peter W. Hall of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Rutland, Vt., for whom Mr. Plato was a law clerk, officiated.

title: Tamara Vostok, John Krasting
description: Tamara Vostok and John Paul Krasting were married Saturday at SS. Peter and Paul Russian Orthodox Church in South River, N.J. The Rev. David F. Garretson, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Jillian Feldman, P. J. Moriarty
description: Jillian Mara Feldman and Patrick Joseph Moriarty were married Saturday at the downtown location of Alger House, an event space in New York. The Rev. David L. James, a minister of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Sylvia Mohen, Jeffrey Gower
description: Dr. Sylvia Anna Mohen and Jeffrey Bryan Gower were married Saturday at the Carimar Beach Club in Meads Bay, Anguilla. The Rev. John A. Gumbs, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Liner Captain Is Questioned in Capsizing Off Italy Coast
description: GIGLIO, Italy  The captain of the cruise ship that capsized aground near an Italian island, killing at least five people, may have caused the accident by taking the ship too close to the islands rocky shore, the owner of the vessel said on Sunday, as rescue workers extracted three survivors and two bodies from the wreck.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: In an analysis of the comparative strengths of political parties in Uttar Pradesh, Outlook magazine finds that no clear majority emerges and predicts that the state elections scheduled for February may end in a hung verdict. In 2012, the most interesting candidate Faizabad has thrown up is a kinnar (eunuch) who plans to contest as an independent, the piece observes about the election constituency, which has been a political stronghold over the past several decades. Despite the eunuchs being a marginalized community, a local trader said, a hijra is better than all of these useless parties, suggesting a sense of despair about the current crop of political candidates.

title: Tim Tebows Postgame Comments, and Unclear Future
description: Because Tim Tebow has transcended football, he has steadily gained casual fans and many who are barely familiar with the game. These two categories of fans may not be aware that his long-term future as a starting quarterback with the Denver Broncos is far from secure.

title: Why Did Tom Brady Punt Late in the Game?
description: In their 45-10 rout of the Broncos on Saturday night, the Patriots didnt pull Tom Brady late in the fourth quarter.

title: Bain The Betrayer
description: William Cohan has an interesting take on Mitt Romney, which is completely distinct from the policy and left/right issues. According to Cohan, who did deals with Bain during the Romney years, the company specialized in dirty tricks.

title: Republican Candidates: Drop Out? Who, Me?
description: Mitt Romneys biggest asset as he tries to wrap up the 2012 Republican presidential nomination may be the egos of his rivals.

title: Mad Men Season Premiere Is Set for March 25
description: Jon Hamm has been a bad boy, and not just in his scenes in Bridesmaids. A few days ago Mr. Hamm let it slip in a podcast interview that the long-awaited season premiere of Mad Men, the AMC period drama on which he plays the advertising executive Don Draper, would be shown on March 25. Though a few days of radio silence from the network followed Mr. Hamm can now wipe those beads of sweat from his Brylcreemed brow: AMC has confirmed the news, announcing over the weekend that Season 5 of Mad Men would begin on that date, with a two-hour episode written by the series creator, Matthew Weiner, and directed by Jennifer Getzinger, who directed the episode The Suitcase last season.

title: A Score of Ways to Serenade a City
description: The Five Boroughs Music Festival began in 2007 with the idea of presenting concerts all over New York. The festival has no preconceptions about genre: its offerings have included folk music, early music and art song. To celebrate its fifth anniversary the festival commissioned 20 composers to write songs about the city for one to four voices, using texts of their choice (several wrote their own). The resulting Five Borough Songbook had its premiere at Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn three months ago and made its way to Manhattan on Thursday, to the Baruch Performing Arts Center.

title: As French Vote Nears, Sarkozy Is Haunted by Grim Economy

description: I have a bone to pick with you, Meryl Streep said to the Bagger. That sound you dont hear is our heart stopping just a little.

title: A New Law Firm With 161 Years of Experience
description: Norman Siegel and Herbert Teitelbaum were classmates at New York University law school. Mr. Siegel is married to Saralee Evans, a former acting State Supreme Court justice. Their wedding ceremony was performed by Emily Jane Goodman, a Supreme Court justice. They all come from Brooklyn. Collectively, they have 161 years of legal experience and a record of impact in and out of court. And now, when most of their contemporaries are contemplating retirement or have already quit, the four of them are starting a new law firm.

title: The Great Gatsby Curve
description: Alan Krueger, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers  who is not only a colleague of mine at Princeton, but gets a lot of my mail and vice versa  gave a very informative speech on inequality last week that should have received more press than it did. Much of it was stuff that inequality mavens already know, but he had one striking result that was what I suspected but hadnt seen demonstrated: a clear negative relationship between inequality at a point in time and intergenerational social mobility.

title: But The Top 0.1 Percent Isnt Diverse
description: The Times has a piece today showing, correctly, that the top 1 percent of the income distribution is a fairly diverse group. But what that mainly reflects is the fact that the slogan we are the 99 percent sets the cut too low. A large part of the rising share of the top 1  about 60 percent, according to the Piketty-Saez data  is actually attributable to the top 0.1 percent. And thats not a diverse group at all, according to Heim et al (pdf):

title: Eight Men In: A Night in Milwaukee
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men  they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee  have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

title: The Reflected Lights and Shadows of Californias 1970s Troubadours
description: Too many stories, too many heartbreak songs/ Where nobodys right, nobodys wrong, go the words to Faithless Love, the aching country-rock ballad popularized by Linda Ronstadt 38 years ago in a memorable duet with its composer, J. D. Souther. On Friday evening Mr. Souther sang a solo rendition of Faithless Love at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series. With its plaintive winding melody and lyrics that picture an endless river of romantic sorrow, the song conjures the darker side of Southern California hedonism during the long-gone heyday of the Laurel Canyon troubadours.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Producer Price Index for December, and industrial production and capacity utilization for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for December, housing starts for December, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for January (Thursday); and existing home sales for December (Friday).

title: Do Thrifty Brains Make Better Minds?
description: Might the miserly use of neural resources be one of the essential keys to understanding how brains make sense of the world? Some recent work in computational and cognitive neuroscience suggests that it is indeed the frugal use of our native neural capacity (the inventive use of restricted neural bandwidth, if you will) that explains how brains like ours so elegantly make sense of noisy and ambiguous sensory input. That same story suggests, intriguingly, that perception, understanding and imagination, which we might intuitively consider to be three distinct chunks of our mental machinery, are inextricably tied together as simultaneous results of a single underlying strategy known as predictive coding. This strategy saves on bandwidth using (who would have guessed it?) one of the many technical wheezes that enable us to economically store and transmit pictures, sounds and videos using formats such as JPEG and MP3.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday. The stock and bond markets are closed Monday in observance of the Martin Luther Kings Birthday holiday.

title: A Typical Ravens Success: With Grit and Without Fear
description: BALTIMORE  As television cameras and recorders descended on him in the Baltimore Ravens locker room late Sunday afternoon, Terrell Suggs tucked in his dress shirt, slipped into a vest and slid on his watch. Turning around to face reporters, Suggs instead found Ray Lewis waiting to fix his collar, which had stood up.

title: ABC Kills Work It
description: The critically panned cross-dressing comedy Work It has been canceled by ABC after only two episodes. Repeats of the Tim Allen comedy Last Man Standing will run in its place starting Tuesday. Work It featured two unemployed men who tried dressing as women to get jobs. It was criticized ahead of its premiere by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation and the Human Rights Campaign, which said in a joint statement that by encouraging the audience to laugh at the characters attempts at womanhood, the show gives license to similar treatment of transgender women. The show was poorly received by viewers in early January. Days before the schedule change was made public, Paul Lee, the president of ABC Entertainment, defended the show to TV reporters by saying, We thought there was room for a very, very, very silly show. ABC has not said what show will succeed Work It in the time slot on Tuesday at 8:30 p.m., but it may go to the returning sitcom Cougar Town, which has yet to be assigned a spot this season.

title: Ricky Gervais, the Host With the Most (Friends in on the Joke)
description: More than a few eyebrows were raised when the Hollywood Foreign Press Association invited Ricky Gervais back to host the Golden Globes tonight. You may remember the kerfuffle that resulted the last time he emceed ceremonies and offended a few celebrities in the room. Or maybe they werent entirely offended, as our colleague Dave Itzkoff writes in his profile of the comedian. He adds that Mr. Gervais has become the entertainment industrys favorite irreverent person, because he manages to be irreverent in such a deeply reverent way.

title: The Ives Songbook, Without Interruption
description: I think there must be a place in the soul all made of tunes, of tunes of long ago, Charles Ives wrote in The Things Our Fathers Loved. He set that poem to music as the 43rd entry in 114 Songs, the collection he published in 1922, which was performed in a four-hour marathon on Saturday by the young, ambitious Brooklyn Art Song Society at Galapagos Art Space.

title: Sex, Death and Melancholy: Or, Three Friends Walk Into a Dublin Bar ...
description: I thought I had a handle on myself, Danny tells the audience in Dedalus Lounge, a mesmerizing mess of a play at the Interart Theater Annex. When will I be normal? he asks, his voice shaking. Those lines are part of an unsettling monologue, and theyre not the only compelling moments in a story that is by turns earnest and odd, tender and disturbing.

title: Revenge in Garden of Good and Evil
description: No one who encounters The Poisoned Kiss, the third of five operas by the English composer Ralph Vaughan Williams, can fail to see why it never found a place in the standard repertory. Seen in what was claimed to be its first professional New York production, mounted by the Bronx Opera Company in the Lovinger Theater at Lehman College on Saturday night, the work readily showed its intrinsic shortcomings: a plot too whimsical for modern tastes, a wayward libretto, a girth too protracted for the frivolity of its material.

title: Section 5 and the Right to Vote
description: Is Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act still necessary? That provision requires nine states and some counties and towns with histories of severe racial discrimination to get approval from the Justice Department or a court before changing their voting procedures. The question hovers over three consolidated cases the Supreme Court heard last week on redistricting for legislative and Congressional seats in Texas, a state governed by Section 5.

title: On the Trail of Mortgage Fraud
description: Queens has been harder hit by foreclosures than any other New York borough, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation believes it has found a culprit. Last July, the F.B.I. accused Edul Ahmad, a local broker, of a $50 million mortgage fraud, saying he lured fellow immigrants into subprime mortgages, inflated the values of their properties and concealed his involvement in deals that were ruinous for scores, if not hundreds, of borrowers. Mr. Ahmad pleaded not guilty, and posted $2.5 million bail. Now, according to court papers, as reported in The Times, he is plea-bargaining with federal prosecutors.

title: Study on Teacher Value Uses Data From Before Teach-to-Test Era
description: My four children have all attended public schools in our middle-class suburban district. When my oldest was in fourth grade, in 1998, he took the state tests, and I was not even aware of it. Later, he said the tests were kind of fun; he got to miss his regular classes.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: How Fares the Dream?
description: I have a dream, declared Martin Luther King, in a speech that has lost none of its power to inspire. And some of that dream has come true. When King spoke in the summer of 1963, America was a nation that denied basic rights to millions of its citizens, simply because their skin was the wrong color. Today racism is no longer embedded in law. And while it has by no means been banished from the hearts of men, its grip is far weaker than once it was.

title: Suit on Police Treatment of Livery Riders Is to Proceed
description: A civil rights lawsuit accusing the New York Police Department of flouting the constitutional rights of livery cab passengers has been allowed to move forward by a federal judge, who denied the citys attempt to have the suit dismissed.

title: Flexing Muscle, Baghdad Detains U.S. Contractors
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi authorities have detained a few hundred foreign contractors in recent weeks, industry officials say, including many Americans who work for the United States Embassy, in one of the first major signs of the Iraqi governments asserting its sovereignty after the American troop withdrawal last month.

title: Big Stop From Boley Gives Giants a Lift
description: A capsule look at the Giants 37-20 upset victory over the Packers in the divisional round on Sunday.

title: The Scapegoat of Balls Bluff
description: As 1862 dawned, the Unions military fortunes appeared decidedly grim. Defeats like those suffered at Bull Run and Balls Bluff, as well as the growing realization that Gen. George McClellan was at best a reluctant warrior, gave rise to a growing claque of congressional critics. On Dec. 10, 1861, they had established the Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War, designed to examine every aspect of the war effort and empowered to send for person and papers as needed. Far from being a dispassionate check on the Executive Branch, however, the committee was, from the very beginning, a tool for partisan politics, a weapon forged out of, in Senator Charles Sumners words, a strong desire to hold someone responsible for the Union Armys recent misfortunes.

title: Corrections: January 16
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Donors Gave as Santorum Won Earmarks
description: The announcements flowed out of Rick Santorums Senate office: a $3.5 million federal grant to Piasecki Aircraft to help it test a new helicopter propeller technology; another $3.5 million to JLG Industries to bolster its bid to build all-terrain forklifts for the military; $1.4 million to Medico Industries to upgrade equipment for its munitions work.

title: Governor Who Took On Unions May Face a Closely Watched Recall Election
description: MILWAUKEE  Thousands of volunteers have raced to collect signatures near busy intersections and malls all over Wisconsin, at makeshift drive-through operations in parking lots, during Green Bay Packers viewing parties and New Years Eve pub crawls, and even at a fold-up table inside Milwaukees airport just off Concourse C.

title: Defying Gravity Proves Easier Than Escaping From Loneliness
description: Lots of people who live in closet-size apartments in New York know all too well what it feels like to be alone and isolated in a small space. Oh, if they only had acrobatic training.

title: From Violence in Iraq to Hardships in Brooklyn
description: On a warm December afternoon, Zahra Nahim stood in her narrow kitchen pulling flat ovals of bread out of the oven, piling plates with yellow rice and shredded chicken  and thoroughly dusting the front of her black abaya with white flour.

title: Danish Player Cant Live Up to Family Legacy
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Frederik Nielsen of Denmark was expanding his familys tennis legacy the hard way  earning a spot in the main draw of the 2012 Australian Open by winning three qualifying matches.

title: Len and Latoya
description: In this homemade video, Len Kamdang and Latoya Nelson recall their awkward first date, which led to a lifetime of love.

title: In Silicon Valley, the Ripe Scent of New Money
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Sam Odio expected a few congratulatory e-mails when he sold Divvyshot, his online photo-sharing service, to Facebook last April for millions of dollars.

title: A Changed Way of War in Afghanistans Skies
description: INSIDE STRIKE FIGHTER VENGEANCE 13, over Kandahar Province, Afghanistan  Cmdr. Layne McDowell glanced over his left shoulder, through the canopy of a Navy F/A-18, to an Afghan canyon 9,000 feet below. An American infantry company was down there.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther Kings Birthday, actually Jan. 15, will be observed.

description: Wanted: 50 former science majors with an interest in teaching  no experience, please  and a willingness to relocate. Must be comfortable sharing a classroom with dinosaur bones and giant squid.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Though she is without her sister Venus in Melbourne, Serena Williams has found a new doubles partner for the Australian Open: her longtime friend Andy Roddick.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday issued an amnesty for crimes committed during the 10-month uprising, at least the fourth such gesture since protests began and another official step that seemed to underscore the gap between the demonstrators demands and the governments vision for change.

title: Day Care Centers Adapt to Round-the-Clock Demand
description: ELYRIA, Ohio  Dinner (chicken and mashed potatoes) was long over, teeth were brushed, and a rousing game of Monopoly had come to a close. It was 9 p.m., and the children nestled into bed under blankets emblazoned with superheroes.

title: Bahrain Opposition Says Kings Measures Fall Short
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Bahrains king on Sunday announced constitutional amendments that will give the elected Parliament greater powers of scrutiny over the government, but the concessions fell short of the oppositions demands for change.

title: An Unexpected Focus Before the Next Primary
description: The Republican battle for South Carolina was supposed to have been a time for the states socially conservative voters to weed out the candidates they found unfit. Instead, the primary has been dominated by a loud and unruly argument over whether Bain Capital, the private equity firm that was led by Mitt Romney, drove companies out of business and put people out of work while enriching itself with billions of dollars.

title: Russias Failed Mars Probe Crashes Into Pacific
description: A Russian scientific probe that was meant to visit a Martian moon but never made it out of Earth orbit crashed into the Pacific Ocean about 700 miles west of Chile on Sunday, a Russian military spokesman said.

title: The Artist and The Descendants Take Globes
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Moviegoers looking to the Golden Globe Awards as Oscar forecasters should consider their bets hedged. The Artist was Sunday nights big winner, taking home three prizes, including one for best comedy. But it was a photo finish with The Descendants, which won two awards, including best drama.

title: The Met Reimagines the American Story
description: Right on time for the election year, American art has reoccupied the Metropolitan Museum of Art en masse. After four years of renovation the museums galleries of American painting and sculpture  long the most popular part of its now completely reopened American Wing  will be back on view on Monday, washed with light, rich with stories and scenic prospects, and packed with enough politics to fuel any presidential campaign.

title: Hoarding Is Seen as Cause of Fuel Shortage in Egypt
description: CAIRO  A sudden shortage of gasoline gripped Egypt over the weekend, raising new concerns about its teetering economy and its political stability.

title: Eight Men In: Savoring a Victory
description: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team  a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen  traveled to Lambeau Field for Sundays showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. They were joined by two pals in Milwaukee.

title: Study of Retail Workers Finds $9.50 Median Pay
description: Retail workers in New York City earn a median of $9.50 an hour, most are part-time or temporary, and just 3 in 10 receive health insurance through their jobs, according to a new study of the citys larger retailers.

(If any Bitcoin evangelists find their way to this post, they can abuse me for calling the virtual money system, which went online in 2009, obscure.) The writers clearly loved the case at the center of Bitcoin for Dummies on Sunday night, though  I didnt put a stopwatch on it, but it felt as if the Case of the Week received more time than it had for quite a while.

title: Pairings: Sweet-and-Sour Sardines
description: Name your quaff. White, red, still, sparkling, sweet or dry? We sampled them all in our tasting of wines from the Canary Islands. And as food-friendly as these well-balanced wines were, deciding exactly what food would work best with them was the challenge. Some sort of marinated fish seemed to be the best idea, especially one that delivered bold swagger to welcome a red wine. Mackerel, sardines, wahoo or tuna were possible draft choices; a dozen fresh sardines on ice in the market made the team. And dressed in a bright, lemony wine sauce enriched with honey, like a Venetian in saor preparation, they also flattered the wines, whether white, red or sparkling. Sweet would not have been off base either, but deserved to be saved for a cheese course or dessert.

title: Grapes Born of Volcano and Sea
description: TO drink only the best-known wines from time-honored regions is a little like eating in the same restaurants over and over. You cant go wrong, perhaps, but without the rewards of exploration, you are missing out on so much more.

title: Passport for Life
description: MOSCOW  As of last Friday, I am an undocumented person in my own country. I cannot open or close a bank account, receive medical care at a state clinic, buy a cellphone, return a purchase to a store or enter into a contract, which my job requires me to do several times a day. All of these operations and many more require a valid internal passport, a peculiar document that may be the most significant vestige of the U.S.S.R. in modern Russian society.Back when we lived behind the Iron Curtain, these passports entitled us to travel only within the confines of the Soviet Union. Anyone lucky enough to be allowed to travel abroad was issued a special foreign-travel passport just for the occasion and had to surrender it upon returning home. When Russians acquired the right to travel freely, they got to keep their foreign-travel passports. But the internal passport refused to die. So now each adult Russian citizen has two passports. The documents look alike, except that the one for internal use is printed on lighter paper stock, making it feel less substantial.

title: A Conversation With: Shoma Chaudhury
description: Since it started more than a decade ago, Tehelka has been one of the most aggressive investigative news outlets in India, reporting on and often using sting operations to uncover everything from cricket match-fixing to corruption in the defence industry, toppling government figures, sparking widespread investigations and sometimes raising questions about its methods along the way.

All around the lobby and lounge, groups of young girls, ordering one bottle of water among them, sat with their eyes glued on the front door, hoping for a sighting of the performer Joe Jonas, who was in town, once again, to attend the Calvin Klein mens show during Milan Fashion Week.

The Beverly Hilton Hotel auditorium was packed with a lot of Hollywood insiders who also get a vote at the Oscars. Who wins a Globe has nothing to do with who wins an Oscar. But the warmth of a winners reception in the room can tell a lot about Hollywood sentiment, and where the Oscar ballots are headed.

description: MADRID  The European Unions long-term energy plans to abate global warming while still burning fossil fuels hinge on proposals to capture carbon dioxide emissions and store them in deep underground rock formations. Yet weak support for the untested technology is putting Europe in the rear ranks of its development.

title: Exit Huntsman
description: Jon Huntsman had a more impressive resume, a better policy shop, better odds in November and stronger conservative bona fides than many of the candidates vying for the Republican nomination. But several of them are still running while hes dropped out, and that almost all of them enjoyed temporary surges in the polls while he always languished at the bottom of the pack. For this, theres plenty of blame to go around: Huntsman can blame the mainstream media, for constantly depicting him as the sane Republican tragically doomed to irrelevance by the folly of his partys base; he can blame his own advisers, for embracing that self-defeating image and trying to re-run John McCains 2000 campaign in a very different climate; he can blame Republican voters for dismissing him because of symbolism and identity politics rather than judging him on his record; he can blame conservative machers and opinion-makers for doing the same. (He can even blame his father, who declined or wasnt asked, or both  to play Sheldon Adelson to his sons cash-poor campaign.)

title: Milan Top 5 | Burberry
description: The obsessively descriptive list of coat styles in the notes for Christopher Baileys fantastic Burberry Prorsum show read like a comprehensive history of English outerwear: heritage trench coats, luggage lock duffle coats, sartorial tailored Chesterfields, college stripe down-filled car coats, cropped bomber jackets and on and on and on. This is a house built on a coat  the trench  and Bailey always sticks smartly to the program. The torso-hugging, slim-legged suits at the shows opening were my favorites, with models in tweed flat caps toting umbrellas with carved animal head handles, their coats over their shoulders or buttoned up tight against the cold.

title: Chinglish to Close
description: David Henry Hwangs Broadway comedy Chinglish, about the misadventures and cultural misunderstanding of an American businessman as he is trying to close a deal in China, will end its run on Jan. 29, after 128 performances. The bilingual play, which features Gary Wilmes as the businessman and Jennifer Lim as a Chinese official who becomes his unlikely ally and lover, opened at the Longacre Theater in October to generally favorable reviews, and was named by Time magazine as the No. 1 new American play of 2011. Despite those accolades, and the strong reputation of Mr. Hwang, a Tony Award winner whose previous work includes M. Butterfly, box office sales remained modest.

title: Omelets: The Ultimate Fast Food
description: For some time now the medical literature has been countering the myth that the cholesterol in eggs goes straight to the arteries and that eggs should be shunned by anybody committed to healthy eating. Studies have shown that only a small amount of dietary cholesterol passes into the blood and that saturated fats and trans fats have much bigger effects on cholesterol levels. In fact, according to the Harvard School of Public Health, the only large study that looked at the effect of egg consumption on heart disease found no correlation between the two, except among people with diabetes, who were a bit more likely to develop heart disease if they ate an egg a day.

title: American McHale Upsets Safarova
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Christina McHale of the United States upset 24th-seeded Lucie Safarova of the Czech Republic in the first round of the 2012 Australian Open on Monday.

title: Taliban Declares Victory, as Fighting Goes On
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Talibans one-eyed leader, seems to have taken a page from George W. Bushs playbook.

title: Reads & Reactions
description: In this edition: Iowa, New Hampshire, steak dinners and more.

title: Penguins, Hockey and Serious Stuff Too: Scotts Polar Chronicles
description: The British explorer Robert Falcon Scott finally reached his destination a century ago, Jan. 17, 1912, more than a month too late to claim victory in the race to be first to the South Pole. But the triumphant Norwegian Roald Amundsen could not deny him at least one distinction: Scott was the founder of The South Polar Times, the first magazine to be produced on the Antarctic continent.

title: Etro Mens
description: Milan.

title: Depression Defies the Rush to Find an Evolutionary Upside
description: In certain quarters of academia, its all the rage these days to view human behavior through the lens of evolutionary biology. What survival advantages, researchers ask, may lie hidden in our actions, even in our pathologies?

title: Milan Top 5 | Prada
description: Miuccia Pradas extravagant show entitled Il Palazzo had the typically reserved fashion crowd hooting and hollering by the end of it,so great was the spectacle. Capital A actors, including Tim Roth, Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe and Gary Oldman (looking perfectly arch in his part), made a regal procession across a room-dwarfing red carpet that was better fit for monarchs than for models. That said, Oldmans beautifully cut, high-buttoned double-breasted coat over a layered white turtleneck and crisp white shirt looked ready to reign.

title: Cracking Open the Scientific Process
description: The New England Journal of Medicine marks its 200th anniversary this year with a timeline celebrating the scientific advances first described in its pages: the stethoscope (1816), the use of ether for anesthesia (1846), and disinfecting hands and instruments before surgery (1867), among others.

title: Florida Evangelical Leader Now Backs Santorum
description: John Stemberger, president of Florida Family Action, on Monday became one of the first evangelical leaders to switch his support to Rick Santorum after a meeting of evangelicals in Texas last week voted to support Mr. Santorum in his bid for the 2012 Republican nomination.

title: Son of a Gun
description: One grunt did Marine push-ups. A few guys lolled on their bunks. The model Ricardo Felix, buck-naked and with his back to the audience, rinsed himself under a shower. In a barber chair, Francesco Guzzi received a painful new piece of permanent artwork on his left bicep from Simone Falcetta, a former equestrian champion now best known as the pre-eminent tattoo master of Milan.

title: Personal Health: Lifelines for People With Hearing Loss
description: Hearing loss, a disability currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nations most damaging and costly sensory handicap. It is a hidden disability, often not obvious to others or even to those who have it.

title: The Caucus Click: Then There Were Five
Puerto Rico Traces Baseballs Slide to the Draft
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  This used to be the climax of baseballs peak season in Puerto Rico. The storied winter league lured many of Major League Baseballs biggest Puerto Rican stars back to the island  from Roberto Clemente and Orlando Cepeda to Roberto Alomar and Bernie Williams  and they would regularly play before tens of thousands of fans during what was otherwise their off-season.

title: Political Tourism Comes to South Carolina
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Political tourists are a familiar breed in Iowa and New Hampshire. People in the rest of the country understand that voters in those two states have unparalleled access to presidential candidates, and they like to travel there to catch the unique flavor of a presidential race in its early stages and get an up-close look at the contenders while they are still working out their schtick.

title: Toe Fossil Contributes to a Head-Scratcher
description: Which came first, the nail or the claw?

title: Coming Soon | Chunky Knit Coats
