title: Forget the Charts, Adele Tops Karaoke Too
description: Just how popular is Adele becoming? A new survey by a market research group in Britain has found that two songs recorded by the singer accounted for more than a third of all karaoke performances there in 2011. Leading the list, not surprisingly, was Someone Like You, a hit single from the CD 21, which was chosen by one in four karaoke singers and is also up for a Grammy next month in the best pop performance category. In second place, with 10 percent of the three million total performances tabulated, was her cover version of Bob Dylans Make You Feel My Love, a track from her debut CD, 19. The top non-Adele karaoke song was Heroes, a track written by David Bowie and Brian Eno in the 1970s that enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after it was featured on the television program The X Factor.

title: BASF to Stop Selling Genetically Modified Products in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  BASF, the German chemical group, has abandoned efforts to sell genetically modified products in Europe, including its Amflora potato, because of overwhelming opposition to the technology, the company said Monday.

title: Irish Court Declares a Former Tycoon Bankrupt
description: Sean Quinn, a businessman who was once one of the richest men in Ireland, was declared bankrupt on Monday by a court in the country, where stiff regulations could prevent him from resuming his business activities for up to 12 years.

title: Puerto Rican Baseball League Struggles
description: Baseball in general seems to be on the decline in Puerto Rico.

title: Moschino Mens
description: Milan.

title: Salesforce Hires Vivek Kundra and Looks Overseas
description: Salesforce.com, best know for its sales, customer service and collaboration software for business, is raising its ambitions by aiming at the international businesses and sales to foreign governments that have been the mainstays of companies like I.B.M.

title: Amid Doubts About Presidential Run, Senegalese Singer Releases Music Video
description: The Grammy Award-winning singer Youssou NDour, who announced his candidacy for president of Senegal this month, put out a new music video on his YouTube channel over the weekend, presenting an optimistic face amid doubts about the strength of his run.

title: Liberias President Stresses Reconciliation in Second Inaugural Speech
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia inaugurated a second six-year term on Monday, calling for political reconciliation after a runoff election that was tarnished by an opposition boycott and street clashes between protesters and the police.

title: Hulu Adds to Its Original Programming Lineup
description: Lining up more original programming for its Web site, Hulu said Sunday that it would introduce its first scripted series, Battleground, and a documentary series by the writer and director Richard Linklater.

title: Day Care Thats Available at Night, Too
description: Good day care is hard to find. Good day care for the night shift? Impossible, or at least it used to be. Sabrina Tavernise reports that as working hours change (about 40 percent of the American labor force works nonstandard hours now, particularly in the growing fields of nursing, retail and food service), some child-care centers are changing, too. Centers providing after hours care make up a large part of growth for a company that runs employer-sponored child-care centers, and many independent child-care centers are offering expanded hours  dinner, homework help and bedtime included.

title: Hulu Commissions Its First Original Scripted Programming
description: 3:02 p.m. | Updated The online video service Hulu, most of whose programming consists of material licensed from television and film companies, has commissioned its first original script-based program, which is scheduled to be available on Hulus free web service, rather than its premium pay Hulu Plus site, as of the middle of next month. Called Battleground, the new series is described as a faux documentary-style political drama-comedy set in Wisconsin which in real life has emerged as a frontline in combat between liberals and conservatives since Republican governor Scott Walker took office a year ago.

title: Leonardo DiCaprios Mom, Meet Jane Fonda
description: LOS ANGELES  It seems appropriate to use a traffic metaphor here.

title: A Surprising Victory in 1972 Stands the Test of Time
description: Ken Rosewall, the reigning champion at 37, had just won his fourth Australian Open, but he felt a little guilty.

title: Climate Proposal Puts Practicality Ahead of Sacrifice
description: The current issue of the journal Science contains a proposal to slow global warming that is extraordinary for a couple of reasons:

title: Climate 101  Online and Free
description: As part of the trend in higher education toward moving more course offerings onto the Web, the University of Chicago has launched Open Climate 101, an online version of a popular course led by David Archer that explores for non-science majors the body of research pointing to a rising human influence on the climate system.

title: Huntsman Ends Campaign and Backs Romney
description: Former Utah Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. announced Monday that he would end his campaign for the presidency and called for the party to unite behind the candidacy of Mitt Romney.

title: Military Drill With the U.S. Is Postponed, Israeli Says
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and the United States have agreed to postpone major joint missile-defense exercises that had been scheduled for the spring because of regional tensions and instability, according to Israels foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman.

title: Man vs. Youth: The New Reality-Show Frontier
description: Sometimes a critic has to step forward to nip a programming trend in the bud, in the interest of preserving the basic tenets of civilization. Last week the National Geographic Channel announced a new spring show, Are You Tougher Than a Boy Scout?, in which, the press release said, adult civilians will go head to head with scrappy Scouts in challenges like setting up a campsite, starting a fire and cooking dinner as fast as possible.

title: Flowers in Winter
description: Q. We have a winter jasmine that blooms in the coldest weather. What insects are active in January and February to pollinate the flowers?

title: Taiwan Election Stirs Hopes Among Chinese for Democracy
description: BEIJING  There was another winner in the election this weekend that handed President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan a second term in office  the faint but unmistakable clamor for democracy in China.

title: Street Style: Tailored Coats
description: The best of readers street style for the week of Jan. 9.

title: U.S. to Force Drug Firms to Report Money Paid to Doctors
description: WASHINGTON  To head off medical conflicts of interest, the Obama administration is poised to require drug companies to disclose the payments they make to doctors for research, consulting, speaking, travel and entertainment.

title: Streeps Shout-Outs and Gervaiss Jokes
description: Im in shock, said Adepero Oduye, the young star of Pariah, who was given a shout-out by none other than Meryl Streep during the Golden Globes on Sunday night. Meryl Streep said my name, Ms. Oduye said, still reeling in the lobby of the Beverly Hilton afterward. I got to meet her, and she kissed my hand. Shes one of my idols!

title: Manhattan Country School Students See Civil Rights Battles Still to Be Fought
Slightly Fewer Viewers for This Years Golden Globes
description: In a year in which nine of the top 10 movies at the box office have been sequels, perhaps it was appropriate that Ricky Gervais served up a slightly less compelling version of last years Golden Globe Awards. NBC said on Monday that its live Globes telecast on Sunday night drew 16.8 million viewers, down a whisker from last years 17 million. About 4 percent fewer people in the target demographic, adults age 18 to 49, tuned in, as measured by raw ratings points. (A 5.0 this year compared to a 5.2 last year.) NBC had heavily promoted Mr. Gervaiss acerbic comedic style as a reason to watch. As promised, he delivered a crude monologue  a repeat performance of 2011, when his remarks drew gasps  but shocking people twice with the same shtick is hard to pull off. Other factors possibly affecting interest in the show: NBC has limited ability to promote itself (the networks overall schedule remains in the ratings basement), and the Globes also celebrated a batch of smaller films like The Artist that have produced limited box-office results. Still, the telecast was a win for NBC, delivering the networks biggest audience, excluding sporting events, since last years Globes.

title: Is Depression a Natural Condition?
description: In todays Science Times, Dr. Richard A. Friedman, a psychiatrist, explores a growing trend in academic circles to view depression as a natural condition that, like ordinary sadness, may provide evolutionary advantages. He writes:

title: What to Watch for in Tonights Debate
description: A dwindling group of Republican presidential contenders  now just five  will debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C., tonight as the party lurches closer toward choosing its nominee.

title: A Life Hidden Behind Adjectives
description: The cloud of adjectives that has come to hover over the Republican candidate Mitt Romney in news reports is familiar by now: smooth, smart, slick; detached, disciplined, dogged; pragmatic, protean, phony; careful, cautious, calculating.

title: Key Protein May Give Ebola Virus Its Opening
description: THE HYPOTHESIS

title: National Polls Suggest Romney Is Overwhelming Favorite for G.O.P. Nomination
description: While most of the political worlds attention has been focused on South Carolina, Mitt Romney has moved into a clear lead in a set of national polls conducted since his victory in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Hungary, Once a Star, Loses Its Shine
description: BUDAPEST  Zoltan Zsoter, an 80-year-old retiree, would seem to be about as far from the world of currency speculation as a person can get. Yet he is an example of how the workings of the global financial system, amplified by the policies of a single political leader, can have a devastating effect on ordinary people.

title: Juilliard School Announces $20 Million Gift for Early Music
description: Devotees of early music in New York may be experiencing whiplash. The year began in inspiriting fashion, with the Green Mountain Projects superb annual presentation of Vespers music by Monteverdi, sponsored by Trinity Church at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste. Then, days later, a bleak midwinter seemed to settle in, when Trinity declared a hiatus in its own music program, suspending the activities of its excellent Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at least until March. Now, on Tuesday, the Juilliard School is announcing a $20 million gift to endow its graduate-level program in historical performance. The sheer size of the gift is enough to make heads snap in the early-music world, whose practitioners typically struggle to stay a step ahead of poverty.

title: The Real Artists of Marfa | Sam Schonzeit
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: For Intrigue, Malaria Drug Gets the Prize
description: The Chinese drug artemisinin has been hailed as one of the greatest advances in fighting malaria, the scourge of the tropics, since the discovery of quinine centuries ago.

title: India: Full Year Without a Reported Case of Polio
description: For the first time, India has gone a full year without a new polio case, the World Health Organization announced last week.

title: Yeast Experiment Hints at a Faster Evolution From Single Cells
description: Our ancestors were single-celled microbes for about three billion years before they evolved bodies. But in a laboratory at the University of Minnesota, brewers yeast cells can evolve primitive bodies in about two weeks.

title: Equity and Quality Debated at M.L.K. Event
When Breakthroughs Begin at Home
description: Cathal Garveys home laboratory in Cork, Ireland, is filled with makeshift equipment. His incubator for bacteria is an old Styrofoam shipping box with a heating mat and thermometer that he has modified into a thermostat. He uses a pressure cooker to sterilize instead of an autoclave. Some instruments are fashioned from coffee cans.

title: Versace Mens
description: Milan.

title: Knicks Limit Howard, but Not the Long Shot
description: Sixty minutes after the buzzer sounded on another Knicks defeat, Carmelo Anthony emerged from the trainers room  his left wrist still wrapped tightly, his right ankle still tender, his self-belief unimpaired.

title: Preparing to Live With Wolves
description: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

title: Personal Best: Workouts Have Their Limits, Recognized or Not
description: At the gym last week I saw a guy lifting weights, working out his shoulders while two friends urged him on. He alternated two similar exercises with heavy weights, repeating one exercise 10 times and then the other one 10 times, never resting between sets.

title: Stay-at-Home Fathers Arent So Rare Anymore
description: The household stories in last weeks Bloomberg Businessweek are ordinary. Try not to nod off during the following quotation (in which I have made a few key changes):

title: Daily Aspirin Is Not for Everyone, Study Suggests
description: Nearly a third of middle-aged Americans regularly take a baby aspirin in the hope of preventing a heart attack or a stroke or lowering their cancer risk. But new research shows that aspirin is not for everyone, and that in some patients this so-called wonder drug is doing more harm than good.

title: Students Explore the Breadth of Humanness
description: As Martin Luther King Day draws toward a close, its worth posting this engaging Im Human video created at the 1,170-student Liberty Middle School in Madison, Alabama:

title: M&Ms to Unveil New Speaking Role at Super Bowl
description: A POPULAR candy will offer elocution lessons of a sort on Super Bowl Sunday, answering the question How now, brown?

title: New Breed of Tight End Is Unchecked So Far
description: John Lynch spent 15 years as one of the N.F.L.s hardest-hitting safeties, so when he watches the hulking and high-speed tight ends barreling into this weekends conference championship games, it is with the particular bloodlust of a defensive player with a lingering distaste for offense.

title: Look of The Moment | The Golden Globes
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Anna Dello Russo, Always the Fashion Chameleon
description: Sometimes I change in the car, said Anna Dello Russo, the fashion Zelig and creative consultant to Vogue Japan. Ms. Dello Russo has been seemingly everywhere this week, and very seldom in the same suit of clothes.

title: Tunes in Which Everything Is So Complicated
description: To the casual listener the theater songs of William Finn may sound like the agitated stream of consciousness of a compulsive talker running off at the mouth  their loose structures held together by seemingly haphazard internal rhymes. The words sometimes spill over the music. But if you pay close attention to a song like How to Make Delicious Chocolate Pudding, a jolly banjo-inflected number sung by Megan Lawrence at the Allen Room on Saturday evening as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, you discover a witty short story that follows its own unconventional songwriting logic.

title: Wikipedia to Go Dark on Wednesday to Protest Bills on Web Piracy
description: The wave of online protests against two Congressional bills that aim to curtail copyright violations on the Internet is gathering momentum.

title: Lobbyist for Students? New Yorkers Have Their Doubts

title: Going by Twitter,  Globes Were a Big Hit
description: The ratings for the Globes may have dipped slightly, but it was a robust presence on Twitter, where the Tweets-per-second (TPS) count reached 6,162 at its highest point, more than last years Super Bowl (4,064 TPS) or the royal wedding (3,966), though still less than the MTV Video Music Awards (8,868 TPS, which had the advantage of the Beyonce bump).

title: Lush and Sweet Sounds, by Way of a Youthful Ensemble
description: The early-20th-century Spanish violinist Manuel Quiroga is not as well known internationally as his compatriots Sarasate and Casals, but he is an esteemed figure in Spain. The Cuarteto Quiroga, a youthful ensemble founded in Madrid in 2004, is keeping his name alive and creating curiosity about him among listeners outside Spain, and is doing him proud. Its program, in the intimate concert room at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon, was exquisite: precise, perfectly balanced, interpretively fresh performances, couched in consistently warm hues.

title: Worlds Within Worlds Within Worlds. And a Duane Reade.
description: All sorts of walls come tumbling down in World of Wires, Jay Scheibs slap-happy, mixed-media murder mystery at the Kitchen. Divisions between reality (that old chimera) and perception  not to mention the borders that separate screen from stage and human from machine  are stomped upon with the glee of a precocious, permanently stoned, science-fiction-reading 14-year-old who has just discovered, like, philosophy, dude.

title: Kathleen Edwards, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Cate Le Bon
description: KATHLEEN EDWARDS

title: Silent on the Plane, but Chatty With the Locals
description: ALTHOUGH I really feel as if Im part of a cattle herd every time Im at the airport, I still love being on a plane. I dont have to do anything if I dont want to. When you work crazy hours, that time to do nothing is really precious.

title: At Versace Party, the Show Goes On
description: MILAN  Donatella Versace organized a customary dinner party following her mens fashion show in Milan on Monday night, inviting a few guests into the ornate apartment where Gianni Versace once resided, on the second floor of the companys headquarters. Once the last of the models, who walked in a collection Ms. Versace called tough glamour, had changed into more casual Versace sportswear and made their way upstairs from the show, a man walked through the crowd telling them, The show is about to start. Hadnt it just ended?

title: Selling Boarding Perks to the Forlorn
description: SINCE the first of the year, Ive had many conversations with business travelers who said they had made a last-minute trip in December to top off their miles flown for 2011 and qualify for renewal of some level of elite status for 2012.

title: The Rich Are Different: Theyre in 3-D
description: LOS ANGELES  With Avatar, 3-D conquered the world.

title: In Heated Primary Fight, Romney Keeps Focus on Obama
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Speaking at the South Carolina Faith and Freedom Coalition before yet another Republican debate here in Myrtle Beach Monday night, Mitt Romney kept his focus on President Obama, making a point of drawing contrasts between himself and the president on social issues.

title: Luisi Crosses Border To American Territory
description: During the last couple of seasons, audiences in New York have had ample opportunities to get to know the work of Fabio Luisi, the Metropolitan Operas principal conductor, who has been taking over most of the performances the ailing James Levine has had to withdraw from. But on Sunday afternoon Mr. Luisi, conducting the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, revealed another dimension to his artistry. Who would have expected this Italian maestro to be so at home conducting Coplands jazzy Clarinet Concerto, let alone an aria from Wuthering Heights, the only opera by Bernard Herrmann, of Psycho fame?

title: Iran Face-Off Testing Obama the Candidate
description: WASHINGTON  The escalating American confrontation with Iran poses a major new political threat to President Obama as he heads into his campaign for re-election, presenting him with choices that could harm either the economic recovery or his image as a firm leader.

title: A Merger Proposal For Actors Unions
description: After five rounds and nearly two years of negotiations aimed at producing a merger, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, the two main unions representing actors and other performing artists, have agreed on the terms of an agreement, leaders of both groups said on Monday. No specifics of the accord were officially announced, but news reports said that all differences regarding a new constitution, dues-paying procedures and a governing structure had been resolved. The boards of both groups are scheduled to vote on the agreement on Jan. 28; the guild represents about 125,000 actors, and the federations approximately 70,000 members include broadcasters, singers and dancers as well as actors.

title: As Idol Returns, It Must Face New Rivals
description: PASADENA, Calif.  American Idol is returning to the Fox network this week amid a growing roster of competitors, but its stars and producers say they sense no threat from the other singing contest on Fox this season, The X Factor, and especially not from the version on NBC, The Voice, that will start a second season next month.

title: Beneath Pink Parasols, Identity in Stark Form
description: Young Jean Lee is, hands down, the most adventurous downtown playwright of her generation. In previous shows this Korean-American writer has devised a comic revue about black identity politics, retailored Shakespeares King Lear and taken to the stage herself to perform a cabaret act mostly about death.

title: Wayward Children Of the 80s
description: During his contribution to a shared evening as part of the American Realness festival at the Abrons Arts Center on Sunday, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones took on animal cruelty, bondage, teenage murderers and Satan worship. But the part that most likely triggered traumatic memories came before all of that, at the very beginning, when the audience was herded onto the stage and greeted by a nervous-seeming man in a sweater vest and tie. The setting was clear: a high-school assembly.

title: A Warriors Quest for Fame, Ending in a Last Stand
description: Its too bad reality television didnt come along about a century earlier than it did. There might never have been a Battle of the Little Bighorn because George A. Custer would have channeled his energy into competing on Dancing With the Stars instead.

title: Reaganite Delusions
description: Ah. Noah Smith goes reading in the fresh waters, and finds that people there are still claiming that there was a dramatic improvement in growth once Reagan/Friedman came along.

title: Charles H. Price II, Ambassador to Britain, Dies at 80
description: Charles H. Price II, a former United States ambassador to Britain who helped sustain warm relations between President Ronald Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, died on Thursday at his home in Indian Wells, Calif. He was 80.

title: A Twitter War Between Advisers
description: It did not even take the full 140-characters to start the great Twitter war Monday afternoon.

title: Magics Howard Has Help From Ex-Net Anderson
description: Before the Orlando Magic defeated the Knicks at Madison Square Garden on Monday, the teams starting power forward, Ryan Anderson, discussed the ins and outs of New York  commuting, the best pizza  as only someone who had lived in the area could.

title: Euro Woes Could Revive Bout of Market Volatility
description: Investors are bracing for a return to volatility when markets in the United States reopen on Tuesday as renewed gloom about the debt crisis in Europe threatens to end the calm that has prevailed on Wall Street in recent weeks.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: E-Books at the Library and Steve Jobs Dolls
description: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Louise J. Kaplan, Psychoanalyst and Author, Dies at 82
description: Louise J. Kaplan, a psychoanalyst and author who used a psychological lens, literary allusion and a feminist sensibility to soberly define and explain seemingly titillating topics like sexual perversity and fetishes, died on Jan. 9 in Manhattan. She was 82.

title: For Packers, Regrets Now and Questions for Later
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The Green Bay Packers radio network can be heard from eastern Minnesota to the Dakotas. So Packers fans who tuned in while driving home from Lambeau Field after their team lost, 37-20, to the Giants on Sunday heard an anguished audio moment replayed time after time, regardless of their destination.

title: Web Gang Operating in the Open
description: Five men believed to be responsible for spreading a notorious computer worm on Facebook and other social networks  and pocketing several million dollars from online schemes  are hiding in plain sight in St. Petersburg, Russia, according to investigators at Facebook and several independent computer security researchers.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 16
description: As the youth Olympics gathered steam in Innsbruck, Londoners prepared for the Summer Games with test events and the heavyweights had an easy time of it at the Australian Open.

description: To the Editor:

description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  With new calls on Monday for Republicans to rally around Mitt Romney as their presidential nominee, some conservatives showed new signs of fracturing despite a vote over the weekend by religious leaders to coalesce behind Rick Santorum as an anti-Romney alternative.

description: To the Editor:

title: Learning to Be Lean
description: As one of the many outgrowths of the sweeping federal health care law, health insurers and employers must now pay the cost of screening children for obesity and providing them with appropriate counseling.

title: One-Year Deal for Hughes
description: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the right-hander Phil Hughes by agreeing on a one-year, $3.2 million contract, with performance bonuses, for the 2012 season. But that may not be the final transaction for Hughes this year.

title: Live Blogging the Myrtle Beach Debate
description: The five remaining Republican presidential contenders square off in Myrtle Beach, S.C., Monday night just five days before the states primary.

title: Frenchwomen Worry About Suspect Breast Implants
description: LA ROCHELLE, France  Some of the women who received substandard breast implants made by the now defunct company Poly Implants Prothses no longer sleep facedown. Others have stopped playing with their children, for fear of taking a punch to the chest.

title: Analysts Fault Additions to RIM PlayBook Tablet
description: OTTAWA  Nearly 10 months after its debut, the BlackBerry PlayBook tablet will finally get e-mail and other important missing features in February. But after examining a preview of the software upgrade last week, several analysts said the devices maker, Research in Motion, continues to struggle with significant technical issues, which could hinder its effort to reverse its declining fortunes.

title: Metro Pucks Weekly: Honoring the Underrated
description: Our weekly review of the New York metropolitan regions three N.H.L. franchises, through Monday:

title: Thwarted Travelers
description: Travel groups and convention planners are among the groups pressing the United States to change some of its more onerous visa requirements, arguing that the current rules are keeping out many international business travelers and that a faster, more efficient process would help American companies compete in the global marketplace.

title: Many Ills, Constant Care, but Calling Her Own Shots
description: Verona Peters is clear: nursing homes are just not for her. Yes, she takes more than 300 pills a month and needs constant care for a litany of ailments: failing kidneys, high blood pressure, diabetes, congestive heart failure and a bout of diverticular bleeding. Yes, she undergoes dialysis, and the colostomy bag attached to her abdomen must be changed twice a week.

title: Fingers That Turn Back the Clock
description: The wristwatch may now be an anachronism. Need the time? Check your cellphone.

title: Giuseppe Quintarelli, Revered Vintner, Dies at 84
description: Giuseppe Quintarelli, a wine producer from the Veneto region of northeastern Italy whose Valpolicellas, reciotos and Amarones were revered by devoted followers all over the world, died Sunday at his home in Negrar, Italy. He was 84.

title: Danny Evins, Restaurant Founder and Focus of Controversy, Dies at 76
description: Danny Evins, who created Cracker Barrel Old Country Store, a restaurant heavy on grits and nostalgia, expanded it into a $2 billion chain and then fought a losing battle to discriminate against gay employees, died on Saturday in Lebanon, Tenn. He was 76.

title: The Invisible Hand Behind Bonuses on Wall Street
description: When asked about his job at cocktail parties, Alan Johnson has a curiosity-piquing line.

title: Battling Baseballs Decline in Puerto Rico
description: While the winter league proceeds with only four teams, hopes for the sports future rest in part on a baseball academy and school for young players on the island.

title: Where the Cruise Ship Crashed
description: The Costa Concordia cruise ship that partially sank near an Italian island may have been caused by human error.

title: A Countrys Frustration, Fueled Overnight
description: Lagos, Nigeria

title: Ravens Seek Offense Worthy of the Defense
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  The Baltimore Ravens coaching staff spent part of Monday reviewing film of their divisional-round victory from the day before, a valuable exercise but also a somewhat redundant one.

title: Taxes and Transparency
description: Barack Obama released his tax records when he ran for president in 2008. So did Richard Nixon in 1968. In fact, so did George Romney in that same campaign.

title: Hughes Gets One-Year Deal, but Future Isnt Secure
description: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the right-hander Phil Hughes on Monday by agreeing on a one-year, $3.2 million contract, with performance bonuses, for the 2012 season. But that may not be the final transaction for Hughes this year.

title: Convenient, but How Secure?
description: According to a survey commissioned by the American Bankers Association last year, 62 percent of Americans preferred to do their banking online rather than at a branch or ATM. Banks and their online customers also lost more than $2 billion in 2010 because of payment card scams, fraudulent wire transfers and other Internet swindles, according to data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as reported by The Financial Times.

title: A New Day in Suffolk? Heres Hoping
description: Suffolk County on Long Island got a new county executive this month, Steve Bellone. In his inaugural speech, he went down the list of things he intended to do, like fix the countys budget woes, hold the line on taxes, make government more efficient, create jobs and affordable housing, and invest in clean water infrastructure.

title: Suspect in Killings of Homeless Men Has Family Link to Homelessness
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif.  The man charged on Tuesday with the stabbing deaths four homeless men in Orange County over the last month, Itzcoatl Ocampo, has a personal connection to the areas group of homeless: his father lives among them.

title: Counting Voters Fairly
description: A Federal District Court late last month wisely upheld a 2010 Maryland law that counts prison inmates as residents in their home communities for purposes of redistricting, rather than at the prisons where they are incarcerated.

title: 9 Years Later, Sorry Still Doesnt Cut It
description: Matt Allen visited his friend Lawrence Tynes, the Giants kicker, at the teams practice facility last month. Allen  a former punter for the Giants who played with Tynes in college  recalled that as he walked through the building, he realized there were no active players remaining from his final N.F.L. game.

title: Black Voters Are Wary as Hopefuls Seek Kinship
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  On Martin Luther Kings Birthday, Newt Gingrich spoke to black voters about growing up in segregated Georgia.

title: At Cablevision, Expected to Install Everything Except a Union
description: They describe themselves as beaten-up workhorses, these burly fellows with linebacker shoulders and bass-register voices.

title: Querrey Set to Take On Tomic
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  When Sam Querrey of the United States flashed his slap forehand with a flourish Monday, he overwhelmed Kenny De Schepper of France, a qualifier, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

title: Lottery Numbers
Keep It Simple
description: What if Jamie Dimon is right?

title: Belgian Church Offices Raided in Abuse Inquiry
description: BRUSSELS  The Belgian authorities searched the offices of bishops in three cities on Monday, removing documents as part of an investigation into child sexual abuse that has plunged the countrys Roman Catholic church into crisis.

title: Giving Fox Viewers a Clear Window Into Officiating
description: The controversial call during a divisional playoff game between the Giants and the Green Bay Packers on Sunday looked like a perfect Mike Pereira moment. The Giants were leading in the first quarter, 10-3, and one game official ruled that Packers receiver Greg Jennings had fumbled the ball after a catch, but a second official said Jenningss calf was down before the ball came loose.

title: Perry Prods Romney on Tax Returns at Debate
description: Rick Perry just put Mitt Romney on the spot, urging him to release his tax returns.

title: Quietly Confident, Giants Quickly Look Ahead to N.F.C. Title Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants locker room was quiet on Monday. There was no hollering among teammates or loud music playing from the speakers. This is how the Giants operate, and it may explain why they are playing this late in the season.

title: No Closure for Denvers Beltway Loop
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  Breathes there a soul who really, truly, loves a beltway? Maybe, but you are not likely to find one here in this little city in the Rocky Mountain foothills west of Denver.

title: The Loneliness of the Guyanas
description: The coming weekend might very well be an historic one for Franco-Brazilian relations. Nicolas Sarkozy will be in French Guiana to deliver his annual New Years address to Frances overseas territories, in which he is likely to announce the opening of the bridge across the Oyapock River, French Guianas border with Brazil.

title: South Carolina Diarist
description: Sumter, S.C.

title: Struggling, Egypt Seeks Loan From I.M.F.
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers asked the International Monetary Fund on Monday for a $3.2 billion loan that they had previously rejected, bowing to the realities of a worsening economy nearly a year after the exit of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

title: A Sharp Exchange Between Santorum and Romney
description: An exchange between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum just now is a reflection of the tension that has built up between the two of them.

title: Gingrich on the Defensive at Debate
description: Its Newt Gingrich on the defensive right at the start about his attacks on Mitt Romney.

title: Jew Is Charged in Anti-Semitic Acts; Police Cite Business Dispute
description: In December, an 80-year-old Jewish woman in the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn received several phone calls in which the caller made anti-Semitic threats. On Thursday, a 78-year-old Jewish woman living nearby received a similar call.

title: Dilapidated Distinction for the Rangers Best
description: For the first time, the Broadway Hat, a black fedora with a ribbon and a bow, is making its way around the Rangers dressing room. No one can, or will, say where the hat came from. The rules for the hat are sketchy. And the looks of the hat are deteriorating.

title: Embracing the Pretzel
description: At debates his opponents sported ties with colors from the flag: blue or, better yet, blistering Republican red.

title: Invoking King, Cuomo and Bloomberg Stoke Fight on Teacher Review Impasse
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, each irate that a stalemate over teacher evaluations is endangering federal education aid, fixed their sights Monday on a shared opponent: what they derided as New York States education bureaucracy.

title: An Education, Over the Border and Under the Radar
description: Dozens of high school students cross from Tijuana, Mexico, into Southern California every day to attend American high schools.

title: Young U.S. Citizens in Mexico Brave Risks for American Schools
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  Weekday mornings at 5, when the lights on distant hillsides across the border still twinkle in the blackness, Martha, a high school senior, begins her arduous three-hour commute to school. She groggily unlocks the security gate guarded by the family Doberman and waits in the glare of the Pemex filling station for the bus to the border. Her fellow passengers, grown men with their arms folded, jostle her in their sleep.

title: Debate Fact-Check: Super PAC Coordination
description: When Mitt Romney was criticized tonight for attack ads that a super PAC supporting him has run against his opponents, he dismissed the suggestion that he could do anything about it.

title: Despite Long Slide by Kodak, Company Town Avoids Decay
description: ROCHESTER  In what was once the ultimate company town, virtually everyone has a trove of bright Kodak moments.

title: Britain: Nazi Game Led to Brawl, University Student Says
description: The London School of Economics said Monday that it was investigating allegations that a Nazi-themed drinking game during a student union ski trip to the French resort of Val dIsre last month led to a brawl in which a Jewish students nose was broken. The university, one of Britains most renowned academic institutions, said in a statement that it was prepared to take disciplinary action. The universitys student newspaper said the drinking game involved arranging playing cards on a table in the shape of a swastika, and that players were required to salute the Fhrer. The student who claimed to have been assaulted was not identified by the university, but The Guardian newspaper, quoting an interview with him, said that he had left the card game after a mix of personal references and general Jewish insults, that led him to conclude that I couldnt forgive myself if I let it slide. The university was shaken by controversy last year over its decision to accept a $450,000 donation for research from a foundation run by Saif al-Islam al-Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Can a Few Years Data Reveal Bad Teachers?
Tuesday: Deeply Impressed
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Elizabeth A. Long has had a few puzzles published in The New York Times each year since 2007, although todays grid is her first Tuesday. Now she has a puzzle for every day of the week, except weekends. So, Ms. Long: are you planning to bat for the cycle any time soon?

title: Nadal Mends Fences With Federer and Overcomes Knee Problem to Win
description: MELBOURNE  Perhaps Roger Federer had a point about the benefits of keeping negative thoughts out of the public domain. Only a day after Rafael Nadal deviated from a long-established pattern and ripped his friendly rival Federer at a news conference, Nadal sheepishly said that he regretted the outburst, still valued their connection and should have made his comments to Federer in private.

title: Debate Fact Check: Romneys 120,000 Jobs
description: While defending his record as a corporate buyout specialist at Bain Capital, Mitt Romney said tonight that companies he had invested in while at Bain ended up today having some 120,000 jobs. That number is slightly higher than the usual figure Mr. Romney cites on the campaign trail for job creation under Bains supervision  100,000  and neither number tells the full story.

title: A Development Test in Adirondack Park
description: Ballston Lake, N.Y.

title: Afghanistan: 3 U.S. Contractors Are Killed in Helicopter Crash
description: Three American private contractors working for the Defense Department were killed when their helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Monday, their company said. The contractors company, AAR Airlift, said that there were no other passengers on the helicopter and that the cause of the crash was not yet known. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the crash, but Marjan Haqmal, the chief of police of the Nad Ali district of Helmand Province, where the crash took place, said the helicopter had technical problems.

title: Debate Fact Check: Romney on Tax Returns
description: Mitt Romney declined to commit to release his income-tax returns when challenged twice, first by Gov. Rick Perry and then by a debate questioner, but said he might do so in April. Last month, he had said in an interview that he doubted that he would release the returns.

title: Romney Is Opponents Main Target in G.O.P. Debate
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Mitt Romney withstood forceful attacks during a debate here on Monday evening, with his Republican rivals lining up to question his job-creation record, wealth and character, as they implored voters to scrutinize his candidacy more deeply before allowing him to sail to the partys presidential nomination.

title: Growth Fell for China at Year End
description: BEIJING  Chinas economy slowed further in the fourth quarter of 2011, the government reported, lowering the growth in gross domestic product for the year to 9.2 percent, from 10.4 percent in 2010.

title: Mott Wins 3rd Eclipse Prize as the Nations Top Trainer
description: Bill Mott is a patient man, and it paid off for him Monday night when he was given his third Eclipse Award as the nations outstanding trainer.

description: A new proposal to slow global warming is extraordinary, John Tierney writes in The New York Times, because it would help poor countries now, and it might actually work.

description: Sydney Leroux, the U.C.L.A. striker who was the first pick in last weeks W.P.S. draft, was one of 20 players named to U.S. Soccers roster for the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament in Canada this month.

description: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates during Monday nights debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C.

title: With Bill, Washington State Shifts Its Views on Marriage
description: SEATTLE  The bill that would legalize same-sex marriage in Washington State is notable not just for the boldness of its ambition or for the fact that it was proposed by Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat whose last memorable remarks on the issue placed her firmly in the not-yet camp.

title: Channel Surfing: Betty Whites Off Their Rockers
description: Whats the best way to breathe new life into a tired television idea? Not turn it over to the Betty White generation, apparently.

title: Open Science, Numberplay style!
description: This weeks Science Times has a cover article by Thomas Lin about the open science movement, one of the whose ideas is that by collaborating over a large network, scientists can solve difficult problems much faster than they could alone. Thomas immediately realized that this is exactly the kind of problem-solving approach that happens every week on Numberplay. We have at various times referred to our unique communal problem-solving approach as a collaboratory and a microcosm of how science progresses. Thomas invited me to design a Numberplay problem that showcased this online collaboration.

description: Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator who has called himself the consistent conservative, released his first campaign ad that directly attacks Mitt Romney.

title: Stosur, U.S. Open Champion, Topples Out in Melbourne
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Samantha Stosur, the reigning United States Open champion, became the highest seed to fall from the Australian Open on Tuesday, losing her first-round match to Sorana Cirstea of Romania, 7-6 (2), 6-3, before a stunned partisan crowd at Rod Laver Arena.

title: Hasina Kharbhih: Raising the Stakes Against Child Trafficking
description: Hasina Kharbhih, 40, has spent the better part of her life working for human rights. She started a nonprofit, Impulse, and developed a comprehensive strategy to prevent child trafficking called the Meghalaya Model, which is being applied in eight Indian states. The activist, who is based in Shillong in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, was in Delhi earlier this month to receive a North East Excellence Award from the Indian Chamber of Commerce. The award honored her service in the field of human rights and trafficking, HIV and AIDS intervention, and for providing livelihood support for individuals in the rural areas of the northeast.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Newt Gingrich and the Art of Racial Politics
description: Thats the way I like to spend my Martin Luther King, Jr. Day: watching Newt Gingrich sneer at Juan Williams, a black man, for having the temerity to ask him if his condescending remarks about the work ethic of poor black people are indeed condescending:

title: U.S. Presses South Korea to Reduce Oil Imports from Iran
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A senior American diplomat urged South Korea on Tuesday to reduce its imports of Iranian crude oil as the United States continued to seek support from major Asian economies to increase pressure on Tehran to halt its nuclear program.

title: More Bodies Found on Ship, as Transcripts Reveal Rebuke to Captain
description: GIGLIO, Italy  Rescuers pulled five bodies clad in sodden life vests from the partly sunken cruise liner Costa Concordia on Tuesday, bringing the death toll in the disaster to at least 11, as the Italian news media published transcripts of a tense screaming match between the coast guard and the captain, who fled to a lifeboat after he smashed the ship on a reef.

title: Jan. 17, 1893 | Hawaiian Monarchy Overthrown by America-Backed Businessmen
description: On Jan. 17, 1893, Hawaiis monarchy was overthrown when a group of businessmen and sugar planters forced Queen Liliuokalani to abdicate. The coup led to the dissolving of the Kingdom of Hawaii two years later, its annexation as a U.S. territory and eventual admission as the 50th state in the union.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 17, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed article The Rise of the New Groupthink.

title: Lost and Alone Under Tokyos Red Rain
description: Soon after shooting memorial concerts on the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, my sister called to tell me that our father had died unexpectedly. Two days later, I returned to Japan for the first time in 20 years to attend his funeral. I felt constant vertigo, like I had been violently cut and pasted from New York to Tokyo.

description: An article about the dangers of yoga that appeared in the Sunday magazine of The New York Times this month inspired an outpouring of criticism in the United States and Britain.

title: Nearly 90,000 Minis Recalled for Fire Hazard
description: After an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Mini is recalling almost 89,000 of its turbocharged models because they could catch fire when the engine is off.

title: London Art Fair to Showcase Modern Works
description: Britains largest modern and contemporary art show, the London Art Fair, will present works from more than 120 major galleries from Jan. 18 through Jan. 22 at the Business Design Centre, 52 Upper Street. Novices will find themselves side-by-side with museum curators, gallery dealers and artists, all eager to see the paintings, drawings, large-scale sculpture, installations, photography and video on offer. Twenty-four thousand people attended last year.

title: 49ers Nostalgia: Revisiting Walsh and Montana
description: With the 49ers deep in the playoffs for the first time in a long time, its hard not to get a little nostalgic. In the video above, Bill Walsh, with Joe Montana going over some steps, explains the West Coast offense.

description: Group work  love it or hate it, its a regular part of the school or work day for many of us. Do you enjoy collaborating with your classmates on projects? Do you learn better as part of a group or by working independently? Do you prefer one style or the other? Why?

description: MELBOURNE  It is an Olympic year but also a year with two opportunities to win a prize that glitters at the All England Club, which is making for unusual behavior at the years first Grand Slam tournament.

title: With Redesign, a Special Retailer Tries to Create an Equally Special Web Site
description: Bi-Rite Market is something of an institution in San Francisco. A grocery store with a huge and faithful following, it doesnt see itself as just a grocery store. People actually line up on the street to get inside. The reviews for the store on Yelp are overwhelmingly positive. The homepage on the stores Web site proclaims, Bi-Rite is a neighborhood market, feeding our community with love, passion & integrity.

title: For Butler, a Slow Start
description: In 2010 and 2011, the Butler Bulldogs were college basketballs favorite Cinderella story. But this season has been a struggle. Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, will file occasional posts for The Quad about the teams efforts to return to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: British Maker of Recycled Packaging in $2 Billion Deal
description: LONDON  DS Smith, a British maker of recycled packaging, agreed on Tuesday to buy a packaging unit of Svenska Cellulosa of Sweden for $2 billion to expand its market share in Europe.

title: Olympus Clears Auditors in an Accounting Cover-Up
description: TOKYO  Olympus, the Japanese camera maker whose executives have admitted to covering up $1.7 billion in losses, said Tuesday that its auditors, KPMG Azsa and Ernst & Young ShinNihon, had not been complicit in the false accounting  though those firms remain under investigation by the Japanese authorities over possible roles in the scandal.

title: To Intervene or Not to Intervene?

title: On the Horizon, Planes Powered by Plant Fuel
description: The use of jet fuel from renewable sources is now well demonstrated, but it costs more than double what fuel made from petroleum does, according to airlines, aircraft companies and suppliers. One way to cut the cost may be to tinker with the plants that biofuel is made from.

title: Organizers Settle Dispute Over Fashion Week Dates
description: Just as the mens runway collections came to a close in Milan on Tuesday, organizers of the shows in New York and London announced that they have settled, for now, a dispute over the dates of the womens runway shows planned this September. The New York and London collections will not overlap with those of Milan, as had been risked by a standoff between the cities over when the season should begin.

title: European Court Rules Britain Cannot Deport Terrorism Suspect
description: LONDON  The European Court of Human Rights ruled Tuesday that Abu Qatada, a radical Islamic preacher regarded as one of Al Qaedas main inspirational leaders in Europe, cannot be deported from Britain to his native Jordan because his trial there would be tainted by evidence obtained by torture.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Plans to Name Names in Fight Against Worm
description: The computer worm known as Koobface was a menace to Facebook users over the past few years, and it played a role in sharpening Facebooks defenses against attackers of all kinds. Now Facebook is planning to disclose the names of the men it believes are behind the worm, Riva Richmond reports in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Gingrich Finds a Foil and Wikipedia Protests SOPA
description: The presidential debate in South Carolina Monday night  sponsored by Fox News, The Wall Street Journal and the state Republican Party  was notable for its raucous crowd. Newt Gingrich, who was considered by most analysts to have had a very successful night, seemed to revel in using one of the questioners, the Fox News analyst Juan Williams, as his foil, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write. Mr. Gingrich won loud, sustained applause when replying with mock impatience to Mr. Williams who pressed him about his call for schoolchildren to work as janitors, for his description of Mr. Obama as a food stamp president and remarks that Mr. Williams said, to loud boos, seemed intended to belittle the poor.

title: Cheryl Tyler: Something Worth Fighting For
Cuomo Ties State Aid to Teacher Evaluations
Vain Glorious | Borrowed From the Boys
description: Ive been wearing mens cologne since the day I was tall enough to reach for my fathers Van Cleef & Arpels Pour Homme. The striking black lacquered bottle held far more appeal than the delicate, glass-encased floral fragrances on my mothers vanity, as did the rich, intoxicating aroma. It appears my infatuation with masculine scents is more common than springs focus on hyper-feminine fragrances might lead us to believe. Here, five of the citys trendsetters reveal their own androgynous olfactory obsessions.Santa Maria Novella Acqua di Cuba CologneI wear this fragrance because it smells like the Maquis in Corsica, the island where I was born.  Garance Dor, photographer, illustrator and writer

title: A Bridesmaids Star on Naked Clowns and a Very Special Scene
description: If you saw Bridesmaids  or even if you saw it on the clip reel at the Golden Globes  theres probably one scene that sticks out. It did for Ricky Gervais, who introduced the Bridesmaids star Melissa McCarthy by reminding audiences of the moment when, in a pivotal scene in a wedding-dress shop, she defecated in a sink.

description: Jeremy Peters reports from Myrtle Beach on a day spent observing the preparations with the Fox News team ahead of Mondays presidential debate.

title: A Spare Lectern and Little Left to Chance at Republican Debate
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Jon M. Huntsman Jr.s sudden decision to quit the presidential race and endorse Mitt Romney left Fox News with an empty lectern on its debate stage and a gaping hole in its script Monday night. But it also left one of the debates moderators, Bret Baier, with a nagging feeling.

title: When Freedoms Ring Isnt a Cash Registers
description: You would have been hard-pressed to find a New York politician or civic leader who didnt feel duty-bound to invoke the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Monday, the day his birthday was observed. But there was one vital group of New Yorkers who, as usual, gave Dr. King a pass. They were those who keep this citys commerce humming.

title: Confusion and Then Anger Heard in Audio Recordings of Calls to Cruise Ship Captain

title: The Golden Age Of Impersonation
description: In the old days, impersonating someone was hard  you had to find some way to convince people in person that you were someone else, and it was especially hard if the individual you were trying to impersonate was fairly well known.

title: Literary Agent Helps Create Training Program at Syracuse for Arts Leaders
description: Having served on several cultural boards, the literary agent Morton L. Janklow found that many arts leaders lacked basic business skills necessary to manage their institutions. So he has spearheaded a new masters of arts degree program at Syracuse University, which is to be announced Tuesday.

title: Majority of Chinese Now Live in Cities
description: BEIJING  Chinas urban population exceeded its rural population in 2011 for the first time in the nations history, the governments National Bureau of Statistics reported, continuing a trend that has helped drive its rapid economic growth but poses an increasingly difficult social transition for scores of millions of Chinese.

title: Home-Field Advantage Losing Grip in N.F.L. Playoffs
description: We think of Lambeau Field as an impenetrable fortress come January. Visiting teams arent supposed to win playoff games there. Except that these days, they do. The Packers are 2-4 in their last six home playoff games. Theyre not the only ones.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: The Walt Disney Company is continuing its march toward the crib.

title: Look at Them All: George Harrisons Guitar Collection Gets iPad App
description: Though it has been some years since their owner left this plane of existence, the guitars of George Harrison need not weep for loneliness or lack of use: they are about to be shown off and shared in a new iPad app planned for release next month. On Tuesday the George Harrison estate said that it was working with Bandwdth Publishing, which makes applications for mobile devices, to create a virtual showroom of that singer-songwriters trove of guitars that will make use of many of his personal recordings.

title: Harrison Falls to Murray in Four Sets
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Murray of Britain overcame a faltering start to eliminate Ryan Harrison of the United States, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in a first-round match at the 2012 Australian Open.

title: Walid Chammah to Retire From Morgan Stanley
description: Walid A. Chammah, the chairman of Morgan Stanley International, is retiring, according to a memorandum sent on Tuesday to employees.

title: Milan Top 5 | Tom Ford
description: Tom Ford was in town to present a new fall collection that was surprisingly neutral in comparison to brighter seasons past. The handpicked house models walked around the hyper-elegant and intimate showroom so that the clothes most tactile qualities could be properly appreciated. Argentine coyote, which has a rougher texture that Ford prefers, topped the lapels of this luxurious tweed coat worn with the softest buttoned knit and a checked, pleated trouser, all in toffee brown tones.

title: On Our Radar: Capsized Ship Stirs Environmental Worries
description: With an estimated 2,380 metric tons of fuel on board, the wrecked Costa Concordia cruise ship is an ecological time bomb, the mayor of the Tuscan island of Giglio said. The waters are treasured by divers. A Dutch salvage vessel is expected to start removing the ships fuel within days; the process could take two to four weeks. [The Guardian]

title: TimesTalks | Neeson & Carnahan: Preview
description: The actor and director describe shooting their film The Grey in the frozen Canadian tundra, and talk about what they really think of each other.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Answering the Call
description: Part 7: The actor and director discuss whether The Grey has an environmentalist message, and talk about the arc of Liam Neesons character in the film.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: The Moral High Ground
description: Part 9: The actor and director reflect on the role of nature in The Grey, and talk about what they learned from observing the live trained wolves used in the film.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Digging Out the Set
description: Part 5: The actor and director describe how shooting The Grey in extreme cold weather transformed the way they worked.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Let Your Beard Freeze
description: Part 2: The actor and director recall how their experience making 2010s The A-Team led to their collaboration on The Grey.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Minus 30 Degrees
description: Part 4: The actor and director explain why they chose to shoot The Grey on location in freezing, unforgiving conditions.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: North of Belfast
description: Part 14: Joe Carnahan talks about his Pablo Escobar film project and the obstacles impeding its production; Liam Neeson reminisces about his upbringing and how he got into acting.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: The Shark in Jaws
description: Part 8: The actor and director talk about why the wolves in The Grey were portrayed using puppetry and animatronics instead of CGI.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actor Liam Neeson and the director Joe Carnahan.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: We Ate Wolf
description: Part 10: The actor and director describe what wolf meat tastes like and why they ate it.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Eh Joe
description: Part 13: Liam Neeson talks about his recent theater projects.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: A Lost Art Form
description: Part 6: The actor and director speak about why they admire each other and love working together.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: Snowshoes and a Whip
description: Part 12: The actor and director recall which book the entire cast of The Grey was instructed to read in preparation for the film, and talk about Liam Neesons unique approach to action film acting.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: On Taken
description: Part 11: The actor and director reflect on the success of Liam Neesons Taken films and speculate on why they appeal to audiences.

title: Neeson & Carnahan: A Mythical Quality
description: Part 3: The actor and director explain the story they wanted to tell through Liam Neesons character in The Grey, and discuss how Neeson prepared for his role.

title: Crackdown Continues on Activists in China
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities have charged another veteran human rights activist with attempting to subvert the state, the latest in a series of indictments or trials of well-known dissidents that have brought unusually stiff prison sentences and widespread condemnation abroad.

title: Ralcorp Outlines Post Cereals Spinoff
description: Ralcorp Holdings, the food conglomerate, announced on Tuesday that its board had approved the spinoff of its Post cereals business and offered new details on the structure of the separation.

title: A Date for the Tony Awards
description: The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. (Off Broadway and regional shows are not eligible.) The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30.

title: Bring Back the Lockout!
description: We interrupt this N.F.L. playoff season with the disturbing news that the N.B.A. season is going on. While the conclusion of the leagues shameful lockout did bring a few benefits, including festive Christmas Day openers and a blissfully shortened season, it turns out the benefits quickly developed downsides. Christmas Day was, alas, only one day. And the blissfully shortened season came with a microscopic preseason, creating teams with all the organization of New Jersey traffic, and has been condensed like a can of tomato soup. There are games on top of games on top of games, all held together by xanthan gum.

title: George Lucas, Hitmaker
description: On the set of Star Wars, Raiders of the Lost Ark and more.

title: George Lucas Is Ready to Roll the Credits
description: This was a new feeling for George Lucas. He made a movie about a plucky band of freedom fighters who battle an evil empire  a movie loaded with special effects like no one had seen before. Then he showed it to executives from all the Hollywood studios. And every one of them said, Nope.

title: In a Slugfest, Tsonga Defeats Istomin
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France outslugged Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5 on Tuesday night to gain the second round of the 2012 Australian Open.

title: Exploring the Arctic Circle by Kayak
description: A rugged trip around Ellesmere Island included fending off a 3,000-pound walrus.

title: Where the Sun Never Sets, a 1,500-Mile Trip by Sea Kayak
description: To stave off a breaching 3,000-pound walrus from the cockpit of a small sea kayak, Erik Boomer recommends using the paddle.

title: We Still Need To See Those Returns
description: Aha. Romney concedes that the estimates people have been making about his taxes are basically right:

title: Q&A: Fixing Those Ailing Laptop Keys
description: Q.

title: Dragon Tattoo and Bridesmaids Earn Editors Nods
description: LOS ANGELES  The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo and Bridesmaids may have been shut out at the Golden Globes, but they are still very much a part of the Oscar conversation, as evidenced by the American Cinema Editors nominations, announced on Monday. Both films made the cut, along with other Oscar favorites like The Descendants, Hugo, The Artist, Midnight in Paris, Moneyball and War Horse, which has otherwise been faltering lately. An editing award is considered a must for a best-picture win at the Oscars  no film has received that top prize without at least an editing nomination since 1981  and the editors group has a lot of overlap with the Academy voters in its membership, so its choices are usually an above-average predictor.

title: Bruno Senna Joins Williams Team
description: Williams announced Tuesday that Bruno Senna would drive for the team in 2012. The announcement carried far more emotional undertone than any other so far this year as Williams was the team for which Sennas uncle, Ayrton Senna, was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy, in 1994.

title: Bruno Senna Joins Williams Team
description: Williams announced Tuesday that Bruno Senna would drive for the team in 2012. The announcement carried far more emotional undertone than any other so far this year as Williams was the team for which Sennas uncle, Ayrton Senna, was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy, in 1994.

title: Dsquared2 Mens
description: Milan.

title: Runway in Review
description: Alexander McQueenDesigner: Sarah BurtonDate and Location: Monday, Jan. 16, Spazio Revel, Via Thaon de Revel, 3Photos: slide show

title: Romney Says His Effective Tax Rate Is About 15 Percent
description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated FLORENCE, S.C.  After speaking to a smaller-than-usual crowd on Tuesday morning in Florence, S.C., Mitt Romney took questions from the press and said that his effective tax rate was about 15 percent.

title: As States Weigh Online Gambling, Profit May Be Small
description: It has been more than four decades since states began putting numbers runners out of business by starting their own legal lotteries, which now yield them close to $18 billion a year. Now several states are thinking about trying to plug budget gaps by profiting again from their residents optimism  by legalizing, licensing and taxing Internet gambling.

title: Breaking Riskes Serve, Radwanska Prevails
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In the final match of a long day on a distant outside court, Alison Riske of the United States battled for nearly two-and-a-half hours before falling to Urzula Radwanska of Poland.

title: Romney Shares Some Tax Data; Critics Pounce
description: Under growing pressure from rival Republicans to release his tax returns, Mitt Romney said on Tuesday that he paid a tax rate approaching 15 percent on his millions of dollars in annual income but said he would not make public his full return until April.

title: Allstate Offers Credit to Clients Unhappy With Claims Service
description: Allstate says that if its car insurance customers arent satisfied with the service they received on a paid claim, they can get a credit for six months of auto premiums for the car in question.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: What does Joe Flacco have to do to beat the Patriots? What do the Giants have to do to stop Alex Smith? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

title: Hearing Begins on Israeli Foreign Minister
description: JERUSALEM  Israels state prosecutors began a hearing on Tuesday to decide whether to indict Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman on charges of fraud, breach of trust and money laundering, a move that could shake up Israeli politics and lead to early elections.

title: Wheelies: The Damage Control Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Welcome to Rendezvous
description: Rendezvous is the digital gathering place for the globally engaged  in particular, the readers and fans of the International Herald Tribune, the global edition of The New York Times, people who care about global issues, in politics, economics and business or the arts, culture, travel and style.

title: Giorgio Armani Mens
description: Milan.

title: In Denver, Patience Is Paying Off for the Nuggets
description: DENVER  There are traditional, tried-and-true methods of rebuilding a team. There is the draft-and-wait philosophy, which has the Oklahoma City Thunder poised for a long stay among the N.B.A.s elite. There is the future-is-now credo that propelled the Boston Celtics from a 15-year rut without a 50-victory season to 234 wins over the last four years, two finals appearances and a title.

title: Romney Calls Voters, With an Old Message From Santorum
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Rick Santorum has tried to soft-pedal his endorsement of Mitt Romney in 2008, saying he did so because he preferred Mr. Romney to the leading Republican alternative at the time, Senator John McCain.

title: Obama to Accept Nomination in Stadium After Shortened Convention
description: President Obama once again will accept the Democratic presidential nomination from a football stadium to accommodate tens of thousands more supporters, and after a shorter-than-usual convention, convention planners announced on Tuesday.

title: Helping Teachers Stand Up for Science
description: Two years ago I wrote about a nascent alliance between people who oppose teaching evolution in the schools and those who oppose teaching about the role of human activity in climate change.

title: Holidays in the Deep South
description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

title: Money Low, Occupy Wall St. Tightens Budget
description: With donations to Occupy Wall Street falling significantly and money starting to run low, the movement has imposed a partial spending freezeto make sure enough money is available for crucial functions like bailing protesters out of jail.

title: In S.E.C.s Actions, a Hint at a Tougher Stance
description: One of the criticisms that has been leveled against the Securities and Exchange Commission is that even when it has pursued cases, it has not been tough enough in seeking sanctions for violations of the federal securities laws. Since the new year began, however, it seems that the agency has taken a couple of small steps to burnish its image as Wall Streets top cop.

title: Knicks Idling, Waiting for Baron Davis
description: Perhaps more than any other N.B.A. team, the Knicks have fostered a reputation for laying franchise fortune at the feet of superstars either in the midst of  or well past  their primes: Bob McAdoo, Spencer Haywood, Stephon Marbury, Steve Francis, Amare Stoudemire, Carmelo Anthony and, most recently, Tyson Chandler.

title: Tomics Most Important Skill? His Temperament
description: I watched Bernard Tomic come back from two sets down to beat Fernando Verdasco, and marveled at his quirky, inventive game. He reminds me of Andy Murray, with his ability to hold the ball on his strings a little longer to disguise his shots, his superb anticipation, and his use of different spins and heights to confuse and confound more powerful opponents.

title: Chef Has Diabetes, and Some Say I Told You So
description: FOR 10 years, wielding slabs of cream cheese and mounds of mayonnaise, Paula Deen has become televisions self-crowned queen of Southern cuisine and one of the countrys most popular chefs, with an empire built on layers of gooey butter cake, fried chicken and sheer force of personality.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each Monday. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Diesel Black Gold Mens
description: Milan.

title: Late Show Replaces Its Longtime Comedy Booker
description: 4:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, part of WPP, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010. The drop came after two years of increases, of 8 percent in 2009 and 7.2 percent in 2010. The amount of promotion pages from retailers that appeared in the inserts, which are typically carried in Sunday newspapers, rose 30.7 percent last year compared with 2010, the report said; the retailers included Walmart, Dollar General, Target and Walgreens.

title: Ship Salvage Workers Roll Up Their Sleeves
description: A Dutch marine salvage company prepared on Tuesday to begin pumping half a million gallons of fuel from the stricken cruise ship Costa Concordia, the first step toward hauling the luxury liner away for a complete overhaul or cutting it up for scrap.

title: At Least 34 People Killed in Syria as Monitors Are Unable to Quell Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Violence surged in Syria on Tuesday as activists reported that at least 34 people had been killed in several towns and cities across the country, including six soldiers who had defected and three members of the security forces.

title: The South Carolina Debate and G.O.P. Golden Oldies
description: The people of South Carolina should be grateful. The Republicans competing for their partys nomination are subjecting them to only two of the carnival sideshows that pass for presidential debates. The first was Monday night and the second will be on Thursday.

title: A New Pastry Chef for Le Bernardin
description: Eric Ripert, the exectuive chef and a partner in Le Bernardin, has hired Laurie Jon Moran as its new pastry chef. He replaces Michael Laiskonis, who left, as planned, on Dec. 31 to pursue opportunites outside the restaurant world. Mr. Moran, 30, is from England, where he worked at Le Manoir aux QuatSaisons near Oxford, before joining Daniel here. Most recently he was pastry sous-chef at Per Se.

title: Former Marketing Executive to Lead Formula One Grand Prix Into New Jersey
description: Tom Cotter, a former motorsports marketing entrepreneur who has worked as an automotive writer for the last decade, was named the president of the Formula One Grand Prix of America at Port Imperial on Tuesday. He will be charged with executing the contract to bring a Formula One race to New Jersey in June 2013.

title: The Artist and Tinker, Tailor Top British Nominations
description: The Artist and Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy were the heavies with the Bafta crowd, the British answer to the Oscars, whose members announced their picks today. The Artist earned 12 nominations and Tinker, Tailor, 11. Hugo was close on their heels with 9; My Week With Marilyn, The Help and War Horse all also fared well.

title: TVs Game of Three-Card Monte
description: Alcatraz, a new show from J.J. Abrams, had its premiere last night, and it bears all the earmarks of an Abrams project: tantalizing mysteries, befuddling questions, whispered promises of startling revelations just over the horizon.

title: Which Paula Deen Recipe Tops Them All?
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: Perrys Inaccurate Remark on Turkey Draws Rebuke
description: In Monday nights Republican debate in South Carolina, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas described the leaders of Turkey as Islamic terrorists, an inaccurate characterization that drew a swift rebuke from the Turkish government.

title: Brand Seeks to Make Childs Play of Cooking
description: The Uncle Bens line of rice products is extending a campaign that carries the theme Begin With Ben to a group of consumers who, the brand hopes, are just beginning to cook.
