title: TimesCast | January 17, 2012
description: A recorded telephone call reveals that the captain of the Costa Concordia abandoned ship | Wikipedia and others plan blackouts to protest Web piracy bills.

title: When Parents Can Opt Out of School Curriculums
description: Once upon a time in Bedford, N.H., a teacher in a high school personal finance class set out to educate her students on what day-to-day life was like in a minimum wage job. The teacher assigned the students to read Barbara Ehrenreichs Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting by in America. Heres Ms. Ehrenreich on her time working as a member of a corporate housekeeping team:

title: Yemeni Official Suggests Delay in Presidential Vote
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Adding to fears of a worsening political crisis in Yemen, a top government official hinted at a possible delay in presidential elections set for February that would mark the formal end of President Ali Abdullah Salehs 33-year rule.

title: UniCredit Gaining Investor Support for $9.6 Billion Rights Issue
description: LONDON  Aabar Investments, an investment vehicle for Abu Dhabis sovereign wealth fund, said on Tuesday that it would increase its stake in the Italian bank UniCredit to 6.5 percent from 5 percent after the Milan-based firm completes a so-called rights offering at the end of the month. The deal would make Aabar the largest individual investor in UniCredit.

title: Morgan Stanley Is Said to Cap Cash Bonuses at $125,000
description: Morgan Stanley employees may want to put their kitchen renovations off until next year.

title: In Portugal, Mirandese Spoken Here  and Only Here
description: An old woman in a plain gray dress and a shopping bag full of oblong orange squashes called out to me from down the street. I had no idea what she was saying  and that couldnt have made me happier. After all, I had come to her rural village  Malhadas, in the northeast corner of Portugal  with the specific hope of not understanding anyone.

title: Santorum Says He May Have Won in Iowa
description: 2:43 p.m. | Updated Rick Santorum expressed new hope on Tuesday that the final vote count in the Iowa caucuses might show that he  not Mitt Romney  actually won there by a small margin.

title: Red Wings and Sabres Go in Different Directions
description: The contrast couldnt have been more striking on Monday evening: the Detroit Red Wings, streaking to a 15th-straight win at Joe Louis Arena, and the Buffalo Sabres continuing to slump to new depths. The Red Wings crushed the Sabres, 5-0, thanks to a flurry of three first-period goals.

title: Gin-Infused Celery
description: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of Modernist Cuisine, and Melissa Clark infuse celery sticks with gin.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Tom Robbins on Judith Clark
description: Tom Robbins, who wrote Sundays cover story on the Brinks robbery accomplices transformation in prison, is a former reporter for The Daily News and The Village Voice. He now teaches investigative reporting at CUNYs Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Seared Frozen Steak
description: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of Modernist Cuisine, shows Melissa Clark his method for preparing seared steak.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, with rhythmic gymnastics in England, bulls in India and cycling in Australia.

title: Indictment for Man Accused in White House Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  A federal grand jury in Washington on Tuesday indicted the man arrested after shots were fired at the White House in November, charging him with attempting to assassinate President Obama along with 16 assault and firearms counts.

title: Mens Designers Get Their Pelts
description: Despite the latest signs of continued economic turmoil in Europe, mens wear designers are not shying away from on luxury fabrics for fall, what with all the press notes about vicua and cashmere. One unexpected, and very expensive, material that turned up in several collections in Milan was astrakhan, a fairly controversial fur that is also known as Persian lamb, made from the skins of newborn (and sometimes unborn) lambs.

title: Magic/Bird To Land at the Longacre Theater
description: Magic/Bird, Eric Simonsons play about the rivalry and friendship between Larry Bird, the former Boston Celtics forward, and Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, has a Broadway theater and a complete cast. The play, to be directed by Thomas Kail, will open on April 11 at the Longacre Theater, the shows producers announced Tuesday. Previews begin March 21.

title: For Indias Army, Age Dispute Rattles Leadership
description: NEW DELHI  Certainly, Indias army already has plenty to keep it busy. To the northeast lies China, which is quietly but rapidly expanding its military presence along the border. To the northwest lies nuclear-armed Pakistan, which has already fought three wars with India and is now wobbling with political instability.

title: Daviss Performance Recalls Winslows Epic Day
description: It is fitting that in the Year of the Tight End, two of the greatest postseason performances by a player at that position would occur.

title: Too Dandy for Tough Times  Or Is Couture the Cure?
description: Alexander McQueen is dead but not gone. True to its corset-and-drama heritage, the brand is teaming with the traditional Savile Row tailor Huntsman to create a made-to-order suit service. The designer Sarah Burton announced the move in Milan during the mens wear autumn 2012 season, writes Suzy Menkes, the IHT fashion editor, where the tilt in mens fashion toward formal and evening wear is being confirmed every day.

title: Media Decoder | Web Sites to Go Dark
description: January 17, 2012  Wikipedia and other Web sites plan Wednesday blackouts to protest two Congressional web piracy bills.

title: Gingrich Pokes Romney on Taxes
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Newt Gingrich poked fun at Mitt Romneys acknowledgment on Tuesday that he paid about a 15 percent tax rate because his income was largely returns on investments.

title: Prized Quarterback Shifts To Notre Dame From L.S.U.
description: The Notre Dame football season ended on a sour note, with a pair of losses and Ohio States poaching two of the teams assistant coaches.

title: Digital Notes: Royalties for Streaming Music Grew 17% in 2011
description: Royalties Increase for Streaming: SoundExchange, the agency that compensates performers and record labels when music is played on satellite and Internet radio, paid $292 million in royalties last year, up 17 percent from 2010, the group announced. SoundExchange signed up 15,300 new artists and labels last year, yet the agency is still often criticized in the music industry for holding back royalties from unregistered acts and has faced challenges from its biggest contributor, Sirius XM Radio.

title: Even Big Companies Cannot Protect Their Data
description: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast | Cruise Captain Abandons Ship
description: January 17, 2012  A recorded telephone conversation with Francesco Schettino, captain of the Costa Concordia, reveals that he abandoned the cruise ship long before all passengers had been evacuated.

title: In Cuomos Budget, Nip-and-Tuck Cuts and Big Policy Aims
description: ALBANY  Presenting what he called both a budget and a reform plan, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday asked legislators to demand more rigorous teacher evaluations, to restrict pension benefits for future public employees, and to slightly reduce overall state spending by consolidating the state bureaucracy.

title: 32,100 and Counting: New Yorkers Speak Out on Fracking
description: Officials with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation say they have counted 32,100 statements so far since the close of a public comment period on Wednesday on their proposal to allow hydrofracking in the state.

title: Frances Oscar Hopes Depend on Its Health Care System
description: Other than Italy, no country has a better track record with the Academy Award for best foreign-language film than France, which has received 36 nominations and 12 Oscars (with 27 and 13 for Italy). But last years competition was disappointing for the French: the highly acclaimed Of Gods and Men, which won the Grand Prix at Cannes, failed even to make the shortlist, while an Algerian film set in France and spoken largely in French, Outside the Law, was one of the five finalists.

title: What Start-Ups Can Learn From a Crime Boss
description: What lurks in the hearts of mild-mannered software developers? Donald DeSantiss answer may surprise you. The 29-year-old Seattle techie recently penned a tale of unlikely inspiration called Everything I need to know about start-ups, I learned from a crime boss.

title: Mitt Romneys Taxes
description: Having suggested at Monday nights debate that he would release his 2011 tax returns in April, Mitt Romney must have realized he would need to inoculate himself against the inevitable public backlash over his annual income, where it comes from and how little tax he pays on it. He started this process Tuesday morning, when he told reporters in South Carolina that his effective tax rate is about 15 percent.

title: High-Tech Cocktail Lounge Is Opening at Momofuku Ssam Bar
description: A little liquid nitrogen with your manhattan? Warm up that drink with a foot-tall flame?

title: A Founder of Noma Is the Chef at Acme
description: The way Jean-Marc Houmard tells it, Mads Refslund, a founder of the world-famous Noma in Copenhagen, was in New York on vacation last summer, dining at Bond St., one of the downtown restaurants in which Mr. Houmard is a partner. We hit it off, Mr. Houmard said. At that time we were looking for a chef and we convinced him to drop something he was doing in Copenhagen.

title: Carr and Stelter on Wikipedias Day of Protest
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter, in this TimesCast video, discuss the decision by Wikipedia to close on Wednesday to educate its audience about proposed antipiracy legislation in Congress that it considers a threat to an open Internet. Time to crack open those old copies of Encyclopedia Britannica.

title: Caldwell Fired as Colts House-Cleaning Continues
description: The Colts announced the firing of Coach Jim Caldwell on Tuesday in perhaps the least-surprising move of the teams rebuilding following their 2-14 season.

title: A Le Mans-Winning 1960 Corvette Finds Fame in a Sequel
description: PHOENIX  In June 1960, four Chevrolet Corvettes were entered in the 24 Hours of Le Mans. One of them eventually became the first American vehicle to win its class in the endurance test, held annually on the famed circuit in France.

title: Your Moneys Worth: Examining Facts and Attitudes About Income Inequality
description: Overview | What does income inequality say about contemporary American society? What should be done to address income inequality? In this lesson, students examine Times infographics about income and wealth distribution in the United States and discuss what this information says about society.

title: Mushroom and Herb Omelet
description: Mushroom omelets are my favorite type of omelet. You can get fancy with them and use wild mushrooms, but its much more economical and equally satisfying to make them with cultivated creminis or white button mushrooms.

title: Los Angeles Mandates Use of Condoms for Sex Films
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles City Council approved a new mandate Tuesday requiring all actors in pornographic films to wear condoms during any filming that takes place within city limits. The law is the first of its kind in the country, advocates said, and could have a significant impact on what some say is a $1 billion industry.

title: In Grand Forks, 11 Goals, 16 Penalties, and Dead Gophers on the Ice
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Police Seek Thieves Impersonating Detectives
description: The three men said they were police detectives, but by the time they left a womans apartment in the Bronx it was clear that they were something else entirely: thieves.

title: Romera New York
description: Inside the restaurant that Dr. Miguel Snchez Romera, a Spanish neurologist turned chef, opened at the Dream Downtown hotel.

title: A Feast for the Eyes, at Least
description: THE first thing I ate at Romera New York was a jam of black olives and tomatoes. Sticky, sweet and salty, it made a fine spread for the warm roll that came with it, and it was just as appealing eaten with a spoon.

title: Obesity Rates Stall, But No Decline
description: After two decades of steady increases, obesity rates in adults and children in the United States have remained largely unchanged during the past 12 years, a finding that suggests national efforts at promoting healthful eating and exercise are having little effect on the overweight.

title: European Union Acts to Halt Hungarian Laws
description: BRUSSELS  Reawakening a debate on what the European Union should do when one of its members threatens its democratic principles, the blocs executive arm opened legal proceedings on Tuesday against Hungary, which critics contend is sliding toward authoritarianism.

title: Photos of the Moment | DSquared2
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Europe Leans Toward Blocking NYSE-Deutsche Borse Merger
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Alcatraz Could Be a Breakout Hit for Fox
description: The series premiere of Alcatraz  which features a crack investigative team tracking former inmates of the infamous prison  managed to capture a large portion of the broadcast audience for Fox on Monday night. The new drama averaged 10 million viewers and outperformed the premiere of the previous time slot occupant, Terra Nova, in the 18-to-49 demographic, according to Nielsen data. The numbers also remained consistent throughout the two-hour period, suggesting viewers liked what they saw.

title: Measuring the Top 1% by Wealth, Not Income
description: After our demographic profile of the 1 percent appeared on Sunday, there were a lot of questions from readers about the top 1 percent by wealth, rather than the measure we used, the top 1 percent by income.

title: After Years of Decline, Polio Cases in Afghanistan Triple in a Year
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It has often been called the polio cease-fire.

title: A Fresh Look at Nuclear Power, from Fukushima to the Hudson
description: Tonight, the PBS program Frontline is running Nuclear Aftershocks, a 50-minute documentary examining the implications of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear calamity for the future of nuclear power in the United States and elsewhere.

title: Cuomo's Budget Targets Evaluations, Busing and Special Ed
Israels Clash of Civilizations
description: Women carefully guarded. Women scientists barred from speaking at podiums. Ultra-Orthodox men spitting on an 8-year-old girl deemed immodestly dressed.

title: Billy Crystals Oscar Reunion
description: If anyone was still wondering whether this years Oscar telecast, hosted by Billy Crystal, would be something of a nostalgia-fest, the answer is as certain and as dependably comforting, as a Betty White birthday joke. In a new behind-the-scenes video released by the Academy, Mr. Crystal ruminates on the pressure of returning to host  theres so much expected of this, he says  and, though he wouldnt reveal anything about his opening monologue (a magician never tells his tricks) he did offer some spoilers about the direction of the program. I think thats going to be a theme of the evening  how did you fall in love with movies? he says. Its a common experience we all have. We have to celebrate that more.

title: Mets Owners Can Look Forward to Trial During Spring Training
description: Judge Jed S. Rakoffs ruling on Tuesday was full of case citations, legal reasoning, a Yogi Berra quotation and a reference to the hijacked Achille Lauro cruise ship.

title: Inspector General to Leave S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  The inspector general of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who has been a thorn in the side of the agency over its fumbling of early inquiries into the Madoff and Stanford cases, will leave the commission at the end of January to join a private investigations firm.

title: Romney Disclosure Reignites Debate Over Carried Interest
description: The carried interest tax debate that has raged in Congress and on Wall Street over the last half-decade took center stage in the presidential race on Tuesday.

title: Tips on Shopping for Energy-Efficient Bulbs
description: How many types of light bulbs does it take to confuse consumers? Three, apparently.

title: Mets Sign Pelfrey, Ramirez, Acosta and Torres, Avoiding Arbitration
description: The Mets avoided hearings with four players eligible for salary arbitration after reaching one-year agreements with starter Mike Pelfrey, relievers Ramon Ramirez and Manny Acosta, and center fielder Andres Torres, the team announced Tuesday.

title: Turkish Verdict in 2007 Murder of Editor Fuels Outrage
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish court convicted one man on Tuesday of instigating the 2007 murder of a prominent editor, but acquitted all 19 suspects on charges of being members of a terrorist organization, rejecting claims that the murder was an act of conspiracy by an illegal network within the Turkish state.

title: Photos of the Moment | Giorgio Armani
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Officers Workaday, Work-a-Night Lives, Far From Movie Glamour
description: When our culture represents police officers, its usually a good cop-bad cop situation. With notable exceptions, like the characters in The Wire, those who enforce the law are typically noble or corrupt, glamorous detectives or dirty dealers.

title: Open Science And The Econoblogosphere
description: Interesting article in the Times about the push for open science, bypassing the traditional structure of refereed journals in favor of a sort of fluid, self-policing online community. I cant and wont weigh in on this issue with regards to hard science, but I think there are some interesting parallels with what has been happening in economics.

title: Wells Fargo Stands Out With Trading Gains
description: Wall Street banks reporting poor trading results might want to take some tips from Wells Fargo & Company.

title: Turns Out You Can Find Good Bosses These Days
description: Maybe Cate Ryan means The Picture Box to be the anti-Help.

title: Police Working on Technology to Detect Concealed Guns
description: For years, detectives trying to distinguish gun-carrying New Yorkers from others have had to rely on observations, street smarts and luck. A man with a gun on his hip might grab the front of his sport coat to keep it from flapping open and revealing the pistol. Someone getting out of a cab might hold tight to his side, to keep a weapon secure.

title: A 1731 Morality Tale That Aged Well, Unlike Its Characters
description: The long title of the play: The London Merchant, or the History of George Barnwell. The short review: excellent.

title: Sewanee, the University of the South, Announces a Rare, Four-Year Tuition Guarantee
description: The University of the South, a liberal arts college also known as Sewanee, announced Tuesday that it would guarantee a four-year rate of tuition, room and board for the class entering the university next fall. Sewanees board of regents set the annual tuition and fees for incoming students at $44,630, and it should hold steady through the Spring 2016 semesters for students starting in 2012, the university said.

title: Court Rejects Candidates Effort to Appear on Virginia Ballot
description: A federal appeals court in Virginia on Tuesday denied another effort by several Republican presidential candidates to appear on the states primary ballot.

title: Organizers Say 1 Million Signed Petition to Recall Wisconsin Governor
description: Critics of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin submitted to the state on Tuesday more than a million signatures, nearly twice as many as required, on recall petitions against him to force a new election.

title: Iran Offers U.S. Tiny Replica of Lost Drone
description: While Irans government has so far refused an American request to return the C.I.A. stealth drone it captured last month, on Tuesday, an Iranian company that is manufacturing miniature replicas of the drone in several colors offered to send President Obama a pink one.

title: Pressure-Cooked Butternut Squash
description: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of Modernist Cuisine, and Melissa Clark demonstrate how to make butternut squash pure using a pressure cooker.

title: Obama Taps Lew Deputy to Head Budget Office
description: President Obama on Tuesday promoted the deputy director of his budget office, Jeffrey Zients, to be acting director when Jacob J. Lew, the current budget director, becomes the White House chief of staff later this month.

title: Simple Sous Vide Salmon
description: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of Modernist Cuisine, and Melissa Clark demonstrate how to prepare simple sous vide salmon at home.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, India, Italy and Iraq.

title: Sizing Up the Top 25
description: Each week The Quad will analyze the top 25 N.C.A.A. teams (rankings and results are from The Associated Press).

title: After Space Probes Failure, Russia Looks to U.S. Radar
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials said on Tuesday that they were investigating whether powerful American radar systems might have caused the failure of a $170 million scientific probe headed for a moon of Mars.

title: Yahoos Jerry Yang Resigns From Board
description: Yahoo announced on Tuesday that Jerry Yang, a co-founder and board member, had stepped down from the board effective immediately. He has also resigned from the boards of Yahoo Japan and the Alibaba Group.

title: Questions Fly Over a Flag Flown Upside Down
description: International incident avoided!

title: Pennsylvania Republican Abides by Term-Limit Pledge
description: Representative Todd R. Platts, a Republican from York, Pa., will not seek a seventh term this year, abiding by the 12-year term limit he has pushed for in Congress.

title: The (Solar) Light at the End of the Tunnel
description: A consultant for the Defense Department reports that introducing solar installations on nine military bases in the Mojave and Colorado Desert could generate 7,000 megawatts of power.

title: Coming Soon | Double-Breasted Suits
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Paul to Break From Trail for Debt Ceiling Vote
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Representative Ron Paul of Texas is taking a day off from campaigning on Wednesday to return to Washington to vote against an increase in the nations debt ceiling, forgoing a day on the hard-fought trail just three days before South Carolinas presidential primary.

title: Porgy and Bess Director Will Take on Cirque du Soleil Next
description: Diane Paulus is moving from Catfish Row to a mysterious island. The producers of Cirque du Soleil announced this week that Ms. Paulus, the director of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess, which just opened on Broadway, is set to direct Amaluna, the companys latest touring spectacle, which will open in Montreal on April 19 before moving to Quebec City and Toronto.

title: Sorcerers Apprentice Hosts a Dinner
description: MY friends were perplexed when I invited them over for a dinner party based entirely on recipes from Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking, the multivolume examination of avant-garde cooking and culinary technology.

title: Protest Vote Set on Debt Ceiling
description: There is no showdown on the horizon on whether to raise the debt ceiling, but a mini-legislative sign of disapproval is nigh.

title: Todays Scuttlebot:  AC Adapters, and Watching Out for Text Neck
description: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: The Agony Behind an Erotic Clubs Ecstasy
description: Crazy Horse, Frederick Wisemans new documentary, invites the viewer to contemplate the intricacies of the creative process, the daily rhythms of a complex organization and the tensions between artistic ambition and practicality  and also to look at very beautiful women wearing very little.

title: Capital Gains: Romney and the 1%
description: Few aspects of the division between the 1 percent and the 99 percent have proven so divisive as the fact that the rich often pay a lower tax rate than everybody else. That is because the top federal tax rate on capital gains income is 15 percent, compared with a top marginal tax rate of 35 percent on other taxable income, like wages and salaries, that exceeds $380,000 a year.

title: Robo-Learning and Making Science Fun
Gingrich's Plan to Turn Students Into City School Cleaners? Only in the Movies
Moncler Gamme Bleu Mens
description: Milan.

title: Technology Helps Sundance Films Capture the Moment
description: LOS ANGELES  If the Sundance Film Festival is a mirror of America, this years installment depicts an unusually stark image of a broken place filled with broken people.

title: The Great Wikipedia Blackout of 2012: The Media Try to Fill the Void
description: 6:10 p.m. | Updated Our friends at The Washington Post announced an ambitious plan to fill the void during the Great Wikipedia Blackout of 2012: a Twitter campaign to answer Internet users questions,  la Wikipedia.

title: Clsico Overload? Is That Possible?
description: Could a Real Madrid-Barcelona clsico ever be considered to be passico (with apologies to the city of Passaic, N.J., a place where I worked many, many years ago)?

title: The Hiss of Steampunk, the Roar of the Digital Judge
description: The residency program at the Here Arts Center in the South Village encourages composers, choreographers, playwrights, video artists and even puppeteers to get into one anothers business and to create freewheeling hybrids. It is an ideal home for a musician like Kamala Sankaram.

title: Cruise Ship Accident Stirs Thoughts of the Andrea Doria
description: First thing Saturday, Pierette Domenica Simpsons boyfriend called and said, Go online. Youll be interested.

title: In the Kitchen With Nathan Myhrvold
description: Nathan Myhrvold, the co-author of Modernist Cuisine, visits Melissa Clark, preparing his simple sous vide salmon, gin-infused celery, seared steak and pressure-cooked butternut squash.

title: Does Elizabeth Warren Read My Blog?
description: In a Thursday blog post on (the obscene amount of) money in politics, I noted that Elizabeth Warren, whos running for Senate in Massachusetts, raised $5.7 million in the last three months of 2011, while the Republican incumbent, Scott Brown, raised $3.2 million. In the very next paragraph I suggested that individual Democrats around the country should formally pledge to run transparent campaigns so long as the other guy pledges the same.

title: Spider-Man Producers Sue Taymor for Breach
description: Using caustic private e-mails as weapons, the producers of the popular Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark marshaled a muscular counteroffensive in federal court in Manhattan on Tuesday against a lawsuit by Julie Taymor, the $75 million shows former director. In it they essentially seek to erase Ms. Taymor from the Spider-Man universe going forward.

title: Recalling When Nighttime Was Dark
description: A documentary about light pollution that is entertaining and thought-provoking? It hardly seems possible, but thats what Ian Cheney has made in The City Dark.

title: Former Challenger to Barney Frank to Run in 2012
description: Sean Bielat, a Republican who ran an aggressive race against Representative Barney Frank in 2010, said Tuesday that he would again seek the seat in Massachusetts 4th Congressional District.

title: Anne Frank, Still Writing in the Attic
description: At the start of Shalom Auslanders staggeringly nervy new novel Hope: A Tragedy, a doleful Jewish non-farmer named Solomon Kugel climbs fearfully into the attic of his recently acquired farmhouse. He hopes the tapping sounds in the attic are being made by nothing worse than mice.

title: Beyond the Brightest Searchlights, Other Cases of the Lost
description: As the new series Find Our Missing begins, S. Epatha Merkerson  still recognizable as Lieutenant Van Buren from Law & Order, despite the braids in her hair  says, Its a mystery that has confounded family, friends and the police.

title: Modernist Dishes for a Dinner Party
description: Melissa Clark, a columnist for The Times, prepares a menu based entirely on recipes from Modernist Cuisine, the multivolume avant-garde cookbook.

title: Surviving a Big Risk on Fifth Avenue
description: The Kushner Companies purchase in 2007 of 666 Fifth Avenue, an aluminum-clad office tower in Midtown Manhattan, for a record price of $1.8 billion is considered a classic example of reckless underwriting. The transaction was so highly leveraged that the cash flow from rents amounted to only 65 percent of the debt service.

title: Windows Into Big but Little-Understood Worlds
description: Inside Natures Giants, besides being the liveliest scientists-at-work program to come along in a while, is the perfect thing for anyone trying to lose weight. You wont be doing any snacking while watching this cut-them-open extravaganza.

title: Spider-Man Producers Countersuit Against Julie Taymor
description: The producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark marshaled a muscular counteroffensive in federal court against a lawsuit by Julie Taymor, the former director of the $75 million show, essentially seeking to erase Mr. Taymor from the Spider-Man universe going forward.

title: Obama Campaign Looks Into Ad Rates
description: In a sign that the Obama campaign could be getting close to airing its first television commercials of the 2012 race, aides on Tuesday began asking television stations in certain swing states for their advertising rates.

title: Judge Dismisses Dot-Com Lawsuit Against Quattrone
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Credit Suisse and its former star investment banker, Frank P. Quattrone, ending a decade-old shareholder action brought by investors in AOLTime Warner stock.

title: For Opera Stars Birthday, Spotlight Is on Young Artists
description: It says everything you need to know about the great mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne that she spent her 78th birthday on Monday listening to young singers. She has followed one of the most spectacular singing careers in opera history with devoted work as a teacher and conservatory administrator, always emphasizing the art of the song recital.

title: Tenants Gain Advantage in Office Tower Market
description: In New Yorks most exclusive office towers, the pendulum of power has swung from landlords, who last year basked in rising rents and competition for prime buildings, to tenants, who are now being offered incentives like prebuilt offices to fill empty spaces. And the leverage held by tenants is likely to continue through this year, market experts say.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Right to Work Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Terry S. Brown
description: Mr. Brown, 50, is the chief executive of Edens, an independent owner and operator of shopping centers on the East Coast, including the South Bay Center in Boston and the Port Plaza in Port Jefferson, N.Y.

title: As European Union Beckons, Allure Fades for Wary Croatia
description: HARMICA, Croatia  Zoran Sluga has a small family farm here on the border with Slovenia, his 300-year-old barn filled with thousands of squawking chickens.

title: Court Weighs Protections for Lawyers of Cities
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday considered whether private lawyers hired by municipalities to conduct investigations are entitled to protections against lawsuits available to government lawyers.

title: Kitchen Modernism With Nathan Myhrvold
description: Some of the modernist cooking techniques that Nathan Myhrvold showed me for this weeks column seem a lot more confusing than they actually are  at least if youve never, say, cooked salmon using fake sous vide before. These four short videos help illustrate the methods. And its instructive to hear Mr. Myhrvold talk about the recipes, explaining some of the finer points in more depth than in a written recipe.

title: Designation of Historic District in East Village Wont Stop Project
description: It seems like a classic case of closing the barn door after the horses have gotten out.

title: New Questions Raised About Tamiflus Effectiveness
description: A new review of medical evidence continues to raise questions about the safety and effectiveness of the influenza drug Tamiflu, which the United States and other nations have spent billions of dollars to stockpile for use in a possible flu pandemic.

title: Sometimes a Dragon Needs to Nibble
description: Chinese (or Asian) New Year starts on Monday and celebrations last about a week. To kick off the Year of the Dragon, Peter Callahan, a New York caterer with an office in Philadelphia, is selling clever fortune cookie hors doeuvres. Though shaped like the folded cookies, they are made with wonton wrappers, fried and filled with a spiced chicken mixture. They come with a little red acrylic tray that has six tiny reusable takeout boxes attached for serving the tidbits. You get three dozen hors doeuvres, to be reheated before serving. Add some parsley or shredded cabbage to the bottom of each box for a nice presentation, and put a paper fortune, also provided, on top. You can even order your own custom fortunes.

title: Robertson and Chamberlain Agree to Terms
description: The Yankees avoided arbitration with relievers Joba Chamberlain and Dave Robertson by agreeing to one-year contracts with both, the team announced Tuesday.

title: Mind Your Manners: Eat With Your Hands
description: JULIE SAHNI vividly remembers the first time she had to eat with utensils. Ms. Sahni, a New York-based cookbook author and cooking teacher, grew up in India eating the traditional way, with her right hand. Then, in college, she won a dance competition that would take her to Europe. How, she wondered, would she eat?

title: Killer of 4 Pleads Guilty to Attack in Subway
description: On a quiet Saturday morning last February, a steely-eyed young man stepped in front of a rider on a No. 3 train beneath Times Square, calmly warned him that he was about to die, and lunged out with a large knife to try to make good on the promise.

title: Moelis Gets $93 Million Investment From Sumitomo Mitsui
description: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has signed an agreement to receive an investment of $93 million from the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, one of the largest banks in Japan, and SMBC Nikko Securities, a securities firm owned by Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, the companies announced in a joint release on Tuesday.

title: In Tech, Starting Up by Failing
description: Every entrepreneur hopes to start the next big thing. But sometimes the first try doesnt go as planned.

title: Perspectives on the Wives of Priests
description: To the Editor:

title: The Myth of Anybody but Romney
description: Perhaps the most fundamental question surrounding this years Republican nomination race has been what to make of the fact that support for Mitt Romney rarely exceeded 20 or 25 percent in national polls, despite seemingly running a strong campaign and being up against a somewhat marginal set of opponents.

title: Iran Tightens Its Security for Scientists After Killing
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran has ordered extra security for scientists because of the drive-by assassination last week of the deputy director of the countrys primary uranium enrichment facility, which he attributed to the evil hands of arrogance and Zionist agents, the state-run news media reported Tuesday.

title: Christie Proposes a 10% Income Tax Cut in New Jersey
description: TRENTON  Gov. Chris Christie vowed on Tuesday to press ahead with what he called the New Jersey comeback, proposing a 10 percent, across-the-board cut in income taxes and a host of changes to the states schools and criminal justice system.

title: Praise for a Developer
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Reserve as a Hedge Fund: Higher Profits, Lower Pay
description: The year 2011 is over, and soon well be hearing again about billion-dollar paydays for select hedge fund wizards.

title: Beyond Tebowmania: Giving Women a Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Diversified Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Renews Criticism of Romneys Record at Bain
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Maybe it was the debate talking.

title: Senna Switches Teams
description: Bruno Senna will drive for the Williams team in Formula One 2012. Williams was the team for which Sennas uncle Ayrton was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in 1994. Bruno had raced for the Hispania team in 2010, then finished the season at Lotus Renault.

title: The Clam Returns to Brooklyn
description: COULD the clam roll become the new lobster roll? Two new Brooklyn restaurants are betting so.

title: Reginald Hill, Prolific Writer of Crime Novels, Dies at 75
description: Reginald Hill, the prolific British author best known for his 24 idiosyncratic but elegant crime novels featuring the Yorkshire police detectives Andrew Dalziel and Peter Pascoe, died on Thursday at his home in Cumbria, England. He was 75.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Parents Welcome, Too

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Rugby, the Royals and Unruly Behavior
description: Yeah, sure, everybody became upset last week when the police revealed they had smuggled a fake bomb into Olympic Park in a security test announced six months ahead of the London Games.

title: Egypt: Mubarak Defense Is Opened
description: Lawyers for Hosni Mubarak, the ousted president, called him a clean man who could not do wrong as they began laying out their defense on Tuesday against charges that he participated in corruption and directed the killing of demonstrators. Mr. Mubaraks chief lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, cited the testimony of the former intelligence chief Omar Suleiman that Mr. Mubarak had instructed the police to use only nonlethal weapons like tear gas, water cannons and nightsticks in battling the protests last year that ultimately ended his rule. Mr. Mubarak, 83, was once again rolled into the court on a stretcher. But for the first time since the trial began in August, he then sat up in a wheelchair, presenting his face to the court as he listened to the defense, state news media reported.

title: At South Pole, a Game of Cricket
description: British adventurers braving weather of 31 degrees below zero played cricket on Tuesday at the South Pole to commemorate the centenary of the arrival there on Jan. 17, 1912, of the ill-fated British expedition led by Robert Falcon Scott, which reached the pole only to discover that a rival team led by Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian, had accomplished the feat a month earlier. The British cricketers won a narrow victory over a rest of the world team of scientists working at the Amundsen-Scott research center. The captain of the British team, Neil Laughton, a former Royal Marine commando, said he hoped the victory would have pleased Captain Scott and his four companions, all of whom died on the 900-mile return trek.

title: U.S. Says Sudan Is Blocking Aid
description: The United States and Sudan traded accusations over the humanitarian situation in the states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, embattled since the north and south of Sudan split into two nations last summer. About 500,000 displaced people face famine if substantial international aid does not begin to flow by March, said Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador, calling an aid blockade imposed by Sudan unconscionable and unacceptable. Sudans United Nations envoy, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, said the situation for most civilians in the area was fantastic, denying any blockade except in pockets where rebels took shelter.

title: Williams Battles Injury, and Insects
description: MELBOURNE, Australia (AP)  If anything, it was the insects buzzing around Rod Laver Arena that bothered Serena Williams the most.

title: Beyond Twitter on Capitol Hill
description: The findings of the first Congressional Hackathon were released Tuesday.

title: Google Plans to Protest SOPA on Its Home Page
description: 11:42 a.m. | Updated to correct the number of unique visitors to Google each month.

title: Boxers, Briefs or a Hybrid Sheath?
description: KITZBHEL, Austria  The latest front in nefarious performance enhancement in sports: underwear.

title: Young, in Love and Sharing Everything, Including a Password
description: Young couples have long signaled their devotion to each other by various means  the gift of a letterman jacket, or an exchange of class rings or ID bracelets. Best friends share locker combinations.

title: Knicks Send Two Bench Warmers to D-League
description: Jeremy Lin and Jerome Jordan became the first Knicks ever assigned to the D-League on Tuesday, when team officials sent both players to the Erie BayHawks.

title: New Sergeant-at-Arms for the House
description: The House elected Paul D. Irving as its 37th sergeant-at-arms on Tuesday, the opening day of the second session of the 112th Congress. Mr. Irving will become the chambers top law enforcement official after a 25-year career in the Secret Service.

title: In Year of Hut, Hut, Hut, the 49ers Hit, Hit, Hit
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Last week, as the San Francisco 49ers defense sauntered onto the field, safety Dashon Goldson wore eye black and full pads. His fellow safety Donte Whitner pushed his mouthpiece in. This would have been normal had it happened on game day, but the scene Whitner described took place last Wednesday, in practice.

title: Gustav Leonhardt, Master Harpsichordist, Dies at 83
description: Gustav Leonhardt, the Dutch harpsichordist, organist and conductor who was a pioneer in the world of period instrument performance and research into Baroque performance styles, died on Monday at his home in Amsterdam. He was 83.

title: Cardinals and the First Lady Celebrate
description: The St. Louis Cardinals were at the White House on Tuesday to celebrate their World Series championship but shared the moment with Michelle Obama  an avowed Chicago Cubs fan  to mark her 48th birthday.

title: Jerry Yang, Chief Yahoo, Steps Down From Board
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang has left Yahoo, the stumbling Internet company he co-founded 17 years ago, the company announced Tuesday.

title: Seen It All on Subway? Look Under This Seat
description: It was a few minutes before 4:30 a.m. when the call came in: a suspicious passenger was aboard a Manhattan-bound subway train. Other riders were alarmed. The suspect was said to be making furtive movements.

title: Jimmy Castor, Musician Who Mastered Many Genres, Dies at 71
description: Jimmy Castor, a singer, instrumentalist and songwriter whose mastery of genres from doo-wop to Latin soul to funk, and instruments including saxophone and bongos earned him the title Everything Man, died on Monday in Henderson, Nev. He was 71.

title: Twinkies, the Undead Snack
description: The news that Hostess filed for bankruptcy last week was met with nostalgic dismay by millions of baby boomers who lamented what they thought was the imminent demise of the Twinkie. Hostess, which emerged from bankruptcy just three years ago, has maybe 100,000 creditors, mostly labor unions and pension funds (one of which is reportedly owed $944 million) that represent the companys employees. Its debt approaches a billion dollars, a lot by most standards.

title: For God So Loved the 1 Percent
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Industry Weighs Effect of Ship Accident
description: Shares of the Carnival Corporation, the worlds largest cruise ship operator, fell 14 percent on Tuesday as analysts and investors sought to gauge the effect of the grounding of Carnivals Costa Concordia after days of continual images and videos of the listing ship.

title: Canada Accuses Naval Officer of Sharing State Secrets
description: OTTAWA  A Canadian naval officer who worked in some of the countrys key military intelligence centers has been charged with breach of trust and passing along government secrets to a foreign entity. The officer, Sub-Lt. Jeffrey Paul Delisle, 40, remained in jail on Tuesday after his lawyer asked a court in Halifax, Nova Scotia, to delay a bail hearing to give him more time to study the governments case.

title: World Bank Warns Developing Nations of Slowing Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank is urging developing nations to start planning for a major slowdown in global growth this year.

title: Letter Accuses Affirmative-Action Opponent of Mismanaging Funds
description: Ward Connerly, the African-American businessman who has been the face of the movement to end affirmative action for nearly two decades, is facing accusations from a prominent former ally, Jennifer Gratz, that he has mismanaged donations.

title: My So-Called Bipolar Life
description: Washington

title: Colts Dismiss Caldwell as Shakeup Continues
description: Jim Caldwell was Peyton Mannings quarterbacks coach for seven years before he became the head coach of the Indianapolis Colts two years ago and promptly led the team to the Super Bowl.

title: Affirmative-Action Foe Is Facing Allegations of Financial Misdeeds
description: WASHINGTON  Ward Connerly, the black businessman who has been the face of the movement to end affirmative action for nearly two decades, is facing accusations from a prominent former ally that he has mismanaged  and exploited for his own benefit  donations to that cause made by fellow conservatives.

title: Another Bitter Divorce for Perelman
description: Ronald O. Perelmans marital breakups  divorces from the actress Ellen Barkin and Patricia Duff among them  have been rich fodder for the gossip pages. Now a split with a longtime business associate promises to be almost as acrimonious.

title: Shermans Southern Sympathies
description: The Baton Rouge dinner party in early 1860 had been enjoyable, but as it went on William Tecumseh Sherman couldnt help but hear his name mentioned repeatedly down at the tables far end. He suspected it had something to do with his position as superintendent of the newly formed Louisiana State Seminary of Learning and Military Academy (todays Louisiana State University). He had held the post for a few months and was well regarded by those who knew him personally, but many who didnt were concerned that the states only college was run by a Northerner whose congressman brother was seen across the South as an abolitionist.

title: Liu, Facing Investigation, Reports Drop in Donations
description: The New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, reported a sharp drop in his campaign donations on Tuesday, providing the clearest indication yet that his aspirations for the mayors office have been hurt by a federal investigation into his fund-raising practices.

title: Braun, Amid Drug Furor, to Attend Awards Dinner
description: At some point Saturday evening, hundreds of baseball fans, players, officials and members of the news media will sit in rapt attention as Ryan Braun approaches the podium to make a short speech at the Hilton in Manhattan.

title: Trust, but Verify
description: A few items came across the desk last week that underscore the challenge America faces in making policy toward the Islamist parties that are emerging as the early beneficiaries of the uprisings across the Arab world. The first was a news article about the Jan. 11 meeting in Cairo between Bill Burns, a deputy secretary of state, and Muhammad Morsi, the chairman of the Muslim Brotherhoods political party, during which Morsi said his party believes in the importance of U.S.-Egyptian relations, but said they must be balanced.

title: Hunting, Dear Sir? Delighted!
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.

title: Kraft Tries an Aged Cheese Marketing Campaign
description: KRAFT FOODS is reviving a vintage marketing recipe with a campaign that promotes five Kraft cheese products together as well as separately.

title: Romney Looks Past Weekends Primary as Rivals Find New Hope
description: FLORENCE, S.C.  Mitt Romney delivered a 13-minute speech here on Tuesday morning, shook hands with an audience that filled only a small part of a ballroom and caught a plane for a fund-raising gala in New York, a clear sign that he is looking beyond South Carolina.

title: Before Giants Go West, a Few Might Head Downtown
description: The Giants have enjoyed connecting their latest postseason run to the Super Bowl title surge in 2008, but before Sundays N.F.C. championship game is played a less positive track record may be tested first.

title: Greek Premier Says Creditors May Be Forced to Take Losses
description: ATHENS  Taking direct aim at hedge funds and other private holders of Greeces debt, Prime Minister Lucas Papademos says he will consider legislation forcing the creditors to take losses on their holdings if no agreement can be reached in critical negotiations scheduled to resume Wednesday.

title: Companies That Sell Services to Nonprofits Begin Deal Talks
description: Blackbaud, which provides software and services to help nonprofit groups manage their relationships with donors and supporters, has made an offer to acquire a competitor, Convio, for about $275 million.

title: Preaching Division in South Carolina
description: By mixing falsehoods with racial condescension, Newt Gingrich brought a raucous presidential debate crowd to its feet on Monday night in South Carolina, further cheapening his reputation and that of the state Republican Party.

title: Not the Bane of His Existence
description: Newt Gingrichs closing argument to South Carolina voters is pretty simple. Hes the only candidate within striking distance of Mitt Romney in the pre-primary polling, which makes him the only candidate capable of preventing a coronation.

title: Niles Ford, Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 52
description: Niles Ford, a performer and choreographer who had been active in the downtown New York dance scene since the late 1970s, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 52.

title: Gov. Cuomos Sound Budget
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo proposed a $132.5 billion state budget on Tuesday that features two promising ideas: one to ensure that New York will not lose more than $700 million in federal education funds and a second to save taxpayers money by reducing public pension costs.

title: Risks for G.O.P. in Attacks With Racial Themes
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  South Carolina has the nations first female Indian-American governor (a Republican), the highest-ranking African-American in Congress (on the Democratic side) and a rapidly growing population of Latinos, all evidence, longtime political players here say, that the state is shedding its racially charged past.

title: A Death Penalty Commutation
description: On Tuesday, Gov. Jack Markell of Delaware commuted the death sentence of Robert Gattis to life without parole. In doing so, he said he gave great weight to the careful decision of the state board of pardons to recommend that the sentence be commuted, the first such recommendation the board has made since the death penalty was reinstated there in 1974. As a condition of the commutation, which is supported by a long list of former judges and prosecutors, Mr. Gattis is expected to waive all legal challenges and live out his life in prison.

title: How Will You Use Your Leap Second?
description: When February comes, we will receive the gift of an extra day because 2012 is a leap year. But that isnt all the extra time we get this year. On the night of June 30, there will be one more second in the day  a leap second.

title: Higgins, Executive and Adviser to Owner, Is Leaving the Jets
description: Matt Higgins, the Jets executive vice president for business operations and an adviser to the teams owner, Woody Johnson, will step down at the end of the month.

title: Wednesday: Bewhiskered Frolicker
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Yes, I know. Chris Handman did not, technically speaking, add a SPARE TIRE or even a TIRE to each of the starred entries as the payoff at 64 Across indicates. He added the letters T, I, R, and E to each of the entries (Update: this is a correction to my previous statement that there was an S in the theme entries), but taken in the aggregate, and looked at through the forgiving lens of artistic license, I believe he pulled this theme off very well.

title: Those Who Seek to Make Art Often Find Themselves Alone
description: As Rosemary Harris says the word, darkness is a thing with tentacles that clutch and choke and smother. It erupts from her with a soul-deep rumble late in the first act of Athol Fugards Road to Mecca, which opened on Tuesday night at the American Airlines Theater. And once Ms. Harris has said darkness or said it that way  its impossible to look on her character or the play in which she appears with the comfort of detachment.

title: New Gas Economy Rules Generate Wide Support
description: DETROIT  Writing new regulations that will require cars and trucks to have significantly higher fuel economy by 2025 prompted years of fighting among automakers, environmentalists, regulators and consumer groups.

title: Two Officers Sentenced in Rikers Island Assault Case
description: Two former correction officers, who were among 15 people implicated in a series of crimes at a facility on Rikers Island for inmates ages 16 to 19, were sentenced on Tuesday after they admitted to assaulting or attempting to assault prisoners in their custody.

title: Keeping Film Aspirations Intact While Building a Life of Sobriety
description: The bookshelves in Joseph Salterss bedroom tell the story of his life. On the bottom shelf sit well-thumbed paperbacks with titles like Adult Children of Alcoholics and Narcotics Anonymous. The top shelf is lined with Shakespeare plays and a copy of Screenwriting Tricks of the Trade.

title: When Different Parts of the Country May Recover
description: Estimate of when jobs will reach pre-recession levels in metropolitan areas.

title: In Contract Talks, City Opera Reaches Deal With a Union
description: The New York City Opera and its orchestra union have reached a tentative agreement on a contract, a step forward in the companys effort to put on a season, officials said Tuesday. Management and the other major union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, were still in talks but reportedly making progress.

title: Lottery Numbers
Money Flows to Republican Backers of Gay Marriage
description: ALBANY  Gay rights advocates from Wall Street to Hollywood poured donations into the coffers of four little-known Republican state senators after the lawmakers provided the decisive votes for same-sex marriage in New York last June, according to new campaign finance filings released on Tuesday.

title: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry
description: With a Web-wide protest on Wednesday that includes a 24-hour shutdown of the English-language Wikipedia, the legislative battle over two Internet piracy bills has reached an extraordinary moment  a political coming of age for a relatively young and disorganized industry that has largely steered clear of lobbying and other political games in Washington.

title: Pinkberry Co-founder Arrested in Beating of Homeless Man
description: LOS ANGELES  The co-founder of the Pinkberry frozen yogurt franchise, Young Lee, was arrested Monday in connection with the beating of a homeless man in June.

title: Veteran Charged in Slayings of Four Homeless Men
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.The Iraq war veteran accused of killing four homeless men in the past month stalked his victims before striking, enjoyed the media coverage of his crimes and had a list of future victims at the time of his arrest, according to Orange County prosecutors.

title: What the Polls Cant Tell Us
Pining for Sideshow Rex and His Bickering Jets
description: The N.F.L. conference championship games on Sunday feature nearly everything a fan could want: great offenses, tough defenses, exciting new stars, respected future Hall of Famers with perhaps their final chance at a title.

title: Duggars Are Surprise Guests at Santorum Event
description: ANDERSON, S.C.  The two speakers who introduced Rick Santorum to the overflow crowd at a Fuddruckers here both proudly described their seven children as blessings  a popular sentiment in a gathering that was heavy with people who call themselves pro-life Christians.

title: Rangers Owner Climbs Aboard Their Bandwagon
description: The giddiness over the league-leading Rangers latest victory, 3-0 over Nashville on Tuesday night, led to an impromptu cameo appearance by the team owner James L. Dolan at Coach John Tortorellas postgame news conference.

title: Knicks to Face Suns and Steve Nash, the Point Guard They Are Lacking
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: For Gingrich, an Endorsement of Sorts From Sarah Palin
description: ON THE NEWT GINGRICH PRESS BUS, Interstate 20, S.C.  Sarah Palin, who conducted a lengthy flirtation with a run for the Republican nomination last year, ended the equally lengthy speculation over which candidate she would endorse by naming Newt Gingrich  sort of.

title: Charles M. Haar Dies at 91; Used Courts to Clean Boston Harbor
description: Charles M. Haar, a Harvard Law School professor who helped spur the cleanup of the notoriously befouled Boston Harbor through the strategic use of judicial power, died on Jan. 10 in Miami. He was 91 and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla., and Princeton, N.J.

title: Corrections: January 18
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Parties Confident of Extending Payroll Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  With both parties largely in agreement on a yearlong extension of President Obamas payroll tax cut, the fight in Congress over the coming weeks will boil down to how to pay for it, and Democrats appeared to hold the advantage as members of the House returned to Washington on Tuesday.

title: How Exercise May Keep Alzheimers at Bay
description: Alzheimers disease, with its inexorable loss of memory and self, understandably alarms most of us. This is especially so since, at the moment, there are no cures for the condition and few promising drug treatments. But a cautiously encouraging new study from The Archives of Neurology suggests that for some people, a daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimers or change the course of the disease if it begins.

title: Video Everywhere Gets Another Boost
description: Polycom, best known for table top phones in conference rooms, aims to pressure Cisco as the two fight over sales of cheap and easy to use videoconferencing software for small businesses and telephone companies.

title: Taking a Swing at the Practice of Dowry
description: These are chicks you dont want to mess with.

title: Word of the Day | girth
description: girth \grth\ noun and verb

title: For Indias Army, Dispute Over Chiefs Age Rattles Leadership
description: Vijay Kumar Singh, the chief of the Indian army, on Monday filed a petition with the Supreme Court of India, asking justices to decide a seemingly simple question: When was he born?, Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/18/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/18/2012

title: Few Cities Have Regained Jobs They Lost, Report Finds
description: Less than a tenth of the nations metropolitan areas have regained the jobs they lost in the economic downturn, according to a report being released Wednesday by the nations mayors as they gather in Washington to express their exasperation that the federal government seems more intent on cutting aid to cities than on sending more.

title: Delaware: Governor Commutes Death Sentence
description: Gov. Jack Markell approved the first sentence commutation in Delawares recent history on Tuesday, converting the death sentence of Robert Gattis to one of life in prison without the possibility of parole. Mr. Gattis, who was convicted of the 1990 murder of his longtime girlfriend, Shirley Slay, was scheduled to be executed by lethal injection on Jan. 20. Advocates for Mr. Gattis petitioned the State Board of Pardons for clemency, arguing that his abusive childhood was not understood by the court at the time of his sentencing. Mr. Markell, a Democrat, followed the advice of the board, making Mr. Gattiss commutation conditional on his agreement not to ask for an additional commutation or a pardon. Mr. Gattiss lawyers say he will accept those conditions. This commutation in no way relieves Mr. Gattis of his moral or legal guilt, Mr. Markell wrote in a statement. My decision is among the most difficult I have had to make in all my years in public service.

title: Since 1980s, the Kindest of Tax Cuts for the Rich
description: The effective federal income tax rate paid by the wealthiest Americans has dropped significantly during the last several decades, largely because of tax cuts on investment income.

title: Playing at Sundance
description: Images from select films appearing at the 2012 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Wikipedia Blackout Lets In Some Light
description: Wikipedias much publicized 24-hour blackout in protest of online antipiracy laws is not, it turns out, quite so dark.

title: Smoke Bomb Tossed Over Fence at White House
description: A smoke bomb was lobbed over the north fence of the White House on Tuesday night from a crowd of protesters affiliated with the Occupy movement participating in demonstrations aimed at lawmakers returning for the next session of Congress.

title: McHales Patience Propels Her Into Third Round
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Trailing by a set and surrounded by about 100 fans encouraging her opponent to Put her away!, Christina McHale of the United States worked her way back from the brink of defeat on Wednesday.

title: Rushdies Uncertain Date With Jaipur
description: Will Salman Rushdie show up or wont he? That is the question everyone is asking days ahead of the Jaipur Literature Festival, which starts on Friday.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 18, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Young Concedes Poor Play in Four-Set Loss
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It wasnt Donald Youngs day.

title: Homai Vyarawalla, First Lady of the Lens
description: Homai Vyarawalla, Indias first female photojournalist, who died on Sunday, chronicled Indias independence with a spirit that was unmatched by the following generations, in part because of changes in India itself.

title: Jan. 18, 1912 | Robert Falcon Scott Discovers Tent of Explorer Who Beat Him to South Pole
description: On Jan. 18, 1912, one day after reaching the South Pole, the English explorer Robert F. Scott and his expedition found a tent erected by Roald Amundsens expedition, which had reached the pole five weeks earlier. Inside the tent, Scott found a note addressed to him from Amundsen. Should he not return home safely, Amundsen wanted someone to tell King Haakon of Norway that he had indeed reached the pole.

title: Disaster Cripples Cruiser, Not Cruising
description: PARIS  As every seafarer knows, its an ill wind indeed that blows nobody any good.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 18, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article Saints Sweep Past the Lions, Mostly by Going Over Them.

title: Sites Go Dark to Protest Web Piracy Bills
description: WHY is Wikipedia going dark today?

title: Greek Premier Warns Hedge Funds
description: My colleague Rachel Donadio reports that Lucas Papademos, Greeces prime minister, warned hedge funds and other private bondholders that he would consider legislation forcing them to take losses on their Greek bond holdings if no agreement can be reached in critical negotiations scheduled to resume Wednesday. It was Mr. Papademoss first interview with a newspaper since he came to office in November. Read the full article

title: A Mess on the Ladder of Success
description: Throughout American history there has almost always been at least one central economic narrative that gave the ambitious or unsatisfied reason to pack up and seek their fortune elsewhere. For the first 300 or so years of European settlement, the story was about moving outward: getting immigrants to the continent and then to the frontier to clear the prairies, drain the swamps and build new cities.

title: The Fast Life of Oscar Pistorius
description: Oscar Pistorius trains inside a converted garage at the home of his personal trainer, a former professional rugby player. Iron pull-up bars and a variety of ropes and pulleys are bolted to brick walls. Free weights are lined up on the floor, along with hammered-together wooden boxes that serve as platforms for step-ups and standing jumps. Some of the equipment is clamped to an exterior wall of the garage, opposite an uncovered patio; when it rains, athletes just carry on and get soaked. Its old-school, Pistorius said as we drove up to the place early one morning. Some of the guys who train here, they bang it so hard, they often get sick in the garden. Nobody judges them.

title: The Heart of the Matter: Love
description: In the spring of 1965, my husband, Grey Villet, was given a Life Magazine assignment to photograph the Lovings, an interracial married couple then embroiled in legal tangles after their arrest for miscegenation in Virginia. Grey did not concern himself with those entanglements. He chose, as he did in every essay we ever worked on together, to seek out the literal heart of the matter: a love story.

title: Given Unlimited Resources, What Scientific or Medical Problem Would You Investigate?
description: The Science Times this week has several articles about citizen scientists taking research into their own hands, whether through labs open to the public (including non-scientists), or via collaborative, online sites for sharing science research and knowledge.

title: Captain of Stricken Vessel Says He Fell Overboard in Passenger Panic
description: GIGLIO, Italy  The saga of the stricken cruise liner Costa Concordia took further twists Wednesday, with a warning from Italys environment minister that it could sink and news that the captain claimed he had slipped on deck and tumbled overboard, winding up in a lifeboat during the panicky passenger escape  not abandoned ship like a coward, as accused.

title: China Expands Program Requiring Real-Name Registration Online
description: BEIJING  China will expand nationwide a trial program that requires users of the countrys wildly popular microblog services to disclose their identities to the government in order to post comments online, the governments top Internet regulator said Wednesday.

title: Womenscapes
description: The Female Factor is the IHTs look at the place of women in the early 21st century. Many women have more power over their bodies and their fates than at any time in history. What are they doing with this new-found influence? Where do they want to go? This year, the third of this uniquely broad and thorough series on the worlds women, we will paint Womenscapes, portraits that illustrate the vast possibilities  and the limitations  in a world that has now largely embraced womens empowerment as a positive force.

title: Decision to Attack Iran Is Far Off, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM  Israel moved to calm the increasingly tense discourse over Irans nuclear program on Wednesday, with the Israeli defense minister asserting that any decision on a possible pre-emptive military strike on Iranian targets was very far off.

title: Mind Your Manners: Eat With Your Hands
description: Until recently, you would have been hard-pressed to find many restaurants in the United States  especially those with $20 or $30 entrees  where digging in manually was encouraged, Sarah DiGregorio writes in The New York Times. Now, several high-profile chefs are asking diners to get their hands dirty, in the belief that it heightens the sensual connection to food and softens the formality of fine dining.

title: Fantasy Football Accuracy Rankings for 2011
description: Sara Holladay is the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Disclosures and Loans
description: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with individualized legal advice. Questions have been edited and condensed.

title: Testing for Need
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: MTVs Latest Facebook App is About Scholarships, Not Snooki
description: MTV, home to television shows like Jersey Shore and Teen Mom, might be the last place many students would think to turn for guidance about financial aid. But on Wednesday the network is launching a Facebook application to help students efficiently navigate the financial aid morass.

title: From M.I.T., a Chromeless Response to Chromes Drawbacks
description: Chrome, that onetime ubiquitous detailing material with the come-hither glint, is making a comeback, if not in its original form.

title: Tip of the Week: Easy Switching Among Programs
description: Do you have a bunch of programs open on a PC or Mac and want to switch around between them without fumbling for the mouse? On a Windows system, just hold down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to see a box showing your open windows and applications. Keep holding down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to cycle through the icons and let go when you get to the program or window you want to use.

title: China Expands Program Requiring Real-Name Registration Online
description: China will expand nationwide a trial program that requires users of the countrys wildly popular microblog services to disclose their identities to the government in order to post comments online, the governments top Internet regulator said on Wednesday.Read the full article

title: Man Groups Funds Decline
description: LONDON  Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund, said on Wednesday that its funds under management fell 9.5 percent, to $58.4 billion, in final three months of 2011, as investors withdrew money in response to volatility in financial markets.

title: For Minnesota Duluth, a Loss, and the Top Ranking
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

description: Serving up links as the Giants-Niners and Patriots-Ravens games approach:

title: Romney Holds Solid Lead Over Rivals
description: Mitt Romney has solidified a sizable coalition of Republican primary voters nationwide over his rivals for the G.O.P. nomination, fracturing key blocs of the partys base, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Mind the U.N.-A.U. Gap
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave an unusual speech at the U.N. Security Council last week. In a plea for better relations between the United Nations and the African Union, he blamed the West for the weakness of the ties between the two organizations. Citing the intervention in Libya last spring, he accused NATO of running roughshod over the African Unions preferences for how to prevent and resolve conflicts in Africa.

title: On Berlins Literary Calendar (for English-Speakers)
description: Berlins rich and diverse literary scene is a crucial component of the citys creative makeup. Since reunification, it has attracted a number of established and aspiring writers  all drawn to its openness and support for artistic expression.

title: A Digital Wallet Now Available on Some Smartphones
description: Good news for people suffering from discomfort caused by sitting on a thick wallet full of credit cards and credit card receipts for a long duration: Visa, the credit card company, said it supported making wireless payments through some smartphones, though it would replace the plastic Visa cards issued by banks.

title: Prediction and the Brain: A Response
description: Sincere thanks for all the thoughtful reactions to my post on the thrifty and predictive brain. I was cheered that so many posts found value or resonance in the piece, and I am especially grateful for the various suggestions of additional concrete examples in our daily life.

title: Digital Textbooks From a Company Not Named Apple
description: Theres an old saying that if you want to be a leader and you see a parade, jump in front of it. So it is with digital textbooks, an area thats about to experience the high-tech equivalent of the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade as Apple prepares to push into the business.

title: Cute but Tough, With a Nose for the Food in Your Bags
description: New York City does not lack for exotic and specialty food shops, but perhaps the most diverse display of ever-changing imported produce can be found in what is called the grinding room in the customs area of John F. Kennedy International Airports Terminal 4, the major gateway for international arrivals.

title: Wind Turbines and Health Hazards
description: There is no conclusive evidence so far that wind turbines are responsible for health problems ranging from balance problems to diabetes, an independent panel of health experts reports.

title: Brazils Ruling Family of Film
description: SOMETIMES they limit themselves simply to producing movies, though on many other occasions they have also written, directed or actually filmed them. But by any standard the Barretos  Luiz Carlos and Lucy and their children, Bruno, Fbio and Paula  are the first family of cinema in Brazil.

title: N.F.L. Title Game Matchups: What the Film Says
description: Andy Benoit has contributed weekly film analysis to the Fifth Down this season:

title: Daily Report: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry
description: The battle over two Congressional bills intended to prevent copyright violations on the Internet marks a political coming of age for the tech industry, reports Jenna Wortham in Wednesdays New York Times. The relatively young and politically disorganized tech industry has found its voice in opposing the bills, which it says would go too far  potentially violating free speech and stifling innovation  by allowing media companies to shut down Web sites they say are abusing copyrights. Its an issue that has led to a rare show of unity for the industrys players  from venture capitalists to the smallest Web sites.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Another Bitter Divorce for Perelman | Ronald O. Perelmans marital breakups  divorces from the actress Ellen Barkin and Patricia Duff among them  have been rich fodder for the gossip pages. Now a split with a longtime business associate promises to be almost as acrimonious.

title: G.O.P. in Congress Gets Blame for Gridlock
description: The public is not assigning blame equally between President Obama and Republicans in Congress for the partisan gridlock over key legislation.

title: Strauss-Kahns Wife to Edit Huffington Post in France
description: PARIS  The French journalist Anne Sinclair, who is married to the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, has been chosen to edit the French edition of The Huffington Post, the news Web site, which is being set up in partnership with the newspaper Le Monde.

description: Source.
