description: When Mitt Romney suggested this week that he pays a lower tax rate than most wealthy Americans do, he refocused attention on his tax proposals  which, like those of his major Republican rivals, would largely cut taxes for the rich while driving down tax collections and widening the nations deficit.

title: Governor Romney, Meet Governor Dukakis
description: A couple of months ago, Mitt Romney was a hapless would-be frontrunner who couldnt stay ahead of a motley crew of unelectable cranks, extremists and vanity candidates. (Theres some overlap in these categories.) Then he won the first two states. Now, ahead in the polls in South Carolina and Florida, Romney is on track for the Republican nomination in the worst election year for an incumbent party since  well, since 2008.

title: Michigan: Officials Revive Transit Plan
description: The City Council of Troy has voted to save a transit infrastructure project it voted down in December. Construction costs for the project have been scaled back to $6.3 million, from $8.5 million, to win the vote of a council member who had expressed concerns about the cost, though the federal government fully financed construction. The city will seek a business model that will relieve the local taxpayer of ongoing operating costs of $30,000 per year, said Michele Hodges, president of the Chamber of Commerce. Mayor Janice Daniels, a Republican who is active in Tea Party politics and led the opposition to the project, said that she had not changed her opinion, but that it is in my best interest, and all of Troys best interest, to work toward making this a fiscally responsible venture.

title: Corrections: January 19
description: NATIONAL

title: Details of the Candidates Tax Plans
description: A look at the Republican candidates tax plans.

title: The Jets Tomlinson Sheds Further Light on Turmoil
description: When the Jets were ousted from playoff contention with a loss to Miami on Jan. 1, LaDainian Tomlinson delivered the strongest on-the-record rebuke of Santonio Holmes and the strife that had engulfed the team.

title: Checketts on Way Back to New York
description: For the past decade, Dave Checkettss sports interests have taken him out of New York, where he had been the president of Madison Square Garden for seven years and the president of the Knicks for three.

title: Group Sues Over Denial of Permit to Protest at Courthouse
description: A group that is planning to protest at a Manhattan courthouse around the second anniversary of the Supreme Courts decision in the Citizens United case, which eliminated barriers to corporations political speech and spending, sued federal officials on Wednesday after its request for a permit to gather was denied.

title: A Good Call on the Pipeline
description: President Obama has properly rejected, at least for now, the Keystone XL oil pipeline that would run from Canada to the Gulf Coast. He rebuffed the demand of House Republicans that the controversial project be decided in haste under an election-year deadline.

title: A Way of Life on its Way Out in Wichita
description: After eight decades as one of its biggest employers and most prestigious brands, Boeing leaves Wichita in a trail of broken promises and bitter recriminations.

title: Boeing Departure Shakes Wichitas Identity as Airplane Capital
description: WICHITA, Kan.  The crowd gathered at the local headquarters for Boeing was euphoric. The company had just won one of the largest military contracts in history. Thousands of the resulting jobs, Boeing had promised, would be headed here, to the sprawling manufacturing complex where residents have been building airplanes for generations.

title: Budget Wars Are Revived With a Vote in the House
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted Wednesday to block President Obamas request for $1.2 trillion in additional borrowing authority, knowing that its action was mainly a symbolic protest with no effect on the seemingly inexorable increase in the federal debt.

title: Marty Springstead, Longtime Baseball Umpire and Supervisor, Dies at 74
description: Marty Springstead, who umpired games in Major League Baseball for 20 years and supervised major league umpires as an executive for more than 20 more, died on Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 74.

title: Edward J. Derwinski, First V.A. Secretary, Dies at 85
description: Edward J. Derwinski, who honed an effusive political personality in Chicagos American Legion halls, then put it to use as a top-ranking Republican congressman, a high State Department adviser and the first secretary of veterans affairs, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Oak Brook, Ill. He was 85.

title: Michael Mussa, Adviser to Reagan on Economy, Dies at 67
description: Michael L. Mussa, a former chief economist for the International Monetary Fund who was known for his blunt and often witty economic assessments, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 67.

title: Trump Cleared to Manage Golf Course, Despite Opposition
description: Over the objections of critics, Donald J. Trump has been cleared to run a new public golf course in the Bronx.

title: Will Europe Ever Get Its Supergrid?
description: Many renewable energy supporters see the creation of an energy supergrid as an indispensable part of Europe decreasing its reliance on fossil fuels. The supergrid would take renewable energy from where it is produced  say, on wind farms in Scotland or in solar arrays in Spain or North Africa  and deliver it to Europes faraway population centers. In addition to the environmental argument, there is also an economic one. In this Business of Green special report, Beth Gardiner writes:

title: News Quiz | Jan. 19, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: A New Fight on Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  It is legislative season in New Mexico, which means it is time once again to debate whether illegal immigrants should be granted drivers licenses.

title: Why Doctors Cant Predict How Long a Patient Will Live
description: Slender, in her 60s and possessing the stoicism of someone who had single-handedly raised children in the toughest section of the city, our patient faced a difficult challenge of the medical kind. She had diabetes and such severe peripheral vascular disease that even the strongest antibiotics could not heal a long-standing foot infection. She needed an operation.

title: YouTube Announces New Film Competition With Venice Film Festival and Ridley Scott
description: YouTubes aggressive effort to leave its low-rent entertainment reputation behind continues: On Thursday the Google-owned video hub plans to announce a partnership with the Venice Film Festival and Ridley Scotts production company to create what its calling an online film festival.

title: BankUnited Calls Off Short Sales Process
description: BankUnited, the private equity-owned bank that went public last year, said on Wednesday that it had ended an effort to sell itself and planned to remain independent.

title: Word of the Day | kleptomaniac
description: kleptomaniac \klep-t-ma-ne-ak\ noun

title: Idol Begins 11th Season With Auditions in Georgia
description: Kicking off its 11th season Wednesday night with an audition show filmed in Savannah, Ga., American Idol kept things light and hopeful, relegating most of the painful performances to montages and sketching out a few of the storylines of the standouts who made it to the next round.

title: I.M.F. Seeks $500 Billion More to Lend
description: The International Monetary Fund said Wednesday, that it was seeking as much as $500 billion more to lend as it prepared to slash its forecasts of global growth, Annie Lowrey wrote in The New York Times.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/19/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/19/2012

title: Byron Donzis, Inventor of Football Flak Jacket, Dies at 79
description: No way to know for sure, but Byron Donzis just might hold the world record for being thwacked in the belly with a baseball bat.

title: Obama Strategist Plans Post-Vote Academic Role
description: CHICAGO  David Axelrod, the longtime political strategist for Barack Obama, is already making plans for after the 2012 election, and they do not involve another candidate or another trip to Iowa. Mr. Axelrod says he plans to lead a new, nonpartisan Institute of Politics at the University of Chicago aimed at helping students seeking careers in public and social service.

title: After Protest, Wikipedia Says Were Not Done Yet
description: The (day)long national nightmare is over.

title: Nash Shows Knicks What Theyre Missing
description: Steve Nash raised his arms triumphantly near halfcourt. It was not his corner 3-pointer that bounced off the rim and kissed the top of the backboard before falling through the net to give the Phoenix Suns a 5-point lead with 35 seconds to play. It was Shannon Browns.

title: Eastman Kodak Files for Bankruptcy
description: Eastman Kodak, the 131-year-old film pioneer that has been struggling for years to adapt to an increasingly digital world, filed for bankruptcy protection early on Thursday.

title: Kops-Jones and Spears Fall to Unseeded Pair
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Americans Raquel Kops-Jones and Abigail Spears, seeded 15th, lost on Thursday to an unseeded pair, Julia Grges of Germany and Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, in the first round of womens doubles play at the Australian Open.

title: Pakistans Prime Minister Makes Plea to Avoid Jail Time
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A bitter legal clash between Pakistans top court and its civilian government inched toward resolution on Thursday as the prime minister made a dramatic court appearance to ward off possible imprisonment while his legal team agreed to engage the court over the key issue of presidential immunity.

title: Michael Bradley in Italy: Hes Bravissimo
description: VERONA, Italy  Hes a painting with lots of different colors, said Tommaso Franco, the press officer of the Italian Serie A team Chievo Verona, about the United States international Michael Bradley. Theres red, theres blue, theres yellow. Hes bravissimo.

title: Jan. 19, 1937 | Howard Hughes Breaks His Own Transcontinental Flight Record
description: On Jan. 19, 1937, the millionaire Howard Hughes flew his monoplane from Los Angeles to Newark, N.J., in 7 hours, 28 minutes and 25 seconds, breaking the record he set a year earlier by about two hours. He averaged 332 miles an hour during the 2,490-mile journey.

title: Insurgents Kill Dozens in Southern Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  More than two dozen people were killed in a four insurgent attacks in southern Afghanistan that began late Wednesday and continued through Thursday afternoon, Afghan authorities said.

title: With Pollutants a Peril, Italy to Seek a Buffer to Avert Future Cruise Ship Disasters
description: GIGLIO, Italy  Alarmed by potentially disastrous pollutants lurking in the bowels of the Costa Concordia shipwreck, Italys environment minister will seek a three-mile-wide coastal no-go zone for the luxury cruise liners that have long plied the picturesque Italian shoreline, his spokesman said Thursday.

title: Will Higher Taxes Dampen Demand For Gold?
description: Indian officials have turned to an old tool to help it rein in its twin deficits in trade and the federal budget: higher import duties on gold and silver.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 19, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Fingers That Turn Back the Clock.

title: Primary Season 101
description: This edition of 6 Qs poses questions that help students use the rich resources of The Timess Campaign 2012 Politics section to learn about the Republican presidential primaries. Each question links to an article or graphic in which answers to that question can be found.

title: British Aide Admits Russian Spy Claims
description: LONDON  For the first time, a former senior official has confirmed Russian accusations that the British spy service was caught trying to use a fake rock in Moscow to hide electronic communication equipment six years ago.

title: Why Saudi Oil Pledge Could Prove Hollow
description: PARIS  Can Saudi Arabia live up to a promise to fill the oil-supply gap if new U.S. and European sanctions succeed in locking down Irans exports of crude?

title: Cynthia Nixon, All Grown Up
description: Decades of performances, from the film Little Darlings to Tony Award-winning play Rabbit Hole.

title: Life After Sex
description: When Cynthia Nixon was 9, she played an impostor on To Tell the Truth. There was a little girl who was a professional horse rider who had won all these blue ribbons, she recalled, and the cool thing about her was she rode a Shetland pony, and I pretended to be her. My mother worked on the show; her job was to brief the impostors, coach them in pretending. But I couldnt believe that no one on the panel recognized me, because I was around the studio a lot. So when I rode out on the horse with a cowboy hat on, I was like this  she ducked her head low  because I knew they absolutely remembered me. Even now, her face fell. And no one recognized me.

title: Egypts Human Bellwether
description: On a recent winter evening, a gray Mitsubishi sedan made its way slowly down the narrow main street of Qalyubiya, a farming town in the Nile River delta, hemmed in on all sides by shouting fruit vendors, bumping donkey carts, strings of colored lights and tiny bakeries and butcher shops. Election posters were plastered to every available surface, and a voice squawked loudly over a distant, tinny loudspeaker: God willing, we will all soon live in an era of social justice. The revolution taught us that we are all equal. As the sedan reached a crowded election rally outside a mosque, the back door opened and out stepped a striking man with deep-set eyes and a broad forehead. He is here! someone shouted. The hero of the revolution! Almost instantly, a murmur rippled through the crowd, and the man was surrounded by adoring fans. A pair of burly aides grabbed his arms and bustled him through. God is great! the crowd chanted as he smiled and waved, making his way toward a brightly lighted stage. Freedom and Justice! Tomorrow we will be strong!

title: Washing Dishes, Herding Reindeer
description: Erika Larsen may have discovered the solution to that enduring question: How do you fund a long-term photojournalism endeavor?

title: Should We Trust Paid Experts on the Volcker Rule?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Whom Would You Share Your Passwords With?
description: A  recent article described the intimate custom of teenage couples expressing affection for each other by sharing their passwords to e-mail, Facebook and other accounts. Have you ever shared your passwords with someone else? What do you think of the practice in general? Do you know any stories of password-sharing gone awry?

title: The New Student Activism
description: ASHLEY WARD, an aspiring idealist with waning faith in the world, was standing in the newsroom of her college paper at Humboldt State University in Northern California when a fellow student rushed in with startling news.

title: A Sharper Mind, Middle Age and Beyond
description: IN 1905, at age 55, Sir William Osler, the most influential physician of his era, decided to retire from the medical faculty of Johns Hopkins. In a farewell speech, Osler talked about the link between age and accomplishment: The effective, moving, vitalizing work of the world is done between the ages of 25 and 40  these 15 golden years of plenty.

title: A West Coast University Targets Spanish Speakers Struggling with English
description: The pathway to higher education can be blocked for some would-be students because they are not proficient enough in English to succeed in a traditional college. And as they grow older, they may find their opportunities further constrained by their lack of a degree.

title: Fiat to Unveil 500 Wagon at Geneva Auto Show
description: In an interview with Bloomberg, Olivier Franois, the head of the Fiat brand, said that the Italian automaker would show a wagon variant of the 500 supermini at the Geneva auto show in March, which would go on sale in the United States next year.

title: Josh Norman Gains Notice Before Shrine Game
description: Cecil Lammey will file reports leading up to the East-West Shrine Game on Saturday. It is the first of the major postseason scouting events.

title: Securities Lawsuits Hold Steady but Below Average
description: While some commentators may believe that corporate America is awash in class-action lawsuits by angry investors, a new study to be published on Thursday suggests otherwise.

title: Bogomolov Switches Flags in a Boost For Russia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  When Michael Llodra of France is playing his best tennis, one can almost hear light chamber music playing softly from somewhere in the distance, matching Llodras airy, graceful prancing around the court, his one-handed backhand sweeping like a conductors wand.

title: Swiss Re Appoints New Chief Executive
description: LONDON  Swiss Re, the worlds second-largest reinsurer, said on Thursday that Michel M. Lis will take over as the companys chief executive on Feb. 1.

title: Tomlinson Says Rex Ryan Should Tone It Down
description: After the Steelers traded Santonio Holmes to the Jets for a fifth-round pick in April 2010, this question was posed on The Fifth Down:

title: A Sauce Worth Slaving Over
description: A couple of years ago, a friend told me that a vegan Japanese restaurant called Kajitsu was doing the best food in the city. I ignored him. (Typical: I ignored him when he told me about Noma, and I at first ignored friends who told me about Momofuku, El Bulli and, in 1987, the young chefs Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Thomas Keller. So much for the vision thing.) After this friend called me stupid once or twice, I made it over to the place, which is in the East Village, just down the block from the Good Beer Store. The word best should not be thrown around, but I will say that Kajitsu is distinctive, astonishing and wonderful.

title: Do Men Treat Female Business Owners Differently?
description: There are many ways a factory can botch an order of dresses. Susan Parker spent the last month of 2011 dealing with a couple of them. She shared her experiences during the most recent meeting of our business group, and we wandered into a discussion of the challenges faced by women who own businesses, especially those operating in male-dominated industries like the garment business.

title: A Federal Budget of Just $10 Million, but Somethings Familiar
description: This is going to sound unpleasantly like a question on a high school history exam: Compare and contrast the federal budget of 1797-98 with the federal budget of 2012.

title: Santorum Edges Ahead of Romney in Iowa
description: 2:25 p.m. | Updated  Rick Santorums campaign claimed a belated victory in the Iowa caucuses on Thursday morning after certified results from the contest showed him leading Mitt Romney by 34 votes, a reversal from the eight-vote edge for Mr. Romney on caucus night.

title: Big Serve, Bright Future for a Young Canadian
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It is the shot, the gift, that could make Milos Raonic a big tennis star in an era already brimming with them. It begins with Raonic selecting the most promising of three balls and stepping to the baseline.

title: What a Difference a Year Makes
description: CAIRO  When I first met Sally Toma last year, she was flush with victory. After 18 days of protests in Tahrir Square, Hosni Mubarak, Egypts long-time strongman, had been toppled and the credit went to the Coalition of Revolution Youth, the 17-member committee of representatives from different youth groups that had started the protests. Toma, a 33-year-old psychiatrist, was the only woman and Coptic Christian member.

title: Murdoch Settles Suits by Dozens of Victims of Hacking
description: LONDON  Rupert Murdochs media empire has agreed to pay substantial damages to several dozen high-profile victims of phone and e-mail hacking, and lawyers for those victims said Thursday that they had seen documents showing that senior managers not only knew about the hacking but also lied about it and destroyed evidence as part of a cover-up.

title: Bank of America Swings to a Profit, Mostly From One-Time Items
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Morgan Stanley Reports Loss as Settlement Weighs on Results
description: Morgan Stanley, hit hard by a big legal charge and a difficult economy, swung into the red in the fourth quarter, reporting a loss of $275 million.

title: Pilots Who Fought to Soar Above Racism
description: Patriotic, jingoistic, old-fashioned, corny and inspirational for teenage boys. Those are the words of George Lucas, the executive producer of Red Tails, describing his whiz-bang action film about African-American fighter pilots in World War II on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.

title: Peter and the Starcatcher Will Land on Broadway in March
description: Peter Pan is coming back to Broadway  though not the flying, singing Peter who audiences know well. Rick Elices play Peter and the Starcatcher, which had a well-reviewed Off Broadway run at New York Theater Workshop last spring, will begin preview performances at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on March 28 and open on April 15, the producers of the show said on Thursday.

title: Title Game Probabilities: Giants Should Be Favored
description: Recency bias is when we overemphasize the importance of recent events, just as many observers are doing this week with the most recent Ravens and Patriots games. Baltimore eked out a win over the Texans with a lackluster performance on offense, while New England dominated the Broncos on both sides of the ball. Dont put too much stock in those two games. In Baltimores case, keep in mind that Houston owned one of the very best defenses this season, allowing only 5.2 yards per pass attempt and yielding only a 39 percent run success rate, good for second and seventh in the league. And regarding New England, remember that Denver was overmatched in several departments and had backed into the playoffs with a mediocre record.

title: More Veterans Receive Help With Heating Bills
description: The number of low-income veterans receiving government assistance for their heating and cooling bills hit a new high last year, according to a survey by a federal energy-assistance program.Over the last four years, the survey found, the number of low-income households with at least one military veteran receiving federal energy assistance rose by about 1.1 million households, to 1.78 million.

title: BlackRocks 4th-Quarter Profit Falls 16%
description: 5:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Teachers Turn Out in Force at PEP Meeting
Daily Report: A New Power Hits Washington
description: Washingtons old guard of media lobbyists  including the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Recording Industry Association of America and the motion picture lobby  was forced to make way for the new on Wednesday as Web powerhouses backed by Internet activists rallied opposition to antipiracy legislation by using Internet blackouts and cascading criticism, reports Jonathan Weisman from Washington. He said it sent an unmistakable message to lawmakers grappling with new media issues: Dont mess with the Internet.

title: Opinion Report: Online Piracy
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Image of the Day: January 19
In Bat Deaths, a Catastrophe in the Making?
description: A biodiversity crisis: thats how some conservationists describe new numbers released this week by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service on so-called white-nose syndrome. According to the agency, 5.7 million to 6.7 million bats have died from the fungal ailment in eastern North America since an epidemic first broke out in upstate New York in 2006.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: The Web Rages and Gingrich Pushes Back at ABC
description: The campaign of Newt Gingrich issued an open letter on Wednesday night to ABC News leadership, as word leaked out  if a siren on Drudge Report can be called a leak  that the network had conducted an interview with one of Mr. Gingrichs former wives, Marianne Gingrich. The letter, signed by Mr. Gingrichs two daughters from his first marriage, Kathy Lubbers and Jackie Cushman, faulted the network for engaging in talk about the past, just days before an important primary election, Trip Gabriel and Brian Stelter reported. The interview will be broadcast on Nightline at 11:35 p.m. Thursday, shortly after a Republican debate sponsored by CNN.

title: Romneys New Target: Gingrichs Job Creation Claims
description: IRMO, S.C.  Mitt Romneys stump speeches at rallies like the one here on Wednesday night are largely patriotic goo, but in the last day or two hes also thrown in a newly sharpened jab at Newt Gingrich.

title: The Campster | The Everglades
description: In this column, Jeff Thrope stakes out sublime weekend excursions for the city-dwelling camper.

title: Politicians Ambitions and Indiscretions, on Taxpayers Tab
description: In the dispute over New York Citys policy of digitally fingerprinting applicants for food stamps, an interesting footnote was provided by Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. In 2007, Gov. Eliot Spitzer (remember him?) banned finger-imaging for most of the state beyond the city. Mr. Berg reminded us that one elected official among Mr. Spitzers fellow Democrats vigorously attacked the governor for this action.

title: Perry Ends Bid for Presidency
description: 11:45 a.m. | Updated NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas dropped out of the Republican presidential race here on Thursday and announced his endorsement for the candidacy of Newt Gingrich, a man he called a conservative visionary.

title: European Central Bank to Recover Most of Its Lehman Loans
description: 5:31 p.m. | Updated

title: The Tweeting Dead
description: Oy. Ari Fleischer is using Twitter to repeat the old zombie lie about how the tax burden on the rich has risen, because theyre paying a higher share of federal taxes than they used to. Mark Thoma handles this fine, no need for me to weigh in. Basically, if the income of the 1 percent has tripled relative to the income of the middle quintile, how are they suffering if their tax burden relative to the middle class rises by a substantially smaller amount?

title: Thursday Reading: Healthy Patients Can Delay Bone Density Retests
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Says Law For Thee But Not For Me
description: In correspondence, Mark Thoma notes a double standard in the conservative outcry over the Keystone XL decision. As he notes, when it comes to the question of whether government spending can create jobs, the usual suspects claim that its logically impossible: income has to be spent somewhere, so all the government can do is divert funds from other uses. But when its a private investment, somehow that logic no longer applies.

title: Occupy London to Appeal Ruling Against Campsite
description: LONDON  Protestors in the Occupy London movement have until Jan. 27 to appeal against a legal ruling to remove their campsite in front of St. Pauls Cathedral, located in the heart of Londons financial district.

title: Long-Awaited Scipio Tombs Reopen in Rome
description: The founder of one of ancient Romes most illustrious clans, consul Lucius Cornelius Scipio Barbato, began building monumental tombs for his relatives in the third century B.C., and the family continued to use the site as a place of rest until the first century A.D. The site was forgotten, then made into a public park in 1929 and shuttered for restorations in 1992. This week, for the first time in two decades, the tomb of the Scipios has been reopened to the public (Via di Porta Sebastiano 9, www.060608.it).Among the Scipios entombed there were two of the Punic Wars greatest Roman heroes: Scipio Africanus Major, the general who defeated Hannibal and ended the Second Punic War, and Scipio Africanus Minor, who destroyed Carthage and ended the Third Punic War.

title: The Price of Leadership
description: A Duty to Be Brave?

title: Edgar Allan Poe Fans Say Nevermore to Vigil for Mystery Admirer
description: It wouldnt be an Edgar Allan Poe story without an unhappy ending. For the third year in a row an enigmatic fan who has visited the Baltimore grave of that macabre author has failed to materialize, and the custom of awaiting this visitors arrival has come to an end.

title: Media Deal Brings Ads to Photographs
description: Consumers have gotten used to seeing digital advertisements near articles they read, before videos they watch or next to search results on the Internet. Now they will probably start seeing more ads placed on photographs.

title: Seeing Things | Found Muji
description: I make a beeline for Muji whenever I visit Tokyo (or New York, London or Paris). Japans chicly simple no-brand brand hasnt set up shop yet in Los Angeles, and Im addicted to its basic, everyday products. When I was in Tokyo a few weeks ago, I was excited to discover Found Muji, a new concept store that opened in November. (The Web site is in Japanese only.) Housed in the Aoyama-area retail space where Mujis first stand-alone store opened in 1983, Found Muji takes the company back to its roots.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Post: So much for that healthier eating thing: The night before Paula Deen announced she has diabetes, Page Six reports, she finished off a meal at Ristorante Asellina with the tiramisu.  Patrick Farrell

title: Panko-Fried Vegetables
description: Time: About 1 hour

title: Vegan Worcestershire Sauce, Two Ways

title: And the Official Winner in Iowa Is  Who Cares?
description: I travel to Iowa for the caucuses every four years, like all political journalists, but Ive never quite understood the point. Yes, I know Iowa is commonly referred to as the first delegate selection contest in the nation. But its not. No delegates are actually selected at the caucuses. Its supposed to be a bellwether for the nation, but its not. The Iowa caucuses, especially the Republican ones, have a mixed record at predicting the next nominee, and a fairly bad one at predicting the next president.

title: 36 Hours: Hamburg, Germany
description: A photographic tour of the city.

title: 36 Hours: Hamburg, Germany
description: NO one tells you how pretty Hamburg is. Thats because so few people mention Hamburg in the first place. American tourists and businesspeople gravitate toward other German cities: Berlin, Munich, Frankfurt. And so Hamburg, bigger than all but Berlin, remains a bit of a mystery, poised to become a thrilling discovery. Did you know about the lake? Its smack dab in the city center and skirted by regal buildings, a postcard-ready tableau if there ever was one. And the canals? They lattice the part of the city nearest the Elbe River, allowing Hamburg to joust with Stockholm, Amsterdam and Bruges for informal rights to call itself the Venice of northern Europe. Hamburg in winter is cold and often gray. No getting around that. But the indoors migration of many Hamburg residents gives the city a quiet and peace that I relished on a recent visit. Sure, the blustery weather persuaded me to skip the lake ferries and Elbe cruises recommended in summertime. But it wasnt an obstacle to appreciating Hamburgs formidable charms.

title: U.S. Navy Says It Assists Third Iranian Crew in Distress

title: Someone Done Her Wrong. Horrible Mistake.
description: When you think about it, the phrase action movie is a bit redundant. Really, what else are motion pictures for? In the earliest days of cinema our ancestors were thrilled to behold images of galloping horses, hurtling trains and capering dancers. Though our entertainments are now more elaborate, our appetites are not so different. A large part of what we crave is action: running, jumping, fighting, driving, flying. Sometimes everything else  plot, character, emotion  can seem superfluous.

He was surrounded by models wearing plastic covers, like tea cozies, over their suits and vicuna coats to keep them spotless for the runway. title: Broadways Big Prime-Time Moment
description: DECADES before his elaborate film productions like E.T. and Saving Private Ryan, Steven Spielberg cut his teeth as a high school stage manager in Phoenix, feeding lines to forgetful actors in Guys and Dolls and trying to keep the members of a large Brigadoon cast from turning into bumper cars. Backstage drama provided the first adrenaline rush of his career, he said, and always struck him as good material. So much so that, a few years ago, Mr. Spielberg began shopping around a television series set on Broadway, but he met with rejection from HBO (where he made Band of Brothers) and the broadcast networks.

Clean with modern finishes (light gold hardware, single zipper pouch inside) and not a logo in sight, the canvas shopper also comes in navy, orange and yellow leather. title: Theater Talkback: Watching Without Expectations
description: The new production of Porgy and Bess that opened recently on Broadway  now crassly, not to mention inaccurately, branded The Gershwins Porgy and Bess  has become perhaps the most controversial musical revival in recent memory. It has been interesting to note how people are reacting to the show in different ways according to their familiarity with the score, and more particularly their history (or not) of hearing it in the opera house, where it has most regularly been performed since its Broadway debut in 1935. Despite laffair Sondheim, many people seem to enjoy it.

title: Mike OBrien Is Famous! (On the Internet)

Online, there exists a different set of A-Listers, whose work reaches an audience of millions and attracts rabid, devoted fans. And no one in the real world has any idea. Internet fame can be cultivated or unexpectedly backed into. It can lead to TV pilot deals, commercial work, merchandise sales, book agents and other tangible successes. Its time these secret celebrities got introduced to the mainstream in Theyre Famous! (On the Internet).

title: Self-Immolation Protest in Morocco Captured on Video
description: Silhouetted against a ball of flame, a Moroccan protester lurched forward through a screaming crowd in the center of Moroccos capital, Rabat. The scene, captured on video, offers a rare glimpse of the spate of self-immolations across North Africa and the Middle East in emulation of the Tunisian protest that helped set off the Arab Spring.

title: Parental Quandary Considered: Lying to the In-Laws About Church
description: S. admits it. She and her husband have been lying to her in-laws about going to church. I suggested they were fibbing, but whatever you call it, the truth remains: its so much easier to pretend, on the phone to her husbands minister father and his wife, that the religion S. and her husband both grew up in remains a part of their daily life. But as S. said when she described her quandary to me, the differences between the way she and her husband practice their religion and the way his parents do cant be tiptoed around for long  not with a chatty toddler in the mix.

title: New Definition of Autism Will Exclude Many, Study Suggests
description: Proposed changes in the definition of autism would sharply reduce the skyrocketing rate at which the disorder is diagnosed and might make it harder for many people who would no longer meet the criteria to get health, educational and social services, a new analysis suggests.

title: Newt Gingrich, Nutty Radio Talk Show Host
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  Newt Gingrich is climbing past Rick Santorum in the polls here, and is already proclaiming himself the only conservative alternative to Mitt Romney. The reason for his rising popularity is not really because hes more conservative than Mr. Santorum  hes not  or because he will bring about more conservative change, as Rick Perry said in endorsing him today before leaving the race.

title: Corporate Taxes And The .01 Percent
description: Some readers have asked whether the picture of very low taxes on the very rich changes once you take taxes on corporate profits into account, and impute them to stockholders. The answer is that yes, it does, somewhat  but there are a number of implications of such an imputation, and if I were a conservative, I really wouldnt want to go there.

title: Two More Billion-Dollar Weather Disasters
description: The count of billion-dollar weather disasters for 2011 has taken another jump. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, still adding up the costs of the extreme weather events that plagued the country last year, announced on Thursday that two more had surpassed the $1 billion mark, for a total of 14. And the agency is still counting.

title: Dries Van Noten: Wilde but Not Crazy
description: The show notes promised psychedelic elegance and Wilde meets Zappa, and backstage Dries Van Noten explained that his mens collections had become so serious and that he wanted to get a little crazy. Both Oscar Wilde and Frank Zappa are fairly loaded guns, and after seeing the show tonight at the Grand Palais, I cant really tell you how much of either man was represented in the multicolored prints (mildly psychedelic), the calligraphy-lettered quotations on shirts (definitely Wilde), or the elongated 70s tailoring (could be Frank). The prints certainly didnt make a crazy statement. If youre in the market next fall for a good-looking peacoat or streamlined overcoat with modest military styling, this collection is worth a look. But there was very little madness in Mr. Van Notens method.

title: Reading With Strangers: Ways to Study Literature Collaboratively
description: Inspired by the example of two New Jersey high school teachers who brought their students together in reading John Steinbecks Of Mice and Men, we offer you some ideas for reading alongside others in different places, circumstances and stages of life, and perhaps to bridge some divides.

title: Citys Jobless Rate Rises as Nations Falls
description: Almost since the recession began, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has boasted that New York Citys economy weathered the downturn better than the rest of the nation and bounced back faster.

title: Swiss Downhill Star Cuche Announces Retirement
description: KITZBHEL, Austria  The skier Didier Cuche, a former butcher from the small Swiss village of Le Paquier, has won an Olympic medal, 4 world championship medals and 18 World Cup victories. His impressive 19-year career was hardly showing signs of a steep decline, as he has won four of the last five World Cup downhill titles.

title: ABC Worked for Months to Get Marianne Gingrich Interview
description: The television interview of Marianne Gingrich, a former wife of Newt Gingrich, that will be broadcast on Thursday night was initiated back in November, when ABC News was looking into an old federal investigation that involved the family.

title: Stephenss Talent and Promise Evident in Loss
description: Sloane Stephenss close loss to the veteran Svetlana Kuznetsova in the second round of the Australian Open Thursday was filled with subtle lessons. She had chances to win the first set, but Kuznetsova prevailed, 8-6, in the tiebreaker. The set took 69 minutes and Stephens came away with nothing. It is perhaps the harshest aspect of the tennis scoring system: sets and games  no matter how close  are winner take all. Other sports (football and basketball come to mind) stop at halftime and each team still has a chance to win. In other words, the losing teams points are not erased.

title: Yet Another Insider Trading Case Begins to Unfold
description: The government has moved yet again in its effort to crack down on insider trading, filing charges against seven defendants with ties to hedge funds who federal prosecutors say operated as a circle of friends by trading information.

title: State Department Readies an R.S.V.P.
description: Congressional Republicans,furious over President Obamas rejection of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, are calling for Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to address the State Departments review of the project at a House hearing next week.

title: Unearned, and Taxed Unequally
description: Whatever happened to unearned income?

title: Data Analytics Company Finds Fraud Is a Friend
description: Crime detection pays.

title: Laurents/Hatcher Playwriting Prize Goes to Modern Terrorism
description: A new play titled Modern Terrorism has been selected for the 2012 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, a generous theater prize that provides $50,000 to the author  in this case, Jon Kern  and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for the plays premiere. Trustees for the foundation of the writer and director Arthur Laurents (West Side Story, Gypsy) and his partner of 52 years, Tom Hatcher, announced the selection of Mr. Kern on Thursday; he is a graduate of the Columbia University masters program in playwriting as well as the University of Chicago.

title: Tout Wants to Tame Your Inbox
description: Each year, the average person receives about 15,000 e-mails. For business professionals, the number is a bit bigger, anywhere from 40,000 to 80,000 messages a year, according to Tout, a small start-up company that tries to help people manage their e-mail accounts.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 19
description: A view of the day in sports, including ski jumping in Poland and dog sledding in Scotland.

title: Suicides Among Active-Duty Troops Rose in 2011, U.S. Army Says
description: WASHINGTON  Suicides among active-duty soldiers hit a new high in 2011, Army officials said on Thursday, although there was a slight decrease in suicides overall, if non-mobilized Reserve and National Guard troops were included in the calculation.

title: Gingrich Does Not Respond to Ex-Wifes Claims
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  It was a day of extraordinary contrasts for Newt Gingrich, who welcomed the endorsement of Rick Perry, and hoped to use it to unite conservatives and add to his momentum in the polls, while playing down how values voters might respond to a former wifes claim that he had asked for an open marriage.

title: Musical Version of Far From Heaven Will Debut at Williamstown
description: From Douglas Sirk to Todd Haynes and now to the stage of the 2012 Williamstown Theater Festival: thats the journey to be taken by Far From Heaven, a musical adaptation of Mr. Hayness 2002 film of the same name, which starred Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid.

title: TimesCast | Phone Hacking Settlements
description: January 19, 2012  In the legal battle over phone hacking, lawyers identify some of the high-profile victims, including Jude Law, who have reached settlements with the News Corp.

title: Ethnic War Rekindled in Myanmar
description: For years, the Kachin Independence Army controlled Myanmars northern hills, which separatists call their ethnic homeland. Now, the Burmese Army has pushed in, displacing thousands.

title: Violence Against the Kachin in Northern Burma
description: A report from a fact-finding mission to northern Myanmar in October 2011 to document violence against the Kachin ethnic group. (Warning: Contains Graphic Images)

title: In Battle for Autonomy, Kachin Come Under Siege in Myanmar
description: A look inside territory controlled by the Kachin ethnic group in Myanmar, near the border with China.

title: Gagosian Sued for Selling Lichtenstein Painting Without Owners Consent
description: A prominent art collector has sued the dealer Larry Gagosian, claiming that he sold a 1964 Roy Lichtenstein painting from her collection without her consent. The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers.

title: An Ethnic War Is Rekindled in Myanmar
description: MAIJA YANG, Myanmar  Even as the Burmese government initiates political reforms in much of the country, it has intensified an ethnic civil war here in the resource-rich hills of northern Myanmar, a conflict that at once threatens its warming trend with the United States and could alienate Chinese officials concerned about stability on the border.

title: Googles Results Disappoint, Sending Shares Down
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Larry Page, Googles chief executive and co-founder, celebrated the first anniversary of the announcement that he would take over the company with the news Thursday that it had exceeded $10 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time.

title: Egypts Military Ruler Told Carter Video of Soldiers Stomping on Woman Was Fake
description: During a conversation with former President Jimmy Carter last week, Egypts current head of state, Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, claimed that widely circulated video images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking a female protester on the pavement of Tahrir Square last month were entirely fake.

title: Profit Increases 6% at Intel
description: Intels profit rose only 6 percent in the fourth quarter, the company said Thursday, as the impact of last years catastrophic flooding in Thailand, which devastated hard-drive production, began to affect PC sales.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 20-26
description: Around Town

title: New York City Opera Ratifies Agreement
description: New York City Operas orchestra ratified a three-year contract on Thursday that provides for deep cuts but also a new labor-management committee to deal with fund-raising, planning and artistic matters. An agreement had been reached earlier this week, ending a lockout and nearly a year of bitter negotiations. Tino Gagliardi, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra players, said in a statement that they agreed to deep concessions in hopes of raising City Opera from the ashes. The financially pressed company has moved out of its home at Lincoln Center to present a sharply reduced season in several theaters around New York.

title: Ben Jonson: In and Out of Shakespeares Shadow
description: Writing a few decades after the deaths of the two greatest writers of the Elizabethan and Jacobean era, the poet and critic John Dryden came clean about his feelings toward both. I admire him, he wrote of Ben Jonson, but I love Shakespeare.

title: Mugler: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: I.B.M.s Profit Beats Forecast
description: The I.B.M. formula continues to pay off.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 20-26
description: Movies

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 20  26
description: Theater

title: 8 Guilty for Prison Massacre in Rare Trial of Haitis Police
description: In a country where officials who abuse their power are almost never held accountable, 8 of 14 police officers tried for a 2010 prison massacre were found guilty on Thursday in the southern city of Les Cayes, Haiti.

title: Driving the Fisker Karma
description: The production version of the Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid visited The New York Times Wednesday evening and was offered for a brief test drive that amounted to a modest victory lap for the long-delayed performance sedan. The Karma finally reached dealers and its first customers late last year, albeit at a price roughly $20,000 higher than its initial projections.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Jan. 20-26
description: Brooklyn Inventgenuity Festival

title: Christian Lacroix: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Watching Them Watching Me
description: TO celebrate our 25th anniversary, I had the videotape of our wedding converted into a DVD as a surprise for my wife. This was going to be a stay-at-home anniversary; we had splurged on our 20th knowing that by this year our oldest son would be frighteningly close to college. So a quiet dinner and a movie  our own movie  were what I had in mind.

title: Weak Sales of PCs Over the Holidays Hurt Microsofts Income
description: SEATTLE  Weak sales of personal computers made for a tough holiday selling season for Microsoft.

title: How the Definition of Autism May Change
description: Read the American Psychiatric Associations proposed changes to the definition of autism.

title: L.L. Bean Outfits Bootmobile for Nationwide Tour
description: In 1912, Leon Leonwood Bean, a hunting enthusiast who had grown dissatisfied with the standard leather hunting boot of the time, designed a model with a rubber sole and shell stitched to a leather upper. The Maine Hunting Shoe was the first product to be sold by L.L. Bean, the clothing company he founded in Freeport, Me.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 20-26
description: Pop

title: Issey Miyake: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 20-26
description: Jazz

title: Want a Cheaper Super Bowl Ticket? Wait Two Weeks.
description: Think you might want to go to the Super Bowl? To get the lowest price on the resale market, you may want to wait until the last minute.

description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 20-26
description: Dance

title: Debate Caps Big Day on the Trail
description: The shrinking field of Republican candidates  now just four  will cap a volatile day on the campaign trail with another debate on Thursday night, this time at the North Charleston Coliseum in Charleston, S.C.

title: Another American Dancer Joins a Russian Ballet Company
description: Keenan Kampa, a member of the Boston Ballet  and a rare American to attend the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia, is joining the Mariinsky Ballet. The Mariinsky said Ms. Kampa, 22, was becoming the first American in its ranks. She starts June 2012. The announcement follows the news last year that David Hallberg was joining the Bolshoi Ballet, the first American to become a principal dancer there. Ms. Kampa, from Reston, Va., attended summer programs at the Boston Ballet and American Ballet Theater in New York as well as master classes at the Kennedy Center. The Mariinsky said she was also the first American to receive a degree from the Vaganova, a storied school that produced George Balanchine, Vaslav Nijinsky, Rudolf Nureyev and Anna Pavlova, among other prominent dancers.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 20-26
description: Art

title: Decision About One Second Is Postponed for Three Years
description: The leap second survives  for at least three more years.

title: Karzai Aide Says U.S. Isnt Providing Enough Details About Taliban Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzais chief of staff expressed concern on Thursday about the American role in starting talks with the Taliban, complaining that Afghan officials were not being kept well informed and worrying about the possibility that the Taliban might make a secret deal with the United States.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Chile, Cuba and Turkey.

title: Rick Owens: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: A Lilac-Hued Bacon at Christies
description: Have a Francis Bacon to sell? London is where many auction house experts are advising collectors to try their luck. Weve seen extraordinary prices paid for Bacons in London in recent years, said Brett Gorvy, international chairman of Christies postwar and contemporary art department. Americans have competed as aggressively as buyers from emerging markets. And with so many rich Russians and Middle Easterners putting down roots in London, its the obvious place to sell.

title: Louis Vuitton: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: The Childrens Cup
description: Amsterdam Arena, capacity 52,342, became one of the biggest day-care centers in the world Thursday when about 20,000 children (joined by their minders) were given free admission to the Dutch Cup replay between Ajax and AZ in the Netherlands.

title: Reinventing Textbooks: A Hard Course
description: A technology company announces plans to reinvent higher education by encouraging the creation of a new kind of textbook. Students will learn better, faster, cheaper. They will be spurred to new triumphs that will finally reverse the persistent decline in American education and the American way of life.

title: Migraine Art
description: A series of paintings by migraine patients.

title: A City Portrayed by Diarists Who Had Their Own Problems
description: When Simone de Beauvoir, the French existentialist, first tried to smoke marijuana, she, like Bill Clinton, did not inhale. It was May 3, 1947, and she was as new to New York City as she was to the drug.

title: Sniffing and Pinching Help Her Deal With Her Grief
description: Grief causes people to do odd things. Like sniff their grown daughters bra. (Not while its being worn, but still.) Or pinch a police officer. Twice.

title: Meeting Complex Bartok With Ease and Imagination
description: The superstar pianist Lang Lang may shamelessly cultivate a flamboyant persona. And he has been criticized widely for exaggerated expressivity. Still, no fair-minded person can deny that Mr. Lang has stupendous technique and keen musical instincts.

title: A Master and His Peers in the Glow of a Golden Age
description: You wont see much of Rembrandt in Rembrandts World: Dutch Drawings From the Clement C. Moore Collection, at the Morgan Library & Museum. This exhibition of about 90 works on paper, all promised gifts to the Morgan, includes just four drawings attributed to that master.

title: At a Winter Perennial, Old Objects That Are Never Pass
description: This years Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory offers the usual embarrassment of riches. Shining suits of knightly armor, mysteriously sensuous classical Indian stone sculptures, ceramics and red lacquer boxes from the Far East, sumptuous rugs, rare books and autographic documents, paintings and furniture from several centuries, jewelry, fancy early-American rifles and countless hard-to-classify oddities are displayed by 73 dealers from around the world.

title: Beauty Queen With No Place to Hide
description: A first-rate art-house thriller, Miss Bala tells the strange, seemingly impossible story of a Mexican beauty queen who becomes the accidental pawn of a drug cartel. Its an adventure story that could be called a contemporary picaresque if it werent so deadly serious, and might be called fantastical if it werent loosely based on a true story of a former Miss Hispanic America. One day a beautiful young woman, Laura (a sympathetic Stephanie Sigman), is trying to enter a Miss Baja contest; a few hours later shes cowering in a nightclub, dodging gunfire and gangsters who bequeath her another title, Miss Bala  Miss Bullet.

title: Brokers Say Good Riddance to 2011
description: Melville

title: What Other Auctioneers Decide to Leave Behind
description: As soon as a rich New Yorker dies, the major auction houses typically send condolence letters. Then their experts go to the apartment or town house, offering to handle antiques and artworks worth more than a few thousand dollars each. Once the estate has been settled and the best stuff taken away, the secondary auction houses help clean out anything else old.

title: Belly Up to the Basement Bar
description: THERE was a classic 50s wet bar in the basement of a Bloomfield Cape sold by Roberta Plutzik Baldwin a few years ago. It had knotty pine paneling, a plaid carpet, sea netting and harbor lights  and it looked, Ms. Baldwin recalled, as if Troy Donahue might show up any minute.

title: Why Taxes Arent as High as They Seem
description: WASHINGTON  When people heard that Mitt Romneys federal income tax rate was about 15 percent, the immediate reaction of many was to assume that their own rate was higher. The top marginal rate is 35 percent, after all, and the marginal rate on a couple with $70,000 in taxable income is 25 percent.

title: A Tough Sell, in Concrete and Glass
description: RIDGEFIELD

title: Q & A
description: Landmark Co-op, New Windows

title: A Reprieve for Unemployed Borrowers
description: FANNIE MAE and Freddie Macs recent extension of forbearance programs will give short-term aid to unemployed homeowners, but housing counselors warn that these borrowers will need to look at longer-term solutions.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook Verbs and Taming E-Mail Alerts
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Photos of the Moment | Kolor
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Phillip Lim Mens
description: Paris

title: Esquire Uses Clinton to Lead Print Readers to Video
description: As Republicans battle to see who will win the presidential nomination, a familiar Democrat is turning up on covers of Esquire magazines February edition: Bill Clinton.

title: For Edith Whartons Birthday, Hail Ultimate Social Climbers
description: In dramas about the British aristocracy we Americans await with tingly pleasure the inevitable moment when the family learnsthat there is no more money to run the estate, and everyone must retrench or  worse  the heir must get a job. Then, like the arrival of the cavalry in a western, all is saved  the footmen, the ancestral portraits, even the Georgian silver  by theimminent commingling of fortunes with an American kissing cousin who has daughters and dollars. The Upstairs Downstairs details long familiar from novels, movies and television shows, and nowfrom the popular Downton Abbey, seem to render us spellbound.

title: Edith Wharton Turns 150
description: As the popular Downton Abbey proves, stories of Americans mingling with members of the British aristocracy titillate as much as they did when Edith Wharton wrote of them.

title: Two Fairs, Not Homogenized
description: New York has become saturated with art fairs in the past decade, with committed art viewers spending much of late February and March wandering through partitioned spaces in convention centers, former warehouses or hotels turned into ad hoc trading posts. Not surprisingly, complaints of a homogenizing effect have been on the rise; all that newness, hipness and being in sync with the discourse can have an anesthetizing effect. Two smaller, idiosyncratic fairs taking place this weekend offer a slightly different experience.

title: AT&T Raises Data Prices for New Smartphone Customers
description: AT&T, the wireless carrier, will raise the cost of Internet data for new smartphone customers beginning Sunday. Though AT&Ts overall prices have increased, the new plans give customers more value per megabyte.

title: Plenty of Opponents, Outside and In
description: Hands tell the story in On Freddie Roach, a six-episode documentary series beginning on Friday on HBO. The flashing fists of young boxers in the ring move in counterpoint to the trembling fingers of Mr. Roach, a trainer and former fighter who now does battle with Parkinsons disease.

title: The Semantics and Statistics of Santorums Win in Iowa
description: Amid the swirl of developments on Thursday came word from the Iowa Republican Party that it had certified the results from the states Jan. 3 caucuses  and that Rick Santorum, not Mitt Romney, had gotten more votes. Mr. Santorum received 29,839 votes in the states certified tally, 34 more than Mr. Romney, who had 29,805.

title: High-Level Track and Field and Squash to Enjoy
description: The Misers new year exercise regime has not quite kicked in. No matter. This weekend is better for watching sports than for playing them. Theres a lot to choose from: squash at Grand Central Terminal and track and field at the Armory. Then next week theres wrestling, the first tournament of the NYC Mayors Cup 2012 season, at the Harlem Armory.

title: 3.1 Phillip Lim: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: The Trip Calculator of Another Time
description: BEFORE GIS, before GPS, before Google Earth, there was the milestone. These heavy markers, inscribed with distances to City Hall or other locations, went up in series as early as 1769, and once numbered 40 or 50 in all. About two dozen now survive, mostly in museums. Even at several feet high and weighing 200 pounds, the markers have proved remarkably difficult to track.

title: Sarah Burke, Freestyle Skier, Dies From Injuries in Training
description: Hurtling down a towering halfpipe on a pair of skis, no maneuver is routine. But Sarah Burke had done this one, the 540 Flat Spin, countless times.

title: Time to Stay Put
description: EIGHT years ago, after couch-surfing in faraway places, Ben Schulson called a friend who lived in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. His friend suggested that the footloose Mr. Schulson stay in his spare room, enticing him with the news that some cute girls shared the duplex downstairs.

title: Yohji Yamamoto Mens
description: Paris

title: Beyond the Roaming and Rambling, The Sensitive Side of Woody Guthrie
description: I never dread the day that I will die/Because my sunset is somebodys morning sky, Woody Guthrie wrote in his journal on April 17, 1942. More than six decades later those words became the bridge in My Battle, an unpublished Guthrie lyric set to music by the folk-rock singer-songwriter Jonatha Brooke and recorded on her 2008 album, The Works. That record was the focus of Ms. Brookes 90-minute Lincoln Center American Songbook show, in celebration of Guthries centennial, in the Allen Room on Wednesday night.

title: Symbiotic Bond for Stage and Screen Versions
description: FOR decades Broadway producers regarded Hollywood as the agent of death. They fought to delay film adaptations of West Side Story, Hello, Dolly!, The Wiz and other shows for fear that those movies would decimate ticket sales for the Broadway originals and their national tours. But this winter producers of the hit Broadway play War Horse have been cheering Steven Spielbergs new screen version, while those on the musical Rock of Ages have been helping rush the movie version (starring Tom Cruise and Alec Baldwin) toward a June release.

title: Birds, Jesus, Crystal and Rainbows, Dancing
description: When you think back on a concert in the hours and days after its over, it is no longer a unified whole. You have a general impression, sure, but what sticks out most are specific moments, individual players, passages of special eloquence.

title: Cronenbergs World
description: Images from films appearing in the Museum of the Moving Image series on David Cronenberg.

title: Happy to Mine Hidden Charm in Youthful Anger
description: SALLY FIELD likes the Welsh actor Matthew Rhys, she really likes him.

title: Some Smoother Edges, Soon to Come
description: Just how long will it take for Howler to become very, very handsome? Its the sort of transformation that happens to young and deeply capable bands plucked from relative obscurity  the bustling Minneapolis indie-rock scene in this case, but still  and delivered to the wider world.

title: Buildings Once Institutional, Now Exclusive
description: THERE have been times in New Yorks history, in response to economic downturns, when large apartments have been split up into smaller units. This is not one of those times.

title: Tracking the Hezbollah Connection in Thailand
description: PARIS  When police in Thailand this week discovered large stockpiles of chemicals often used to make bombs, they quickly said the material was going to be shipped out of Thailand to another (unnamed) country. The chemicals fertilizer ingredients in bags labelled as kitty litter  were going to be packed into boxes labeled electric fans and exported.

title: West African Rhythms And a Catalog Retooled
description: The E. J. Strickland Project and Olatuja Project, which appeared one after the other at 92Y Tribeca on Wednesday night, have a lot more in common than the last word in their names. But that mundane point of overlap tells you something about each group. One, led by the jazz drummer E. J. Strickland, made its set a bundle of newly rearranged Stevie Wonder songs; its project was discrete, like a home-improvement job. The other, led by the bassist Michael Olatuja and his wife, the singer Alicia Olatuja, simply delivered a well-honed message; its project was a perpetual thing, a way of being.

title: He Made Blood and Guts Familiar and Fabulous
description: The International Center of Photography has been Weegee Central since the end of 1993. Thats when it was bequeathed 16,000 photographs and 7,000 negatives by Wilma Wilcox, the longtime companion of Arthur Fellig (1899-1968). Fellig, the Austrian-born son of Jewish immigrants, grew up poor on the Lower East Side, fell in love with photography as a darkroom assistant, and in 1935 set out as a freelance news photographer.

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Perry Exits, and So Does His Depleted War Chest
description: Gov. Rick Perry took his fund-raising muscle with him Thursday when he bowed out of the Republican presidential race. His exit freed not only what was left in his federal campaign coffers, but also the support of the political action committee that had spent $3.9 million in Mr. Perrys favor.

description: Bureau

description: D. Wigmore Fine Art

description: Howard Greenberg Gallery

title: Thousands in Turkey Protest Verdict in Journalists Murder
description: ISTANBUL  Tens of thousands of people marched in central Istanbul on Thursday to mark the fifth anniversary of the murder of the prominent journalist Hrant Dink, and to protest a Turkish criminal courts refusal this week to investigate whether the killing had resulted from a conspiracy by an illegal network.

title: A Nuclear-Free Zone in the Middle East?
description: To the Editor:

title: Interiors: Pierre Bonnard, Marc Camille Chaimowicz, William Copley, douard Vuillard
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: McConnell Urges Delay on Piracy Bills
description: 7:06 p.m. | Updated Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, lent his voice Thursday to the growing chorus of lawmakers distancing themselves from legislation aimed at curbing Internet piracy that has lit up the Web with netizen protests.

title: Will Super Bowl Viewers Use an App During the Game? Chevy Hopes So
description: The Chevrolet division of General Motors, one of many car brands that will be advertised during Super Bowl XLVI on Feb. 5, is seeking to stand out by offering an app that viewers can use during the game to play games, interact with one another through Twitter and win prizes.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
