description: To the Editor:

title: A Final Indignity, Where the Crusade Began
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Year after year, the legend grew, in election night parties that always ended the same way  in victory.

title: Greece Inches Toward a Deal With Its Bondholders
description: LONDON  Greece and its private-sector creditors inched closer late Thursday to a completed deal over how much of a loss investors should take on just over 200 billion euros in Greek government bonds

title: Richard J. Sheirer, City Emergency Chief on 9/11, Dies
description: Richard J. Sheirer, the former head of the citys Office of Emergency Management who led the agency during the Sept. 11 attacks, died on Thursday morning while driving to work in Manhattan, the city said.

title: Two Koreas, at War but Closely Entwined
description: The barren expanse of rocks and dirt where most of Jang Huns Korean War drama, The Front Line, takes place is a hilly wasteland that has nothing of value beyond its strategic location near the disputed border of North Korea and South Korea. To watch the soldiers scrambling up and down slopes scarred with trenches and foxholes is to observe a maddening exercise in futility. Each engagement produces a new round of slaughter.

title: Brown Kicks Off Campaign by Warning of One-Party Control
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  At a rally to kick off his re-election campaign on Wednesday, Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts reminded several hundred supporters that he had defied steep odds to win a special election for the late Edward M. Kennedys Senate seat in 2010 and urged them to help prevent Democrats from reclaiming it in November.

title: After a Campaign That Fell Apart, a Second Act Is Still Possible
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Moralizings High Cost
description: Multiple marriages and even adultery are not automatic disqualifications for the presidency. If they were, the country would have a very different roster of former presidents and candidates. But when a political party decides that moralizing about personal conduct is as important as public policy, it inevitably makes some of its leaders vulnerable to the worst charges of hypocrisy.

title: A Case of She Said, She Said and He Cant Say
description: Structured much like the triangle from which it takes its name, Scalene opens with a scene so volcanic and mystifying that we are immediately ensnared.

title: Capital One Expects to Complete ING Direct Deal Soon
description: Whatever happened to Capital Ones bid for ING Direct USA?

title: Weegee: Murder Is My Business
description: The tabloid crime photographer Weegee is the subject of two new exhibitions in New York.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,859 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: UnitedHealth Beats Forecasts
description: UnitedHealth Group, the nations largest health insurer by sales, reported fourth-quarter earnings Thursday that beat analysts estimates after the company gained members and controlled costs.

title: A Match That Ends at Deuce
description: Pablum tarted up with tennis racquets, 16-Love is, in a sense, the perfect movie for teenagers: you can text and tweet to your hearts content and never miss a thing.

title: Gary Carter Has New Brain Tumors
description: Gary Carters condition has worsened with the discovery of new tumors on his brain, his daughter said Thursday on the familys blog.

title: Redefining Autism
description: After a proposed change to the definition of autism and a related disorder, far fewer people would meet the criteria for autism spectrum disorder.

title: A Jedi of Deals Brings His Magic Back to Morgan Stanley
description: Charles Cory, a longtime Morgan Stanley deal maker, spent the financial crisis cloistered in academia, working as a law professor at the University of Virginia.

title: Giants Pick Honorary Captains With Super Bowl Pedigrees
description: The Giants announced Thursday that three former Super Bowl winners  Mark Bavaro, Michael Strahan and Rich Seubert  would serve as honorary captains for Sundays N.F.C. championship game against the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Governor Cuomo to Be Subject of a Biography
description: A new  if inevitable  subgenre of New York political literature has arrived: the Andrew M. Cuomo biography.

title: Teamwork Propels a Plan to Expand Gambling
description: As lawmakers prepare for their spring legislative session, supporters of expanding gambling in Illinois said they were working toward a breakthrough agreement that might finally resolve one of the states longstanding items of unfinished business.

title: Who Owns My Ticket?
description: Washington

title: City Says It Will Focus on College Readiness
A Renewal of Urban History
description: The Pruitt-Igoe Myth tells the story of a public housing project in St. Louis that opened in the mid-1950s, part of the postwar dream of replacing slum apartments with modern, affordable high-rises. By the 1970s Pruitt-Igoe was in such disrepair that it was torn down, the demolition was televised, and a myth was born: public housing was a disaster, an example of government overreaching. The architect Charles Jencks even called the projects demise the death of Modern architecture.

title: A Judge Rules Vermont Cant Shut Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Thursday blocked Vermont from forcing the Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor to shut down when its license expires in March, saying that the state is trying to regulate nuclear safety, which only the federal government can do.

title: Russia: Election Official Offers to Resign
description: The countrys top election official, accused of overseeing a fraudulent parliamentary election last month, submitted his resignation on Thursday, Russian news agencies reported. But in a sign that the official, Vladimir Y. Churov, left, remains in favor with Russias leaders, the Central Election Commission immediately rejected his resignation. Mr. Churov, an ally of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, has called the elections free and fair, and he has denied any wrongdoing.

title: The Wealth Issue
description: Mitt Romney is a rich man, but is Mitt Romneys character formed by his wealth? Is Romney a spoiled, cosseted character? Has he been corrupted by ease and luxury?

title: Rwanda: 4 Military Officers Arrested
description: The government has placed four senior military officers under house arrest on counts of indiscipline and illegal business dealings in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, the military said Thursday. The arrests, which were made Wednesday, include Rwandas chief of military intelligence and chief of external intelligence. They were arrested for their dealing with civilians doing business in the Congo, a military spokesman, Col. Joseph Nzabamwita, said. The arrests come amid growing tensions between the government and a league of exiled soldiers in South Africa that the government accuses of trying to destabilize Rwanda. Colonel Nzabamwita denied the arrests were in connection to security threats, calling the suggestion a wild rumor.

title: Anime Heroes to the Rescue
description: Welcome back the Elric brothers, Edward and Alphonse, heroes of the Fullmetal Alchemist franchise. You may not know them, but plenty of anime fanatics do: a manga that began in 2001, the property later became two television series (one still on the Cartoon Network) and later a feature. (The Sacred Star of Milos is the sequel.)

title: For Online Privacy, Click Here
description: SOMETHING viewed online billions of times a month would seem to need no further promotion, but that assumption falls short when the something in question  a turquoise triangle in the upper right-hand corner of banner ads  is a critical piece of the debate about online privacy.

title: Gingrich Angrily Denies Open Marriage Request at Debate
description: There may have been no better way for Newt Gingrich to hammer back at the personal allegations from his ex-wife than to make the media the enemy for telling her story.

title: Taxes at the Top
description: Call me peculiar, but Im actually enjoying the spectacle of Mitt Romney doing the Dance of the Seven Veils  partly out of voyeurism, of course, but also because its about time that we had this discussion.

title: After 14-Year Run, Squash Juggernaut Loses a Match
description: The last time the Trinity mens squash team lost a match, President Clinton was denying he had sexual relations with an intern and Michael Jordan was midway through his final season with the Chicago Bulls. Since that loss to Harvard on Feb. 22, 1998, Trinity won 252 consecutive matches, including 13 national championships  the longest winning streak in college sports history. But The Streak, as it is known in squash circles, came to an end in New Haven on Wednesday when Yale downed Trinity, 5-4.

title: Pick Your Poison: A Bullet or a Virus
description: The Viral Factor wants to be both an action movie and a soap opera. But the merging of the two genres by Dante Lam, a director based in Hong Kong, is clumsy, and so is the film.

title: Aons Move to Britain and a Fleeting Notion of Corporate Citizenship
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: More on Romneys Tax Rate (and Everyone Elses)
description: There are any number ways to calculate a households tax rate. You can look at just the federal income tax and conclude that almost half of Americans dont pay taxes, or look at all taxes and conclude that a vast majority of Americans do pay taxes.

title: Syrias Rising Toll
description: The death toll from the brutal 10-month war by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria against his own people is now more than 5,400, according to the United Nations and others. Yet the international community still has not mustered the tough pressure that might force Mr. Assad to stop the killing, or Syrias Army and business elite to toss him out.

title: Looking for Halston, Finding the 70s
description: Early in Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston, Liza Minnelli, dressed in Halston stretch velvet leggings (wonderful!), gives the director, Whitney Sudler-Smith, a great piece of advice: Go do some research.

title: How Lennons Death Affected U.S.-Chinese Relations
description: In Watching TV With the Red Chinese, Tzu, Chen and Wa, three proud young Communists, arrive in New York in 1980 to pursue higher degrees in systems science. Dexter (Ryan ONan), an English literature graduate student living across the hall, becomes their cultural guide, decoding American customs and activities, like Halloween and football.

title: Spains Central Government to Rush Aid to Financially Ailing Regions
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The central government of Spain has moved to shore up the finances of the countrys 17 regional governments  some of which are having trouble paying their bills  while taking steps to tighten control over their spending.

title: The Pulse: Low Health Revenues Afflict County Budget
description: Cook Countys revenues fell $166.3 million (7.1 percent) short of expectations in the fiscal year that ended Nov. 30, with nearly all of the shortfall attributed to lower-than-expected patient fees fromthe countys health system, the countys interim comptroller said Wednesday.

title: Traveling to Teach English; Getting Sermons Instead
description: A few weeks before Christmas, someone passed Malachy F. Cleary Jr. a flier as he rushed from the subway station to class at Hunter College on the East Side of Manhattan. It was a call for volunteers to teach at an English Camp in Mexico during the winter break, no experience needed; $300 would cover transportation, room and board.

title: Santorum Attacks Romney and Gingrich on Health Care at Debate
description: Rick Santorum may have just made his clearest, most aggressive case yet that he  not Mitt Romney or Newt Gingrich  should be the nominee.

title: In a Family Emergency, $204 and Help With Red Tape
description: Last winter, when Salena Johnson had no money, her two young sons missed school for a week.

title: The Pulse: Woman Who Inspired Farmers Help Dies
description: Carol Bolander, 45, whose battle with cancer inspired the DeKalb County farm community to pull together and harvest her familys crops, died on Jan. 12 at home before dawn on the prairie, with her husband, Glenn, clasping her hands.

title: Gingrich Reports $3.1 Million in Income for 2010
description: While Newt Gingrich was beating up on the CNN moderator John King at Thursdays debate, his staff released his 2010 tax return.

title: A Complex at Aqueduct Is Risk-Free, Cuomo Says
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, stung by widespread doubts about his support for the privately financed construction of the countrys largest convention center at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, offered a full-throated defense of the proposal on Thursday, saying the only cost to the state if the project failed would be an empty building.

title: Putin Welcomes Kissinger: Old Friends to Talk Shop
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin will meet Friday with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to discuss world affairs, including elections in Russia and the United States, said Mr. Putins press secretary, Dmitri S. Peskov.

title: A Milestone in Fisheries Management
description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is about to reach a historic achievement. By May, the agency will have set annual catch limits for every federally managed fish species, more than 500 in all. Whats more, this vital task has been accomplished in a genuinely bipartisan manner. The law requiring annual limits, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, was reauthorized in 2007 with support from President George W. Bush and has been carried out by the Obama administration.

title: The Brute Force Behind the 49ers
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  The legend of Justin Smith began long before he shoved a Pro Bowl left tackle backward into his own quarterback, as if steering a childs push toy, on national television. It began even before he chased down a wide receiver in the open field to cause a fumble earlier this season.

title: Charleston, S.C., Debate Live Blog
description: The Republican presidential candidates  minus one, after Rick Perry dropped out earlier Thursday  take the stage in Charleston, S.C., at 8 p.m. Eastern time Thursday for the final debate before Saturdays South Carolina primary.

title: On Gary Carter and Faith
description: There is sad news about Gary Carter, the Hall of Fame catcher and a hero of the 1986 World Series for the Mets. Carters daughter wrote on the familys Web site Thursday that her fathers doctors had discovered several new spots/tumors on his brain. The Daily News called his condition extremely grave, and said doctors were deciding whether to continue his cancer treatments.

title: Romney Continues to Be Dogged on Tax Returns
description: Will Mitt Romney follow his fathers lead and release a dozen years of his tax returns?

title: The End of a Friendship?
description: We just witnessed the implosion of a long-time friendship and political alliance, as Mr. Santorum unloaded against Mr. Gingrich, his one-time mentor in the House  on his grandiosity, not having cogent thoughts and worrying whether somethings going to pop about his personal life.

title: Italy Finds a Heroic Foil for Its Scorned Captain
description: ROME  In Gregorio Maria De Falco, the until recently unknown head of operations at the Port Authority in the Tuscan coastal city of Livorno, Italy found itself not just a national hero, but the anointed foil to Capt. Francesco Schettino, the reckless and apparently cowardly captain of the cruise ship Costa Concordia.

title: Lechery, Immodesty and the Talmud
description: IS it possible for a religious demand for modesty to be about anything other than men controlling womens bodies? From recent events in Israel, it would certainly seem that it is not.

title: The Meaning of Scouting
description: The Colorado affiliate of Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. showed admirable understanding, and taught its young members a valuable lesson, when it said that it welcomes youngsters who were born male but identify as a girl and have a family that presents her as a girl. The group clarified its policy after the mother of a 7-year-old was mistakenly told that her child could not join a troop because he has boy parts and she publicly complained. The Scouts contacted the mother, but the child has not enrolled.

title: Candidates Weigh In on Internet Piracy Bills at Debate
description: The Republican candidates for president appear to be on the side of the Internet, not Hollywood.

title: Would South Carolina Be Better Off Blue?
Gunfire on Rocky Top
description: Despite being in the geographic center of the Civil War, battles in Appalachia were few and far between. There are a few conventional explanations. The areas topography made it a near-impenetrable borderland for an army of any size. And there was little there for a large occupying force to conquer in any case.

title: Legs That Go On and On, but Maybe Not for Long
description: SAG HARBOR, N.Y.  Of the sassy pair of female legs in retro stockings stepping out into Sag Harbors historic district, one can say this:

description: WASHINGTON  Suicides among active-duty soldiers hit another record high in 2011, Army officials said on Thursday, although there was a slight decrease if nonmobilized Reserve and National Guard troops were included in the calculation.

description: An officer shot a man in Queens on Thursday after he tried to steal an elderly mans car and brandished a painted BB gun, the police said.

description: WASHINGTON  A Central Intelligence Agency drone strike in Pakistans tribal area on Jan. 10 killed an operative of Al Qaeda who was believed to be planning attacks against the West, an American official confirmed on Thursday.

description: When Wikipedia went dark and Google blacked out its logo on Wednesday, millions of people could not help but notice. For most, it was the first time that they had heard about two antipiracy bills. One puzzled Twitter user wrote: Isnt a SOPA some kind of food?

description: WASHINGTON  When Jack Valenti walked the halls of Congress, friends by the dozen gripped, grinned and took note of what was worrying the movie industrys dapper chief lobbyist.

title: Los Angeles Police Investigate Human Remains Found in Bronson Canyon
description: LOS ANGELES  First there was a head, severed at the neck, found inside a plastic grocery bag near a popular hiking trail in the Hollywood Hills on Tuesday. Then on Wednesday, one hand was found, then the other. Then two feet.

title: A Boost for the Worlds Poorest Schools
description: Since the turn of the millennium, the world has made stunning progress toward the goal of universal primary education. In sub-Saharan Africa, enrollment in primary school has risen by 18 percentage points; in Asia and Latin America there has been more limited progress. While globally, 69 million school-age children do not attend school now, in 1999 that figure was 106 million. This is a huge achievement.

Newt Gingrich angrily turned aside questions about his marital history at the outset of the final Republican presidential debate before the South Carolina primary, and then aggressively took on Mitt Romney and the other remaining candidates in a raucous confrontation on Thursday night about immigration, abortion, conservative credentials and electability.

title: Ally of Christie Will Seek U.S. Senate Seat

Chris Christie, announced on Thursday that he would run in New Jersey this year for the United States Senate, seeking to unseat Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat and a bitter rival of the governor.

title: Romanian Protesters Urge Governments Ouster
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Thousands of protesters gathered in Romanias capital on Thursday to demand the ouster of the government and new elections, as a week of demonstrations against far-reaching austerity measures and years of difficult reforms seemed to gain strength.

description: ORLANDO, Fla.  While the Republican presidential contest in South Carolina riveted media attention on Thursday, President Obama literally flew above the fray in a day that captured the perquisites of incumbency for a president facing re-election.

title: After Anti-Semitic Crimes, Revisiting the Nightmares Forever Within
description: They come to talk about their families, to laugh, to learn and to praise Hilda Weisss famous chocolate coffee cake. Other than Mrs. Weisss recipe from Hungary, they never liked to go on about the past  even if this was the reason that originally brought the women together in a weekly support group for Holocaust survivors.

title: For Gingrich, Rivals Gift and an Ex-Wifes Sting
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  A moment that Newt Gingrich had long been hoping for and one that he had long been dreading collided on Thursday as a new opening for him to rally conservatives around his candidacy was suddenly complicated when the second of his three wives stepped forward to say he had asked for an open marriage.

title: A Free Legal Clinic That Opens When Class Is Over

That modest beginning has evolved into the Chicago Law and Education Foundation, a free clinic that has now expanded to eight additional city high schools.

title: Santorum Rose Quickly From Reformer to Insider
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Santorum arrived on Capitol Hill as a new member of Congress in January 1991, 32 years old and bristling with the impatience of a man looking to kick up a fuss. Eight months later, he got his chance when he learned of lawmaker overdrafts at the little-known House bank.

title: Richard J. Sheirer, Official in Charge of Sept. 11 Rescues, Dies at 65
description: Richard J. Sheirer, who as director of New York Citys Office of Emergency Management was thrown into the limelight on Sept. 11, 2001, after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 65.

description: 9:35 a.m. | Updated  We are no longer accepting questions.

title: When the Nursing Home Resident in the Next Room Is a Convicted Criminal
description: Before Kenneth Bryan Holcomb shot and killed a homeless man in San Mateo County in 1992, he had been in prison for burglary and drug dealing. While he was serving a 22-years-to-life sentence for the murder, he fractured his spine during a fight, which left him a quadriplegic, unable to walk, dress or bathe himself.

title: Beckham Says Family Played Key Role in Decision to Stay
description: LOS ANGELES  While the soccer world speculated where or whether David Beckham would resume his career, he quietly made his decision on New Years Eve in London, he said Thursday. As a result, Beckham will stay with the Los Angeles Galaxy after signing a two-year contract.

title: There They Go Again
description: A week ago, 150 evangelical leaders meeting at a ranch outside Houston backed Rick Santorums candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination. Presumably, they hoped that their endorsement would pull Mitt Romney back from the front of the race. Saturdays primary in South Carolina  with evangelicals expected to make up sixty percent of the electorate  provides what seems like a perfect testing ground for disrupting any claims about Romneys inevitable nomination.

title: Live From the V&A: Whats in a Pose?
description: Can a great model inhabit the style of a designer without necessarily wearing the clothes? Do her gestures and poses reveal fashions magic, as surely as a great photographer does, and can those movements be isolated and set in motion in a different venue? On Friday, the curator Olivier Saillard may answer those and other questions when he presents Models at Work, a performance at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, as part of its Fashion in Motion series. You can watch the live stream here at 12 p.m. The models will include Axelle Dou, Claudia Huidobro, Anne Rohart, Violeta Sanchez and Amalia Vairelli.

title: Afghanistans Soldiers Step Up Killings of Allied Forces
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American and other coalition forces here are being killed in increasing numbers by the very Afghan soldiers they fight alongside and train, in attacks motivated by deep-seated animosity between the supposedly allied forces, according to American and Afghan officers and a classified coalition report.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 20, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Italian Crews Struggle to Secure Cruise Ship
description: GIGLIO, Italy  Rescue crews at the Costa Concordia shipwreck deployed undersea robots on Friday to determine new ways to secure the partly submerged 950-foot hull after it shifted for the third time in a week. That movement forced another suspension in the search for bodies as relatives of the missing gathered on this picturesque Tuscan island, hoping their loved ones had miraculously survived.

title: Jan. 20, 1981 | Iran Releases American Hostages as Reagan Takes Office
description: On Jan. 20, 1981, Iran released 52 Americans who had been held hostage for 444 days, minutes after the presidency had passed from Jimmy Carter to Ronald Reagan. The hostages were placed on a plane in Tehran as Reagan delivered his inaugural address.

title: Reactions to the Supreme Court Decision on Vodafone
description: Indias Supreme Court said Friday afternoon that Vodafone Group was not liable for about $2.5 billion in back taxes (and interest and fees that would have brought the figure above $5 billion) related to its 2007 purchase of the Indian assets of Hong Kongs Hutchison Telecommunications International. The case has been closely watched by foreign investors and local businesses alike, who said before the decision that it could seriously impact investment in India in the future. For Vodafone, which has been expanding rapidly in emerging markets, with mixed results, the decision will free up cash which could be put towards further investment in India.

title: Nalbandian Is Fined Following Overrule Controversy
description: 12:50 p.m. | Updated MELBOURNE, Australia  Argentine David Nalbandian was fined $8,000 for unsportsmanlike conduct following a controversy-plagued five-set loss to John Isner in the second round earlier this week.

title: In Legal Limbo

title: Romneys Prevent Defense Yielding Big Gains to Opponents
description: Most football fans have learned to hate the prevent defense, a strategy that is employed when a team holds a lead late in the game. In theory, the strategy involves being willing to yield short completions to the offense in an effort to prevent a big gain. In reality, it seems to yield plenty of short completions  but also its share of big gains as the offense takes advantage of the soft coverage. Hence the aphorism the prevent defense only prevents you from winning.

title: Do You Think Youre Brave?
description: Scorn has been heaped on the captain of the Costa Concordia, the cruise ship that ran aground off the coast of Italy last weekend, for failing to stay on the ship, as is a captains duty. title: Its Not Quite as Lonely at the Top

description: Behavior that normally would get an audience member kicked out of a screening is welcome at movie sing-alongs. Throwing rice at The Rocky Horror Picture Show. Hand-jiving at Grease. Twirling in a dirndl at The Sound of Music.

title: Toronto Is Having a Seattle Moment
description: At the end of last year, I was looking over a list of Torontos Best Albums of 2011 in the Toronto-based publication The Grid (full disclosure: I am from Toronto) when something struck me: The list of best albums from Toronto in 2011 could have easily doubled as a list of the best albums of 2011, full-stop.

title: Floodwaters Are Gone, but Supply Chain Issues Linger
description: KHLONG LUANG, Thailand  The floodwaters receded weeks ago from this sprawling industrial zone, but the streets are littered with detritus, the phones do not work and rusted machinery has been dumped outside warehouses that once buzzed with efficiency.

title: What You (Really) Need to Know
description: A PARADOX of American higher education is this: The expectations of leading universities do much to define what secondary schools teach, and much to establish a template for what it means to be an educated man or woman. College campuses are seen as the source for the newest thinking and for the generation of new ideas, as societys cutting edge.

title: Come Hell With High Water
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Earlier this month, Bangladeshs foreign minister chided the worlds developed nations for failing to honor their pledge to help this low-lying, water-logged nation adapt to the effects of climate change. Of the $30 billion that poor countries were promised three years ago, just $2.5 billion have been disbursed. Our achievements  social, economic, environmental  of the past decades are at risk, Dipu Moni told the Guardian.

title: Deadline Approaches for European Banks Recapitalizations
description: LONDON  European banks must submit their recapitalization plans to their national authorities by Friday as the banks seek to increase their capital reserves by a combined 115 billion euros, or $147 billion.

title: Finance Business Helps Lift G.E. Profits by 6%, but Revenue Falls Short
description: General Electric, the nations largest industrial company, is steadily lifting its profits, even though its sales are lagging.

title: Pushing the Green Button for Energy Savings
description: The White House hopes that someday soon everyone will be able to monitor and control their home energy usage, and lower their monthly utility bills, with a few swipes on a smartphone app. At least thats the vision of the Green Button initiative, a recent White House effort to bring together the nations utilities, energy consumers and private industry to develop Internet and mobile phone-style technologies and business models aimed at reducing energy consumption.

title: Championship Game Matchup: Patriots vs. Ravens
description: Ravens at Patriots3 p.m., Line: Patriots by 7

title: True to His Abstraction
description: Spencertown, N.Y.

title: Fill-In | Twinkies
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this article from the Style section, Sweet, Gooey and an Icon.

title: Opinion Report: Newts Hypocrisy
description: From the editorial page

title: European Agency Orders Inspections of 20 Airbus Jets
description: PARIS  European air safety regulators on Friday ordered inspections of nearly one-third of all Airbus A380 jets after hairline cracks were found in a component of the wings on a handful of the 555-seat superjumbos in recent months.

title: Image of the Day: January 20
Morning Take-Out
description: New Normal on Wall Street: Smaller and Restrained | With firms like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley reporting weak results for last year, Wall Street is having to confront doubts about itself.

title: Teachers' Union Uninvited City From Joint Training Sessions
Documentaries and Oscar Try to Get Along
description: AROUND the parties and panels of Amsterdams international documentary festival in November there seemed to be less focus on the hundreds of films in the festival than on 15 that werent: namely those on the Oscar semifinalist shortlist, which is released each fall by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Once again it stirred up trouble.

title: Daily Report: Fallout From a File-Sharing Sites Shutdown
description: The tech world is still digesting Thursdays news that federal authorities had shut down Megaupload, a popular file-sharing site that they said was a piracy hub and accounted for 4 percent of global Internet traffic.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: At G.O.P. Debate, News Media in the Cross Hairs
description: Newt Gingrich seized Thursday nights Republican presidential debate from the start with a scathing response to a question from John King, of CNN, about the allegations from Mr. Gingrichs ex-wife that she was asked to enter into an open marriage. He met the question with cold anger, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny reported, denying the account from Marianne Gingrich, which was reported first on Thursday by ABC News, and he put the blame squarely on the news media:

title: Just Opened | The Oracle Club
description: Anyone lamenting the dearth of surrealist literary salons in New York has only to stop by The Oracle Club, a new members-only workspace for artists and writers in Long Island City. Open since early December, the club is the result of Jenna Gribbon and Julian Tepper  a couple who live above the space and a painter and novelist, respectively  having asked themselves, one morning in October, What would be the most amazing scenario we could imagine for ourselves? The three-room space includes a library, a living room and an art studio, all decorated by Gribbon and Tepper. Its Salvador Dalis house meets Whistlers Peacock Room meets Coco Chanels house meets Cocteaus Chapel, Gribbon said. For monthly fees ranging from $50 to $175, members get a key; access to the space from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., seven days a week; and a standing invitation to any readings or events held at the club. The interior is still evolving. Im looking for the perfect small kaleidoscope to put in the bathroom wall as a fake peep hole, so you think youre going to peep into the bathroom but it turns out to be a kaleidoscope, Gribbon said. Everything in time, Tepper said.

title: A Shining Moment for the Bridesmaids Director
description: Despite heavy interest, Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo are not currently working on a sequel to Bridesmaids, as Ms. Wiig has said several times (and confirmed in our recent TimesTalk). But there is a follow-up of sorts to the hit comedy: Bridesmaids, the porn version.

title: Dodd Calls for Hollywood and Silicon Valley to Meet
description: Christopher Dodd, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, suggested the White House convene a meeting to discuss antipiracy. Read more

title: In New Ads for Bing, Doing Is the Thing
description: Bing, the search engine from Microsoft, is changing advertising approaches for the first time since 2009, when it bing-ed its first bing.

title: Outcry Over Antipiracy Bills Began as Grass-Roots Grumbling
description: The protest against antipiracy legislation grew out of a grass-roots movement  a collective flexing of Internet muscle that started in some of the less mainstream parts of the Web, like the social news site Reddit and the blogging service Tumblr, and in e-mail chains and countless message boards. Read more

title: Changing Science of Movie-ology
description: IN 1958 the writer and independent filmmaker Jonas Mekas contacted Jerry Tallmer, an editor and critic at The Village Voice and asked why the paper, which had started three years earlier, didnt have a regular movie column. Mr. Tallmer invited Mr. Mekas to write one. He did. His first movie column that year inaugurated The Voices extraordinary, decades-long commitment to deeply personal, often political, always partisan, sometimes cranky and wonderfully crazed film criticism written by Andrew Sarris, Molly Haskell, Amy Taubin, Georgia Brown and David Edelstein, among many others, a tradition that effectively came to an end this month, when that papers longtime senior film critic, J. Hoberman, was laid off and told that his position was being eliminated.

title: Whoops, I Tripped Into a Lifeboat
description: Capt. Francesco Schettino would have us believe that he did not abandon his ship, the Costa Concordia, after it struck a reef. He does not deny that he was safely off board before hundreds of others, but he claims his absence was accidental. He told the Italian newspaper La Repubblica that he was dutifully escorting passengers into lifeboats in an orderly fashion when, [s]uddenly, since the ship was at a 60-to-70 degree angle, I tripped and I ended up in one of the boats. Thats how I found myself there.

title: Seven-Minute Shakespeare
description: Over on Education Life, I have a short piece about CliffsNotes Films, a new series in which classic literature becomes animated edutainment. The first offerings  six Shakepearean plays  debuted online in October.

title: Totes Shakespeare
description: IF reading Cliffs Notess Hamlet seems to be a pokey, 20th-century way to speed-comprehend Shakespeare, never fear. Now theres a seven-minute cartoon version, complete with a talking Yoricks skull. Think of it as Cliffs Notes for Cliffs Notes.

title: What Were Reading
description: Details: Which nutritional supplements should you take  and avoid?  Jeff Gordinier

title: A Whiff of Reconciliation
description: In Siem Reap, Cambodia, tourist buses filled with Korean visitors pull up to the entrance of Pyongyang Restaurant, an international chain that seems to be run by the North Korean government.

title: Fleet of Pricey Cars Seized at Megaupload Founders Mansion
description: Updated | 11:55 a.m. As our colleague Ben Sisario reports, authorities in the United States has charged the founder of Megaupload, one of the Internets most popular file-sharing sites, and six others in charge of its operation with running a criminal piracy enterprise causing $500 million in damages to copyright owners.

title: 30 Rock Seeks to Close a Controversial Chapter With Comedy
description: When real-life events pierce the fictional world of 30 Rock, the NBC series unhesitatingly turns it into fodder for comedy, whether its the death of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il or a controversy that engulfed its co-star Tracy Morgan while the show was on hiatus.

title: More About Corporate Taxes And The .01 Percent
description: A further thought about the proper calculation of tax burdens on very high income Americans: if you remember past debates, its kind of peculiar to see conservatives jumping up and down to say that Mitt Romney does too pay reasonable taxes if you include the profits taxes on the corporations in which he invests. Because if memory serves me, just a few years ago conservatives were denouncing the flypaper theory of tax incidence, arguing that much of the burden of corporate taxes really falls on labor, not on stockholders. Is it just my imagination?

title: An Architect Returns to His First Triumph
description: At 89, the architect Kevin Roche finds himself back in the spotlight with the opening this week of the renovated American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Marking an Epic Polar Journey in London
description: Few scientific explorations have captured the publics imagination like Robert Falcon Scotts expedition to Antarctica from 1910 to 1913. He and a team of scientists withstood incredible hardships and perished before reaching home, but not before they had discovered a large number of zoological and geological specimens that greatly furthered scientific knowledge of the vast region. These included 2,109 different species of animals and plants from land and water, more than 400 of them new to science.

title: After Burkes Death, a Time for Contemplationand Questions
description: This is when sports gets hard, on days when people like Sarah Burke die, when the awe over spectacular performances in increasingly dangerous sports is replaced by horror that someone could die doing them. Burkes sport, freestyle skiing, is one of a long line of sports growing more perilous as the athletes get better and the physics get riskier as speeds and heights increase. Sure, we cheer as we see skiers and snowboarders flip in the air, gasp as race cars pass inches from one another at top speeds, howl as hockey players and football players pound each other, our knowledge of the dangers safely stashed away. But when the worst happens, then what? How long can the knowledge stay stashed away?

title: Take It Slow. Look Around. Watch Out!
description: EARLY in The Innkeepers, a film about two desk clerks at a soon-to-be-shuttered hotel who engage in some amateur ghost hunting, one tells the other to watch closely a video clip that purports to contain evidence of paranormal phenomena. Theres the image of a lone, stationary rocking chair on a dark porch. Tension builds, and the score swells, but what happens next is a surprise, one that challenges audience expectations. The moment reflects the filmmaking goals of its director, Ti West, who has spent his relatively brief career subverting the assumptions of horror fans.

title: Championship Game Matchup: Giants vs. 49ers
description: Giants at 49ers 6:30 p.m. Line: 49ers by 2.5

title: Friday Reading: Why Taxes Arent as High as They Seem
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Friday Roundup: Mistrust in Afghanistan and Taliban Talks
description: Fridays New York Times takes a look at two problems that could complicate ending the war in Afghanistan: the growing mistrust between Afghan soldiers and coalition forces and concerns by Afghan officials over clarity regarding peace talks between the United States and the Taliban.

title: A Splashy Tradition, Gatorade-Style
description: For nearly three decades, the thrill of victory for football coaches everywhere has often come with the unmistakable taste of orange. Or fruit punch. Or lemon-lime.

title: First Round: Entergy 1, Vermont 0
description: As I wrote in Fridays New York Times, the first round in federal court has gone to Entergy, the electrical power production company that does not want to shut down its Vermont Yankee nuclear plant. The state of Vermont has been seeking to close the plant when its initial 40-year federal operating license expires on March 21.

title: A Macabre Start to the Sprawling Jaipur Lit Fest
description: The Jaipur Literature Festival got off to a macabre start on Friday with organizers announcing that the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie would not attend the event because of a new assassination threat against him. Instead, Mr. Rushdie said he would address the event via a video link.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Judge-Drawn Maps in Texas Redistricting Case
description: The Supreme Court on Friday instructed a lower court in Texas to take a fresh look at election maps it had drawn in place of a competing set of maps from the Texas Legislature. The justices said the lower court had not paid enough deference to the Legislatures choices and had improperly substituted its own values for those of elected officials.

title: Pilots-Eye View of the War in the Air
description: THE Academy Award nominations for 2011, which will be announced on Tuesday, will most likely include a few nods to The Artist, Michel Hazanaviciuss careful if sometimes condescending pastiche of silent-era filmmaking. Most people seeing The Artist will probably be seeing a movie without (much) spoken dialogue for the first time; the trick will be getting them to see a second example, preferably an authentic one.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rick Owens
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Debt And Transfiguration
description: Ryan Avent points out an important fact: if you look at total debt, public and private, the United States is doing better at deleveraging than countries that talk much more about the evils of debt than we do. I thought I would redo the calculation for the US so that I understood it. I focus on nonfinancial debt  thats because money that banks owe to each other is more a reflection of the structure of the financial system than of the degree of overborrowing more broadly. So heres nonfinancial debt, public plus private, as a percentage of GDP:

title: How Americans Have Reshaped Language
description: There has always been disagreement on these American shores as to just what the best English is. The status of Parisian French or Tuscan Italian has long been unassailable. Yet in the early 1940s, fusty Chicagoans were writing to The Chicago Tribune declaring Midwestern speech Americas purest, while New York radio announcers were speaking in plummy Londonesque, complete with rolled rs. Down in Charleston, S.C., the elites sense of the best English involved peculiar archaisms like cam for calm and gyardin for garden.

title: The Art of Mastering Many Tongues
description: Among the most surprising qualities of Babel No More, Michael Erards globe-trekking adventure in search of the worlds virtuosos of language learning, is that a book dealing with language acquisition and polyglot linguistics can be so gripping. But indeed it is  part travelogue, part science lesson, part intellectual investigation, it is an entertaining, informative survey of some of the most fascinating polyglots of our time.

title: Experts Consider Changing the Definition of Autism
description: Autism, as a psychiatric disorder, is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published by the American Psychiatric Association, which covers all mental health disorders for both children and adults. That definition matters  an official diagnosis of autism is what opens up access to services and treatment to many affected individuals, both children and adults.

title: Guidebooks to Babylon
description: Librarians may regard me as a highbrow pervert, frowning over their spectacles at my choice of reading matter. In certain archives, Ive even been directed to sit at a solitary table, where my movements can be carefully watched. But Ive learned to ignore the suspicious looks. The truth is, for any writer who is researching a golden age of vice  whether it be Renaissance Venice, Georgian London, belle poque Paris or fin de sicle New Orleans  there is nothing quite so satisfying as a guide to local harlots.

title: (Photographing) Murder Was His Business
description: Arthur Fellig had a knack for being in the right place at the right time. He also had an eye.

title: Author Q&A: The Insurgency in Chechnya and the North Caucasus
description: Today, for those who follow the North Caucasus or who keep up with books on conflict, we have a treat: a guest appearance on the blog from Lt. Col. Robert W. Schaefer, a Green Beret specializing in the Russian-speaking world.

title: After an Online Firestorm, Congress Shelves Antipiracy Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders on Friday indefinitely shelved two antipiracy bills that had rallied the Internet and rocked Capitol Hill, dealing a major defeat to the traditional media industry while emboldening a new breed of online political activists.

title: Pity the Billionaire
description: To the Editor:

title: Roger Williams
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BALFOUR DECLARATION: The Origins of the Arab-Israeli Conflict,  by Jonathan Schneer (Random House, $17.) Schneers richly documented study puts the famous declaration  a Nov. 2, 1917, letter by the British foreign secretary Arthur James Balfour supporting the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people  in the context of Britains promises to Arabs, Jews and its European allies in World War I.

title: Editors Choice
description: DISTRUST THAT PARTICULAR FLAVOR,  by William Gibson (Putnam, $26.95.) Instead of predicting the future, Gibson, one of our greatest science-fiction writers, finds the future all around him in this beguiling collection of essays.

title: Up Front
description: Charles Isherwood, who reviews Ian Donaldsons biography of Ben Jonson on the cover, has been a theater critic at The New York Times since 2004. When I grew up theater was what the adults did, mostly, Isherwood wrote in an e-mail. But I evinced an early sensitivity to the form. One of my first memories is of being taken to see a stage version of The Wizard of Oz. I was so traumatized by the appearance of the Wicked Witch of the West that I had to be taken home in hysterics at the intermission. Not the last time Ive gotten weepy at the theater. Isherwood went to Stanford, where he was a generic English major: My mother bemoaned this fact, and remains pleasantly surprised that I am still employed today. I took classes in Shakespeare and Restoration comedy and Japanese theater, but never formally studied theater. For me college was basically an excuse to sit around reading Henry James novels, when I wasnt racing off to San Francisco in my secondhand Chevy Vega to see bands like Siouxsie and the Banshees and the Gang of Four and dance all night at clubs. Had I known the path my career would take, I would have spent a lot more time on Molire and Stanislavsky.

title: Cheaters Never Win
description: A big city never looks the same once youve walked its streets with a hard-boiled private eye. Preferably someone as perceptive and thoughtful as Leonid McGill, the shady but honorable bruiser-for-hire in an addictive series of New York crime novels by Walter Mosley. A former mob fixer who has gone straight, McGill doesnt so much walk the city as case it for danger. Keeping pace with him is as much an education as an adventure.

title: Paris Mens: Lean and  Still Hungry
description: The plaids and patchwork in Junya Watanabes show Friday looked culled from a farm supply store or a college town like Portland, Ore., and so felt a bit in a worn groove. At Yves Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati stuck to slim dark tailoring with leather insets and flashes of silver on shoes. There was much black leather, which was based on motorcycle gear but given more polish and presented in ensemble. You can imagine people coveting pieces, especially some of the nicely shaped jackets, but the show didnt offer much direction.

title: Day Planner (Turn Off the Alarm)
description: So youve skied the chutes of Jackson Hole and youve risen at dawn to porpoise through the powder from a helicopter. But are you ready for your greatest challenge  learning to throttle back and enjoy skiing the Spanish way? Then stop counting the days vertical feet and follow this itinerary.

title: Taking Your Ease in the Pyrenees
description: The ski area is enjoyed as much for its slopes as for its embrace of the good life.

title: Skiing the Spanish Pyrenees
description: NOTHING made sense.

title: Enough Snow?
description: To the Editor: Re Oh, for Just a Little Snow (Practical Traveler, Jan. 15), I teach skiing at Park City Mountain Resort. Maybe the snow totals look weak, but with top-gun snowmaking and state-of the-art grooming, the main runs are as good as it gets. The days are sunny and warm. No one is unhappy. Ive been up there since opening day in mid-November and have not hit a rock yet.

title: Kia Recalls 146,000 Optimas and Rondos for Drivers Air Bag Flaw
description: Kia is recalling about 146,000 vehicles because the drivers air bag may not deploy in a crash, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Q&A With Yolanda Edwards, Editor and Blogger
description: WHEN Yolanda Edwards gave birth to her daughter, Clara, friends said her traveling days were done. Refusing to accept this, she booked a trip to England from New York when Clara was five weeks old, and from then on, they often joined her husband, a photographer, on assignments. There I was on maternity leave, she said. So I thought, why shouldnt we all be together as much as possible?

title: The Momentum of Ideas
description: During last nights Republican debate, the candidates were asked to name something from the campaign that they would have done differently. Here was Newt Gingrichs answer:

title: A Widower Hits the Dating Scene
description: In the opening lines of Hilma Wolitzers wonderful new novel, the recently widowed Edward Schuyler stands in his living room, ironing, when the telephone rings. He picks it up to hear the clamorous, intrusive voice of a female suitor, attempting to break in on his grief. But hed rather iron the blouses of his deceased wife, Bee, as a way of reconnecting with her when she was so irrevocably gone than date any of the women now scurrying in his direction. Bee, on her deathbed, had predicted this fate: Look at you. Theyll be crawling out of the woodwork.

title: Saxapahaw, N.C., Middle of Somewhere, Becomes a Draw
description: I WAS polishing off a steaming bowl of coconut curry soup when a server appeared bearing a plate of plump pan-seared diver scallops atop creamy applewood-bacon succotash and braised asparagus. The food was befitting a candlelit restaurant, but I had a view of gas pumps outside and, a few steps from my table, fluorescent-lighted aisles packed with workaday necessities  toilet paper, motor oil, sauerkraut juice (aids digestion, according to the label).

title: BuzzFeed Makes Another Splashy Hire, This One From Rolling Stone
description: BuzzFeed, the social Web site that made a splash last month by hiring the blogger Ben Smith away from Politico, will signal its expansion plans on Friday by announcing that it has hired Doree Shafrir of Rolling Stone to oversee culture coverage.

title: In Jane Eyres Footsteps
description: When Margot Livesey was 9 years old, growing up motherless and lonely in Scotland, a book on her fathers shelf caught her eye: Jane Eyre. Liveseys discovery of Charlotte Bronts masterpiece was transformative. The promised friend between the covers, a character whose indomitable spirit has consoled and inspired readers for over a century and a half, allowed Livesey to understand that life is change. Like Janes, my life had changed for the worse, Livesey wrote in an essay a few years ago, and like hers, it could also change for the better. Time would, irrevocably, carry me to a new place.

title: Hotel Review: Element Times Square West, N.Y.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Hollywood Needs Unified Effort, Dodd Asserts
description: WASHINGTON  As Hollywood and its indie film counterparts head to Park City, Utah, for the Sundance festival, theres a question they might kick around in the aprs ski lounges: Should everyone in a movie business that is clearly grappling with serious issues be doing more to advance their interests in Washington?

title: Singapore Hawker Stalls Move Indoors
description: JUST look around, said Malcolm Lee, a 27-year-old Singaporean chef, as he gestured toward the dozen or so street food stands surrounding our table. I doubt that one of these hawkers is under the age of 40. When this generation is gone, their recipes will probably go with them. Their children want to be bankers or lawyers. Who wants to slog it out six days a week, morning through night, in a hot, dirty environment?

title: U.S. General Urges Closer Ties With Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called Friday for closer engagement between the United States and Israel during a short visit here at a time of tension over Irans nuclear program.

title: Documentary Footage Raises Questions About Lawsuit
description: PARK CITY, Utah  David Siegel, a Florida time-share mogul, is suing the Sundance Institute and Lauren Greenfield, the director of a documentary about his family, The Queen of Versailles, for defamation. The plot twist: Mr. Siegels lawsuit may turn out to be more embarrassing for him than Ms. Greenfields film.

title: Dave Grohl: From Antsy Student to Nirvana to Foo Fighters
description: Among musicians, drummers are a breed apart. On the one hand, the drummer is the timekeeper, the one who counts off the song and keeps the other band members on the beat. On the other, the drummer sits behind everyone else and usually doesnt write songs or sing them, so often hes only the drummer.

title: Restaurant Review: Blu Ice Bar and Splashing Rock Restaurant, Two Harbors, Minn.
description: At restaurants on Lake Superiors North Shore in Minnesota, the fish tends to be fresh and local. At the Blu Ice Bar, in Two Harbors, much of the restaurant is as perishable as the catch of the day.

title: The Political Price of Austerity
description: Most books about contemporary politics are designed for quick obsolescence. A notable exception to the rule is the work of Thomas Byrne Edsall, whose five careful books, starting with The New Politics of Inequality in 1984, are still found on the shelves and in the footnotes of everyone who writes about politics  left and right, academics and journalists alike. Edsalls distinctive method combines his own reporting with rigorous use of data from across the social sciences, including psychology and anthropology. Though his previous book, Building Red America, seemed poorly timed when it appeared in 2006 just as Karl Roves quest for permanent Republican dominance collapsed, its insights into conservative attitudes about authority and autonomy remain as useful as anything written more recently about the Tea Party and the right-wing resurgence.

title: Temple Oranges, Here Today
description: Im no great fan of snow or the groundhog, but one arrival I look forward to each winter is temple oranges  shiny, spongy to the touch and deeply rutted with pores, like a cartoonists idea of an orange. I spotted a temple-like pyramid (a ziggurat?) of them the other day in front of Fairway on the Upper West Side.

title: Revisiting Shakespeares Coriolanus
description: Some women swoon for swashbuckling Antony or bodice-ripping Othello, but Ive always had a soft spot for prideful, imperious Coriolanus. Next to Shakespeares other tragic figures, who sometimes sound like Freudian case studies  Hamlet, that whiny, dithering ball of nerves who accidentally murders his girlfriends father; Lear, who judges his daughters so egregiously in a vicious game of favorites that he deserves to be left out on the moors  Coriolanus comes across as downright noble. Uniquely among these figures, this war hero turned disgraced politician does nothing truly wrong: he is punished without having committed a crime. In fact, his worst fault might be his refusal to speak anything less than exactly what he believes.

title: The Choice on Today': Tips on Fafsa, and Net-Price Calculators
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: A Brazilian Beach Beauty, Refined and Untouched
description: FROM the balcony of Quinta do Bucanero, a pousada in the center of Praia do Rosa, the appeal of the Brazilian seaside town is obvious. Perched on top of a cliff, the 10-room hotel is surrounded by a tropical jungle and forested mountains, with views of a long, sweeping stretch of golden sand and two lagoons. Surfers dot the waves, and orchids scent the air.

title: On a Brazilian Island, Sophistication With a Barefoot Atmosphere
description: Praia do Rosa has only two paved roads, but in recent years the town has seen the opening of new hotels and night spots.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: A co-worker of mine saw a van plow into two parked cars. She wrote down the license plate number as the van drove away, but when she pulled up alongside it, she recognized the driver  a known criminal in her neighborhood who is always armed and has a very bad reputation. They made eye contact, and he knows that she saw the accident. Is it her responsibility to get involved with this dangerous man? YAMIT REMZ, NEW YORK CITY

title: The Hand-Held Highlighter
description: Once, when readers wanted to remember something, they had to mark important passages with thin, wobbly lines in drab, hard-to-relocate colors. Before the rise of the highlighter, says Dennis Baron, a University of Illinois professor and the author of A Better Pencil, attentive readers relied on a combination of underlining and marginal notes.

title: How Many Stephen Colberts Are There?
description: We all knew that there was Stephen Colbert, the man, and Stephen Colbert, the character on television. Well, Charles McGrath tells us theres a third Colbert: his televised persona interacting with our reality. For those of us waiting for the G.O.P. primaries to be over so we can just get to November and cast our pre-determined vote, we may actually have to pay attention, because Stephen Colbert (and his multiple personalities) will be providing some quality entertainment. And who knows? Maybe he will accidentally (or purposely?) change the entire process.

title: The Not-So-Retiring Barney Frank
description: You recently said about Newt Gingrich: Hes just one of the worst people I know of who didnt commit violence on somebody. Did he kill your dog?He transformed American politics from one in which people presume the good will of their opponents, even as they disagreed, into one in which people treated the people with whom they disagreed as bad and immoral. He was a kind of McCarthy-ite who succeeded.

title: All Bent Out of Shape
description: I first heard about William Broads debate-sparking article, How Yoga Can Wreck Your Body, in yoga class on Saturday afternoon. As the class inhaled in an extended downward dog, the teacher asked if anyone had read the article. As we were guided into pigeon pose, the teacher offered this: The thing is, she told us, if youre mindful, you wont get hurt. I went home and read the article. I had not so much a crisis of confidence, but a feeling that if youre mindful, you wont get hurt was very possibly an inadequate answer.

title: The Fat Trap
description: In The Fat Trap (Jan. 1), Tara Parker-Pope implied that obesity is virtually incurable based on the observation that eating calorie-restricted diets (less than 1,200 or 1,500 calories a day) doesnt cure it.

title: Inside the List
description: FEMALE POWER: Jayne Ann Krentzs latest paranormal romance, Copper Beach, is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Krentz is no stranger to this page  shes had more than 30 New York Times best sellers  and with her success she has become a vocal defender of the romance category as a whole. In interviews, she talks about the genres link to the heroic tradition, and as far back as 1992 she edited a cultural studies anthology, Dangerous Men and Adventurous Women, in which she argued that romances were by nature both feminist and subversive: Readers understand that the books celebrate female power. In the romance novel . . . the woman always wins. With courage, intelligence and gentleness she brings the most dangerous creature on earth, the human male, to his knees.

title: Georges Remi: Learning His Lines
description: Cartoonists are a peculiar breed of artist. For one thing, theyre hesitant about the use of the A-word. Their craft  now thats better  also comes with great constraints. Because the work appears in newspapers and comic books, it must strike a commercial chord quickly: there isnt much time for it to find an audience. The field doesnt boast many lonely geniuses whose work is discovered posthumously. The demands of reproduction put limits on complexity, and the panel format  those squares and rectangles  erects graphic walls. For successful cartoonists, producing every day on someone elses schedule, the grind is relentless. Cartoonists tend not to be boulevardiers; their way of life is sedentary and often solitary, and their days are spent in the company of invented characters in an invented world. Life and work can merge in curious ways. I happen to be the son of a cartoonist  a happy and well-adjusted cartoonist  and collaborated with him on Prince Valiant, but it was clear to all of us in the family that our situation was not quite normal. Or, thinking back to the moment when an electrician came into my fathers studio and found him posing  on his back, wearing a wig and a skirt, holding a garbage can lid as a shield and using a plunger on a rubber tube to snap a Polaroid  it may just have been that we had a different sense of what normal was.

title: Margaret Fuller: Woman of the World
description: Margaret Fuller, a woman of great talent and promise, had the misfortune to be born in Massachusetts in 1810, at a time and place in which the characteristics of what historians have termed true womanhood were becoming ever more rigidly defined. Well brought-up women like herself were to be cultured, pious, submissive and genteel. Fuller, by contrast, was assertive and freethinking. She was also  and to some extent, still is  a difficult person to like.

title: William Gasss Lifelong Attachment to Literature
description: When reviewers take the trouble to compliment a writer on her style, William H. Gass writes in Life Sentences, his new collection of essays, it is usually because she has made it easy for them to slide from one sentence to another like an otter down a slope. Gasss sentence enacts its own dissent from this critical preference for clear and simple prose: as soon as the otter barges in, the readers attention is forcibly drawn away from Gasss meaning and toward his style.

title: The Shadow of Nuremberg
description: On the campaign trail in June 2008, Barack Obama commented on the Supreme Courts extension of the constitutional right of habeas corpus to detainees held at the naval facility at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. During the Nuremberg trials, part of what made us different was even after these Nazis had performed atrocities that no one had ever seen before, we still gave them a day in court, and that taught the entire world about who we are but also the basic principles of rule of law, Obama said. Now the Supreme Court upheld that principle yesterday, he added. Obamas statement linked Nuremberg to an idea central to his presidential campaign: The Bush administration in the fight against Islamist terrorists had compromised American values and undermined Americas wartime rule-of-law legacy. The Supreme Court had begun the task of restoring those values, Obama suggested, and he promised to finish the job as president.

title: What We Find Gross, and Why
description: Did you hear the one about the Texan at his first Passover Seder? He was mightily impressed with the soup. These matzo balls sure are delicious, maam, he told his hostess. What other parts of the matzo do yall cook with?

title: Collect Call | Tracy Zabars Charm Bracelets, Snowglobes, Santa Mugs, etc., etc.

title: Tightening Race Comes as Abrupt Blow to Romney Team
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  With Mitt Romney facing the biggest challenge to his presidential aspirations since he announced his candidacy, his aides acknowledged Friday what seemed unthinkable just seven days ago: He could lose the South Carolina primary.

title: On Hold
Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Charles Isherwood discusses a new book about playwright Ben Jonson; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Yves Saint Laurent
description: Paris

title: Yves Saint Laurent: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: On Our Radar: Compensation for Yellowstone Spill
description: Exxon Mobil agrees to pay $1.6 million in penalties to the state of Montana for pollution caused by a pipeline break last summer that fouled dozens of miles of shoreline along the Yellowstone River. Of that amount, $300,000 is a cash fine and the rest is to go toward future environmental projects. Exxon says that more than 63,000 gallons of crude swept into the river. [The Associated Press]

title: A Monster in the Age of Abolition
description: Few of its readers are likely to forget Barry Unsworths Sacred Hunger, a co-winner of the Booker Prize in 1992. The novel contains a vision of hell on earth unlike any in contemporary fiction, largely because its account of the unimaginable cruelties of the slave trade is told in the well-wrought prose of an old-fashioned 19th-century novel with an omniscient narrator. The effect is uncanny: its intelligent, controlled and immensely readable sentences glow with a deathly pallor.

title: When Childrens Speech Turns Lethal
description: In a career spanning nearly 20 years, Ben Marcus has written just four spare volumes: a story collection, two novels and a chapbook. Formally inventive, dark and dryly comic, this work has earned him critical praise and a small army of devoted fans. His prose is heavily metaphorical yet coolly ironic; it traffics in the language of scholarship, myth and history, and until now has forsaken the conventional trappings of narrative. Indeed, the pieces in The Age of Wire and String (1995) function more like prose poems than stories; their emotional impact is derived from their distinctive diction and syntax. The opener, Argument, might serve as a map of Marcuss early career, with its stated goal of cataloging a culture through an array of documents settling within the chief concerns of the society, of any society, of the world and its internal areas. The books archness is both bracing and absurd; it attempts to reinvent story by repurposing, gleefully, the jargon ordinarily used to analyze it.

title: Ecological Connectivity as Climate Warms
description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

title: Etta James Dies at 73; Voice Behind At Last
description: Etta James, whose powerful, versatile and emotionally direct voice could enliven the raunchiest blues as well as the subtlest love songs, most indelibly in her signature hit, At Last, died on Friday morning in Riverside, Calif. She was 73.

title: Hes So Vain, Hed Be Right in Thinking This Post Is About Him
description: I am not one of those people who think the president should be just like me. He should be in touch with the needs and aspirations and fears of ordinary Americans, sure. But how many of your neighbors would you like to see with the nuclear trigger in their hands?

title: For Fans, a New Focus on the Best Soccer in the World
description: There is a new breed of sports fan in the United States.

title: Blanchett and Husband Leaving as Artistic Directors of Sydney Theater Company
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Country and Tropiclia in a Punk-Folk Diet
description: FOR two decades Ani DiFranco has been a fiercely independent folk singer in punk clothing, a writer of feminist anthems, protest songs and clear-eyed explorations of the messy side of love. But when shes listening for pleasure and inspiration, Ms. DiFranco ranges farther afield, she said, adding, Im not even someone who listens to a lot of music you would consider similar to mine.

title: A Valkyries Voice Flashing More Than Steel
description: Vienna

title: Once a Millstone, GE Capital Is Now a Profit Center
description: GE Capital weighed heavy on General Electric during the financial crisis.

title: The Big Profile: John Mulaney
description: In the post-Al Franken, post-Robert Smigel, post-Tina Fey era of Saturday Night Live, it is perhaps only its nerdiest and most obsessive viewers who have a favorite writer on that NBC late-night sketch show. But since joining the S.N.L. writing staff for its 2008-09 season, John Mulaney has found himself a place in the hearts of completists and casual fans alike: a Chicago-born standup comic, Mulaney has gained recognition as a creator and writer of Stefon, the ultra-hip nightlife correspondent played in frequent Weekend Update appearances by Bill Hader; and for his own occasional riffs, delivered as himself from the Update desk. (Also joining him in this modern-day pantheon is his fellow S.N.L. writer and Internet microcelebrity Mike OBrien.)

title: In England, Bond Cars of the Villains, Vixens and Dapper Hero
description: With a new James Bond film, Skyfall, being released this fall, and Her Majestys favorite cinematic spy franchise celebrating its 50th anniversary, an exhibition of Bond cars has opened at the National Motor Museum in Beaulieu in the south of England.

title: Agile Patriot Thrives in a Teammates Hulking Shadow
description: FOXBORO, Mass.  On the fourth play of the Patriots divisional playoff game against Denver, Aaron Hernandez broke a 43-yard run to the Broncos 7-yard line.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Chinese New Year commences Monday, but some restaurants will jump-start their celebrations and offer special menus this weekend. At Masak, 432 East 13th Street (between First Avenue and Avenue A), in the East Village, a preview menu is offered today through Sunday, with items like arrowroot chips and roasted quail stuffed with rice, chestnuts, lotus seeds, kale and a salted duck yolk. A more extensive New Year menu is offered starting Tuesday. To celebrate the Year of the Dragon, Chinatown Brasserie, 380 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street), in NoHo, will cook up dim sum specials, traditional Chinese fare and an assortment of desserts starting on Sunday. Culinary tours led by Adventure on a Shoestring this weekend include a walking tour of Manhattans Chinatown at 1 and 3 p.m. with samplings of dumplings, pastries and ice cream. The tours will meet at the southeast corner of Canal and Mott Streets. The fee is $10 and does not include food. Call (212) 265-2663 for more information.

title: Off the Charts: New-Car Registrations Decline in Europe
description: The number of new passenger cars registered in the European Union declined 15.8 percent from 2007 to 2011. Registrations fell in 17 of the 24 European countries with populations over 1 million.

title: My Wines Long Way Home
description: PARIS  In my latest column, I look at the wines of Galicia, in the far northwestern corner of Spain, where the cool influence of the Atlantic is strong. For anyone expecting big, Mediterranean style reds, youll have to look elsewhere.

title: Defrosting the Hamptons
description: FRIGID winter temperatures have just arrived in the Northeast, and beach-ready bodies are thousands of sit-ups away. But for some buyers and summer renters  especially year-end bonus recipients  now is when thoughts turn toward house-hunting in the Hamptons.

title: Justices Texas Redistricting Ruling Likely to Help G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday rejected elections maps drawn by a federal court in Texas that had favored Democratic candidates there.

title: Paris Top 5 | Louis Vuitton
description: The giant silver globe that was suspended over the runway at Louis Vuitton made it clear from the moment we took our seats that we were in for quite a trip. Kim Jones, an Englishman in Paris, presented his stunning second collection for the luxury house. Exploring influences from both Tokyo and the City of Light, the clothes paid homage to the legendary fashion illustrator Antonio Lopez, an artist with links to both fashion capitals. Lopezs drawings were brought vividly to life in a group of graphic, patterned (and LV-monogrammed) blanket coats with coordinating scarves pinned at the neck. A vicuna double-breasted, belted coat (see Coming Soon: Belted Coats) worn with a mink scarf, kimono-style shirt and gray double-faced pajama trousers made references to both East and West in the most luxurious way possible.

title: In Europe, Cars Stay in Showroom
description: THE new passenger car is becoming an increasingly rare item in some European countries.

title: Video Feed of Wisconsin Recall Count Draws Thousands
description: The daily work of government bureaucracy may not be as captivating to watch as Shiba Inu puppies or giant pandas sleeping. But the risk of boredom has not deterred tens of thousands from visiting a site broadcasting video from a Web camera trained on a cinderblock office in Madison, Wis., where state workers are processing signatures calling for the recall of the governor.

title: Pipeline Project Emerges as Marker in Tax Fight
description: 1:55 p.m. | Updated BALTIMORE  House Republicans, undaunted by the payroll tax holiday debacle that dinged their conference last month, said Friday that they were considering using the Keystone XL Pipeline as a chip in the next round of negotiations over the tax break, as part of their overall efforts to push back against White House policies this year.

title: In Ankara, Turkey, New Restaurants Enliven the Diplomatic Area
description: The neighborhood has gone from a staid diplomatic hub to Ankaras choicest destination for an evening out.

title: Religious Groups Get Delay in Birth Control Insurance Requirement
description: The Obama administration said it would give religious organizations one additional year to comply with a new policy requiring employers to provide free contraception services in insurance plans.

title: A Dyslexia Film and a Directors Family
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Its an emotional strain for a filmmaker to bring a project to Sundance. The thrill of getting in is quickly followed by fear: What happens if nobody likes it? Now imagine what added emotions might be surging through a director whose film showcases his sons disability.

title: The Ivies Squash Back
description: The streak is over. After 13-plus years, after 13 consecutive national championships, after 252 straight victories  the longest such run in college sports  the Trinity mens squash team has lost a match, to Yale.

title: Wedding Q&A
description: The Significant Other Is Not Insignificant

title: TimesCast | January 20, 2012
description: The Citadel remains an important stop for Republican candidates | Nate Silver on South Carolina primary projections.

title: At Mens Fashion Shows, A Mix of Aspiration and Powerful Intrigue
description: The movies often keep fashion designers in duds, as we saw at Miuccia Pradas fall mens show in Milan and a few days later at Rick Owens in Paris. But these designers approach the imagery very differently.

title: Time for a Fresh Approach to Bankruptcy Fees
description: The executive office of the United States Trustee plans to revise professional fee guidelines, especially as they apply to lawyers retained in big Chapter 11 cases.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $9.5 Million
description: The director M. Night Shyamalan  whose breakthrough film, The Sixth Sense, told the story of a boy empowered to see and talk to the dead  was finally able to commune with a living buyer for his TriBeCa penthouse after more than a year, selling it for $9.5 million, the biggest sale of the past week, according to city records.

title: How Did the Eurostar Lose Its Luster?
description: BETWEEN PARIS AND LONDON  What has happened to the Eurostar, this train I so envied as an American university student studying in Paris?
