title: Eating Out in Amsterdam: Way Beyond Herring
description: NEARLY 10 years ago I went to Amsterdam in search of Dutch food; for the most part what I found was Mediterranean. This past fall I tried again. To put it nicely, I failed less miserably. Because although it is safe to say that the Dutch have yet to rediscover their culinary heritage in the fashion of some of their nearby neighbors, there has been much progress.

title: Dear Governor: Lobby to Save a Love of Reading
The Teacher 'Brand' Gets a Makeover
Car Batteries Are Not Just For the Car
description: Coda Automotive is supposed to start selling its electric sedan next month. On Friday, its parent company announced that it was also moving into a related line: stationary batteries for electricity storage.

title: Business Social Media: Rise of the Machines
description: Maybe the old guard in enterprise software is firing back at the social media upstarts. At least one, Tibco, is using the best ammo it has, boring old business data.

title: The South Carolina Primary
description: Two candidates dropped out in South Carolina as the campaigns have gotten more aggressive in the Palmetto state.

title: Parental Quandary: The Sex Offender Next Door
description: C. has a problem perhaps too serious to be called a quandary. A few months ago, she says, her family received a flier from the local sheriff. A registered sex offender was moving to her street of small, single-family homes. Hers is a long street, though, and she expected the offender to be some distance away and easily avoidable.

title: First Ratings for CBS This Morning Highlight Steep Challenges Ahead
description: 1:39 p.m. | Updated The ratings for the first week of CBS This Morning, which were released on Friday, gave CBS reasons for optimism  but they also reiterated the cliff-like, uphill climb that the network is facing.

description: Packed with writers, publishers, school kids and chief executives, the Jaipur Literature Festival can and has been described in many ways, from circus to the front lines of the fight against extremism.

title: Pie Face Offers Australia to Go
description: Do you celebrate Australia Day, that countrys national holiday, coming up on Thursday? If not, this would be a good year to start. With a mess of Australian meat pies to go and some shiraz or Fosters, youre all set. And for those pies, there is a new source in New York: Pie Face, the first American outpost of a down-under takeout chain.

title: Leslie Hawke and David Weiss
description: IN the 12 years since she left online publishing to do humanitarian work with disadvantaged children in Romania, Leslie Hawke has advised many younger women on matters of the heart.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: X-Men Take Over Top Spot
description: X-Men: Schism lands at No. 1 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. When an international incident sends hatred of mutants into a new frenzy, Cyclops and Wolverine are divided in their response and cause a rift in the team. This collected edition contains the five issues of Schism, written by Jason Aaron with each issue illustrated by a different powerhouse artist (Carlos Pacheco, Frank Cho, Daniel Acuna, Alan Davis and Adam Kubert). It also includes the standalone special X-Men: Regenesis, written by Kieron Gillen and illustrated by Billy Tan, in which the other X-Men choose whether they will stand with Cyclops or Wolverine. The X-Men are synonymous with change, with the characters getting reshuffled into new teams every few years, so the fracture among the heroes may be temporary. (Particularly with a huge conflict with the Avengers coming right around the corner.)

title: Overmisunderestimating Rick Perry
description: On Thursday night I happened to call a friend just before 10 p.m. and caught her a little tipsy  she had been out celebrating Rick Perrys ignominious withdrawal from the presidential race.

title: Runway in Review

title: Coping With High-Priced Insurance That Lenders Make You Buy
description: FORCE-PLACED insurance. Most homeowners never hear about it until their mortgage lender sends them a letter saying that they must have flood or some other kind of insurance and that if they dont act quickly, the lender will buy it for them  at a price, it turns out, that is almost always much higher than the market rate.

title: Death Penalty Death Watch: The Mailroom Mix-Up
description: Todays installment in my continuing series on the folly of Americas refusal to abandon the death penalty comes courtesy of an article by Adam Liptak in The Times. As Mr. Liptak reported, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that just because someone messed up in the mailroom, you dont necessarily deserve capital punishment.

description: THERE are lots of crab-meat salads out there. Some are fine, but many tend to be rather indifferent mixtures of crabmeat and bottled mayonnaise.

title: Scientists to Pause Research on Deadly Strain of Bird Flu
description: The scientists who altered a deadly flu virus to make it more contagious have agreed to suspend their research for 60 days to give other international experts time to discuss the work and determine how it can proceed withoutputting the world at risk of a potentially catastrophic pandemic.

title: 538 | S.C. Primary Projections
description: January 20, 2012 - Just a day before the South Carolina primary, Nate Silver's latest projections show a shift in the lead.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: An Alzheimers Classic
description: More than 30 years ago, when the psychiatrist Dr. Peter Rabins and the psychologist Nancy Mace began working with dementia patients and their families at Johns Hopkins Hospital, they had to write and mimeograph (younger readers: look it up) small pamphlets to explain to them what was going on and what was to come.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Reading the Fine Print on Apples Book-Making Software
description: Apples free book-creation tool, iBooks Author, seemed too good to be true: it gives anyone the ability to easily lay out an interactive book with no programming required, slap it up for sale in Apples iBooks Store and ideally make a quick buck. But hours after Apple released the software on Thursday, people noticed that they were not allowed to sell these books outside Apples store.

title: Fast and Easy Omelet Meals
description: If youre looking for a simple meal, the egg is a good place to start, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: A Versatile and Direct Voice: Etta James
description: Etta James has died at age 73.

title: Many Evangelicals See Something to Admire in Candidates Broods
description: The Republican presidential field has produced a lot of babies. There is Mitt Romney, father of five sons. Ron Paul, an obstetrician by training, is also a father of five, and his campaign Web site credits him with bringing 4,000 babies into the world. Newt Gingrich and the recent dropout Rick Perry have only two children each, but Rick Santorum, who has said contraception is not O.K., has seven children, and so does another former candidate, Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

title: Just One Look | Valentino
description: There was a lot to get excited about at Valentino this morning. The accessories, for one, are stellar and studded: the seasons new loafer, pictured here, is stamped on top with a large gold pyramid stud; the combat boot, another favorite, is ruffled in the front; the brogues come in patent leather with spiky metal toe caps (similar to the ones we just saw at the mens shows in Europe). Romantic, rose-embellished and decorated with bows and lace, the dresses and skirt looks are lovely and expertly tailored. Just what you expect from the Italian house  though its the suit story made of nipped silk satin tuxedos and soft, tie-neck blouses that caught this editors attention. Here, the rippling asymmetrical lapel on a blush-pink jacket flirts with Le Smoking without going all the way.

title: For Gallinari, a Long-Awaited Return to New York
description: Danilo Gallinari is ready to come back to New York. It was Feb. 22 of last year when il Gallo, one of most popular players during Coach Mike DAntonis tenure with the Knicks, was involved in the trade that brought Carmelo Anthony to New York.

title: Landmarks on the Fringe
description: Wallabout is a two-block-wide semi-industrial neighborhood inland from the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Where History Meets Industry
description: SLOPING down from Myrtle Avenue to the walled fortress of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Industrial Park, and bisected by the rumbling equator of the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the two-block-wide semi-industrial neighborhood of Wallabout would seem to have some unenviable physical challenges. It lacks subways, and although it shares a name with nearby Wallabout Bay, its residents are cut off by the Navy Yard from the tantalizingly close waterfront.

title: Obama Reaffirms Insurers Must Cover Contraception
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that most health insurance plans must cover contraceptives for women free of charge, and it rejected a broad exemption sought by the Roman Catholic Church for insurance provided to employees of Catholic hospitals, colleges and charities.

title: Giants, Ravens, Patriots, 49ers (and the Jets): Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Vending Machines May Not Cause Student Weight Gain, Study Says
description: Pulling the vending machines out of schools has long been something of a battle cry for parents concerned with childhood obesity. Many schools and districts rely on vendor contracts to finance extracurricular activities (in New York City, snacks sold in vending machines are limited in calories, fat and sugar content), while advocates worry that the omnipresent snacks will mean weight gain in students.

title: Washington Post Managing Editor Leaves for The Journal
description: The Wall Street Journal has hired Raju Narisetti, a managing editor of The Washington Post, to become managing editor of its online news properties, Dow Jones, the parent company of the Journal, announced on Friday.

title: Hungarian Leader Softens on Central Bank Merger
description: BRUSSELS  Hungarys prime minister promised Friday to abandon plans to merge the nations central bank and its financial markets regulator, seeking to defuse criticism from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund over the countrys increasing centralization of power.

title: A Marriage of Influences
description: Hisham Modine and Nadia Bishai live in a brownstone in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: His Style, Her Style, Their Style
description: THE brownstone at 127 St. James Place in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, boasted a lustrous pedigree. Its elderly owner, Adele Premice, was the daughter of Lucas Premice, a Haitian aristocrat who fled to the United States in the early 20th century. Her younger sister, the glamorous actress Josephine Premice, reigned for decades as the toast of Broadway.

title: Russian Envoys Leave Canada After Officer Is Accused of Spying
description: OTTAWA  Four Russian diplomats have left Canada just days after a naval intelligence officer was charged with passing government secrets to a foreign entity.

title: The Whole Fish, and Little but the Fish
description: A WHOLE roasted fish is the aquatic analogue to roast chicken.

title: A Word From the J. Edgar Contingent
description: In the undulating curve of expectations, hype and maneuvering that is Oscar season, J. Edgar has had a hard time catching on. Clint Eastwoods biopic, starring Leonard DiCaprio as Hoover and Armie Hammer as his associate and paramour, Clyde Tolson, might wind up being the Jon Huntsman of the awards race: it had high expectations  the Bagger started hearing about it last Oscar season, when Mr. Hammer, then making the rounds for The Social Network, was cast  some glowing reviews and many of the right elements for prize glory, including a good back story.

title: Will Standardized Tests Kill Reading?
description: Please click over to the SchoolBook blog to read a fantastic post from Anne Stone and Jeff Nichols about their unusual choice for a New Years Eve activity with friends: they took the third-grade English language arts practice test one of their children took home over vacation.

title: Citadel Clears Its High Water Mark
description: Citadel, the hedge fund behemoth that experienced losses of more than 50 percent during the financial crisis, has finally recovered.

title: A Steep Drop in Ratings for American Idol
description: 5:11 p.m. | Updated American Idol may have officially crossed over from phenomenon to mere hit television show on Thursday, as the second outing of this years edition fell a steep 27 percent in the ratings from its performance on the same night last year  and 44 percent from its number two years ago.

title: Brent Bozell and Ghetto Crackheads
description: Whenever I write about the undertones (and sometimes overtones) of race in American politics, I get a lot of critical emails and Tweets, some reasonable, some pretty nasty.

title: European Union Moves Closer to Imposing Tough Sanctions on Iran
description: PARIS  The European Union moved closer to imposing a phased oil embargo on Iran and some form of narrow sanctions against transactions with Irans central bank, European and French diplomats said on Friday.

title: From Icy Waters, a Cold-Weather Pleasure
description: This time of year, after a few weeks of post-holiday deprivation and perhaps a little too much foul weather, a bit of decadence may seem in order, at least for one meal. Why not treat yourself and your table mates to the one of the cold seasons treats, and indulge in a fresh crabmeat salad? In this weeks City Kitchen, were making a deviled crab salad with slightly bitter chicory greens and a lemony, mustardy dressing, suitable for a fine first course or weekend lunch.

title: The Dangerous Notion That Debt Doesnt Matter
description: WITH little fanfare, a dangerous notion has taken hold in progressive policy circles: that the amount of money borrowed by the federal government from Americans to finance its mammoth deficits doesnt matter.

title: Christophe Bellanca Is Chef at LAtelier de Jol Robuchon
description: Joel Robuchon has anounced the appointment of Christophe Bellanca as the new executive chef for LAtelier de Jol Robuchon in the Four Seasons Hotel in New York.

title: Laying the Beetles Foundation
description: Josef Ganz, a Jewish engineer, laid out the basics for the original VW Beetle before being forced from Germany.

title: 2012 Volkswagen Beetle
description: Volkswagen has redesigned the Beetle, making is more masculine and even getting rid of the interior flower vase.

title: The Caucus | A Political Army
description: The Citadel Military College is an imposing political symbol on its own, but it also has engaged students who are deciding among the candidates.

title: Founder of Shuttered Web Site Sought Limelight
description: BERLIN  Some uninvited guests showed up at Kim Dotcoms mansion outside Auckland, New Zealand, on Friday: the police, in two helicopters.

title: Normally United, Citadel Cadets Differ on Republican Favorite
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  At the Citadel, cadets wear matching uniforms, march in lockstep and endure rigorous physical training together. But these days, the Republicans among them  and they are overwhelmingly Republican  are divided on a crucial issue: whom to support as the next commander in chief.

title: Obama Says 2012 Choice Is Stark
description: It is a political truism: fear is a major motivator for voters. And President Obama wants supporters to know that whoever emerges from the blood bath of the Republican primaries, that presidential nominee will be much farther to the right than Mr. Obamas 2008 opponent, Senator John McCain.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom 1948 colonial in Little Falls, N.J., and a six-bedroom fieldstone and wood home in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side one-bedroom, a Fashion District loft and a Park Slope condo.

title: Photo Replay: January 20
description: A look at the day in sports, from the tennis courts in Australia to a World Cup skeleton race in Switzerland.

title: Fashion Silhouettes, Sharply Drawn
description: Last season, Rei Kawakubo used bridal lace in her mens collection; this time, she went for old-time pink roses on gray suiting, sweet polka dots and boxy shorts or culottes with jackets that evoked the classic Chanel cardigan. And the shoes came with little heels and socks with boldly colored ribbing, while the models wore Joan Jett wigs, at times with a beribboned bowler hat. All these elements felt warmly and securely Comme des Garons, but perhaps the most appealing thing about the show today was the silhouette: longish and free at the waist, with those full shorts (or knee-length skirts) and, naturally, hairy calves before the splash of pink at the ankles. One impulse was romantic  Jane Eyre, I thought  the other punk.

title: Why Students Leave the Engineering Track
description: 1/21/12 | Updated to correct Professor Babcocks academic affiliation.Amid broader discussions about the future of the American work force, the National Science Foundation has just released a comprehensive report on the state of engineering and science in America. Theres a lot of meat in the report, but I found this chart to be particularly striking:

title: Debates Arent to Blame for Perrys Failure
description: Nineteen times this political season, the Republican candidates for president have stood shoulder to shoulder on a stage, regardless of how much money they had raised or how many endorsements they had won, and passionately laid out for the voters the ideas and qualifications that they believe make them the best choice for the nations highest office.

title: Chic in Review | Carey Mulligan Double-Dipped a Dress
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Auction Winners Pay It Forward in Arizona
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Charitable organizations that assist wounded American veterans received unexpectedly large windfalls Thursday at the Barrett-Jackson classic car auctions here, with help from the prominent motorsports figures Roger Penske and Mario Andretti.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: With Athleticism and a Deft Touch, Egyptians Put Their Mark on Squash
description: Egyptians are having a moment, though it is nothing political. It involves a rectangular walled squash court rather than an outdoor square, and an offensive shotmaking style that is more beguiling than combative.

title: Two Art Fans Complete the Circuit of Hirst Spot Shows
description: A blogger and a magazine editor are the first two adventurers to complete Damien Hirsts wacky spot challenge.

title: Union Leader at Murry Bergtraum Asks Teachers: Tell Us How You Really Feel
Interior Candidate Bows Out
description: President Obama will not renominate his chosen candidate for assistant secretary of interior for parks and wildlife, who ran into a firm wall of Republican opposition in the Senate.

title: Nominating Fight Wears on Romneys Favorability Ratings
description: This chart from Talking Points Memo shows what seems to be a reasonably sharp rise in Mitt Romneys unfavorable ratings among the broader electorate, much of which seems to have come since we last checked in on the issue just a week ago.

title: Somali and African Troops Hit Rebel Posts in Mogadishu
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Government and African Union forces began a heavy offensive early on Friday against insurgent strongholds on the outskirts of the capital, Mogadishu, trying to drive the Islamic militants they have long battled out of the city, officials and witnesses said.

title: Fields Less Comfortable Amid Knicks Changes
description: Last season, Landry Fields took New York by storm, winning over Knicks fans almost instantly in his rookie year. He seemed to fit perfectly into the teams lineup, serving as a defensive cog in a first unit that was otherwise filled with offensive firepower.

title: Looking for Signs of Crime in Megauploads Memos
description: For those who follow copyright issues, cases of infringement are usually fought with civil lawsuits. Yet the operators behind the site Megaupload have been charged with criminal offenses, and four of them are being held without bail in New Zealand. What is different about Megaupload, and why have the authorities cracked down so hard on it?

title: Rick Santorum and the Three Bears
description: LEXINGTON, S.C.  Rick Santorum has started using an unfortunate new metaphor to describe his position among the remaining candidates: Goldilocks and the three bears.

title: Indian Authors Protest Threats to Rushdie by Reading From His Satanic Verses
description: As my colleagues Vikas Bajaj and Sruthi Gottipati report, the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie canceled a planned appearance at a literary festival in India on Friday, citing recent death threats.

title: Honda NC700X Set for U.S. Sales
description: Honda kicked off the 2012 New York motorcycle show early, revealing a new model on Thursday night intended for the American market. The NC700X was first introduced at the EICMA industry show in Milan in November, but was described then as a Europe-only model.

title: Under the VW Big Top, Even the Sky Isnt the Limit
description: TESTED 2012 Volkswagen Eos Lux

title: In Beetles Creation Story, a Plot Twist
description: THE tale is intriguing: a Jewish engineer and journalist, whose designs and published work in the 1930s laid out the basics for the Volkswagen Beetle championed by Hitler, was arrested, chased from Germany and nearly airbrushed out of history.

title: To Be Cute as a Bug Isnt Enough Anymore
description: THE New Beetle is dead. Long live the all-new Beetle, as Volkswagen calls the successor, squeezing together the adjectives just as it has squashed down the roof.

title: Book Review Podcast: Ben Jonson, In and Out of Shakespeares Shadow
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Charles Isherwood reviews Ian Donaldsons Ben Jonson: A Life. Jonson, a playwright and Britains first literary celebrity, was a contemporary of Shakespeare. In his book, Mr. Donaldson makes the case that Jonson was as central as Shakespeare to the development of the British theater. Though he was posthumously eclipsed by his fellow writer, Jonson was the more noticeable of the two while they lived. Mr. Isherwood writes:

title: One on One: Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia
description: Wikipedia has been a household name for years. But when the site announced that it would black out its English-language site earlier this week in support of a Webwide protest against two antipiracy bills, it became a hot topic of conversation.

title: A Beguiling Electric Diversion
description: History suggests that the latest edition of the Beetle, like its predecessors, will spawn myriad variations. At the Detroit auto show this month, VW introduced the E-Bugster, a design study for an all-electric version.

title: JPMorgan Hires Credit Suisses Granetz to Lead Finance Initiative
description: JPMorgan Chase has hired Marc Granetz, until last month a senior banking executive at Credit Suisse, to spearhead an internal push to improve the firms own financial strength and strategy, the bank announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

title: An Often-Painful Lesson in Insurance
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about force-placed insurance  something that most homeowners dont know about until their mortgage lender sends them a letter telling them they need it. If the homeowners dont act quickly, the lender will buy the insurance for them, almost always at a price thats a lot higher than the market rate.

title: Pistons to Daye: Please Dont Take the Ball to the Basket
description: The Detroit Pistons have one of the worst offenses in the N.B.A. The ball never seems to get to the players it should, the shots seem to go up before a quality opening is actually created and the team as a whole stumbles into an alarming number of miscues. Its no trick of scheduling that lost Detroit 12 of its first 15 games, as the inability to score in any kind of efficient or consistent manner has been a big problem  and sadly, a big problem among many  for the Pistons thus far.

title: Fish Without the Fear
description: In this weeks column, I roast a whole fish. If it sounds familiar its because we posted a video of the process last winter. Here it is again, and it may help flesh out the recipe if you have any questions about the techniques.

title: Olympus Is Given Fine but Avoids Delisting
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Stock Exchange said Friday that it would allow Olympus, the Japanese camera maker that has admitted hiding $1.7 billion in losses, to remain listed after paying a small fine for its false accounting.

title: Another Independent Dream Comes True
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Melanie Lynskey has playing wacky down cold. Shes done it for years on Two and a Half Men as Rose, the off-kilter neighbor. And she shines in dramatic parts, as when she played Matt Damons wife in The Informant!

title: A Painful Farewell to Saabs Heritage
description: More than 100 Saabs, from the streamlined 1947 prototype known as the Ursaab to a 2010 9-5 sedan, are to be taken from their home at the companys museum in Trollhattan, Sweden, and sold to the highest bidder.

title: Sharing Where Speed Traps Lie
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Michael Anthony Returns to Gramercy Tavern After Surgery
description: Michael Anthony, chef and partner at Gramercy Tavern, returned to the kitchen last week after recovering from surgery to repair a tear in his aorta, Papermag reports. Mr. Anthony, 44, had surgery in the fall for a rare condition.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 20
description: Subjects include a billboard collapse onto the B.Q.E., a beagle with a nose for illegal produce, and master watch restorer.

title: David Helfands New Quest
description: AFTER 35 years at Columbia University, where he was chairman of the astronomy department and co-director of the Astrophysics Laboratory, David J. Helfand is on leave to serve as president of Quest University Canada, a tiny liberal arts college in British Columbia that graduated its first class last spring. It is Canadas only private, secular nonprofit university.

title: E-Testing: The Future Is Here
description: ITS midterms, but instead of taking the test during class with a No. 2 pencil, you sign up for 7 p.m. Thursday (your biorhythmic high) and march over to the e-test center on campus. And instead of all multiple choice, theres a video-based question, and diagrams with drag-and-drop labels.

title: The Worlds Most Difficult Quiz
description: THE General Knowledge Paper has stumped pupils at King Williams College for over a century. Upper-level students would sit for the test on the last school day before Christmas. Over the next month they would pore over reference books and retake the test in January.

title: General Studies Moves to the Mainstream
description: ALISSA MORRONE had hoped to attend Johns Hopkins, perhaps Carnegie Mellon. But both returned thin envelopes. What she thought was a safety school, Boston University, sent similarly defeating news. Its College of Arts and Sciences rejected her, but the envelope was not thin. The College of General Studies, the letter promised, had a place for her.

title: One Percent Education
description: IT has been a populist winter. As Occupy Wall Street needles Americas financial sector over the countrys economic imbalance, it also focuses attention on another issue that helps feed that imbalance: educational inequality.

title: A Bridge to Recovery on Campus
description: IN their undergrad uniforms of fleece and sweats, a clutch of Rutgers students gathered on the worn red couches of their dorms common room and told their stories. A good-looking, fun-loving 23-year-old named Greg described arriving at college freshman year with a daily pot-smoking habit and a close relationship with alcohol. He soon followed the lead of his alcoholic father and was binge drinking (five drinks or more in a row). It was pretty scary, he said.

title: For Math, Click Calculate
description: THE banner hanging above the speaker at a TED conference on math instruction seemed to sum up the prevailing thinking: Stop teaching calculating. Start teaching math.

title: Bottom Lines
description: THE big story concerning early admissions programs this past fall was the re-entry of Harvard and Princeton into the fray. After deciding four years ago to no longer offer applicants an early option, both decided to reinstate single-choice early action programs beginning with the class of 2016.

title: The Debate X Factor
description: HOW does a tiny regional college in Danville, Ky., with just over 1,300 students attract 29 million TV viewers? Host a debate.

title: Renaissance Man
description: AFTER midnight, when most college students are cavorting or cramming, Jeremy Gleick is just settling into his learning hour. He occasionally curses when the hour looms so late, but he still does it.

title: Blogs vs. Term Papers
description: OF all the challenges faced by college and high school students, few inspire as much angst, profanity, procrastination and caffeine consumption as the academic paper. The format  meant to force students to make a point, explain it, defend it, repeat it (whether in 20 pages or 5 paragraphs)  feels to many like an exercise in rigidity and boredom, like practicing piano scales in a minor key.

title: A Nurse Need Never Forget
description: THESE days, when a nursing student at the University of Iowa fields a question about a drug, the answer is often, I dont know, but give me a few seconds, and she pulls out her phone, according to Joann Eland, an associate professor there.

title: How Big-Time Sports Ate College Life
description: IT was a great day to be a Buckeye. Josh Samuels, a junior from Cincinnati, dates his decision to attend Ohio State to Nov. 10, 2007, and the chill he felt when the band took the field during a football game against Illinois. I looked over at my brother and I said, Im going here. There is nowhere else Id rather be.  (Even though Illinois won, 28-21.)

title: Stress Survival Guide
description: Student photographers snap their classmates for The Times. This issue: how students relax during exam time.

title: Citing Security Fears, Rushdie Wont Attend Literary Festival
description: JAIPUR, India  In the latest setback for free speech in India, Salman Rushdie, the author who has survived a 23-year-old Iranian fatwa calling for his death, backed out of attending a literature festival in his native country because of a new assassination threat against him.

title: The Dawn of Lower Pay on Wall St.
description: The day of reckoning may be at hand.

title: George Washington Was A Hypocrite
description: OK, thats not what I believe. But its apparently what Scott Brown believes.

title: General Studies: Nuts and Bolts
description: Generalstudies takes various shapes. But many programs are aimed at students who are not accepted elsewhere in the university and referred by admissions. If in good standing on completion, they can transition into the larger university.

title: Interactive Graphic: Tracking Independent Spending
description: Since the start of the presidential campaign, independent groups have spent at least $29.5 million asking voters to elect or defeat candidates through television advertisements and other means. The most active groups have been super PACs, which can raise unlimited money from individuals, corporations and labor unions. Although these groups cannot legally be tied to a candidate, several of the most-active ones are run or advised by former associates or campaign staff. Track the spending of each of these independent groups here.

title: In Fire Investigation, Regulators Say They Found No Defect in Volt
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators on Friday closed their investigation into the Chevrolet Volt, saying that they found no evidence of a defect and that plug-in vehicles posed no greater fire risk after a crash than gasoline-powered ones. Still, analysts say that General Motors faces a challenge to rebuild consumer confidence in the car and that related safety concerns could hurt overall acceptance of the growing number of electrified vehicles coming on the market.

title: Is Bridal Fashion Taking a New Turn?
description: Unwritten rules that have long hemmed in the traditional bride have been jettisoned in favor of statement-making fashion-forward choices.

title: Wear a Denim Bridal Gown? Not Yet, but ...
description: SHOPPING for a gown, one of the first to-dos on any brides checklist, is about as unfettered and do-as-you-please as it has ever been. Unwritten rules that have long hemmed in the traditional bride (like wearing white, unless its a second wedding) have been jettisoned in favor of statement-making fashion-forward choices that better express a brides true personality and tastes, industry experts say.

title: A Dancer Who Can Remember The Giants
description: IF Wendy Whelan were a Hollywood star, glossy profiles about her would forever be opening with vignettes underlining how remarkably down to earth and likable she is.

title: Union Goes Up With Anti-Romney Ad in Florida
description: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the giant public employees union, will begin airing a 30-second video ad in Florida on Saturday attacking Mitt Romney for making what it said was a $473,000 profit from his firms investments in a medical company that admitted engaging in Medicare fraud.

title: Time Travel at the Met, Thanks to CDs
description: For insatiable opera buffs, there can never be too much of a good thing. These consumers are certainly in the sights of Sony Classical and the Metropolitan Opera, who are collaborating on a project to release no-frills, remastered recordings of historic live Saturday afternoon broadcasts from the Met.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 20
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Bahrain, Virginia and South Carolina.

title: Friday Night Music: Enya Meets The Queen Of The Night
description: Or thats what it sounds like to me!

title: Entering Weegees World
description: Our colleagues downstairs at the Lens blog have a great post today about the current exhibit of Weegees photographs at the International Center of Photography.

title: Bill Cunningham | World Unite
description: The fashion and design worlds are looking back to the Renaissance and the Victorian era for guidance on discovering a new aesthetic for today.

title: A Frightening Drug Resurfaces
description: The police found five additional gallons of liquid PCP in an East Harlem housing project that was raided this week, with officials calling it a dug-in hub for a drug thought to be an obsolete relic.

title: On Foreign Policy, Romney Breaks With Advisers
description: In October, Mitt Romney announced a roster of national security advisers that lent his campaign instant gravitas. Studded with heavyweight names, many from the Bush administration, the list suggested that Mr. Romney was the clear choice of the Republican foreign-policy establishment.

title: A Believer Packing Beer and Guitars
description: CRAIG FINN has always been a religious guy. He sees God as just but also notices that he has a wicked sense of humor. The barflies, losers and knock-around guys that he writes about in the songs for his band, the Hold Steady, often end up on their knees, sometimes retching, but more often praying for that moment when everything both aligns and goes off the rails at the same time. Its a moment of clarity, often seen through beer goggles: Went down with a tallboy can and he woke up in a cargo van, he sings on Barfruit Blues from the bands 2004 debut album, Almost Killed Me.

title: Obama Vow on Exports Is on Track, With Help
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, President Obama popped a surprise into his State of the Union address: His administration would double American exports in five years, helping to create two million jobs.

title: Britain Revokes Iranian TV Networks License
description: LONDON  Britains media regulator revoked the broadcast license for the Iranian state-owned television network Press TV on Friday, saying the network had failed to address concerns over its editorial independence and had not paid a fine.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Bahrain, Syria and Israel.

title: In the Arts, a Fleeting Freedom
description: Over the last couple of decades, musicians have been reconstructing the legacy of composers who spent World War II in Terezin (also known by its German name, Theresienstadt), a garrison city near Prague that the Nazis turned into a concentration camp. About 140,000 Jews were sent there, starting in 1941, including an unusually large number of musicians, writers and painters.

title: A Yippie on Familiar Turf, Both in New York and in Jail
description: A jail stint and a heart attack have done nothing to temper the spirit of Dana Beal, who still has his bushy, General Custer-style mustache, his thick head of gray hair, and the activist streak that has defined his nearly half-century of marijuana activism and radical politics.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Cellphone Stacking and the Next SOPA
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Android Is No. 1, But Google Says It Still Makes Little Money
description: In just three years, Android has become the king of mobile operating systems. But its only now starting to make money for Google, says Larry Page, Googles chief executive.

title: How Redistricting Plans Differ
description: An example of how the new Congressional district plan drawn by the Texas State Legislature differs from the one drawn by a special three-judge federal court.

title: App Smart Extra: A Stylish New Storybook App for Kids
description: Moonbot Studios, the developer of one of my top 10 iPad apps of 2011, The Fantastic Flying Books of Morris Lessmore, this week released a new book app, The Numberlys ($6).

title: A Program for Singers Shows Them the Way to Carnegie Hall
description: Im still here, an ebullient Marilyn Horne crooned to a delighted audience at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, invoking the classic Stephen Sondheim song. On one level this great mezzo-soprano was referring to herself, having come through extensive treatments for cancer in recent years. But her words also applied to the Marilyn Horne Foundation, which has provided support to young singers and fostered the art of the song recital.

title: Jan. 22  28
description: Theater

title: Gingrich Gains on Romney in Final South Carolina Polls
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The latest survey of likely voters in Saturdays Republican primary suggests that Mitt Romney has lost the advantage he once held.

title: Disdainful of Strategists, Gingrich Acts as His Own
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  If Newt Gingrich soars on his strong debate performances this week, overcomes the blowback within his party from attacking Mitt Romney as a corporate buyout king, and goes on to do well when South Carolina voters go to the polls on Saturday, one political strategist will get both blame for the stumbles and credit for successes: Mr. Gingrich himself.

title: Reviewing the Volkswagen Beetle
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Phil Patton reviews the 2012 Volkswagen Beetle, the German automakers sleeker, sportier and, above all, more masculine bug.

title: Tulum, Mexico, Is a Hot Spot for Fashion Insiders
description: Tulum has become a destination so popular with the fashion crowd this time of year, it almost feels like Fashion Week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 20
description: More Photographs

title: G+ Hangout | South Carolina Primary
description: Michael Shear and Paul Volpe of the New York Times Politics desk talk with readers on the eve of the South Carolina primary.

title: Milan Gets a New Star Recruit
description: MILAN

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a billboard collapse onto the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a beagle with a nose for illegal produce, and a master watch restorer.

title: Neutral Milk Hotels Frontman Does Most of the Work Himself, Including Horns
description: Sex, devastation, war, death, God, reincarnation and how strange it is to be anything at all were some of the things Jeff Mangum sang about on In the Aeroplane Over the Sea, the second album by his band Neutral Milk Hotel, released in 1998. Then he made himself scarce, rarely performing in public until 2010.

title: New in Your Wireless Store: The Cable Guy
description: Customers walking into a Verizon Wireless store in Portland, Ore., or Seattle this week may notice something unusual: cable salesmen.

title: Olympic Qualifying: U.S. Women vs. Dominican Republic
description: 2:37 a.m. | Final Score: U.S. 14, Dominican Republic 0 The United States womens national team opened the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament by thrashing the Dominican Republic, 14-0, on Friday night in Vancouver, but the joy of a record-setting night was tempered by what was described as a serious knee injury sustained by defender Ali Krieger.

title: Long Nap Didnt Improve Her Mood All That Much
description: Milla Jovovich may have the zombie post-apocalypse covered with the Resident Evil series (guided by her husband, Paul W. S. Anderson). But in vampire-werewolf warfare, Kate Beckinsale rules, with the Underworld movies (guided by her husband, Len Wiseman). No wan, moony Twilights these: were talking more than a thousand years of battle between Lycans (werewolves) and vampires, recounted in three installments before the latest, Underworld: Awakening. (Underworld scholars, see Chapter 3, Rise of the Lycans, for some origin details.)

title: Lighting the Shadows Behind the Queen and Her Consort
description: Prince Philip: The Turbulent Early Life of the Man Who Married Queen Elizabeth II. By Philip Eade. 368 pages. Henry Holt. $28.

title: Digital Notes: Blogger Rejects Subpoena in Grooveshark Case
description: Blog Responds in Grooveshark Case: Digital Music News, an industry blog that has found itself in the middle of a copyright infringement suit against the streaming service Grooveshark, has responded to a subpoena it received in the case. A pair of anonymous comments on the blog, purportedly written by Grooveshark employees, have become central pieces of evidence in the major record labels case against the service, and last weekend Grooveshark served Digital Music News with a subpoena for information about those comments. Paul Resnikoff, the blogs publisher, explained in a detailed post on Friday addressed to Groovesharks lawyers why he would not comply with the subpoena. He noted that to protect the identity of anonymous commenters, the site flushes relevant data after 24 hours and that he is entitled to the protection of state shield laws for journalists. He wrote:

title: Roots of a Problem
description: My boyfriends mother, who is in excellent health and has a full head of hair, has taken to wearing wigs. She photographs herself in them and texts the pictures to us. My strategy has been to ignore the photos and hope the wigs go away. My boyfriend responds by saying how much better she looks with her own hair. Should we come right out and tell her we dont like the wigs?

title: Good-Humored Maturity When Life Proves Tough
description: Last month LaChanze, the winsome Broadway star who won a 2006 Tony Award for best performance by a leading actress in a musical (The Color Purple), turned 50. That milestone wouldnt be worth noting had she not announced it on Thursday night at the Allen Room, where she appeared as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series. Her concert was also a 10th anniversary; she last visited the series in 2002 at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse.

title: Cracking Teenagers Online Codes
description: WITH her coordinated zebra-striped scarf, tights and arm warmers (arm warmers?), spiky out-to-there hat and pierced tongue, 34-year-old Danah Boyd provides an electric Gen Y contrast to the staid gray lobby of Microsoft Research in Cambridge, Mass., which she enters in a flurry of animated conversation, Elmo-decorated iPhone in hand. In a juxtaposition that causes her no end of mischievous delight, her laptop bears a sticker of Snow White, whose outstretched arm gently cradled the Apple logo.

title: Central Bank Becomes an Unlikely Hero in Euro Crisis
description: BERLIN  Throughout the month, countries caught in the eye of the European financial storm, including Italy, Spain and France, have repeatedly defied expectations, selling big batches of bonds to the public at interest rates significantly lower than investors demanded at the height of the euro crisis late last year.

title: In a Chairs Curves, a Past Reclaimed
description: MANY great talents started young, charging forward right out of the gate.

title: New York City Ballet
description: Performances of the Paul McCartney-Peter Martins vehicle, Oceans Kingdom, and two other ballets at Lincoln Center.

title: Chinese Poets, Public Enemies
description: Its a heady thought  if a bit preposterous  that a few lines of verse might undermine a government. But poetry, it is now clear, can be tantamount to treason in China, just as it was in Czechoslovakia (Vclav Havel), the Soviet Union (Joseph Brodsky and many others) and other authoritarian regimes of yesteryear.

title: Social Satire as a Sustainable Career Move
description: ON a walk down Main Street in Santa Monica with David Wittman, everything suddenly looks like a kooky California clich. The young women in Lululemon pants prancing into the raw-foods cafe. The guy with the Ask me about my divorce T-shirt. The coexist bumper sticker on the back of a Prius.

title: Investment Firm Y Combinator Goes on Offensive Against Hollywood
description: After the Stop Online Piracy Act and Protect Intellectual Property Act were shelved on Friday, some Web sites and venture capitalists went on the offensive against the people and companies behind the controversial piracy bills.

title: Diving Into Sea, and Then Gershwin
description: Some stories get better with age. In ballet, when the timelessness of a great fairy tale meets the ephemeral nature of dance, you end up with a Swan Lake," a work that never loses its ability to enchant.

title: The 2012 International Motorcycle Show
description: An up-close look at the bikes featured in the industrys annual expo in New York City.

title: Gingrich, Riding High, Dismisses Romneys Call to Release Ethics File
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  It was a day when not much could go wrong for Newt Gingrich.

title: 2 Families Face a Gust of Fortune
description: Gerald and Kitten Dowden have a name for the blessing thats changed their lives and that of their family: mailbox money. Not long ago they found that their Shreveport, La., home sits atop a natural-gas well, and now they receive six-figure checks for the hard work of staying put.

title: Air Kisses, Spike Heels and Ample Rubato
description: It was like something out of a fever dream: Donald Trump air-kissing both of Julie Andrewss cheeks on the stage of Carnegie Hall, just a few feet from the piano Vladimir Horowitz played for more than 40 years.

title: Comme des Garons: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: The G.O.P. Campaign, at a Fever Pitch
description: To the Editor:

title: A Decision on the Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Comme Des Garcons Homme Plus
description: Paris

title: To Hold Banks Accountable
description: To the Editor:

title: Everything Went Whoosh and a Friend, Lighting PCP, Died
description: The last hour of Hilda Santiagos life began in a pew at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul in East Harlem. An odd place to find someone on her way to buy drugs, but there she was last Sunday, between Masses, with her friend and partner in crime, Krystle Ortiz. They made this trip often from their apartments in the Bronx: the No. 4 train downtown to the No. 6 train, then to church, then to 1780 Madison Avenue to cop some dust, as they called buying PCP.

title: The 99 Percent
description: To the Editor:

title: Austrias Downgrade: The Governments View
description: To the Editor:

title: Clouding Together for a Storm, and Shedding Light on Immigration Stories
description: Last years inaugural FLICfest (Feature-Length Independent Choreography), a festival of dance created by Jeramy Zimmerman in partnership with the Irondale Center in Brooklyn, generated a lot of goodwill buzz for its mission of supporting evening-length work.

title: For South Carolinians, No Escape From the Messages
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Darlene Kleckley was at home recovering from knee surgery one recent afternoon when she heard the phone ring. It does that a lot these days.

description: Paris

title: A Porgy for Theatergoers, Not for Fans of the Opera
description: The new production of Porgy and Bess that opened recently on Broadway  now crassly, not to mention inaccurately, branded The Gershwins Porgy and Bess  has become perhaps the most controversial musical revival in recent memory. It has been interesting to note how people are reacting to the show in different ways according to their familiarity with the score, and more particularly their history (or not) of hearing it in the opera house, where it has been performed most regularly since its Broadway debut in 1935. Despite laffaire Sondheim, many people seem to enjoy it.

title: A Nobel Laureates Problem at Home
description: Monrovia, Liberia

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A Web uprising over Congressional efforts to halt online piracy  followed closely by the closing of a popular Web site on charges of copyright infringement  and a bankruptcy filing by Eastman Kodak were among the top business stories of the week.

title: With Hours to Decide, Few Are Willing to Commit
description: BELTON, S.C.  Heidi Trull does not usually allow customers to talk politics or religion at Grits and Groceries, her restaurant here in the farmland that defines the northwest corner of the state.

title: Audience Has Its Say in the Controversy
description: The New York Times theater critic Charles Isherwoods essay on The Gershwins Porgy and Bess follows an online discussion between the Times chief theater critic Ben Brantley and the Times chief classical music critic Anthony Tommasini about the production, which is scaled back and has eliminated parts of the score. Following are edited responses from readers:

title: John Galliano: Fall 2012 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Romney Turns His Attention Away From Gingrich and Toward Obama
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Hitting the campaign trail on Friday, the day before South Carolina voters head to the polls in the Republican primary, Mitt Romney turned his focus away from Newt Gingrich.

title: John Galliano Mens
description: Paris

title: Playing Well and Being Lucky at District 3 Winter Regional
description: Friday the 13th is supposed to be unlucky. This month it wasnt for R. Jay Becker and Brian Glubok of New York City, who won the two-session Open Pairs that day at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: The Gingrich Question: Cheating vs. Open Marriage
Developing Arm Strength Feet First
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  One day last week, a visitor walking by the weight room at the Giants practice facility could look through the glass windows and see Eli Manning, in a gray T-shirt, slowly and deliberately doing bicep curls with medium-sized dumbbells. Half a room away, offensive lineman Chris Snee was also lifting weights  with a barbell that looked to be sagging from all the pounds plated at each end.

title: Violin Masters on Parade
description: VIOLINISTS are hardly an unknown quantity on the Westchester County concert stage. But over the next month, three leading practitioners of the instrument will turn the Purchase College Performing Arts Center into a veritable violin mecca, presenting the music of Brahms, Bach and the Bard of Avon in concerts of varying scale, style and temperament.

title: Gingrich Gets a Boost on Intrade
description: Newt Gingrichs presidential candidacy is on the upswing in South Carolina, if Intrade, a popular online market for political bets, is any indication.

title: Weegees Killer Decade
description: Steps away from the sanitized, commercialized and pacified Times Square is a portal to a sinister urban past, where two-bit hoods lay sprawled in pools of blood with stogies clenched in their lifeless jaws, watched over by the police and the curious alike. Its a world of men with guns and hats who played their final hands under elevated tracks and tenements that have long since vanished.

title: Bad Year for Wall St. Not Reflected in Chiefs Pay
description: Wall Street stocks and profits took a beating in 2011. But there is one corner of the Street that took a lighter hit: the compensation paid to chief executives.

title: West Coast Brew Gave Kezar Stadium Its Color
description: SAN FRANCISCO  N.F.L. Hall of Famers called it home. It was where the alley-oop was invented. The 49ers founding owner died in his seat at the 50-yard line while watching a game. And it was there, atop a midfield hash mark, where Dirty Harry shot a serial killer called Scorpio.

title: A Brazilian Magnate Points to Himself for Inspiration
description: RIO DE JANEIRO

title: Prison Death Brings Outcry Against Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  Human rights advocates and American officials condemned the Cuban government on Friday for continuing to limit political freedom, reacting to the death of an imprisoned Cuban dissident who had carried out a hunger strike to protest his sentence.

title: From Patti Smith, Images Romantic and Morbid
description: Patti Smith entered the world of famous people in 1975 with her album Horses, which combined punk and classic 60s rock with elements of Van Morrison and Bob Dylans folk agitation. But Ms. Smith has always been more than a musician. In the late 60s and 70s, living in New York, she wrote poetry, music criticism for Rolling Stone and Creem, and a play with her onetime partner Sam Shepard. Her memoir, Just Kids, about her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, won the 2010 National Book Award. And last year she marked another celebrity rite of passage with a television acting debut on Law & Order: Criminal Intent.

title: Dolphins Hire Packers Coordinator as Head Coach
description: The Miami Dolphins, who last year tried to woo Jim Harbaugh while still employing Tony Sparano, and who were rebuffed by Jeff Fisher last week, finally abandoned their quest for a big name and chose Joe Philbin as their new coach on Friday.

title: The Caucus: Republican Candidates at the Citadel
description: Over on The Caucus, Ben Werschkul follows the Republican candidates to the Citadel, the military college of South Carolina. Candidates and presidents alike have long used the Citadel as a backdrop for foreign policy speeches.

title: Kansas Law on Sodomy Stays on Books Despite a Cull
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  Gov. Sam Brownback created the Office of the Repealer to recommend the elimination of out-of-date, unreasonable and burdensome state laws that build up in any bureaucracy over time.

title: Amish Man Held in Beard Attacks Seeks Bail Deal
description: Samuel Mullet Sr., the renegade Amish leader being held in Ohio in connection with beard-cutting attacks on Amish rivals, made a new request for bail on Thursday, telling a federal judge that he would allow electricity inside his home to permit electronic monitoring. But federal prosecutors replied on Friday that Mr. Mullet posed a danger to the community and that the Amish aversion to electricity had not figured in the decision to keep him in custody until his trial, which is now scheduled for March.

title: Opening Newts Marriage
description: Right now, you are probably asking yourself whether two divorces, a history of adultery and an ex-wife who says you asked for an open marriage would be enough to disqualify a person from becoming president of the United States.

title: Who Else Is Paying Your Doctor?
description: It took longer than expected, but the Obama administration is finally poised to enact badly needed regulations requiring that the manufacturers of drugs, medical devices and medical supplies disclose all payments they make to doctors or teaching hospitals. The information, which would be posted on a government Web site, will allow patients to decide whether they need to worry about any possible conflicts of interest.

title: Sobering Report Describes Trends in Deaths of Abused and Neglected Children
description: The child who came to be known as Case No. 95-2011-00009 was the fourth born into a home where abuse and neglect were practically a family tradition.

title: Richard M. Ketchum Dies at 89; Chronicled the Rural Life
description: Richard M. Ketchum, an author and editor who co-founded Country Journal, a magazine that offered a blend of the bucolic and the practical, particularly to city folk who had opted for the rural life, died on Jan. 12 at a retirement home in Shelburne, Vt. He was 89 and until four years ago had lived on his nearly 1,000-acre farm, Saddleback, in Dorset, Vt.

title: Gingrich Is Victim of False Smear Campaign
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Newt Gingrich was the subject of an ugly and false smear campaign on Friday, the day before South Carolina Republican voters were set to go to the polls.

title: Yankees and Gardner Agree to Contract
description: The Yankees avoided arbitration with outfielder Brett Gardner by agreeing to a one-year contract worth $2.8 million in Gardners first year of arbitration eligibility.

title: China Leader Warns Iran Not to Make Nuclear Arms
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao wrapped up a six-day Middle East tour this week with stronger-than-usual criticism of Irans defiance on its nuclear program, and with multibillion-dollar oil deals that would seem to signal less reliance on Tehran for Chinas growing energy needs.

title: 49ers Reclaim a Famous Fan
description: Having given up watching football about five years ago because it had grown too violent and far less interesting than baseball and soccer, sports he finds much more poetic, Lawrence Ferlinghetti stumbled into watching the second half of the 49ers victory over the Saints last weekend.

title: Sticky Stickers, Cleaner Streets
description: When it comes to the question of cleaner streets or cleaner windows on cars parked illegally on those streets, the New York City Council has now sided with the vehicles and their owners.

title: Teen Spirit, With 80s Hair
description: Photography may be a technological medium, but photographs themselves differ from most products of technology in one significant way: Rather than becoming obsolete, they often get better, or at least more interesting, with age. An example of this can be seen in Coming of Age in America: The Photography of Joseph Szabo at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

title: Once Schooled by Him, Santorum Moves to Give Gingrich Lessons
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Late in Thursday nights debate, Newt Gingrich yielded his time to Rick Santorum to address whether Mitt Romney genuinely opposed abortion rights.

title: Guilty Until Proved Innocent
description: In America, a person is presumed innocent until proved guilty. Unless, that is, he plays college sports.

title: Redistricting in Texas
description: In a closely watched case about a redistricting battle in Texas, the Supreme Court on Friday issued a per curiam opinion that added a further twist in a rushed and messy controversy. In the unanimous ruling, the Supreme Court told a three-judge district court in San Antonio to put aside redistricting plans it created and devise new maps based on those made by the Texas Legislature. And this time, the Supreme Court said, the district court must do a better job of explaining any maps it draws.

title: At an Unexpected Reunion, Revisiting a Shared Past
description: Perhaps it has happened to you: catching a passing glimpse of somebody familiar and yet changed from the way you fondly knew him or her years ago.

title: In Battle of Top Teams, a Chance to Measure Potential
description: On Saturday afternoon in Boston, two of the N.H.L.s best teams will finally meet.

title: Troopers Hit 2 Pedestrians Near Cuomos Home
description: On two consecutive days this week, members of a high-level state security team were involved in car accidents near Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos home in Westchester County, both times badly injuring a pedestrian.

title: For Gingrich, Wives Always at Center of Career
description: WASHINGTON  When Newt Gingrich was House speaker, lawmakers would routinely arrive at his elegant suite in the Capitol and find an unexpected adviser sitting on the couch: his wife, Marianne.

title: A Widespread Pattern
description: Blacks file Chapter 13 bankruptcies at a higher rate than other groups even in areas that have a low rate of those type of bankruptcies.

title: For Beer Aficionados, the World on a String
description: ON a recent weeknight at Growlers Beer Bistro, where patrons are sometimes asked to seat themselves, an elderly couple had barely settled at a corner table when the host approached and asked if they had been helped. No, said the man.

title: A Raucous Hazing at a Wall St. Fraternity
description: Updated |

title: Antipiracy Case Sends Shivers Through Some Legitimate Storage Sites
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Megaupload is guilty, then who among its brethren is innocent?

title: U.S. Warns It May Close Embassy in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The continuing violence in Syria prompted the United States on Friday to warn that it may close its embassy here in the capital unless the Syrian government acts on a request to bolster security around the compound.

title: Newts Southern Strategy
description: Up with Newt. Down with dignity. Thats the way it goes.

title: Egypts Economic Crisis
description: In the year since President Hosni Mubarak was ousted, Egypt has faced many challenges: the military-led governments brutality against protesters and pro-democracy groups, its resistance to handing power to civilian leaders and the rise of Islamists in the countrys first free elections. Now worsening economic conditions are further sabotaging hopes for a democratic future.

title: With Small Devices, Older New Yorkers Gain Independence and Peace of Mind
description: There was a time when Angelo Boccino did not mind falling  if it was from an airplane and he had a parachute. In fact, Mr. Boccino jumped out of planes on combat missions when he was an Army paratrooper in World War II, he said. Today, he is 93, and falling can be hazardous to his health. So Mr. Boccino, who uses a wheelchair, an electric scooter and a walker to get around, depends on an emergency alert bracelet he wears on his left wrist.

title: In Flash of Fire, Florida Loses Old Friend
description: LONGWOOD, Fla.  Back, way back, before King Tut was born and Alexander the Great roamed his empire, the Senator sprouted in a swamp here in central Florida, one of thousands of its kind.

title: Saturday: Slice From Beneath the Ribs
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I have to confess that I was initially creeped out in a big way by this grid by Martin Ashwood-Smith.

title: Lottery Numbers
Preservation Push in Bohemian Home Stirs Fear of Hardship
description: The East Village is arguably Americas bohemian capital, home to the major countercultural waves of the second half of the 20th century  beatniks like Allen Ginsberg, hippies like Abbie Hoffman and punk rockers like Joey Ramone.

title: Defense Chief Ends Probation Status of Marine Warplane
description: NAVAL AIR STATION PATUXENT RIVER, Md.  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta visited a flight testing center along the shores of Chesapeake Bay on Friday to give a lift to the beleaguered F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, announcing that he was taking the Marine Corps version of the costly warplane off probation.

title: City Criticizes Judge in Case Of Hiring At Fire Dept.
description: The federal judge who ruled that the New York Fire Department discriminates against minority candidates and ordered a court-appointed monitor to oversee its recruiting efforts has lost any semblance of neutrality and should be removed from the case, the city said in an appeal filed this week.

title: House Republicans Hone Plan to Take On Obama
description: BALTIMORE  President Obama may be running against Congressional Republicans in his re-election campaign, but they intend to run right back against him.

title: Italy Announces New Steps to Get Economy Moving
description: ROME  In a bold effort to transform Italys protectionist economy and to foster growth amid a deepening recession, Prime Minister Mario Monti on Friday announced a new set of measures aimed at reviving Italys sluggish economy by investing $7.1 billion in infrastructure and opening up professional guilds to competition.

title: Complexity and Intrigue Amid the Old Standbys
description: SOMETIMES having too many projects  and the restaurateurs Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich have many  can dilute even a fine concept. But that is not the case at one of the pairs newest ventures, Tarry Lodge Enoteca Pizzeria in Westport. A sister to the well-known Tarry Lodge that opened in Port Chester more than three years ago, it is a smoothly run hands-on effort by Mario La Posta, the chef, and Andy Nusser, executive chef and managing partner with Nancy Selzer  all from the Port Chester team. And the bill for a lunch or dinner is reasonable, bucking the current Fairfield County trend of rising prices, which may explain why so many young couples dine there.

title: A 49ers Linebacker With Two Men to Call Dad
description: BRUCETON, Tenn.  The strange and impromptu family reunion took place Wednesday on a high school basketball court.

title: A Specialists Debate on Autism Has Many Worried Observers
description: A debate among medical professionals over how to define autism has spilled over into the public domain, stirring anger and fear among many parents and advocates of those with the neurological disorder, even as some argue that the diagnosis has been too loosely applied.

title: Accuser of Syracuse Coach Admits Doctoring E-Mails and Drops Civil Suit
description: A man who accused the former Syracuse assistant basketball coach Bernie Fine of molesting him has withdrawn a civil suit against Fine after acknowledging that he lied and doctored e-mails in an attempt to bolster parts of his story.

title: The Remarkable Path of a Football Star
description: A look at the background of the star 49ers linebacker Patrick Willis, who was raised by a struggling single father and than a foster father in western Tennessee.

title: Blacks Face Bias in Bankruptcy, Study Suggests
description: Blacks are about twice as likely as whites to wind up in the more onerous and costly form of consumer bankruptcy as they try to dig out from their debts, a new study has found.

title: U.S. Investigates Trade Complaint on Washers
description: The Commerce Department agreed to investigate a trade complaint by Whirlpool that said residential washing machines made in South Korea and Mexico were being sold below cost in America. The United States imported $1.1 billion of the washers from the two nations in 2010, the agency said. Whirlpool is requesting antidumping duties on LG and Samsung imports from South Korea and Mexico. The department also is considering whether to impose countervailing duties against the Korean products, to offset benefits of subsidies.

title: A New Rustic Bistro (Comes With a Crowd)
description: WHEN the owners of a highly regarded restaurant open another place, the new spot is often on a fast track to popularity. Such is the case with Market Bistro in Jericho, which was opened in November by Bill Holden and Bob Caras, proprietors of the well-liked, 20-year-old West End Cafe in Carle Place, along with Adam Acerra, a former bartender at West End.

title: Probation for a Former Galleon Group Employee
description: David R. Slaine, a former Galleon Group employee who helped the authorities investigate the hedge funds co-founder, Raj Rajaratnam, was sentenced to probation for three years for securities fraud. Mr. Slaine wore a hidden device to record dozens of conversations with suspects including Zvi Goffer, a former Galleon trader. Judge Richard J. Sullivan of United States District in Manhattan, who sentenced Mr. Slaine, also ordered him to perform 300 hours of community service and pay a $500,000 fine. The judge praised Mr. Slaines cooperation, which began in 2007.

title: Out in Three Attempts, Another Shot at a Super Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Steve Weatherford would rather have had the Giants miss the playoffs if they do not win the Super Bowl. It is a perspective in heartbreak he has gained after a few N.F.L. postseasons.

title: Ejection and Dejection as Knicks Skid Goes On
description: The night before the Knicks have to face the possibility that the Denver Nuggets may have stolen their future, Brandon Jennings and the Milwaukee Bucks handed them their fifth straight loss Friday in part by making important steals with the alarming ease of practiced pickpockets.

title: Threat From Gangs Heightens Anxiety in a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: In the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Yizbeth Leon and her co-workers stopped walking to the B12 bus stop after dark for fear of being robbed or attacked.

title: Bread Touched by Human Hands
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J.

title: Wall Dogs With Paint
description: Sign painters, a k a billboard artists, have almost disappeared, their trade strangled by the advent of vinyl sheets. But there is still call for their artistry, skill and pluck.

title: On a Cold Night, Good Wine and Cozy Plates
description: The burgeoning Terroir empire of site-specific wine bars concocted by Paul Grieco and the executive chef Marco Canora has touched down in Murray Hill. The two have become known as providers of cozy, comfy small plates that allow imbibers to go all experimental on beverage selections. The narrow room has de rigueur exposed-brick walls, Parson-style tables and rustic wood shelving meant to suggest a Revolutionary War-era farmhouse atmosphere: to wit, the neighborhood is named for the 29-acre farm belonging to the Murray family that once occupied this section of Manhattan. As a tribute to the late Murray Hill Hotel, Mr. Canora plucked, and tweaked, four historic dishes from a menu in the New York Public Library archives: smoked beef tongue pastrami, fried scallops, the ever-hardy French dip and an oyster sandwich.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Police Cruiser Update

title: Corrections: January 21
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In the Push of a Button, Safety and Freedom
description: The emergency alarm response system, or EARS, allows seniors to live independently while having instant access to help in the event of falls or illness.

title: Coffee, Couch Time and a Trip to Jail
description: The perennially ponytailed Ronald L. Kuby, who says he hasnt had a haircut since 1989, is the counsel of choice for alternative types; five protesters from the Occupy Wall Street encampment retained him after tangling with the New York Police Department. From 1999 to 2007 he was a host of a radio show on WABC-AM with Curtis Sliwa. On Sundays, Mr. Kuby, 55, works a bit but mostly relaxes by cooking, walking or biking, and watching TV. He lives in Chelsea with his wife, Marilyn Vasta, 60, a psychotherapist, and their bichon fris, Lily; they are sometimes joined by their daughter, Emma, 19, who attends Wesleyan University. The couple also owns a country house in the Poconos.

title: Sign Says What? Park at Your Peril
description: APP Can I Park Here

title: With Braun, Awards Dinner Gains Unusual Attention
description: The annual awards dinner organized by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America, typically a low-key affair, will take place Saturday night in Manhattan under an unusual amount of scrutiny.

title: Petty Differences Mask Consensus on Teachers
description: Popular culture has surely produced no more satiric a view of that great scourge of public progress, the Apathetic Teacher, than last years bluntly titled comedy Bad Teacher. In the film, Cameron Diaz plays Elizabeth Halsey, a junior high school teacher so incompetent and chemically regulated that she shows movies all day, barely registers one students slapping another with coleslaw and steals the answers to a state-administered exam. A bonus of $5,700 is to be given to the teacher whose students score highest on the test, and Halsey pursues it to pay for her adventures in plastic surgery. Perhaps you watched the movie wondering whether it had been subsidized by a political action committee aimed at dismantling the teachers union.

title: Self-Immolation Is on the Rise in the Arab World
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than a year after a young Tunisian set himself on fire and touched off revolutions throughout the Arab world, self-immolation, symbolic of systemic frustration and helplessness, has become increasingly common across the region.

title: After Mt. Everest, the Bronx
description: JINPA SHERPA is unfailingly cheerful and helpful as he rings up your gas and coffee and lottery ticket at the Gulf station mini-mart on Leggett Avenue in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

title: Inebriated Love
description: A STRANGER across the bar, a glass in his or her hand, a wild fire in the eyes. What is it that draws us to drunk people? Their volubility? Their lack of inhibition? Or is it that  in a birds-of-a-feather sort of way  our would-be partners muddled state is so often a reflection of our own? Whatever the case, intoxications influence on romance is a classic literary trope, ably demonstrated in these poems found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: Sharapova Reaches Round of 16
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Maria Sharapova powered her way into the Round of 16 with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Angelique Kerber on Saturday.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Julie Taymor: The many visitors to India this week included Oprah Winfrey, Australian actor Joel Edgerton and director Julie Taymor, who won an Oscar nomination for Frida and also directed the theatrical blockbuster The Lion King on Broadway. She and her partner, Oscar-winning composer Elliot Goldenthal traveled through Rajasthan, Kerala and visited New Delhi and Mumbai.

title: Sermon: I Love New York
description: November 14, 2010: The Twenty-Fifth Sunday After Pentecost. Based on Luke 21:5-19.

title: The Last Sermon of Mr. Fix-It
description: HIS work here is done. His reinvention of a dying church with ratty old wooden pews is emblemized by the 900 brand-new chairs  bought by parishioners for $900 apiece, engraved plaques included  arrayed in the exquisite mosaic, marble and stained-glass sanctuary. With a congregation of nearly 3,400, up from a foundering flock of just a few hundred when he took over in 1994, the Rev. William MacDonald Tully, 65, is retiring from active duty at St. Bartholomews Episcopal Church on Park Avenue and 50th Street. His final sermon is on Sunday.

title: Dropping Everything to Live in the Highlands
description: Its sort of the American Dream  in reverse.

title: In a Club Fight, Power, Ego and Real Estate
description: THE president of the National Arts Club, Dianne Bernhard, sat on a loveseat the other day and spoke affectionately about the man she succeeded. Her lawyer sat opposite.

title: Russia: Putins Popularity Inches Upward
description: A respected polling agency connected to the Russian government announced Friday that the popularity of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin had reversed its slow decline, rising above 50 percent for the first time in weeks. The news comes just over a month before presidential elections that Mr. Putin is widely expected to win. The polling agency, VTsIOM, put Mr. Putins rating at 52 percent as of Jan. 14. He remains Russias most popular politician, but his decision to seek the presidency again after four years as prime minister set off huge anti-Kremlin protests in December. In another survey released this month by the Levada Center, a prominent independent polling agency, 36 percent of Russians said they would vote for Mr. Putin, more than would support any of his opponents, but not enough for him to win the election in the first round.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Move to Investigate the Investigators in WikiLeaks Case
description: This much is known: In its hunt for information about three people it believes to be associated with the whistle-blower site WikiLeaks, the Justice Department has sought to extract details about them and their communications on Twitter. What is not yet known is where else the Justice Department went looking.

title: Ivanovic Closes Out Kings Musical Run
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Vania Kings quest for a berth in the Round of 16 ended without a victory song on Saturday when Ana Ivanovic of Serbia prevailed, 6-3, 6-4, in a closely fought match before about 8,000 fans at the 2012 Australian Open.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The Indian Air Force has been asked by the Jammu and Kashmir government to airlift people stranded by heavy snowfall between Srinagar and the Jammu region.
