The Jammu-Srinagar national highway, an important road link connecting the state to other parts of the country, remained closed for passenger traffic since the last one week, affected by landslides and snowfall, Kashmir Live reports.

title: African Cup: Ivory Coasts Last Chance for Glory?
description: The African Cup of Nations kicks off Saturday with two games in Equatorial Guinea but no clear favorite. Theres a reason for that: of the past nine champions, eight failed to qualify for this years tournament.

title: Scheduling Conflict for a Bryan
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Bob Bryan is in Melbourne, playing in another Australian Open. His wife, Michelle, is in Miami awaiting the birth of their first child.

title: Red Faces Over Vienna Culture Bid
description: PARIS  The winter season of Vienna balls is at its glittering height but there were red faces in the Austrian capital this weekend over a bid to have them officially designated as an international cultural treasure.

title: The Weekend Word: Nail-Biter
description: Todays Times

title: The Quiet End of the Runway
description: IT was a honey-gold morning in Tulum, Mexico, the low-rise, high-key ocean strip in the Yucatn 75 miles south of Cancn. While many visitors saluted the sun in various yoga poses along the white swatch of the Atlantic Ocean beach, Irene Albright and her daughter, Marina, stared at a computer screen in the open-air lobby of the Hotel Nueva Vida de Ramiro. They were looking at Chlos Web site.

title: Undercover Police Will Wear Giants Jerseys at Candlestick
description: Following up on Fridays post about fan behavior at Candlestick Park. (Most readers agreed that it was a concern.)

title: Should We Root for One of the Harbaugh Brothers to Lose?
description: It doesnt matter which one.

title: Gingrich Is Well-Positioned as South Carolina Votes
Reading The Satanic Verses in India: Is it Illegal?
description: Did Amitava Kumar, Hari Kunzru and other authors who read passages from Salman Rushdies The Satanic Verses, which is banned in India, Friday evening at the Jaipur Literature Festival violate Indian law?

title: A Small-Business Owner Bird-Dogs the Republican Candidates
description: One undeniable benefit of holding an early primary (or caucus) in a small state like New Hampshire is that any citizen has a chance to meet the candidates for president individually and interrogate them on the issues  even if the citizen is not, technically, a resident of that early voting state. And so Mark Dunau, a New York farmer and gadfly for the self-employed (through his Web site, dontsubmit.org), headed up to the Granite State to bird dog the Republican candidates in the week before the New Hampshire primary.

title: Divers Resume Search of Capsized Cruise Ship
description: GIGLIO, Italy  A week after the Costa Concordia luxury liner ran aground off the island of Giglio in Tuscany, bodies were still being retrieved from the wreck that is threatening the protected environment here.

title: The Least Refuse Of A Squirrel
description: People have been asking me about Steve Rattners op-ed, which does seem to be aimed at me. My initial reaction was sheer bafflement: Rattner first attacks a view that, as far as I know, nobody holds, then makes his case by saying in as many ways as he can think of that the debt is huge, huge I tell you. Whats going on here?

title: Michael Kinsley And The Phantom Menace
description: Kevin Drum sends us to Michael Kinsley, who is still worried about inflation despite its failure to explode the way he thought it would.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hewitt Conjures Some Old Magic to Defeat Raonic
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Though he is nearly 10 years removed from his last Grand Slam title, Lleyton Hewitt pushed his way back into the business end of a major tournament, reaching the second week of the 2012 Australian Open with a surprising four-set win over the Canadian Milos Raonic.

title: Gingrich Confident as Voting Begins
description: Newt Gingrich began a busy day of brief drop-by stops at restaurants and a school across South Carolinas conservative northern tier. First up was the Grapevine Restaurant in Boiling Springs, where some breakfast patrons already had their small I voted stickers.

title: Five Questions For: Tiger Mother Amy Chua
description: At the Jaipur Literature Festival this weekend, India Ink is asking authors in attendance five questions about writing and themselves. Nikhila Gill caught up with the author of controversial memoir Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother on Saturday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Yves Saint Laurent
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Fielders Options Are as Narrow as His Talent Is Vast
description: It is a standard negotiating tactic, an argument hard to beat on the surface. Player A is better than Player B. Therefore, Player A should make more money than Player B. Fill in the zeros, shake hands, sign the contract.

title: Romney Will Participate in Monday Debate
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  After a high-stakes game of chicken between Mitt Romney and NBC News over whether he would participate in the next debate, Mr. Romney blinked.

title: Actor Gets Attention as Director of The End of Love
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Hollywood comes to Sundance to discover new directors. Quentin Tarantino, Michael Moore, Bryan Singer and Darren Aronofsky all got noticed for the first time (more or less) at the festival.

title: Photos of the Moment | Givenchy
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Gronkowski Earning Name for Scores and Spikes
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Conan OBrien featured him in a parody of the song St. Elmos Fire on TV last week. The Worcester Sharks of the American Hockey League are paying him $7,500 to spike a hockey puck before one of their games next month.

title: Romney Urges Gingrich Disclosure on Freddie Mac
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  As South Carolina residents began voting Saturday morning, Mitt Romney stopped to thank supporters and volunteers at his campaign office here, and he called on Newt Gingrich to release the details of his contract with Freddie Mac.

title: Homecoming for Player Who Grew Up Amid Nature but Without a Course
description: IDYLLWILD, Calif.  The sign welcoming visitors into this towns snug embrace reads: Home of Adventure, Music, Art and Harmony. Nestled like a dogleg in the San Jacinto Mountains, it is protected by tall pines, pocked by boulders and redolent of cedar, and has neither a golf course nor a driving range. It would seem infertile ground for raising a professional golfer, and yet it is where Brendan Steele, the reigning Texas Open champion, grew up.

title: Variety: A Furry Diagramless
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  About five years ago, we decided to get a dog. My older dogs had crossed the Rainbow Bridge, and, to be absolutely truthful, my kids and I just arent used to living without a four-legged companion in the house. We honestly dont know what to do with ourselves without a dog telling us when its time to go for a walk.

title: Sunday Dialogue: State Laws on Unions
description: Should workers be compelled to join unions or pay dues? Readers debate right to work laws now being considered.

title: Farewell Is Also a Win as Cuche Becomes the King of Kitzbhel
description: KITZBHEL, Austria  Two days after unexpectedly announcing that he would retire after this season, Didier Cuche on Saturday won his record-breaking fifth Hahnenkamm downhill, largely considered skiings most difficult and prestigious race.

title: Williams Turns Back the Clock and Turns Up the Heat
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was a time-warp Saturday for Serena Williams at the Australian Open as she crushed the suspense out of a third-round night match in Rod Laver Arena against an intimidated opponent and fielded questions in the interview room about extracurricular activities: fashion, studies and even that old standard, acting.

title: Hello, Big Rat
description: Just a guess, but Im betting few early morning passengers on the northbound D train on Jan. 13 fully appreciated the admirable qualities of the possum crouching under one of the seats in their subway car.

title: Of Mouselike Bites and Marathons
description: THE people who invite us to wallow in food seldom remind us to beware.

title: Do Drones Undermine Democracy?
description: Washington

title: Julia Heiman
description: Julia Heiman is the director of the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction at Indiana University, Bloomington. For more than 60 years, the institute has been investigating, and educating the public about, sexual matters. Dr. Heiman is also a professor of clinical psychiatry and psychological and brain sciences.

title: A Near Showdown Over Some Real Pork
description: GREENVILLE, S.C. In the end, Pork-alypse Now did not go down.

title: Rick Perry Is Back Home, With Fences to Mend
description: When Gov. Rick Perry suspended his presidential bid, he said it was because there was no viable path forward. But is there a viable path back?

title: Coughlin Goes by the Book, and Wins
description: Mike Perkins was one of the first people Tom Coughlin hired as he built an N.F.L. franchise in Jacksonville during the mid-1990s. When the Jaguars stadium was nearly complete, Coughlin ordered Perkins, the son of the former Giants coach Ray Perkins, onto the new field to calculate how many steps there were from the home sideline to the locker room.

title: Ready for Worst, New York Gets First Major Snowfall
description: A powdery section of snow slid across the mid-Atlantic region and out toward sea on Saturday, making the seasons first significant storm a less ferocious affair than a freakish Halloween weekend northeaster, or the blizzard of 2010.

title: Five Questions for: Abhijit V. Banerjee
description: At the Jaipur Literature Festival this weekend, India Ink is asking authors five questions about writing and about themselves. Nikhila Gill caught up with the co-author of Poor Economics, a book which reexamines ways of fighting poverty.

title: Confronting Iran in a Year of Elections
description: WASHINGTON

title: Numbers Indicate That Skill Usually Packs a Bigger Punch Than Fists
description: Does fighting help N.H.L. teams win?

title: Variations on an Explosive Theme
description: WHEN George Gershwins Porgy and Bess  arguably the most important piece of American music written in the 20th century  first opened on Broadway in 1935, the operas libretto was littered with a word now shunned as an antiblack slur. The African-American residents of Catfish Row, the only slightly imaginary block in Charleston, S.C., where the opera is set, used it liberally, and so of course did the white characters during their occasional menacing visits.

title: Runway In Review
description: Comme des GarconsDesigner: Rei KawakuboDate: Friday, Jan. 20Photos: slide show

title: Obama to Draw an Economic Line in State of the Union
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will use his election-year State of the Union address on Tuesday to argue that it is governments role to promote a prosperous and equitable society, drawing a stark contrast between the parties in a time of deep economic uncertainty.

title: Hungarys Lurch Backward
description: The soothing words of Hungarys prime minister, Viktor Orban, do little to counter his governments assaults on the independence of Hungarys press, judiciary and central bank. Without strong European pressure, Mr. Orban is unlikely to change the new banking, judiciary and media laws.

title: The Affirmative Action War Goes On
description: Last month, the Obama administration issued important guidance to colleges and universities on how to increase racial diversity on campuses, explaining ways to navigate the narrow legal channel charted by the Supreme Court. The benefits of diversity, the Department of Education said, contribute to the educational, economic and civic life of this nation. The administrations support for such efforts stands in stark contrast to the policy of the George W. Bush administration to discourage them. That difference has played out between the political parties for decades, as it will in this presidential election.

title: Rejected in Tucson
description: The Tucson Unified School District has dismantled its Mexican-American studies program, packed away its offending books, shuttled its students into other classes. It was blackmailed into doing so: keeping the program would have meant losing more than $14 million in state funding. It was a blunt-force victory for the Arizona school superintendent, John Huppenthal, who has spent years crusading against ethnic-studies programs he claims are brainwashing children into thinking that Latinos have been victims of white oppression.

title: Friends of Angelo, Part 2
description: Four lawmakers have been referred to the House Ethics Committee for receiving special mortgage loans from the notorious V.I.P. program of Countrywide Financial. Ethics rules require members to accept loans only on terms generally available to the public. It should be of great interest for the public, particularly those mired in mortgage trouble, to see if anything comes out of the Congressional investigation.

title: How Mrs. Grady Transformed Olly Neal
description: IF you want to understand how great teachers transform lives, listen to the story of Olly Neal.

title: Quick Rebound in Cleveland
description: When LeBron James left the Cavaliers, the devastation was supposed to be complete. But in the second season after his departure, they are doing something that few expected: winning.

title: The Ongoing Debt Transformation
description: A followup on my note about US deleveraging. It turns out that if you measure debt as a percentage of potential GDP (as estimated by the CBO) and use a stacked-area graph, you get a pretty clear picture. Here it is, using nonfinancial debt (for reasons explained in the previous post):

title: Tallying Disasters and Gauging a Greenhouse Impact
description: I encourage you to read Global Warming and Severe Weather: Is There a Link? This excellent newGreen Grokpost is byBill Chameides, the blogging dean of the Nicholas School for the Environment at Duke University. (Hat tip @KeithKloor.)

title: A Good Candidate Is Hard to Find
description: THERE are 300 million people in the United States of America. There are millions of political activists, volunteers, organizers and would-be officeholders. There are hundreds of thousands of elected officials. Yet somehow, out of all this multitude, the Republican Party has been unable to find a candidate for the White House in 2012 who inspires anything but weary resignation from its voters.

title: Caucus Click: Waiting for Romney
How the U.S. Lost Out on iPhone Work
description: When Barack Obama joined Silicon Valleys top luminaries for dinner in California last February, each guest was asked to come with a question for the president.

title: Lynn Shelton Offers a Thank-You to Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  For the films screening here, the crew from Your Sisters Sister might have been the most relaxed. Not only did the film already have distribution, a rarity at this years buyer-ready festival, but it came with a lot of good buzz from its premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. Thats where IFC picked up the film, a largely improvised comedy about a depressed guy (Mark Duplass), his best friend (Emily Blunt) and her sister (Rosemarie DeWitt), with plans to release it this summer. So the movie, directed by a Sundance favorite, Lynn Shelton (Humpday), was not in competition here. But Ms. Shelton nonetheless felt it was important to show it.

title: The iPhone Economy
description: Apples iPhone is a model of American ingenuity, but most of its components are manufactured somewhere else. The decline of manufacturing led to the loss of other kinds of jobs.

title: The Energy of New York Still Seduces Jackson
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Every time Phil Jackson thinks the winter of his career is finally here, he awakens to find it is Indian summer and someone is luring him back to coaching. Elusive as Jackson may be at 66, the hunt continues. With 11 N.B.A. titles, he will not reach the end without saying no to at least a few more teams.

title: Dempsey on a Roll
description: If this keeps up someone might mistake Clint Dempsey for a prolific Brazilian goal-scorer.

title: Trying to Appeal to U.S. Under-10 Generation by Shrinking the Games Scale
description: At the Australian Open, the news looked grim again for American tennis. For the first time since 1973, no American man reached the fourth round there, and entering the tournaments second week, Serena Williams is the only American left in the singles draws.

title: U.S. Men vs. Venezuela
description: Most of Jurgen Klinsmanns first-choice players have games in Europe this weekend, so he will run out the best of his B and C list on Saturday night for a friendly against Venezuela in Glendale, Ariz. (8:09 p.m. | Updated With Lineups, Below)

title: Ravens for the Ages, Running Out of Time
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  If he listened closely, Cory Redding could hear the men laughing. The sounds, deep and resonant, were coming from around the corner, in the Baltimore Ravens training room, where Redding found Ray Lewis on one table and Ed Reed on another, cracking jokes and poking fun at each other. When Lewis offered advice to a younger teammate, Reed interrupted, pleading not to believe him: He told me that, too, and it didnt work.

title: Reality Bites and the Perils of Being a Generations Touchstone
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The 20-something hipsters partying on Main Street here make us feel old enough. Does Reality Bites really need to be a Sundance rediscovered in the archive selection?

title: South Carolina Primary Overview and Forecast
description: Just days ago, Mitt Romney appeared to be on a glide path to the Republican nomination. Coming off a big victory in New Hampshire and an apparent win in Iowa, he had just received the endorsement of Jon M. Huntsman Jr., and had as much as a 23-point lead in some national polls of Republican voters. He also led in South Carolina polls, sometimes by double digits, and attacks by Republican rivals on Mr. Romneys tenure at Bain Capital did not appear to be harming him.

title: More Than 100 Killed by a Radical Group in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  More than 100 people have been killed in a series of attacks in northern Nigerias largest city, officials said Saturday, in what appears to be the deadliest strike yet by a radical Islamist group.

title: A Year Later, Concussions Keep Savard Off the Ice
description: BOSTON  Marc Savard, the star Bruins forward, said Saturday that he still has headaches and short-term memory loss a year after his last concussion.

title: Ousted Leader Is Thwarted in a Return to Madagascar
description: JOHANNESBURG  A commercial airliner carrying the ousted president of Madagascar back to that countrys capital was turned around midflight, after government officials abruptly closed the nations airspace on Saturday, apparently to prevent the flight from landing.

title: Q. & A. With Manchester Uniteds Alex Ferguson
description: Alex Ferguson, marking his 25th season as Manchester Uniteds manager, turned 70 on Dec. 31. A former player, he began coaching in 1974 with East Stirlingshire in Scotland, which gave him 2,000 (about $3,100) to acquire five players. His 1999 United team won three titles, sweeping championships in Englands Premier League, F.A. Cup and the Champions League. Fox will televise Uniteds game against Arsenal at 11 a.m. Eastern on Sunday, the first live Premier League match on that network. In an interview with Claire Bloomfield for the British online magazine Sabotage Times , Ferguson recently reflected on how the game, and his job, had changed over the years.

title: Q. & A. With Manchester Uniteds Alex Ferguson
description: Alex Ferguson, marking his 25th season as Manchester Uniteds manager, turned 70 on Dec. 31. A former player, he began coaching in 1974 with East Stirlingshire in Scotland, which gave him 2,000 (about $3,100) to acquire five players. His 1999 United team won three titles, sweeping championships in Englands Premier League, F.A. Cup and the Champions League. Fox will televise Uniteds game against Arsenal at 11 a.m. Eastern on Sunday, the first live Premier League match on that network. In Claire Bloomfield for the British online magazine Sabotage Times, Ferguson recently reflected on how the game, and his job, had changed over the years. Read the interview here.

title: New Generation of 49ers Success
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last weekend at Candlestick Park, it felt the way it used to feel when Montana and Young and Rice were stitched onto jerseys, when the 49ers boasted a franchise as successful as any in sports.

title: Needed: More Political Dimensions
description: One dimension  left to right  doesnt suffice to deal with todays political reality.

title: I Disclose ... Nothing
description: IN New York and a growing number of American cities, diners are encountering sanitary grades in restaurants windows  A, B or C. That system is an example of helpful disclosure, researchers say: information that is simple and comprehensible, important to recipients and easily acted upon. I recently chose between outwardly identical Japanese noodle shops on East Ninth Street in Manhattan based on the system, walking into the A rather than the B.

title: Target for the Next Winter Classic: 104,174
description: Even going into its sixth year, the N.H.L.s Winter Classic retains the capacity to delight and astonish, as evidenced by last weeks reports that the game next Jan. 1 will be played at Michigan Stadium in Ann Arbor and will feature the Detroit Red Wings and the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Santorum Says He Will Remain in Race Through Florida
description: CHAPIN, S.C.  Rick Santorum said he would be pleased with a third-place finish in South Carolina Saturday but vowed to stay in the presidential race through the Florida primary no matter what.

title: In Showdown, Penalty by Bruins Leads to Injury and Victory for Rangers
description: BOSTON  It was a showdown of two of the N.H.L.s best teams this season, a first meeting between voracious opponents who play a similarly relentless style. And when it was over Saturday afternoon, only 3.6 seconds from the end of overtime, the Rangers stood alone, victorious.

title: Japanese Struggle to Protect Their Food Supply
description: ONAMI, Japan  In the fall, as this valleys rice paddies ripened into a carpet of gold, inspectors came to check for radioactive contamination.

title: The Most Important Job in America
description: My Sunday column returns to education, and the importance of teaching as a way to improve education outcomes. I think education is, in the long run, the most important challenge America faces and the one where were in greatest difficulties. If we want to maintain economic competitiveness and chip away at poverty, we simply have to improve high school graduation rates and college attendance  and that in turn will depend on an overhaul of the entire education system, starting with early childhood education.

title: Yemen Legislators Approve Immunity for the President
description: Yemens Parliament approved immunity on Saturday to free President Ali Abdullah Saleh from prosecution, following through on a requirement in a deal for him to give up power. The lawmakers extended the legislation to grant immunity for politically motivated crimes committed by all officials working under Mr. Saleh, according to the state-run Saba news agency.

title: Q. and A. With Tom Seaver
description: The Mets will be honored on the franchises 50th anniversary at the Baseball Assistance Teams annual fund-raising dinner Tuesday in Manhattan. B.A.T. helps former players and baseball employees who have fallen on hard times.

title: NASA Searches for Loot That Traveled From Space to Another Void
description: HOUSTON  West Virginia lost one, until it turned up one June day on a bookshelf in the basement of a retired dentist. New York has one in a vault at a museum in Albany, but another one given to the state for safekeeping was not kept very safe, because it appears to be missing, though the attorney generals office has started looking into the case.

title: Cleaning Up the Old West the Modern Way
description: TOMBSTONE, Ariz.  It is fair to say that well before the Earp brothers shot three cowboys in a lot behind the O.K. Corral, this city had a trash problem. Mule and horse droppings were everywhere. The stench of leather being tanned, charcoal burning and ore being dug out of the earth burned the nostrils. Garbage piled high in the muddy streets.

title: Karzai Honors Slain Officials in Speech
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a somber but dramatic flourish, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Saturday used a speech during the annual opening of Parliament to recite an honor roll of 49 senior government officials and elders slain over the past year.

title: In a Romney Believer, Private Equitys Risks and Rewards
description: IT was, the gossip pages would later report, the talk of the Hamptons  a midsummer nights bacchanal in the playground of the 1 percent.

title: Hazard Insurance With Its Own Perils
description: ONE of the richest and most secretive sources of profit in the mortgage business is coming under scrutiny.

title: In Syrian City, a Calm That Few Expect to Last
description: ZABADANI, Syria  This small city, jutting from the side of a rocky mountain and known for fruit trees and summer tourists, has recently become famous as something else: a surprise stronghold for President Bashar al-Assads opponents, who, for the moment at least, seem to have wrested most of Zabadani from the states control.

title: A Math Study Provides Hints About the Games Gender Gap
description: The findings of a new study about mathematics may explain why there are so few women among the chess elite. It concluded that cultural factors, not biological ones, are the reasons why boys outperform girls in math.

title: Ensuring That Ideas Are Employee-Owned
description: This interview with  Katherine Hays, chief executive of GenArts, a visual effects technology company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Letters: Paying With Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Records Need to Be Portable, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Showtime at the Apollo
description: FOR eight seconds, we saw the president we had craved for three years: cool, joyous, funny, connected.

title: 2008 South Carolina Primary Benchmarks
description: As results stream in from South Carolina tonight, here are some helpful maps  courtesy of Matthew Bloch, a New York Times graphics editor  to keep track of how the candidates county-by-county vote shares compare with 2008.

title: What to Watch in South Carolina
description: As we wait for the polls to close at 7 p.m., heres what to watch in South Carolina, and what the first-in-the-South primary might tell us about the races to come.

title: American Voters: Still Up for Grabs
description: A Washington Post-ABC News poll released on Friday found that two-thirds of Americans would consider voting for a third-party presidential candidate, while 48 percent definitely wanted a third party in the race. Now what does that tell you? It tells you that with the campaign about to go into full swing, as the president delivers his State of the Union address next week, voters are still casting about for a leader with a winning message. I can save both parties a lot of money. I am one of those voters, and I can tell you exactly for whom I want to vote  and I dont think Im alone.

title: A Better Tax System (Assembly Instructions Included)
description: ITS that time again. Start filing all those W-2s, 1099s and scraps of paper youll need for your annual tax return. No doubt, this isnt your favorite activity. At some point, you may ask yourself whether theres a better way.

title: Hamas Says That Its Political Leader Does Not Plan to Seek Re-election
description: GAZA  The Palestinian militant group Hamas announced Saturday that its political leader, Khaled Meshal, would not seek re-election, opening the door to a possible leadership contest and adding to the uncertainty enveloping Hamas at a time of regional turmoil.

title: Trying to Nudge Drowsy Drivers
description: A DRIVERLESS car is not yet ready for the market. But in the meantime, automakers are continuing to market some components of one. The Ford Motor Company announced last month that it would offer lane-keeping technology as an option for its 2013 Ford Fusion and Ford Explorer. The price has not yet been set.

title: Deep Conflict Looms Over Billion-Dollar BART Extension to Livermore
description: A battle is brewing between top Bay Area Rapid Transit leaders over a billion-dollar rail extension to Livermore.

title: From One Tragedy, Tools to Fight the Next
description: WHEN the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck northern Japan last March, the home of Shoji Tanaka, more than 200 miles south of the quakes epicenter, was spared any major damage. But he worked as a volunteer in the disaster zone, supplying clothing and helping with clean-up, and said he was appalled by the horrifying damage.

title: The Money Traps in U.S. Health Care
description: Why does an appendectomy in Germany cost roughly a quarter what it costs in the United States? Or an M.R.I. scan cost less than a third as much, on average, in Canada?

title: The Other Final Frontier
description: Los Angeles

title: Hungary, Misunderstood?
description: My Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele has another post about Hungarian affairs, below the fold. Incidentally, shes going to Budapest this coming week; shell be giving some public lectures and meeting with a number of people. Wish her luck.

title: Keeping Them Honest
description: AS election season rhetoric heats up, so does the demand for aggressive examination of candidates claims.

title: Restaurant Bill Shock? Some Readers Say Au Contraire
description: AFTER every episode of the Haggler, it is a safe bet that a handful of readers will write to say that the Haggler is a patsy and a twit. Or words to that effect. The gist of these e-mails is that the wrong party  an aggrieved consumer, in most instances  has prevailed. The Haggler, it is argued, failed to appreciate the companys side of a dispute, and the consumer should have known better, or behaved differently, or merely had the decency to shut up.

title: A Clash of Media Worlds (and Generations)
description: BACK in high school they always told us that brains prevail  that cool gets you only so far.

title: Why World War I Resonates
description: IN France I live near a little village called Sadillac. Its no more than a cluster of houses, an old chateau, a church and a graveyard surrounded by a few farms and vineyards. The village probably hasnt changed much since the French Revolution; its population hovers around 100. By the graveyard is a simple obelisk with the names of the 30 or so young men from Sadillac who died in the First World War, 1914-18. Its almost impossible to imagine the effect on this tiny community of these fatalities over four years. Every year on Nov. 11 at 11 a.m.  the hour and the day of the 1918 armistice  villagers gather to participate in a short memorial service around the obelisk.

title: City Grazing
description: The 60 goats living in the rail yard near Pier 96 at the Port of San Francisco contribute to the city of San Francisco in their own way, clearing brush as fire prevention and offering a green alternative to toxic herbicides. Perched on the edge of Bayview-Hunters Point, an industrial area, these hard workers avoid the busy roads and  incredibly  return home when called.

title: Why Credit Downgrades Can Be Poor Predictors
description: THOUGH Wall Street is worried that the European debt crisis will worsen, the stock market barely budged when Standard & Poors downgraded the credit ratings of several euro zone nations  in the process stripping France, Austria and the euro zones primary rescue fund of their AAA standing.

title: What We Give Up for Health Care
description: WHEN it comes to health care, most liberals are committed above all to ensuring that every American has insurance. In their view, the greatest achievement of the health care reform act passed under President Obama is to finally erase the moral stain of the United States being the only major developed country without universal coverage. But we also hold the questionable distinction of having the worlds most expensive health care system  what about cost control? For many liberals, that just sounds like a cover for heartless conservatives who care only about cutting benefits and not about helping people in need.

title: Charges Against Sheriff Present a Political Twist
description: People following Venezuelas news Web site Noticias24 Tuesday were treated to a plot that might have been lifted from one of the popular Venezuelan soap operas featuring Eliana Lopez.

title: The Power of Mentoring
description: I WAS born in Lowell, Mass., where my father, a child of Armenian immigrants, was a dentist. He went to dental school on the G.I. Bill and later met my mother when she was working as a dental hygienist.

title: As Passion Increases for N.F.C. Championship Game, Stadium Officials Are Alert
description: As thousands of passionate fans descend upon San Francisco for the 49ers National Football Conference championship showdown with the Giants on Sunday, officials are touting a widely ignored text-messaging service as a solution to bad fan behavior.

title: Her Key to Efficiency: Arrive Late, Leave Early
description: A COUPLE of years ago, a well-intentioned friend, hearing me describe the horrors of my commute in Paris, said I should decide when I wanted to see my son each day: in the morning or at night, but not both.

title: Islamists Win 70% of Seats in the Egyptian Parliament
description: CAIRO  Egyptian authorities confirmed Saturday that a political coalition dominated by the Muslim Brotherhood, the 84-year-old group that virtually invented political Islam, had won about 47 percent of the seats in the first Parliament elected since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. An alliance of ultraconservative Islamists won the next largest share of seats, about 25 percent.

title: Lessons From the South Carolina Exit Polls
description: 9:28 p.m. | Updated Heres what were learning about the South Carolina primary electorate from exit polls conducted by Edison Research. Graphic: How Different Groups VotedVoters Focused on the Economy Back Gingrich

title: High Heating Oil Costs Hurt More in Northeast
description: Since 2003, even as heating oil use, heavily concentrated in the Northeast, has declined, its price has risen sharply above gas, a gap that is expected to continue widening.

title: Live Coverage of the South Carolina Primary
description: Welcome to FiveThirtyEights live blog of the South Carolina primary. Polls have closed, and well be bringing you data-driven observations as the results take shape.

title: A Smart Power Grid Begins With a Promise for the Future
description: Substation No. 505 in Oak Park, with its nondescript cluster of bulky transformers and web of power lines, seems an unlikely place for Commonwealth Edison to start the $2.6 billion smart grid it says will prepare the regions antiquated power system for the digital age.

title: Sunday: Snow Whites Employment Agency
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  At this rate, Snow White is never going to make her employment agency take off.

title: As Price of Oil Soars, Users Shiver and Cross Their Fingers
description: NORTH BROOKFIELD, Mass.  When David Harris built his 2,000-square-foot hilltop home nine years ago, he wanted to put in natural gas, but the utility wouldnt run a line to his house. Like many people here, he was stuck using heating oil.

title: Making Longer School Day Happen May Have a Budget-Busting Price Tag
description: Six months after barely closing a $712 million deficit, Chicago Public Schools officials have spent nearly $10 million that has not yet been budgeted in their aggressive push to lengthen the school day.

title: Little Red (Litigious) Shoes
description: CAN you trademark the color red?

title: Maybe a Lot More Than a Mischievous Kid Type
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: The Corner of 53rd Street and 5th Avenue
description: The New York street corner on Jan. 19, 2012.

title: A Forced Prison Haircut Brings Up Questions About Freedom of Religion
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 22
description: To say that it has been an eventful week in the Republican presidential race seems like an understatement.

title: Saudi Women Shatter the Lingerie Ceiling
description: A SOCIAL revolution began in Saudi Arabia this month, and it has little if anything to do with the Arab Spring. Women are going to work in lingerie shops.

title: Back to the Hood for Men at the Paris Shows
description: The opening suits at Hermes on Saturday night, in a blend of wool and cotton gabardine, had a hint of shine that designers like this season.

title: Austin Brothers Fill Idiosyncratic Niche at Sundance
description: The classic Sundance Film Festival story goes something like this: A gifted young filmmaker  say Quentin Tarantino or Kevin Smith  maxes out his credit cards and pours everything into a debut feature. The film is introduced at the festival, in Park City, Utah, where its embraced as a bold leap forward for American cinema. Agents and distributors come calling, helping to propel the director into a lucrative Hollywood career and a considerably bigger budget for a second feature film.

title: Latest Questionable Hit Takes Out Rangers Defenseman
description: 3:20 p.m. Sunday | Updated  Andrew Ference has been suspended three games for the hit on Ryan McDonagh.

title: Some of the People All of the Time, Avidly
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: High Winds Delay Humana Challenge
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  In his first competitive round since 1995, former President Bill Clinton broke 70, but only with a huge assist from Mother Nature. Clinton had completed nine holes at the Palmer course at PGA West when play at the Humana Challenge on Saturday was suspended because of high winds that toppled trees, turned portable toilets into projectiles and caused a giant scoreboard to take a dive into the lake along the 18th green at the Palmer course.

title: Texas State University, a Step Closer to the Top Tier, Keeps a Focus on the Future
description: The view of the Texas State University campus from its presidents 10th-floor office windows in San Marcos may be the same as it was last week, but the institution has fundamentally changed.

title: Chvez Gets Bluster Back and Reclaims the Spotlight
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  After a year shadowed by his cancer treatment, in which he appeared weakened and his strident voice was muted, Hugo Chvez, the colorful and obstreperous Venezuelan president who has made a habit of defying and taunting the United States, has found his swagger again.

title: Gingrich Wins South Carolina Primary, Upending G.O.P. Race
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Surprising his rivals and scrambling the Republican race for the presidency, Newt Gingrich won the pivotal South Carolina primary Saturday, just 10 days after a distant finish in New Hampshire left the impression that his candidacy was all but dead.

title: Krieger Has Torn Ligaments in Knee; Likely Out for Olympics
description: United States defender Ali Krieger tore ligaments in her right knee in the Americans 14-0 win over the Dominican Republic on Friday night, an injury that will most likely keep her from playing in this summers London Olympics if the Americans qualify.

title: The Neediest Cases | Mailbox
description: Thousands of readers sent in donations to the centennial fund-raising campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The following are some responses that came by mail and via the Web.

title: Donors Offer Money, Time and Encouragement
description: Natalie Jenner has a deal with herself.

title: Live Blog: South Carolina Primary
description: Ten days ago, Mitt Romney barreled out of New Hampshire as the winner of the first two presidential contests hoping that a third victory in Saturdays South Carolina primary would essentially seal his bid for the nomination.

title: Paternos Condition Is Listed as Serious
description: Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, was said to be in serious condition Saturday night after experiencing health complications while battling lung cancer.

title: Lobbyist Helps a Project He Financed in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Soon after he retired last year as one of the leading liberals in Congress, former Representative William D. Delahunt of Massachusetts started his own lobbying firm with an office on the 16th floor of a Boston skyscraper. One of his first clients was a small coastal town that has agreed to pay him $15,000 a month for help in developing a wind energy project.

title: In Texas, Rick Perry Still Holds the Reins
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry was back in town on Friday, the day after announcing in South Carolina that he was pulling out of the Republican presidential race.

title: From a Small Town, Big Accomplishments
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  You wont find many PGA Tour players who come from a small mountain town, miles removed from the nearest golf course, as the Idyllwild, Calif., native Brendan Steele did. His story is unusual, but hell tell you that among the kids he grew up with, he isnt even the one with the most impressive rise to a professional summit.

title: Robert Nelson, Experimental Filmmaker, Dies at 81
description: Robert Nelson, whose sprightly, arch experimental films brought spontaneity, teasing and wit to the often deadly serious arena of avant-garde moviemaking, died on Jan. 9 at his home in Laytonville, Calif. He was 81.

title: Romney Congratulates Gingrich but Slams Attacks on Free Enterprise
description: Mitt Romney offered his congratulations to Newt Gingrich after the South Carolina primary, but he also implicitly criticized his rivals legislative experience.

title: Santorum, in Third, Hails Romneys Struggle
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  CHARLESTON, S.C.  Rick Santorum entered a half-filled gymnasium at the Citadel at 8:36 p.m. A chanting crowd of about 30 people stood behind him and perhaps 100 amassed in front of him.

title: Many Voters Moved to Gingrich With Days, or Moments, Left
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney came within minutes of bumping into each other at Tommys Country Ham House here on Saturday morning.

title: Pilar Montero, Bar Owner and Link to a Seafaring Past, Dies at 90
description: Pilar Montero spent most of her life in the little bar she owned near the waterfront in Brooklyn with her husband, or around the corner in the apartment where they reared their children. But Mrs. Montero saw the world.

title: Exit Poll Tells Story Behind Gingrich Win
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Concerns about the economy, the desire to defeat President Obama and Newt Gingrichs performance in the recent debates helped voters in the South Carolina Republican primary make their decisions.

title: Romney Gives Concession Speech in S.C.
description: Mitt Romney congratulates Newt Gingrich on his South Carolina primary win and says that the Republican party can't be run by someone who has never run a business or a state.

title: Chefs, Butlers, Marble Baths: Hospitals Vie for the Affluent
description: The feverish patient had spent hours in a crowded emergency room. When she opened her eyes in her Manhattan hospital room last winter, she recalled later, she wondered if she could be hallucinating: This is like the Four Seasons  where am I?

title: Paul Likes His Progress
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Representative Ron Paul, who appears to be on his way to his weakest showing in three nominating contests, told supporters in South Carolina on Saturday night, This is the beginning of a long, hard slog.

title: How to Keep the Dear Leader Well Preserved
description: PARIS  Kim Jong-il has been dead for just over a month, and the embalmers in Pyongyang are reportedly at their work  draining blood, scooping out internal organs, removing the brain and preserving the genitals. Even in death, Mr. Kims remarkable bouffant hairdo will remain intact.

title: Fresh Doubts About Republican Contest
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  For Mitt Romney, the South Carolina primary was not just a defeat, though it was most emphatically that. It was also where his campaign confronted the prospect it had most hoped to avoid: a dominant, surging and energized rival.

title: Santorum Gives Concession Speech in S.C.
description: Rick Santorum says three states, three winners, what a great country.

title: Clinton Plays to Crowd at PGA Tournament
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  Seventeen years after his first PGA Tour appearance in the desert, former President Bill Clinton returned Saturday for the third round of the Humana Challenge and was in fine form, at least sartorially. As Clinton stood on the first tee box at the Palmer Private course at PGA West, a fan in the stands shouted, Those are gorgeous shoes, Mr. President.

title: Corrections: January 22
description: NEW YORK

title: The Fog of War
description: As the morning fog of Jan. 19, 1862, gave way to the haze of musket and cannon smoke around Logans Crossroads, Ky., Confederate Gen. Felix Zollicoffer gingerly approached a regiment of Kentuckians. After imploring the Kentuckians not to shoot one of their own in the confusion of battle, one of the men  perhaps the units leader, Col. Speed S. Fry of nearby Danville  identified Zollicoffer, a Tennessean, as an enemy commander. There was a hail of lead and the white-coated Zollicoffer lay dying on the battlefield. He was the first Confederate commander to die in battle in the Western Theater, but far from the last.

title: Ron Paul Gives Concession Speech in S.C.
description: Ron Paul says that he realized you promote causes by winning elections and delegates so he will pursue more delegates.

title: Gingrich Has Kind Words for Rivals and Venom for Elites
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Newt Gingrich, whose campaign was twice left for dead and came back to win a landslide victory in South Carolina, used his victory speech Saturday night before a raucous crowd of hundreds to attack the elites in New York and Washington, whom he identified as President Obama and the news media.

title: South Carolinas Divisive Message
description: Since it was first held 32 years ago, the South Carolina Republican primary has been won by the partys most electable candidate, the one backed by the Republican establishment and invariably the winner of the nomination. On Saturday, the state veered in an extreme direction, and the outcome spoke poorly for a party that allowed itself to be manipulated by the lowest form of campaigning.

title: Gingrich Gives Victory Speech in S.C.
description: Newt Gingrich praised his competitors saying Rick Santorum showed enormous courage, Ron Paul's critiques about the Federal Reserve are correct and Mitt Romney "is a good example of America."

title: Video of Candidates Speeches From South Carolina
description: The candidates gave their speeches after Newt Gingrich was declared the winner in South Carolina.

title: Santorum, Optimistic, Plans Effort Nationwide
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Despite the cloud cast over Rick Santorums campaign by his third-place showing in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, his aides said he was pressing on to Florida on Sunday while also pursuing a broad national campaign strategy.

title: Braun Takes M.V.P. Amid Challenges
description: A murmur of expectation bubbled through the ballroom at the Hilton Hotel in Midtown Manhattan as it became clear Ryan Braun would soon be approaching the podium.

title: Lottery Numbers
Anthony and Knicks Are Left to Second-Guess
description: This was not about Carmelo Anthony, or grudges or homecomings or controversial trades, or so the participants claimed in the days and hours before the Knicks and the Denver Nuggets finally met again.

title: More Than 20 Horses Killed in New Jersey Barn Fire
description: More than 20 horses were killed in Lafayette Township, N.J., when a predawn fire engulfed the barn they were stabled in on Saturday, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: The Scene in South Carolina
description: Newt Gingrichs victory in the states Republican primary has Mitt Romney scrambling and third-place Rick Santorum pledging to continue the fight.

title: A Long-Awaited Win for Uganda
description: After being unable to take part in the Little League World Series, the Rev. John Foundation team from Kampala, Uganda, finally got to play against Canada in the Pearl of Africa series.

title: Anne Dean and Peter Zaitzeff
description: Anne ODonnell Dean, a daughter of Mary Hoskinson-Dean and Robert Dean of Redding, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Peter Zane Zaitzeff, a son of Amine Zaitzeff and Roger M. Zaitzeff, both of New York. Richard J. Sullivan, a United States District judge for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Museum of the City of New York in Manhattan.

title: Emily Rover and Charles Grace III
description: Emily Christine Rover and Charles Brown Grace III were married Saturday evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Mia Wilson, Andrue Kahn
description: Mia Angelina Wilson and Andrue Jacob Kahn are to be married Sunday at Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Lisa Rubin is to perform the ceremony.

title: Emily Stamell, Eric Ruiz
description: Dr. Emily Frank Stamell, a daughter of Susan B. Stamell and Jared B. Stamell of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Eric Litman Ruiz, a son of Stacey Litman Ruiz and Dr. Jorge R. Ruiz Jr. of Pinecrest, Fla. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated with Cantor Robert P. Abelson participating at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Briana Sullivan and Alexander Radetsky
description: Briana Bancroft Sullivan and Alexander Radetsky were married Saturday at the Basilica of St. Patricks Old Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Donald Sakano, the cathedrals pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Caitlin Loomis and David Stitelman
description: Dr. Caitlin Loomis and Dr. David Hugo Stitelman were married Saturday afternoon at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Joan T. Osgood, the senior associate pastor of Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: Ardith Spence, John McGinnis
description: Ardith Anne Spence and John Oldham McGinnis were married Saturday at the Chapel of the Reformed Faith at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. Michael L. Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Jubilance for Gingrich Team in South Carolina
description: After Newt Gingrichs victory, the campaigns of Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum assessed their positions and moved on.

title: How Do You Say Mormon in French?
description: PARIS  Republican primary voters in South Carolina, many of whom are Evangelical Christian conservatives, made their discomfort with Mitt Romneys Mormonism plain on Saturday by handing Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and a conservative Christian favorite, a resounding victory.

title: A Grand Canyon Cabin Gets New Life, and Guests
description: The oldest building on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon is the national parks newest overnight accommodation.

title: Last-Minute Goal and Glimpse of Future Leave Klinsmann Smiling
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  With the top tier of talent of the United States mens national team still competing in Europe, the lineup fielded on Saturday by the Americans in their first international action of 2012 will not be the one they use in June when the team begins qualifying for the 2014 World Cup.

title: The Artist Wins Producers Guild Award
description: The Artist has made its way to pole position in the awards race. The black-and-white largely silent film picked up the top prize, best feature, from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its winners on Saturday night in Los Angeles.

title: The Caucus | A Race Upended
description: Jeff Zeleny reports from South Carolina on the strong victory of Newt Gingrich and steps ahead as the race moves to Florida and beyond.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Venezuela
description: The United States national team defeated Venezuela, 1-0, on Saturday night on a dramatic stoppage-time header by Ricardo Clark. Jurgen Klinsmann now has his first winning streak as U.S. coach, and the team can head to Panama with a bit of confidence and a sense of satisfaction.

title: In India, Oprah Woos Crowd
description: Some foreigners come to India and make observations about the country that many Indians find unbearable. Not Oprah Winfrey.

title: With Giants-49ers, Who Wins With the Weather?
description: The Fifth Down will provide live blogs of both the Ravens-Patriots and Giants-49ers games. Join us.

title: A Giants Postseason Specialty: Using Their Heads
description: For the Giants, the blue helmet with the red center stripe isnt just part of the uniform. Having figured into four of the Giants most memorable plays over the past 25 years, its also part of the franchises lore.

title: Did Gingrichs Win Break the Paradigm?
description: During the Republican nominating contest, competing paradigms have arisen for how to interpret the evidence from polls, voting results and other tangible indicators of success or failure. The paradigms present profoundly different conclusions about the most likely outcome.

title: Romney to Release Tax Returns on Tuesday
description: 10:32 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney said Sunday morning that he would release his 2010 tax returns on Tuesday, bowing to that mounting pressure that might have helped lead to his defeat in the South Carolina primary on Saturday.

title: Bloombergs Deferred Compensation (of 93 Cents)
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said last week that he paid the highest tax rate on his personal income, but his boast (or lament) does not exactly apply to his salary from the city.

title: Hotels Band to Offer Their Own Search Site
description: Six of the worlds largest hotel companies have collaborated to create a Web site that allows travelers to search listings and then book rooms directly on hotel sites, effectively cutting out middlemen like Expedia.

title: A Win in Melbourne for Top-Ranked Wozniacki
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Caroline Wozniacki, the worlds top-ranked womens tennis player, kept alive her hopes of retaining that title Sunday night with a 6-0, 7-5 win over a former No. 1 seed, Jelena Jankovic, at the fourth round of the Australian Open.

title: Paris Top 5 | Yves Saint Laurent
description: The Justify My Love remix (from Madonnas steamy SEX days, of course) that ricocheted off the marble halls of the Sorbonne set the already sensual mood for Stefano Pilatis great, tight YSL collection. Glossy black leather and rich, dark cashmere played cat and mouse in a collection that seemed camera ready for Helmut Newton: slick black lapels and cuffs on suits and outerwear; body-hugging shiny shirts and pants styled with motorcycle jackets. Here, a double breasted coat (what did we tell you?) with top-stitching on the shoulders and trim paired with a vest, shirt, and tie contained both the elegance and decadence that made this collection a real success.

title: Joe Paterno, the Face of Penn State
description: Under Paternos leadership, Penn State won two national championships and became a college football powerhouse.

title: Joe Paterno, Longtime Penn State Coach, Dies at 85
description: Joe Paterno, who won more games than any other major-college football coach, and who became the face of Pennsylvania State University and a symbol of integrity in collegiate athletics only to be fired during the 2011 season amid a child sexual abuse scandal that reverberated throughout the nation, died Sunday in State College, Pa. He was 85.

title: G.O.P. Turns Its Focus to Florida
description: A drastically reshaped Republican presidential campaign begins anew in Florida on Sunday as the partys establishment confronts the likelihood of an extended and bitter leadership fight and the increasing possibility that Newt Gingrich could be its nominee.

title: Turning Subway Tracks Into Ad Hoc Wishing Wells
description: Michael Shannon did it for love.

title: Notes On Deleveraging
description: The new McKinsey Global Institute report on debt and deleveraging has attracted a lot of attention, and rightly so. I have some quibbles with the way the data are presented, but theyre very useful data  and lead to some surprising conclusions.

title: Clijsters Wins Rematch of 2011 Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The reassuring news on a miserable afternoon for Li Na was that one actually can forget these moments.

title: In National Polls, a Mixed View of Gingrich
description: About a week ago, the most recent national New York Times/CBS News poll showed that Republican voters were divided in their assessment of Newt Gingrich.

title: At Jaipur Fest, Difficult Balancing Act
description: Controversy over Salman Rushdies invitation to the Jaipur Literature Festival and the public reading of his The Satanic Verses has forced organizers to walk a difficult path between championing free expression and keeping the festival safe and open, William Dalrymple, one of the festivals co-directors, said Sunday.

title: Runway in Review
description: Ann DemeulemeesterDesigner: Ann DemeulemeesterDate: Saturday, Jan. 21, Beaux-Arts de Paris  salle Melpomne  13 quai Malaquais, 6ePhotos: slide show

title: Greek Talks Hit a Snag Over Rates
description: LONDON  Talks between Greece and its private sector creditors over restructuring its debt hit a snag over the weekend over how large an interest rate the new bonds would pay.

title: A Chat With the Writer-Director of Bachelorette
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Im warning you, Im operating on four hours of sleep, said Leslye Headland, the Kathleen Turner-voiced writer-director of Bachelorette, a lacerating comedy that will have its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival on Monday. Seriously, youre speaking to a crazy person right now.

title: Libya Protests Spur Shake-Up in Interim Government
description: Libyas post-Qaddafi transitional government faced a political crisis Sunday after protesters ransacked its offices in Benghazi, highlighting growing nationwide unease with its leadership and triggering a shake-up in which the governing councils No. 2 official resigned and several members were suspended.

title: Yemen Leader Leaves for Medical Care in New York
description: Yemens departing president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, left Yemen on Sunday and will travel to New York for medical treatment, Yemeni and American officials said.

title: Talks With Taliban a Long Way Off, American Envoy Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  No peace talks with the Taliban this week: That was the short message on Sunday from the American envoy charged with starting those negotiations.

title: Happily Up to Her Ears in Angst
description: The first song Kelly Clarkson sang for American Idol judges 10 years ago was At Last, the well-worn number popularized by Etta James that is used by bluesy performers to show their mettle. Maybe Ms. Clarkson rushed it a bit back then, smiled too much, did not quite nail the languor of the song. But she was delicate with the lyrics, and she showed off a voice that moved in all sorts of ways, without ever appearing to strain.

title: Underworld Awakening Leads at the Box Office
description: This is why Hollywood keeps churning out sequels: The fourth movie in Sonys Underworld vampire series, Underworld Awakening, was an easy No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, taking in about $25.4 million despite winter storms that kept business light in parts of the United States. Solid ticket sales for Underworld Awakening were fueled by turnout for higher-priced Imax screens. Even so, this 3-D movie will need to perform well overseas to justify its cost of about $70 million, sharply higher than the budget for Underworld: Rise of the Lycans in 2009.

title: Disruptions: Tech Valuations Defy the Restraints of Reality
description: On a recent Thursday night I stood motionless and perplexed on the dance floor of a San Francisco club. As I looked around, 300 or so people danced and darted back and forth to a free open bar while laser lights shot overhead. Cellphones glowed, like a video of luminescent jellyfish, as people snapped pictures and slung moments of the evening onto dozens of social networks.

title: China Reports a Second Bird Flu Death in Less Than a Month
description: BEIJING  A man died in southern China on Sunday from the H5N1 bird flu virus, the Health Ministry reported. It was Chinas second such death in less than a month.

title: Stravinskys Travels, Recounted in Melody
description: There has been much debate about the Russian-ness of Stravinsky, who lived and worked away from his native country for most of his life. In a program called Stravinsky Outside Russia, on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, the conductor Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra offered selections that reflected both Stravinskys Russian heritage and the aesthetics of his adopted homelands.

title: Gabrielle Giffords Says Shes Leaving the House
description: 10:49 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: Sandusky Issues Statement About Paterno
description: Reaction to the death of Joe Paterno has come from retired and current coaches, former Penn State players and even a former president of the United States. But one statement may get a little more scrutiny than the others. Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant coach under Paterno who is accused of sexually abusing young boys  accusations that roiled the Penn State community and eventually led to Paternos firing last year  released a comment through his lawyer on Paternos death:

title: Some See Two New Gilded Ages, Raising Global Tensions
description: NEW YORK  On a bitter evening in mid-January, a group of bankers and book publishers gathered on the 42nd floor of Goldman Sachss global headquarters here. The setting could not have been more New York  skyscrapers twinkled out the windows to the north and a jazz ensemble played softly in the corner. But the appetizers, reflecting the theme of the event, were an international mishmash: thumb-sized potato pancakes with sour cream and caviar, steaming Chinese dumplings, Indian samosas and Turkish kebabs.

title: Metaphors of Movement Around the Spoken Word
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Bill T. Jones has long talked about his simultaneous attraction toward narration and abstraction, and about how his desire to lay claim to both of these artistic traditions has often left him in conflict. How to tell a good yarn but not be yoked to it structurally?

title: Photos of the Moment | Raf Simons
