title: Tomic Holds His Own Against Federer in Defeat
description: Roger Federers straight-sets win over Bernard Tomic was filled with long stretches of inspired play from both players. Unlike Rafael Nadals drubbing of his countryman Feliciano Lopez, which looked like a foregone conclusion early in the first set, the Federer-Tomic match had tense moments throughout, as Federer had to play at his sublime best to beat the rapidly improving Tomic.

title: Lets Raze Javits Center (but First Finish Renovations)
description: Part of architectures appeal, at least to architects, is posterity: the notion that what they design will last. So it came as something of a shock to the architect Bruce S. Fowle this month when he learned that a building he was renovating is already on death row.

title: Coughlin Not Looking for Vindication, but Ahead to Indianapolis
description: San Francisco

title: Like Knicks Fans, Nuggets Faithful Were Once Seduced by Anthony
description: Familiarity breeds contempt.

title: Now Novices Can Try Ice Climbing in Wyoming
description: For seasoned ice climbers, the many cliffside springs and waterfalls banking the south fork of the Shoshone Rivernear Cody, Wyo.  about 50 miles east of Yellowstone National Park  have long been popular. Now novices and anyone unfamiliar with the valley can get a toehold in the ice with new guided expeditions.

title: In Middle of Winter, a Sunny Day at the Beach, and Deaths Shadow
description: When the curtain rises on Jerome Robbinss In G Major, the first of three works on the All Robbins program performed by New York City Ballet on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, the setting is simple but unmistakable. Stylized designs on the backdrop evoke sun, sea and sky. Young people gambol about in costumes resembling chic bathing wear. Were at the French Riviera, between the wars.

title: Costa Concordia May Have Had Unregistered Passengers
description: GIGLIO, Italy  As rescue workers recovered another body on Sunday from the wreck of the cruise ship Costa Concordia, bringing the death toll to 13, Italian officials offered their first explanation for the shifting numbers of missing people, saying that there may have been unregistered passengers aboard the ship.

title: Veterans and Young Guns Pay Tribute to the Cuban Father of the Mambo
description: Carlos Henriquez stood front and center with his bass throughout The Music of Cachao, Jazz at Lincoln Centers tribute to the pioneering Cuban bassist and composer Israel Cachao Lpez on Friday night at the Rose Theater. This was, as Mr. Henriquez noted with a chuckle in the concerts second half, a departure from his usual station near the back of the stage. But it made perfect sense: the tumbaos that boomed from Mr. Henriquezs bass, in patterns more or less invented by Cachao, gave the music its flexible spine  along with a strong heartbeat, steady in its syncopations.

title: New York Band, Worldly Desires
description: The 10th anniversary concert of the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra couldnt encompass all the ambitions of this remarkable New York institution, even in two generous sets on Friday night that kicked off the groups two-night appearance at Symphony Space.

title: Franois Hollande, Challenging Sarkozy, Calls for Change
description: PARIS  The Socialist Party candidate for the presidency of France, Franois Hollande, formally opened his campaign on Sunday with a passionate speech calling for change, equality and justice.

title: Murdochs Trusted Outsider Takes a Larger Role
description: Last August, as News Corporation scrambled to contain a phone-hacking scandal at its British newspaper unit, Chase Carey, the companys president and chief operating officer, proposed an idea to his boss, Rupert Murdoch: buy back $5 billion worth of stock.

title: Searching the Brain for the Roots of Fear
description: You are taking a walk in the woods  pleasant, invigorating, the sun shining through the leaves. Suddenly, a rattlesnake appears at your feet. You experience something at that moment. You freeze, your heart rate shoots up and you begin to sweat  a quick, automatic sequence of physical reactions. That reaction is fear.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: A Link to the Past Has the Rebels Runnin Again
description: LAS VEGAS

title: A Jewish Museum Shifts Identity
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The story of how the Judah L. Magnes Museum  whose collection of Judaica is the third largest in the country  became the Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life at the Bancroft Library of the University of California, Berkeley, might not seem terribly ripe with complication or implication. In recent years small private museums facing financial strain have often sought refuge by negotiating new lives within universities. Perhaps on Sunday, when the Magnes opened its doors to the public in a building it had long owned near the campus here, it was simply inaugurating another phase of its 50-year life.

title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Foreign Commander Fighting for Militants in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A senior foreign commander fighting with Shabab Islamic militants was killed in an American drone strike a few miles south of the capital over the weekend, according to Shabab officials.

title: Superfly in the Air, Corpses in the Trees
description: George Pelecanoss latest book, What It Was, sends his best stock character into an extended 40-year flashback. It begins in a Washington bar, where a song by the Dramatics gets Derek Strange to thinking about the summer of 1972. He was 26. Bell-bottoms and Afros were everywhere. Fly was an adjective, as in regal and fly in their natural hairstyles and up-to-the-minute fashions. The soundtrack from Superfly was on every jukebox not playing the soundtrack from Shaft.

title: Apple And Agglomeration
description: The big Times article on Apple manufacturing was excellent, and Ill have more to say about it when I have the time. One thing worth noting right away, however, is that the piece is in large part an essay on the economies of agglomeration (pdf, wonkish):

title: At Rye Brook Open Pairs, the Better of Two Xs
description: The Open Pairs on Jan. 13 at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., was an A/X event. That meant there were two flights: A for players with more than 5,000 master points and X for those with fewer points.

title: Good Fortune, and Penalty Kick, Help Manchester City
description: If Manchester City is to become Englands champion after 44 years of longing for that title, its followers around the world might remember Sunday as the day Lady Luck finally bestowed her full favors on the Blues.

title: A Beloved Set of Strings Goes to a Good Home
description: It is considered one of the greatest cellos in the world, a beautifully preserved product of Antonio Stradivari that was once owned by Nicol Paganini and most recently by Bernard Greenhouse, a founding member of the Beaux Arts Trio. Mr. Greenhouse played the cello for a half century, and after his death last year, his family decided to sell it, hoping it would go to a deserving musician.

title: Underground Metal and Hardcore, Set Aflame
description: All Pigs Must Die sits right where hardcore and underground metal intersect. Its Rosetta Stone might be the first LPs by Negative Approach, Discharge and Slayer, melted together. About half of the bands total stance, titles to lyrics to singing, seems inflexible, nonnegotiable.

title: The Artist Wins Producers Guild Prize
description: The Artist has made its way to pole position in the movie awards race. This black-and-white, largely silent film, starring Jean Dujardin, above, with Uggie, picked up the top prize, best feature, from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its winners on Saturday night in Los Angeles. The guild has followed the lead of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in nominating 10 films for best picture in the last two years. It has also accurately predicted the eventual best-picture Oscar winner, even in the expanded field. When it chose The Hurt Locker over the much higher-grossing Avatar in 2010, awards watchers considered it a bellwether prize. (Though the Academy may nominate anywhere from 5 to 10 films this year, the Producers Guild stuck with 10.) Steven Spielbergs Adventures of Tintin won best animated film, and Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest earned the documentary feature prize. ABCs hit Modern Family took home the first award of the night, for best TV comedy, and Downton Abbey (PBS) won for best long-form show. Boardwalk Empire (HBO) picked up best drama, beating Mad Men (AMC). The Amazing Race (CBS) won for television competition, and The Colbert Report (Comedy Central) won for talk show.

title: Footnote
description: The American Ballet Theater is to announce on Monday that Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer for the theater since 1997, will retire at the end of the 2012 Metropolitan Opera House season. His final performance is scheduled for July 7 as part of the companys production of Le Corsaire, according to a statement from the theater. Although it is not easy to step away from performing, I am gladdened by the fact that I have other invaluable opportunities to continue to contribute to the art form, Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. I am deeply grateful to everyone who has helped to shape my success as an artist and has supported me throughout the years. He became the artistic director of Royal New Zealand Ballet in September.

title: Harding
description: I gather that theyre still trying to claim that the recovery from the 1920-21 recession somehow vindicates austerity policies.

title: Marketers, Seeking Family Show, Hold Script Contest
description: FOR several years, marketers like Frito-Lay and General Motors have sponsored contests asking consumers to create television commercials, with winning spots appearing on shows including the Super Bowl. Now, a group of marketers has expanded the idea by sponsoring a contest asking consumers to create shows.

title: A Lesson in Anatomy
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Did everyone do their homework, class? Welcome to Anatomy 101, where everything is on the final but, this being Monday, the class is an easy A.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include pending home sales for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, durable goods for December, new-home sales for December and leading economic indicators for December (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

title: Drake Feels the Indie-Film Love
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Insert your own sweater joke here: Somehow the knitwear-loving rapper Drake arrived at the one place most welcoming to a cozy cardigan, during a blizzard no less, wearing just a black T-shirt, some gold chains and a parka.

title: Final: A.F.C. Championship, Patriots  23, Ravens 20
description: In a back-and-forth battle that ended in heartbreak for the Baltimore Ravens and kicker Billy Cundiff, the New England Patriots advanced to Super Bowl XLVI with a 23-20 victory on Sunday.

title: Womens Draw Has Contrasting Styles
description: The two matches in the top half of the womens draw at the Australian Open represent contrasting approaches to playing tennis. In a phrase, its offense versus defense.

title: All Robbins
description: The New York City Ballet performed works by Jerome Robbins.

title: Final: N.F.C. Championship, Giants 20, 49ers 17, OT
description: Lawrence Tynes kicked a 31-yard field goal almost eight minutes into overtime Sunday to give the Giants a 20-17 victory over the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game at Candlestick Park.

title: Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life
description: Images from the museum at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Patriots Defense Holds, and Ravens Miss a Last-Second Kick
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  For some franchises, four years is a fragment of time. For the New England Patriots, it is a millennium. Their transformation over that span has been swift and overarching. Their offense, if possible, is more capable and explosive. Their defense is not as formidable or feared. The imbalance created the perception that they were too flawed, too unreliable, to restore glory to Patriot Place.

title: Cameras May Open Up the Board Room to Hackers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One afternoon this month, a hacker took a tour of a dozen conference rooms around the globe via equipment that most every company has in those rooms; videoconferencing equipment.

title: Bird-Watchers Revel in Unusual Spike in Snowy Owl Sightings
description: HELENA, Mont.  From coast to coast across the northern United States, a striking number of snowy owls have been swooping onto shorelines and flying over fields this winter, delighting bird-watchers and stirring speculation about the cause of the spike.

title: How Esquire Survived Publishings Dark Days
description: Esquire magazine, a monument to male vitality, seemed about to keel over in 2009. Famous for laying down a much-followed literary track with an article in 1966 by Gay Talese titled Frank Sinatra Has a Cold, the magazine found itself gasping for breath and fighting for survival.

title: In Florida, Romney Seeks to Link Gingrich to Foreclosure Crisis
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla.,  Less than 24 hours after his disappointing showing in the South Carolina primary, Mitt Romney took his campaign fight to Florida, linking the mortgage foreclosure crisis here  the nations worst  to his rival, Newt Gingrich, the victor in the South Carolina contest.

title: A Mothers Love and Her Pregame Profanity Sustain a Giant in the Trenches
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  An hour before each opening kickoff, Dave Tollefson retreats to a quiet area of the Giants locker room to perform his pregame ritual: a call to his mother. She, in turn, provides support in a manner more mouthy than motherly: a loud, profanity-laced pep talk.

title: Bruins Ference Suspended for Hit on Rangers McDonagh
description: Andrew Ference of the Bruins was suspended for three games by the N.H.L. on Sunday for a check on Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh in overtime of the Rangers 3-2 victory Saturday in Boston.

title: How About Not Bombing Iran?
description: If you need more convincing of the grave risks of a preemptive bombing attack on Iran, I recommend these freshly published arguments from Colin H. Kahl, who was until recently Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for the Middle East in the Obama administration; R. Nicholas Burns, who was Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs in the George W. Bush administration; and my Times colleague Roger Cohen, who sums it up this way:

title: The Film Archivist of Legendary Football Preps for Game Day
description: When N.F.L. Films put a microphone on the Denver Broncos surprise star Tim Tebow during a game against the Chicago Bears last month, it knew that every one of its television partners would want a piece of the audio and video of the quarterback.

title: Mary C. Henderson, Author and Scholar of Theater History, Dies at 83
description: Mary C. Henderson, a scholar of the theater whose interests as a historian and curator spanned centuries and as a Tony nominator and critic were up to the minute, died on Jan. 3 at her home in Congers, N.Y. She was 83.

title: Hunger Games Book Sales Bode Well for the Film
description: Lionsgates movie adaptation of The Hunger Games does not arrive in theaters until March 23  still too far away for analysts to predict ticket revenue. But if spiking sales of the books are any indication, Lionsgates marketing efforts are whipping up a five-alarm box-office fire.

title: Edgar Kaiser Jr. Dies at 69; Owned Denver Broncos
description: Starting in 1914, Henry J. Kaiser built one of the worlds largest business empires, encompassing ships, cement, steel, aluminum and even kitchen sinks. In the 1970s his grandson Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. began methodically dismantling it  even as he built his own.

title: Line of Scrimmage Forms Over Union Bill
description: INDIANAPOLIS  This city is in full preen for its moment in the spotlight, its first Super Bowl. Everywhere, workers sprouted from cherry pickers over the weekend, hanging football banners from signposts, windows, buildings. The constant beeping of machinery backing up filled the air as an 800-foot zip line was built in a Super Bowl Village that is emerging downtown. And right outside the Statehouse, the intersection formally known as Capitol and Washington has fancy new honorary street signs  Dolphins Drive and Browns Boardwalk.

title: New Yorks Bad Bet
description: Philadelphia

title: Flora, Now in English
description: BOTANISTS long thought the tallest trees on Madagascar all belonged to only three species of the genus Canarium, but two scientists have now determined that there are actually 35 species of the genus there, of which 29 are new to science.

title: When the Drug Maker Pays the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Research Be More Freely Available?
description: To the Editor:

title: Web Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wealthy and Class War
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest-Rate Swaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Antipiracy Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Federer Heads Into 1,000th Tour Match
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  One thousand tennis matches. In a career full of major milestones, here comes another for Roger Federer, who will hit quadruple digits when he hits his first ball against Juan Martn del Potro in their Australian Open quarterfinal on Tuesday.

title: Mistaken Early Report on Paterno Roiled Web
description: A rapid succession of journalistic slip-ups on Saturday night led to the spread of false news reports of the death of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State coach, more than 12 hours before his doctors and family members said he had died.

title: A Week of Challenges and Potential for Romney
description: Mitt Romney enters Florida on Monday wounded by his political collapse in South Carolina and facing a central challenge for his candidacy: How to regain the initiative after being forced for weeks into a defensive crouch.

title: Sharing a Screen, if Not a Classroom
description: In a hushed first-grade classroom at Public School 55 in the South Bronx, Edward Muoz, a bashful 7-year-old in scuffed sneakers and a worn hoodie, was sounding out tricky words with his tutor.

title: A Day That Seemed as if It Would Never Come: Uncle Chichis Last
description: Uncle Chichi, a toy poodle whose unusual longevity led to fame and an appearance on Good Morning America, died on Tuesday after a yearlong battle with cancer. He was 26. Or 24. Or maybe 25.

title: Why Politicians Get Away With Lying
For Paterno, Lover of Classics, Tragic Flaw to a Legacy
description: Joe Paterno loved the classics. He quoted Shakespeare to his team, devoured the poems of Virgil and donated his money to help save Penn States classics department, even endowing a scholarship in the name of his high school Latin teacher, the Rev. Thomas Bermingham.

title: Dissent in the Jobs Council
description: At Disney World last week, President Obama announced new executive orders to speed up visas for foreign tourists to the United States. The measure, a priority for the travel industry, was one of several sensible recommendations made in the last year by Mr. Obamas Council on Jobs and Competitiveness, a 27-member panel of corporate executives, academics, investors and labor leaders. The White House has carried out 17 others so far.

title: Fed Begins an Effort to Remove All Doubt on What Its Doing
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, which does not like to surprise financial markets, has worked unusually hard to prepare the public for the changes to its communications policies that it plans to introduce on Wednesday.

title: After Tumultuous Events at Penn State, Death Adds to the Anguish
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  They crunched across the snow-blanketed campus Sunday to lay flowers at his statue, to gather for a candlelight vigil outside the Old Main administration building and to simply glance at his home while they walked past. Waves of students, alumni and fans were paying their respects to the man they knew as JoePa.

title: Mr. Gingrichs Deceptions
description: Newt Gingrichs victory in South Carolina turned on an almost comically broad deception, an inversion of the truth in which the insider whose personal wealth and political experience are entirely creations of Washington becomes the anti-establishment candidate. That it worked speaks poorly of voters who let themselves be manipulated by the lowest form of campaigning, appealing to their anger and prejudices.

title: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears for Stability
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Once they were heroes, cloaked justices at the vanguard of a powerful revolt against military rule in Pakistan, buoyed by pugnacious lawyers and an adoring public. But now Pakistans Supreme Court is waging a campaign of judicial activism that has pitted it against an elected civilian government, in a legal fight that many Pakistanis fear could damage their fragile democracy and open the door to a fresh military intervention.

title: The Emerging Gilded Age
description: As IHT Rendezvous kicks off a week of special coverage of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Chrystia Freeland, an IHT Page Two columnist and Reuterss global editor at large, writes about the new Gilded Age.

title: Young Strivers in Two Worlds
description: What is it like to get up at 3 every morning to leave the country to go to school? To walk for miles and wait in long lines at an international crossing, to hustle along by trolley and bus, worrying all the while about missing the 8 a.m. bell? This is the bleary-eyed world of young Mexican-Americans who live in Tijuana and go to school in Chula Vista, Calif., as described by Patricia Leigh Brown in The Times. These striving students, or transfronterizos, are not immigrants but American citizens, lawfully crossing the border to get an education.

title: Searching Through Brooklyn
description: Just as Americans visit the Old World in search of family roots, tourists are showing up at the Brooklyn Historical Society, in hopes of tracking down their grandparents neighborhood ties and old houses  brownstones in Park Slope, row houses in Bay Ridge  in the New World. As usual, Walt Whitman anticipated the future: There will come a time here in Brooklyn and all over America, when nothing will be of more interest than authentic reminiscences of the past.

title: After a Legal Setback, Commodity Traders Complaint Is to Be Heard by a Lower Court
description: Wall Streets legal challenge to a regulatory crackdown met a procedural obstacle last week, when a federal appeals court dismissed the case.

title: Ai Weiwei: Evolution of a Dissident
description: The filmmaker Alison Klayman presents an exclusive look at the Chinese dissident artist Ai Weiwei and his struggle for the freedom of expression.

title: Ai Weiwei: The Evolution of a Dissident
description: I have always believed that the story of the dissident artist Ai Weiwei is not about how censorship stifles creativity, but rather how one artist is able to work around such obstacles. Its not about the system crushing individual expression, but about the power of an individual in the face of forces greater than himself. One thing is clear  Ai Weiweis story could not be possible without the Internet. We cannot imagine an Ai Weiwei without the megaphone of blogs and Twitter, without the ability to communicate instantaneously and connect to like-minded netizens around China and the globe.

title: Bowing to Critics and Market Forces, RIMs Co-Chiefs Step Aside
description: OTTAWA  Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, who made the BlackBerry a leading business tool but then presided over its precipitous decline, said they would step down on Monday as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of Research in Motion.

title: G.O.P. Ventures Into Florida, a State Harder to Pigeonhole
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After three bruising contests that each produced different winners, the Republican nominating contest has moved to a state that is much more like the rest of America in its diversity, its multiplicity of media markets and its voter base, which is less likely to be swayed by the family values issues that played a dominant role in prior contests in Iowa and South Carolina.

title: For New England, Patchwork Becomes a Safety Net
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: Stories From Museums, Diners and the Streets
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Photo Replay: A.F.C. Championship Game
description: The New England Patriots beat the Baltimore Ravens, 23-20, to earn a Super Bowl berth.

title: Gingrich and Romney Trade Jabs as G.O.P. Race Rolls On
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney, facing a restive Republican Party and a resurgent Newt Gingrich, opened a combative new phase of the presidential campaign on Monday and warned of the prospect of an October surprise if Mr. Gingrich emerged as the partys nominee.

title: For M.T.A. and Union, Obstacles Delay a Contract
description: One week after the expiration of a labor contract between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Transport Workers Union Local 100, there is no shortage of evidence that the two sides are far apart on a new deal.

title: Rising Strife Threatens Tenuous Iraqi Stability
description: BAGHDAD  Violence and political instability have escalated across Iraq since the withdrawal of American forces, as political and sectarian factions have fought for power and influence in a struggle that, within weeks, has threatened to undo the stability that allowed the pullout in the first place.

title: More Lockouts as Companies Battle Unions
description: Americas unionized workers, buffeted by layoffs and stagnating wages, face another phenomenon that is increasingly throwing them on the defensive: lockouts.

title: Arab League Floats Ambitious New Peace Plan for Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Faced with the failure of its observer mission to curb the violence here as the stark features of a civil war emerge, the Arab League on Sunday unexpectedly floated an ambitious peace proposal that would require President Bashar al-Assad to hand over power to a deputy and start negotiations with his opponents within two weeks.

title: Flacco Outshines Brady, but Team Comes Up Short
description: FOXBOROUGH , Mass.  He outplayed Tom Brady. Even the most ardent Brady supporter would have to acknowledge that on Sunday, Joe Flacco outshone the New England Patriots star quarterback.

title: As Closed-Door Redistricting Drags On, Incumbents Edge Only Grows
description: ALBANY  Howard Leib, a 53-year-old entertainment lawyer, is considering a run for the New York State Senate this year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Under the Name of a Senate Hopeful, Blog Posts on Sex and Drugs
description: As he travels New York trying to build support for a Senate candidacy, Marc Cenedella has impressed Republican leaders with his Ivy League credentials, his success in building a business and his promise to tap his wealth in the race.

title: In Egypt, Signs of Accord Between Military Council and Islamists
description: CAIRO  Egypts first freely elected Parliament in more than 60 years sits for its first session on Monday, charged primarily with overseeing preparation of a new constitution after the ouster of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

title: Bomb-Bomb-Bomb, Bomb-Bomb-Iran?
description: O.K., Mr. President, heres the plan. Sometime in the next few months you order the Department of Defense to destroy Irans nuclear capacity. Yes, I know its an election year, and some people will say this is a cynical rally-round-the-flag move on your part, but a nuclear Iran is a problem that just wont wait.

title: Former Catcher for Red Sox Wins Case Against Merrill Lynch Adviser
description: Nearly five years after he earned his second World Series ring, Doug Mirabelli has another big win.

title: Is Our Economy Healing?
description: How goes the state of the union? Well, the state of the economy remains terrible. Three years after President Obamas inauguration and two and a half years since the official end of the recession, unemployment remains painfully high.

title: In Race to the Top, the Dirty Work Is Left to Those on the Bottom
description: Even if you think the Obama administrations signature education program, Race to the Top, will not help a single child in America learn more, you have to admire its bureaucratic magnificence.

title: Desperate in TV Fight, Some Knicks Fans Buy Tickets
description: Their new star was facing his old team. Their old favorites were returning under the lights of Madison Square Garden. Yet many Knicks partisans could not watch the game on television because of a nasty dispute between Time Warner Cable and the MSG channels, and for those fans, options were limited.

title: From Unyielding Cameraman, an Acclaimed Film
description: BILIN, West Bank  Emad Burnat was born to the land and, like generations of his family in this hilltop West Bank village, he has eked out a modest living from its rocky soil. But six years ago, at the birth of a son, he was given a video camera and turned unexpectedly into the village chronicler.

title: In Britain, Rising Outcry Over Executive Pay That Makes Peoples Blood Boil
description: LONDON  As company boards prepare to vote on the annual compensation of their senior executives, investors and the government in Britain are pushing for ways to shrink what some have called excessive pay packages.

title: For Giffords, House Comeback Is One Too Many
description: WASHINGTON  For months, Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who was shot in the head in an assassination attempt last year, signaled that returning to Congress, something she desperately longed to do, was in the realm of the possible.

title: Croatia Votes 2 to 1 to Join European Union
description: BRUSSELS  Croats voted by a two-to-one margin on Sunday to join the European Union, signaling that the bloc retains its allure despite the debt crisis engulfing the euro currency that many of its members use.

title: Tablet and E-Reader Sales Soar
description: There was no must-have toy of Christmas 2011  for youngsters, anyway.

title: Over Turkish Protests, French Lawmakers to Vote on Bill Penalizing Genocide Denial
description: PARIS  The French Senate is scheduled to vote on Monday on a law that would penalize those who deny genocide, taking another step along a path that has already damaged Frances relations with Turkey.

title: Doubt Cast on Threat That Deterred Rushdie
description: JAIPUR, India  At an old Mughal palace accommodating what organizers called the greatest literary show on earth, the headliners on Sunday included Oprah Winfrey, Deepak Chopra and Tom Stoppard. But the absence of another star, Salman Rushdie, continued to overshadow the event.

title: Many Freed Burmese Werent Jailed for Politics
description: WASHINGTON  Fewer than half of the 651 prisoners the Myanmar government announced it was releasing 10 days ago were political prisoners, according to two human rights groups that have compiled lists of those released. Petty criminals, whose sentences are being commuted, were among the rest.

title: Kvitova Beats Ivanovic in Battle of Fraying Nerves
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Petra Kvitova, the reigning Wimbledon womens champion, shook off a case of nerves to eliminate Ana Ivanovic, whose own nerves betrayed her on the verge of tying the match in the fourth round of the Australian Open on Monday.

title: In Guatemala, Former Dictator Is Told to Appear in Court
description: MEXICO CITY  A Guatemalan judge has ordered a former military dictator, Efran Ros Montt, to appear in court on Thursday, the first step in a process that could lead to his being tried on genocide charges and to a reopening of the darkest chapter in Guatemalas brutal 36-year civil war.

title: Gingrich Bets on Attack Mode Against News Media
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  They were Newt Gingrichs other adversaries in the South Carolina primary and they helped define his surge to victory as much as Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum and Ron Paul did.

title: Field Goal by Tynes in Overtime Sets Up a Rematch in the Super Bowl
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The ball skittered sideways, shooting out of the punt returners grasp, bouncing into Giants lore.

title: Thrse Delpech, French Political Adviser, Dies at 63
description: PARIS  Thrse Delpech, one of Frances leading foreign policy analysts and intellectual historians, died on Wednesday at her apartment in Paris. She was 63.

title: Manning Delivers Again, Earning Hug and Praise From Brother
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the Giants went through their various transformations this season  from a running team to a passing team, from a weak defense to a stout one  the constant was always Eli Manning in the fourth quarter. It did not matter what had happened to the Giants early in the game; a heavy dose of Manning late was the cure for all that ailed them.

title: Corrections: January 23
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: What the Left Gets Right
description: Todays column is a counterpart to last weeks, in which some thoughtful liberals responded to the question, What does the right get right?

title: Kelly of Oregon Emerges as Buccaneers Top Candidate, and Implications Abound
description: Oregon Coach Chip Kelly has emerged as the front-runner to become the next head coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, a move that could cause a seismic shake-up in college football.

title: Joining His Father, but Carving Out His Own Path
description: When Francis Stephen arrived in the United States from Bangladesh two years ago, his father already had a career plan in mind for him, he said.

title: Word of the Day | mutinous
description: mutinous \my-t-ns, myt-ns\ adjective

title: For Indian Cricket Team, Failure Takes Many Forms
description: The Indian cricket team is, increasingly driving its fans back home to hit the off button, as defeat follows defeat on its overseas tours, Huw Richards wrote in the International Herald Tribune.

title: In a City Fighting Blight, Ghost Signs as Portals to a Bygone Era
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/23/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/23/2012

title: Special Parking Rules in New York City
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Monday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Short of a Win, Garrigus Happy to Have Been in Such a Position
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  The sun had dipped behind the mountains Sunday by the time Robert Garrigus reached the 18th green at the Palmer Course at PGA West, but it was not nearly as dark as it felt when he stood in the same spot in broad daylight three days earlier.

title: Early Look at Giants-Patriots Matchup
description: The New England Patriots are back in the Super Bowl, despite the best efforts of their opponents and the preferences of millions of fans who are weary of their mix of arrogant excellence and excellent arrogance. The Jets tried to beat them with rhetoric, the Denver Broncos with an Elvis-strength cultural juggernaut, the Baltimore Ravens with everything but a healthy kicker. But nothing could stop Bill Belichick and Tom Brady from returning to the Super Bowl for the fifth time in 11 seasons. Judging by the chip-shot field goal the Ravens missed at the end of the Patriots 23-20 A.F.C. championship game victory, New England is again augmenting its considerable skill with some timely doses of good luck, the way it did in its rise to dominance a decade ago.

title: Photo Replay: N.F.C. Championship Game
description: A look at the Giants 20-17 victory over the 49ers in San Francisco, which sent the Giants to the Super Bowl against the New England Patriots.

title: Manchester 2, London 0
description: Sunday was yet another big day in Manchester Citys pursuit of the Premier League title, and a 3-2 win over Tottenham will surely be vital to that quest, since it kept City three points ahead of Manchester United.

title: Strange Bedfellows in the Conflict with Iran
description: 1:29 p.m. | Updated  Europe agrees to impose oil embargo and other sanctions on Iran

title: Serena Williams Suffers Rare Loss in Melbourne
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It is still a surprise when Serena Williams fails to claw her way out of a bad place against an unseeded player, but it was no shock that it happened at the Australian Open this year.

title: Tsonga Falls to Nishikori in 5-Set Drama
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Kei Nishikori of Japan barged into the quarterfinals of the Australian Open on Monday with a five-set upset victory over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France. Struggling from a set down, Nishikori surged back into the match after an unusual 10-minute suspension while officials and workers punctured and tamped down a section of court that had bubbled.

title: Rattled Heritage: Sikkims Monasteries after the Quake
description: For a week after the Sept. 18 earthquake, many towns in Sikkim were cut off from the outside world. The roads slowly became passable and as they did, photographs and video clips began to circulate. Rumors traveled too, especially that the major monasteries  Pemayangtse, Dubdi, Tashiding and Ringhim  were barely standing and that some of the smaller monasteries in Khechiperi and Hongdi had been obliterated.

title: The Patriots Have No Shot Against the Giants. Just Ask Them.
description: The Patriots hadnt even carried their A.F.C. championship trophy off the podium on Sunday and already Tom Brady was discussing the one person who had nearly kept them from winning it at all. Namely, Tom Brady.

title: Navratilova Backs Kvitova; Criticizes Ranking System
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It shouldnt be surprising to hear one Czech lefty standing by another, but the conviction with which Martina Navratilova defended No. 2-ranked Petra Kvitova was something to be noticed.

title: Stalemate Deals Grief and Fury in Syria
description: HOMS, Syria  Women threw rice onto three coffins draped with the countrys flag, a tribute to young men of marrying age who died in the violence that is ripping this city apart.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 23, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Jan. 23, 1973 | Nixon Announces End of U.S. Involvement in Vietnam
description: On Jan. 23, 1973, President Richard Nixon announced an accord had been reached to end the Vietnam War. In a televised speech, Nixon said the accord would end the war and bring peace with honor.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 23, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Private Sector Gets Job Skills; Public Gets Bill.

title: Not to Everyones Taste
description: HONG KONG  For weeks now, in the prelude to the Lunar New Year holiday that started Monday in Asia, the ramshackle restaurants along Nht Tn Street in Hanoi have been jammed with patrons. Happens every New Year. The menus feature meat prepared seven different ways, and the meals, which typically cost about $15, almost always include heroic drinking bouts with rice wine or the local turpentine called ruou.

title: More of the Same  but Different
description: Paul Octavious never calls the hill from his series Same Hill, Different Day by name.

title: Ringing In the Year of the Dragon
description: Chinese New Year starts today. To mark the beginning of the Year of the Dragon, we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

title: Europe and U.S. Tighten Vise of Sanctions on Iran
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union agreed Monday to impose a phased ban on oil purchases from Iran that officials said was needed to help force a shift in policy and avert the risk of military strikes against Tehran, as the United States expanded its sanctions to include the countrys third-largest bank.

title: The Early Word: Moving On
description: Todays Times

title: The New Gilded Age  Who Will Benefit?
description: As IHT Rendezvous kicks off a week of special coverage of the World Economic Forum in Davos, our colleague Chrystia Freeland, an IHT Page Two columnist and global editor at large at Reuters, writes about the new Gilded Age.

title: The Best States to Grow Up In
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: In Paris, Examining the Art of Cuisine
description: The city of light is home to the fourth annualParis des Chefs festival, an event that seeks to blend cooking and art by having chefs prepare food with a creative partner.

title: What Is Your Most Memorable Writing Assignment?
description: Chances are, youve had many, many writing assignments for school over the years. Whether paragraphs or autobiographies, term papers or journal entries, some of them probably stand out in your memory. What are they? What makes them so memorable?

title: Apache to Buy Cordillera Energy for $2.85 Billion
description: The independent oil and natural gas producer Apache Corporation agreed on Monday to acquire the privately held Cordillera Energy Partners for $2.85 billion, the latest deal centered on the controversial drilling technology known as hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

title: Special-Teams Blunders Sink Harbaugh Brothers
description: Quick hits on Sundays two championship games:

title: From Heros Parent to Politician
description: TEL AVIV  Last week, I spoke to a Knesset member from the Kadima Party. The party is losing ground to more fashionable players just entering Israels political fray: it holds 28 seats, and a recent poll found that it would win only 11 if elections were held now. I toyed with my phonemate, joking that he should make sure hes in one of Kadimas first ten slots or else hed soon have to find a new job. Well, what can I do? he said, No family member of mine was ever kidnapped, so I guess I dont have much chance.

title: This Week in Small Business: Gross National Happiness
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Cooking With Bill Belichick
description: Bill Belichick may beat the Giants in the Super Bowl in two weeks. He will almost certainly wind up in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. And, Spygate or no Spygate, he may one day be considered the games greatest coach.

title: A Retro-Futuristic Coif
description: For anyone who needs visual inducement to see Richard III at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, there is Haydn Gwynnes hair. Coiled to perfection in a manner reminiscent of Wallis Simpson, it lends authority to Queen Elizabeth, Ms. Gwynnes steely character, and provides the production with a moment of chic.

title: Daily Report: RIMs Co-Chiefs Step Aside
description: Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, who made the BlackBerry the indispensable business tool but then presided over its precipitous decline, said they would step down on Monday as co-chief executives of Research in Motion, reports Ian Austen of The New York Times. The move, while surprising, is not expected to herald major changes at the company. The new chief executive, Thorsten Heins, is one of RIMs two chief operating officers. He pledged during an interview on Sunday to follow the strategy Mr. Balsillie and Mr. Lazaridis set in place.

title: Redistricting and Increased Partisanship Fuel House Departures
description: The race for the exits is gaining steam in the United States House of Representatives.

title: Patriots Open as 3-Point Favorites in Super Bowl
description: The Giants have already beaten the Patriots this season, on the road, but they are not favored to beat the Patriots in two weeks in Indianapolis. The general publics familiarity with Bill Belichick, Tom Brady and the long-term excellence of the Patriots no doubt played a role in the Super Bowl opening line, which is intended to spur maximum betting, balanced on both sides.

title: Increasing Internet Can Raise G.D.P., Study Says
description: Indias economy can grow more than 1 percent with every 10 percent increase in Internet subscribers, according to a New Delhi economic policy think tank.

title: Home, Home  on Less Range
description: To see how thoroughly the concept of ecosystem services  the economic analysis of the natural worlds intersection with human endeavors  is embedded in climate change research, check out this forecast from a group led by researchers at Duke University and the Environmental Defense Fund.

title: Ticket Talk at the Circuit of the Americas
description: The Circuit of the Americas, the race track in Austin, Texas, where the U.S. Grand Prix is supposed to take place on Nov. 18, opened on Monday a select seating waiting list for tickets to the race on its Web site. Actual sales of tickets for the race will not begin until early summer, according to a circuit statement.

title: Ticket Talk at the Circuit of the Americas
description: The Circuit of the Americas, the race track in Austin, Texas, where the U.S. Grand Prix is supposed to take place on Nov. 18, opened on Monday a select seating waiting list for tickets to the race on its Web site. Actual sales of tickets for the race will not begin until early summer, according to a circuit statement.

title: Five Questions for: Chandrahas Choudhury
description: India Ink is asking authors attending the Jaipur Literature Festival five questions about writing and about themselves. Heather Timmons caught up with the author of Arzee the Dwarf and India  A Travellers Literary Companion.

title: Opinion Report: The Transfronterizos
description: From the editorial page

title: Why Bradshaws Fumble Wasnt a Fumble
description: The N.F.C. title game had become a stalemate. It seemed that a turnover might be decisive. The Niners Kyle Williams had two. And the Giants had none  with one very close call.

title: Bullying Changes a School, One Child at a Time
Touring a School? Look Beyond the Superficial
A Focus on Teachers and Teaching

Morning Take-Out
description: Bad Year for Wall St. Not Reflected in Chiefs Pay | Wall Street stocks and profits took a beating in 2011. But there is one corner of the Street that took a lighter hit: the compensation paid to chief executives.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Ruperts Man for Now and Looking Up at Esquire
description: Chase Carey, the president and chief operating officer of News Corporation, was long seen as a placeholder until one of the Murdoch children could take full control of the company. But the hacking scandal in London has complicated succession plans, and Mr. Carey, the blunt long-time aide, has filled the vacuum, writes Amy Chozick: Never in the $60 billion media companys history has an executive other than Mr. Murdoch taken such a major role in running the daily operations. He has, she writes, become particularly critical in getting Rupert Murdoch to focus on the stock price and in soothing Wall Street.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Be Near Sale of British Wealth Manager
description: 9:46 a.m. | Updated

title: Eli Mannings Durability on Display
description: You might remember that Brett Favre was the leader in N.F.L. consecutive starts. And then that Peyton Manning took over that title among quarterbacks.

title: Larry and the Invisibles
description: Ryan Lizzas new piece on policymaking in the Obama administration is out. One of the documents the piece rests on is a December 2008 policy memo from Larry Summers to Obama on the size and composition of stimulus; Ryan shared it with me to get my take, and some of what I said is reflected in his article.

title: For an Israeli Director, the Oscar Ceremony Gets Interesting After Its Over
description: At the age of 43, the American-born Israeli director Joseph Cedar is already a veteran of the Oscar process. Israel has submitted all four of the feature films he has made as official selections. His previous project, Beaufort, about Israeli soldiers in the waning days of the war in Lebanon, was a nominee for the Oscar for best foreign-language film in 2008, and his latest film, Footnote, was named this week to the shortlist of nine films contending for this years Oscar. On Tuesday, hell find out if hes one of the five nominees.

title: Paris Top 5 | Lanvin
description: The Lanvin runway show took the lions share of this seasons trends and solidified them in a singular stroke. The designers Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver combined the many amazing but disparate sides of the season  belted coats, drop shoulders, soft tailoring, proportion, fabric mash-ups, leather and motocross  and wrapped them all into a collection that was clear, understandable and one of the houses most wearable yet. Here, a nylon bomber jacket applied to a coat over a black-tie outfit deftly interprets the unselfconscious, random art of layering during a big city winter.

title: More Than You Want To Know About Warren Harding
description: Yesterday I mentioned that theyre still flogging the old line that Warren Harding proved that austerity works. I linked to my old demonstration that the 1921 economy was nowhere near the liquidity trap, and that there was substantial monetary easing, making comparisons to the current situation nonsense.

title: Tale of Comic Adventures Wins Newbery Medal
description: A sly, gothic and quasi-autobiographical tale of a boy who is grounded by his parents and sent to type obituaries for a neighbor, leading to a string of comic adventures, won the John Newbery Medal on Monday for the years most outstanding contribution to childrens literature.

title: Egypts Islamist Parliament
description: As Egypts Parliament holds its first session Monday following confirmation Saturday that Islamists had won nearly 70 percent of the seats, opinion writers are assessing what it could mean for the country and the region.

title: Leading Off: And Then There Were Two
description: In the end, the Super Bowl combatants were not decided by magnificent touchdowns or beautiful interceptions. They were chosen by fate seemingly for their grit and stubbornness, two teams that dont question themselves when doubt starts raining down on them. They just dig in and refuse to go away.

title: Soccers Battle of the Financial Davids and Goliaths
description: The Beatles told us that money cant buy you love.

title: New RIM Chief Not Looking to Split Company
description: Despite the problems at Research in Motion, the companys incoming chief executive says he is not entertaining the idea of splitting the company into two separate businesses.

title: After Giants vs. Patriots, It Could Be Christie vs. Bloomberg
description: Stunningly, some would go so far as to say miraculously, the New York Giants of New Jersey are going to the Super Bowl. You know what this means, dont you? For the next two weeks there may be cross-border skirmishing over whether the west bank or the east bank of the Hudson River gets to organize the celebration if the team wins the big game, scheduled for Feb. 5 in Indianapolis.

title: Breach of Trust
description: Since I just gave Larry Summers a bit of a hard time over that distressing Dec. 2008 memo to Obama, this is probably a good time to note that way back when he and Andrei Shleifer wrote an essay on the economics of leveraged buyouts (pdf) that is very worth reading now that Mitt Romney is running on the theme that his Bain experience means that he knows how to create jobs.

title: AbortionDocs.Org
description: You know those Western-style Wanted posters that anti-abortion activists liked to distribute? The ones with the names and addresses of doctors who perform the constitutionally protected procedure? That tactic has migrated to the Web.

title: Pan American to Acquire Minefinders for $1.5 Billion
description: The Pan American Silver Corporation agreed on Monday to acquire the Minefinders Corporation, a Canadian silver and gold exploration company, for $1.5 billion.

title: What Were Reading
description: Fast Company: For the run-up to Valentines Day, a paean to the Philadelphia-based John & Kiras chocolates, especially the $189 Bee My Love Tug Tower, a fantasy of ganache-filled chocolates, caramel honeybees, drunken figs and dark-chocolate ladybugs.  Glenn Collins

title: Monday Reading: Web Surfing for a Vacation Rental
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: 2:54 p.m. | Updated

title: There Is No Perfect (or Permanent) Financial Plan
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, The Behavior Gap, was published earlier this month. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

title: On Our Radar:  Freshwater Bulge in the Arctic
description: Scientists suggest that a dome of freshwater in the western Arctic Ocean might eventually disturb the warm currents that assure relatively mild weather in Northern Europe. [BBC]

title: Now, Online-Only Fashion Shows for Busy Editors
description: KCD, the public relations company that produces fashion shows for top labels like Marc Jacobs and Givenchy, announced on Monday that it is offering a new service wherein it will produce some shows in an entirely digital format so that overtaxed editors can watch them online. During Fashion Week, particularly in New York, it has become a common complaint that there are too many shows, something like 300 scheduled within eight days, and that a lot of designers get lost as a result. The new idea, which is being pitched as an alternative to runway or presentation formats, is that rather than slogging across town or making some excuse about being on deadline, an editor or buyer can watch the collection on a computer or mobile device.

title: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Account of Clash That Ended With Airstrike
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans military issued an uncompromising formal rejection on Monday of the United States report last month on a contentious border exchange of fire that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers, dealing a fresh blow to American hopes of reviving a troubled strategic relationship.

title: Editor Is the Story as the French Huffington Post Starts
description: PARIS  Anne Sinclair smiled big for the cameras, not as the betrayed wife standing by her man but as the star journalist she once was and hopes to be again.

title: A Piece of the Manhattan Dream, Only $331.76 a Month
description: With 11-foot ceilings, exposed brick walls, piles of hardcover books and views of chimneys and water towers, Arnold Warwicks apartment is a 1,200-square-foot monument to the Greenwich Village of our fantasies.

title: $4.62 Million Mercedes Gullwing Leads Strong Auction Weekend in Arizona
description: As the auctions in and around Scottsdale, Ariz., over the weekend proved, the uppermost reaches of the collector-car hobby remain virtually unfazed by the various crises roiling the global economy.

title: Creating Family Time With Unofficial Flextime
description: Call it stealth flextime.

title: Fuel to Be Removed From Stricken Cruise Ship
description: GIGLIO, Italy  Rescue divers discovered the bodies of two women in the submerged Internet cafe lounge of the Costa Concordia shipwreck on Monday, raising the official death toll to 15, as salvage crews were authorized to start extracting the vessels half million gallons of fuel.

title: S.B.A. Readying Program to Invest in Start-Ups
description: With its legislative agenda for job creation stuck for the foreseeable future, the Obama administration has turned inward, looking to the federal bureaucracy for new ways to jump-start the economy.

title: A Glimpse of Polar History
description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

title: Post-Mubarak Parliament Holds First Session
description: Islamists hold a majority in the first Parliament elected after the ouster of Mubarak.

title: Really? The Claim: Excess Weight Raises the Risk of Acne
description: THE FACTS

title: Rand Paul Is Stopped by T.S.A. in Nashville
description: 12:33 p.m. | Updated  Senator Rand Paul, the libertarian-leaning Republican from Kentucky, was detained at the airport in Nashville by the Transportation Security Administration on Monday, according to people close to the lawmaker, although the T.S.A. quickly disputed their account.

title: Tim Rice Has No Hosannas for Andrew Lloyd Webbers Superstar Reality Show
description: Look at all the trials and tribulations of Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice. The one-time partners behind some of musical theaters most successful (and lucrative) works are feuding again, this time over a British reality series that would cast the lead for a new production of Jesus Christ Superstar.

title: Romney Warns of October Surprises if Gingrich Is Nominee
description: TAMPA  Mitt Romney raised the possibility that Newt Gingrich might have broken laws in representing corporate interests and warned of politically damaging October surprises if Mr. Gingrich became the Republican presidential nominee.

title: Numberplay: The Five-Pirate Puzzle
description: Five smart, greedy and mean pirates find themselves on a boat with 100 gold coins. The pirates are ranked according to seniority, from 1 to 5, the most senior being ranked 1. Here is the deal: the most senior pirate must make a proposal for splitting the coins among the pirates, including herself (no fractional coins!). If her proposal has at least 50 percent acceptance (she votes, too), she is fine; otherwise, the other four pirates throw her into the shark-infested sea. The remaining pirates play the same game, starting with a proposal from the next most senior pirate, that is, the pirate ranked 2.

title: Tibetans Fired Upon in Protest in China
description: HONG KONG  Security forces opened fire on Tibetan protesters in western China on Monday, wounding at least 32 people and killing at least one of them in the largest violent confrontation in ethnic Tibetan areas of China since 2008, two Tibetan rights groups and the Tibetan exile government said.

title: Photos of the Moment | Lanvin
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Calling Mitch Daniels
description: For months now, even as the rest of the conservative commentariat has gradually resigned itself to the existing presidential field, the Weekly Standards Bill Kristol has continued to pine  publicly, unstintingly, immune to either embarrassment or fatiguefor another candidate to jump into the race. Hes dreamed of Mitch Daniels, touted Chris Christie, talked up Paul Ryan and Marco Rubio, name-dropped Jeb Bush, and circled back to Danielsonce more. Hes quoted poetry on behalf of his cause  Yeats, and (with some revisions) Andrew Marvell. Hes endured snark from the Huffington Post, eye-rolling from Slate, mockery from New York Magazine. But hes continued undeterred  and in the wake of Newt Gingrichs South Carolina victory, he wasback at it again, throwing out a link to a new online petition was launched Saturday night  atrunmitchrun.com.

title: Taking Up Taxes on the Campaign Trail
description: Republican politicians talk a great deal about saving small businesses, and routinely play the mom-and-pop card when arguing against raising taxes, or charging a decent minimum wage, or providing everyone with access to health insurance. Last year, when the Senate was debating how to pay for a renewal of the payroll tax cut, Democrats proposed a surcharge on incomes over $1 million a year. Republicans screamed that this would hurt small businesses, and hence the economy, because small businesses are job creators.

title: Romeo Is Dead, but Lemur Conservation Endures
description: The Duke Lemur Centers beloved Romeo died this weekend at 19. He was the Western Hemispheres only successfully housed captive diademed sifaka, one of Madagascars increasingly rare lemur species. Still, his tale is one of hope, with efforts expanding to assure the survival of endangered lemur species.

title: 2 Live Crew to Live Again
description: The rap group 2 Live Crew, which set off a fierce debate over freedom of speech with its graphic sexual lyrics in the 1980s and early 1990s, plans to reunite and begin touring, The Associated Press reported. The groups former leader, Luther Campbell, said at the Sundance Film Festival in Utah that the rappers, whose hits like Me So Horny drew fire, would get back together. I just cant wait to start practicing, he said. Mr. Campbell, who is 51 and is also known as Luke, visited the festival to promote his appearance in a short film, The Life and Freaky Times of Uncle Luke.

title: Supreme Court Decision: The United States v. Jones
description: In a 5-4 decision, the Supreme Court on Monday unanimously ruled that the police violated the Constitution when they placed a Global Positioning System tracking device on a suspects car and tracked its movements for 28 days.

title: A Journeyman Giant Kept Ending Up in the Right Place
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After all the preparation and posturing, the difference between the Giants and the 49ers on Sunday essentially came down to a 25-year-old special-teams player who managed to be in the right position to fall on a uniquely contoured ball best known for taking strange bounces.

title: Survivals Ick Factor
description: Disgust is the Cinderella of emotions. While fear, sadness and anger, its nasty, flashy sisters, have drawn the rapt attention of psychologists, poor disgust has been hidden away in a corner, left to muck around in the ashes.

title: Federer vs.Tomic: Breaking It Down
description: Roger Federers straight sets victory against Australian teenager Bernard Tomic in the fourth round of the Australian Open this morning highlighted a major difference in how the two players view and play the sport.Federer, who will play against Juan Martin del Potro in the quarterfinals Tuesday (Federers 1,000th tour match), won, 6-4, 6-2, 6-2, displaying a game style vastly different from his inexperienced yet highly touted opponent.

title: A Sunscreen Warning for Parents of Teenagers
description: Half of a group of 360 fifth graders told researchers from Memorial Sloan-Kettering that they used sunscreen regularly when in the sun. Three years later, in 2007, among those same children, at least two things had changed: they were now eighth graders, with all the increased rebellion and decreased supervision that that implies  and now, only about 25 percent still used sunscreen.

title: The Court at the State of the Union
description: The State of the Union attendance records of the nine current Supreme Court justices.

title: Justices Say GPS Tracker Violated Privacy Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday  ruled unanimously that the police violated the Constitution when they placed a Global Positioning System tracking device on a suspects car and monitored its movements for 28 days.

title: Reading List: Some Recent Books on Disgust
description: Yuck! The Nature and Moral Significance of Disgust, by Daniel Kelly. M.I.T. Press, 2011. 194 pages.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Sokolove on Oscar Pistorius
description: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story on the double-amputee Olympic hopeful Oscar Pistorius. Sokolove is the author of three books: Warrior Girls, about the epidemic of injuries among young female athletes; The Ticket Out: Darryl Strawberry; and Hustle: The Myth, Life, and Lies of Pete Rose.

title: For Justices, State of the Union Can Be a Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has called the State of the Union address, which is being delivered Tuesday night, a political pep rally. For Justice Antonin Scalia, it is a juvenile spectacle.

description: 9:45 p.m. | Updated  BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown and Elizabeth Warren, his likely Democratic opponent, agreed Monday on a plan to try to stop outside groups from running attack ads in their high-profile, high-stakes race. But while they labored over a mutually acceptable agreement, the hardest part  trying to enforce it  comes now.

title: Charles Duhigg Responds to Readers on Apple and the iEconomy
description: 7:36 p.m. | Updated  Charles Duhigg has provided answers to select reader questions. See the comments, below.

title: Lunches to Take to Work
description: Many people who have chimed in on the Recipes for Health page on Facebook have requested recipes for lunches they can take to work and eat at a desk. Although I work at home, my lunch requirements are probably similar to those of many of you who work in an office. I dont like to eat complex dishes with strong flavors like raw garlic or onion at midday, because I dont want those flavors lingering when I get back to work. I want a lunch thats light and simple, enjoyable but not distracting. It usually includes protein and a vegetable of some kind, often a complex carbohydrate like whole-grain bread or a grain. I dont spend much time preparing it because Ive made it ahead (salad, wraps, something Ive tested for this column that fits the bill), or because its as simple as cottage cheese and avocado with a corn tortilla or two, heated over the gas burner so that it has a nice charred taste.

title: Buffett Rings in Chinese New Year With a Serenade
description: Warren E. Buffett is many things, but a songster?

title: New Florida Polls Show Big Swing to Gingrich
description: 1:59 p.m. | Updated I had written on Saturday night, before the results of the South Carolina primary were known, that Mitt Romney could not necessarily bank on holding down a lead in Florida despite recently having had a double-digit advantage in the polls there.

title: Queens Man, 50, Dies in Explosion
description: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | A 50-year-old man who may have been experimenting with fireworks died in an explosion at his home in South Ozone Park, Queens, on Monday morning, the police said.

title: Stem Cell Treatment for Eye Diseases Shows Promise
description: LOS ANGELES  A treatment for eye diseases that is derived from human embryonic stem cells might have improved the vision of two patients, bolstering the beleaguered field, researchers reported Monday.

title: Just One Look | Versace
description: Atelier Versace, the haute couture division of the Italian house, showed for the first time since 2004 this morning at the Beaux Arts. It was a modest return  a presentation of 15 looks on a gold staircase to a standing audience  but very, very Versace: swishing ponytails, smoky eyes, vertiginous heels and lots of sparkle. Sculptural (ergonomic) aluminum bands defined the curves of delicate encrusted lace columns and minis. Here, a get-thee-to-a-red-carpet number in brazen persimmon.

title: Mark Kelly to Join First Lady for State of the Union
description: Capt. Mark Kelly, the husband of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, will sit with Michelle Obama in the first ladys box at Tuesdays State of the Union speech, Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said on Monday.

title: Bang & Olufsens Homage to Its Past
description: Bang & Olufsen, best known as makers of high-style audio equipment, is starting what the company is calling its new affordable subbrand, B&O Play, with a high-fidelity lunchbox.

title: Most Serious Charge in a Privates Death May Be Dropped
description: A military investigator has recommended that the most serious charge be dropped against an American infantryman implicated in the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, a Chinese-American soldier from New York City who, relatives said, was brutally hazed by members of his Army unit in Afghanistan and then apparently killed himself.

title: Thomas Langmann, the Man Who Took a Chance on The Artist
description: American audiences were introduced to Thomas Langmann, a producer of The Artist, at the Golden Globes, when he gave one of the evenings best speeches, about his father, the filmmaker Claude Berri, winning an Oscar in 1966 and not having enough money to come to the United States to accept it. The winning streak The Artist is now on  it picked up the top Producers Guild prize over the weekend  may give Mr. Langmann a chance to rectify that; the Bagger and everyone else will start to find out the fate of The Artist when Oscar nominations are announced on Tuesday.

title: New Romney Ad Hits Gingrich on Freddie Mac
description: Mitt Romney is taking his attacks on Newt Gingrich up a notch in a new television ad that tries to link him to the implosion of the housing market.

title: Dont Pat On Me
description: Whether or not you agree with them on the issues, its nice to find politicians who actually have principles and actually stick to them. Obviously, Im not talking here about either Newt Gingrich or Mitt Romney. In fact, Im not talking about the presidential race at all, although the politician I have in mind is at least related to one of the candidates.

title: Corporate Rule Is Not Inevitable
description: President Obama formally rejected the Keystone XL pipeline. Fingers crossed there, but that, plus the evident death of the SOPA bill (and little things, like B of A, Verizon and Netflix all being forced to change their behavior after massive Web protests by their customers) give reason to hope. The campaign against Citizens United may well pick up steam as more people begin to feel the power. Corporate rule, as this piece details, is not inevitable.

title: In Poland, a Pirate of the Highway
description: Moving a trailer of beef along Interstate 80 like John Wayne driving a herd along the Chisholm Trail, many American truck drivers fancy themselves heirs to the cowboy tradition. For at least one of Polands knights of the highway, however, the romantic vision of his occupation is more surf than turf.

title: TimesCast | January 23, 2012
description: Egypt seats its new Parliament | Romney and Gingrich trade jabs before Monday's debate | China celebrates the Year of the Dragon.

title: Some Rosy Predictions for Windows Phone 7
description: Sales of new devices running Windows Phone 7 have been so small that even Microsoft is shy about revealing numbers. And yet two research firms predict that phones running the operating system will surpass the iPhone by 2015.

title: Supreme Court Rebuffs Conservative Group on Health Care Lawsuit
description: A conservative group that wants Justice Elena Kagan to recuse herself when the Supreme Court takes up a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul has been denied permission to take part in oral arguments in the case.

title: Etta James: One of Everyones Own
description: Perhaps the most astounding thing about Etta Jamess voice was how it traveled so freely in so many different musical circles, and that was again the most evident aspect of the tributes given to her over the weekend. On Saturday morning, she was featured on a rhythm-and-blues radio program; later that day, on a rock n roll show. On Sunday morning, jazz radio was claiming her as one of their own, and she was even plastered all over the touch screen of the treadmill at my gym. And that seemed the most appropriate format, because no matter what James sang  R&B, rock, blues, jazz, pop  her voice was one that got your blood pumping.

title: Chaotic Start to Egypts First Democratically Elected Parliament
description: CAIRO  As Egypts first freely elected Parliament in six decades held its opening session on Monday, the Muslim Brotherhood received a lesson in the unwieldiness of democracy when a dispute over choosing a speaker degenerated into a shouting match that overshadowed the day.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Advertising or Not, Billboards Have a Towering Presence
description: The collapse of a billboard along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway on Jan. 13 has turned the citys attention again to the presence of highway billboards: how many are legal, how many are safe and what are they doing there in the first place? In the realm of outdoor advertising in the city, definitive answers can be elusive, Patrick McGeehan reported in The Times on Friday.

title: Maison Martin Margiela Mens

He made elaborate plans for his time away, arranging for his mother, Dotty, who has advanced Alzheimers, to stay with nearby friends; getting his first cellphone lest there be an emergency; and bit by bit, day after day, reminding her of his coming departure.

Schoolgirls Needlework Sampler Sells for $1.07 Million
description: In 1807, a New Jersey schoolgirl named Mary Antrim embroidered a farm scene with silk thread on linen. On Sunday, Sothebys in New York sold her view of livestock, picket fences and clapboarded outbuildings for $1.07 million (the top estimate had been $120,000), setting an auction record for a needlework sampler. The sale contained 198 lots from the collection of the needlework historian Betty Ring. Of all the colorful pastoral views at the Sothebys showroom, Mary Antrims piece stood out in a unique way as a folk art statement, said the dealer David Schorsch, who bought it for an undisclosed client. The auctions other top prices were in the low six figures and shared by the specialist dealers Stephen and Carol Huber and Amy Finkel. A quarter of the Ring material did not sell, especially images of veiled mourners and gravestones sewn in memory of deceased relatives. The buzz in the field this week, Mr. Huber said, is that the memorials all died.

title: Just One Look | Salvatore Ferragamo
description: The mens shows just wrapped in Paris, couture is under way, and back in New York prefall presentations continue. For Salvatore Ferragamos first prefall collection (its true!), Massimiliano Giornetti retraced the brands archives to design a travel-inspired capsule that includes a new set of trunk totes and updates on the favorite pointy-toe kitten heel in rich renditions of crocodile, ostrich and python. The mood of the collection was thoughtfully throwback: mod 1960s-style prints (like this emerald plaid pantsuit), python pleated skirts and a camel shift dress with a cape to match. We hear fall 2012 will sing a similar tune.

title: The High Cost of Violating Human Rights
description: It used to be that the United Nations human rights commission denounced violations in some of the nastiest parts of the world  sub-Saharan Africa, South Africa, junta-dominated Latin American countries, Communist-occupied Europe. These days, that office denounces the United States. Thats what happens when you operate a prison on the margins of the law and justice, where people are held without trial, on tainted evidence, without consideration for their rights under international treaties or the laws of the nation that built the prison.

title: Summing Up the Paterno Legacy: Its Complicated

It left little time to make sense of it all. Sandusky hasnt even been tried yet for allegedly sexually abusing children on Paternos watch. The scandals history is still in the first-draft stage. And now to sum up the life of a venerated coach who was above reproach until it all came down at once?

title: Dental Exam Went Well? Thank Fluoride
description: I admit to being jealous of my sons for growing up in a time when vaccines spared them miseries like the measles, mumps and polio scares that marred my childhood. But Im most envious of their freedom from the dental decay that forced me to spend countless miserable hours with my mouth propped open while the dentist did his best to stay on top of rapidly rotting teeth.

title: In Urination Video, Behavior Unbecoming a Marine

title: After Hardship and Homelessness, National Science Fair Honors

Her face was on the cover of Newsday, her hometown newspaper. Her congressman, Steve Israel, invited her to work in his office in Washington this summer. She has hired an agent to juggle interview requests.

title: Drug Seen to Curtail Cancer Left in Prostate
description: Fewer than 10 percent of the 100,000 men each year who get a diagnosis of early-stage prostate cancer and have the option of leaving the cancer in place while watching it actually do so. The rest want to just get rid of it, with surgery or radiation. But those treatments can have serious side effects like impotence and incontinence.

title: Examining the Flotsam, Hoping for the Treasures

But rather than find its own formula, it was content to borrow from existing shows, and it borrowed all the wrong things.

title: Squinting at Gingrichs Slogan
description: On primary nights, while hardworking daily reporters are trying desperately to tally votes and crunch the exit polling, magazine guys like me get to watch TV and think about things like: Hey, what is that on Newt Gingrichs campaign signs, and why are the letters so flippin small? And so, on the heels of my recent sit-down with Newt and my article on South Carolina for the magazine, heres a column on Gingrichs new slogan and what we should make of it.

title: Drink Up | Pressed Juicerys Chalkboard Goes Live
description: Pressed Juicery in Los Angeles began as a labor of love. When the co-founder Carly Briens mother got ill, she and her friends Hayden Slater and Hedi Gores decided to change career paths (from public relations, production and full-time motherhood, respectively) and create something healthful and positive. At the time, Los Angeles was lacking a juicery that used a hydraulic press, a machine that squelches an entire fruit or vegetable into a pulp, extracting three to four times more than an average juicer. After yoga class one day, Slater found the perfect spot for one: a 22-square-foot broom closet adjacent to the Brentwood Country Mart. Today, Pressed is a thriving business  a second location (in a truck) opened in Malibu last summer, and at the end of last year Slater and friends brought a storefront to West Hollywood. The juicery also takes orders online and delivers nationwide to loyals who cant live without its Greens 2 (a blend of kale, spinach, romaine, parsley, cucumber, celery, apple and lemon), Detox 2 (pineapple, green apple and mint) and Almond Milk (almonds, dates, vanilla bean, sea salt and filtered water).

title: Mexican Guitarists Come Home From the Cold
