Intricate melodies  and solos challenging the laws of nylon  rode over crashing, furious percussion as they raced from heavy-metal riffs to jazz to something vaguely Turkish.

title: Follies Closes Without Turning a Profit
description: More than 216,000 people saw the Broadway revival of Follies by the time it ended its five-and-a-half month run on Sunday, and most major theater critics raved about the production, which added three weeks of performances in response to ticket demand. Yet all of this was not enough to recoup the shows capitalization and turn a profit, according to Michael Kaiser of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, where the Follies revival began last spring and which was one of its lead producers on Broadway.

title: The Pure Romanticism That Fokine Took West Returns After a Detour
description: WASHINGTON  Go west, young man!, the saying goes, and a century ago almost all the Russian choreographers did just that. In 1909 Michel Fokine, master of poetic evocation and characterful dance drama, was the first of them to migrate and make most of his ballets in Europe and the Americas. Thanks to him and those who followed, ballet in the West was transformed. It took most of the 20th century, however, for ballet in Russia even to catch up with what Fokine had been doing elsewhere.

title: After Being Stricken by Drought, Istanbul Yields Ancient Treasure
description: ISTANBUL  For 1,600 years, this city  Turkeys largest  has been built and destroyed, erected and erased, as layer upon layer of life has thrived on its seven hills.

title: Zoos Have a New Head Keeper
description: The Bronx Zoo and its cousins have a new head keeper. Cristin Samper, the director of the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of Natural History, will take over as president and C.E.O. of the Wildlife Conservation Society starting in August, the society announced on Monday.

title: What Will Be Nominated? Even the Oscarologists Arent Entirely Sure
description: The Super Bowl competitors are decided. The Republican presidential field is narrowing (sort of). There is only one slice of American life left to bet on, and that is the Oscars. The Bagger will be watching and updating when the nominations are announced early on Tuesday morning, but until then, there is still intrigue in every category, starting with the number of best picture nominees.

title: Would You Like a Side of Nonsense With That?
description: My piece in The Times Magazine, inspired by a series of visits to Kajitsu, detailed a recipe for vegan Worcestershire sauce that, if you have a few hours to spare, is not terribly difficult and worth the effort. But its length and detail reminded my friend Ed Schneider (former Bitten blogger and now a contributor to the Wall Street Journal and Washington Post, among others) of some of the nonsense recipes of the weirdo 19th century nonsense poet Edward Lear. That stuff is hilarious.

title: Genocide Bill Angers Turks as It Passes in France

title: Greece Publishes List of 4,000 Tax Scofflaws
description: In a name-and-shame campaign aimed at getting tax evaders to pay up, the Greek government published a list of more than 4,000 people, including several household names, who owe a total of $19 billion to the cash-strapped state. The list published late Sunday includes the veteran crooner Tolis Voskopoulos with debts of nearly $650,000; Pavlos Psomiadis, the owner of a defunct insurance firm, with arrears of nearly $2 million; and Giorgos Batatoudis, a former soccer club president who owes more than $3 million. Greece is under pressure from foreign creditors to curb endemic tax evasion, a key barrier to its economic recovery.

title: Washington: Gay Marriage Wins a Crucial Backer
description: The state appeared likely to become the seventh to allow gay couples to marry, after a state senator who had previously said she was undecided announced her support on Monday for a marriage bill moving through the Legislature. The measure, proposed by Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, has wide support in the House and had been just a few votes short in the Senate. After several undecided senators announced their support in recent weeks, Senator Mary Margaret Haugen, a Democrat, said she also would vote for the bill, becoming the decisive vote. A vote has not yet been scheduled. If the measure passes, opponents are expected to challenge it through a ballot referendum this fall. For me personally, I have always believed in traditional marriage between a man and a woman, Ms. Haugen said in a statement. That is what I believe, to this day. But this issue isnt about just what I believe. Its about respecting others, including people who may believe differently than I. Its about whether everyone has the same opportunities for love and companionship and family and security that I have enjoyed.

title: The Hasty Retreat of the Dung Beetle
description: After dung beetles collect the substance that gives them their name, they do a little dance, swinging around in one direction, and then sometimes the other.

title: Missouri: Message-Laden House Will Be Preserved
description: A destroyed house filled with the signatures and well-wishes of thousands of the volunteers who came to Joplin to help with the recovery after the deadly tornado last spring will be preserved, city leaders announced Monday. The house and the messages within had been decaying under the elements because the walls and roof were stripped off by the storm. A makeshift roof was erected to protect the building, which will be sealed on Tuesday with a type of shrink wrap to protect the messages from eroding further, said Patrick Tuttle, director of the Joplin Convention and Visitors Bureau. The house, he said, will soon be moved out of the rebuilding neighborhood and to a city-owned storage area until it can be incorporated into a museum or other public display.

title: A Dearth of Disclosure About Expired Tickets
description: WITH income tax time ahead, Ive been rummaging through drawers for records, which explains why I just came across a slip of paper reminding me of an airline ticket to Seattle that I canceled in late 2010.

title: Cabdrivers, New Yorkers, Even Darth Vader. Everyones Nice.
description: IM in marketing for a health care technology company and a typical road warrior, flying out every Monday from my office in Tulsa, Okla., to either our headquarters near Denver or to meet with clients. Its tough flying anywhere direct from Tulsa, so I usually have to change planes, which can create some extensive delays.

title: U.N. Investigates Allegations Against Troops in Haiti
description: The United Nations is investigating allegations against its police officers in Haiti involving two cases of sexual abuse of minors, the organizations spokesman said Monday. The allegations were made against United Nations officers in Port-au-Prince, the capital, and in Gonaives. The officers have been removed from their duties while a team from New York investigates the allegations, said Martin Nesirky, the spokesman, adding that the leadership of the organization was outraged by the allegations. He declined to identify the nationality of the officers involved. There are about 11,000 United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti, about 3,500 of whom are police officers.

title: Chesapeake to Cut Number of Gas Rigs
description: HOUSTON  Chesapeake Energy, the nations second biggest natural gas producer, announced Monday that it would cut production of gas in response to plummeting prices.

title: As China Reins In Microblogs, Dissidents Find Haven on Twitter
description: Chinese ringing in the first second of the Lunar New Year on social media bombarded the countrys biggest microblogging service with more than 30,000 messages on Monday, roaring past the previous record for messages per second on a social media site, according to a news release by the company, Sina Weibo, quoted by Chinese news media.

title: Newt Gingrichs Contract With Freddie Mac
description: Newt Gingrich released his contract with Freddie Mac on Monday.

title: A G.O.P. Counterweight to Obama, but So Far Just in Speech Response
description: WASHINGTON  In tapping Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana to deliver Tuesdays Republican response to the State of the Union address, Congressional leaders wanted a sober figure, noted for his seriousness on fiscal matters and unencumbered by the presidential nomination fight roiling the party.

title: Some Signs G.O.P. Establishments Backing of Romney Is Tenuous
description: Sundays post on whether Newt Gingrichs recent success has broken the paradigm in which party elites play a decisive role in determining presidential nominations drew hundreds of comments. Since there seems to be considerable interest in the topic, I would also encourage you to read the recent writings of the political scientists Seth Masket, John Sides and Jonathan Bernstein on the subject.

title: Bingham Ray, Executive Who Championed Independent Films, Dies at 57
description: LOS ANGELES  Bingham Ray, a colorful indie-film executive who helped steer art-house movies like Bowling for Columbine and Hotel Rwanda to the masses, died on Monday in a hospice in Provo, Utah. He was 57.

title: France: Government Bans Domestic Islamist Group
description: The government has ordered the dissolution of a domestic Islamist group, saying that it was a terrorist organization training its members for armed combat, Interior Minister Claude Guant said Monday. The Web site of the group, Forsane Alizza or The Knights of Pride, says its aim is to fight Islamophobia. The Web site is laced with anti-Semitic material and postings supporting organizations that are widely deemed to be terrorist groups, including the Afghan Taliban. A recent recruitment appeal by Forsane Alizza called for soldiers, and the group acknowledges some violent aims, in particular in the defense of Muslim women. The group gained attention last year through demonstrations against a French law banning the wearing of the full facial veil in public. A cofounder of the group, Mohammed Achamlane, said it would contest the dissolution order in court. This is truly farcical, he said in a telephone interview from Nantes in western France. They have absolutely nothing against us.

title: As Race Moves to Florida, Facing Political Implications of a Housing Crisis
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla. When Mitt Romney swept into the contentious battleground state of Florida on Sunday, the first local issue he raised was the nations mortgage foreclosure crisis, which is arguably at its worst here, from this city on the northern coast to the ghost-town developments in what used to be farmland south of Miami.

title: Chicago Sun-Times Ends Candidate Endorsements
description: For the first time since it began publishing 71 years ago, the editorial board of the Chicago Sun-Times announced late on Sunday that it would not endorse political candidates in the coming elections.

title: On Defense, Patriots Improve by Yards, if Not by a Mile
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Over the course of the regular season, the New England Patriots won 13 games and earned the top seed in the A.F.C. , and did so without beating a team with a winning record and with a defense ranked dead last in the conference.

title: Shuttering of Megaupload Sends File-Sharing Sites Packing
description: The federal governments takedown of the file-sharing site Megaupload last week has sent file-sharing sites packing in some cases, to Russia.

title: Taking DNA From All Criminals Should Be Standard Procedure
description: WE have a tool that can prevent hundreds of murders, rapes and robberies each year at minimal cost to taxpayers. But were not using it in a majority of cases because a state law restricts its use.

description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  It was the Big Reveal that showed almost nothing.

title: India: 2 Arrested in July Terrorist Attack on Mumbai
description: Authorities in Mumbai announced the arrest of two suspects on Monday in connection with a terrorist attack last July that killed 27 people in bombings across the city. Police investigators also blamed a domestic terrorist, Yasin Bhatkal, who remains at large and has been linked to a radical Islamic group known as the Indian Mujahedeen. Rakesh Maria, a top counterterrorism official in Mumbai, said the police had arrested two men from Bihar State, accused of being Mr. Bhatkals accomplices, and have identified others involved in the conspiracy. The attack consisted of explosions at three locations in Mumbai and investigators initially examined the possibility that the culprits were terrorist groups from Pakistan.

title: Christie Names a Gay Man and an Asian for the Top Court
description: Gov. Chris Christie made a broad stroke for diversity on New Jerseys Supreme Court on Monday, nominating one man who would be the first openly gay justice, and another who would be the first Asian and first immigrant to serve.

title: How to Integrate Europes Muslims
description: Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: With Surplus of Starters, Cashman Looks for D.H.
description: With seven starting pitchers in hand and no steady designated hitter, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said on Monday that he might use what he termed his excess pitching to acquire such a bat.

title: Not Quite Smart Enough
description: As the smart revolution spreads from phones to other electronics, some manufacturers are hoping to make a bundle by selling refrigerators that spew out recipes based on whats inside, robotic vacuum cleaners with remote-controlled cameras, and washers and dryers you can monitor from your phone.

title: Debt-Ridden Greece Hopes Ancient Sites Can Yield New Cash
description: ATHENS  This is what it has come to in Greece: the Acropolis, the quintessential symbol of Greek culture and identity, could soon become a popular destination for fashion photographers and Hollywood producers, as cultural officials look for ways to raise money to make up for cuts in public financing.

title: Europe Weighs Tough Law on Online Privacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Europe is considering a sweeping new law that would force Internet companies like Amazon.com and Facebook to obtain explicit consent from consumers about the use of their personal data, delete that data forever at the consumers request and face fines for failing to comply.

title: The Gusts of Gingrich
description: Not long ago, a veteran Republican strategist told me that a politician could succeed with his zipper down, but not with his words unbridled.

title: Mind Your Ps and Bs: The Digital Humanities and Interpretation
description: The question I posed at the conclusion of my last post was how do the technologies wielded by digital humanities practitioners either facilitate the work of the humanities, as it has been traditionally understood, or bring about an entirely new conception of what work in the humanities can and should be? Im going to sneak up on that question by offering a piece of conventional (i.e., non-digital) literary analysis that deals, as the digital humanities do, with matters of statistical frequency and pattern.

title: Learning to Fend for Himself and Obey House Rules
description: Travis Watson remembers the moment when he went from having everything to having nothing. He had spent a night at a friends house in fall 2010 and was returning to his grandmothers home in Brooklyn, where he and his four siblings lived. He was greeted by the sight of a moving van loaded with furniture: his grandmother was moving to North Carolina, and Mr. Watson had not been invited to go with her.

title: Free Pass for Matchmaking at a Setting in the Alps
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The stars of the guest list for this years annual World Economic Forum, which begins here Wednesday, are a whos who of government leaders pulling the strings of the global economy. On the list are Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany; Timothy F. Geithner, the United States secretary of the Treasury; Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank; and Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Free-Market Socialism
description: I hope President Obama read about Maddie Parlier as he was working on his State of the Union address. Parlier is the subject of Adam Davidsons illuminating article in the current issue of The Atlantic.

title: Super PAC for Gingrich to Get $5 Million Infusion
description: A wealthy backer of Newt Gingrich will inject $5 million into a super PAC supporting his presidential bid, two people with knowledge of the contribution said on Monday, providing a major boost to Mr. Gingrich as he seeks to fend off aggressive attacks from Mitt Romney, his main Republican rival.

title: Giants-Patriots: The Old, the New and the Familiar
description: Yes, the Giants and the Patriots are facing each other in the Super Bowl for the second time in four years, which would intimate that both teams can gain a lot by remembering that experience.

title: Giants Field-Goal Unit, Needing Its Best, Prepared for the Worst
description: Steve Weatherford knew about the Giants recent history of last-second field goal tries at Candlestick Park. Of course he did. Everyone did. And even if he had not known before last week, it would have been impossible for him to ignore the questions and conversations about Trey Junkins bad snap and the disaster that was the end of the Giants collapse to the San Francisco 49ers in a 2003 playoff game.

title: Living in Fear of the N.C.A.A.
description: It was early in the evening of Jan. 13 when Ryan Boatright, the freshman basketball player at the University of Connecticut, learned that he was being suspended from the team for the second time this season. Earlier that day, he had flown into South Bend, Ind., with his teammates for a game against Notre Dame. The 19-year-old point guard was excited because some 400 people from his hometown, Aurora, Ill., were coming to see him play.

title: Political Push Moves a Deal on Mortgages Inches Closer
description: About one million homeowners facing foreclosure could have their mortgage burden cut by about $20,000 each as part of a long-awaited deal taking shape among state attorneys general, federal officials and the nations largest mortgage servicers.

title: Unrest and American Safety Concerns Strand Iraqis in Syria Awaiting Visas for U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  The United States has nearly halted the processing of visas for Iraqi refugees in Syria, leaving thousands of people who fled a war in their homeland marooned in a country in the grip of an increasingly violent insurrection, with little hope of leaving anytime soon.

title: The Unions Newfangled Gimcracks
description: In late December 1861 Abraham Lincoln issued a directive that, had it been vigorously pursued, might have brought the Civil War to a rapid end: An order, via Gen. James Ripley, the Armys ordnance chief, for 10,000 Spencer repeating rifles. Because Ripley resisted the order for months and did nothing to help put the rifles into volume production, initial deliveries didnt start until about a year and a half after Lincoln first tested the rifle. Consequently, Union soldiers had to fight with less efficient weapons, handicapping them and greatly lengthening the bloody conflict.

title: The Worlds Most Exclusive Condominium
description: You are not allowed to visit Pheasant Island, which lies near the Atlantic Ocean terminus of the French-Spanish border. But it can easily be seen from the Joncaux bank, on the Bay Path, the Web site for the local tourist office [1] suggests, without a hint of irony.

title: Confident Obama Knows Wild Cards Can Loom Large
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to address the state of the union on Tuesday night, the state of his presidency has been improving lately  thanks to encouraging economic news as well as divisive infighting among Republicans.

title: In Advance of Releasing Returns, Romney Shifts Tax Discussion
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney waved aside the issue of his taxes returns, saying that his release of two years worth tomorrow would satisfy the American people.

title: Coping With Mistakes That Time Wont Erase
description: The text message lit up Rob Ashs cellphone Monday morning. It read: Coach, Im O.K. Im a fighter. It came from Billy Cundiff, whom Ash knows as the clutch, confident kicker who grabbed the job at Drake University as a true freshman and never let go.

title: The Power Broker
description: After weeks of temporizing, Mitt Romney said he plans to release a small slice of his tax records on Tuesday  his 2010 returns and an estimate for his 2011 taxes. It is not enough. American voters need to know a lot more about the business interests that Mr. Romney says make him the best candidate to be president. (President Obama, after all, released eight years worth of tax records during the 2008 campaign; Mr. Romneys father, George, released 12 years worth when he ran for president in 1968.)

title: Testimony From Paterno Is No Longer Admissible
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The death of Joe Paterno on Sunday will partly weaken the states prosecution of two former university officials who have been charged in connection with the child sexual abuse case involving Jerry Sandusky.

title: Live Blog: Republican Debate in Tampa, Fla.
description: The coming clash between Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney will be the featured attraction at the University of South Florida on Monday, where the two men and their rivals, Rick Santorum and Ron Paul, meet for the first of two debates this week. The 90-minute face-off begins at 9 p.m. Eastern and will be broadcast on NBC.

title: In Shift, Romney Assails Gingrich Relentlessly at Debate
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The clash that had to happen just did, and it marked a shift in Mitt Romneys approach.

title: Iranian Adviser Accuses Brazil of Ruining Relations
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Irans efforts to cultivate political support in Latin America at a time of rising international tension over its nuclear program appear to have encountered a significant obstacle: Brazil, the regions economic powerhouse.

title: Giffords Visits Food Bank That Her Well-Wishers Aided
description: TUCSON  Just before Christmas 2010, Representative Gabrielle Giffords took her staff to the Community Food Bank of Southern Arizona here so they could see firsthand how the organization was helping the less fortunate during the recession.

title: Markets Are Not Convinced by a New Leader at RIM
description: OTTAWA  Thorsten Heins, the newly appointed chief executive of the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion, introduced himself to skeptical securities analysts on Monday and shares of the company fell 8.5 percent.

title: An Assault on Democracy
description: President Rafael Correa of Ecuador is leading a relentless campaign against free speech, harassing his critics, forcing independent broadcasters off the air and hijacking the nations courts in his bid to bankrupt the countrys largest newspaper.

title: Darned Thing
description: Administrivial Fun Contest Alert! Love both music and puzzles? The very talented and extremely dangerous Patrick Blindauer is offering his Puzzlefest once again, and this time it is a suite of music-themed crossword puzzles for the low, low price of $9.95. If you submit your answer by February 15, you will be entered into a drawing to win some semi-valuable prizes, but more importantly, you will have a blast. Click here for more info.

title: Carters Poignant Turns, Chronicled by a Daughter
description: Like her father, Gary Carter, Kimmy Bloemers was a catcher. She played at Florida State. He spent most of his Hall of Fame career with the Montreal Expos and the Mets.

Before the show begins, the audience is invited to take a tour of the stage cum movie studio where it will be performed.

title: Montana Takes on Citizens United
description: Two years ago, when the Supreme Court struck down bans on independent corporate and union expenditures in elections in the Citizens United case, Justice Anthony Kennedys majority opinion claimed that money does not give rise to corruption or the appearance of corruption. While it might result in influence over or access to elected officials, he wrote, it is not the same as bribery.

title: In a Rape Trial, Two Accounts of Acts by a Man With Royal Ties
description: It began as the sort of encounter that happens often and without note in the bars of Manhattan: an older married man vying for the attention of younger women with Champagne and meals at marquee hotels.

title: Saving Lives in New Jersey
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey acted in the public interest when he signed a long-overdue bill that permits pharmacies to sell a limited number of syringes to individuals without prescriptions. This new law will save lives across the state by slowing the spread of blood-borne viruses like H.I.V.

description: WELLFLEET, Mass.  When a single dolphin washed up on Cape Cod on Jan. 12, it was nothing out of the ordinary.

title: In Police Training, a Dark Film on U.S. Muslims
description: Ominous music plays as images appear on the screen: Muslim terrorists shoot Christians in the head, car bombs explode, executed children lie covered by sheets and a doctored photograph shows an Islamic flag flying over the White House.

title: Sex Offender Pleads Guilty in a Womans 2008 Killing
description: A 26-year-old sex offender pleaded guilty on Monday to killing a young Brooklyn woman who disappeared after leaving a popular nightclub in Chelsea more than three years ago, the mans lawyer said.

title: Rangers Rookie Hagelin Is Finding His Own Way
description: During his final semester at the University of Michigan last year, Carl Hagelin, a rookie forward with electrifying speed on the first-place Rangers, was an intern at a private equity company in Ann Arbor. The Web site of the company, Amherst Fund, still includes a brief profile on him: Hagelin analyzes portfolio holdings, market analyses of individual portfolio companies as well as financial pro-forma modeling analysis. Carl is captain of the University of Michigan hockey team and hopes to play professional hockey after his graduation this spring.

title: Romneys Self-Deportation Solution
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney said that his immigration plans relied on what he called self-deportation of illegal immigrants.

title: Archbishop Robert F. Sanchez, Who Fought Discrimination, Dies at 77
description: Archbishop Robert F. Sanchez, who as the nations first Hispanic archbishop fought discrimination within the Roman Catholic Church, but who  resigned in 1993 while facing accusations that he had had sex with several women when they were teenagers, died on Friday in Albuquerque. He was 77.

title: Romney Unleashes Attack With Gingrich Sole Target
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney leveled a searing attack against Newt Gingrichs character and raised pointed questions about his ability to lead during a debate here Monday evening, taking urgent steps to slow Mr. Gingrichs rising momentum in the fight for the Republican presidential nomination.

description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Few places in the world have drawn guests like those who made it behind the pink walls of Sunnylands, the Walter H. Annenberg estate here in the desert.

title: Philip Vannatter, 70, Dies; O. J. Simpson Investigator
description: Philip Vannatter, who as a Los Angeles police detective helped lead the investigation of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman in 1994 and who was a major prosecution witness in the failed attempt to convict O. J. Simpson of the crime, died on Friday in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 70.

title: A New Life for a Former Home to Luminaries
description: The home built by Walter H. and Leonore Annenberg 46 years ago in Rancho Mirage, Calif., was once the place to go for the powerful and celebrities luxuriating in nearby Palm Springs. Now it is about to lift its veil.

title: Remembering Andy Musser, a Gentleman of the Press Box
description: Whenever I write a long feature story, I try to quote everyone I interviewed. I feel like I owe it to them, for helping me. Ive been interviewed for stories but left out of the article, and its not a good feeling.

title: Federer Looks for a Way Past del Potro
description: After losing to Juan Martn del Potro in a heartbreaking five-set match in the United States Open final in 2009, Roger Federer did a rigorous post-mortem of the match and came up with a reason why he had lost. He served for a two-sets-to-love lead against del Potro, and seemed to have the match in hand.

title: Tampa, Fla., Debate Fact-Check
description: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates in Thursday nights debate.

title: Federer and Nadal to Meet in Australian Open Semifinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was killing Roger Federer the last time he played Rafael Nadal at the Australian Open. Now after a day and night when both champions were in classic form, Federer will get his rematch.

title: With DNA Testing, Suddenly They Are Family
description: ST. LOUIS  Growing up, Khrys Vaughan always believed that she had inherited her looks and mannerisms from her father, and that her appreciation for tradition and old-fashioned gentility stemmed from her parents Southern roots. But those facets of her self-image crumbled when she was told, at age 42, that she had been adopted.

title: U.S. Faulted Over Pay at Rescued Firms
description: Federal auditors said that the government failed to rein in executive compensation at the biggest companies it bailed out during the financial crisis because its main concern was simply getting its money back.

title: The Pregame Show (of Commercials) Begins
description: IT was only four years ago that the New York Giants and the New England Patriots last played in the Super Bowl. But the behavior of Super Bowl sponsors has changed significantly since then, reflecting the surging popularity of social media.

title: Might Davos Be a Layover for Chinese Migratory Birds?
description: HONG KONG  Chinese business executives have become increasingly prominent at the World Economic Forum in recent years, arriving with larger entourages and throwing splashier parties  as befits their enhanced economic standing.

title: The IHT Is Taking Your Questions to Davos
description: A team of business and economics reporters from the International Herald Tribune has its boots on the ground this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. They will be interviewing and speaking with some of the worlds most influential leaders in government, business, academia, philanthropy and public service. What are the issues of most concern to you? What would you ask the attendees? Better yet, what can we ask them for you?Submit your queries in the comments field.

title: Too Much Restraint? Or Not Enough?
description: Austerity doesnt save. It sinks. So reads a somber mural on a concrete wall in Oporto, Portugal, depicting a nose-diving submarine.

title: Occupy Protesters Build Igloos in Switzerland to Protest Economic Summit
description: The eviction of Occupy Wall Street from Zuccotti Park in November left protesters without the physical birthplace of the movement around which to rally, and put something of a chill on the endeavor. In Switzerland, protesters of the World Economic Forum have made the movement even chillier.

title: Romney Cant Rumble
description: Mitt Romney just doesnt know how to rumble. It comes across as more of a fumble. Sometimes a mumble. And ultimately a stumble.

description: Susan Saulny reports from Florida on the issue of the foreclosure crisis at Monday's debate. While the candidates offered little specifics, it's a dominant issue for voters.

title: Player Ratings: One Mans Rules
description: Player ratings in soccer are by definition a subjective measure. One persons 6 is another mans 4. And since no two people view players or the game the same way, that is not likely to change. But because some readers have asked, John Godfrey  who regularly contributes ratings to the Goal blog  offers a few insights into what hes thinking when he fills out his report card.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 24, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Jan. 24, 1965 | Winston Churchill Dies
description: On Jan. 24, 1965, former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill died in London at age 90, nine days after suffering a severe stroke. Winston Churchills struggle for life ended this morning, and the people he had cherished and inspired and led through darkness mourned him as they have no other in this age, The New York Times reported.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 24, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article In Liverpool, Moment of Silence Followed by Impassioned Roar.

title: Senior Bowl, Day 1 Impressions

title: Gabrielle Giffords Resigns From Congress

title: Focusing on the Hidden History
description: Perched somewhere above a We Buy Gold joint and a Latin restaurant on Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx, a darkroom turned storage closet was once a repository for an almost overlooked visual history. It was an unlikely spot for an equally unlikely  and unrivaled  collection that now comprises 700 photographs by Latino, African-American and Asian photographers and other artists of color.

title: At Senior Bowl, a Wide Receiver Graduate Seminar
description: MOBILE, Ala.  To the untrained eye, a good wide receiver is a player who can run fast, jump high and catch the ball by any means necessary. This is a basic truth about the position, but there are several explosive athletes who can catch but never succeed in the N.F.L. Thats because of the complexity of the pro game.

title: Intel About Rushdie Threats Was Real, Rajasthan Says
description: Author Salman Rushdie cancelled an appearance at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which wraps up today, after he was informed by festival organizers of attempts against his life. News reports have cast doubts about that intelligence in recent days, suggesting it was fabricated, and Mr. Rushdie said he thinks he was lied to. Those doubts are baseless, the Rajasthan State government said in a statement issued late Monday evening. The full statement is below:

title: What Would You Like to Learn on Your Own?
description: After homework, extracurricular activities, social life and leisure, you may have little time to do anything else. But have you ever made an effort to learn about something outside the classroom, not related to anything youre studying in school? How would you use a daily learning hour?

title: Siemens, a German Bellwether, Reports a Decline in Profit
description: FREIBURG, Germany  Siemens, an electronics and engineering giant that is a bellwether for German industry, said on Tuesday that profit and new orders fell late last year as the European debt crisis made customers more cautious about investing in new projects.

description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

description: If you build it, they will code.

title: Sounding an Alarm on Birds and Mercury
description: It was in 2005 that I first accompanied David Evers into the cool dampness of a Catskills forest. At the time, Dr. Evers, a biologist and director of the Biodiversity Research Institute in Gorham, Me., was hunting for some pretty small game. He had draped a net between several trees in a section of the forest in upstate New York and, with the help of a portable cassette player that replicated the sound of songbirds trilling merrily away, was luring tiny wood thrushes into the trap.

title: An Interview With Donatella Versace
description: Suzy Menkes speaks to the designer about her choice to return to the haute couture calendar, who the true clients are for her elaborate designs and how the brand is reaching a younger consumer.

description: After weeks of speculation and grappling with rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romneys campaign released details of his tax returns on Tuesday morning. title: Calling Mr. DeMille

There was a crowd outside Versace, though nothing like the crowd that would be waiting at Dior a few hours later.

title: Who Should Take the Stage at Dior?
description: It has been about a year since John Gallianos scandalous departure from Christian Dior  and still no successor has been announced. Oh, there have been rumors, lots of them  although Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said Monday that the suspense will continue.

title: Image of the Day: January 24
Daily Report: Europe Considers a Tough Online Privacy Law
description: Europe is considering a sweeping new law that would force Internet companies like Amazon.com and Facebook to obtain explicit consent from consumers about the use of their personal data, delete that data forever at the consumers request and face fines for failing to comply, Somini Sengupta reports in Tuesdays Times.

title: Free Homes, Gracias Chvez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Cacique Tiuna, the Socialist housing commune being built here shows just how the government is planning to leverage housing to its advantage ahead of the presidential election in October. Over a thousand families have been settled in apartments over the last few months  for many, its the first time living outside a self-built shack in a shantytown. The housing project is something of a flagship for President Hugo Chvezs plans to resettle the more than 120,000 people who lost their shanties to flooding in 2010.

title: Smartphone Sales Are Strong, but Verizon Has a Loss
description: Verizon Communications on Tuesday reported rising iPhone sales and revenue growth in its wireless business, but it booked a quarterly loss, primarily because of previously announced pension charges.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Digital Privacy Makes a Comeback
description: The Republican presidential debate in Tampa, Fla., could be summed up like this: different audience, different debate. The invective was as high as in recent debates in South Carolina, with a newly aggressive Mitt Romney saying that Newt Gingrich, as a consultant to the mortgage giant Freddie Mac, had been an influence peddler. But without the raucous audiences of South Carolina, the event seemed more sedate, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write.

title: A Tale Of Two Bubbles

The latest evilness Ive learned about in comments and correspondence is that I have a double standard on bubbles  I talk about the Bush housing bubble, but I never said a word about the Clinton stock bubble.

title: A New G-Shock Watch Awaits a New Bluetooth
description: As one Las Vegas cab driver told me, the International Consumer Electronics Show held earlier this month seems to be in an economic bubble all its own. The big fashion industry convention show was down, from 80,000 attendees to 40,000, he said. But C.E.S. didnt seem to get the e-mail that were in an economic slump.

title: Twitter Acquires Second Security Firm in Three Months
description: If recent acquisitions are any indication, Twitter is beefing up security on its site.

title: De-Coding Jefferson Hacks New Shoes for Tods
description: My first Tods piece was a gommini loafer, says Jefferson Hack, the Dazed & Confused co-founder and editor of AnOther and AnOther Man magazines. Diego [Della Valle] invited me to have it made to my personal specifications, as I was not a typical Tods customer. And so it began. One trip to the companys headquarters in Le Marche, Italy, and Della Valle, the C.E.O., was asking Hack to design a capsule collection that would bring the British editors subversive-cool aesthetic to the storied Italian house. Featuring seven styles (four for women, three for men) including a sea-blue suede lace-up ankle shoe and a patent leather slipper flat, the collection breaks with convention and is untethered to the formal codes of dress or casual attire, says Della Valle, by way of explaining the capsules name: No-Code.

title: State Department Defends Leno After Joke Offends Sikhs
description: Though most comedians hope that their material stands on its own, some additional support from their country now and then doesnt hurt either: The State Department stood up for Jay Leno after the Tonight Show host offended some Indian Sikhs with a joke that implied that a holy shrine in India was a home owned by Mitt Romney.

title: Renowned Spanish Judge Goes on Trial, Accused of Abusing Power
description: MADRID  Baltasar Garzn, a high-profile Spanish judge who garnered international renown by pursuing political leaders, including Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, was himself on trial on Tuesday over accusations that he had abused his powers to investigate atrocities committed during the Spanish Civil War.

title: After a Dispute With Official, Mirza and Vesnina Win Doubles Match
description: MELBOURNE, AustraliaControversial officiating again became a factor in the decisive stages of a match at the 2012 Australian Open, as a womens doubles quarterfinal was extended past what should have been the final point by an incorrect call.

description: WEST PALM BEACH, FLA.  When Mitt Romney pulled in for a campaign rally here recently, he pointedly left his tough stance against illegal immigration far behind in South Carolina, where he had trumpeted the issue repeatedly.

title: Jared Bernstein On The Summers Memo
description: Jared makes the best case for arguing that Larry wasnt really worrying about the invisible bond vigilantes. Thats still not how I read it, but again, its water under the bridge.

title: India Art Fair Goes International
description: The India Art Fair, one of the biggest art exhibitions in South Asia, opens in New Delhi on Wednesday. The five-day event brings together a host of artists, curators, critics, dealers and collectors from across the globe, and this year will draw ninety-one galleries from twenty countries, representing the work of a thousand contemporary and modern artists.

title: Deadly Confrontation Spreads in Tibetan Region of China
description: HONG KONG  Deadly showdowns between Chinese security forces and Tibetans in a restive region of western China spread to a second town on Tuesday, outside advocacy groups reported. At least two and perhaps as many as five Tibetans were killed by gunfire and many more wounded, the groups said, in what appeared to be the most violent outbreak in the region in nearly four years.

title: Tuesday Reading: Women May Suffer More From Pain
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Wanted: Parking Space for Nuclear Waste
description: When the Obama administration killed a plan to create a nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, the government established a blue-ribbon commission to study what to do next. Its final report is due on Sunday, and this week three organizations began a public lobbying campaign for several of the recommendations that they assume the commission will make.

title: For Butler, a Pivotal Road Trip
description: In 2010 and 2011, the Butler Bulldogs were college basketballs favorite Cinderella story. But this season has been a struggle. Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, will file occasional posts for The Quad about the teams efforts to return to the N.C.A.A. tournament.The Butler mens basketball team started off its longest road trip of the season with wins over Illinois-Chicago and Loyola this past weekend. Playing at Loyolas newly renovated Gentile Center on Saturday, the Bulldogs were able to cope with a hostile environment and earn a 63-57 victory.

title: Without a Ravenous Crowd, Gingrich Stumbles in the First Florida Debate
description: Many Republican voters in South Carolina said that much of Newt Gingrichs appeal stemmed from his masterly debating skills. They believed he deftly made brilliant points, was vastly knowledgeable on his feet, and brutally shut down his opponents, and they dreamed of his doing the same thing to President Obama.

title: HSBC Sells Latin American Businesses
description: LONDON  HSBC, one of Europes biggest banks, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its businesses in Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras for $801 million as part of its plan to focus on more profitable operations.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Daily Beast.com: In the end, it always comes down to food and drink. The beer test rule in the presidential election, according to the Democratic Party partisan Paul Begala, rates a politicians electability by whether voters would like to have a few beers with the candidate. Mitt Romney is challenged, he claims, because you get the feeling hed be stiff even over a chocolate shake.  Glenn Collins

title: Best Sellers From a Vanished World
description: In the last two months, five million or so people got a Kindle Fire. Some of them were upgrading from earlier Kindles. They know the ropes. But millions of others must be new at this, and are stumbling around with their tablets looking for content. If they are like the rest of us and still paying the holiday bills, they want it free. That would be Angry Birds, of course, but also the Kindle Top 100 Free best-seller list. Some of these books are out of copyright  Dracula, Jane Austen  and some seem to have originated with Amazon itself. But at the top and interspersed all the way through are novels written by living if somewhat obscure authors. Romances, mostly, often with a Christian theme.

title: Model-Morphosis | Aymeline Valade at Christian Dior Couture
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2012 Couture collections in Paris. Here, the model Aymeline Valade before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Parsing the Surprises and the Snubs
description: 10:26 a.m. | Updated  As usual, the Bagger and other Oscar watchers were in for some surprises with the nominations on Tuesday morning, starting with the number of nominees. Few predicted that there would be a field of nine best picture contenders, and fewer still  hardly anyone  expected that one of those would be Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close, Stephen Daldrys adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foers post-9/11 novel. The film also earned a best supporting actor nod for its 82-year-old star, Max von Sydow. Gasps were heard from the press and others assembled in the announcement room when the poorly reviewed film was called.

description: The foreign-language Oscar category delivered two surprises Tuesday morning: the choice of Bullhead, Belgiums unexpected submission, and the absence of Wim Wenderss Pina, Germanys submission. The three strongest films in the shortlist of nine made public last week were clearly  Irans Separation,  Israels Footnote and Canadas Monsieur Lazhar, and all three, as expected, received nominations, leaving only two spots to be fought over by the six other contenders.

description: Paul Simon and Wynton Marsalis will give three concerts together in April, performing Mr. Simons songs in a rare collaboration between one of the leading pop song writers of the last 50 years and the virtuoso jazz trumpet player, Jazz at Lincoln Center announced Tuesday. The concerts will be staged at the Rose Theater at the organizations headquarters on Columbus Circle.

title: For Those Keeping Score:  Streep Sets a Record; Scorsese Has a Chance at One

As the Baggers colleagues Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes have noted, Meryl Streep becomes the most-nominated actor in history, with 17 nominations to Jack Nicholson and Katharine Hepburns dozen each. I am honored to be in company with such beautiful artists, and touched deeply by my fellow actors for their generosity in giving me this acknowledgment, she said in a statement.

title: Putting Cash Under the Mattress Is So Old School
description: With rates on savings accounts dwindling, you might be tempted to stash a little cash at home.

title: Alison Returns, but Not on Dominick Street
description: Alison Eighteen, Alison Price Beckers return to the Manhattan restaurant scene after an absence of almost 10 years, will evoke memories of her former restaurant, Alison on Dominick Street, when it opens next Tuesday. The chef, Robert Gurvich, is back, and the same designers, Asfour Guzy, have created the new Alison.

title: Dior: Holding Couture to the Light
description: At 2:30 p.m. Monday, I arrived at Dior, on Avenue Montaigne. Whenever couture is shown in the house, in the grand salons on the third floor, an enormous throng of spectators and paparazzi gathers outside. It sounds far more glamorous than it really is. As I reached the main door, a black-suited security guard bellowed at people to clear the area so a guests car could pull up.

title: Boston University, Where Academic Rigor Is de Rigueur
description: There is an assumption, including among more than a few incredulous parents, that high school seniors often choose their colleges based less on academic offerings than on softer factors like campus amenities (think climbing walls and walk-in, dorm-room closets), the ratio of men to women in the class and even the institutions tolerance for keg parties.

title: Dj Supe
description: Let us be the first to welcome you to Super Bowl matchup hangover day. This is the day when all the giddiness about the conference championship games fades and the excitement about a potentially thrilling Super Bowl is superseded by the knowledge that for the next 12 days you will be overrun by stories about two teams. Making heads throb even worse in much of the country, those two teams are from the New York and Boston areas, which is why Mike Vaccaro of The Post took today to apologize to the rest of the nation. We second his thought. Hang in there.

title: On Our Radar: Solar Kits for Haitians
description: Haitis president says he aims to double the number of rural households with electricity within two years by offering people loans to buy solar kits that can charge cellphones or computers. The $40 million program also calls for installing streetlights in the countryside and repairing power lines in the capital. Only 30 percent of the countrys population is estimated to have access to electricity. [Associated Press]

title: Romney Attacks Obamas Address as Nothing More Than Tall Tales
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney on Tuesday charged that President Obamas State of the Union speech will be nothing more than partisan plans for his re-election campaign, and tall tales about America.

title: Paris Top 5 | Ami
description: Arriving in Paris Wednesday night, I went straight from Charles de Gaulle airport to a trs Parisienne apartment off Place de la Republique for the designer Alexandre Mattiussis cocktail-party-as-fashion-presentation for Ami. Though Champagne and cigarettes abounded, this was no chic Rive Gauche affair; more like the Williamsburg-on-the-Seine scene of Rue Oberkampf or, as our in-the-know illustrator Richard Haines said: So Bushwick L train/Morgan stop. So true. It was an ber-groovy crowd  hard to discern the models from the viewers  and a perfect welcome to the final leg of the European fashion show season. Whats more, it heralded the arrival of this new French sportswear brand, following the model of A.P.C., with its cult following and affordable prices. Quirky outfits like short leather bombers and trim tweed coats layered over colored sweaters and clashing untucked shirts (with the odd floral or plaid here and there) felt more like great personal style statements than forced fashion. A bright-eyed bearded fellow wore a tee with a floralized bearded fellow on it, along with a harvest-colored houndstooth vest, matching carrot-cut pants (imagine a slightly dropped crotch with full legs that narrow at the cuff) and a tonal, double-breasted plaid coat; an amusing outfit with Parisian charm that had me at Bon soir.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Coughlin vs. Belichick? Manning vs. Brady? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

title: From Far Back in the Pack to the Lead in War Horse
description: Before he went Hollywood, the thoroughbred gelding Finders Key accounted for only torn-up mutuel tickets at Los Alamitos Race Course, a track better known for quarter horse racing in Orange County, Calif. Winless in four $2,500 claiming races, he was beaten by a combined 30 lengths, never finishing higher than fifth.

title: If Its The Artist vs. Hugo, Hollywood Self-References Win
description: 11:23 a.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELESIf you accept the theory advanced by some here that the Oscar race is now a showdown between The Artist and Hugo, then you are facing one of the weirder matchups in Academy Awards history. Both films are about the film business. But from Hollywoods point of view, one picture comes from the outside and looks in, the other comes from the inside and looks out.

title: Flying the Friendly Skies of Chanel Couture
description: Karl Lagerfeld spends enough time in the air to eventually think it might be a hoot to stage a Chanel show inside an airplane. He has had icebergs hauled to Paris. He has created farm scenes, a formal garden and a monument to the quilted bag, all in the Grand Palais. Whats an airplane, with a drinks cart and fake clouds floating past the windows?

title: Springsteen Announces U.S. Tour Dates
description: Bruce Springsteen announced on Tuesday the dates for this years Wrecking Ball tour, and they include two concerts at Madison Square Garden, two gigs at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., and his first concert at the Prudential Center in Newark. The United States leg of the tour will kick off in Atlanta on March 18, a week and a half after Mr. Springsteens new album is to be released on Columbia Records. This tour is the first Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band have done since the groups longtime saxophonist, Clarence Clemons, died last year.

title: Bryan Twins Win Midnight Marathon
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Bob and Mike Bryan of the United States outlasted Marcin Matkowski and Mariusz Fyrstenberg of Poland in a three-set marathon, 6-4, 6-7 (4), 6-4, to gain the semifinals of the Australian Open.

title: The Candidates Tax Returns
description: Comparing President Obama and Mitt Romneys tax returns for 2011 to the typical taxpayer and the top 0.1 percent.

title: A Good Day for Woody Allen and Sony Pictures Classics
description: LOS ANGELES  Is this the year Woody Allen warms up to the Oscars?

title: Where Our Readers #WanttoGo in 2012
description: For our 45 Places to Go in 2012 article we asked readers to tell us on Twitter where they want to go this year. Some highlights are below. Join the conversation in the comments below and tell us where you want to go in 2012.

title: Police Gang Tyrannized Latinos, Indictment Says
description: They were known as Millers Boys, police officers who worked the 4-to-midnight shift, patrolling the largely working-class town of East Haven, Conn., including the small but growing Hispanic community that has spread out in recent years from New Haven.

title: The Men Who Didnt Run
description: Dismissing the argument in my previous post, Daniel Larison suggests that none of the alternative candidates for the Republican nomination possesses the unique skill set that my Sunday column identified as crucial to a successful presidential contender:

title: Just One Look | Christian Dior
description: For the second season the house of Christian Dior has offered an haute couture collection without announcing a successor to its prior couturier, John Galliano. For spring/summer 2012 the atelier (helmed by Bill Gaytten) went back to the archives and rendered classic Dior silhouettes in translucent organdy. The idea was to create dresses that resembled X-ray images of Mr. Diors original designs (as if the pieces had been photographed by the likes of Nick Knight). For the clients it offers a rare opportunity to buy something classically Dior. So why not a ballgown? This one, in black silk, has a bodice of trapped sequins and a swirling skirt of pliss.

title: Egypt Military Council Partly Curbs State of Emergency Law
description: CAIRO  The army officer acting as Egypts de facto head of state said Tuesday that the military government would limit its use of extrajudicial arrests and detentions to cases of what he called thuggery.

title: I.M.F. Trims Estimates for Global Growth on Sharply Escalating Risks in Europe
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that global growth prospects had dimmed as the sovereign debt crisis in the euro zone entered a perilous new phase.

title: Can the Cowman and the Panther Coexist?
description: Ranchers in south Florida have long been accustomed to losing calves to coyotes, buzzards, even alligators. They may have to steel themselves for another predator: the Florida panther.

title: Boehner Offers His 2 Cents on Romneys Tax Rate
description: Speaker John A. Boehner offered an economic justification on Tuesday for the relatively low tax rate paid on investments by taxpayers like Mitt Romney, and House Republicans fired off more criticism of President Obama in advance of his State of the Union address.

title: When Breast Isnt Best: Outcry Over Comics Post
description: Two months after she gave birth to twins, Ahna Tessler was feeling confined in her Manhattan apartment and in need of artistic expression. So on Jan. 14 Ms. Tessler, a comedian who lives on the Upper West Side, did what came naturally: she recorded a humorous skit that incorporated her routine of breast-feeding her babies, Madelyn and Elliot, and tried to post the video on the online comedy site Funny or Die.

title: Timberwolves Work on Extension for Love
description: There is little doubt that power forward/center Kevin Love should be a keeper for the Minnesota Timberwolves. Hes averaging a career-high 24.9 points and 13.9 rebounds per game and logging more than 39 minutes.

title: Poll: Partisan Split Over Tax Policies
description: It may come as no surprise, but Americans are deeply split along party lines when it comes to federal tax policy.

title: Brown Fat, Triggered by Cold or Exercise, May Yield a Key to Weight Control
description: Fat people have less than thin people. Older people have less than younger people. Men have less than younger women.

title: Joseph Murphy Named Pastry Chef at Jean Georges
description: Joseph Murphy has replaced Johnny Iuzzini as executive pastry chef at Jean Georges. Mr. Murphy has been the corporate pastry chef for Jean-Georges Management and the executive pastry chef of BLT Market and the Ritz-Carton New York. Mr. Iuzzini resigned at the end of last year.

title: Yale Turns To Royal Shakespeare Company For Its New Playwriting Chair
description: The Yale School of Drama announced on Monday that Jeanie OHare, the company dramaturg for the Royal Shakespeare Company, would succeed Paula Vogel as chair of the Yale playwriting department beginning July 1.

title: Morgan Stanley Names Managing Directors
description: Morgan Stanley said on Tuesday that it had named 210 new managing directors, down from last years class of 232.

title: The Buffett Rule Isnt About Mitt Romney. Or Is It?
description: There are two words that President Obama is unlikely to utter when he talks about tax fairness during the State of the Union address: Mitt Romney.

title: Austerity Could Again Sow Seeds of Extremism in Europe
description: NEW YORK  Does this sound familiar?

title: Face Time | Rachel Roy
description: Rachel Roy is constantly in motion, with a namesake fashion collection and diffusion line, Rachel Rachel Roy, various collaborations and charitable work. The designer has even dabbled in makeup, creating a signature day-to-night eye shadow palette that stores couldnt keep in stock. Next up: a partnership with OrphanAid Africa, an organization that benefits children in need. She also has two daughters, and is beautiful to boot! Naturally, I had some questions.

title: Abu Dhabi Greenlights Its Mega-Museum Project
description: It was on. Then it was off. Now its back on again. The executive council of Abu Dhabi announced through its website on Monday that it had approved construction plans for its multi-billion-dollar vision for a cultural tourist center to be constructed on an island just off the coast of the city, a hub that will include branches of the Guggenheim and the Louvre museums.

title: For BMW ActiveE, a Home Base That Speaks Fluent E.V.
description: BMW and Tendril, an energy management company, are developing a fully wired home to house the automakers electric ActiveE sedan.

title: The Thrill of the Nod for Viola Davis, Brad Pitt and Gary Oldman
description: Calm. Excited for a fellow nominee. Deeply touched. When it comes to reactions to their good fortune, this years nominees are a rather diplomatic bunch. Viola Davis, Brad Pitt and Gary Oldman shared their initial impressions with us:

title: City Bakery Chef Opens 606 R&D
description: Ilene Rosen, who left City Bakery last summer after 15 years of overseeing the savory dishes, and Sara Dima, who managed the bakery there, are opening 606 R&D, a small homestyle restaurant and bar.

title: Photos of the Moment | Christian Dior
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Putting Candidates Tax Rates in Perspective
description: Here is a quick way to put the recent flurry of tax numbers into perspective: Newt Gingrich and President Obama each pay a federal tax rate typical of most affluent Americans, with rates well above those of many middle-class households. Mitt Romney pays a federal tax rate more typical of an upper-middle-class household making perhaps $80,000 a year  higher than the rate of most households but not enormously so.

title: Punk-Rock History? Or Just a Leather Jacket?
description: Updated, Jan. 25 The contested jacket was withdrawn from auction. Read the follow-up

title: State of the Union Wish List
description: Despite what some paranoid people on the Internet seem to think, the New York Times editorial board does not write the presidents speeches (and his speechwriters dont draft our editorials). But with some regularity we discuss what we wish Barack Obama would say. And, of course, we always have a lot of opinions about what he said  and no, they are not always positive..

title: Bradley Revives Boston Defense With One-Man Press
description: The Boston Celtics defensive domination over the Orlando Magic on Monday night was comprehensive and unrelenting. It began with a statement first quarter; the Celtics held the Magic - who at the time boasted the N.B.A.s second-best offense - to 6-of-18 shooting from the field in the opening frame. Boston allowed just 20 points for the quarter  an impressive mark on its own and a lofty benchmark for the Celtics D the rest of the way.

title: For Romneys, Friendly Code Reduces Taxes
description: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, made $27 million in 2010. They held millions of dollars in a Swiss bank account and millions more in partnerships in the Cayman Islands. His familys trusts sold thousands of shares in Goldman Sachs that were offered to favored clients when the storied investment house first went public. The couples effective federal tax rate for the year worked out to 13.9 percent, a rate typical of households earning about $80,000 a year.

title: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
description: For the Couture edition of The Daily Shoe, T picks the most exquisite made-to-measures.

title: Adoption and the DNA Family Search
description: Many (although far from all) adult adoptees are frustrated by their lack of access to their biological past. The relative openness of adoption records varies from state to state and from year to year, and while many adult adoptees have searched for and found birth relatives, their legal right to information is inconsistent at best. Last year, the adoption advocate Adam Pertman framed it as a civil rights issue: denying adult adoptees access to their original birth certificates, he said, is denying a minority group equal rights under the law.

title: Very Thin Film of Slick Reported from Stricken Cruise Ship
description: GIGLIO, Italy  Salvage and rescue workers reported the first sign of a significant contaminant slick beginning to ooze from the partly submerged Costa Concordia on Tuesday as divers recovered the sodden body of the 16th victim from the Jan. 13 shipwreck.

title: Documentarians and Animators Go Their Own Ways
description: 5:36 p.m. | Updated  Two groups of Academy voters have traditionally been independent-minded in their choices, and this year is no exception. The documentary branch, which has been roiled by  the changes to its nomination process that will affect selections in the coming years, still managed to have some noteworthy snubs this season, chief among them Project Nim.

title: SPX Sells Auto Tools Business for $1.15 Billion
description: The SPX Corporation, an industrial conglomerate, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its auto tools and solutions business to Robert Bosch of Germany for $1.15 billion in cash.

title: Reagan Count: Gingrich 55, Romney 6
description: In Monday nights debate in Tampa, Fla., Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, mentioned Ronald Reagan just four words into his first answer of the night. It was the first of five times that Mr. Gingrich would mention Reagan; no other candidate did so even once.

title: No Disrespect for the Meatball Hero
description: IF the meatball parmigiana hero were a Southern dish, scholars from Chapel Hill, N.C., to Tallahassee, Fla., would hold academic conferences every six months just to talk about it.

title: Parm
description: Inside Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbones Italian-American lunch counter on Mulberry Street.

title: The Difference Between a Good Web Site and a Great Web Site
description: In last weeks post, we featured the Web site of Bi-Rite Market, an extremely popular San Francisco grocery. One year ago, Sam Mogannam, the markets owner, redesigned the site and upgraded its social media efforts as part of an overall branding program. Mr. Mogannam reported that he believed the redesign of the site  which promotes the store but does not sell products online  resulted in a steep increase in visitors to the site and a 20 percent increase in the stores sales.

title: Scene City: Silent Party for Abramovic at Sundance
description: HBO held this high-concept party to celebrate Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present, a documentary playing at this years Sundance Film Festival.

title: TimesCast | January 24, 2012
description: Mitt Romney releases his tax returns | Activists mark the anniversary of the Egyptian revolution | Animated CliffsNotes

title: Silence for a Talkie
description: PARK CITY, Utah

title: Edmunds Says Kia Sales Rose 83 Percent in New York
description: Kia experienced exceptional growth in the New York metropolitan area in 2011, with sales increasing 83 percent, according to Edmunds.com. Its Web site compared new-car registration data provided by Polk, the automotive forecasting company, from January through November 2010 with the same 11-month period in 2011. Kias performance made it the fastest-growing automotive brand in the metropolitan area among the 35 brands included in the Edmunds analysis.

title: Mostly Dramas From White Men: Why Its a Conventional Best Picture List
description: LOS ANGELES  Stretched all the way to nine entries, the years field of best picture nominees says one thing loud and clear about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: It hasnt changed.

title: Without Money in Place, Rebecca Postpones Broadway Opening Until Next Season
description: The producers of the Broadway-bound musical Rebecca, which had been scheduled to begin performances on March 27, said on Tuesday that they were postponing the show until the 2012-13 season because they ran out of time to raise the productions $12 million capitalization. The musical, which had been set to begin rehearsals on Feb. 6, would have been one of the most expensive of the 2011-12 theater season, but the producers were widely known around Broadway to be struggling to raise the final 20 percent of the shows budget.

title: Mitt and Ann Romneys Tax Returns
description: The Romney campaign released Mitt Romneys tax returns on Tuesday.

title: Off the Wall | Alison Eighteens Biographical Toile
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Is It Too Early for a Song of the Summer?
description: The quest to name a song of the summer has become both more scientific and more quixotic  in part because were all entombed in our earbuds now, listening to our niche, custom-curated music feeds, rather than communally riding down Main Street in low-riders blasting Steal My Sunshine. And, in part, because most of winter this year, at least in New York, feels weirdly like mid-April.

title: Big Down Payments Could Bar Creditworthy Borrowers From Market, Study Finds
description: Requiring a minimum down payment of 20 percent, or even 10 percent, on home loans would push many creditworthy borrowers into higher-cost loans or out of the mortgage market entirely, a new study says.

title: Looking Past the Skepticism on Fate of the Euro
description: PARIS  A decade after the euros birth as a full-fledged currency, the anniversary has been more a sickbed vigil than a celebration.

title: G.M., in Big Ad Move, Consolidates $3 Billion Media Account
description: General Motors, in another effort to cut costs, is consolidating most of an important advertising assignment known as media planning and buying, after pitting four giant media agencies against each other for the task.

title: Tyne Daly, Ben Vereen Among Theater Hall of Fame Inductees
description: The Theater Hall of Fame, which will hold its annual ceremony on Monday honoring lifetime achievement in American theater, has announced its new inductees. They are the actors Tyne Daly and Ben Vereen; the directors Daniel Sullivan and, posthumously, Paul Sills; the costumer designer Ann Roth; and the producers George C. White, Elliot Martin and Woodie King Jr.

title: All-American Religion or Reason to Worry?
description: The best musical number in The Book of Mormon, the Tony Award-winning play from the holy fools who created South Park, is a fantasia that features Hitler, Jeffrey Dahmer, Johnnie Cochran, Genghis Khan and dancing cups of Starbucks coffee. Its title is  Spooky Mormon Hell Dream.

title: Hackers Step Up Attacks After Megaupload Shutdown
description: Last week, after Wikipedia, Reddit and Boing Boing voluntarily blacked out their Web sites to protest proposed antipiracy legislation, hackers began their own blackouts with attacks on dozens of sites across the Internet.

title: Opening Arguments Set for Perelman Trial
description: Opening arguments are set to begin Tuesday afternoon in trial covering the dispute between the billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman and his former business partner.

title: The Buffett Rule Isnt About Mitt Romney. Or Is it?
description: Debbie Bosanek, who is Warren Buffetts secretary, will be joining Michelle Obama in the first ladys box seats during President Obamas State of the Union address, John H. Cushman Jr. reported for The New York Times Caucus blog. Read more

title: A Nominee Toasts His Good Fortune
description: Im already drunk! Demian Bichir announced when he called the Bagger from Mexico City on Tuesday morning, just a few hours after becoming a best actor nominee for his turn as an undocumented immigrant and gardener in A Better Life.

title: A Quirky Set of Technology Predictions for 2012
description: The yearly technology forecasting game tends to be too earnest and too obvious. In part, that is because when the big research houses, like IDC and Gartner, prepare their lists, it is a consensus of their analysts. And why not? The strength of the large research firms is their deep benches  the breadth and depth of their industry smarts. The results, though, are works of what today is called collective intelligence and what used to be called a committee.

title: Data Law in Works, But Tech Booms in Europe
description: Europe may be on the brink of passing what some tech firms and entrepreneurs view as a stifling law on data protection and the rights of consumers to have their data destroyed. But the chatter at an annual tech conference in Munich where E.U. Commissioner Viviane Reding laid out those data privacy plans this week seemed to be that the Web is booming on a continent better known lately for austerity and cutbacks.

title: The First Hours of Egypts Revolution
description: Egyptian activists and the military council that still rules the country are braced for planned demonstrations on Wednesday, the first anniversary of the start of the revolution that toppled former President Hosni Mubarak. Since our coverage of last years events was illuminated by online reports from activists who documented the uprising on social networks, The Lede discussed the anniversary with some of those bloggers.

title: Federer vs. Del Potro: Breaking It Down
description: The brilliance of Roger Federer is best found by not looking at Roger Federer at all.

title: Just One Look | Chanel
description: At Chanel haute couture, Karl Lagerfeld built the interior of an airplane in the attic of the Mini Palais and then set loose a collection of dresses rendered in every possible shade of sky. It soared. Each detail lifted the looks from cocktail to cool: the shoulder duster drop earrings in silver and sapphire, the mohawks and quiffs held high with jewels and feathers. Some of the loveliest frocks had voluminous sleeves and embroidery that nodded to Art Deco, like this short number edged in a fan and bird motif.

title: Officer Pleads Guilty to Civil Rights Violation
description: 5:01 p.m. | Updated  A white New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Tuesday to violating the civil rights of a black man on Staten Island by charging him with resisting arrest knowing that there was no probable cause to support the charge.

title: Wasting the Wastewater
description: Each day, American municipalities discharge treated wastewater back into natural sources at a rate that would fill an empty Lake Champlain within six months. Growing pressure on water supplies and calls for updating the ancient subterranean piping infrastructure have brought new scrutiny to this step in the treatment process, which is labeled wasteful and unnecessary by a spectrum of voices.

title: Peyton Manning a Cheerleader for His Brother
description: Peyton Manning spends most of his time in the Indianapolis Colts weight room now, in a desperate race to rehabilitate from the neck injury that cost him the 2011 season and could imperil his career. That was where he watched the Giants run to the Super Bowl, an extremely well-informed fan with an extremely deep rooting interest.

title: Global Research Awards Showcase Chinas Gains and Efforts to Retain Scientists
description: BEIJING  Chinas government has thrown billions in recent years into building a top-notch research establishment, hoping to keep its best scientists working here and lure back those who are abroad.

title: Council Panel Upholds a Historic Skyscraper District in Brooklyn
description: A historic district composed largely of early office towers in downtown Brooklyn was approved in its entirety Tuesday by the City Councils landmarks subcommittee, all but guaranteeing that the entire Council will ratify it in turn.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 24
description: A view of the day in sports, including Australian Open action and the departure of the Yankees Jorge Posada.

title: In a Plan to Close a Customs Post, Seeing Harm for Beer, Bananas and a Port Itself
description: The journey of a banana from Ecuador to Brooklyn is a precisely timed affair, from the moment it is sliced off a stalk and then packed onto a ship for a seven-day refrigerated cruise to the Red Hook Container Terminal. From there, the banana has one week to make it from container to distributor to grocery store.

title: For Posada, an Emotional Farewell
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated In the latter innings of his career, Jorge Posada faced the painful but inevitable slide of an aging star. Younger and more productive players pushed him lower and lower down the batting order, ultimately resulting in the only real public feud he had with his team.

title: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2012 Couture
description: Paris

title: French Bill on Genocide Is Denounced by Turkey
description: PARIS  The Turkish government and news media castigated France on Tuesday, accusing Parliament of racism and a breach of Frances own free speech principles after the French Senate passed a bill late Monday criminalizing the denial of officially recognized genocides, including the Armenian genocide begun in 1915.

title: Giorgio Armani Prive Couture
description: Paris

title: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Jack Bell, who covers soccer for The Times, will have answers to readers questions on the Goal blog on Wednesday.

title: Road Trip! But First, Saving Money as You Plan
description: Im not really your drive-across-America type  more of a train-through-India or Bolivia-by-bus kind of traveler. But Ive long wanted to do a road trip in Texas. For someone like me, who has never lived west of the Hudson, its perhaps the most fascinating state in the nation. Its vast without being empty, associated with powerful American symbols like cowboy boots and pickup trucks and high school football, carries more than half our border with Mexico, has at least a claim on the nations best barbecue (not to mention all that Tex-Mex), and has a long, complicated and fascinating history. Its at once as American as apple pie and as alien as another planet.

title: On the Stump: Examining the Form and Function of Campaign Speeches
description: Overview | What is a stump speech, and what makes one effective? In this lesson, students analyze the stump speeches of presidential candidates, then write the stump speech they would use if they were running for president.

title: Nascar and Ford Unveil Fusion Sprint Cup Car
description: Wearing the automakers new corporate face, the Ford Fusion Nascar Sprint Cup racecar was unveiled at a news conference by Ford and Nascar Tuesday afternoon at Charlotte Motor Speedway. The car will be campaigned in 2013, making its race debut at the Daytona 500 in February of next year.
