title: Rick Santorums Adventures on the Loony Right
description: There are moments in a political campaign when a sharply aimed question can reveal a great deal about the one thing that candidates most want to hide  their character.

title: Whats Your Response to Obamas Third State of the Union Address?
description: 10:55 p.m. | Updated The president of the United States gives an annual speech to Congress called the State of the Union address. President Obamas third such speech was Tuesday night  and delivered it as his re-election campaign, and the Republican presidential nominating contest, are under way. Did you watch the speech? What did you think of his remarks, and of the Republican rebuttal?

title: Oscars: Not the Usual Suspects
description: There were no major fashion plates among the Oscar nominees announced this morning, but that might provide for a more exciting red carpet at the Academy Awards.

title: Hey, Uggie, Christopher Plummer Wont Back Down
description: Im sleepy, but Im all right. That was a groggy Christopher Plummer today after he learned that he had received his second Academy Award nomination, this one for best supporting actor for Beginners. (Mr. Plummer was also nominated in that category in 2010, for The Last Station.)

title: European Central Bank Moves to Avoid Loss on Greek Bonds
description: LONDON  European leaders have begun discussions with the European Central Bank on several options that might keep it from having to take a loss on its 55 billion-euro portfolio of Greek bonds.

title: House and the Big House Lift Fox
description: With CBS in repeats it was a tight race among the broadcast networks on Monday night as Fox ultimately came out ahead in all ratings categories. House returned on Fox after an almost two-month absence, and Hugh Laurie fans were ready and waiting. The medical drama had its best numbers since October and drew 8.8 million viewers. Alcatraz, also on Fox, held its ground in its second week with only a modest drop to just under 9 million viewers from the 10 million who tuned in to last weeks premiere. It also dipped in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic by 10 percent.

title: Five Dishes at Parm
description: This week I review Parm, where Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone are serving food more or less taken from the Italian-American deli canon: Sausage and peppers, potato and eggs, garlic bread, pizza knots and all kinds of parms. I interviewed the two chefs earlier this week about five of the dishes I especially enjoyed.

title: Why Harry Potter Deserved More
description: Maybe the idea is that if the Academy nominates as many movies as possible across the various high-profile categories, more moviegoers will have a rooting interest and more people will watch. Tree of Life fans, Midnight in Paris fans, A Separation fans, Rango fans  just about everyone is theoretically covered.

title: Joining Mrs. Obama Will Be
description: The guests joining Michelle Obama in her box seats overlooking the House chamber for the presidents State of the Union speech on Tuesday night include Jill Biden, the vice presidents wife; Valerie Jarrett, the presidents senior adviser; and a panoply of ordinary and extraordinary people chosen as archetypes of the policies, priorities and accomplishments Mr. Obama will seek to emphasize.

title: Grief Could Join List of Disorders
description: When does a broken heart become a diagnosis?

title: Looking Outside of Schools for Science and Technology
TimesCast | Egypt's Revolution Continues
description: January 24, 2012  From Cairo, Robert Mackey of the Lede blog interviews Gigi Ibrahim, a liberal activist, on the first anniversary of the Egyptian revolution.

title: Givenchy: Spring 2012 Couture
description: Paris

title: Givenchy Couture
description: Paris

title: Union Radio Ad Assails Romney in Spanish
description: The Service Employees International Union began airing a Spanish-language radio spot in Florida on Tuesday that seeks to turn the states Hispanic voters against Mitt Romney by accusing him of being two-faced on immigration policy.

title: Apps for Children With Dyslexia
description: The parent of a second grader newly diagnosed with dyslexia wrote me asking if I knew of any apps that might help her son with reading and math. Shed searched and come up with nothing  and so did I, with the same result. There is software out there designed to help children with dyslexia read (expensive software) but nothing yet in the way of an app marketed for that purpose (and theres obviously no app that will fix dyslexia).

title: Hundreds of Restaurateurs Sound Off on Sanitary Inspections
description: The New York City Council will announce Wednesday that nearly 1,000 restaurant operators have responded, after only two weeks, to a Web survey seeking their views about the city health departments new letter-grading system for food safety.

title: A Bizarre Turn In The Stimulus Debate (Boring)
description: Wow. Just wow. John Cochrane puts up a post that to all appearances amounts to a complete retreat from his previous denunciations of deficit spending in a recession. But he simultaneously denies having ever held the position everyone thought he held, and denounces me and Brad DeLong as big meanies. Ill outsource the analysis to Noah Smith.

title: Goldman Makes Money for the Romneys
description: After a long, controversial wait, Mitt Romney released details of his federal tax returns on Tuesday, inciting a flurry of wide-eyed analysis from those curious to see exactly how Mr. Romneys personal finances stack up.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Star Dancer Quits Royal Ballet
description: Sergei Polunin, the dark-eyed phenom who was the youngest male dancer ever to be made a principal with the Royal Ballet, abruptly quit the company on Tuesday afternoon. Monica Mason, the director of the Royal Ballet, said in a press statement, This has obviously come as a huge shock. Sergei is a wonderful dancer, and I have enjoyed watching him tremendously, both on stage and in the studio, over the past few years. I wish him every success in the future.

title: David Kenny Named Chief of the Weather Channel
description: The Weather Channel Companies, which owns the Weather Channel, replaced its leadership on Tuesday, and named the digital advertising veteran David Kenny its chairman and chief executive.Mr. Kenny will start immediately. Michael J. Kelly, who had been the chief executive since 2009, will become a special adviser to the company and an adviser to Bain Capital, the private equity firm that co-owns the company with the Blackstone Group and Comcasts NBCUniversal.The surprise change signaled a desire on the part of the co-owners to expand the Weather Channels digital and mobile businesses more quickly. Through mobile apps and Web sites like Weather.com, the company sees an opportunity to have a much bigger international footprint.Six and a half billion people need information about weather, Mr. Kenny said in an interview Tuesday after addressing the companys staff in Atlanta.Mr. Kenny also said that the company would make more investments in long-form programming  part of a gradual move away from live weather news and toward taped weather-related reality shows.Now that people can get the information they need for their forecast off the Web, and certainly on their mobile phone, that gives us more license to do more long-form on the cable channel, he said. The channel remained committed to live news during severe weather, he added.Mr. Kenny, a member of the board of directors of Yahoo, was the president of Akamai until he stepped down last October. He was previously the co-founder of VivaKi, a digital agency that is part of the Publicis Groupe.In a statement, the three co-owners of the Weather Channel said that Mr. Kennys experience gives him a deep understanding of the TV and digital business, and he has the leadership experience and vision to drive global initiatives across all platforms.Mr. Kelly, similarly, had a digital media background when he was hired two and a half years ago.Mr. Kenny said he was initially recruited to join the board of the company, and was later asked by the board to consider the chief executive position.What Ive long stood for is convergence, he said. I think youll see us find better ways to run the Weather Channel as one company, really organized around our hundreds of millions of users.NBCUniversal and the private equity firms have owned the Weather Channel since 2008.

title: Chinese Manufacturing and the Auto Bailout
description: Jon Cohn, in correspondence, makes an important point with regard to the big Times report on Chinese manufacturing. Since he hasnt posted about it, I will.

title: Expanding the Definition of Depression
description: Does grieving over a loved one constitute full-blown depression?

title: The Lowdown | Cass Bird
description: Cass Birds photographs are instantly recognizable: her subjects always look mischievous, and like they are having just a little too much fun. Whether its a teenage model, her own children or the actor Viggo Mortensen (whom she photographed for the cover of T Magazine), Bird consistently manages to get the people she shoots to let their guard down so that the images ultimately reflect an integral part of her own personality: the hyperactive goofball. In her work for the Gap, Wrangler, Urban Outfitters and numerous magazines, Birds aesthetic is best described as young, carefree, loving life and youre so jealous, and her influence radiates throughout popular photography.

title: Newt and Marianne and Ted and Alice
description: Since Im cited repeatedly as the tribune of an unforgiving moral absolutism in Timothy Noahs piece kinda-sorta defending Newt Gingrichs request that his second wife tolerate his ongoing affair, it would be unsporting of me not to find something in his brief to dispute. So Ill take on this point:

title: Occupy Wall Street Drops Suit on Zuccotti Park
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters have decided to drop a lawsuit challenging the rules that prohibited them from camping inside Zuccotti Park, their lawyers said on Tuesday.

title: The Long Odds for a Small Canadian Film
description: The Canadian Philippe Falardeau, who wrote and directed Monsieur Lazhar, one of the five nominees for best foreign-language film, is at the Sundance Film Festival this week. Early on Tuesday morning, he was in a rented condo with his producers watching the Oscar nominations telecast, and when they heard the word Canada, he said, we screamed so loud, with a mixture of joy and relief, that I didnt even hear the title of my film.

title: After MF Globals Demise, Futures Industry Explores Tougher Rules
description: It is not every day that Wall Street volunteers for new regulation.

title: A Low-Key Spot With a High-Wattage Connection
description: THE women made a pilgrimage to West 68th Street, 450 miles from home, squinting in the rain on Monday as they peered through the restaurants front windows. The place was closed, they were told.

title: In Nadal Vs. Berdych, Conditioning Makes a Difference
description: Rafael Nadal withstood a barrage of huge serving and heavy, punishing groundstrokes from Tomas Berdych, prevailing in four grueling sets to advance to the semifinals. The level of play throughout the four hour and sixteen minute match was high, as both players hit more winners than unforced errors. Berdych hit 66 winners while making 56 unforced errors; Nadal had 57 winners and made only 30 unforced errors.

title: Tigers Make Free-Agency Splash, Sign Fielder
description: The Detroit Tigers are on the verge of pulling off one of the biggest free-agent deals of the off-season, having come to terms with slugger Prince Fielder on a nine-year, $214 million deal, according to multiple team sources. The signing was quickly reported by FoxSports and others.

title: Adding Up Those Coffees at Work
description: While a weak economy may have driven consumers to cut back, we know that they are still indulging on the little things.

title: Boehner Guests Include Some Affected by Pipeline Decision
description: Since it became common for lawmakers to invite guests to attend the State of the Union address, honorees have been walking political statements for their hosts, and this year is no different.

title: Google to Update Privacy Policy to Cover Wider Data Use
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Google said Tuesday that it would revise its privacy policies and terms of service, to make them shorter and more readable and to change the way Google can use information that users provide.

title: For Hugos Editor, 11 Reasons to Celebrate
description: When Martin Scorsese goes into an editing room, what he likes to do, said Thelma Schoonmaker, his longtime editor, is just watch a little TV.

title: What They Said
description: I was going to headline this post stupid things Congressmen say, but then I figured that would just be asking for trouble. There is not time enough in the day to fulfill the promise of that headline.

title: Volkswagen Super Bowl Ad Has a Tough Act to Follow: Last Years Ad
description: As popular as Volkswagens Super Bowl commercial was last year, with its Star Wars focus, it was not a given that a Volkswagen spot this year would also pay tribute to the film and its characters.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Research and Its Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoos Income Drops 5% in Struggle for Market Share
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Investors hoping for any hint of what is next for Yahoo in Tuesdays earnings announcement will have to wait a little longer. Instead, they got the same old story: more cost-controls and declining revenue.

title: The Shanty
description: 79 Richardson Street (Leonard Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 878-3579, nydistilling.com/the-shanty

title: Givenchys Deco Punk
description: Cameron Diaz was having a private tour of the Givenchy spring couture collection, courtesy of Riccardo Tisci, when I popped in to see the clothes. It was nearly nightfall. Some photographers were huddled under an awning in the Place Vendme, trying to stay out of the rain that has drenched Paris. Mr. Tiscis collection consisted of 10 outfits, most of which were displayed on suspended dress forms in three rooms, with gilt trim and creaky parquet.

title: Reviewing the Shanty
description: The Shanty, a new bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that I reviewed this week, serves a whiskey cocktail they call the Lonesome Hero. Its a terrific drink: an old-fashioned variant made with cherry liqueur and the Czech herbal bitters Becherovka. Yet ordering one feels a little bit like getting the salmon at Peter Luger. Thats because the Shanty  for the moment, at least  is mostly about the gin. The bar is an annex of the New York Distilling Company, which has been producing two types of gin since November. Theyre not the only people to do the micro-distilling thing in the borough (theres also the Kings County Distillery and Breuckelen Distilling in Sunset Park), but theyre the first with their own bar. The Shanty is clearly more than a gin joint, and no one will push you to order the companys products. But after admiring their gorgeous German-made pot still through a window onto the distillery floor, its hard to choose something made elsewhere. This week, they have started distilling the rye that will be ready for bottling a year from now. They already have a great drink to use it in.

title: Just One Look | Giambattista Valli
description: As the Oscars become fashions talking point, actresses and presenters will be looking for glamorous, pretty gowns to get them through the night looking uncontroversially lovely. They could do little better than to turn to Giambattista Valli, whose second haute couture collection again showcased his considerable talents as a draper and festooner of evening wear. His strapless floral look  made of a beautiful devore-esque fabric  is simplicity and whimsy in a superluxurious stunner.

title: Not All Wetlands Are Created Equal
description: To many, its a familiar scenario: a strip mall suddenly pops up in what was once a desolate quagmire or boggy boondock.

title: In Battered Area, Romney Assails Gingrich on Foreclosures
description: LEHIGH ACRES, Fla.  Mitt Romney toured the epicenter of Floridas foreclosure crisis on Tuesday as he continued to try to draw attention to Newt Gingrichs work on behalf of Freddie Mac.

title: Baylor Football, Post-Griffin
description: WACO, Tex.  From the time he emerged from the second string as a freshman to recording 10 wins last season, adding a bowl victory and the universitys first Heisman Trophy, it is safe to say that Robert Griffin III put Baylor football back on the map.

title: Watson Acquires General Lee, His Dream Car
description: SAN DIEGO  A scheduling conflict kept Bubba Watson from answering the call from President Clinton to play in last weeks Humana Challenge outside Palm Desert. Clinton, with his deep-fried Southern roots, might have given Watson his blessing if he had known how Watson spent the weekend.

title: Germany Permits Itself to Celebrate Prussian King
description: POTSDAM, Germany  The official delegation honoring Frederick the Greats 300th birthday had just finished laying a laurel wreath and a grand cross of white flowers at his grave here on Tuesday when a 70-year-old retiree quietly slipped in behind them and placed a small potato on the gray slab of stone that marks the monarchs resting place.

title: Chinas Coming Standstill
description: BEIJING  This year, as China faces its first leadership change in a decade, its stability, stupid.

title: Calyer
description: 92 Calyer Street (Franklin Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (347) 889-6323, calyerbrooklyn.com

title: Pain That Can Only Be Assuaged by Twitter
description: In the category of making lemonade out of Oscar snubs, the winners are Albert Brooks and Patton Oswalt. Both actors were tipped to be nominees in the best supporting actor category  Mr. Brooks was even a heavy favorite for his against-type turn as a criminal in Drive  and both took to Twitter when they didnt make the cut.

title: In Talk With Team, Manning Emphasizes Focus
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Being part of an event like the Super Bowl encompasses much more than just playing in a football game, and Giants quarterback Eli Manning addressed the team Tuesday to essentially warn his teammates about the distractions that may arise over the next two weeks.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Smoky Anniversary

title: Suspended Ovechkin Chooses Not to Attend All-Star Game
description: Heres something you hardly ever hear about the N.H.L. All-Star Game: It may actually be interesting.

title: Apples Profit Doubles on Holiday iPhone 4S Sales
description: It turns out Apple didnt need an iPhone 5 to bolster sales.

title: State of the Union? More Like State of the Campaign
description: Republicans have good reason to believe that President Obamas goals in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night were more partisan than presidential.

title: Coming Soon | Mash-Ups
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Winter Tomato Worth Buying
description: Lucky Lee has been selling vine-ripened Florida tomatoes for decades, mainly to restaurants in winter. Now she has a new one, a hefty crimson beefsteak. Its meaty, juicy, flavorful and, yes, a winter tomato thats actually worth buying. Called the Tasti-Lee, it is a hybrid developed by Jay Scott, a tomato breeder at the University of Florida. The Lee part of the name, though, has nothing to do with Ms. Lee, the distributor who has just introduced them in the New York area; Mr. Scott named the tomato in honor of his late mother-in law, Leocadia Czarnomski.

title: From the Crucifixion to the Internet, You Are There
description: Judith Malina  a founder and unsinkable bulwark of the Living Theater, a beacon of experimental performance in New York since 1947  instigates another rebellion with History of the World, now at the troupes Lower East Side home. Though Ms. Malina, at 85, shows no loss of fight, there is something almost elegiac about her latest piece, no less than an exuberant, dizzying and exhausting flight through the course of Western civilization, peppered with political observations. Certainly Ms. Malina has earned the right to conduct such an ambitious survey.

title: With Defaults Low, Bankruptcy Experts Keep Eyes on Europe
description: It has been more than two years since the busiest time in recent memory for bankruptcy professionals, and the restructuring industry is still waiting for its business to pick up again.

title: Wines Worth a Taste, but Not the Vitriol
description: ROBERT M. PARKER JR., the powerful wine critic, called it one of the major scams being foisted on wine consumers.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Records From Toyota Investigation
description: DETROIT  Concerned that regulators are dismissing electronic problems in Toyota vehicles, an auto safety firm said Tuesday that it had sued the federal government to get records of its investigation into the unintended acceleration of a Prius last year.

title: Marveling at a Maestro of Glass, Steel and Light
description: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster?, an admiring documentary about the British architect Norman Foster, by Norberto Lpez Amado and Carlos Carcas, gives the viewer quite a lot to marvel at, which is, after all, the root meaning of the word admire.

title: At Brooklyn Prep, Paterno Learned Latin and Bravado
description: At the Jesuit high school Joe Paterno attended in Brooklyn, students wore jackets and ties and were taught by priests or by lay teachers in academic robes. The curriculum was also rigorously Old World: students took several years of Latin and many added three years of Greek, with three hours of homework per night the rule.

title: Romneys Plan for Self-Deportation Has Conservative Support
description: When Mitt Romney said in the Republican debate on Monday night that he favored self-deportation as a solution to illegal immigration, it seemed to come out of the blue, perhaps an effort, as the race moves to Florida, to soften the hard line he has staked out on immigration.

title: G.O.P. Debate on NBC Drew Over 7 Million Viewers
description: The Republican debate on NBC on Monday night attracted the second-highest number of viewers of any debate in the current presidential election season, a little over seven million.

title: Pro-Gingrich Super PAC to Spend $6 Million on Florida Ads
description: A super PAC supporting Newt Gingrich said Tuesday that it was putting $6 million behind a new advertisement in Florida, giving the spots a major presence on airwaves that have up until now been dominated by Mitt Romney.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Steve Jobss Photo Plan, Piracy and Public Outrage
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Facebook Readies Timeline Takeover
description: Facebook announced on Tuesday that it would begin the global rollout of Timeline, a profile-page makeover that displays a users entire history of photos, links and other things shared on Facebook in chronological order, making them accessible with a single click.

title: The First Times Surreal, for Muppet, Man or Dragon Tattoo Girl
description: We heard from a few more nominees today, including three first-timers: Bret McKenzie, Jonah Hill and Rooney Mara.

title: Amid Attacks on Private Equity, Efforts to Study Its Value
description: Controversy swirls around private equity as attacks on Mitt Romney and the entire industry mount. Amid the name-calling, little in the way of evidence has been cited. So lets take a look at some of the best research on this issue.

title: Senate Hopeful Says He Takes Full Responsibility for Blog Posts
description: Marc Cenedella, a Republican businessman laying the groundwork for a possible run for a United States Senate seat in New York, said on Tuesday that he took full responsibility for blog posts about sex, women and drugs that have drawn criticism.

title: Excerpts From the State of the Union Address
description: As in years past, the Obama administration released excerpts of President Obamas State of the Union address several hours before the start of the speech:

title: Readers SotU Wish List
description: Earlier today I posted the editorial boards wish list for Barack Obamas State of the Union speech. We included issues we find important, without regard to political wisdom. Readers then added to the list in the comments section and on Facebook, and made it even less realisticwith one commenter, for instance, calling on Mr. Obama to argue for Medicare for all in lieu of the hard-won Affordable Care Act. Dream on.

title: Gates to Pitch His Charity Work at Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Some people come to the World Economic Forum expecting caviar. Bill Gates said he would bring cassava.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Iraq, Spain and India.

title: Look of The Moment | Natalia Vodianova
description: The Look: Country Strong. An elegant topcoat and tall lace-up boots over white leggings  its a study in neutrals that verges on equestrian but leans most certainly toward sexy, too.

title: In Address, Obama Makes Pitch for Economic Fairness
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama pledged on Tuesday night to use government power to balance the scale between Americas rich and the rest of the public, trying to present an election-year choice between continued leadership toward an economy built to last and what he called irresponsible policies of the past that caused an economic collapse.

title: A Dignitary of Cuban Jazz Holds Court in Carnegie Hall
description: During his final few moments onstage at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, Chucho Valds stopped playing, midphrase, to issue an instructive edict. He was well into his second encore then, alone at the piano, teasing out a Gershwin medley that had whimsically morphed into the Cuban standard El Manisero. The audience, elated, started clapping four beats to a bar. Immediately, his hands lifted from the keyboard to clap a son clave: one, two, three, one-two. He transferred this pattern to the keyboard, implying that the crowd was to follow his lead. Moments later, he was up and gone.

title: A Formidable Piece by Messiaen, Inspired by Two Breathtaking Places
description: Everything about Messiaens Des Canyons aux toiles (From the Canyons to the Stars) is vast. This audacious 100-minute work is scored for 44 individual instruments, including all manner of percussion, and features a formidable solo piano part. It was inspired by Messiaens 1972 visit to Bryce Canyon and Cedar Breaks in Utah, where he looked in awe at craggy rock formations and reddish-orange geological vistas.

title: In Winter Weather, Flying to Find Wolves
description: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

title: Bloomberg Assails Showing of Anti-Muslim Film to  Police
description: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that whoever decided to show a film depicting American Muslims as extremists to nearly 1,500 city police officers exercised some terrible judgment.

title: Facebooks Sandberg Gently Warns Europe About Privacy Rules
description: Concerned about privacy? Maybe you should be concernedabout the economy instead. That was the subtext of a keynote speech by Sheryl Sandberg, Facebooks chief operating officer, at a technology conference in the heart of Europe on Tuesday.

title: Not Just for Sundays After Church
description: JUSTIN SOELBERG, the chef at Communal restaurant in Provo, Utah, has heard all the jokes about Mormon food. People think its just casseroles and Jell-O all the time, said Mr. Soelberg, 30, who grew up Mormon in Idaho and graduated from the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan.

title: Rubio Stays Neutral, but Defends Romney
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has pledged to remain neutral in the Republican presidential campaign, particularly during the intensifying clash between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich before the primary here next week.

title: Storyteller Well Versed in Liszts Versatility
description: The pianist Garrick Ohlsson spoke recently of his affinity for Liszt, an empathy that was certainly evident during his stunning performance of Liszts Sonata in B minor at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon.

title: Aspire Prep Says It Should Not Be Penalized for One Bad Year
A Family Film From a Coppola Family Member
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Goats is the type of Sundance movie you could accidentally drive right past. The title isnt all that enticing. Its Tuesday-night premiere slot is deep in the festival, when your attention is starting to sputter.

title: On a Roll, Bringing a Downtown Attitude
description: MATT ABRAMCYK was obsessed with a seat.

title: Olympic Qualifying: U.S. Women vs. Mexico
description: The United States womens team will have revenge on its mind when it plays Mexico on Tuesday night in the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament in Vancouver (10:30 p.m. Eastern, Universal Sports/streaming at universalsports.com).

title: Rushdies Video Talk Is Canceled at India Literature Festival
description: Salman Rushdies virtual participation at the Jaipur Literature Festival in India was canceled at the last minute on Tuesday after Muslim groups attending the festival threatened violence if his image was shown. After canceling an in-person appearance, Mr. Rushdie planned to address thousands of festival attendees by video conference on Tuesday. There are a large number of people adverse to this link in and around this property, and they have threatened violence, said Thakur Ram Pratap Singh of Diggi, the owner of Diggi Palace, the festival site. This decision is necessary to protect everyone here, he said. Mr. Rushdies plans to attend the festival, above, stirred controversy before it opened, and he said on the first day that he would not attend, citing a risk to his safety. Mr. Rushdies Satanic Verses was banned in India in 1988, and he has been the target of criticism and a fatwa from Muslim groups. His life was threatened several times before the festival, officials told the organizers. Mr. Rushdie criticized both the Indian government and Islamic leaders in an interview on Tuesday evening with the television channel NDTV. Mr. Rushdie said he had been cast as an enemy of Islam even though the real enemies were the various extremist leaders and their followers, who behave like this because what they do is to strengthen the extremely negative image of Islam as an intolerant, repressive and violent culture.

title: Larry Butler, Producer for Kenny Rogers, Dies at 69
description: Larry Butler, the producer of some of Kenny Rogerss biggest hits and the only Nashville session leader ever to win a Grammy Award for producer of the year, died on Friday at his home in Pensacola, Fla. He was 69.

title: Boy With Strange Powers and a Challenged Father
description: One of the smaller leaps of logic in Touch  the new Fox series representing Kiefer Sutherlands full-time return to television  is that the 11-year-old boy at the center of the story has never spoken and is also the shows narrator. Its a perfectly acceptable device, if not a particularly interesting one in this case.

title: In Abu Dhabi, Not Torrey Pines, Woods Acknowledges Lure of Appearance Fees
description: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods was asked in December why he was bypassing this weeks PGA Tour stop at Torrey Pines despite having won here 6 times in 12 appearances. It is also the site of his last major victory, the 2008 United States Open. Woods instead committed to play in a concurrent European Tour event in Abu Dhabi with less than half the total purse  $2.7 million to $6 million here.

title: Martin Agrees to Deal With Yankees
description: Just hours after Jorge Posada, their catcher of the past, announced his retirement, the Yankees said Tuesday that they had agreed on a contract with Russell Martin, their catcher of the present.

title: J.F.K.s Final Words in Office
description: Before President John F. Kennedy left the White House for his fateful trip to Dallas, he said he expected a rough day when he returned to Washington, according to recently released recordings of his final meetings.

title: Buffett vs. Mankiw on Taxes
description: By inviting Debbie Bosanek, Warren Buffetts secretary, to sit in the first ladys box at the State of the Union address, President Obama has signaled that he intends to talk about the tax rate on some investments. Mr. Obama and Mr. Buffett both argue that many investment managers pay too little tax, because the tax code treats their pay as an investment return  and thus taxes it at a much lower rate than ordinary income. Mr. Buffett has famously said that, as a result, his secretary pays a higher tax rate than he does.

title: Bill Mardo, Writer Who Pushed Baseball to Integrate, Dies at 88
description: Bill Mardo, a sportswriter for the Communist Party newspaper The Daily Worker who fought major league baseballs color barrier in the 1940s when the mainstream American news media was largely silent on the subject, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Mudd Resigns as Fortress Chief Executive
description: The Fortress Investment Group said on Tuesday that Daniel H. Mudd had resigned as the investment firms chief executive, as he remained the subject of a government lawsuit tied to his tenure as the head of Fannie Mae.

title: TimesCast | Egypt's Revolution Continues
description: January 24, 2012  Robert Mackey of the Lede blog interviews Mosaab Elshamy, an activist and photographer living in Cairo, about the first anniversary of Egypts revolution.

title: Anger in Iraq After Plea Bargain Over 2005 Massacre
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqis were outraged Tuesday to learn that the Marine considered the ringleader of a 2005 massacre that left 24 of their countrymen dead in 2005 was sentenced on Tuesday to a reduction in rank but avoided any jail time after pleading guilty the day before to a reduced charge.

title: Downton Fans: The Writer Suggests a Book for You
description: To the Editor:

title: Azarenka Wears Down Radwanska With Power Tennis
description: The Agnieszka Radwanska-Victoria Azarenka match was a textbook case of how aggressive play and offense beats risk-averse defense in big matches. Although Radwanska took the first set, winning an error-filled tiebreaker 7-0 as Azarenka self-destructed, the rest of the match was a clinic in power tennis dominating a more conservative game plan. Azarenka began to take the ball early and move Radwanska mercilessly from side to side. The normally stingy Radwanska (she committed only 3 unforced errors in her fourth round win over Julia Gorges) began to crumble as Azarenkas heavy groundstrokes found their mark. Radwanska made 31 unforced errors in the match, and gradually wore down under Azarenkas constant pressure.

title: Learning Amid the Ruins
description: Poor Cambodian villagers come to Siem Reap to work in the tourism industry around the ruins of Angkor Wat, but many also find a path to higher education.

title: Our Options for Dealing With Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating the Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Maker Predicts Lower Sales
description: Advanced Micro Devices, a maker of processors for personal computers, forecast lower sales on Tuesday than some analysts had estimated, hurt by supply shortages and slower demand for PCs.

title: Live Blog: The State of the Union
description: President Obama made his way down the aisle of the House Chamber at 9 Eastern time on Tuesday, shaking hands and accepting kind words from Republican and Democratic lawmakers before delivering his third State of the Union address. It was also an opening of sorts for a re-election campaign amid some glimmerings of optimism in the economy but stiff headwinds from a weary public.

title: In Brazil, Fears of a Slide Back for Amazon Protection
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazil has made great strides in recent years in slowing Amazon deforestation and showing the world it was serious about protecting the mammoth rain forest.

title: Egyptian Activists Say Their Revolution Remains Unfinished
description: As Egyptians prepare to mark the first anniversary of the revolution that toppled Hosni Mubarak but left them under the rule of his top generals, two activists explained in interviews with The Lede on Tuesdau that they plan to protest, not celebrate.

title: Excerpts From the Republican Response
description: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana will be delivering the Republican response to President Obamas State of the Union address, and Congressional Republican leaders released excerpts of his speech Tuesday evening:

title: A Test for Egypt: Hearing All Voices
description: Cairo

title: For Thousands of Mourners, Paternos Legacy Will Remain Unshaken
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Mourners descended on this town in droves Tuesday to say goodbye to Joe Paterno, the football coach who was more than a football coach to them. Wearing suits or Penn State sweatshirts, alumni and fans came from Scranton to Sewickley, and seemingly all points in between.

title: Director Quits After Changes at Global Fund
description: The executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria resigned Tuesday, culminating two months of struggle over the future direction of the fund.

title: Syria Rejects Peace Effort From Region
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Saying that half the universe was conspiring against his country, the Syrian foreign minister forcefully rejected a regional attempt to broker an end to the 10-month conflict here on Tuesday and suggested that there would be no end to the governments use of force to put down the uprising.

title: The Tax Deduction Mitt Romney Did Not Take
description: The release of Mitt Romneys tax returns for 2010, all 500 pages of them, shines a bright light into the strategies wealthy people use to reduce their tax burden  Mr. Romney managed to reduce his effective tax rate on $21 million of income to just 13.9 percent.

title: The Florida State of Play
description: Were exactly one week away from the Florida primary, which looks as though it could be pivotal in the Republican nomination campaign.

title: Mets Look Back and Ahead
description: The annual fund-raising dinner to benefit the Baseball Assistance Team, a charity that aids former players in need, served Tuesday as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Mets. It brought together a wide swath of personalities from the teams past and present at the Marriott Marquis in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Average Is Over
description: In an essay, entitled Making It in America, in the latest issue of The Atlantic, the author Adam Davidson relates a joke from cotton country about just how much a modern textile mill has been automated: The average mill has only two employees today, a man and a dog. The man is there to feed the dog, and the dog is there to keep the man away from the machines.

title: A Way to Make People Buy Homes Again
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Giants Deny Taking Aim at 49er With Concussions
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Two days after two Giants players made an opponent with a history of concussions a target, the team did its best to back away from the notion and the N.F.L. said it would not impose discipline.

title: Courtroom Window Opens on a Battle Between 2 Financiers
description: For more than 20 years, Ronald O. Perelman and Donald Drapkin were the best of friends, a relationship cemented as the two financiers bought and sold companies like Revlon and Marvel Comics.

title: These Lab Specimens Watch 3-D Television
description: A NEW tastefully decorated living room in Manhattan may look like just another high-end home full of iPads, a 3-D television and Xbox gaming console. But this cozy sitting area in the Time Warner Center in New York isnt in one of the complexs residential condominiums.

title: Lincecum and Giants Agree on Two-Year Deal
description: Tim Lincecum, a two-time Cy Young Award winner, and the San Francisco Giants reached a verbal agreement on a contract Tuesday for two years at $40.5 million, according to a club official who said the deal was pending a physical.

title: In Europe, a Conflict Over Bank Capital
description: LONDON  Europes banks and regulators are at odds about how financial institutions should increase their capital reserves.

title: The Justice of the Occupation
description: The filmmaker Raanan Alexandrowicz explores the impact of Israels High Court of Justice on Palestinian rights.

title: The Justice of Occupation
description: Israels Supreme Court is the body that provides checks and balances to the countrys executive and legislative powers, upholding constitutional standards. Over the years the court has gained a reputation as one of the most judicially active, human rights-oriented courts in the world.

title: For Young Austrian, Victory Amid Allegations of Cheating
description: SCHLADMING, Austria  The annual ski-racing extravaganza known as Nightrace Schladming drew more than 40,000 fans to this small village Tuesday evening. They got to see one of their countrymen win the famed World Cup slalom competition under stadium lights, just as he is coming under intense criticism in a debate that is roiling the sport.

title: Obama Urges Tougher Laws on Financial Fraud
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Congress Tuesday to toughen laws against securities fraud and to strengthen the ability of the Securities and Exchange Commission to punish Wall Street firms that repeatedly violate antifraud statutes.

title: Places, Everyone: First for a Catering Firm, and Then on an Unlikely Stage
description: Like so many great and fully implausible schemes, a two-nights-only production of Into the Woods, running this week on the Lower East Side, was hatched in a crevice of time, when its masterminds were madly busy with other things.

title: The State of the Union, With the Future in Mind
description: Jan. 25, 8:40 a.m. | Updated |President Obama focused his State of the Union address on American policies and priorities that work for the long haul  which is one way to define sustainable human advancement anywhere.

title: Blame Photoshop, Not Diabetes, for This Amputation
description: New York Citys health watchdogs warn that drinking too much sugary soda could cost you a leg. But you also might lose a limb if you appear in one of their ads.

title: Is It Poetry, Subversion or Both?
description: HONG KONG  The poem seems to be to a call to arms, and maybe a call to feet.

title: A Family Holds On to Its Musical Dreams, Despite a Promoters Lies
description: Sylvia Brown knows the ending to the old saying: If something sounds too good to be true ....

title: Egypts Partial Step
description: Egypts military junta showed some political sense on Tuesday when it announced the easing of a longtime state of emergency law, a hated symbol of authoritarian rule under President Hosni Mubarak  and now. The generals clearly hope to placate activists who had planned new protests for Wednesday, the anniversary of the revolt that led to Mr. Mubaraks ouster.

title: President Obamas State of the Union Address
description: Following is the transcript of President Obamas State of the Union address on Jan. 24, 2012, as released by the White House:

title: Stocking Up for a Title Run, the Tigers Buy in Bulk
description: Mike Ilitch wanted to show something to Magglio Ordonez. It was the winter after the 2004 season, and Ilitch, the owner of the Detroit Tigers, had presided over 209 losses in the past two years. In a meeting at a Miami country club, he told Ordonez, a star free agent, how badly he burned to win.

title: Bloomberg, in a Visit to Albany, Has Nothing but Praise for Cuomo
description: ALBANY  After a year spent squabbling with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over budget cuts and policy disagreements, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared before Albany lawmakers on Tuesday singing a very different tune.

title: Where I Learned to Love the Game
description: From the outside it looks like a big warehouse. When you walk in, it smells of rubber, perspiration and shinguards. Its noisy. The walkways and bleachers are old, cold and gray. But on the turf, magic happens.

title: At Ecuadorean Shop, in No Mood to Celebrate Arrests
description: EAST HAVEN, Conn.  The Matute family, immigrants from Ecuador, said police officers started lurking around their grocery store on Main Street about three years ago. They would stop and question customers for no apparent reason, sometimes arresting them or towing their cars.

title: Iraqis Angered After Plea Bargain Over Massacre in Haditha
description: An article in Wednesdays Times reports on the outrage in Iraq after news broke of the sentencing of a Marine considered the ringleader in the 2005 massacre in Haditha, in which 24 Iraqis died.

title: Gingrich Tries to Lure Tea Party Support in Florida
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  As he moved to consolidate the conservative base behind him, Newt Gingrich waved the red cape of a former Florida governor who quit the Republican Party and lost to the Tea Party favorite Marco Rubio  a line that got a big reaction from crowds who have not forgotten that act of moderate apostasy.

title: A Wisconsin Judges Refusal to Recuse
description: Justice Michael Gableman of the Wisconsin Supreme Court announced last week that he will not retroactively recuse himself by taking back his vote in one of the courts highly divisive recent cases. The decision is indefensible.

title: In Shift, Police Say Leader Helped With Anti-Islam Film and Now Regrets It
description: The New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, through a top aide, acknowledged for the first time on Tuesday that he personally cooperated with the filmmakers of The Third Jihad  a decision the commissioner now describes as a mistake.

title: Public College, Private Dorm
description: With state budgets tight and demand for a college education at a high point, public universities across the country are increasingly turning to the private sector to build and finance on-campus dormitories.

title: For Belichick, Fond Memories of New York (Giants, Not Jets)
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Much as it was four years ago, when the New England Patriots and the Giants met in Super Bowl XLII, nostalgia will be a prime topic of conversation as Super Bowl XLVI approaches.

title: Pro-Government Libyan Militia Routed From a Qaddafi Bastion
description: CAIRO  Forces loyal to Libyas interim government were violently expelled Monday from a town long seen as supportive of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a local militia leader said Tuesday, an assault that left at least four combatants dead and raised the specter of renewed conflict between revolutionary forces and those supportive of the old order.

title: Captain Huse Gives the South Old-Fashioned Hell
description: Capt. Henry Huse stood atop the star-shaped Fort Independence on a January day in 1862 and delighted in the magnificent view of Boston Harbor. It eclipsed anything he had seen back in the New Hampshire hamlet of Barnstead, where the 22-year-old schoolteacher had worked only a few months earlier.

title: Gingrich Weaves State of the Union Into Obama Attack
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Newt Gingrich wove references to President Obamas State of the Union address into his usual stump critique of the president on Tuesday, telling crowds numbering in the thousands in Sarasota and Naples that defeating Mr. Obama would be the most important election of our lifetime.

title: Christie Wants Voters to Decide on Gay Marriage
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said Tuesday that he would veto a bill legalizing same-sex marriage, and he challenged the State Legislature instead to put the issue on the ballot for voters to decide.

title: Economic Crisis Adds Dangers on Egypts New Political Path
description: CAIRO  After a year of unending turmoil and military rule, Egypt faces an acute financial crisis that could undermine its political transition and pose a defining challenge to Islamists now coming to power.

title: Obama Signals Expansion of Oil Drilling
description: The president used the address to indirectly counter some of the fierce criticism he has received from Republicans and oil industry officials over his decision last week to block construction of the 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline from oil formations in western Canada to refineries on the Gulf coast. President Obama did not mention the pipeline decision  which some Republicans have vowed to reverse  but he stressed the increase in oil and gas production over the past two years. He said that American oil production is the highest it has been in the past eight years and imports are lower than at any time in the past 16 years.

title: Marisa Manley
description: Ms. Manley is the president and founder of Commercial Tenant Real Estate Representation and Healthcare Real Estate Advisors. The companies, based in New York, help businesses find and set up commercial space. The businesses include the medical companies LabCorp, Quest and AmeriPath.

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The victory the Knicks had to have came Tuesday against the Charlotte Bobcats, who are in even-worse shape.

title: Hateful Film

title: The State of the Union Address: And So It Begins
description: If anyone had any lingering doubts about whether President Obama is ready to fight for his job, the State of the Union address tonight should have dispelled them. Im not the biggest fan of the presidents speeches. They can be awfully long, his delivery rather low-key, and his talking points often follow a slow-windup-then-slower-let-down pattern. If he had treated us to that drill tonight, a lot of voters would have switched to a screening of The Shawshank Redemption or maybe reruns of The Big Bang Theory.

title: Georgia: Publisher Quits After Column on Obama
description: The publisher of The Atlanta Jewish Times resigned Tuesday after writing that Israel should consider assassinating President Obama. Andrew B. Adler stepped down after an outcry over a recent column in which he suggested that the Israeli military might take out a president deemed unfriendly to Israel. Mr. Adler could not be reached but has apologized in other interviews. The Secret Service has said it is investigating the episode. On its Web site, the newspaper said it is seeking a successor for Mr. Adler, who is also the owner, and looks forward to trying to serve readers more faithfully than ever in the future.

title: Rise in Oil Imports Drives a Rare Trade Deficit in Japan
description: TOKYO  Japan reported its first annual trade deficit in 31 years last year, government data showed Wednesday, as fuel imports surged in the wake of its nuclear disaster at Fukushima.

title: Missing The Forest

title: Sanctions Against Iran Grow Tighter, but Whats the Next Step?
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration and its European allies toughened economic sanctions against Iran on Monday  blocking its access to the world financial system and undermining its critical oil and gas industry  officials on both sides of the Atlantic acknowledge that their last-ditch effort has only a limited chance of persuading Tehran to abandon what the West fears is its pursuit of nuclear weapons.

title: Trial Begins in Stanford Fraud Case With Appeal to Emotions
description: HOUSTON  Nearly three years after they charged the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford with masterminding a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, prosecutors opened their case against him on Tuesday, saying that he treated the savings of thousands of investors as his personal piggy bank to buy two airlines, build a cricket team and stadium, funnel money to a Swiss bank account and otherwise live a life of luxury on the Caribbean island of Antigua.

title: Pakistan: Peace Talks Considered
description: Pakistani civilian and military leaders met Tuesday to discuss policy toward Afghanistan, including possible peace talks with Taliban militants. Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani met with the army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani; the head of the spy agency Inter-Services Intelligence, Lt. Gen Ahmed Shuja Pasha; and the foreign minister, Hina Rabbani Khar, a government news release said. President Asif Ali Zardari was on a two-day trip to Myanmar. The statement said that the prime minister asked Ms. Khar to plan a visit to Afghanistan and that participants discussed the ongoing reconciliation process  a euphemism for possible peace talks with the Taliban.

The military is waging war against the Kachin despite a Dec. 10 order from President Thein Sein to halt combat. The cease-fire talks were inconclusive.

title: Russia: Protest by Jewish Group Over Memorial
description: The Russian Jewish Congress announced on Tuesday that it had sent a letter of protest to regional officials over the decision to replace a memorial plaque to Jews killed in the Holocaust with one that mentions only peaceful citizens of Rostov-on-Don and Soviet prisoners of war. The plaque was in Zmiyevskaya Balka, near the southern city of Rostov-on-Don. Last November, officials removed a plaque hung in 2004, which read, On the 11-12 of August 1942, Nazis killed more than 27,000 Jews here. Where the old text refers to the Holocaust, the new one reads mass killing by the fascists of captured Soviet citizens, phraseology widely used during Soviet times, according to the Web site of the Russian Jewish Congress.

Grijalva, a Democrat, who led her gingerly to her front-row seat on the Democratic side. Ms. Giffords clutched the hands of both lawmakers as applause thundered.

She looked quite uncomfortable and unstable, Dr. Cronin says.

title: Jan. 25, 1915 | Alexander Graham Bell Demonstrates AT&Ts Transcontinental Telephone Line
description: On Jan. 25, 1915, the inventor of the telephone, Alexander Graham Bell, inaugurated U.S. transcontinental telephone service as part of a demonstration that included dignitaries in New York, Boston, Washington, D.C., San Francisco and Jekyll Island, Ga. Bell, in New York at the time, made the first call to Thomas Watson, his former assistant, who was in San Francisco.

title: Will Israel Attack Iran?
description: As the Sabbath evening approached on Jan. 13, Ehud Barak paced the wide living-room floor of his home high above a street in north Tel Aviv, its walls lined with thousands of books on subjects ranging from philosophy and poetry to military strategy. Barak, the Israeli defense minister, is the most decorated soldier in the countrys history and one of its most experienced and controversial politicians. He has served as chief of the general staff for the Israel Defense Forces, interior minister, foreign minister and prime minister. He now faces, along with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and 12 other members of Israels inner security cabinet, the most important decision of his life  whether to launch a pre-emptive attack against Iran. We met in the late afternoon, and our conversation  the first of several over the next week  lasted for two and a half hours, long past nightfall. This is not about some abstract concept, Barak said as he gazed out at the lights of Tel Aviv, but a genuine concern. The Iranians are, after all, a nation whose leaders have set themselves a strategic goal of wiping Israel off the map.

title: Come On, China, Buy Our Stuff!
description: The first time I visited China, in 2005, an American businessman living there told me that the country was so huge and was changing so fast that everything you heard about it was true, and so was the opposite. That still seems to be the case. China is the fastest-growing consumer market in the world, and American companies have made billions there. At the same time, Chinese consumers arent spending nearly as much as American companies had hoped. China has simultaneously become the greatest boon and the biggest disappointment.

title: Uncovering a Home Away From Home
description: On the first night in his Tokyo apartment, Greg Girard turned on the radio and heard an English-speaking D.J. Youve been listening to the Far East Network of the American Forces, the voice said, segueing into a recording of The Star-Spangled Banner.

title: Scots Begin Bid for Vote on Independence
description: EDINBURGH  Scotlands first minister, Alex Salmond, took the first formal step on Wednesday toward an independence referendum that the government in Edinburgh hopes will secure a mandate from Scotlands five million people for the countrys withdrawal from the United Kingdom within as little as five years.

title: Accusations of Delay in Disclosing Volt Fire
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans accused the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Wednesday of trying to keep secret a battery fire in a Chevy Volt out of fear of damaging the value of the governments investment in the cars manufacturer, General Motors, and jeopardizing President Obamas re-election prospects.

title: A Festival of Experimental Music in Madrid
description: For less than the cost of caf con leche and an order of churros, music lovers in Madrid can take in a top-notch concert at the Festival Internacional de Improvisacin Hurta Cordel, an annual celebration of experimental and improvised music started in 1996. From Wednesday through Jan. 29, La Casa Encendida will charge four euros admission to see performances by legends like the avant-rock guitarist Fred Frith and free-jazz pianist Alexander von Schlippenbach alongside shows featuring up-and-coming artists from Spain and abroad. (Tickets are also available on www.entradas.com.)Moving across genres like free jazz, contemporary classical and experimental electronica, the musicians push past more mainstream definitions of music, each in his or her own way. The festival lineup includes a collaboration between the established British improvisers Michael Fischer, John Edwards and Mark Sanders, as well as a concert by 2|2code, an Australian-Spanish duo that treads the line between music and conceptual art. 2|2code creates ambient surround-sound mash-ups drawn from sources as varied as classic Hollywood films, amateur news footage, and speeches by George W. Bush.

title: Sometimes Even the Experts Can Be Fooled
description: In the realm of musical excavation, even experts can come to the wrong conclusions. In the Feb. 10 episode of Michael Feinsteins American Songbook, the PBS series that follows Mr. Feinstein, the entertainer and musical preservationist, as he rummages through old musical archives, the discovery of an unpublished Irving Berlin song was to be announced. The song, titled So Will I, which was recently copyrighted by the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, which administers Berlins publishing but had no record of the song, has since been found to have been composed in 1926 by the team of Lew Brown and Cliff Friend and published by the Berlin company. A bouncy, wistful breakup song, it was recorded in 2005 by Ian Whitcomb on his album Sentimentally Yours.

title: A Putinesque Party
