description: The online auction house offered a sweat-soaked gem from punk rocks New York glory years  the black leather jacket worn by the Ramones second drummer, Marky Ramone, during his first stint with the band, from 1978 to 1983.

title: Cavaliers Hand Knicks 7th Loss in 8 Games
description: CLEVELAND  With another humiliating loss bearing down, Carmelo Anthony worked to find a better shot, a way forward, a chance to change the Knicks fate. He looked to his All-Star frontcourt partner, Amare Stoudemire, waiting on the perimeter.

title: Warning: The Next Sound You Hear Will Not Be Your Engine
description: When you pay $100,000 for a red-hot BMW M5, you expect the twin-turbo V8 to emit a mighty song. Those who drive this superbrutal version of the midsize BMW are not generally in search of silence. And a nudge on the accelerator fills the cabin with a richly satisfying ascent from low rumble to high scream. But its a recording, a virtual roar.

title: Russia: Election Monitor Group Faces Threat of Eviction
description: Russias only independent elections monitor has been told by its landlord to either find new office space or expect continual power failures from now until March 6, severely hampering the groups ability to monitor the presidential election on March 4. The organization, Golos (whose name means vote in Russian), first came under attack nearly two months ago, as it prepared to send out 3,000 monitors to document any violations in parliamentary elections and created an interactive map for people to upload video and photographs of any election violations directly from their mobile phones. Lawmakers began calling for the group to be investigated, and state-controlled television broadcast a documentary suggesting that Golos, which receives most of its budget from Western governments, served American interests and aimed to incite an Arab Spring-type revolution in Russia.

title: Stop Over in Paris
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  We havent seen Alan Arbesfeld since October, when he told us a very funny riddle about underwear (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but hes back today with a letter addition theme that I thought was a bit easy for the twist Ive come to expect from Thursday grids. Even so, I thought his theme was punny and enjoyable.

title: How Pimps Use the Web to Sell Girls
description: In November, a terrified 13-year-old girl pounded on an apartment door in Brooklyn. When a surprised woman answered, the girl pleaded for a phone. She called her mother, and then dialed 911.

title: Lottery Numbers
Christie Avoids All the Thorns in the Thicket of Gay Marriage
description: In proposing a ballot question to let voters decide whether to legalize same-sex marriage, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey argued this week that the issue was too serious to be treated like a political football.

title: New Housing Task Force Will Zero In on Wall St.
description: After failing to produce any major prosecutions stemming from the housing crisis, an expanded federal task force is planning a new tack, cracking down on financial firms suspected of improperly bundling home loans into securities for investors, officials said Wednesday.

title: President Takes His Economic Message on the Road
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Fresh from a State of the Union address he used to make his case for re-election, President Obama took to the road on Wednesday to build support for his economic message of fairness, calling for Congress to eliminate tax deductions for companies that move jobs overseas.

title: Gingrich, Offstage
description: Those raucous Republicans thrilled by hearing Newt Gingrich denounce the destructive, vicious, negative nature of what he often calls the elite media during debates might be shocked to watch him on other occasions. He enjoys consorting with the enemy.

title: The Early Word: One More Debate
description: In Todays Times:

title: On the U.S.S. Stennis, an Assembly Line
description: If not for the bomb assembly line, life aboard a nuclear aircraft carrier would seem relatively normal. Thursdays Times looks at how, for sailors on the U.S.S. John C. Stennis, part of the daily routine involves preparing bombs for wherever the military needs them. In what could be an atmosphere of nerves, calm prevails.

title: City Students at Small Public High Schools Are More Likely to Graduate, Study Says
description: New York City teenagers attending small public high schools with about 100 students per grade were more likely to graduate than their counterparts at larger schools, according to new findings from a continuing study released on Wednesday night.

title: Romneys Swiss Account Captures Critics Fancy
description: No phrase better evokes wealth and its mysteries than Swiss bank account. And for all the mind-numbing complexity and eye-popping wealth revealed in Mitt Romneys tax returns this week, no other detail more stirred the public imagination, or drew more insinuation from his enemies, than the relatively modest  by their standards  $3 million that a trust in the name of Mr. Romneys wife reported holding in a Swiss money-market account.

title: Corrections: January 26
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Kerrey Weighs Return to Nebraska and Senate
description: Born and bred in Nebraska, Bob Kerrey was the high-profile political face of his home state as governor, senator and presidential candidate. That background made him an obvious choice for Democrats courting the best candidate to retain the seat held by Senator Ben Nelson, who is retiring.

title: Somali Pirate Gun Locker: An Oddball Assault Rifle, at Sea
description: Somali pirates cannot seem to stay out of the news. Whether they are losing their hostages without resistance to a U.S. Navy destroyer or losing their hostages (and their lives) in a U.S. military raid, they have been the January surprise on the conflict beat. This is in some ways unexpected, as, statistically, incidents of piracy off the East African coast have recently been in decline, a result of both an international naval counterpiracy presence in these waters and the wider use among merchant vessels of onboard armed security teams.

title: An Order in Oakland
description: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the Oakland Police Department to consult with a court-appointed monitor before all major decisions, bringing the department one step closer to a federal takeover.

title: Indiana House Passes a Bill on Union Fees
description: The Republican-held Indiana House of Representatives passed legislation on Wednesday barring union contracts from requiring nonunion members to pay fees for representation, ending weeks of partisan battling and all but assuring that the state will become the first in the Midwestern manufacturing belt deemed a right to work state.

title: Oasis for Resisting Status Symbols Just Might Get One
description: MUIR WOODS NATIONAL MONUMENT, Calif.  What do you get when you bring together a groundbreaking lesbian poet, a famous Zen philosopher, the founder of a prostitutes union and the inventor of the self-regulating filtered hot tub?

title: Cuba: Brazil Grants Visa to Blogger
description: Brazil granted a tourist visa on Wednesday to Yoani Snchez, a dissident Cuban author and blogger, ahead of a trip to Cuba this month by Brazils president, Dilma Rousseff. The request by Ms. Snchez to travel to Brazil for the screening of a documentary had emerged as a test of Cubas restrictive travel policies for its own citizens and Brazils willingness to prod a friendly government on a prominent human rights issue. Ms. Snchez, 36, had appealed personally for the visa to Ms. Rousseff, a former member of an urban guerrilla cell, referring to a photograph made public in December that showed Ms. Rousseff as a young woman being questioned at a military hearing by men whose faces were covered. It remains to be seen whether Cuba will allow her to travel to Brazil.

title: Arizona Candidate Challenged Over English Skills
description: SAN LUIS, Ariz.  When Alejandrina Cabrera speaks English, her face takes on an expression somewhere between deep discomfort and outright despair. Her tongue, which darts around her mouth in her native Spanish, slows to a crawl.

title: Syria Chaos Claims Priest and an Aid Group Official
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The secretary general of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent and a Christian priest have been killed in violence that flared in parts of Syria on Wednesday, as Arab and Western nations continued their attempts to isolate Syria by trying to unseat it from two committees at a United Nations agency.

title: Captain of Doomed Cruise Ship Says Course Change Was an Order
description: GIGLIO, Italy  New evidence emerged Wednesday that suggested the captain of the Costa Concordia had been repeatedly ordered by superiors to deviate from its course on Jan. 13 and head toward picturesque Giglio Island off the Tuscan coast, where the 950-foot luxury cruise liner crashed and partly sank.

title: Druid Heights, a Once-Thriving Bay Area Bohemia
description: Secreted away one and a half miles down a dirt road, Druid Heights is unknown to thousands of tourists who flock to the misty redwoods of Muir Woods.

title: Nicol Williamson, a Mercurial Actor, Is Dead at 75
description: Nicol Williamson, a Scottish-born actor whose large, renegade talent made him a controversial Hamlet, an eccentric Macbeth, an angry, high-strung Vanya and, on the screen, a cocaine-sniffing Sherlock Holmes  and whose querulous temperament could make his antics as commanding as his performances  died on Dec. 16 in Amsterdam, where he had lived for more than 20 years. He was 75.

title: Obama Wades Into Issue of Raising Dropout Age
description: President Obamas State of the Union call for every state to require students to stay in school until they turn 18 is Washingtons first direct involvement in an issue that many governors and state legislators have found tough to address.

title: Palestinians and Israelis Dont Agree on New Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Wednesday that a round of exploratory discussions with Israel under Jordanian auspices had ended. But he left open the possibility of a resumption of contacts under certain conditions and after consultations with Arab League representatives on Feb. 4.

title: Theo Angelopoulos, Greek Filmmaker, Dies at 76
description: Theo Angelopoulos, a renowned director whose films explored the human condition in general and the condition of modern Greece in particular through haunting imagery rooted in myth and epic, died on Tuesday of injuries suffered in a traffic accident near Piraeus, Greece. He was 76.

title: Venezuela: Government to Pull Out of Nationalization Proceedings
description: Venezuela said Wednesday that it had begun the process of pulling out of a World Bank arbitration forum that is considering about 20 cases involving property nationalized by President Hugo Chvezs socialist government. The Foreign Ministry said that its participation in the forum, the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, was banned by Venezuelas Constitution, which it said required disputes to be settled in Venezuelan courts. It said that the move was meant to defend Venezuelan sovereignty and that the center was biased in favor of multinational corporations. The cases before the center include one brought by Exxon over the nationalization of its share in a heavy oil project. A World Bank spokesman could not confirm that the organization had received notice of Venezuelas action.

title: Gerre Hancock, Church Organist, Dies at 77
description: Gerre Hancock, a renowned organist known for his skill at improvisation, a rare art among American classical organists, died on Saturday in Austin, Tex. He was 77.

title: Indias Political Blasphemy
description: The controversy over Salman Rushdies proposed visit to the Jaipur Literature Festival is nothing more than a dodge by Indias politicians and Muslim leaders to cover their failure to improve the dreadful conditions in which many Indian Muslims live, Dan Morrison writes in the International Herald Tribune.

title: Dick Tufeld, Robot Voice in TVs Lost in Space, Dies at 85
description: Dick Tufeld, who possessed one of Hollywoods most often-heard disembodied voices, especially from the 1950s through the 1970s, announcing or narrating television shows like Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea and commercials for products like Mr. Bubble bubble bath and Gallo wine, but who was best known for his electronic intonations as the robot in the loopy science-fiction series Lost in Space, died on Sunday at his home in the Studio City section of Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Across the World, Leaders Brace for Discontent and Upheaval
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Protesters in Moscow and Cairo fill public squares to demand representative government. Yet on the streets of Madrid and New York  or of Athens, which gave us the very word for democracy  discontent is almost as rampant.

title: Mutineers Oust Defense Chief in Papua New Guinea
description: SYDNEY  A group of soldiers in Papua New Guinea mutinied early Thursday, replacing the chief of the armed forces in an apparently bloodless raid on the nations military headquarters that they said was aimed at breaking the countrys political impasse, according to the Australian government and news reports.

title: U.S. Backups Prevail and Gain Experience
description: PANAMA  For Jurgen Klinsmann to take the United States to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, he will have to learn how to eke out some good performances  and some positive results  on the road in Central America.

title: Survey Finds That Dwindling Financial Aid Contributes to Fewer College Options
description: College freshmen entering school last fall were less likely to attend their first choice of college, a function of both competition and cost, than at any other time since 1974, and fewer received financial aid through grants or scholarships, according to an annual survey of nearly 204,000 high school students.

title: Turning to Kettlebells to Ease Back Pain
description: Kettlebells, cast-iron weights that have been used for centuries to train Russian soldiers and athletes, appear to be a promising therapy for back and neck pain, new research shows.

title: Word of the Day | skulk
description: skulk \sklk\ verb

title: James Farentino, a Dashing Leading Man, Dies at 73
description: James Farentino, a tall, dark and dashing actor who in his nearly 100 roles on stage, screen and television often defied the stereotype of the leading man, even though he fit the picture, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 73.

title: All but Over, Except for the Shouting
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It will be power and competitive fire against power and competitive fire Saturday when Maria Sharapova and Victoria Azarenka meet in the womens final at the Australian Open.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: All This Craziness
description: Several years back, in Paris, Fendi invited Amy Winehouse to sing at a party, and lots of people went and many more waited outside. I wedged myself into a corner near the small stage and just watched her go to work with that voice. On Wednesday, as the spring haute couture shows wound down, Jean Paul Gaultier evoked her chaotic essence in a marvelous show.

title: The Young General In His Labyrinth
description: HONG KONG  It appears that South Korea and the United States are going to proceed with joint war games involving a quarter-million troops next month  the first external test for the young trainee leader of North Korea.

title: Bryan Brothers Advance to Mens Doubles Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In their 14th year on tour, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, the top-seeded mens doubles team at the Australian Open, have learned the danger of playing too conservatively.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/26/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/26/2012

title: Valentinos Lawn Party
description: In the program notes for Valentinos spring couture show, the dresses had names like Polignac and Nicolas Ledoux, with a mention of the number of hours required to make or embroider the garment. A smocked dress in a delicate shamrock print with organza spirals took 1,000 hours. Dont say it looks like the bedroom curtains.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 26, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Model-Morphosis | Lindsey Wixson at Jean Paul Gaultier
description: (function($) {var data = chameleonData;var sliderCount = data.length;for (var i=0; i

title: Jan. 26, 1950 | India Becomes a Republic
description: On Jan. 26, 1950, two and a half years after gaining independence from Britain, India proclaimed itself a republic, ending its status as a British dominion. The New York Times wrote, Assumption of the status of a sovereign democratic republic brings in to force the new Constitution, which abolishes untouchability and includes the most detailed document of fundamental rights of any constitution.

title: French Police Detain Founder of Breast Implant Maker
description: PARIS  The founder of a French company that made hundreds of thousands of breast implants from industrial-grade silicone, causing anxiety among women around the world, was detained in a dawn raid on his home in southern France, the authorities said Thursday.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 26, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Travel With the Boss: The Pluses and the Pitfalls.

title: Young Egyptians Speak, One Year After Tahrir Square
description: Note: Please preview this video to make sure it is appropriate for your students. All the questions below are based on the video, but students might also read a related article, Egyptians Gather on First Anniversary of Revolt.

title: Newt Gingrich, Gold and Property Rights
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Is There Anything Marc Newson Hasnt Designed?
description: The first week in October, bound for two days of client meetings in northern Italy, Marc Newson chartered a single-engine Pilatus PC-12 prop plane with a paint job by the designer Philippe Starck. It took off from Le Bourget airport outside Paris at 11 a.m. Newson had been back in Europe less than a week after meetings in Singapore. He had also recently been in Australia, where, as part of an extensive fixtures-and-fittings commission from Caroma, an Australian design-and-manufacturing house of bathroom products, he participated in technical tests to determine flow rates of sewage through variously shaped pipes. The Caroma engineers simulated human waste with specially designed plastic bags of miso that conformed to an international stool standard.

title: Ream Completes Transfer to Bolton
description: The day after his wedding, which was Jan. 7, Tim Ream received a phone call from Bolton Wanderers Manager Owen Coyle.

title: Johannesburgs Most Wanted
description: We r taking 1 day / nite off 2 get really drunk wif some homies in a dodgy hood in Johannesburg called FIETAS on New Years Eve, the e-mail read. Dere are always fights in Fietas on New Years Eve which should be fun. And so Ninja, the leader of the South African rap-rave crew Die Antwoord, invited me to ring in 2012 in the lair of zef, the scene the band brought to the world two years ago with a viral music video called Zef Side. Zef is the nasty, freaky, gleefully trashy underbelly of post-apartheid white South African culture. It is bling and bruises and weed-whacker mullets like the one sported by Yo-Landi Vi$$er, the tiny blonde who orbits Ninja like a foulmouthed muse.

title: Challenging the Silence of Others
description: Bharat Choudhary has seen the power of religious hatred up close. After the 2002 sectarian riots in Gujarat State, India, Mr. Choudhary counseled victims who had been paralyzed or raped during the violence.

title: A Timeline of Marc Newsons Designs
description: The prolific Australian-born industrial designers most memorable works over the past 25 years.

title: What Are the Best Movies You Saw in 2011?
description: The Oscar nominations are in, and nine films are nominated for Best Picture this year. What are the best movies you saw in 2011? Why? If you were in charge of giving your own movie awards, what categories would you create, and which films, actors, writers or directors from this or any other year would win?

title: As Tensions Rise, Egypt Bars Exit of Six Americans
description: WASHINGTON  Building tensions between the United States and Egypt flashed into the open Thursday when Cairo confirmed that it had barred at least a half-dozen Americans from leaving the country and the Obama administration threatened explicitly to withhold its annual aid to the Egyptian military.

title: Images of Republic Day 2012
From the Archives: Republic Day 1958
description: Today is the eighth anniversary of the proclamation of the Republic of India, an editorial in The New York Times begins on January 26, 1958.

title: Mike Mayocks Top 5 at Every Position for 2012 Draft
description: The draft is three months away, and the NFL Network analyst Mike Mayock has unveiled his opening rankings on the top five draft prospects at each position.

title: In a Post-Bankruptcy World, Hunting the Elusive Saab Bargain
description: LOS ANGELES  However disheartening the circumstances that lead a business to declare insolvency, we consumers tend to register the brightly colored signage heralding a going-out-of-business sale and think primarily one thing: I can get stuff dirt cheap.

title: Day 3 at Senior Bowl,  Risers and Fallers
description: Cecil Lammey, Jene Bramel and Matt Waldman are in Mobile, Ala., to cover practices leading up to the Senior Bowl.

title: Davos Grand Cru 2012
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  If you gather enough millionaires and billionaires in a single place, the talk during the evening hours inevitably turns to wine. The World Economic Forum used to cater to them by conducting tastings, led by well-known critics, as part of its official schedule of events in Davos. Then the global financial crisis struck, and it no longer looked right to sip grands crus while the economy went down the drain. Wine tastings were taken off the schedule.

title: Root Vegetable Recipes
description: Six recipes based on a given root, with room for improvisation. Bake beets instead of celeriac; make creamy potato soup, braise carrots, braise parsnips and so on.

title: Notes From Underground
description: There was a time when the only root vegetables anyone paid attention to were carrots and potatoes. (I know potatoes are tubers. Whatever.) Turnips were dclass, celeriac unheard of, beets a pain to clean. The perception has changed, in part because it was all wrong; in part because if youre going to eat seasonal and local, you are going to eat roots in winter, even if you live in California; and in part because roasted root vegetables, which most of us have discovered only recently, are, like, the greatest thing ever, and even the company cafeteria cant ruin them.

title: From Alaska, Great Concern for Central Park
description: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | In the interest of preserving an already-compromised sliver of urban wilderness, state legislators are asking the federal government to take over Central Park.

title: 3-D It Yourself, Thanks to New Library Site
description: (Courtesy NYPL Labs) Samuel Dixon crossing Niagara.

title: Running the Numbers: Why Our Productivity Improved
description: My company has 14 employees. In the office we have me, two sales engineers, one design engineer, a part-time bookkeeper and a part-time administrative assistant. The other nine are out on the shop floor. They build, finish, and ship our product.

title: London Bankers Stay Put as Bonuses Wane
description: LONDON  The beginning of the year is usually a busy time for bankers and recruiters as many staff members wait to get their bonuses before setting off to a rival.

title: Trichet Nominated To Board Of EADS
description: PARIS  Jean-Claude Trichet, the former president of the European Central Bank, was nominated Thursday to the board of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent company of Airbus, as part of a long-anticipated reshuffling of the groups senior management. The move carefully preserves the balance of French and German representation in the executive suite.

title: Contemporary Dance From Around the Globe  in The Hague
description: Holland Dance presents a comprehensive and exciting program of contemporary dance from Thursday through Feb. 26. Held in The Hague, only 30 miles from Amsterdam, the festival offers a packed schedule of top companies from Europe, Asia, the United States, South America and Africa, plus numerous workshops and talks.

title: At Zynga, Keeping It Virtual and Vague
description: Even for an Internet company, Zynga has an unusual way of making money. Tens of millions of people play its games, like FarmVille and Mafia Wars, but only a relative handful buy the virtual goods that make the company viable. In the months running up to Zyngas public offering in December, the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to get some clarity on this new-fangled business model. Zynga, whether for competitive or other reasons, tried mightily to keep things obscure.

title: Tigers Infield Defense Could Be Brutal
description: With Miguel Cabrera confirming to a Venezuelan newspaper that he will be moving to third base to accommodate Prince Fielder, the Detroit Tigers may have put together a comical infield defense.

title: Illumina Adopts Poison Pill in Bid to Thwart Roche
description: Illumina has adopted a shareholder rights plan, or poison pill, as it tries to block a hostile takeover by the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding.

title: On Our Radar: A Beached Whale
description: Workers complete the dissection and burial of a 65-foot fin whale, an endangered species, that washed ashore in Ocean City, N.J., apparently after colliding with a vessel. [The Philadelphia Inquirer]

title: Gates Foundation Moves to Close $750 Million Gap in Global Fund
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation said Thursday that it had stepped up its commitment to an international fund to fights AIDS and other diseases, pledging an additional $750 million to the organization.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Futures Industry Sees Chance to Shape Oversight | Earlier this month, in a ninth-floor conference room of the Northern Trust bank in Chicago, an unlikely assembly of futures industry executives, regulators and customers discussed the fallout from MF Globals collapse.

title: One-Billion-Euro Loss and a Silver Lining for Nokia
description: Nokia, the worlds largest seller of mobile phones by volume, said Thursday that it suffered a huge loss in the fourth quarter but reported better-than-expected sales of its new Windows smartphones, sending its shares soaring.

title: Opinion Report: Investigating Mortgage Abuses
description: From the editorial page

title: Iran Says It May Cut Off Its Oil Exports to Europe
description: Iran struck a combative tone Thursday in its confrontation with the West over the nuclear issue, threatening to terminate oil exports to European nations even before their embargo takes effect this summer. But its president also acknowledged that the regimen of punitive sanctions imposed on Iran, which he had long dismissed as insignificant, were hurting ordinary Iranians.

title: Gingrich Winning the Crowd Race in Florida
description: MIAMI  How much do crowds matter?

title: Manila Negotiates Broader Military Ties With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and the Philippines are exploring increased joint military exercises and other military cooperation that would not entail a major buildup or a reopening of permanent bases, officials in both capitals said Thursday.

title: Markets Fall as Bank Shares and Home Sales Decline
description: Stocks fell, reversing a rally that sent the Dow Jones industrial average toward its highest level since 2008 earlier Thursday, after bank shares tumbled and a report showed that sales of new homes declined unexpectedly.

title: New Study Gives Small Schools Initiative a Thumbs Up
Thursday Reading: New School Meal Rules Aim to Cut Obestity
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Netflix Bounces Back, and Giving Debates a TV Moment
description: Netflix reported fourth-quarter numbers that showed it had bounced back after bungling  and later abandoning  a plan to spin off its DVD-by-mail service, Brian Stelter reported. The company had lost about 800,000 subscribers in the United States in the third quarter, leveling off at 23.8 million; at the end of the fourth quarter, it had 24.4 million, somewhat more than it had expected to have.

title: AT&T in $6.7 Billion Loss on Failure of T-Mobile Deal
description: Breakups are tough. Just ask AT&T.

title: Nadal Defeats Federer, Again, to Move to Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Roger Federer attacked. Rafael Nadal defended, perhaps better than he has defended before, which is quite a thought considering how many balls Nadal has hunted down in the corners of the worlds great tennis stadiums.

title: Conventional Wisdom Holding: Times Readers Favor The Artist and Hugo
description: Among the nine nominees for the Academy Award for best picture, The Artist has staked an early claim to the Oscar among New York Times readers  who may or may not be voting members of the Academy.

title: The Get | Tony Duquette for Coach Rings
description: Oftentimes the first thing that Tony Duquette jewelry brings to mind are enormous gems with  unsurprisingly  matching price tags. But this month the estate of the esteemed designer and the American brand Coach are introducing a collaborative collection that has all the splash, for a lot less cash. There are 25 pieces in all, starting at a modest $48 for a bejeweled ladybug stickpin, and the most identifiably Duquette-esque stunners are like this one, the Empire Stone ($650): a malachite cocktail ring set in 18-karat gold-plated silver. Knock, knock.

title: DrChrono Raises $2.8 Million to Digitize Doctors Visits
description: Anyone who has ever spent any amount of time shuttling between doctors offices for medical treatment knows how difficult it is to stay on top of all the diagnoses, treatments, recommendations and prescriptions between visits.

title: Who Has Apples at Work? In Many Cases, Its the Bosses
description: Try McKaskle, the chief technology officer of Symantec Services Group, with an iPad.

title: Carjacking Suspect Fatally Shot by Police
description: Updated, 3:39 p.m. | A 22-year-old carjacking suspect was fatally shot by an off-duty police lieutenant after a predawn car crash in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn, on Thursday, the police said.

title: Cameron Pitches Britain to Investors Sour on Euro Zone
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  With concern lingering about the future of the euro zone, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain donned his salesmans cap on Thursday and delivered a full-throated pitch to the throngs of executives and bankers gathered here: invest in Britain instead.

title: Amgen to Buy Micromet for $1.16 Billion
description: Amgen has agreed to buy Micromet, a biotechnology company that develops cancer drugs, for $1.16 billion.

title: Nigerias Dangerous Slide
description: Since the radical Islamic sect Boko Haram carried out its deadliest attack yet last Friday in the northern Nigerian city of Kano, killing at least 185 people, opinion writers have been mulling over what the country should do about the group that has killed at least 935 people since 2009.

title: London Theater Journal: Comfortably Mousetrapped
description: LONDON  It was a dark and stormy afternoon when I ventured into the old building with the twisting staircases, on one of those London side streets that always seems to be in different places when you look for them. Oh, I knew what I was in for: screams, gunshots, a whistling psychopath, fraught minutes in the dark and rigid postures of fear. But I hadnt come to St. Martins Theater to be frightened or even stimulated. I was there for comfort.

title: Leaner Operations Give U.S. Airlines a Profitable Year
description: Despite everything that has been working against them, from a dismal global economy to rising fuel prices, the nations top airlines  United Continental Holdings, Delta Air Lines, US Airways, and Southwest Airlines  all turned a profit last year.

title: To Deter Illegal Parking, Why Not a Little Shame?
description: Does public shame not have a proper role in New York civic life? A dispute between the citys lawmakers and the mayor boils down to that question.

title: Daily Report: Chinese Factories and the iEconomy
description: In the latest installment of the iEconomy series in The New York Times, Charles Duhigg and David Barboza report on the manufacturing of consumer electronics in China. They report that the workers assembling iPhones, iPads and other devices often labor in harsh conditions, according to employees inside those plants, worker advocates and documents published by companies themselves. Problems are as varied as onerous work environments and serious  sometimes deadly  safety problems:

title: USA, USA, Were No. 47!
description: I like Reporters Without Borders; the Paris-based organization does important work. But its annual Press Freedom Index, which ranks countries from 1 to 179, gets a little ridiculous. Like US News & World Report with colleges, they freshen the list each year based on new developments, andagain like US Newsthey sometimes end up with a pecking-order that doesnt quite mesh with reality.

title: What Were Reading
description: National Restaurant Association: Theres no escaping the pizza and chicken wings now. Some 48 million Americans are expected to order takeout or restaurant-delivery food on Super Bowl Sunday, Feb. 5. And 12 million will visit a restaurant or bar  primarily families with children, or adults between the ages of 18 and 34.  Glenn CollinsThe Washington Post: Everything has to be perfect or it is not accepted. A sushi master laments the decline of traditional Japanese sushi in the United States. Why? Cultural issues, for one thing, along with difficulties in training and immigration.  Eric Asimov

title: Tough Super Bowl for Ryan and Jets
description: Michael Silver of Yahoo Sports has listed the five biggest losers heading into the Super Bowl. Read his reasons for each pick.

title: Time Warner Cables Net Profit Increases by 44%
description: Time Warner Cable, in the process of repositioning itself beyond cable television to attract high-speed Internet users, said Thursday that its net profit increased 44 percent in the fourth quarter that ended Dec. 31, to $564 million.

title: Poetry Pairing | Which One
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Maxine Kumins Which One with a Science Times essay by Natalie Angier, The Creature Connection.

title: World-Roaming Web Site Tells How to Eat Like the Locals
description: Eating locally doesnt necessarily mean eating close to home: Thats what one New York couple learned from years of roaming the globe. Now theyve created Eat Your World, a Web site that steers fellow travelers to indigenous food in scores of destinations, from Detroit to Bali.

title: Through a Glass Darkly
description: Melena Ryzik talks with Jeff Cronenweth, the Oscar-nominated cinematographer of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.

title: Bill Gates Donates $750 Million to Shore Up Disease-Fighting Fund
description: In a show of faith in the faltering Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, Bill Gates donated $750 million to the fund on Thursday.

title: What Are the Odds That Stats Would Be This Popular?
description: Most of my life I went to parties and heard a little groan when people heard what I did, says Robert Tibshirani, a statistics professor at Stanford University. Now theyre all excited to meet me.

title: New Romney Ad Focuses on Gingrichs Ethics Violation
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Moving on to Phase 2 of its aggressive campaign to stop Newt Gingrichs momentum before the primary here on Tuesday, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts is beginning to show a new, bruising advertisement focusing on the Congressional ethics finding against Mr. Gingrich in the 1990s.

title: Questions for Li Qiang of China Labor Watch
description: Li Qiang, 39, is the founder of China Labor Watch, a nonprofit group in New York City that seeks to improve labor conditions in China. In the late 1990s, while studying law in southwest Chinas Sichuan Province, he began supporting striking workers and taxi drivers. Later, he moved south, to Chinas biggest factory zones near Shenzhen. He worked at several electronics, toy and shoe factories, where he investigated labor conditions, and tried to expose what he saw as unjust and inhumane conditions.

title: Davos Potpourri, Day 2: The Party Never Ends
description: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, rolled on Thursday, with news-making speeches by Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, Bill Gates and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, among others. Mr. Cameron proposed a coalition of the willing to open up global free trade, Mr. Gates pledged $750 million to a struggling AIDS fund, and Archbishop Tutu told the downtrodden financiers in attendance: Each one of us is made for goodness, even bankers.

title: Health Insurance Deductibles Doubled in 7 Years, Study Finds
description: 1/27/12 | Updated Headline adjusted to more accurately reflect the article.

title: Oral HPV More Common in Men Than Women
description: About one in 15 Americans is infected with oral human papillomavirus, a sexually transmitted virus that causes throat cancers, and the disease is especially common among men, new research shows.

title: Han Hans U-Turn?
description: BEIJING  Three weeks after Han Han, Chinas most prominent blogger, published three controversial blog posts in which he casts a sullen eye on Revolution, Democracy and Freedom, the online debate has slid into absurdity.

title: Microbe Economics
description: Limited posting, because Im down with a heavy cold  consuming enough Sudafed to run a meth lab  and getting the column out has to take priority.

title: Leno Joke Draws Fire From Two Members of British Parliament
description: Two members of Britains Parliament have become the latest people to condemn Jay Leno for a joke that appeared on NBCs Tonight Show and suggested that a sacred shrine in India belonged to Mitt Romney.

title: Photos of the Moment | Valentino
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Marijuana Push in Colorado Likens It to Alcohol
description: DENVER  Proponents of marijuana have argued for years that the drug is safer than alcohol, both to individuals and society. But a ballot proposal to legalize possession of marijuana in small amounts in Colorado, likely to be on the November ballot, is putting the two intoxicants back into the same sentence, urging voters to regulate marijuana like alcohol, as the ballot propositions title puts it.

title: Intense Tennis for Insomniacs
description: The first thing you noticed if you stayed awake (or woke up) to watch Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer play in their Australian Open semifinal (start time: 3:30 a.m. Eastern), is that the ever-gracious Nadal wore that eye-searing green shirt to help keep you awake. Yes, he has been wearing it the whole tournament, indicating he has a soft spot for American insomniacs, although little regard for their retinas. But the second thing you noticed is just how much these two do not want to lose to each other.

title: Its the Smartest Computer In the Room. Beware.
description: The title of Robert Harriss new thriller, The Fear Index, comes from the volatility index, or VIX  also known as the fear index  which measures expectations of violent swings in the market, as Wall Street watchers know from the harrowing meltdown of 2008. This fleet-footed, if sometimes hokey, novel takes place in the rarefied world of hedge funds, featuring one that has achieved huge returns by short-selling and using trading algorithms that thrive on panic.

title: 2 Biotech Firms Bolster Their Drug Pipelines Through Deals
description: Two big biotechnology companies announced on Thursday that they would buy smaller companies that are harnessing novel technologies to develop drug treatments for leukemias and lymphomas.

title: The Greater Depression
description: One thing everyone always says is that while this Lesser Depression may be bad, its nothing like the Great Depression.

title: Making Indoor Recess More Active
description: Winter months can mean less recess time for students. Anything from sleet to frigid temperatures can force schools to keep children indoors, and children kept indoors and inactive all day are simply not children who are ripe for attentive learning. Research supports recess  but sometimes the weather doesnt.

title: Finalists Named for Jewish Literary Award
description: The Jewish Book Council has announced the five finalists for the 2012 Sami Rhor Prize for Jewish Literature, which will be awarded next month to an emerging writer who seeks to add to the knowledge and understanding of Jewish history and culture.

title: Costa Rica Stands Between the U.S. and London
description: The United States womens soccer team could provide a riveting story line at the 2012 London Olympics, given the household names of players like Hope Solo and Abby Wambach, and the galvanizing performance the Americans displayed last year at the World Cup.

title: Two Percent Is Not Enough
description: Im being asked for comments on the Feds low-rates-until-2014 announcement. Its a step in the right direction  and it has had a visible effect on markets, pushing long-term rates down, which is all good.

title: In Canada, a Sports Juggernaut Missing One Thing: Winning Teams
description: TORONTO  One of the first things you notice when an employee of Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment hands you a business card is the 21 logos on the back.

title: U.S. and France to Honor Miles Davis and dith Piaf With Stamps
description: Both Miles Davis and dith Piaf were maverick, contrarian performers, even more esteemed after their deaths than during their lifetimes, so it makes sense that they should now be recognized simultaneously with stamps issued in their honor. The United States and France announced Thursday that both countries would issue separate stamps this year to commemorate the artists and their music.

title: Runway in Review
description: Elie SaabDesigner: Elie SaabDate: Wednesday, Jan. 25, Muse Bourdelle, Grand Palais, galerie sud-est, porte H, avenue Winston Churchill, 8ePhotos: slide show
Cameron Brown, Carnegie-Mellon 95, and e-commerce director at The New York Times, shares insights into news and technology with his alma mater: Extra, Extra dot com.

title: A Cinematographers Fincher Factor
description: Can cinematography be in your DNA? It is for Jeff Cronenweth, son of the cinematographer Jordan Cronenweth. Jeff, Oscar-nominated this week for his work on David Finchers Girl With the Dragon Tattoo (and last year for The Social Network), grew up on sets assisting his father, a veteran cinematographer who worked on movies ranging from Peggy Sue Got Married to Blade Runner and who died in 1996. It was while Jeff was helping his father that he was introduced to Mr. Fincher on the set of a music video. Mr. Fincher eventually hired him as the cinematographer of Fight Club, and from then they developed their signature moody, dimly lit style  not too different from Jordan Cronenweths  together. Here, Jeff Cronenweth talks about his fathers influence, the Fincher factor and whether hell ever shoot something light and fluffy again.

title: Mr. Camerons Excellent Adventure
description: Despite David Camerons downbeat talk about the euro zone, the British prime minister appears to be enjoying himself on the Continent. Shortly after delivering a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Mr. Cameron dropped in on a private afternoon tea in a cafe on the Davos main street, the Promenade. There, the mayor of London, Boris Johnson, was detailing a new advertising campaign to promote investment in Britain, in conjunction with the 2012 London Olympics.

title: Carnegie Halls 2012-13 Season Includes a Latin American Festival
description: An Arab-Israeli orchestra, a Latin American festival and the crowning ensemble of Venezuelas music program aimed at helping the poor will be major presences at Carnegie Hall next season, examples of the growing urge to make classical music socially relevant.

title: In North Carolina, the Governor and a Lawmaker Will Not Seek Re-election
description: 5:20 p.m. | Updated Bev Perdue, a Democrat who made history when she became North Carolinas first female governor in 2009, will not seek re-election this year, a Democratic source with knowledge of her decision said on Thursday.

title: Video of Wednesdays Protest Marches in Egypt
description: While Wednesdays first anniversary of the Egyptian revolution was treated, officially, as a celebration by the military council that still rules the country, activists who insist that their revolution remains unfinished also took to the streets in protest.

title: Fewer Students Attending Their First-Choice Colleges, Survey Shows
description: A survey of nearly 204,000 college freshmen who started school in 2011 indicated that only 58 percent of them enrolled at their first-choice college, the lowest percentage to do so since the question was first asked in 1974.

title: California to Consider Major Revision to Zero-Emission Mandate
description: This week, the California Air Resources Board, commonly known as CARB, will vote this week on a staff recommendation to require a significant increase of zero- and near-zero-emission cars to be on state roads in 2025. If the program is adopted, it would effectively require the addition of 1.4 million advanced-powertrain vehicles in 2025. They would include 500,000 battery-electric or fuel-cell cars and about 900,000 plug-in hybrids, called transitional zero-emission vehicles, or TZEVs, by CARB.

title: Have These Symptoms? Buy This Drug
description: It began suddenly a little over 10 years ago. With impressive fluency, friends, family members and patients started asking me about random medications, the odd syncopations of those invented, polysyllabic pharmaceutical brand names  Viagra, Lipitor  rolling perfectly off their tongues.

title: Fashion Fund Confidential
description: It seems hard to imagine that there is a great consumer desire for another documentary following the lives of impoverished fashion designers as they struggle to succeed. And yet I found myself oddly compelled by a new Web series that goes behind the scenes of the most recent CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund competition, namely because the directors Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg managed to pull back the curtain well beyond the typical gloss.

title: Gingrich Opens Up New Line of Attack on Romney
description: 12:55 p.m. | Updated  MOUNT DORA, Fla.  Look for Newt Gingrich to abandon his above-it-all presidential tone at Thursdays debate and come out rip-roaring about Mitt Romneys investments that, Mr. Gingrich contends, profited from home foreclosures in Florida.

title: Just One Look | Valentino
description: At Valentino, Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli sent out 43 bewitchingly fragile, feminine looks  dresses of smocking, lace, silver thread embroideries and floral taffetas. As is their custom, the designers listed the number of hours certain embroideries required on the show notes. A stunning sheath with lace collar, sheer sleeves and a caged bodice (crocheted in gold thread and decorated with pearls) required 650 hours just for the crochet. This is, indeed, really slow fashion.

title: Mr. Bogin of Moscow Meets New York's Schools
Jane Addams H.S. Principal Resigns Amid Credit Scandal
Dear FloFab: Should a Host Wait to Wash Dishes?
description: As Valentines Day approaches, with its perilous combination of food, romance and etiquette, Florence Fabricant would love to help with advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a question concerning the holiday  or any dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Ravenous | The Taste of Home
description: I began the Year of the Dragon with the taste of sea and salt.

title: Selling a Business on Facebook
description: An independent florist with a reputation for unusual arrangements, Bloom is a fixture in historic downtown Bentonville, Ark., an area whose rapid growth was recently accelerated by the opening of the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art.

title: Eiko Ishioka, Multifaceted Designer and Oscar Winner, Dies at 73
description: Eiko Ishioka, a designer who brought an eerie, sensual surrealism to film and theater, album covers, the Olympics and Cirque du Soleil, in the process earning an Oscar, a Grammy and a string of other honors, died on Saturday in Tokyo. She was 73.

title: Romney Holds Fire on Gingrich as Surrogates Fire Away
description: 1:38 p.m. | Updated JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Standing before a large Obama Isnt Working sign, Mitt Romney on Thursday came to a printing plant that recently shut its doors and returned his focus squarely to President Obama, criticizing the presidents policies and his State of the Union speech Tuesday night, among other things.

title: TimesCast | January 26, 2012
description: Egyptian authorities block at least six Americans from leaving | Newt Gingrich promotes a new era of space exploration.

title: At Euro Talks, a Calm Arm-Twister From the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The worlds financiers and finance ministers have descended on the annual forum in Davos, Switzerland, at another perilous moment, with the sovereign debt woes in Europe sapping strength from emerging markets and threatening global growth.

title: 36 Hours in Birmingham, England
description: A photographic tour of the city.

title: 36 Hours: Birmingham, England
description: IN terms of respect, Birmingham is the undisputed Rodney Dangerfield of British cities. Ask a Londoner about the city, and youre likely to receive either the blankest of stares or an unkind rendition of Birminghams memorable accent. American travelers, too, have mostly ignored Englands second-largest city, aside from the view from their London-bound flights. But with an only-in-Britain tapestry of vividly multiethnic neighborhoods, a postindustrial urbanity thats gentrifying before your eyes and a food scene that cant be ignored, Birmingham is no longer simply flyover country. Welcome to Englands heartland metropolis: big-shouldered, friendly and fun.

title: Bucs Hire Rutgerss Schiano as Coach
description: 10:19 p.m. | Updated Greg Schiano left Rutgers to become the coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Thursday, less than a week before college footballs national signing day.

title: New Rules for Booking Air Travel
description: New federal rules giving consumers more information and flexibility when they book air travel took effect this week.

title: Winter Getaways for Families
description: Ten places to go from Miami to Arizona to Costa Rica.

title: Franco Named to Mets Hall of Fame
description: John Franco will become the 26th member of the Mets Hall of Fame, the team announced Thursday.

title: Look, Ma, No Hands! Operating a Laptop With Eyes Only
description: When the great history books of technology are written, the early 2000s may be remembered as the Age of Human-Computer Interface Exploration.

title: One Family, Two Evenings
description: While the parents go out for dinner, the children stay behind at the hotels kids club.

title: American Idol Continues Downward Ratings Trend
description: If the Fox network thought it could reverse the downward ratings trend for American Idol this season by exposing the show to the big audience that watched Sunday nights N.F.C. championship game, the results Wednesday night were surely disappointing.

title: Judge Orders Arizona Candidate Struck From Ballot
description: Lawyers for Alejandrina Cabrera, a candidate for the City Council in the border community of San Luis, Ariz., said Thursday that they might appeal to the Arizona Supreme Court a lower-court ruling that Ms. Cabrera be removed from the ballot because she did not speak English proficiently.

title: As You Like It and Into The Woods Will Be This Summers Central Park Productions
description: This summer will mark the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, and to mark the occasion, the Public Theater on Thursday announced a production meant to take full advantage of that setting: a revival of the 1987 Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical Into the Woods that is based on an acclaimed London staging performed outdoors in Regents Park there.

title: Analysts Get to Work: Indies Did Well, Songwriters Not So Much
description: Now that the nominations are out, its time to parse every little Oscar-related thing.

title: A Mayor With a Taste for Cervantes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sometimes detours from his regular literary diet of political biographies and business school bibles to savor an occasional spy novel, as The New York Times reported Thursday.

title: Defense Budget Cuts Would Limit Raises and Close Bases
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon took the first major step toward shrinking its budget after a decade of war as it announced Thursday that it wanted to limit pay raises for troops, increase health insurance fees for military retirees and close bases in the United States.

title: Study Finds Virus to Be Fast Learner on Infecting
description: Viruses regularly evolve new ways of making people sick, but scientists usually do not become aware of these new strategies until years or centuries after they have evolved. In a new study published on Thursday in the journal Science, however, a team of scientists at Michigan State University describes how viruses evolved a new way of infecting cells in little more than two weeks.

title: Dole Releases Stinging Critique of Gingrich
description: 3:59 p.m. | Updated The Romney campaign on Thursday released a scathing critique of Newt Gingrich by Bob Dole, the former Republican presidential candidate and senator from Kansas. The statement comes as some establishment Republicans have been stepping up their attacks of Mr. Gingrich.

title: Out of Perfume? Rosewood Hotels Enlist Fragrance Butlers
description: Hotels today are in the thick of a trend that caters to their guests seemingly smallest needs, by doing things like providing custom playlists for their iPods and giving them eight choices of pillows for their beds. Now, the luxury brand Rosewood has a new amenity to add to the list: perfumes that are specific to each property. This month, eight Rosewood properties began supplying guests with a fragrance butler, who is trained in the merits of the different scents being offered.Within five minutes of receiving a call to the concierge to request the service, a fragrance butler arrives at a room, carrying a silver tray of perfumes and colognes. Guests spritz themselves with a scent from the fragrance menu, which is tailored to each hotel. (The Carlyle, for example, has an elegant, old-world feel, and the choices include Chanel Chance and Herms Eau des Merveilles for women and Ralph Lauren Polo Black for men.) There is no limit to the number of times that the fragrance butler can be summoned.

title: Apple, Electronics and Environmental Ills
description: In an article in Thursdays Times, my colleague Charles Duhigg and I detail the human cost of producing some of the worlds most popular gadgets in an investigation into labor conditions at the plants of some of Apples suppliers in China.

title: A Forgotten Theater Above an East Village Grocery
description: Like many in the neighborhood, Kevin Shea Adams, a photographer and musician living in the East Village, wondered what secrets lay behind a massive brick facade above the awnings of East Village Farms, a grocery store on Avenue A between Sixth and Seventh Streets. Eventually he got permission to photograph the space, a long abandoned theater. The grocery used the vaulted cavern as a storage room, but remnants of the theaters past glory remain.

title: On National Holiday, Australian Leader Forced to Flee Protesters
description: A fancy dinner. A hurried escape. A shoe left behind, found and offered back by an unlikely suitor.

title: Chickpea Soup With Sausage
description: Mark Bittman makes a chickpea soup with (optional) sausage.

title: Mitt Romney Previews Thursdays Debate
description: At a Thursday morning rally in Jacksonville, Mr. Romney said he was looking forward to the debate that evening and previewed some likely themes.

title: Organizations Say Torture Is Widespread in Libya Jails
description: CAIRO  Torture and death in detention have become widespread problems in postwar Libya, international humanitarian groups said Thursday, a troubling indication that some Qaddafi-era abuses continue under the fractured rule of the countrys interim government and regionally organized militias.

title: 24H Party People
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Pentagons Budget Proposal
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta and Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, outlined on Thursday a new budget proposal.

title: Nadal Vs. Federer: Breaking It Down
description: Roger Federer fell for the illusion of the open court in his semi-final loss to Rafael Nadal at the Australian Open Thursday morning.

title: How NYTimes.com Readers Cut the Defense Budget
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has outlined a strategy guiding hundreds of billions of dollars in Pentagon budget cuts. Heres how more than 12,000 readers chose to solve an interactive puzzle with the same goals.

title: Kenny Chesney Leads Country Music Awards Nominees
description: The country music singer Kenny Chesney now has nine more reasons to tip that ever-present cowboy hat of his. He led all artists with nominations in nine categories, entertainer of the year and best song among them, when the Academy of Country Music announced its slate of contenders for its 47th annual honors on Thursday.

title: The Minimalist: Chickpea Soup With Sausage
description: Chickpeas have it all: fantastic texture, rich flavor and  when you cook them from scratch, which I highly recommend  the most amazing cooking liquid.

title: Sharp Drop in State Funding for Higher Education
description: The latest casualty of the economic downturn is state funding of higher education.

title: Suspect Arrested in Fatal Beating of Bronx Man
description: A 29-year-old man was arrested Thursday in the October robbery and murder of a man beaten to death in his former Bronx apartment building for $15, the police said.

title: Cuomo Stays Quiet on Christies Plan to Put Gay Marriage on Ballot
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is not about to get in a fight with his New Jersey counterpart, Chris Christie, over same-sex marriage.

title: Revamped Search Urged for a Nuclear Waste Site
description: WASHINGTON  A commission appointed to find alternatives to a failed plan to store nuclear waste in the Nevada desert declared on Thursday that the United States would have to develop a consent-based approach for choosing a site because leaving the decision to Congress had failed.

title: Azarenka vs. Sharapova: Time to Reach for the Mute Button?
description: There will be a lot at stake in the Australian Open womens final between Victoria Azarenka and Maria Sharapova on Saturday. The winner will become the new world No. 1, supplanting Caroline Wozniacki. Azarenka, a 22-year-old from Belarus, is going for her first Grand Slam title, while Sharapova, 24, is trying for her first since winning in Melbourne in 2008.

title: More Ways to Teach With Film: The 2011 Awards Season
description: Updated: Feb. 27, 2012

title: As Top-Ranked Mens Teams Fall, Baylor Women Keep Winning
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: Music Fan Documents Icons
description: Since 2009 Chad Batka has documented countless singers, song-writers, rappers and musicians for the The New York Times.

title: Macworld Conference Carries On Without Apple
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated to correct the date of the year that Steven P. Jobs last appeared at Macworld.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Slashes C.E.O.s Bonus
description: LONDON  Royal Bank of Scotland announced on Thursday that it would pay its chief executive, Stephen Hester, an all-stock bonus of 963,000, or $1.5 million, less than half what he received last year.

title: Parental Quandary Considered: The Sex Offender Next Door Is Not the Problem
description: C.s quandary was simple, and read something like a nightmare (or the opening sequence of an episode of Law and Order). Shed received notice from the local sheriff that a registered sex offender was moving into the house next door to hers. This was no Romeo and Juliet misunderstood teen, but someone with a genuine history of preying on young men and boys, although not as young as C.s toddler son.

title: House Democrats Embrace Obamas Newfound Combativeness
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  The on-again-off-again relationship between Barack Obama and House Democrats appears to be on again with the presidents turn toward a more populist, confrontational tone on the Republican Party.

title: Look of the Moment | La Seydoux
description: The Look: Vroom Vroom. The classic American cars that speed across pieces from Pradas latest collection give whole new meaning to the term fast fashion.

title: As Evaluation Talks Resume, Some Teachers Press for a Resolution
Leaders in Euro Zone Shift Focus Beyond Gloom
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Is the end of the euro over?

title: China's Factory Cities
description: Catherine Rampell, a business reporter, interviews David Barboza, a foreign correspondent, about working conditions in Chinese electronics factories and the role of U.S. companies.

title: More Than Schnitzel
description: Frank Bruni tours some of Berlins newest restaurants.

title: Get the Whistleblowers
description: There was an article on the front page of the Times on Wednesday that stopped me cold. It reported that the Justice Department has charged a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, John Kiriakou, with disclosing classified information to journalistscharges that could mean 30 years in prison.

title: Theyve Done It Again: An Albatross Chick
description: To the delight of scientists, a pair of lovers returned to Hawaii this year for what might turn out to be an annual sojourn. The two birds are endangered short-tailed albatrosses, and for the second time in the species recorded history, they nested there, producing a chick on American soil.

title: Milwaukee Gets Arty in the Third Ward
description: The city, known for its blue-collar roots, gets a bit of flair.

title: Lawmakers Release Proposed Redistricting Maps
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers on Thursday unveiled their proposal to redraw state Senate and Assembly districts to comport with the most recent Census, setting in motion what is expected to be a bruising fight among legislators, government watchdogs and civil rights groups over how the states political map should look for the next decade.

title: Madison Square, 1:18 p.m.
description: Carol Willis is, appropriately enough, the founder, director and curator of the Skyscraper Museum.

title: With $25 Million Gift, Signature Theater Has a New Name
description: The Signature Theater is only going to unveil and move into its new home on 42nd Street next week, but it has already received one unusually generous housewarming gift: on Thursday the Pershing Square Foundation announced that it is donating $25 million to Signature, much of it to be used in a 20-year initiative to keep ticket prices affordable.

title: TimesCast | Gingrich on Space Industry
description: Though the latest polls show Newt Gingrichs momentum may have stalled, he has found strong backing in Brevard County, Fla., by proposing a bold initiative in space industry employment.

title: Latinos on the Economy: Hard Hit but Hopeful
description: Latinos have been especially hard hit by the economic downturn, with nearly four in 10  38 percent  saying they have skipped meals because they did not have enough money for food, according to a national survey published on Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Firms and Latvian Trader of Market Abuse
description: A Latvian trader is accused of hacking into the brokerage accounts of innocent investors in the United States, making hundreds of thousands of dollars for himself while costing the unwitting victims millions.

title: Teaching the Volt to Charge Smarter and Cleaner
description: On Thursday, General Motors announced an alert system under development that would instruct the Chevy Volt to charge only when a relatively high percentage of renewable energy was available. Being plugged in at those times would further minimize the carbon footprint of the plug-in hybrid. Google plans to test the technology, facilitated by the subscription-based OnStar alert and navigation system, on its fleet of 17 Volts.

title: Chinese Clusters and Me
description: I realized that if you wanted to know where I was coming from on the Apple-in-China story, the best reading is probably the paper I prepared for the Association of American Geographers (pdf), which offers both a nontechnical account of what the new economic geography was about and a discussion of how it applies to China.

title: Caucus Video: Gingrich and the Space Industry
description: Though the latest polls show Newt Gingrichs momentum may have stalled, he has found strong backing in Brevard County, Fla., by proposing a bold initiative in space industry employment. Trip Gabriel reports.

title: A Russian Principal Sniffs Around Brooklyn
description: Cliff Levys article in the magazine about sending his non-Russian-speaking children to a Russian school received hundreds of comments when it ran in September  not a few of which expressed admiration for Vasiliy Bogin, the schools charismatic principal. On Wednesday it was Bogins turn to observe the American educational system  or at least P.S. 321, a well-regarded school in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where as reported here on the Schoolbook site, he found some ideas worth taking home.

title: Plunging Ahead to Poke the Bear
description: WE were camping in a dust pile at Chickenfoot Lake. Elevation: 11,000 feet. The landscape there is beautiful, sublimely so  diamond lakes, wildflowers, soaring mountains flecked with snow. Looking back at pictures, I cant believe I didnt want to be there.

title: Suddenly, Debate No. 19 Means Everything
description: Its the most important night of Mitt Romneys political life.

title: Carrefour Said to Seek Chief Executive
description: PARIS  Carrefour, the French retailer that ranks second in the world in revenue behind Wal-Mart Stores, was in advanced talks to replace its chief executive, people with direct knowledge of the situation said Thursday.

title: In Man vs. Wolf Pack, Survival of the Flintiest
description: The Grey continues what has become a welcome seasonal movie tradition. For the past three winters, just when the Oscar nominees youve missed are trying to dazzle and guilt-trip you with visions of Importance, a lean and angry Liam Neeson shows up at the multiplex, out for righteous payback or at least the paycheck that no one would dare begrudge him. Buy a ticket, punk! Having paid his quality biopic dues as Oskar Schindler, Michael Collins and Alfred Kinsey, Mr. Neeson has, at least for now, turned to the rougher and perhaps more lucrative work of action heroism. It takes nothing away from his earlier achievements to note that hes really good at it. He conveys a ferocious and absolute seriousness even when the going gets silly, and he finds the soul in each new angry-everyman cipher he is asked to play.

title: A Bloody Roman Romp With a Dose of Debauch
description: Spartacus, the Starz channels costume-optional drama set in the waning years of the Roman Republic, returns for a second season on Friday night with the four Bs of its appeal intact: beefcake, blood, breasts and the Bard. (The fourth B refers to the shows solemn, mock Elizabethan dialogue, light on definite articles  When ritual is ended, see blood cleansed  but studded with profanity.)

title: 3Ms Profit Beats Analysts Estimates
description: The 3M Company, the maker of Post-it Notes and industrial products, reported higher fourth-quarter profit than analysts had estimated as demand increased for aerospace and auto products.

title: Marco Rubio Wont Be V.P.
description: Your parents came to Miami from Cuba in the 1950s. Your dad became a bartender, and your mom worked as a hotel maid, among other jobs. Was it always clear that you wouldnt follow them into a service job? The service industry is hard, honorable work, but early on my parents drove it into us that a job is what you do to make a living; a career is when you get paid to do something that you love. They had jobs so I could have a career.

title: Sarkozys Main Rival Offers Proposals for Lifting Frances Economy
description: PARIS  Franois Hollande, the Socialist Party candidate leading in the polls for the French presidency, appeared Thursday to try to address complaints that he had been too vague about his plans for France and its slowing economy, issuing a package of 60 measures that would increase taxes and government spending but aim to balance the budget by 2017.

title: Before and After: Automat Under Wraps
description: An automat at 611 West 181st Street, designed in 1930 by Louis Allen Abramson, was converted to a bank in 1978 and today the space houses a Sleepys mattress store.

title: Can the Blazers Keep All the Pieces?
description: The Portland Trail Blazers of today are deep, versatile and effective on both ends of the court. This particular Portland team certainly isnt without its flaws, but it plays an eminently watchable brand of basketball with more than enough substance as its foundation.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Australia, Somalia and Pakistan.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 27-Feb. 2
description: Movies

title: Gingrich Enters Debate Needing One More Comeback
description: In Wednesdays Florida polling update, I wrote that it seemed reasonably clear that Newt Gingrichs momentum had stalled out in the state. And you could make a pretty good case that the trend had actually reversed itself, and that polling now appeared to favor Mitt Romney again.

title: Expats Face Confusing New Law to Buy Insurance in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Expatriates living in Turkey scrambled this week to try to fulfill a new requirement that foreign residents register and pay for national health insurance by Tuesday, January 31, or face a fine said to be 886.50 lira, or about $495.

title: TimesCast | Egypt Detains Americans
description: January 26, 2012  Egyptian authorities block at least six American employees of American nongovernmental organizations from leaving the country.

title: Boy, Did She Make It
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  In her office at her home here Mary Tyler Moore has one case that holds her Emmy statuettes (she has won seven) and Golden Globe awards (three). A second case has, among other honors, her Peoples Choice awards (four). Shell have another piece of hardware after this weekend. She will receive the Screen Actors Guilds lifetime achievement award on Sunday during that organizations annual ceremony in Los Angeles, which will be broadcast at 8 p.m. on TNT and TBS.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Lees Art Shop
description: The inventory at Lees Art Shop, half a block from Carnegie Hall, makes even casual customers wish they were artists.

title: Supplying the Stuff of Art Dreams
description: IT never fails. You go into Lees Art Shop, half a block from Carnegie Hall, as a customer  usually for something prosaic like a couple of Pilot Razor Points from their amazing 215-slot pen rack  and leave wishing you were an artist.

title: After Fielder Deal, Leyland Works on His Lineup
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Tigers addition of slugger and first baseman Prince Fielder is having some ripple effects across the teams projected 2012 lineup. Tigers manager Jim Leyland and president and general manager Dave Dombrowski shed some light during Fielders introductory press conference at Comerica Park on Thursday about the changes.

description: SEATTLE  The Seattle Operas production of Verdis Attila opens with a scene that is nowhere to be found in Verdis Attila.

title: Rituals Must Be Observed By Those Onstage and Off
description: Theres an overwhelming sense of ritual behind any solo piano concert by Keith Jarrett: a set of expectations and behaviors, often unspoken but widely understood. To the extent that its a code, it involves both the artist and his audience, and especially the transaction between the two. Since the 1970s, when Mr. Jarrett first earned a reputation for sustained, spontaneous rhapsody, he has trained his concertgoers to gather as congregants, complicit witnesses to his search for illumination. Also: no cameras. No coughing. No, seriously.

title: A Scholarly Homo Sapiens Grooms His Protges
description: Jane Goodall, Dian Fossey, Birut Galdikas.

description: The Obama administrations effort to crackdown on banks placing risky wagers with their own money has met Republican opposition.
