description: Around Town

title: The Yin and the Yang of Corporate Innovation
description: IN the hunt for innovation, that elusive path to economic growth and corporate prosperity, try a little jazz as an inspirational metaphor.

title: The Male Mystique of Henry Miller
description: What happens when the unreliable narrator turns out to be the cultural critic?

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 27  Feb. 2
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Tales of Kim Dotcom and the iPhone Makers
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Jan. 27-Feb. 2
description: The Paper Bag Players Laugh! Laugh! Laugh!

title: Parents Waging a Battle Against the Ultimate Foe
description: Declaration of War is a manic sprint whose style and momentum recall French New Wave films like Jules and Jim revved up to double-time. On paper, the story of Juliette (Valrie Donzelli) and Romo (Jrmie Elkam), bohemian Parisians whose 18-month-old son develops a brain tumor, may sound depressing. But the emergency channels their energy into an exhilarating race against time. A crucial insight of the movie, directed by Ms. Donzelli, is that a crisis can infuse daily life with a surreal, zany urgency.

title: Santorum Says Hes Not Going Anywhere
description: MIAMI  Rick Santorum, who has been all but shut out of news media coverage since Newt Gingrich won the South Carolina primary last week, said Thursday that he was staying in the race for the long haul.

title: A Grotesque Stillness Flirts With Flamboyance
description: The tendency of commercial galleries to mount exhibitions of historical material is pushed to rewardingly crazed extremes by the latest offerings at Sperone Westwater. This blue-chip gallery, previously located in SoHo and then Chelsea, has crammed two lavish exhibitions into the four floors of available display space in the narrow, overly hygienic building on the Bowery  commissioned from the British starchitect Norman Foster  to which it moved in 2010.

title: Antiques on Camera and Behind Every Door
description: Reality television about antiques is available practically around the clock now, and half a dozen new shows have appeared in the past few months. But the transactions shown these days little resemble how the trade actually works.

title: A Life of Marital Bliss (Segregation Laws Aside)
description: Whats the difference between a political activist and a political hero? Its often a matter of intention versus accident. Within the civil rights movement Rosa Parks is seen as an activist: She trained at the Highlander Folk School for social justice in Tennessee, and her refusal to give up her seat on a crowded bus was the catalyst for the 1955 Montgomery Bus Boycott. Richard and Mildred Loving, an interracial couple from Virginia whose marriage prompted a benchmark 1967 Supreme Court ruling overturning state miscegenation laws, are portrayed in The Loving Story: Photographs by Grey Villet as heroes who fell into history by accident.

title: Off-Campus, With Elbow Room
description: BY the time he reached his third year of law school at New York University, Michael Igyarto had had enough of dorm living.

title: Previewing the Debate in Jacksonville
description: This one could be the nastiest, most personal debate yet.

title: Good Works Should Top Good Looks
description: I have three daughters, who are still quite young. The oldest is very striking, and people often tell me how beautiful she is  right in front of the other two girls, without saying a word about them. Even my family does this. It makes my heart ache for my younger daughters. I find it so insensitive, even though everyone is just trying to be nice. How should I handle this?J. S., Marina, Calif.

title: Romney Paid More Than He Owed
description: Mitt Romneys tax returns tell us some things about him. They tell us a lot more about the sad state of the tax laws in this country.

title: At Yale, the Collapse of a Rhodes Scholar Candidacy
description: NEW HAVEN  On Nov. 13, Patrick J. Witt, Yale Universitys star quarterback, announced that he had withdrawn his Rhodes scholarship application and would instead play against Harvard six days later, at the very time of the required Rhodes interview. His apparent choice of team fealty over individual honor capped weeks of admiring national attention on this accomplished student and his quandary.

title: Joyce Pensatos Batman Returns at Friedrich Petzel
description: Friedrich Petzel Gallery

title: Namath, an Estranged Jet
description: Joe Namath wishes he had a better connection to the Jets regime. He is their only true icon, but he has also turned critical of them at times, on Twitter, ESPN Radio and his BroadwayJoe.tv Web site.

title: Doug Wheelers Futuristic Installation at David Zwirner
description: David Zwirner

title: JAMES NARES: 1976: Movies, Photographs and Related Works on Paper
description: Paul Kasmin Gallery

title: Shrinking the Escrow
description: WHEN you choose a fixed-rate loan for a home purchase or refinancing  as more than 9 out of 10 people currently do  only one part of the monthly mortgage statement is ever likely to change: the escrow amount.

title: Could Marco Rubio Solve Mitt Romneys Hispanic Problem?
description: A lot has changed since I interviewed Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on the morning of Jan. 17. That evening Newt Gingrich unleashed theatrical opprobrium upon John King, and Mitt Romney went from presumed nominee to bloodied establishment candidate. Rubios home state of Florida, which votes Jan. 31, has become, pick your metaphor  ground zero, Armageddon, The Last Exit To Somewheresville  for both candidates.

title: JORDAN WOLFSON
description: Alex Zachary Peter Currie

title: Surfing on a Hardwood Floor
description: IDONT really like the ocean. Let me clarify: I dont really like the idea of the ocean. Who knows whats down there? Not me. So you might not think of me as a prime candidate for a surfing class. Luckily, a surfing class on dry land is no longer a myth, for I have seen it.

title: Dance on Camera Festival Opens, and Pina Film Is Extended
description: Dance isnt the most affordable art form to keep up with. Decent tickets to the ballet can range from $60 to $200. But Dance on Camera, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Dance Films Association, helps keep the Miser rich in high culture, at movie theater prices.

title: Q & A
description: Who Should Fix a Plumbing Problem?

title: Manic Peter Pan Rules Dance Clubs
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Theyll Strum From Day Into Night
description: If there is one instrument with a built-in passport for crossing genres, it is the guitar. Central to folk music of all kinds, the backbone of the blues and, in its amplified form, both a supple solo voice in jazz and the lifeblood of rock, the guitar also has a classical literature that (with some transcriptional tweaking) stretches back to the 16th century and includes a rich, complex contemporary repertory.

title: Mayor Defends Kelly, but Says Anti-Muslim Film Caused Damage
description: As his administration faces a firestorm over a video  shown to hundreds of police officers that depicted Muslims as extremists, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg conceded on Thursday that the episode had damaged relations between the citys Islamic community and the Police Department.

title: Best Time to List a Home? Midweek
description: GLENN KELMAN, the chief executive of Redfin, an online real estate brokerage based in Seattle that hashad a presence on the Island for two years, always thought that houses on the market in the dead of winter were like a clearance rack. He was convinced that winter was the worst time to sell.

title: Cops and Robbers, and Vertigo
description: It is not just painful, but it is also infuriating to see Ed Harris humiliated by having to deliver his wretched dialogue in the thriller Man on a Ledge. His character, David Englander, is an evil real estate tycoon given to screaming things like, There are two kinds of people in the world  people who will do anything to get what they want and everybody else. Thats about as subtle as it gets.

title: A Quick Roundup of the Pentagons Proposed Budget Cuts
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta outlined on Thursday the first major step  he called it a down payment  of shrinking the Pentagon after a decade of war. Included in the proposal: limit pay raises for troops, increase health insurance fees for military retirees and close bases in the United States. Of those proposals, our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker write that pay-raise limits, though modest, are certain to ignite a political fight in Congress, which since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has consistently raised military salaries beyond what the Pentagon has recommended.

title: Historic Dirt Preserved
description: LONG VALLEY

title: Canadian Legonaut Returns From the Stratosphere Bearing Remarkable Images
description: Even if he didnt quite make it all the way to outer space, as some early reports claimed, a two-inch Lego man, with a fixed grin and a Canadian flag in his hand, did travel about 80,000 feet above the Earths surface to the upper stratosphere this month, and he has the stunning video to prove it.

title: Searching for Love and the Second Book
description: Eric Schaeffer has said he intends his latest film, After Fall, Winter, to be the second of four he will make at 15-year intervals focused on the same character. Watch out, current holder of the Worlds Longest Vanity Project title.

title: Trackside Developments Catch On
description: MORE than a century ago, before the term transit-oriented development entered the urban-planning glossary, plenty of it was being built in Westchester: clusters of housing, shops and sometimes industrial buildings close to railroad stations.

title: Twitter Announces Micro-Censorship Policy
description: 7:52 p.m. | Updated Within hours of the announcement, people had figured out ways to subvert Twitters blocking.

title: AT&T: We Need Spectrum or Prices Are Going Up
description: Smartphones and tablets are squeezing data networks. And because of the limited amount of the frequency spectrum available to expand wireless services, the nation may face a data network shortage in the coming years. AT&T thinks the government is the problem.

title: 14-Year-Old Texan, a Student of Science and Sex
description: Five Time Champion, written and directed by Berndt Mader, is a kind of indie Every Film. Quiet, mostly well observed, a bit quirky, regionally distinct (it takes place in Texas) and aware of human complexity, its also a little pat and a little dramatically underpowered.

title: Fielder Comes Home
description: DETROIT  It was a happily eerie scene at Comerica Park on Thursday, as the new Detroit Tigers slugger Prince Fielder sat on the dais for a news conference, flanked by his cute, curly-haired 7-year-old son, Jadyn.

title: Gingrich Insurgency Tests Partys Old Guard
description: WASHINGTON  The Old Guard of the Republican Party has suddenly surfaced with some acid criticism of Newt Gingrich and warnings that he would be crushed in November, seeking to impose some discipline on an electorate that seems to be flirting seriously with nominating Mr. Gingrich for president.

title: A Venerable Fresh Face Goes on Tour
description: The No. 1 question from visitors to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, according to Emilie Gordenker, is Where is Girl With a Pearl Earring?

title: Web Sites Call Ends in Four Happily-Ever-Afters
description: Oft expectation fails, and most oft there/Where it most promises, says Helena, the heroine of Shakespeares Alls Well That Ends Well, as she pursues her man doggedly despite his brutish behavior. Not for nothing is this comedy characterized as a problem play.

title: Visionaries, Charmers and Demons
description: The near death of the American Folk Art Museum was one of the more alarming events in the New York art world last year. So it is heartening to see this irreplaceable institution rising from the grave with Jubilation/Rumination: Life, Real and Imagined, a wonderful exhibition of works from the permanent collection.

title: Conservatives Criticize Drudge for Anti-Gingrich Assault
description: Furious conservatives have taken to blogs and Twitter on Thursday to vent their ire against what they allege is a conspiratorial dumping of twisted and manipulated negative attacks on Newt Gingrich.

title: Bolstering Staff, Yankees Complete Deal With Kuroda
description: The Yankees announced the signing of Hiroki Kuroda, a right-handed starter, on Thursday and also agreed to a one-year deal with reliever Boone Logan to avoid arbitration.

title: History Unfolding on a Hand Scroll
description: The painter Fu Baoshi was born in China in 1904, seven years before the Chinese Revolution brought 2,100 years of dynastic rule to an end. He died in 1965, months before Chinas Communist regime unleashed the Cultural Revolution, which aggressively persecuted the countrys writers, artists and other intelligentsia, sometimes unto death.

title: A Rising Tide of Applications to Harvard Appears to Crest
Ruling Favors Owner of Rig in Gulf Spill
description: Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, which blew out in the Gulf of Mexico nearly two years ago, is not liable for some of the pollution claims arising from the fatal accident, a federal judge in Louisiana ruled on Thursday.

title: Shot-Up Image of President Draws a Secret Service Inquiry
description: PHOENIX  The Secret Service said Thursday that it was looking into a photograph posted on the Internet that showed a group of young Arizona men posing in the desert with guns while holding up what appeared to be a bullet-riddled image of President Obamas face.

title: Life, Liberty and the Fact of Slavery
description: WASHINGTON  The astounding thing about American slavery is not that it existed  the enslavement of one people by another may be one of historys universals  but that it persisted. It lasted into an era when its absence could be imagined and its presence could become an outrage.

title: Patriots Gronkowski Does Not Practice
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  New England Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski did not practice Thursday, the only player missing from the teams first official workout since Sundays victory over the Baltimore Ravens in the A.F.C. championship game.

title: Auto Retailer Heralds a Turnaround, Citing Demand to Replace Aging Cars
description: DETROIT  The nations biggest automotive retailer on Thursday reported strong financial results for 2011 and suggested the recovery of the American car market had reached a turning point.

title: Long a Divisive Figure, but Still the Grocers Daughter Back Home
description: GRANTHAM, England  It is a poignant story, and the sparse audiences at the Reel Cinema, a few blocks from the handsome 18th-century facades of the town center, tell it as well as anything else.

description: The Senate next week will take up legislation seeking to ban lawmakers from profiting on inside information gleaned through their Congressional work, said Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader.

title: Papua New Guinea: Mutiny Said to Fail
description: A mutiny by a group of soldiers loyal to Papua New Guineas ousted leader, Sir Michael Somare, has failed, the countrys prime minister told reporters late Thursday. The announcement comes amid escalating tensions between the current and former heads of government in the South Pacific island nation, each of whom claims legitimacy. Up to 20 soldiers stormed the barracks of the Papua New Guinea Defense Force in the capital, Port Moresby, early Thursday, detained the military chief and demanded that Prime Minister Peter ONeill bow to a Supreme Court ruling ordering Sir Michaels reinstatement as leader. But after a tense day, Mr. ONeill said his military chief had been freed and the barracks had been returned to the control of his government.

title: A Call Resounds Across Florida for an Overscheduled Candidate: Is He Here Yet?
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It is one of the great unappreciated skills of a political campaign: running out the clock at rallies while waiting for a candidate who is behind schedule.

title: Early Indicators Point to Stellar Season for 76ers
description: The first month of this abbreviated N.B.A. season has brought a number of unexpected twists and turns. One of the more surprising developments has been the stellar play of the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: In Punishing Year for Hedge Funds, Biggest One Thrived
description: The worlds biggest hedge fund is also one of the best performers.

title: With Every Big Drive, Watson Helps Fight Cancer
description: SAN DIEGO  On the two driving holes Thursday on Torrey Pines North Course  the 434-yard par-4 fourth and the 547-yard par-5 ninth  Bubba Watsons shots off the tees traveled 314 and 370 yards. His booming drives are a boon for the Bubba & Friends: Drive to a Million charity campaign he started this week.

title: Israel Senses Bluffing in Irans Threats of Retaliation
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli intelligence estimates, backed by academic studies, have cast doubt on the widespread assumption that a military strike on Iranian nuclear facilities would set off a catastrophic set of events like a regional conflagration, widespread acts of terrorism and sky-high oil prices.

title: Getting Back to Basics After Brain Surgery
description: SAN DIEGO  After J. B. Holmess first competitive swing in more than five months, his shoulders slumped. His drive Thursday on the first hole of Torrey Piness South Course traveled 280 yards, coming to rest in the first cut of the right intermediate rough.

title: Regional Cap-and-Trade Effort Seeks Greater Impact by Cutting Carbon Allowances
description: Adjusting to shifts in the economy, states in the cap-and-trade system known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative have slashed the number of allowances that electric power companies can buy to offset their emissions.

title: South Carolina: Schools Agree to Halt Prayers
description: A school district that was sued for holding a prayer rally at a school assembly and prayers at official events has agreed to end its promotion of religion. A federal judge on Thursday made final a consent decree in which the Chesterfield County schools admitted to violating the separation of church and state. Under the decree, school officials may not encourage prayers at events or allow endorsement of religion in the classroom. The suit was brought by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of a middle-school student who objected to the evangelical assembly and other Christian activities at school.

title: For Many in Pakistan, a Television Show Goes Too Far
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  One morning last week, television viewers in Pakistan were treated to a darkly comic sight: a posse of middle-class women roaming through a public park in Karachi, on the hunt for dating couples engaged in immoral behavior.

title: Deconstructing Gingrich
description: In his weekly column, Timothy Egan writes:

title: In Perelman Lawsuit, a Fight Over Files Not Deleted
description: When Ronald O. Perelman was looking to buy Deluxe Entertainment Services, he turned to Goldman Sachs for advice.

title: Jobs, Jobs and Cars
description: Mitch Daniels, the former Bush budget director who is now Indianas governor, made the Republicans reply to President Obamas State of the Union address. His performance was, well, boring. But he did say something thought-provoking  and I mean that in the worst way.

title: Maine: Gay-Rights Backers Say Petition Goal Is Met
description: Gay-rights advocates say they have almost twice the 57,277 signatures required to put a same-sex marriage referendum on the ballot this November, which will most likely bring the issue before voters for the second time in three years. Same-sex marriage was legalized here in 2009, but voters overturned the law with a so-called peoples veto later that year. Six states and the District of Columbia allow same-sex marriage, but none have yet legalized it with a popular vote.

title: TV Anchor Not Shy About Being Police Leaders Son
description: For some New York journalists, being a son of one of the citys most powerful public officials might require some professional distance.

title: Republican Candidates Debate in Jacksonville, Fla.
description: The debate was a crucial face-off just five days before Floridas presidential primary.

title: Hope, but Not Much Change
description: The Simpson-Bowles report wasnt just a policy document. For a few months, it expanded the national debate. Everybody seemed to realize that the country was beset by large challenges that could no longer be neglected: soaring debt, lagging growth, wage stagnation, family breakdown, political dysfunction.

title: Indignation Over Immigration Marks Beginning of Debate
description: Interesting start to the debate, with a question from the audience about illegal immigration. Though it at first seemed likely to prompt a more civil debate  especially since Wolf Blitzer, the moderator, chose to direct the question to Rick Santorum  it ultimately yielded the kind of vitriol between Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney that some expected.

title: Jacksonville Debate Live Blog
description: The candidates take the stage for the last debate before the Florida Primary on Tuesday. The two-hour debate, being broadcast on CNN, is co-sponsored by the Florida Republican Party.

title: Debate Fact Check: Self-Deportation
description: Wolf Blitzer asked Newt Gingrich whether Mitt Romney is anti-immigrant; a Gingrich campaign Spanish-language radio ad called Mr. Romney anti-immigrant.

title: At Davos, Debating Capitalisms Future
description: Davos, Switzerland

title: North Carolina Governors Decision May Aid Obama Bid
description: Bev Perdue, a Democrat who barely grabbed the governorship of North Carolina three years ago and never gained widespread popularity, said on Thursday that she would not run for re-election this fall.

title: For $2 a Star, an Online Retailer Gets 5-Star Product Reviews
description: In the brutal world of online commerce, where a competing product is just a click away, retailers need all the juice they can get to close a sale.

title: Massachusetts: Congressman Will Marry His Partner
description: Representative Barney Frank, left, one of the first openly gay members of Congress, will marry his partner of five years in a ceremony in Massachusetts, Mr. Franks spokesman said. Mr. Franks partner, Jim Ready, 42, is a photographer and handyman in Ogunquit, Me. Mr. Frank, 71, announced in November that he would retire at the end of this year after more than three decades in the House. Mr. Franks spokesman said the wedding date had not been determined. Same-sex marriage is legal in Massachusetts.

title: In Britain, a Partial List of Those Who Declined to Be Called Sir
description: LONDON  Which is cooler: To accept a knighthood from the queen, or to turn one down?

title: When the Police Say One Thing, the Facts Another
description: One evening in November 1990, at the end of a speech in a hotel on the East Side of Manhattan, a man stuck out his arm and squeezed off shots that killed a militant Israeli politician and rabbi named Meir Kahane. The assassin ran to Lexington Avenue and jumped in a cab, but was caught a few blocks away.

title: With Trays of Tacos, Joining in Condemnation of a Mayor
description: In East Haven, Conn., the menu on Thursday, not surprisingly, was tacos, and perhaps crow, in an episode featuring both allegations of serious civil rights violations and goofy Twitter fodder.

title: Fact Check: Language of the Ghetto
description: Newt Gingrich was asked if he had called Spanish the language of the ghetto, as a new ad from the Romney campaign suggests.

title: Afghanistan: Suicide Bomber Kills 4
description: A suicide bomber exploded a car near a British reconstruction team traveling in a convoy through the center of Lashkar Gah in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing four Afghans, including a child, and wounding 31 others, the provincial governors office and the British government said. Three British citizens were hurt in the explosion, Britains Foreign Office said. It was unclear whether the convoy was the target of the attack. The reconstruction team is one of dozens across Afghanistan in which civilian and military personnel lead efforts to build roads and schools and to help local governments become more effective. Lashkar Gah was among the first cities where Afghan security forces assumed sole control last summer in the first stage of a transition from American security.

title: Dont Mind the Gap
description: Washington

title: Mara Rides Whirlwind Clear Into Super Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Over the past 12 months, here are some things that have happened to the Giants co-owner John Mara:

title: For Greece, the Outlook Is Still Grim
description: LONDON  Even as Greece tries to convince creditors that its debt-reduction efforts are on track, gloomy new International Monetary Fund forecasts about its long-term economy are threatening to derail talks meant to secure the nations next big installment of bailout funds.

title: Mickelson in Unfamiliar Spot After First Round
description: SAN DIEGO  Watching Phil Mickelsons first round at the Farmers Insurance Open was disorienting, like seeing the sun set in the East. Mickelson has 10 top-10 showings here, including three victories and two runner-up finishes, but he looked lost Thursday, posting a five-over 77 on the South Course.

title: Fact Check: Profiting From the Housing Crisis
description: Seeking to exploit questions over Mitt Romneys investments, Newt Gingrich attacked Mr. Romney on Thursday night for profiting from the housing woes of Florida residents.

title: Soap Operas With a Social Message
description: Every Sunday evening, seven million Kenyans sit in front of their television sets to watch Makutano Junction, a soap opera set in a fictional village. In one episode, audiences watch as a woman, Mama Mboga, holds her crying infant. I need some money to take Joni to hospital, she tells her husband, Erasmus, after he wakes up and takes a swig from a bottle. I think he has malaria. Erasmus insists that his son is healthy, that she is overreacting and that he has no money to give her.

title: New York City Tuition Higher and Rising
description: Charts showing the rising tuition at New York City private schools.

title: Romney Stays on the Offense With Gingrich
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Mitt Romney, facing his greatest challenge of the campaign so far, relentlessly pressed Newt Gingrich on Thursday night in their final debate before the Florida primary, seeking to regain the offensive against an insurgent challenge that has shaken his claim to inevitability.

title: Co-op Manager Accused of Theft in the Bowery
description: A property manager for a low-income co-op in the Bowery was charged on Thursday with stealing more than $260,000 from the building.

title: Fair Is Fair
description: President Obamas choice to emphasize fairness rather than equality in the State of the Union address makes good political sense. Although equality is the central concern of the Occupy Wall Street movement, focused as it is on income disparities, Americans are at least ambivalent toward equality as a primary value. They think emphasizing equality was O.K. in the context of the Civil War and segregation because inequality was institutionalized in those days and it is a good thing those days are over.

title: Romney and Gingrich Clash on Immigration
description: The candidates begin the debate with a heated argument over immigration and attack ads.

title: Energy Tax Breaks Proposed, Despite Waning Support for Subsidies
description: Assisted by technological innovation and years of subsidies, the cost of wind and solar power has fallen sharply  so much so that the two industries say that they can sometimes deliver cleaner electricity at prices competitive with power made from fossil fuels.

title: With Rape Inquiry, District Attorney Again Finds Himself in a Tough Spot
description: Given the inherent potential for tension between police departments and prosecutors, any district attorney might be reluctant to investigate the son of a police commissioner.

title: Strong Words Resound at Tribute to Paterno
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Penn State concluded its weeklong goodbye to the former football coach Joe Paterno with a memorial Thursday at a packed arena that featured remembrances from a player from each of the six decades in which he coached, videos of him with the team and an emotional closing eulogy from his son Jay.

title: The Navys Stone Fleet
description: In November 1861, the whaling ship Leonidas sailed from New Bedford, Mass., for the last time. Five times before, the Leonidas had departed New Bedford Harbor bound for whaling voyages in the Pacific, Indian and Atlantic Oceans; each time, the ship returned home with a hold full of oil extracted from sperm whales. Whaling was one of Americas first global industries, and oil carried home in ships like the Leonidas lubricated machinery in booming factories and lit homes in the nations growing cities.

title: Lottery Numbers
Big Victory on Internet Buoys Lobby
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The unlikely coalition of companies and consumer groups that last week helped quash antipiracy legislation on Capitol Hill is now weighing the future of what might be called lobbying 2.0. Can the Internet industry, along with legions of newly politicized Web users, be a new force in Washington? And if so, what else can they all agree upon?

title: Winston Riley, Jamaican Music Producer, Dies at 68
description: Winston Riley, a record producer and singer whose diverse, influential work helped to popularize Jamaican music around the world, died on Jan. 19 in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 68.

title: The Candidates on Housing
description: Mitt Romney brings up Newt Gingrich's connections with Freddie Mac.

title: Obama and Fairness
description: In Fair is Fair, Stanley Fish writes today on our politics blog, Campaign Stops:

title: A Touch During Recess, and Reaction Is Swift
description: It started as schoolyard roughhousing during recess, with one boys hand allegedly touching the upper thigh, or perhaps the groin, of another. There were no reported witnesses, and it remains unclear if anyone complained, but the principal immediately suspended the student, placing the incident on the boys record as a case of sexual assault. The children involved were first graders  the purported assailant just 6.

title: Accused of Atrocities, Guatemalas Ex-Dictator Chooses Silence
description: MEXICO CITY  Efran Ros Montt, Guatemalas former military dictator, was ordered by a Guatemalan judge on Thursday to stand trial on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity leveled at him. He is accused of orchestrating the razing of Indian villages decades ago during the countrys long civil war.

title: Trying to Escape a Path of Violence for the Sake of Her Daughters
description: Alyssa Marrero, 4, sat staring out a window as she waited with her mother for food vouchers they needed to buy milk, beans and bread.

title: In Honduras, a Mess Made in the U.S.
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

title: Rudi van Dantzig, Provocative Dutch Choreographer, Dies at 78
description: Rudi van Dantzig, a provocative choreographer whose mix of idealism and social protest gave the Dutch National Ballet an international profile when he served as its artistic director until 1991, died on Jan. 19 at his home in Amsterdam. He was 78.

title: Student Faces Towns Wrath in Protest Against a Prayer
description: CRANSTON, R.I.  She is 16, the daughter of a firefighter and a nurse, a self-proclaimed nerd who loves Harry Potter and Facebook. But Jessica Ahlquist is also an outspoken atheist who has incensed this heavily Roman Catholic city with a successful lawsuit to get a prayer removed from the wall of her high school auditorium, where it has hung for 49 years.

title: The Delusion of Equality in Triplicate
description: MIAMI

title: Trade Tower Is Set to Add Prime Tenant, a Law Firm
description: Chadbourne & Parke, a 110-year-old law firm, is close to a deal to move to the 1,776-foot skyscraper under construction at ground zero, from its headquarters at Rockefeller Center.

title: Senate Vote Approves Rise in Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Thursday to allow a further increase in the federal debt limit, permitting President Obama to borrow $1.2 trillion more to operate a government that spent about 55 percent more than it collected in revenue last year.

title: Pandoras Problem
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  So weve got this weird enclosure, this navel if you will, right in the middle of our grid. Weve seen enclosures in grids before, like this one by Patrick Merrell (Across Lite, Solution), but now were told that the three letters that fit inside are (1) in alphabetical order and (2) dont appear anywhere else in the grid.

title: Artifice as Armor in a Duel With Death
description: Cynthia Nixons gaze has its own grammar. Playing a terminally ill English professor in the inescapably moving new revival of Margaret Edsons Wit, the 1999 Pulitzer Prize winner for drama, Ms. Nixon seems to construct perfectly composed, illuminating and surprising thoughts with her sky-blue eyes  the kind of thoughts that if you saw them in print would make you stop and savor and reread.

title: Tests on Pitcher Found Five Banned Substances
description: Since baseball introduced drug testing a decade ago, first in the minor leagues and then in the majors, a large majority of those who have tested positive for performance-enhancers and been suspended have not been familiar names.

title: So Whos a Lobbyist?
description: Under the federal lobbying law, Newt Gingrich can legitimately claim that he is not a lobbyist. That alone demonstrates how much the law needs to be changed.

title: More in Mitt's Taxes
description: After criticizing Mitt Romney on his taxes, candidate Newt Gingrich offers a two-way truce.

title: The Debate Heads to the Moon
description: The candidates debate Newt Gingrich's plan to spend on space.

title: Executive at Oprahs Cable Channel Departs Suddenly
description: Lisa Erspamer, a co-executive producer of The Oprah Winfrey Show who was sent to OWN to bring Ms. Winfreys personal touch to her cable channel, has unceremoniously exited the channel.

title: Japan: Nuclear Contamination Cleanup Near Stricken Plant to Start in Spring
description: Japan said Thursday that it would begin a cleanup this spring of radioactive contamination near the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, with the goal of cutting radiation levels in half within two years. The Environment Ministry said the cleanup would cover about two-thirds of the 100-square-mile zone around the plant that was evacuated after last Marchs accident. The ministry says radiation levels in these areas are low enough that the cleanup, along with the natural decay of radioactive materials, should make it possible for residents to return at an unspecified time after two years. However, the ministry said it had no plans to clean the remaining third of the evacuation zone, where it says radiation levels are too high to be brought to safe levels with current technology.

title: School Improves With Help of U.S. Money It May Lose
description: The federal grant had ambitious purpose, few restrictions and a not-so-distant expiration date: three years. With almost $1 million to spend, Brian Rosenbloom, the principal at Chelsea Career and Technical Education High School in SoHo, once one of New York Citys worst schools, knew he had to be strategic.

title: In Airport Run-In, Democrats See Help for Obama Among Hispanics
description: AURORA, Colo.  Democrats see the chance that President Obamas heated exchange with Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona on the airport tarmac in Phoenix could help him with the Hispanic voters he came West to court this week.

title: U.N. Sees an Unexpected Arrival: Bags of Drugs
description: UNITED NATIONS  If you are a United Nations diplomat missing 30 pounds of cocaine, it is now in the hands of the New York Police Department.

title: Giants Take Time Out to Focus on Families
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants assembled Tuesday for the first time since advancing to the Super Bowl, Eli Manning addressed his teammates. He implored. He pleaded. He was firm but blunt, speaking with the wisdom of a man who had been there before and won.

title: Caucus Click: Obama Lands in Detroit

description: Mitt Romney compares his leadership skills to that of President Ronald Reagan.

title: Transfer of Vatican Official Who Exposed Corruption Hints at Power Struggle
description: VATICAN CITY  An Italian television program about the transfer of a whistle-blowing Roman Catholic prelate has caused consternation at the Vatican and prompted speculation about a power struggle among senior clerics in the church.

title: A Revival for Broadway Joe
description: Joe Namath was in the back of the auditorium, watching a documentary about himself. Ninety minutes of Joe Willie. It tickled him to watch, and he chuckled now and then as he sat beside his attentive older daughter, Jessica.

title: Jacksonville Debate Fact Check
description: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates in Thursday nights debate.

title: Santorum on Health Care
description: The Senator says only the strongest stance on health care will help the republicans beat President Obama in November.

title: Voting and Racial History
description: Instead of ensuring that voting rights are extended to all Americans, many state legislatures are engaged in efforts to shut out voters in this election year, taking aim at young people, immigrants and minorities.

title: House Democrats Welcome Obamas Confrontational Tone Toward G.O.P.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  The on-again-off-again relationship between President Obama and House Democrats appears to be on again with the presidents turn toward a more populist, confrontational tone toward the Republican Party.

title: An Outrage in East Haven
description: Hispanic residents and civil-rights advocates have raised alarms for years about the police in East Haven, Conn. Their claims gained chilling corroboration on Tuesday. The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a sergeant and three officers on charges of terrorizing the towns Hispanic neighborhoods, stopping and detaining people, searching businesses without cause, beating people in handcuffs, smashing a mans head into a wall.

title: Gabby Giffordss Farewell
description: House members were moved to tears on Wednesday when Representative Gabrielle Giffords handed in her resignation because, she said, she needed more time to heal from the grievous gunshot wound she suffered last year at the hands of a would-be assassin. The rarest of Congressional events  a display of genuinely bipartisan tributes  was the parting gift from her colleagues along with unanimous approval of Ms. Giffordss bill to fight drug trafficking along the Mexican border.

title: Life With Father, Who Also Runs the State of Israel
description: TEL AVIV  Noa Rothman bears an uncanny resemblance to her grandfather Yitzhak Rabin  so much so that when Rami Heuberger tried out for the prime ministers role in Ms. Rothmans television series, The Prime Ministers Children, he had trouble looking at her.

title: Deconstructing a Demagogue
description: When not holding forth from his favorite table at LAuberge Chez Franois, nestled among the manor houses of lobbyist-thick Great Falls, Va., Dr. Newton L. Gingrich likes to lecture people about food stamps and how out-of-touch the elites are with real America.

title: Gingrich Stuck to Caustic Path in Ethics Battles
description: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrich had an urgent warning for conservatives: Jim Wright, the Democratic speaker of the House, was out to destroy America.

title: Number of Older Inmates Grows, Stressing Prisons
description: The number of Americans in prison older than 55 is growing at a faster rate than the groups share of the population at large, and many prisons are unprepared to provide them with health care, which can cost as much as nine times more than for younger inmates, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Friday.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 26
description: The day in sports, including the memorial service at Penn State for Joe Paterno and action from the Australian Open and the Winter X Games.

title: Kessel Passes Dubious Torch to Couture
description: The last man picked last year, Phil Kessel of the Maple Leafs, was chosen 15th over all, sparing him embarrassment but also the consolation prize of a new car. What is better, the television host, James Duthie of TSN, asked him, to be chosen now, or to get the car?

title: Strong Opinions About Reading and Testing

At All-Star Draft, Spotlight Shines Brightest on Thomas
description: GATINEAU, Quebec  Theres a good chance this N.H.L. All-Star weekend may wind up being all about Bruins goalie Tim Thomas. The kerfuffle surrounding Thomass decision to skip his teams visit to the White House earlier this week because of his political views simply wont go away.

description: Its all over but the reverb.

description: If only Siri could have warned him.

description: HARASTA, Syria  On a tour by Arab League observers through the restless suburbs of Damascus, the stops on Thursday were anxious, brief and few.

description: On a tour by Arab League observers through the restless suburbs of Damascus, the stops were anxious, brief and few.

title: Mainstays Will Reappear in Big Game Once Again
description: THE New England Patriots and the New York Giants have played in the Super Bowl before. So, too, have most companies buying commercials during Super Bowl XLVI on Feb. 5.

title: A Picture Collage of Life After Cancer
description: In April 2010, we asked Well readers to share their stories of cancer survival. Over the following weeks and months, more than 1,150 people submitted their photos and stories, creating an inspiring collage of the life that is possible after cancer.

description: sallow \sa-()lo\ adjective and verb

title: Profitable Ripple Effect Projected for Berkeley Labs Second Campus in Richmond
description: Richmonds selection as the site of a second campus for the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory will not only bring in millions of dollars to a struggling city, but it may signal its shift into one of the most desirable business locations in the region.

title: Attempting to Answer the Arab Question
description: PARIS  Raised, if respectful voices at a private dinner party in Paris on Thursday. Among the guests  two Syrians, both anti-regime but with diametrically opposite analyses of what is going on in their home country.

title: Seeking Out the Funny, Sketchfest Mines the Web
description: The threat of online piracy to the entertainment industry has been all over the news thanks to a set of Congressional bills, but Cole Stratton, co-founder of the 11-year-old San Francisco comedy festival SF Sketchfest, could not be more pleased about the current intersection of comedy and technology.

title: Nursing Home Investigation Finds Errors by Druggists
description: A woman with a medical history of seizures was prescribed the antipsychotic drug Seroquel, despite research showing that elderly people who take antipsychotic drugs are more likely to experience seizures. She was also given the antidepressant Trazodone, which has been linked to an increase in seizures among older patients. And then, according to a recent investigation by the California Department of Public Health, the woman was given a second antipsychotic drug, Risperdal. The combination of the two antipsychotic medications, the investigators said, could cause life-threatening arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats).

title: House Speaker Spreads Blame for States Mess
description: In a crowded college dining hall brightened by white linen tablecloths, a Chamber of Commerce official delivered remarks into a bouquet of microphones on the lectern before him.

title: High Rates of Sick Leave Tracked in County
description: Cook County employees take nearly twice as much paid sick leave as other state and local government workers across the country, according to statistics compiled by the county.

title: Silencing Cheers, to Save Troubled School District
description: PREMONT  A plan to save a school district has come down to rows of yellow Post-it notes.

title: Finnish Flight Attendants Go Bollywood for Indias Republic Day
description: The passengers had all boarded Finnair Flight AY201 from Helsinki to New Delhi on Jan. 17, when two dozen beaming flight attendants dressed in Indian attire came dancing through the aisles to Deewangi Deewangi from the Bollywood mega-blockbuster Om Shanti Om.The well-rehearsed and choreographed routine was in commemoration of Indias 63rd Republic Day, said Helena Kaartinen, the flight attendant who came up with the idea. It was a good way to show respect, she said, and to show Finnairs Indian passengers that we do know some things about them.

title: All-Sports Radio Matures Beyond Screamers
description: Sports talk radio was a phenomenon fairly new to Chicago the first time I heard it here. I was visiting from California, taking my daughter to college on a trip that included a two-hour drive from Chicago. I came upon WSCR  the Score  while punching the buttons in a rental car and heard a boisterous guy later identified as Mike North lambasting the hopeless Bears in a loud, indignant voice that was both unmistakably Chicawgo and scalded-cat screechy.

title: With This Library System, Government Isnt All Bad
description: President Obama should have invited Mary Dempsey to the State of the Union address. Along with other guests, who were used as symbols of a skewed tax system and the need to retrain workers, she could have made another point: government can work.

title: Some Cattle Ranchers Worry About Proposed Ear-Tag Rules
description: In Dan Gattiss Georgetown pasture, cows and their newborn calves have bright yellow ear tags with identification numbers.

title: Its Hard to Campaign Without a Map
description: Its possible to lose an election before it even starts.

description: FORT WORTH

title: American Idol Tries Old Tricks in the Face of Stumbling Ratings
description: American Idols ratings this season have been on such on a downward trend that it has left some people wondering if the reality TV giant might finally have begun to stumble. So it was gratifying for many fans and bloggers to see the show return to its old form during the auditions program aired Thursday night, as the producers highlighted some hilariously deluded performers and zeroed in on arguments among the judges.

title: Mitt Romney, the Jacksonville Jaguar
description: I wrote yesterday that last night was the most important night of Mitt Romneys political life. Another underwhelming debate performance like the ones he delivered in South Carolina would open the door for a Newt Gingrich victory in the Florida primary. Losing Florida could begin the type of downward spiral for Romney that would lead to even less pleasant consequences.

title: Obama Plan Links College Aid With Affordability
description: President Obama is proposing a financial aid overhaul that for the first time would tie colleges eligibility for campus-based aid programs  Perkins loans, work-study jobs and supplemental grants for low-income students  to the institutions success in improving affordability and value for students, administration officials said.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 27, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Oh No, Joe! The Indian Accent Comes Again
description: In a speech in New Hampshire on Thursday, while talking about call center jobs, United States vice president Joe Biden appeared to slip into an Indian accent before thinking better of it and stopping in mid-sentence.

description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article A Skate Shop Where Visitors Can Defy Gravity.

title: Should the Dropout Age Be Raised?
description: In his State of the Union Address President Obama called for every state to raise the dropout age to 18, the first time that Washington has gotten directly involved in an issue that has traditionally been decided by individual states. Do you think more states should require students to stay in school until they turn eighteen? Why or why not?

title: Rockets Hit Pakistan Military School Near Bin Laden Compound
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Unidentified assailants rained rockets on Pakistans elite military academy on Friday morning in an unusual burst of violence near the compound where Osama bin Laden was killed in May.

description: Gilbert and George, Jean Tinguely and Niki de Saint Phalle, Christo and Jeanne Claude: art history is peppered with artist couples coming together creatively  and sometimes breaking a few plates in the process.

description: Todays Times:

title: 434 People Killed in Iraq Since U.S. Pulled Out
description: BAGHDAD  Since the United States military withdrew from Iraq in the middle of last month, 434 Iraqis have been killed in attacks across the country, according to security officials, one of the highest tolls for that amount of time in the past few years.

title: Peyton Manning, Jim Irsay and Bob Kravitz
description: It is so sad and so hard to write it again, but its true: Peyton Manning is done in Indianapolis.  Bob Kravitz

title: Where Fortune Is Just Around the Bend
description: What are the odds that an HBO series by David Milch (Deadwood) and Michael Mann (Miami Vice), that stars Dustin Hoffman and Nick Nolte, and is set in a Damon Runyon-esque world of horse racing could be anything but great?

title: Running the Numbers: Making Sense of Our Costs
description: Im continuing my series of posts detailing how much it cost to run my business in 2011 and looking for conclusions that can be drawn from those figures. Thursday, I discussed some numbers associated with our shop-floor productivity, and what we had done to improve it. In this post, Im going to outline the costs that go into our products.

title: For Veteran Met Singer, Last Curtain but No End of Stories
description: His name never was Baseball Plishka. But some opera fan out there in radioland once thought it was.

title: Five Questions for: Rana Dasgupta
description: India Ink asked authors attending the recent Jaipur Literature Festival five questions about writing and about themselves. Heather Timmons caught up with the author of Solo.

title: Daily Report: The Review Was Fake. The Refund Was Real.
description: In The New York Times on Friday, David Streitfeld reports on how some retailers may go to great lengths to gain an advantage in the brutal world of online commerce  by offering a refund on a product in exchange for a review.

title: For Ford, Three Years of Profit in a Row
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company reported its third consecutive full-year profit on Friday and its largest in 13 years, ensuring its hourly workers one of the biggest profit-sharing bonuses in the companys history.

title: North Korea Warns South Over Military Drill but Accepts Food Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea warned on Friday that a South Korean military drill around frontline islands could lead to a full-scale war, even as it allowed South Korean trucks carrying private food aid for North Korean children to cross the border.

title: It Will Be Nothing Like London During World War II.
description: One of the ways that nations decide what actions to take is through a calculation of means, ends and costs.

title: A Conversation With: Maulana Wahiduddin Khan
description: Following the controversy over author Salman Rushdies appearance at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which ultimately ended with even a video conference with Mr. Rushdie being cancelled, India Ink is speaking with Muslim leaders about the situation, their feelings about his The Satanic Verses and whether politics played a part.

title: Is Spent Nuclear Fuel Really Waste?
description: When the Blue Ribbon Commission on Americas Nuclear Future was established two years ago, after the Obama administration killed a proposed repository for nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, one of the items on its agenda was to determine whether spent nuclear fuel was in fact waste.

title: Wilco Goes Animated With Popeye
description: So it turns out that Jeff Tweedy, the frontman of the Chicago alternative-rock band Wilco, has a sense of humor after all. The group has just released its first video in more than 10 years, and the format is that of an old-fashioned cartoon, with Popeye, Olive Oyl, Bluto, Wimpy and SweePea as the bands fans and foils.

title: Sating the Fiery Dragon, or That Fired-Up Pigskin Fan
description: I HAD the thought that chicken wings would be nice to make in honor of the Chinese New Year, so I pitched the idea to my editor. If wings are too banal or plebeian, it could always be thighs, I offered. The editor replied: wings absolutely, everyone loves wings! But, he said, why not something for the Super Bowl? Perhaps, I ventured, these wings could be multipurpose.

title: Eastman Chemical to Buy Solutia for $3.4 Billion
description: 5:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Eli and the Tebow Effect
description: O.K., the headline might be a stretch, but theres a point to be made.

title: Image of the Day: January 27
Dragon Wings
description: I had fun playing with chicken wings for this weeks City Kitchen column. A lot of chicken wings. I set out to make Chinese-style wings, but the path from concept to realized dish can often be littered with somewhat less than stellar results. Trying to create a recipe sometimes takes several tries. Enlisting the (tasting) help of a few opinionated friends whose palates I trust, I experimented with a few versions until the balance of sweet and spicy rang true, with the right amount of five-spice, ginger and garlic.

title: Words Gingrich Governed By
description: During his years in Congress, Newt Gingrich emerged as one of Washingtons most aggressive practitioners of slash-and-burn politics. He believed, and preached, that harsh language could win elections.

title: Postmodern Business Cycles
description: Noah Smith finds John Taylor claiming that the V-shaped recovery from the 1981-2 recession proves that Reagan roolz. Kind of sad, really: I find it hard not to believe that Taylor actually knows better.

title: Opinion Report: The Federal Lobbying Law
description: From the editorial page

title: Goodbye, Newt
description: I gather from those who watched the debate that this is pretty much over.

title: At Chelsea Career H.S., Worries About How to Get the Job Done
Growth Accelerates, but U.S. Has Lots of Ground to Make Up
description: The American economy picked up a little steam last quarter, growing at its fastest pace in a year and a half. Whether it can sustain that momentum is critical to millions of Americans out of work  and perhaps President Obamas re-election chances.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: In Punishing Year for Hedge Funds, Biggest One Thrived | The worlds biggest hedge fund is also one of the best performers.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Questions for Drudge Report, and When Bowie Said No
description: The 19th Republican presidential debate represented a role reversal, as Newt Gingrich tried to dial down the conflict on stage and a well-prepared Mitt Romney went at Mr. Gingrich, at one point saying, Wouldnt it be nice if people didnt make accusations somewhere else that they werent willing to defend here? Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny noted that while Mr. Gingrich has usually won over debate audiences with an assortment of one-liners aimed at the establishment and, frequently, the news media, those techniques didnt seem to have the same effect.

title: Bookshelf | Snap! Crackle! Pop!
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Friday Reading: Teaching the Volt to Charge Smarter and Cleaner
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Death of a Poser
description: FAYETTEVILLE, North Carolina  The War on Terror hasnt produced many clear signs of progress in the last decade. But heres an unequivocal one: with each year, weve heard a little less about Jonathan Jack Idema, the self-styled mercenary who surfaced in Afghanistan in late 2001, fed credulous journalists lies about his work with the Northern Alliance, and later was convicted by an Afghan court of running his own private torture chamber in a Kabul cellar. (He claimed he was working for the U.S. government to hunt terrorists, but in fact he seems to have been kidnapping his suspects almost randomly off the street, and choosing them partly by beard length.) Hamid Karzai pardoned him in 2007 as part of a general amnesty.After his time in Afghanistan, he sank deeper and deeper into obscurity. Last weekend he died from AIDS complications in Mexico at the age of 55.

title: A Question of Honor
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  In recent years, Pakistanis have been increasingly consumed by the concept of ghairat, or honor. An urge to defend the nations ghairat  a blend of intense patriotism and heightened religiosity  underpins the countrys soaring anti-Americanism and growing calls for the Islamization of society. It also drives the sanctimonious diatribes of politicians and talk show hosts who dominate Pakistans public sphere.

title: Gingrich Campaign Seeks Reinforcement With Florida Ad Buy
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As his momentum shows signs of slowing, Newt Gingrich has poured about $1 million into advertising across Florida in recent days.

title: Fill-In | January Events in History
Geithner Offers Upbeat U.S. Outlook, With European Caveat
description: 12:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Leading Off: The Circus Starts Early in Indianapolis
description: Lets just pause for a few seconds here to contemplate the weirdness going on in Indianapolis, and no we are not talking about the potential difficulty of the Patriots team hotel stocking up on Tom Bradys hair care products. No, its the hometown Colts rushing to the top of the bizarre-o-meter, with owner Jim Irsay deciding to wage a public hissing war with Peyton Manning.

title: What if the U.S. Tied Colleges Financial Aid Resources to Affordability?
description: In todays Times, my colleague Tamar Lewin has a preview of an address that President Obama is expected to deliver at the University of Michigan on Friday morning in which he will call for an overhaul of crucial aspects of the federal financial aid system.

title: UniCredit Shareholders to Profit From Rights Offering
description: LONDON  Investors in the Italian bank UniCredit have had a good month.

title: Michael Jackson Honored at Graumans Chinese Theater
description: Hollywood celebrities have been leaving their handprints and footprints in wet cement in front of Graumans Chinese Theater in Los Angeles for decades. On Thursday at dawn Michael Jacksons children stamped a pair of the late singers shoes and one of his sequined gloves into a wet slab on Hollywood Boulevard to honor him, according to Agence France-Presse.

title: Draghi Points to Signs of Stress in Financial System
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday that action by the central bank had averted a severe credit crunch, but he warned of a short-term contraction in the euro zone as governments cut spending and try to get debt under control.

title: A Trio of Siblings With a Classical Sound
description: A basement bar and pool hall where a bright neon sign touts $1 Massage is the last place youd expect to find a home-schooled classical string ensemble. But the JoSunJari String Trio is used to popping up in unexpected places  like parks and beaches  where their music is like a random gift bestowed upon you by strangers.

title: Face Time | Gretchen Mol
description: As Gretchen Mol gets ready to attend the S.A.G. Awards in Los Angeles this weekend (she plays Gillian, a beautiful showgirl in Boardwalk Empire, which has been nominated for two awards), she reveals what she does when not shooting the show, as well as some of her nominations for Best Supporting Beauty Products.

title: More Fines in Greenlight Insider Case in Britain
description: LONDON  Britains financial regulator said Friday that it had fined a former Greenlight Capital compliance officer and a JPMorgan Cazenove trader in connection with Greenlights sale of shares in a British pub operator more than two years ago.

title: How to Manage U.S. Forests, Version 3.1
description: In the high-tech world, new versions of programs are released to fix new bugs. In the federal regulatory world, new versions of management blueprints are released to address legal problems. Each is generally judged by a simple metric: did the fixes work, or will they have to be redone?

title: What Were Reading
description: Specialty Food: Hot trends from last weeks Winter Fancy Food Show in San Francisco: heritage grain products (quinoa, amaranth, chia) proliferate in snacks and pastas; pickling of beets, carrots, peas, okra and fruits is increasing; oats and almonds are coming to juice drinks; coconut is in everything, and the gluten-free category is expanding rapidly (gluten-free granola, anyone?).  Glenn Collins

title: The Art of the Doodle
description: English artist David Shrigley is a master of the incompetent line.

title: The Scare
description: One day last summer I got an e-mail from one of my best friends, updating me on the last few months of his life: work developments; a vacation recap; a reply to a barbecue invitation; and one other thing that he would tell me about when we met. We had dinner a few weeks later, and at the end of our second beers, he casually said, Im H.I.V.-positive.

title: Judith Clarks Radical Transformation
description: If Judy Clark is not a fit candidate for clemency, it is hard to imagine what argument could be made for giving clemency to anyone. The pain and anger of the Rockland families is completely understandable, but should the desire for endless retribution prevail over every other consideration? I hope that Governor Cuomo will choose the just and courageous course and release her.

title: Preschool of Hard Knocks
description: My daughter loves her preschool. So do my wife and I: Its affordable, its on our way to work and it teaches Mandarin, her second language. Recently, the schools co-owner and director was indicted for stealing a ton of money meant to feed low-income children at her other business. I wouldnt be shocked if the charges stick. How do my ethical obligations not to support a (supposed) crook square with my daughters love of the school and its teachers, especially given the lack of equivalent options? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

title: The Dilemma of Being a Cyborg
description: This kind of thing happens all the time now, but three or four years ago it still seemed momentous and thrilling: a sudden argument at a dinner party (something about Tom Selleck and Burt Reynolds and iconic mustaches of the 70s) was quickly put to rest when half the people present picked up their phones and started to Google. Observing this, a friend of mine made what struck me as a very clever remark about our stegosaurus brains. It didnt occur to me that only a dinosaur would delight in a dinosaur analogy.

title: Romney Goes on Offensive in Florida, Bolstered by Debate Performance
description: MIAMI Mitt Romney might have felt on Friday that he had finally gotten his groove back.

title: Reconsidering the Genius of Gertrude Stein
description: Approaching Gertrude Steins writing critically is tricky. Because she strove to reshape literary conventions  syntax, language usage, narrative order and the sense of making sense  any comment on her choices may already be rebuffed in her poetics and practice. Stein is a trickster. This may be why, as I read Ida and Stanzas in Meditation, both reissued in corrected, authoritative editions from Yale University Press, I remembered a Jonathan Richman lyric Ill paraphrase as Pablo Picasso never got called a jackass.

title: The Anointed
description: To the Editor:

title: Something Big
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rise of the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vigor of Middle Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: INDIA CALLING: An Intimate Portrait of a Nations Remaking,  by Anand Giridharadas (St. Martins Griffin, $14.99.) Through the prism of his migr family history, Giridharadas, a columnist for The International Herald Tribune, captures fundamental changes in the very idea of what it is to be Indian. Moving among entrepreneurs, radicals and religious seekers, he notes that the greatest upheaval is in the mind, in how people conceived of their possibilities.

title: Editors Choice
description: BEN JONSON: A Life,  by Ian Donaldson (Oxford University, $39.95.) In his time, Jonson was as central to the development of British theater as Shakespeare was, if not more, Donaldson argues in this deeply researched but happily readable biography.

title: At Sundance, One Star Bakes; Another Keeps the Party Going
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Sundance is drawing to a close just as the Bagger is emerging from our Academy foxhole, where (incoming!) we have been dodging snubs while hoping to see Michael Fassbender in a pirate hat.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jeanette Winterson discusses the legacy of Henry Millers Tropic of Cancer; Charles McGrath on the deeply personal poetry of publisher Jonathan Galassi; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Fourth-Largest City in America in Mourning
description: And now, a moment of televised silence (if you turn the volume down) to mark the passing of Robert Hegyes, former portrayer of the small screens reigning 26-year-old Puerto Rican Jewish high school student and sideways role model.

title: Queen Elizabeth II in Public and Private
description: As a British expat trying to keep in touch with the old sod, Ive acquired the slightly eccentric habit of buying coffee mugs recording key moments in the public life of our royal family. Alas, those celebrating the weddings of Prince Charles and Prince Andrew broke soon after their marriages fell apart. Not so the mug I bought for Queen Elizabeths Golden Jubilee in 2002. In fine bone china, no less than in person, she just keeps on going.

title: How the Jews Handled Prohibition
description: Even in New York Times headlines, they were known as Izzy and Moe. Their very presence could make bartenders faint. They possessed a keen sense of smell and a theatrical flair that included disguises as fruit peddlers and football players. Stumpy Izzy, who had rejected a career as a rabbi, and his partner were credited with 4,392 arrests in five years, including one in a Manhattan meatpacking district club where Izzy posed as a turkey salesman and found bottles of booze concealed in a huge stuffed bear.

title: Islam and the West Through the Eyes of Two Women
description: Very few of the heroes and villains made famous in the wars of the past decade are women. Of the scant exceptions, two of the most fascinating are the subjects of Deborah Scrogginss thoughtful double biography, Wanted Women.

title: The Influence of the Inquisition
description: In the moral atlas of Cullen Murphy, the road to Abu Ghraib, Guantnamo Bay and the secret black sites of the war on terror begins in Montsgur, a fortress in the foothills of the Pyrenees. There, in 1244, a French army assembled at the behest of the Roman Catholic Church besieged several hundred Cathars. Their sects heresy was dualism, a belief in both a beneficent God and an equivalent evil deity. Enticed into surrendering by the promise that their followers would be spared, the Cathars were burned alive on a pyre.

title: The Dangers of Sharing
description: It may surprise anyone under 16, but even before the advent of social networking we faced threats to our privacy. A hospital accidentally releasing patient records or a shady marketing firm engaging in Stasi-like data collection  such violations were substantial enough and disturbing enough to make the evening news. Today, however, the death of privacy is more like death by a thousand cuts: information leaks out slowly and invisibly, and so routinely that were hardly shocked when it does. Internet companies, which use the word sharing almost as a euphemism for oops, like to pretend these lapses are normal, even natural. If Mark Zuckerbergs private photos are up for grabs (as when a recent glitch exposed his Facebook account), what can the rest of us expect?

title: Edmund Whites Body Language
description: Some novels plumb psyches, others draw social outlines and still others leave character pretty much out of it in favor of cerebral concepts or intricate plotlines. Over the course of his long career, Edmund White has written all of the above. But with his latest, Jack Holmes and His Friend, White delivers something rare: a novel that above all else leaves its readers intimately familiar with its characters bodies.

title: Up Front
description: Sara Wheeler is no stranger to the rigors  and the literature  of polar exploration. The author of The Magnetic North: Notes From the Arctic Circle and Terra Incognita: Travels in Antarctica, she has also written a biography of Apsley Cherry-Garrard, whose classic account of the doomed Robert Falcon Scott expedition, The Worst Journey in the World, she first read in a lonely tent on the West Antarctic ice sheet. In a recent e-mail, Wheeler recalled that her travels have also taken her to Spitsbergen, Norway, the remote site from which S. A. Andre began his aeronautical assault on the North Pole  yet another frigid failure and the subject of Alec Wilkinsons Ice Balloon, which she reviews this week.

title: Falling Short of the North Pole
description: The history of 19th-century Arctic exploration is gruesome. Ice floes throttle creaky ships, men vanish into the white silence, and the North Pole remains elusive. At that time, nobody even knew if that sacred spot lay on land or sea. Then a Swedish aeronaut had a new idea. Approaches by sledge and ship had failed, so why not fly to the pole?

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: BERLIN STORIES  By Robert Walser.  New York Review Books; paper, $14.

title: The Reign of Venice
description: Medieval travelers were overwhelmed by Venices affluence  the sacks of spices! the bales of brocades!  and driven to distraction by its seeming paradoxes. The city was surrounded by sand and mud, yet its markets dazzled with variety. Since there was no land to speak of, it had no feudal system, yet its councils handed down orders like holy writ. Its people reveled in their republican freedom, yet bowed undemurringly to the collective good. Even the physical city defied logic: a wooden settlement perched on piles in a swampy lagoon had turned into the densest urban area in Europe, its brick bell towers jostling for airspace, its stone palaces squatting on reclaimed land.

title: Our Favorite Weapon
description: You rarely pull a gun to start a conversation, but when I recently told an in-law that I was writing about Glock pistols, he improvised a research project. Reaching beneath his jacket, he quickly unholstered, unloaded and handed me his Glock 9 millimeter  this was in Kentucky, land of permissive concealed-carry laws. I always carry this, and I always will, he said before giving me a primer that could have been used in a promotional video for both the pistol and Glock: The Rise of Americas Gun, Paul M. Barretts engaging if uneven history of the most famous handgun in contemporary America.

title: Chris Christie, Revisionist Historian
description: Some readers thought I was a little hard on Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey this week. On Wednesday I wrote about his decision to veto any law guaranteeing marriage rights to all state residents. He said he thought the issue should be left up to voters. And I said that civil rights dont belong on a ballot. Besides, referendums are a bad way to govern a state. Check out California sometime.

title: Memories of South Africa During and After Apartheid
description: Zakes MDA and J. M. Coetzee, the two most acclaimed South African novelists of the past 20 years, could be writing about different countries  and, in a way, they are. Coetzee excels at sparsely populated fictions of gnawing interiority. His socially uneasy and anguished solitaries, often academics like himself, wrestle with psychological dilemmas and metaphysical maladies. In contrast, Mdas greatest gift is his Dickensian social range, his ability to generate characters from diverse backgrounds, colluding and colliding across the barriers erected to divide them. Where Coetzee is drawn to existential hinterlands, Mda takes us deep into his countrys literal interior, those rural regions that, in most South African writing, are pushed to the margins.

title: The Will to Believe
description: Stella Morrison is an elegant woman: an accomplished hostess for her financier-turned-member-of-Parliament husband, a devoted but not doting mother, tastefully devout in her religious beliefs. Shes also beguiling to the opposite sex, one of whom regards her charm as will-o-the-wisp and indefinable, all strands and tendrils and impossible to pin down. Yet Stella is unhappy, trapped in a loveless marriage, pining for her children, all of whom have left home. Getting ready for yet another dinner party, she thinks of herself as a priestess in an Attic temple preparing for sacrifice. This unsettling combination of magnificence and pathos suffuses Francesca Kays second novel, The Translation of the Bones. (Her first, An Equal Stillness, won Britains Orange Award for New Writers.)

title: Connecting the Lowly and Mighty in New York
description: Any beginning writer could find both instruction and inspiration in Elliot Perlmans new novel, The Street Sweeper. If it were tricked out with commentary in the margins  in fact, now that Ive finished marking it up, anyones welcome to take my copy  it could serve as a textbook on how not to write fiction. At the same time, it gives the lie to those killjoy teachers who tell you that no reputable publisher will touch your work if you dont learn your craft. This 600-plus-page epic turns out to have only a novellas worth of story and substance: the rest is repetition, over and over, of basic information about who the characters are, where they are and whats going on, long expository and hortatory speeches that no real person would ever deliver and the padded, ping-ponging dialogue beloved of amateur writers.  And your family? My family?   Ive always felt kind of . . . fraudulent. Fraudulent?

title: Chinese Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters Again
description: HONG KONG  The police in the western Chinese province of Sichuan fired on Tibetan protesters for the third time this week, killing at least one and injuring several, overseas Tibetan activist groups said on Friday.

title: Cultural Conflicts, Playing Out on the Football Field
description: After his team was routed by the New England Patriots this month, driving the Denver Broncos out of the N.F.L. playoffs, Tim Tebow jogged off the field. Camera crews and photographers surrounded him, waiting for Mr. Tebow, the quarterback, to drop to one knee and bow his head in prayer, his famous and controversial signature gesture.

title: Final Reckonings, a Tuneful Fedora and Forgiveness
description: LEONARD COHEN generally takes his time. He sings, speaks, writes and records at his own measured pace. Concerts on his recent world tour have stretched to three hours. His new album, Old Ideas, is his first studio album since Dear Heather in 2004.

title: Work Wear | Brook Klausing
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Market for Films Signals Good, Not Great, Year for Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The buzz means nothing, said Robert Redford as his Sundance Film Festival opened in this luxury ski town last week. Wait until its over, and see what sticks.

title: Wheelies: The $2 Billion Addition Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: In Michigan, Obama Calls for Overhaul of Financial Aid
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  President Obama called on Congress to approve a financial-aid overhaul that for the first time would tie federal financing to colleges and universities to the success of these institutions in improving affordability and value for students.

title: Winter Jam Canceled Due to Lack of Winter
description: Sorry, kids: The parks department has officially canceled winter.

title: Pushed to Limit, Djokovic Defeats Murray to Set Up a Familiar Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There were big hints of a power shift at this Australian Open. There were grueling, long-form semifinals bristling with uncertainty. But when Friday night had turned into Saturday morning in Melbourne and Novak Djokovic lay spread-eagled on his back with a fulfilled look on his stubbled face, the status quo had been preserved.

title: Top Central Banker Urges No Delay to Basel III
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  A top central banker on Friday damped the hopes of some in the banking industry that they might get more time to comply with new regulations.

title: Wolf-gang! Wolf-gang!': Mozart Opera at Cowboys Stadium
description: It will be Sarastros host versus the Queen of the Night and her minions at Cowboys Stadium. The stadium, the home of the Dallas Cowboys, will open its gates for a free simulcast of Mozarts Magic Flute on April 28, the Dallas Opera and the football team said on Thursday. In a statement, the Cowboys executive vice president for brand management, Charlotte Anderson, called it a distinctive event. Dallas Operas general director, Keith Cerny, called it a game-changing collaboration. The production comes from the Lyric Opera of Chicago. Officials said the opera would be shown on the worlds largest high-definition video board structure, which consists of four screens suspended over the field.
