description: When Thomas Holton began visiting the Lam family in 2003, he was struck by how much life they fit inside their 350-square-foot apartment on Ludlow Street in Manhattan. Three small children, their parents, relatives and friends, a bathtub in the kitchen, with clothes racks above the table. It was a jumble that fascinated him for its grit, warmth and can-do optimism.

title: Back to Classroom for Skills Not Taught in High School
description: On a recent morning in a small classroom in the Bronx, Ivette Gongn-Volmar asked a group of students to list their needs.

title: Tending the Soul, and Earthly Gardens
description: FOUR years ago, the Rev. Forrest Church informed members of his congregation, the Unitarian Church of All Souls, on the Upper East Side, that he had terminal cancer. Less than 20 months later, he was dead at 61. In Being Alive and Having to Die: The Spiritual Odyssey of Forrest Church (St. Martins Press, $27.99), the book critic Dan Cryer ably captures the theologian who was the son of a United States senator and became a champion of liberal political causes in religion.

title: Newts Real Legacy
description: DO you think that after all is said and done, Newt Gingrich will just go down in history as the politician who conclusively proved that voters dont care about a candidates sexual misbehavior?

title: Corrections: January 28
description: SPORTS

title: A Slimmer Curry Aims to Regain Relevance
description: MIAMI  As he attempts to revive a lost career, Eddy Curry is focusing firmly on the road ahead and shunning any discussion of the jagged path behind him.

title: Lunar Colonies, Lunacy and Losses
description: Newt Gingrich is spaced-out. Literally.

title: Rabbis Followers Cast Doubts on Congressmans Fund-Raising
description: Soon after he began running for Congress in 2009, Michael G. Grimm, a Staten Island Republican, needed to convince party leaders in Washington that he could raise enough money to become a viable candidate. Seeking help, he turned to an unlikely source: followers of an Orthodox rabbi and mystic from Israel.

title: Cathedral Expects New Revenue, and Controversy, in Residential Tower Deal
description: After years of inactivity, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine is completing a lease agreement to bring a second residential tower  and a second stream of revenue  to its verdant 11-acre campus and famously unfinished cathedral. A 2013 groundbreaking is planned.

title: Lundqvist and Gaborik on Opposing Teams (and Now at Odds)
description: OTTAWA  Neither the quiet Marian Gaborik nor the debonair Henrik Lundqvist are noted for their comedic abilities, but the Rangers teammates have a little shtick going at the N.H.L. All-Star festivities.

title: Seized Pirates in High-Seas Legal Limbo, With No Formula for Trials
description: Earlier this month off the coast of Pakistan, 15 Somali pirates held aboard the aircraft carrier John C. Stennis were loaded onto a helicopter and flown to a newly arrived carrier nearby, the Carl Vinson.

title: A Gentile Who Lives for Yiddish
description: OFF East Seventh Street in the East Village, through a doorway marked with a faded Hebrew Actors Union plaque and up a flight of stairs, a slim man in a dapper suit kept dashing madly into the long, empty room, rehearsing slapstick stage entrances.

title: Lone Wolf Commands a Following
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On the Chinese calendar, this week ushers in the year of the dragon. But here, it feels a lot more like the year of the wolf.

title: Rutgers Is Left to Re-Evaluate Programs Worth
description: Greg Schianos decision to leave Rutgers has left Scarlet Knights fans up and down the New Jersey Turnpike with this question: What next?

title: A South African Partys New Face, and Lightning Rod
description: CAPE TOWN

title: Tour of Wealth for All Seasons
description: Earlier this week, perhaps in an effort to test my forbearance among those receiving Romney-esque tax advantages, I visited the Winter Antiques Show, the annual paean to furnishings you will not find reproduced at Target.

title: President, Buoyed by Rising Numbers, Seeks to Rally Democrats
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  President Obama, buoyed by improving economic news and rising poll numbers, rallied House Democrats here on Friday with an address that inched toward a morning in America tone and dwelled heavily on his vision of a national collective responsibility.

title: Bracing for $40,000 at New York City Private Schools
description: THERE are certain mathematical realities associated with New York City private schools: There are more students than seats at the top-tier schools, at least three sets of twins will be vying head to head for spots in any class, and already-expensive tuition can only go up.

title: Latin America Looks at Wests Fiscal Crises, and Sees Its Own Past
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Sometimes it comes in the form of a news dispatch, like the item from Milan explaining how Italians fret about the spread, a term used to refer to the gap between their high borrowing costs and the lower interest rates for Germany.

title: Poems From Left-handed
description: Three poems from the forthcoming poetry collection by Jonathan Galassi. Read more about Mr. Galassi and "Left-handed.

title: Contradictions of the Heart
description: JONATHAN GALASSI likes to say that he has backed into most of the things he has wound up doing in life. If thats the case, he has reversed himself into some pretty nice spots. He is the president and publisher of Farrar, Straus and Giroux, a trustee of Phillips Exeter Academy and an acclaimed translator of the Italian poets Eugenio Montale and Giacomo Leopardi. In New York publishing circles he is greatly admired for running a publishing house that is both commercially viable and a home for Nobel Prize winners and books of high literary quality.

title: At Event, a Rare Look at Putins Life
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, a man whose private life is revealed to the public only in glimpses, on Friday described the loss that his family suffered during the 872-day siege of Leningrad, the Soviet-era name for St. Petersburg, when his 1-year-old brother was taken from his mother, died in a childrens home and was buried in an unmarked grave.

title: Giants Not-So-Secret Plan: Pressure Brady
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In Super Bowl XLII, the Giants harassed Tom Brady all game, sacking him five times and forcing a fumble, which they recovered.

title: Close Ties to Goldman Enrich Romneys Public and Private Lives
description: When Bain Capital sought to raise money in 1989 for a fast-growing office-supply company named Staples, Mitt Romney, Bains founder, called upon a trusted business partner: Goldman Sachs, whose bankers led the companys initial public offering.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Optimism as U.S. Transfers Security Control to Afghans in Jalalabad
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  In the garden of the governors residence here, a red-coated brass band struck up  erratically  the Afghan national anthem, and after some fumbling and delay with the rope, two guards raised the black, red and green of the Afghan flag.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Navy Plans to Make Base From Old Ship
description: WASHINGTON  The Navy is converting an amphibious transport and docking ship to serve as a floating base for military operations and humanitarian assistance, with deployment expected this summer to waters in the Middle East, Pentagon officials said Friday.

title: Legal Limbo for Captured Pirates
description: What happens to Somali pirates after they are seized at sea, such as in a previously reported American naval operation? A news analysis in The New York Times on Saturday examines a seam in international law enforcement, and a case of high-seas legal limbo.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Kevin H. White, Mayor Who Led Boston in Busing Crisis, Dies at 82
description: Kevin H. White, a four-term mayor of Boston who came to national prominence for shepherding the city through years of racial violence and economic stagnation  and for a decadelong federal investigation into corruption in his administration  died Friday night at his home in the Beacon Hill section of Boston. He was 82.

title: Dick Kniss, a Bassist for Peter, Paul and Mary, Dies at 74
description: Dick Kniss, a self-taught musician who for more than 40 years played stand-up bass behind Peter, Paul and Mary, becoming a veritable fourth member of the folk-singing trio, died on Wednesday in Kingston, N.Y. He was 74.

title: North Carolina: Report Delivered on Eugenics Program
description: The report from a task force examining how to compensate thousands of North Carolinians who were sterilized against their will under a state program was delivered to Gov. Bev Perdue on Friday. The governor has said she will review the report, which suggests $50,000 per living victim and mental health services, and will make her recommendations to the legislature. The program, which ran from 1929 to 1974, was intended to reduce welfare rolls by preventing mostly poor, uneducated and sometimes mentally handicapped people from bearing children. About 7,600 people were deemed unfit to reproduce. The task force estimates that as many as 2,000 of them are still alive.

title: Bronx Man Charged With Murder in Death of 1-Year-Old
description: A Bronx man was charged with murder on Friday in the death of his girlfriends 1-year-old son, the police said.

title: Arizona: Arrest of Man Accused in Death Threat Case
description: Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County said Friday that a man accused of threatening to kill him was arrested in Tennessee. Adam E. Cox, 33, was arrested on an unrelated warrant, but he is the prime suspect in the death threat inquiry, Sheriff Arpaio said in a statement. Mr. Cox is accused of threatening to kill the sheriff and his family last year, perhaps because of the sheriffs continuing investigation into the legitimacy of President Obamas birth certificate, the sheriff said. Sheriff Arpaio, who called Mr. Cox an Obama fanatic, said a cold case posse that includes retired detectives and lawyers working as volunteers would announce its findings within 30 days.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,870 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following Americans this week:

title: Week in Politics Pictures
description: From Florida to Maine, the Republican candidates fought to be the presidential nominee.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Rescue teams are searching for five security personnel who went missing on Tuesday, after an avalanche hit a seven-member team near the line of control. The avalanche struck at Pharkian Gali in the Kupwara district in northern Kashmir, The Tribune reported. Bodies of two of the seven officers have been recovered.

title: French Elles Black Eye
description: LONDON  The editor-in-chief of French Elle went on television on Friday night to try to draw a line under a racism controversy that has prompted calls for a boycott of the womens lifestyle magazine.

title: Greek Debt Talks Again Seem to Be on the Verge of a Deal
description: Greece once again appears on the verge of reaching a deal with its private sector creditors on how much of a loss they would be willing to accept on their bond holdings.

title: The Early Word: Rebuttal
description: Todays Times

title: Its Not Me, Its You: How to End a Friendship
description: WHEN Jeryl Brunner, a writer in Manhattan, was in her 20s, she had a friend who was just the sort of acquaintance people scoop up in their social net when they are young and trying to carve out a life in a new city. The friend was fun, outgoing and stylish, and always up for a night of dancing at Area, or a weekend jaunt to a Neiman Marcus outlet in New Jersey.

title: Azarenka Powers Past Sharapova, Claims No. 1 Ranking
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For two games and two points, Victoria Azarenka did a fair impression of a first-time Grand Slam singles finalist. She looked edgy, slightly off target and under pressure from her more experienced opponent and sonic soul mate Maria Sharapova.

title: The State of Chad Ochocinco
description: Believe it or not, Chad Ochocinco is still a member of the Patriots.

title: Super Bowl: Why Giants Will Win
description: Super Bowl XLVI

title: Atlanta Teenager Wins Singles Title in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A 15-year-old from Atlanta, Taylor Townsend, became the first American to win the girls singles title at the Australian Open since 1989.

title: Bryan Twins Fall to Stepanek and Paes
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Playing like riverboat gamblers, Leander Paes of India and Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic upset the defending champions, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, 7-6 (1), 6-2, to win the Australian Open doubles title.

title: In Nonstop Whirlwind of Campaigns, Twitter Is a Critical Tool
description: When Newt Gingrich said in a recent debate that he was a man of grandiose ideas, Mitt Romneys campaign pounced. It sent mocking Twitter messages with a hashtag, #grandiosenewt, encouraging voters to add their own examples of occasions when they felt Mr. Gingrich had been grandiose.

title: Save The Welsh
description: Landon Thomas has a very nice piece  aside from one error  comparing the situation of Wales within the sterling area, also known as the United Kingdom, to that of Greece within the euro area.

title: Expedited Customs Program Will Expand
description: Global Entry, a program that allows low-risk travelers entering the United States to bypass customs agents and be screened at kiosks instead, will expand and become permanent. The news was recently announced by President Obama as part of a series of actions by his administration intended to increase travel and tourism to the United States.

title: Austerity Memories
description: A further thought on the observation that Britains slump has now gone on longer than the slump in the 1930s: its worth remembering the rapturous reception the Cameron austerity program received here, not just from the right, but from centrists. Heres David Broder:

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Bollywood award season  is in overdrive with ceremonies being held in quick succession. The Colors Screen Awards were followed by the Zee Cine Awards, in which there were two awards in each acting category. Ranbir Kapoor and Shah Rukh Khan each picked up a statue; the former for best actor in the popular category and the latter for best actor jury award. Actress Vidya Balan won in both categories, while Farhan Akhtar won the award for the Male International Icon, which presumably has nothing to do with acting.

title: A Rally for Putin, Enthusiasm Optional
description: YEKATERINBURG, Russia  With calls for workers unity and denunciations of the bourgeoisie, teams of mechanics, welders and heavy-machinery operators gathered here Saturday in subzero temperatures for a Soviet-style rally in support of Vladimir V. Putin. But that does not mean all were happy about it.

title: Report Claims Syrian Rebels Moved Iranian Hostages to Lebanon
description: A new element was added to the mystery surrounding five Iranians who were abducted by Syrian rebel fighters last month, with a report from Iran on Saturday that the men are now being held in Lebanon.

title: A Long Wait for Information
description: Federal agencies must list their 10 oldest requests each year, to help focus them on cutting the backlog.

title: In Davos, Europe Is Pressed for Debt Crisis Solution
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  World leaders turned up the pressure on Europe on Saturday to erect a more formidable wall of money against the sovereign debt crisis, warning that the euro zone continues to pose a severe threat to the global economy.

title: Milk Thistle Farm Has Closed
description: Milk Thistle Farm, producers of what might be the favorite local organic milk, has gone out of business.

title: Variety Puzzle: A Curious Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Did you fall down the rabbit hole on this one, or were you victorious?

title: Marriott Plans More Edition Hotels
description: Despite losing its first Edition hotel in Waikiki, Hawaii, to a different management company last summer, Marriott International says it has plans to open Edition hotels in five major cities.

title: Mixed Doubles Remains an Afterthought
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Despite being reintroduced as an Olympic event for 2012 for the first time since 1924, mixed doubles remains a clear afterthought in tennis.

title: Baseballs Identity Fraud Problem May Be More Prevalent
description: When Sandy Alderson traveled to the Dominican Republic in 2010 to investigate identity fraud for the commissioners office, he went armed with a message. Alderson had previously served as the chief executive of the San Diego Padres, and related his experiences.

title: White House Boycott Could Cost Bruins Thomas
description: What a week it was for Tim Thomas, hockeys most consistently incandescent goalie. At the end of it, rumors were flying that Thomass days with the Bruins  the team he led last season to the Stanley Cup  are numbered.

title: At Romney Rally, Actor Assails Obamas Path to Socialism
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.  The crowd that greeted Mitt Romney, stretching from dock to dock and leaning over the balconies at the Fish House here, was treated to several cameos Saturday morning before an energetic and sunny Mr. Romney finally took the stage.

title: A Governor Still Trying to Become a Politician
description: MIAMI  As the Republican presidential candidates darted from city to city in Florida last week stitching up votes for Tuesdays primary, Gov. Rick Scott stayed largely ensconced in the State Capitol, far from the fray, filling his days with business meetings, receptions and talk of his legislative agenda.

title: Azarenka Sweeps Past Sharapova to Her First Grand Slam Crown
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For two games and two points, Victoria Azarenka looked the way one might imagine a first-time Grand Slam singles finalist should look.

title: 5 Are Arrested in British Tabloid Scandal
description: LONDON  A Scotland Yard team investigating the bribery of police officers by journalists searched the offices of Rupert Murdochs flagship British tabloid, The Sun, on Saturday after arresting a police officer and four men identified as current or former journalists at the paper. A police statement said searches were also being conducted at the homes of the arrested men.

title: Sharp Rise in Violence Halts Monitoring by League in Syria
description: RANKOUS, Syria  The Arab League suspended its monitoring mission in Syria on Saturday, saying that a harsh new government crackdown made it too dangerous to proceed and was resulting in the deaths of innocents across the country.

title: For Giants, Quarterback and Coach Together in Excellence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning rarely gets animated when taking questions from reporters, but his detachment reached a new level last week when he was asked if he ever tires of considering questions about his legacy.

title: Gingrich Vows Long Fight and Gets Cains Backing
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Despite signs that he could lose the important Florida primary on Tuesday, Newt Gingrich, who picked up the endorsement of a former opponent, Herman Cain, pledged Saturday to stay in the nominating race until the very end, telling reporters he would press on until the Republican convention in Tampa in August.

title: Energy, Charm and Ample Ambition
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  The wrestling room at the United States Olympic Training Center smelled of stale sweat and fresh expectation. Training amid dozens of Greco-Roman wrestlers was a familiar athlete with a crew cut and an overstuffed suitcase of a body. Never sculptured, his round physique had gone to flab and now aspired again to fitness. This was Rulon Gardner, the Wyoming farm boy who beat the unbeatable Russian and now had a 64-inch chest, 9 toes and seemingly 9 lives, few if any lived in moderation.

title: In Cradle of Games, a New Olympic Trial: Debt
description: ATHENS  What happens if the country that invented the Olympics cannot afford to produce Olympic athletes?

title: Amid Players Hoping for N.B.A., a Few Trying to Get Back
The Dream May Be Over for Irsay and the Colts
description: INDIANAPOLIS  His office has been stripped of much memorabilia, the guitar once owned by Jerry Garcia and the original manuscript scroll of Jack Kerouacs classic On the Road sent to a local museum in anticipation of the tourists and parties to come. So Jim Irsay has his televisions and his Twitter feed, and pictures of the Rolling Stones and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. keeping him company until his team re-emerges.

title: Eighth Graders Helped a Low-Key City Land the Super Bowl
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As drizzle shrouded the city in a damp chill last week, and the downtown steam plant churned billows of clouds into a low sky. A train rumbled past the football stadium carrying flatbeds of tractors, and a question hung as plainly as the 30-story facsimile of the Lombardi Trophy plastered on the side of a downtown hotel.

title: Chinese Crackdown Seals Off Ethnic Unrest
description: CHENGDU, China  This regional metropolis is roughly 200 miles from the wave of protest by ethnic Tibetans that is sweeping the towering mountains of western Sichuan Province. But take a stroll through Chengdus Tibetan quarter, and the tensions generated by the distant unrest become palpable.

title: Keeping Score: For Tigers, Defensive Issues That Are Hard to Outslug
description: In March 2008, the Detroit Tigers signed a lumbering slugger to what was then the fifth-largest contract in baseball history. His physique and conditioning were suspect, prompting skeptics to warn that he would become a defensive liability and that his hitting might tail off. But Dave Dombrowski, the clubs general manager, brushed aside such concerns and gave him an eight-year, $152 million deal.

title: Chicago Seeks Visibility, Not Trouble
description: Careful planning always precedes summit meetings like those scheduled for May in Chicago for the Group of 8 economic powers and the NATO military alliance. But events rarely unfold as planned.

title: The Patriots Triple Threat
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Julian Edelman said he never saw it coming. True, he had been a versatile performer for the New England Patriots, catching passes and returning punts and kicks. He had also set season records for total offense as a quarterback in college. But playing defense?

title: PGA Rookie Carballo Had to Dodge a Few Rocks
description: DEL MAR, Calif.  The golfer Miguel ngel Carballo sat contentedly in the middle of the kitchen before dinner while his entourage buzzed around him. His manager kneaded dough for pizza. His caddie chopped basil and tomatoes. Shuffling between them, topping the wine glasses, was his swing coach. The fellowship in the room was like yeast, making the others voices rise as Carballo quietly turned his gaze from one familiar face to the next.

title: Panetta Credits Pakistani Doctor in Bin Laden Raid
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has confirmed publicly for the first time that an imprisoned doctor in Pakistan was working with the C.I.A. to gain access to Osama bin Ladens compound in the months before American troops killed Bin Laden last May.

title: The Worse-than Club
description: Further thoughts on the observation that the current British slump has now gone on longer than the slump of the 1930s. Is Britain unique?

title: Squash, a Growing Sport, and Nutritious, Too
description: Two hundred fifty-two consecutive matches won over 13 years. Thirteen national titles. The longest winning streak in college sports.

title: Squash Stir Fry
description: 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 30 Seconds With Howard Cross
description: Howard Cross played the most games at tight end in Giants history (207) and was a member of their 1990 Super Bowl team. The position will be in the spotlight Sunday in Super Bowl XLVI, as the Giants try to stop New Englands Rob Gronkowski and Aaron Hernandez.

title: Barton and the Jet
description: Having a conversation with Barton Silverman is like following a hockey game, where words scoot by like a puck on ice  glancing off events, people and places before it glides into the goal. That can mean a lot of interesting asides, considering the countless games, big and small, he has covered as a longtime sports photographer.

title: NBC News Asks Romney Campaign to Remove Ad
description: 4:29 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  NBC News is asking that the Romney campaign remove from its ads any references to material from the network in response to a new commercial that consists almost entirely of old footage of its former news anchor, Tom Brokaw, reporting on Newt Gingrichs legal troubles.

title: Greg Cook, the Story of an N.F.L. Shooting Star
description: Greg Cook was a talented quarterback whose promising career was cut short by injury after only one season. Cook died on Friday after being hospitalized with pneumonia. He was 65:

title: How Azarenka Won Australia
description: Victoria Azarenka thoroughly outplayed Maria Sharapova in Saturdays Australian Open final. The spirited Azarkena had superior hands, better footwork and near-perfect shot selection as she withstood Sharapovas blistering pace with astonishing ease. How did Azarenka handle Sharapovas big game? And why did Sharapova struggle when Azarenka attacked?

title: Beltway Lobbyists Drop Egypts Government as Client
description: WASHINGTON  Lobbyists for the Egyptian government in Washington have ended their contracts with the country because of growing tensions after a raid by Egyptian authorities on several American nonprofit organizations.

title: In England, Tension Without Arrests
description: LONDON

title: The Bookstores Last Stand
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: For Sydney Leroux, Dual Citizenship, Single-Minded Approach
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Sydney Leroux is a substitute forward for the United States womens soccer team with dual citizenship, an encouraging future and a complicated past. Depending on ones point of view, she is either a revelatory young star who scored five goals in one game last week or a turncoat in her hometown.

title: Are We Ready for a Morality Pill?
description: Last October, in Foshan, China, a 2-year-old girl was run over by a van. The driver did not stop. Over the next seven minutes, more than a dozen people walked or bicycled past the injured child. A second truck ran over her. Eventually, a woman pulled her to the side, and her mother arrived. The child died in a hospital. The entire scene was captured on video and caused an uproar when it was shown by a television station and posted online. A similar event occurred in London in 2004, as have others, far from the lens of a video camera.

title: It Has a Fancy Name, but Will It Get Tough?
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA told the nation last week that he was convening a task force to investigate the abusive practices in the mortgage industry that led to our economic woes. Both lending and the practice of bundling loans into securities will come under scrutiny, he said, adding: This new unit will hold accountable those who broke the law, speed assistance to homeowners and help turn the page on an era of recklessness that hurt so many Americans.

title: An Appointment With Dread
description: Across the waiting room in the doctors office, a woman is generously showering each page of last months Newsweek with wet coughs. Her expression is a dutiful one, like that of a priest sprinkling holy water upon his congregation; occasionally she flips back to bestow a second layer where the first might have been too thin.

title: Rangers Girardi Rises From Free Agent to All-Star
description: OTTAWA  Rangers Coach John Tortorella can always find a teachable moment. Here at the N.H.L. All-Star Weekend  where he is coach of Team Alfredsson but asserts he will do nothing on the bench except watch, just like you  that moment came at Fridays media day, when he told reporters how much he admired Rangers defenseman Dan Girardi.

title: Letters: The Burdens on Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: A New Tax System Needs Fairness, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Anthony Is Resting His Ailing Body
description: MIAMI  Carmelo Anthony is shutting himself down for at least a few days to rest a sore ankle and a painful wrist, having conceded that his erratic play was hurting the Knicks cause. He missed Friday nights game against the Miami Heat and will miss Saturdays game in Houston.

title: No. 2 Overlooked, Except at the Board
description: Is it possible to be No. 2 in the world and be overlooked? In some respects, that is the situation facing Levon Aronian, 29.

title: Expanded Playoffs Coming to a Park Near You
description: CHICAGO  Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, was at the Palmer House Hilton on Friday night for the annual White Sox fan convention. He talked at length to fans and the news media about the state of the game, including an announcement that he still expected his 10-team playoff proposal to take effect for the 2012 season.

title: For Some Vassar Applicants, Joy Then Misery as College Corrects Mistake
description: Yap Zong Yao woke up at 5 a.m. Saturday in Singapore to check his admissions decision from Vassar College. He returned to sleep overwhelmed with joy, he said.

title: Wagners Horsewoman of Apocalypse
description: Gtterdmmerung, the final installment in the Metropolitan Operas new production of Wagners Ring cycle, which opened on Friday, is the most theatrically effective staging of the four works in this epic series, and the clearest representation of the director Robert Lepages vision. Thats because with each installment Mr. Lepage has simplified the staging and used fewer of the capacities of Carl Fillions 45-ton set: the machine, as it has been called, a huge gizmo of 24 planks that rotate on an axle in combination with video projections to evoke rivers, cliffs, mountain passes, forest dwellings and more.

title: Just Dont Call Her Che
description: Santiago, Chile

title: Hysteria and the Teenage Girl
description: LOS ANGELES

title: At War With So Paulos Establishment, Black Paint in Hand
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  This mega-citys authorities have waged war for years against what they call visual pollution, banning billboard advertising, demolishing abandoned skyscrapers and planning to raze concrete eyesores like the elevated highway known as the Big Worm.

title: The Perils of Bite Size Science
description: IN recent years, a trend has emerged in the behavioral sciences toward shorter and more rapidly published journal articles. These articles are often only a third the length of a standard paper, often describe only a single study and tend to include smaller data sets. Shorter formats are promoted by many journals, and limits on article length are stringent  in many cases as low as 2,000 words.

title: Stormy Seas Delay Recovery of Liners Fuel
description: ROME  Rough seas and strong winds forced salvage crews to suspend preparations to drain the fuel from a half-sunken luxury liner off the Tuscan coast on Saturday, and officials said the conditions might keep them from resuming work until midweek.

title: Ritalin Gone Wrong
description: THREE million children in this country take drugs for problems in focusing. Toward the end of last year, many of their parents were deeply alarmed because there was a shortage of drugs like Ritalin and Adderall that they considered absolutely essential to their childrens functioning.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Bird Flu Experiments
description: Research into the bird flu virus has set off an impassioned scientific debate over its risks and benefits. Here is a sampling.

title: Not Everyones in Tune Over Precious Violins
description: IN a dimly lighted hotel room, violinists blinking through vision-obscuring welders goggles picked up six violins. One was a Guarnerius and two were Stradivariuses, among the most storied names in instrument making and considered the epitome of violins; three were modern. The players were asked their preference. Only 8 of the 21 picked the precious products of the old masters, according to an academic article published this month.

title: Tension on the Tarmac
description: MIAMI

title: Made in the World
description: THE Associated Press reported last week that Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, wrote an opinion piece on a Cuban Web site, following a Republican Party presidential candidates debate in Florida, in which he argued that the selection of a Republican candidate for the presidency of this globalized and expansive empire is  and I mean this seriously  the greatest competition of idiocy and ignorance that has ever been.

title: Whats He Got to Hide?
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Filibustering Nominees Must End
description: The system for reviewing presidential appointments is broken. The Senate has a constitutional duty to provide advice and consent on the naming of judges and high-ranking executive branch officials. But the process has been hijacked by cynical partisanship and cheap tricks.

title: Genetic or Not, Gay Wont Go Away
description: BORN this way.

title: Government and Its Rivals
description: WHEN liberals are in a philosophical mood, they like to cast debates over the role of government not as a clash between the individual and the state, but as a conflict between the individual and the community. Liberals are for cooperation and joint effort; conservatives are for self-interest and selfishness. Liberals build the Hoover Dam and the interstate highways; conservatives sit home and dog-ear copies of The Fountainhead. Liberals know that it takes a village; conservatives pretend that all it takes is John Wayne.

title: In Tucson, Finding a Game to Replace the One That Took Its Ball and Left
description: TUCSON  The last few years have not been kind to the Old Pueblo, as this city is known. The collapse of the housing market sapped its growth. Boycotts over the states immigration policies kept tourists away. The shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords shook its residents.

title: Beyond SOPA
description: We welcomed the collapse this month of two flawed bills to prevent online piracy, bills that could have stifled speech and undermined Internet safety. But piracy by Web sites in countries like Russia and China, which offer high-quality bootleg copies of movies and music, is a real problem for the nations creative industries. And there is legislation that could curb the operation of rogue Web sites without threatening legitimate expression.

title: Unfinished Business in Iraq
description: When the last American troops came home from Iraq in December, thousands of Iraqis who had worked with the Americans were left behind. Many have already been targeted by militants, and some had taken refuge on American military bases. But once the bases were closed  or handed over to the Iraqi government  those Iraqis were forced into hiding. Unless Washington lives up to its moral obligation, many more will suffer or be killed.

title: Towels Become Treasured Souvenirs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  More often than not, tennis players want to leave tournaments with more than just the trophy.

title: The Missing Bird Flu Report
description: In November, a federal advisory board recommended that two scientific papers describing research that created strains of bird flu potentially transmissible in humans should be published only if key details are omitted. The fear is that terrorists or hostile nations could learn how to cause a pandemic. This week we will finally find out how the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity reached its conclusion.

title: Questions About the Groundhog
description: Groundhog Day  celebrated this Thursday  is a holiday specifically for discussing the weather, as if people were otherwise silent on the subject. (It is also a wonderful movie about infinite chances  and the perfectibility, at least, of Bill Murray  that is well worth watching, in case you havent seen it in a while.)

title: Dont Expect a Party in Brussels
description: Theyre back. The European Unions top leaders gather in Brussels Monday for their first summit meeting of 2012. Last years summits were an endless series of disappointments, with crucial details endlessly deferred. While markets teetered, leaders equivocated.

title: The BlackBerry, Trying to Avoid the Hall of Fallen Giants
description: FORGET the Union  whats the state of the BlackBerry?

title: Former Taliban Officials Say U.S. Talks Started
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Several Taliban negotiators have begun meeting with American officials in Qatar, where they are discussing preliminary trust-building measures, including a possible prisoner transfer, several former Taliban officials said Saturday.

title: Fact-Gathering Without the Facts
description: Re Keeping Them Honest (Jan. 22):

title: William Gibson
description: William Gibson is a prescient science fiction writer best known for coining the term cyberspace and accurately foreshadowing how humans would become so inextricably intertwined with their technology that their reality would be altered. His latest book, Distrust That Particular Flavor, is a nonfiction collection.

title: When Journalists Are Imprisoned
description: I wondered a bit about the topic of my Sunday column. Its in part about the way Ethiopias heightening repression has resulted in the imprisonment and abuse of journalists, including two Swedes who are now serving an 11-year prison sentence in awful conditions. My sense is that Ethiopias Prime Minister Meles Zenawi thinks that imprisoning those Swedes will intimidate and silence the international press corps  and I want him to realize that hes dead wrong. Thats also why I went after him by Twitter at Davos.

title: To Tithe or Not to Tithe ...
description: MITT ROMNEYS 2010 tax return, along with an estimated version of his 2011 filing, was released on Tuesday and attracted attention for a number of reasons  chief among them his high income and low tax rate. But the disclosure also called attention to his high level of charitable giving  much in the form of donations to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints  in a nation where most donate far less.

title: Facing Second Loss to Gingrich, Romney Went on Warpath
description: MIAMI  Facing the unthinkable here just seven days ago  a second loss in a row to Newt Gingrich  Mitt Romneys campaign team hatched a two-part plan to win in Florida:make Newt mad and Mitt meaner.

title: You Cant Find the Future in the Archives
description: This interview with  Harry West, chief executive of  Continuum, an innovation design consulting firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Higher Taxes Help the Richest, Too
description: TAXES and regulation will occupy center stage in the presidential contest.

title: How Long Can the Market Forget About the Pain?
description: THE year has started so splendidly for stock investors that it may seem churlish to point out that there are any lingering problems at all.

title: Sunday: Networking Event
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Confession: I dont watch a lot of television.

title: Building a Bridge to a Lonely Colleague
description: ITS lonely at the top, or so it is said. But in fact it doesnt matter where a person is in the office hierarchy  employees at all levels become lonely, even when other workers are all around them.

title: Romney Says Gingrich Should Not Rewrite History
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  After offering the crowd gathered at a shipbuilding yard here a preview of what he would do as president  a list that covered energy production and foreign policy  Mitt Romney paused and observed, Now Im speaking to you today as if Im already the candidate for president of the Republican Party. But Im not.

title: From Drumrolls to Designs
description: WHEN I was a senior in high school, a recruiter from the Marines contacted me. I was questioning what I wanted to do with my life, and my parents were pressuring me about the same thing. I thought I might become a professional musician, but I lacked the commitment.

title: Gingrich Suggests a Link Between Himself and Reagan Victories
description: WINTER PARK, Fla. As his bus rolled through middle Florida on Saturday afternoon, Newt Gingrich was asked at a stop at a church here what assurances he could give the audience that he could beat President Obama in November.

title: In a Daughters Voice, a Respite From the Darkness
description: Striped burgundy curtains block any hope of sunlight in Faith Scotts living room in Brooklyn. On an unseasonably warm and bright January day, she shrugged at the choice, saying, Just habit, I believe it is, just habit.

title: Slow Responses Cloud a Window Into Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Is a FOIA delayed a FOIA denied?

title: Celebrating Joe Louiss Contribution to Golf
description: SAN DIEGO  While the golf world trains its collective eye on Abu Dhabi, where Tiger Woods is poised for his first victory in a full-field event in over two years, the 60th anniversary of the color barrier being broken in a PGA Tour event is being quietly celebrated at this weeks Farmers Insurance Open.

title: Neediest Cases | Where Are They Now?
description: After finding out he was losing his vision, Alfredo Santiago became a painter.

title: Russian Liberals Growing Uneasy With Alliances
description: MOSCOW  About two and a half hours into a recent strategy session of Russias new protest movement, someone raised the question that could tear apart the crazy-quilt alliance opposing Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putins power.

title: Hoping for a Comeback
description: Five once-Olympic athletes are looking to get back in the 2012 Games.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 29
description: Tensions between the Republican presidential candidates are increasing as the nominating contests continue. Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney traded jabs during the debate on Thursday as Mr. Romney fought to regain his front-runner status ahead of Tuesdays primary in Florida.

title: Five More Looking to Get Back in the Games
description: Janet Evans

title: Private Snoops Find GPS Trail Legal to Follow
description: Only yesterday it was the exotic stuff of spy shows: flip on a computer and track the enemys speeding car.

title: Agreement Said to Be Closer on Beginning H.G.H. Tests
description: The N.F.L. and the players union  deadlocked during the regular season over the implementation of blood testing for human growth hormone  have made progress in discussions over the last few weeks, creating the possibility that testing of players will begin during the off-season, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

title: New Report by Agency Lowers Estimates of Natural Gas in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Just how much natural gas is trapped underground in the United States?

title: Privacy, Technology and Law
description: EVERY day, those of us who live in the digital world give little bits of ourselves away. On Facebook and LinkedIn. To servers that store our e-mail, Google searches, online banking and shopping records. Does the fact that so many of us live our lives online mean we have given the government wide-open access to all that information?

title: In Rankous, Barely Holding On
description: Free Syria Army tries to hold on to Rankous, a town located near Damascus.

title: Ex-Congressman Retreats on Energy Project
description: WASHINGTON  A former congressman who became a lobbyist has abandoned his plans to collect $90,000 from working on an energy project that he helped finance through Congress.

title: Feeling Better, Johnson Begins to Return to Form
description: SAN DIEGO  Dustin Johnson said he probably would have been in Abu Dhabi this week, but arthroscopic surgery on his right knee the last Tuesday in November forced a change in plans.

title: The Man Behind Gingrichs Money
description: The trip to Jordan by a group of United States congressmen was supposed to be a chance for them to meet the newly crowned King Abdullah II. But their tour guide had a more complicated agenda.

title: Yemeni Leader Arrives in U.S. for Medical Treatment
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who left Yemen last week to seek medical treatment in the United States for injuries sustained when the presidential palace was bombed in June, arrived in the country Saturday night, Yemeni officials said.

title: Another Injury for Crosby
description: Sidney Crosby, the Pittsburgh Penguins star who has been sidelined twice since last January with concussion symptoms, has also sustained a neck injury, the Pittsburgh Penguins said in a statement Saturday night.

title: A Renewed Public Push for Somewhere to Sit Outdoors
description: On recent sunny day in San Francisco, Rebecca Scalfaro left her office to eat lunch and read a few pages of a John Steinbeck novel in Civic Center Plaza in front of City Hall. As usual, Ms. Scalfaro, a petite 48-year-old who works in accounting, found a seat along one of the low-lying concrete walls that surround the square patches of grass on the plaza.

title: A Premeditated Opinion on City Schools
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Ex-Workers at City Colleges Paid for Unused Sick Days
description: Many public and private employers have a use-it-or-lose-it policy toward sick time. But the City Colleges of Chicago has generated more than $7 million in postemployment sick day payments for about 140 former employees in the last decade, according to records obtained by the Better Government Association.

title: Homeless Seek Help From New Plan 2.0
description: The stories were varied. There was the formerly homeless woman who said she had become ill from shelter food; the social worker who felt that without sufficient resources, she was being set up to fail; the youth who asked for more drop-in services; the mother who lost her job and then her home; and the man who was told he was ineligible for certain services because he was neither an addict nor mentally ill.

title: Gingrich Deflects Questions About a Big Supporters Casino Interests
description: WINTER PARK, Fla.  The possibility of gambling exploding across Florida has worried many on the religious right, and they questioned Newt Gingrich on Saturday about his financial backing by Sheldon Adelson, a casino magnate.

title: Homai Vyarawalla, Pioneering Indian Photojournalist, Dies at 98
description: Homai Vyarawalla, a photojournalist celebrated in India for chronicling the countrys march toward independence and capturing enduring images of world figures like Mohandas K. Gandhi, Ho Chi Minh and American presidents of the mid-20th century, died on Jan. 15 in Vadodara, in west India. She was 98.

title: Required Delay Between Sonogram and Abortion Creates Logistical Issues
description: Moments after Amy Hagstrom Miller heard the news earlier this month that a panel of federal judges had directed Texas to immediately enforce the most controversial tenet of the states new abortion sonogram law her phone started ringing. It was the doctors who perform abortions at the five Whole Womans Health clinics she founded in Texas, confirming that they had to start showing their pregnant patients the image of the fetus and playing the fetal heartbeat.

title: In Their Election Drought, Texas Democrats Find Solace in G.O.P.s Past Struggles
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Its No Beijing, But Hong Kong Is Choking, Too
description: HONG KONG  For the business, political and media glitterati assembled in the rarefied Alpine atmosphere of Davos, air pollution has probably not been terribly high on the agenda.

title: A Former Boy Wonder Takes Charge of His Career
description: Last week, Ben Kweller was on his hands and knees on the front lawn of his South Austin office, helping a delivery driver shrink-wrap a pallet of 1,000 CDs destined for Japan. When they had secured the goods, Mr. Kweller, the 30-year-old singer-songwriter  dressed in a black version of Michael Jacksons Thriller jacket and ripped jeans  popped a leg onto the boxes and threw up a devils sign, posing for a picture he immediately texted to his Tokyo distributor to show that the CDs were on their way.

title: Cain Endorses Gingrich for President
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Herman Cain, who ended his presidential bid in early December, endorsed Newt Gingrich on Saturday night, three days before the crucial Florida primary.

title: A Divide on the Payoff of Legalizing Immigrants
description: Granting legal status to the illegal immigrants living in one of Texas largest metropolitan areas would generate at least $1.4 billion a year in revenue for state and federal agencies, with Social Security and Medicare being the largest potential beneficiaries, according to an analysis by a Houston business group.

title: Scaling Skyscrapers to Leave Their Mark
description: Joo Wainers documentary film Pixo captures taggers who scale skyscrapers to leave their mark.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: January 29
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Consensus of Polls Shows Romney Up in Florida
description: You can find pretty much every species of poll in Florida right now.

title: Eureka Airship
description: Often seen cruising Bay Area skies about 1,000 feet off the ground, the Eureka airship is one of only two of its type in the world, and the only one in the United States that carries commercial passengers. This German-made zeppelin, owned by Airship Ventures, is not a blimp; though both types of airships are filled with helium, only a zeppelin has an internal framework.

title: Old Techies Never Die; They Just Cant Get Hired as an Industry Moves On
description: Silicon Valley may be booming again, but times are still tough for the 200 out-of-work professionals who crowd into Sunnyvales City Hall every Thursday morning.

title: Break Brick, Break Bread, Break the Mold
description: Art and food mixed at a dinner last Thursday at Engine 43, a private residence and social club in San Franciscos Excelsior neighborhood, in the form of bricks served on a bed of hay.

title: N.H.L. and Players Union Look Ahead to New Labor Deal
description: OTTAWA, Ontario  The battle lines over contract negotiations between the N.H.L. and the players union discreetly took shape Saturday, as Commissioner Gary Bettman and the unions executive director, Donald Fehr, met with reporters during All-Star weekend.

title: Brown Releases Records From National Guard
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown released 170 pages of records late Saturday from his three decades of service in the Army National Guard. Mr. Brown, a Republican who is facing a tough re-election race against Elizabeth Warren, wanted to be open and transparent about the records, according to his Senate office, which released them.

title: At End of Knicks Trip, the Wheels Come Off
description: HOUSTON  Down one All-Star, with no reliable playmaker, a bruised and bedraggled lineup and the losses piling up, the Knicks were left Saturday night to a mission best described as hunting and pecking.

title: Bettman Says League Has Advanced Money to the Devils
description: The financially troubled Devils have been advanced money by the N.H.L., Commissioner Gary Bettman said Saturday in Ottawa at a news conference after the leagues board of governors meeting.

title: Santorum Leaves Florida to Tend to Daughters Illness
description: Rick Santorums 3-year-old daughter, Bella, who suffers from a rare and life-threatening genetic disorder, was hospitalized in Philadelphia on Saturday evening, according to a spokesman for Mr. Santorums presidential campaign.

title: Joseph Mattioli, Who Gave Up Dentistry to Build Pocono Raceway, Dies at 86
description: Joseph Mattioli, who gave up his Philadelphia dental practice, bought a spinach farm off Interstate 80 in northeast Pennsylvania in 1960 and transformed it into Pocono Raceway, one of the primary stock-car racetracks in the country, died Thursday in Allentown, Pa. He was 86 and lived at the raceway, in Long Pond, Pa.

title: Williams Rules High Jump in New Meet at the Garden
description: Jesse Williams could not have asked for better timing, really, the way things have been coming together of late.

title: Romney Holds Solid Lead in Latest Florida Polls
description: Updated: The latest polls of likely Republican primary voters in Florida give Mitt Romney front-runner status heading into the final days of campaigning before Tuesdays primary.

title: Lauren Potter and Yoav Roth
description: Lauren Potter and Yoav Roth were married Saturday evening at the W Hotel in Miami Beach. Cantor Rachelle F. Nelson officiated.

title: Hctor Lozada and Norman Simon
description: Hctor Ramn Lozada and Norman Christopher Simon were married Saturday at the Glasshouses, an event space in New York, by State Supreme Court Justice Doris Ling-Cohan.

title: Dawn Bramlette, Eric Hartley
description: Dawn Marie Bramlette and Eric Matthew Hartley were married Saturday on the beach at Four Seasons Resort Hualalai in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. Libby Kelson-Fulcher, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Marisa Warren, Brian Spiro
description: Marisa Ilana Warren and Brian Matthew Spiro were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Levin led the ceremony.

title: Rebecca Jarvis and Matthew Hanson
description: Rebecca Jarvis and Matthew Pierce Hanson were married Saturday evening at the McNamara Alumni Center in Minneapolis. Rabbi Barry Axler officiated, with the bridegrooms father, the Rev. Craig H. Hanson, the lead pastor at Roseville Lutheran Church in Roseville, Minn., taking part.

title: When Tibetan Despair Leads to Self-Immolation
description: HONG KONG  Why do they do it, these Buddhist monks and nuns and other young Tibetans? Why would they drink a cup of kerosene, then douse themselves and strike a match? What is behind these horrifying self-immolations, especially since Buddhism forbids suicide and the Dalai Lama himself has preached against it?

title: An Extraordinary Aurora Borealis
description: Theres not much to say here. Just click and watch. This is the aurora borealis generated by a recent burst in solar storminess and recorded over Tromso, Norway, without any time-lapse acceleration. The imagery was shot by weather-chasing cameraman Alister Chapman.

title: Occupy Protesters and Police Clash in Oakland
description: A march to take over a vacant building by members of the Occupy movement in Oakland, Calif., turned into a violent confrontation with the police on Saturday, leaving three officers injured and about 200 people arrested.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Traversing the Bundelkhand region, traditionally considered the stronghold of Mayawati, chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, the journalist Revati Laul finds that the elephant  the symbol of the Bahujan Samaj Party (B.S.P.)  has lost its draw. In a piece titled Dalit and the dominoes in Tehelka, Ms. Laul analyzes the reasons behind this shift in perception and how it might affect the outcome of the state assembly elections scheduled for February. With devastating drought and farmer suicides growing at an alarming rate in her voter base, disgruntled farmers from the dalit, or untouchable, caste have begun to voice their discontent. Ms. Laul speculates that this might mean that the B.S.P. will not sweep Uttar Pradesh with the sizable majority it achieved in 2007, leading to instability in the state and a possible harbinger to an era of coalition politics.

title: Advantage Romney in February, but Risks Abound
description: Conventional wisdom holds that the handful of states that vote in February are favorable ones for Mitt Romney. Still, Mr. Romney could be vulnerable in several of them.

title: To Prodigy and Retiree (Twice), Hingis Adds Coach
description: MELBOURNE  Show Court 3 was not far from empty on Friday as Yulia Putintseva and Eugenie Bouchard played in the full heat of a Melbourne summer in the semifinals of the Australian Open girls tournament.

title: For Giants Fans, Just Read What Jerry Reese Said
description: Again, we won 10 games last year. It wasnt like we were 6-10. We were 10-6. We expect to build off that. If we made a couple of plays here and there last year, we wouldve made the playoffs and who knows what wouldve happened if that were to happen, but it didnt happen. Well make the plays this time and well get into the playoffs and well make a run.   Jerry Reese, Giants general manager, channeling Joe Namath and Mark Messier, on Aug. 11

title: Sudan Rebels Are Said to Hold Road Crew From China
description: HONG KONG  More than two dozen Chinese road workers have been seized by a Sudanese rebel group, Chinese and Sudanese officials said Sunday, underlining the risks for China in sending ever-greater numbers of its workers into some of the worlds most turbulent countries.

title: Destructive Austerity, USA
description: Jared Bernstein has been emphasizing, rightly, the extent to which our weak recovery is being undermined by cutbacks at the state and local level:

title: Giants-Patriots: Four Years Later
description: While a lot has changed since the Giants met the Patriots in Super Bowl XLVI, much of the game plan remains the same for both teams heading into this years matchup.

title: Australian Open Mens Final
description: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal face off in the seasons first Grand Slam final.

title: Djokovic Tops Nadal in Five Sets to Win in Australia
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated

title: Hotels Create Rooms and Floors Just for Women
description: The Dukes London hotel has created several initiatives catering to women, including 19 new Dutchess Rooms (right) with fresh flowers, womens magazines and size-appropriate slippers and robes and female staff members who are escorts at check-in. As a result, the hotel says, bookings by women have surged 30 percent in the last two months.

title: Gingrich Presses Attack as Polls Show Romney Ahead
description: 2:22 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich pressed ahead on Sunday in a battle of increasingly negative campaigning between himself and Mitt Romney, even as polls showed Mr. Romney surging in Florida with only 48 hours left before primary day.

title: Exxon Mobil to Sell Its Japanese Arm for $3.9 Billion
description: Exxon Mobil said on Sunday that it had agreed to sell its Japanese subsidiary to TonenGeneral Sekiyu, a major refinery operator in Japan, for about $3.9 billion, as part of a revamping of the oil giants operations in that country.

title: Michel Hazanavicius Wins at the Directors Guild
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild of America honored a bespectacled filmmaker for his love of classic Hollywood cinema, and he was a Frenchman: Michel Hazanavicius won the prize for best feature from the organization, whose choices usually dovetail with the Oscars. (Pundits quickly called it: The Artist will win best picture at the Academy Awards.) On Saturday night, Mr. Hazanavicius beat out Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Alexander Payne and David Fincher.

title: On Fourth Down, Coaches Arent Going for It
description: What do Bill Belichick, Tom Coughlin, Sean Payton and Jim Harbaugh have in common? They ranked among the top eight N.F.L. coaches in aggressiveness on going for it on fourth down this season. That shouldnt be a huge surprise. Those four coaches are highly respected and very successful. And if there is one thing all N.F.L. statistical analysts agree on, coaches should go for it on fourth down more often.

title: Disruptions: In Davos, Technology Moves Center Stage
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  When I set out to report at the World Economic Forum, I imagined it might be difficult to find technology-related stories. It turns out, I was a tad wrong. I would have had more luck finding a snowless Alpine mountain in the winter than finding people discussing a topic that did not involve technology.

title: Sundance Honors Beasts of the Southern Wild
description: Quvenzhan Wallis, 8, cemented her status as the It Girl of this years Sundance Film Festival on Saturday night, as Beasts of the Southern Wild, starring Ms. Wallis as a poor Louisiana girl named Hushpuppy, took the festivals top grand jury prize.

title: A Stormy Romance on the Moors, via the Netherlands
description: An elemental wildness runs through Wuthering Heights, Restless Souls, Theater Artemiss spare but impressively theatrical adaptation of Emily Bronts novel. Though intended for young audiences (13 and up), this production never condescends. Quite the opposite: it can be ferocious, even scary, as it gives physical shape to the bond between Cathy and Heathcliff (Alejandra Theus and Joris Smit, both feral, both terrific).

title: Catchy Slogans, Sloppy Ideas
description: TAMPA  Herman Cains endorsement of Newt Gingrich on Saturday night made perfect sense, as each man gravitates to catchy slogans and sloppy ideas. Mr. Cain still dreams of his 9-9-9 tax plan, while Mr. Gingrich fantasizes about a moon base that would probably require a 90-90-90 tax plan.)

title: The Grey, Starring Liam Neeson, Leads at the Box Office
description: Liam Neeson does it again: The Grey, the latest in a line of successful action thrillers featuring that 59-year-old star, was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, with an estimated $20 million in ticket sales. The movie, about a group of oil drillers in Alaska who become hunted by wolves, was made outside the studio system and acquired for $5 million last summer by Open Road Films, an upstart distributor backed by the multiplex operators AMC Entertainment and Regal Cinemas.

title: Gtterdmmerung
description: Photos of the final installment in the Metropolitan Operas new production of Wagners Ring cycle, directed by Robert Lepage.

title: A Pros Tip Sheet: Justin Sayfies Guide to Florida Politics
description: Ah, Florida. The state looms large in Republican politics, not just because its primary on Tuesday will involve the largest, most diverse electorate yet. Republicans in Florida played kingmaker to Senator John McCain when he won its primary in 2008, but Barack Obama ultimately won the general election. The state is home to two of the Republicans biggest heroes: Jeb Bush, a former governor, and Senator Marco Rubio  who, like Gov. Rick Scott, rode into office with Tea Party backing  and one the partys villains: former Gov. Charlie Crist, a moderate Republican who ran for the Senate against Mr. Rubio as an independent.

title: Gingrich Upset Chances Dwindle in New Florida Polls
Plans for a Return of Jekyll & Hyde to Broadway
description: Nederlander Presentations announced on Sunday that it would stage a new production of the four-time Tony Award-nominated musical Jekyll & Hyde. The show features music from the composer Frank Wildhorn, who has struggled with a string of flops, including two short-lived 2011 productions, Bonnie & Clyde and Wonderland. Although Jekyll & Hyde is arguably the most well-known of Mr. Wildhorns works, with an original run on Broadway lasting more than three and a half years, the show failed to turn a profit before it closed in 2001. Constantine Maroulis (Rock of Ages) will play both central characters; the book and lyrics are by Leslie Bricusse. The producers are aiming for a spring 2013 arrival on Broadway after a 25-week national tour scheduled to begin on Oct. 2 in San Diego.

title: Sunnis End Boycott of Iraqi Parliament, but Crisis Remains
description: BAGHDAD  In the first sign that Iraqs leaders may yet halt a sectarian political crisis that has raised fears of civil war, Iraqs Sunni leaders said Sunday that they would end their boycott of Parliament.

title: New Music Opens a New Hall in a Venerable Building
description: It has been a long time coming  about four years of raising money and renovating  but on Wednesday evening the Issue Project Room settled into its new digs in the former Board of Education building at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn. For anyone who spent time in Issue Projects former home, a tiny space at the Old American Can Factory, also in Brooklyn, this is a new world: the room is spacious (5,000 square feet) and rich in retro grandeur, with marble floors, columns and arches, and a high, ornate ceiling.

title: Gingrich Sees Non-Romney Majority of Delegates Forming
description: LUTZ, Fla.  Newt Gingrich predicted on Sunday that Mitt Romney, who is leading him in the polls in Florida by double digits, would fail to win a majority of the votes in Tuesdays primary and would not be able to muster a majority of the delegates by the time of the Republican convention in August.

title: Greek Coalition Is Said to Back More Austerity
description: ATHENS  As European Union leaders prepared for a summit meeting on Monday in Brussels that will seek ways to spur economic growth, Greeces prime minister struck a different tone on Sunday, suggesting that the three leaders in his fractious coalition were prepared to back additional austerity measures and reforms needed to receive a second bailout.

title: An Occu-Party in Brooklyn Leads to 4 Arrests
description: Six officers were injured in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, when the police broke up a party in a vacant residential building thrown by members of the Occupy movement on Saturday night, the police said. Four protesters were arrested, including a 21-year-old woman who was charged with assaulting a police officer.

title: Romney Says Gingrich Is Making Excuses for His Florida Woes
description: NAPLES, Fla.  As Mitt Romneys surrogates tried to draw subtle contrasts between their candidate and Newt Gingrich at an outdoor rally here on Sunday morning, Mr. Romney took the argument straight to Mr. Gingrich. He used the first several minutes of his stump speech to criticize the former speaker of the House, to whom he would like to deliver a major blow in the states primary on Tuesday.

title: Azarenka vs. Sharapova: Breaking It Down
description: Is Victoria Azarenka really that good, or is Maria Sharapova really that bad?

title: A Rescued Organ Gets a New Life in Manhattan
description: This is about an organ transplant, but not the kind they write about in the science section.

title: Surveying a Global Power Shift
description: The 2008 crash and America and Europes continuing economic woes; the rise of China and worries about the decline of the West; and technology-fueled uprisings around the world from the Arab Spring protests to anti-Putin demonstrations in Russia  such developments underscore just how prescient Zbigniew Brzezinski has been in his earlier writings.

title: For G.O.P. Ads, CSI but Not Letterman
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Republican presidential candidates have flooded this state with commercials in all the usual places: local newscasts in the morning, talk shows during the day, Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy! at dinnertime.

title: Hundreds Held in Oakland Occupy Protest
description: About 400 people were arrested and three police officers were injured after a weekend protest by members of the Occupy movement in Oakland, Calif., turned into a violent confrontation with law enforcement officers that led to an assault on City Hall.

title: Boatright Returns but Cant Lift UConn
description: HARTFORD  The freshman guard Ryan Boatright returned to the Connecticut basketball team Sunday after an N.C.A.A. investigation and scored his first points on a floater in the lane to close out the first half. The basket, which put UConn ahead by 3 points, seemed to be a bright omen for the Huskies.

title: Syria Targets Rebels Based in Suburbs of Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Facing a growing threat on the doorstep of its capital city, the Syrian government struck out at its opponents in the rebellious eastern suburbs on Sunday, sending soldiers, tanks and armored vehicles to vanquish pockets of rebel fighters in an escalation of the spreading war.

title: Sydney Leroux and Soccer Without Borders
description: Jer Longman has a profile in the Sunday Times of the United States national team newcomer Sydney Leroux, a striker with worlds of talent and a complicated background. Leroux scored five goals in the Americans 13-0 demolition of Guatemala last week, but she has nonetheless been taunted in Vancouver, her hometown, for her decision to compete internationally for the United States instead of her native Canada.

title: Very Clearly, a Woman You Dont Want to Mess With
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J  Before Miranda Lambert came onstage at the Izod Center here Saturday night, the audience watched a video montage set to Beyoncs Run the World (Girls). It flashed pictures of women that one assumes were selected by Ms. Lambert to serve as her archetypes, and they included Patsy Cline, Lady Gaga and Betty Boop.

title: Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, Ex-President of Italy, Dies at 93
description: ROME  Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, who was the president of Italy during a tumultuous period in the 1990s marked by a widespread corruption scandal that felled an entire political class, died here on Sunday. He was 93.

title: New Contract for Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonics management and musicians have agreed on a new contract, the players union said late Saturday. Union officials said orchestra members had been prepared to strike, jeopardizing a European tour starting Monday, without an agreement this weekend. In a statement the musicians reported reaching a two-year deal  relatively short by industry standards  in which, they said, management had dropped proposals for drastic cuts to health insurance and a radical reduction in pension benefits. The Philharmonic confirmed in a statement on Sunday that the defined-benefit pension plan would remain, and that pension benefits would be capped at $70,000 a year per player. The orchestra also said that both sides agreed to hire a consultant to study the advisability of moving to a defined-contribution pension plan. Tino Gagliardi, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents Philharmonic players, said management backed down from eliminating defined-benefit pensions and replacing them with defined contributions. The Philadelphia Orchestra, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, recently made the change. In light of that, Mr. Gagliardi said, it was really, really important to take a stand. But the matter was essentially put off for two years. Mr. Gagliardi said the pension issue would be studied by both sides and revisited for the next contract. On health insurance, he said, the agreement gives small economic relief to the employer. The pact, he added, calls for no wage increase this year and a 2 percent raise next year.

title: With Homeland, Showtime Makes Gains on HBO
description: Showtime has long been second to HBO among premium cable channels, but on the strength of its critically acclaimed drama Homeland, it has seized a coveted title from its larger rival: the channel with the most discussed, praised and award-festooned cable show of the year.

title: In a New Wheeldon Ballet, Overlapping and Piling on the Riches
description: Christopher Wheeldon and New York City Ballet have a special relationship. Perhaps there were some bruised feelings when, in 2008, he resigned as resident choreographer  a position City Ballet had created for him in 2001  to concentrate on his own company, Morphoses, which he later abandoned. And its true that Mr. Wheeldon maintains strong ties to the Royal Ballet, where he was trained, and that he shares his talents with many other troupes.

title: In John Cages Room, Sounds of Gertrude Stein
description: Some music now considered transporting was simply too revolutionary for its time: Beethovens late works often baffled his peers but inspire us. The music of some 20th-century composers, on the other hand, will probably never move the listener, which was not the goal of an artist like John Cage.

title: Following in Marie Antoinettes Footsteps
description: Pierre-Alexandre Monsignys opera Le Roi et le Fermier (The King and the Farmer), with its exploration of class issues and caricature of aristocrats, might seem an unlikely work for Marie Antoinette and her courtiers to have performed at Versailles in 1780. It was bold material for 18th-century France; the librettist, Michel-Jean Sedaine, had to tweak a scene involving the King and a commoner to appease the censor.

title: Song and Dance With a Story to Tell
description: The best that can be said about an evening spent with the choreographer Camille A. Brown is that she knows how to hold an audience in the palm of her hand. (This is formulaic choreography made for an easy response.) Ms. Browns expertise is the dance skit: solos that tell stories through a measured combination of slow-and-sharp movements and song lyrics.

title: Rival Hot Sauce Makers in a Duel for Attention
description: SOME like it hot, Tony Curtis told Marilyn Monroe in the 1959 movie of the same name, referring to music. Since then, Americans have grown to like something else  food  even hotter, as evidenced by the popularization of spicy fare like Buffalo chicken wings, made with cayenne pepper hot sauce.

title: Erratic Blogging Ahead
description: So whats different, you ask? Well, intermittent too. Nightmare travel week looming.

title: Energized Gingrich Goes After Wall Street and Washington
description: LADY LAKE, Fla.  During an afternoon speech at The Villages, a vast retiree complex here Sunday, Newt Gingrich was suddenly energized as he railed against Wall Street and Washington, lumping them in as the establishment that wants to defeat him.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Footnote
description: The French ballerina Sylvie Guillem, below, will bring her production 6000 miles away to the David H. Koch Theater this spring in a rare New York appearance. She last performed in New York in 2006. This years engagement, a co-production with Sadlers Wells London, on April 4, 5 and 7, is the latest to fill empty nights at the theater, which lost New York City Opera this season because of that companys financial problems. 6000 miles away, a reference to the earthquake and tsunami in Japan last year, is being presented by the Joyce Theater Foundation.

title: Expanding Reach, Cuomo Creates Second Cop on Financial Beat
description: ALBANY  Benjamin M. Lawsky is not the attorney general of New York State.

title: At Knockout Teams, Clues About a Void in Spades
description: At the Orlando Regional at the beginning of January, the team of Reanette Frobouck of Vero Beach, Fla.; Curtis Cheek of Las Vegas; Allan Graves of Barnet, Vt.; and Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla., won more master points than anyone else. They entered four knockout team events, winning two and being runners-up twice.

title: Good Works Overshadow Goth Looks
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Its not subtle: in his forthcoming movie, This Must Be the Place, Sean Penn resembles Robert Smith, the goth frontman of the Cure. The resemblance was intentional; the Italian director Paolo Sorrentino, known for the political biopic Il Divo, idolized the Cure growing up and decided to make his English-language debut about a rich, depressed 80s rocker married to a no-nonsense woman (Frances McDormand) whos a firefighter.

title: Flying the Coop
description: Administrivial Cool Article Alert! Want to think about some of the more common celebrities in crosswords in a totally different way? Matt Gaffney published an article called The Shortz Factor in Slate Magazine recently.

title: A Studios Real-Life Drama
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie fans are fretting over where to peg War Horse and The Help in the Oscar pool.

title: New York City Ballet
description: Photos of the world premiere of Christopher Wheeldons Les Carillons.

title: Arizonas Ethnic-Studies Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Residents Delivering Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Language Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Blood Pressure in Both Arms, Study Says
description: Doctors who make a habit of measuring blood pressure in only one arm may be doing their patients a disservice.

title: Health Costs, Regardless of Your Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: For Mattek-Sands, a Loss Turns Into a Win
description: MELBOURNE  Few players win their first Grand Slam title because they lost on the first day of the tournament, but thats exactly what happened to the Minnesota-born Arizona resident Bethanie Mattek-Sands.

title: ABB to Buy Thomas & Betts for $3.9 Billion
description: 6:52 a.m. | Updated ABB of Switzerland agreed on Monday to buy Thomas & Betts, an American maker of electrical connectors, for about $3.9 billion in cash.

title: Egypts Military Seeks Advice on Early Handing of Power to Civilians
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers have asked a panel of advisers for suggestions about handing over power to civilians earlier than the scheduled deadline at the end of June, state news media reported Sunday.

title: In Florida, Romney and Gingrich Go for New Lows in Pandering on Cuba
description: TAMPA  At a Cuban restaurant in Hialeah today, two days ahead of the Florida primary, Mitt Romney carved up some pork and denounced Fidel Castro, a ritual as old and formalized as politicians putting on plastic yarmulkes and consulting with wizened rabbis in Brooklyn. Well, except maybe for the pork part.

title: With Focus on Income Inequality, Albany Bill Will Seek $8.50 Minimum Wage
description: The Occupy Wall Street encampment at Zuccotti Park is no more, but the focus it brought to income inequality is having an impact in Albany and beyond.

title: Kiwanuka Goes Home, but His Heart Is Far Away
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Mathias Kiwanuka says he does not remember how old he was when he first found out his grandfather had been assassinated. He struggles to remember the point at which he realized the true meaning of his own last name. He is not certain when he became aware of his familys importance in African history.

title: Jonathan Idema, Con Man and Afghan Bounty Hunter, Dies at 55
