description: Jonathan K. Idema, a convicted con man who gained notoriety in post-invasion Afghanistan as a swaggering hunter of terrorists, then ignominy when he was imprisoned for taking Afghans hostage and torturing them, died Jan. 21 at his home in Bacalar, Mexico. He was 55.

title: U.S. Banks Tally Their Exposure to Europes Debt Maelstrom
description: After a hurricane, homeowners check nervously to see if their insurance will cover all of the damage. With the European financial crisis still threatening a trail of defaults, United States banks are betting that their insurance is going to pay out.

title: English Is Global, So Why Learn Arabic?
New Playbook for Post-Career Success
description: In the moments before kickoff in an early-season game between the Tennessee Titans and the Baltimore Ravens, two linebackers engaged in some good-natured trash talking. The banter had nothing to do with who would win; it was about who was further behind on his homework.

title: Mulberry Street May Fade, but Mulberry Street Shines On
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  Ill take you to see Mulberry Street, said Guy McLain, the director of the Museum of Springfield History.

title: Coaching Can Be Older Mans Game, if Wins Keep Coming
description: If the Giants win the N.F.L. championship on Sunday, 65-year-old Tom Coughlin will become the oldest winning coach in Super Bowl history.

title: To Mend Ties After Clash, Kazakhstan Makes an Offer
description: ZHANAOZEN, Kazakhstan  Despite the vast wealth of nearby oil fields, this industrial settlement in the desert of western Kazakhstan is a picture of rural poverty. Sheep meander through the town. The streets, mostly unpaved, are so deeply rutted that cars must slow to a crawl.

title: Imagine His Shock. His Leg Had Vanished.
description: Having played a singing elephant on stages across the country, Cleo Berry is well acquainted with the vagaries of show business. But he still was stunned to learn that he had unwittingly become an amputee in advertisements that New York City is posting to warn of the dangers of diabetes.

title: Bridges Partial Fencing Points to a Bigger Divide
description: The footbridge is, at first glance, unremarkable. It connects two sections of the Ingersoll public housing project in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and its dull red walkway matches the brick apartment houses on either side. Underneath it are the roadway and bike lanes of Navy Street.

title: Private Equity Trade Group to Name Permanent Chief
description: The Private Equity Growth Capital Council plans to formally appoint Steve Judge as its chief executive on Monday, making him the official leader of the private equity industry trade group.

title: A Glimpse of Murdoch Unbound
description: As American business has become more and more media savvy, its leaders have appeared in media less and less. Business reporters have to work their way past background conversations with underlings, written statements that state nothing, and that increasingly hardy perennial: the no comment. The modern chief executive lives behind a wall of communications operatives, many of whom ladle out slop meant to obscure rather than reveal.

title: U.S. Drones Patrolling Its Skies Provoke Outrage in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A month after the last American troops left Iraq, the State Department is operating a small fleet of surveillance drones here to help protect the United States Embassy and consulates, as well as American personnel. Some senior Iraqi officials expressed outrage at the program, saying the unarmed aircraft are an affront to Iraqi sovereignty.

title: Rural Land Grabs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mixtape of the Revolution
description: DEF JAM will probably never sign them, but Cheikh Oumar Cyrille Tour, from a small town about 100 miles southeast of Dakar, Senegal, and Hamada Ben Amor, a 22-year-old man from a port city 170 miles southeast of Tunis, may be two of the most influential rappers in the history of hip-hop.

title: Its Time to Police the N.Y.P.D.
description: THE Police Department has the formidable responsibility of keeping New Yorkers safe from a terrorist attack. It is entrusted with significant powers and broad discretion in how to use them. It has done an admirable job in preventing violence. But last week, we were reminded that no government entity with such powers should operate free from independent oversight.

title: Santorum to Return to Campaigning on Monday, in the Midwest
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.,  Rick Santorum will return to the campaign trail on Monday afternoon, but instead of coming back to Florida before Tuesdays primary, he will head to the Midwest.

title: Not Diseases, but Categories of Suffering
description: Scotland, Conn.

title: For Family of Burned Woman, an Offer, but No Help
description: For the family of a woman burned to death inside an elevator in Brooklyn, the apparent act of generosity could not have come at a better time.

title: Facebook Users to Put Political Views Up in Lights on Times Square
description: As the country prepares for this years presidential election, political devotees have been following the nuances of every debate, caucus, straw poll and primary. A new application for Facebook users, however, is intended to encourage those who are not as engaged to talk about the election issues that are most important to them.

title: Birth Control and Reproductive Rights
description: It was good news that the Obama administration withstood pressure from Roman Catholic bishops and social conservatives to deny contraceptive coverage for millions of American women who work for religiously affiliated employers. Kathleen Sebelius, the Health and Human Services secretary, rejected broad exemptions from a new rule requiring all health plans to cover birth control, without a deductible or co-payment.

title: Back With Patriots, Branch Returns to Familiar Stage
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  As Deion Branch prepares to play in his third Super Bowl, he has a very specific to-do list that has nothing to do with the Giants.

title: Online Ambitions, and a Dash of Real Estate, Drive Newspaper Deals
description: IF the future of media is digital, who would want to buy a newspaper? Many people, it turns out.

title: BlackBerry Under Siege in Europe
description: The iPhone has taken a big bite out of the BlackBerry in a market where the older phone once dominated: business customers in North America.

title: After Florida, a New Tenor for the G.O.P. Campaign
description: As polls showedMitt Romney pulling far ahead ofNewt Gingrich in Florida, both campaigns have begun looking ahead to a period of campaigning that is likely to look and feel very different.

title: Justice Department Official to Join Davis Polk Law Firm
description: Greg D. Andres, a senior Justice Department official, is leaving the government to join the law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, according to two people with direct knowledge of his move.

title: A Reform for Fair Courts
description: With rising special-interest spending in state judicial elections, there is an urgent need to protect judicial integrity from the flood of campaign cash. Tennessee is leading the way with a new rule prohibiting judges from hearing cases when campaign spending by lawyers or litigants raises a reasonable question of their impartiality.

title: Djokovic Prevails in Australia
description: Novak Djokovic won the Australian Open title by outlasting Rafael Nadal, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, 6-7 (5), 7-5.

title: Moving Ahead on Marriage Equality
description: Gov. Chris Christies announcement last week that he would veto a measure to legalize same-sex marriage in New Jersey is maddening, but sadly predictable. He vowed to block marriage equality when he ran for office in 2009 and is now calling for a statewide referendum.

title: Trampolines New Frontier
description: Professional trampolinist Julien Roberge is hoping to make the wall trampoline an extreme sport.

title: New Strategy, Old Pentagon Budget
description: The $259 billion in budget cuts over the next five years announced by the Pentagon may sound like a lot. But they are mainly a scaling back of previously projected spending  the delights of the Washington budget games.

title: The Austerity Debacle
description: Last week the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, a British think tank, released a startling chart comparing the current slump with past recessions and recoveries. It turns out that by one important measure  changes in real G.D.P. since the recession began  Britain is doing worse this time than it did during the Great Depression. Four years into the Depression, British G.D.P. had regained its previous peak; four years after the Great Recession began, Britain is nowhere close to regaining its lost ground.

title: Defying Gravity With Creativity
description: QUEBEC  One by one, five athletes hurl themselves off a wall beneath the sweeping arches of what once was the St.-Esprit church. Sixteen feet below, they land on a trampoline, snap back toward the wall and send themselves outward again.

title: A Tearful Response to a Final-Hole Collapse
description: SAN DIEGO  After building a five-stroke lead through 54 holes of the Farmers Insurance Open, Kyle Stanley described himself as kind of an internal guy. And it was true. For 71 holes, Stanley betrayed no emotion, his body language a study in stoicism.

title: Search for Aliens Is on Again, but Next Quest Is Finding Money
description: HAT CREEK, Calif.  E.T. might be phoning, but do we care enough to take the call?

title: For Young Wizards, a Difficult Season and a Shaky Future
description: WASHINGTON  On Jan. 10, when the Washington Wizards won their first game of this truncated N.B.A. season after eight losses, the talk in the locker room was of relief, but also of candy and coins.

title: Insider Jury May Hear From a Top Aide at Berkshire
description: Ajit Jain, a top lieutenant at Berkshire Hathaway, is on the short list of candidates to succeed Warren E. Buffett, Berkshires chief executive.

title: Flourishing Without Packers as a Shadow
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The connection between the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay and the iconic N.F.L. franchise it shares a city with goes back to the 1960s. As the story goes, Vince Lombardi, the legendary Packers coach, advised the universitys first chancellor, Edward W. Weidner, to make mens soccer the signature athletic program rather than football, in part to avoid competing with the Packers for community attention.

title: Afghan Family, Led by Father Who Called Girls a Disgrace, Is Guilty of Murder
description: OTTAWA  It began with a puzzling and grisly discovery in 2009: a car submerged in a 19th-century canal lock with the bodies of three teenage girls and a middle-aged woman inside. On Sunday, the father, the mother and a brother of the girls were each convicted of four counts of first-degree murder.

title: Romney and Gingrich Scrap Amid Shifting Fortunes
description: HIALEAH, Fla.  His fortunes turned upside down in the span of a week, Newt Gingrich sought on Sunday to rally his grass-roots coalition against the heavy campaign machinery of Mitt Romney, whose resurgence was punctuated by new polls showing his lead in Florida widening two days ahead of the Republican presidential primary here.

title: Young Golfers Emerge as Woods Fades From View
description: SAN DIEGO

title: Food Network Executive to Run YouTube Channel
description: Bruce Seidel, who oversaw shows for the Food Network and the Cooking Channel on cable, is moving online to a forthcoming food channel for YouTube.

title: In Later Years, Rediscovering Love but Finding the Rent Too Much to Pay
description: Norma Zevallos does not speak much English, having lived in the United States for only eight months. But she knows the words to one of her favorite American songs, a classic by the Platters that she likes to sing for her husband.

title: Fishing Rules, a Different Sort of Nun and Other New York Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Florida Bush Stays Silent, and to Many, That Says a Lot
description: MIAMI  A steady stream of endorsements has been flowing to Mitt Romney, with his campaign promoting Republicans who are giving their blessing to his presidential candidacy. Yet on the eve of the Florida primary, he has been unable to land the biggest catch of all: Jeb Bush.

title: Playing Against Type, Belichick Is in Jovial Mood as Team Arrives
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When Bill Belichick coached the Giants defense in the 1980s, he spoke in such a monotone that the players branded him Captain Sominex. Even now, at his fifth Super Bowl as the coach of the New England Patriots, when Belichick arrives in a room, he is not expected to bring levity with him.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/30/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/30/2012

title: For ProPublica, More E-Books
description: ProPublica, the nonprofit news organization known for its investigative journalism, is about to expand its e-book efforts.

title: Lottery Numbers
Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for December (Monday); the S.& P./Case-Shiller home price index for November, the Chicago purchasing managers index for January, and consumer confidence for January (Tuesday); ADP employment for January, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for January and construction spending for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and productivity for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and unemployment for January, the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for January and factory orders for December (Friday).

title: Iraqs Sunni Leaders End Their Boycott
description: In a development in Iraqs political crisis, the countrys Sunni leaders said on Sunday that they would end their boycott of Parliament. In an article in Mondays Times, Tim Arango reports on the decision by members of the Iraqiya coalition, a largely Sunni-backed group of lawmakers.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Critics of SoHo Proposal Ask, You Call This Improvement?
description: Living in SoHo for decades has taught Sean Sweeney how to urge people to hurry up in several languages, though not without his blood pressure shooting up.

title: Hamas Leader Takes Rare Trip to Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Khaled Meshal, the leader of Hamas, made a rare and pointedly low-key visit to Jordan on Sunday, days after Hamas officials signaled that he had effectively abandoned the groups base in Damascus, the Syrian capital.

title: Gaborik Touches Off a Typical Goalfest
description: OTTAWA  The N.H.L.s two biggest stars were missing from the All-Star Game, but that did not seem to matter. The event was its usual just-for-laughs exhibition, the climax of a happy weekend for a league that continues to prosper but may be only months from a labor impasse.

title: Bound for London, U.S. Keeps Foot on Gas
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Pia Sundhage, the coach of the United States womens soccer team, wanted an honest answer.

title: Sarkozy Unveils Tax Raises but Not a Re-election Bid
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy, insisting that he was acting as a head of state  not a presidential candidate  announced Sunday that he would raise consumer taxes to make French companies more competitive and reduce the national budget deficit.

title: Floridas Diverse Electorate and Economic Climate
description: A look at Floridas electorate and electoral climate ahead of Tuesdays Republican primary.

title: The Caucus | Voters on the I-4 Corridor
description: Susan Saulny talks to voters along Interstate 4 - which runs through the center of Florida and is a crucial swing region - ahead of the state's primary on Tuesday.

title: Sour Mood for Voters in Florida
description: A journey along Interstate 4, through central Florida, reveals despair about the economy.

title: Years of Despair Add to Uncertainty in Florida Race
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Only four years ago, life certainly seemed on the upswing for Kate and Marcus Freeman, young professionals who had recently moved from Worcester, Mass., into a new house here in sun-splashed central Florida, where they hoped to enjoy the warmer weather and new jobs. He was an accountant. She would be teaching preschool.

title: The Help Tops the S.A.G. Awards
description: The Help led the Screen Actors Guild awards on Sunday night, taking home three honors: best cast performance (the S.A.G. equivalent of best picture), best actress for Viola Davis and best supporting actress for Octavia Spencer. Among the men, Jean Dujardin of The Artist was named best actor, and Christopher Plummer from Beginners, best supporting actor.

title: Brees Is No Flutie, Blowing  Drop Kick in Pro Bowl
description: There isnt much to say about the Pro Bowl, as usual, but at least we have this:

title: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges
description: Bridgette Dunlap, a Fordham University law student, knew that the schools health plan had to pay for birth control pills, in keeping with New York state law. What she did not find out until she was in an examining room, in the paper dress, was that the student health service  in keeping with Roman Catholic tenets  would simply refuse to prescribe them.

title: Corrections: January 30
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Excerpts From a Report on Womens Health
description: When the Obama administration wanted a list of preventive services that women needed to stay healthy and that should be insured with no co-pay, it commissioned a report by the Institute of Medicine, an independent group of doctors and researchers. Increased access to contraception made the list. The institutes report found the following:

title: Proposal to Cut Some Felonies From Records
description: The New York State Bar Association is proposing a change to state law that would allow more types of criminal records to be sealed, saying the shift would give offenders who stay out of trouble a better chance to rebuild their lives.

title: Newt Gingrich and the Future of the Right
description: In 1999, shortly after the Senate voted to acquit President Clinton on two charges of impeachment stemming from his affair with the intern Monica Lewinsky, Paul Weyrich  mastermind of the union of the Republican Party and the Christian right, a founder of the Heritage Foundation, the Moral Majority and the Free Congress Foundation  threw up his hands in despair.

title: Brett Kimmel: Create a 'To-Die-For' Place
One-Room School Also One-Student School
description: GREENOUGH, Mont.  At a time when many schools are concerned about overcrowded classrooms, the Sunset school in this ranching community has a different problem  keeping its lone student at her desk so it can remain open.

title: Rangers Gaborik Is M.V.P. of All-Star Game
description: OTTAWA  The Rangers just keep rolling, through win after win in the first half of the regular season and victory in the Winter Classic, to first place in the Eastern Conference.

title: State Departments Drones in Iraq Stir Outrage
description: With American troops gone, the State Department is using unarmed aerial drones in Iraq to help protect the United States Embassy, consulates and personnel, and senior Iraqi officials are calling the program an affront to the countrys sovereignty. In an article in Mondays Times, Eric Schmitt and Michael S. Schmidt report on the program and a possible expansion of drone operations by the American government into its diplomatic arm.

title: In a Gang-Ridden City, New Efforts to Fight Crime While Cutting Costs
description: SALINAS, Calif.  People in California generally know two things about this agricultural city nestled among lettuce fields east of Montereys beaches and hotels: John Steinbeck was born here, and it has a big problem with gangs.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 29
description: A look at the day in sports, from the United States Figure Skating Championships to the N.H.L. All-Star Game.

title: Word of the Day | nirvana
description: nirvana \nir-v-n, ()nr-\ noun

title: Drive Time in Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  There might have been a deep sense of foreboding  along with renewed hopes and trills of excitement  as Aung San Suu Kyi traveled from her home in Yangon to the rural southern coast of Myanmar this past weekend.

title: Good Wife Watch: Moments Savored, Loose Ends Tied Up
description: Sunday nights chapter of The Good Wife, titled Another Ham Sandwich, was like a highlight reel  an agglomeration of the sort of too-good-to-be-true moments that are usually rationed, two or three to an episode. Alicia saying to Will, as the grand jury considered indicting him, So use me. The ever smug David Lee telling Will: Thats how a pro does it. Youre welcome. The final, reassuring reveal that Kalinda was working a long con on the prosecutors rather than selling out Will, followed by Dana slapping an impassive Kalinda in the courthouse. A classic David Lee-Eli Gold confrontation. Peter finally snapping and admitting to Alicia that this entire plot line was driven by his anger over her affair.

title: Riddles In The Dark: Is a Temples Treasure Worth Billions?
description: A committee appointed by the Supreme Court of India will return to the vaults of the Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram on the southern tip of India in the second week of February. Their task: try to put a value on what is believed to be the largest temple treasure in the world.

title: Punjab, Bread Basket of India, Hungers for Change
description: Punjab State goes to polls Monday to elect representatives to its legislature. Once considered the pioneer of green revolution in India, the state is now struggling with slow industrial growth, Reuters reports.

title: Homai Vyarawalla, Pioneering Indian Photojournalist, Dies at 98
description: Homai Vyarawalla, Indias first female photojournalist who chronicled the countrys march toward independence and captured enduring images of leaders like Mohandas K. Gandhi, Ho Chi Minh and various American presidents of the mid-20th century, died on Jan. 15 in Vadodara, in west India, Haresh Pandya wrote in an obituary for The New York Times.

title: A Conversation With: Akhtarul Wasey
description: Following the controversy over author Salman Rushdies appearance at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which ultimately ended with even a video conference with Mr. Rushdie being cancelled, India Ink is speaking with Muslim leaders about the situation, their feelings about his book The Satanic Verses and what role politics played in the affair.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 30, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: 12 Arrested at Manhattan March for Oakland Protesters
description: Twelve protesters were arrested Sunday night on a march through Lower Manhattan to show support for Occupy protesters in Oakland, where a violent confrontation erupted on Saturday night between the police and demonstrators who tried to take over an empty convention center.

title: China Denies Sudan Freed Workers Held by Rebels
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  The Sudanese military said Monday that it had rescued 14 of the 29 Chinese road workers kidnapped by rebels in southern Sudan, but China denied early Tuesday that any workers had been freed.

title: Jan. 30, 1948 | Mahatma Gandhi Assassinated
description: On Jan. 30, 1948, Indian political and spiritual leader Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi was murdered by the Hindu nationalist Nathuram Godse, who fired three shots at close range as the 78-year-old Gandhi entered a prayer meeting.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 30, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Joe Paterno, Longtime Penn State Coach, Dies at 85.

title: A Rock Star Emissary From the World of Teenagers
description: WHO is Danah Boyd?WHO are the subjects of her research?

title: Odd Shadows in a Sunny Land
description: Before Art Basel, Miami Beach and Miami Vice, there was another South Florida.

title: Bedsheet Revolution
description: VALPARASO, Chile On a Valparaso street choked solid with traffic not long ago, I looked up as Chilean students on a balcony unfurled a bedsheet banner. Please pardon the bother, it read, but were having a revolution.

title: Angry Over Austerity Measures, Belgian Workers Go on Strike
description: BRUSSELS  Belgium was paralyzed by a national strike Monday as unions, angry over austerity measures, timed the protest to coincide with a one-day meeting of European Union leaders here in the capital.

title: Fables and Fantasy Infuse 40th Hong Kong Arts Festival
description: Fables, fantasy and spirituality inspire many of the performances in the 40th annual Hong Kong Arts Festival, which runs through March 8. This years festival features over 160 productions, staged at 17 venues.

title: Fear and Trembling on the Post-Application Roller Coaster
description: A couple of weeks ago, I started teaching Saturday morning tot ice skating classes at an arena near my house. These children scramble through the door and pile onto the ice. Some are barely 3 years old. Some cant stand up in skates without being hoisted under the armpits. These are the students our program director calls Very-Beginners.

title: Traffic Jam Economics
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: The Early Word: Meaningful Silence
description: Todays Times:

title: How Should You Handle the End of a Friendship?
description: Sometimes, good friends simply grow apart. Interests change, social circles shift, a family moves awaythese are just a few reasons a friendship might fail apart. What is the best way to handle a friendships end? What have you learned from your experiences or from witnessing other friends grow apart?

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Chief Waives Bonus
description: LONDON  The chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland, which was effectively nationalized during the financial crisis, has decided to turn down his bonus after coming under heavy pressure from British politicians.

title: Iran Offers to Extend Inspection by U.N. Team
description: LONDON  Irans foreign minister offered on Monday to extend a three-day visit to his country by United Nations inspectors in what seemed to be a further attempt to lower the strident tone of a crisis with the West over Tehrans nuclear program after the imposition of new economic sanctions.

title: Q. & A.: Mobile Phones on the New York City Subway
description: Q.

title: Super Bowl Arrival: Bill Belichick Transcript
description: I never had too much hospitality here until I went for it on fourth and 2, and since then, Ive been greeted in a lot more friendly manner than I have in the past.  Bill Belichick, Patriots coach, after being asked about Indianas hospitality

title: In Australia, Djokovic Was Unbeatable, but Not Untouchable
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The leading men played overtime in Rod Laver Arena in the homestretch of the Australian Open this year, and they often exchanged pleasantries with Laver.

title: Gary Marcus, Cognitive Psychologist, Answers Readers Questions
description: At 13, an age when most boys want to learn the guitar, Gary Marcus, decided he wanted to be a scientist. Twenty-five years later he had become one of the countrys best known cognitive psychologists, with major papers and three general-interest books on the workings of the human mind and a position running New York Universitys Center for Language and Music. And he wanted to play the guitar. He said he had no rhythm, but spent his sabbatical finding a way to learn to play the guitar and wrote a book about his effort, discussed in this New York Times article last week. Dr. Marcus agreed to answer readers questions about the fears and challenges of learning new skills as an adult. Here are his responses.

title: This Week in Small Business: A Twitter Lesson
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Starbucks Comes to India
description: Starbucks Coffee, the worlds largest coffee company, became the first foreign retailer to enter India Monday, after the government loosened rules about how single brand companies can invest here.

title: Former UBS Trader Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
description: 4:26 p.m. | Updated

title: A Plea for Southern Treasures
description: The Southern Environmental Law Center, a Virginia-based nonprofit legal advocacy group, has released its 2012 list of the Top 10 endangered places in the Southeast, environmentally speaking. While the list changes from year to year, certain places like the Chesapeake Bay remain a top concern  and issues like pollution from coal-fired power plants and the protection of public lands and old-growth forests are recurring themes. While the list only considers six states, the issues raised by each site resonate nationally, and even globally.

title: British Regulator Appoints Senior Investment Banking Adviser
description: LONDON  The Financial Services Authority, Britains financial regulator, said on Monday that Will Samuel had been appointed a senior adviser in its investment banking supervisory unit.

title: Bain Capital Ventures Raises $600 Million Fund
description: For the largest venture capital firms, there is no shortage of capital.

title: Opinion Report: Pentagon Budget Cuts
description: From the editorial page

title: Pro Bowl Is Missing a Skills Competition
description: The N.F.L. has been called the No Fun League by some because of its strict rules on touchdown celebrations.

title: Pairings: Party Picadillo
description: With some Douros as cheap as a pizza, and just as bold, Id think of them as party wines, to serve to a crowd fortified with big sandwiches, wings and meaty casseroles. Even at the high end, most are not wines to contemplate but to quaff with slabs of seared red meat.

title: One Sip Says Portugal
description: THE Douro Valley region of Portugal has so much going in its favor, its almost ridiculous.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: 5 U.S. Banks Tally Exposure to Europes Debt Maelstrom | Five large American banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have more than $80 billion of exposure to Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Greece, the most economically stressed nations in the euro currency zone, according to a New York Times analysis of the banks financial disclosures.

title: Bank Organization to Buy Stake in Russian Stock Market
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire a stake in a Russian stock exchange as part of an effort to encourage transparent capital markets in the country.

title: Remembering Gandhi on Martyrs Day
description: Carved stone footprints dot the path that Mahatma Gandhi took toward a prayer meeting in New Delhi 64 years ago, ending where his frail body was torn by an assassins bullets.

title: Portugal Suffers as Loss of Confidence in Bonds Sends Yields Higher
description: Investors fled out of bonds of weaker European countries on Monday, sending yields on Portuguese government bonds to a record high over concerns that the euro zone debt troubles were spreading beyond Greece.

title: China Says It Curbed Spill of Toxic Metal in River
description: BEIJING  Officials in southern China appear to have averted environmental calamity by halting the spread of a toxic metal that had threatened to foul drinking water for tens of millions of people, the state media reported Monday.

title: Sundance Documentaries Transform Data Into Stories
description: Over the weekend, The House I Live In, Eugene Jareckis heart-heavy investigation into the American war on drugs, nabbed the grand jury prize for documentary at the Sundance Film Festival. Mr. Jareckis other movies include The Trials of Henry Kissinger, about you know who, and a 2005 grand jury prize winner, Why We Fight, about the American military industrial complex. Notably, one of this years jury members was Charles Ferguson, whose documentaries include No End in Sight and Inside Job, and who, like Mr. Jarecki, has a methodological gift for transforming boatloads of information into both political arguments and eminently watchable narratives.

title: Bocuse dOr USA Winner Is a Veteran Competitor
description: Richard Rosendale, executive chef of the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., won the gold medal at the Bocuse dOr USA  competition on Sunday at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. He and his commis, Corey Siegel, a 21-year-old senior apprentice at the Greenbrier, will compete at the international Bocuse dOr in France, next Jan. 29 and 30.

title: Monday Reading: Winter Getaways for Every Age
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Bank of America Taps Meissner as Head of Investment Banking
description: The management shuffle at Bank of America continues.

title: The Florida Primary
description: Republican candidates campaigned hard in Florida, but Mitt Romney won a decisive victory.

title: Private School Tuition in New York City 'Higher Than Harvard's'
Pep Boys to Be Sold in $791 Million Buyout
description: Pep Boys is prepped for a tuneup.

title: On a Day Full of Go Daddy Girls, There Will Be Beckham in His Underwear
description: When word got out that the soccer star David Beckham would appear in a Super Bowl commercial for the H&M retail chain, selling a new line of underwear named after him, the speculation began: just how revealing would the spot be, given that it is to appear on a broadcast network (NBC) in prime time?

title: Here Come the Cloud Cartels
description: What kind of cartels will deliver business computing, and how should businesses respond?

title: U.S. Embassy in Cairo Shields 3 Americans
description: CAIRO  The United States Embassy in Cairo is giving shelter to three American citizens to protect them from potential arrest by the Egyptian authorities in a politically charged investigation of four American-backed nongovernmental organizations operating here, colleagues said Monday.

title: Morning T | Pierre Hardy
description: In this installment, Ts Online Editor Jane Herman talks to the designer about his work for Herms, his store in New York and how he can love two very different pairs of shoes at the same time.

title: Technology Companies Confront a Scourge of the Internet
description: For all the engineer-poaching and trash-talking going around Silicon Valley these days, there has also been a surprising amount of behind-the-scenes collaboration.

title: Rolling Protest on the Garden Ring
description: MOSCOW  A carwash is about the last place I would expect to find myself on a very, very cold Sunday morning, but there I was last weekend.

title: Morning T | Pierre Hardy
description: The designer sits down with T Magazines Jane Herman to discuss his work for Herms, his store in New York and how he can love two very different pairs of shoes at the same time.

title: Daily Report: Businesses Look for a BlackBerry Substitute
description: The BlackBerry from Research in Motion was once the first choice, often the only choice, for companies choosing a phone for their employees.

title: Sundance, Sean Penn and Oscar Indicators
description: It was a busy weekend for awards-watchers. In case you stepped away from the big or small screen, here are a few highlights you may have missed:

title: In Million-Dollar Theft Case, Church Worker With a Secret Past
description: For eight years, the woman worked in accounts payable for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, gaining the trust of her superiors.

title: Were Not So Bad. Really.
description: Over the last few days City Hall has noted that more people came to New York in 2011 than it had previously thought. The mayor made the point again on Sunday in his weekly radio talk. It seems that 50.5 million masochists from foreign countries and other parts of the United States journeyed to our city last year and spent $32 billion.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: Eric Ripert discusses his favorite airport food in New York and around the world. He doesnt mention World Bean coffee in the Delta terminal at La Guardia, one of the best pour-overs in the city. Are they still there?  Nick Fox

title: Welcome
description: Whenever I bump into my friend Felix Salmon, the ridiculously prolific business blogger at Reuters, he starts pestering me about getting back to blogging again. I point out to him that blogging is what he gets paid for, whereas for someone like me, blogging is something Im supposed to be doing in between the things I get paid for, like writing Op-Ed columns as well as articles for the Times Magazine.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Reading Ruperts Tweets, and B.&N. Wears a White Hat
description: At 80, Rupert Murdoch has jumped into Twitter with both feet, among a rare number of moguls who share their thoughts as soon as they pop up. David Carr assesses his corpus of writing  107 Tweets and counting. They are devoid of nuance, partisan in the extreme and prone to crankiness, he writes; in other words, vintage Rupert Murdoch.

title: Commerzbank Chief Defends Not Paying Past Bonuses
description: LONDON  Martin Blessing, the chief executive of Commerzbank, said on Monday that he thought he had acted honorably when the bank decided not to pay 2008 bonuses to 104 investment bankers.

title: Grand Old Stage at Ryman Auditorium Is Being Replaced
description: Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, home of the scuffed oak stage most associated with the Grand Ole Opry, is getting an overhaul, The Associated Press reported.

title: In Final Florida Push, Romney Takes Aim at Gingrich
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Mitt Romney may have set a new personal record here Monday morning.

title: Europe Zeroes In on Shipping Emissions
description: New rules to limit pollution from ships are set to start moving through the European Parliament on Tuesday, with the specter of potential environmental contamination from a stricken cruise ship lending momentum to the debate.

title: On Eve of Florida Primary, Romney and Gingrich Travel State in Appeal to Voters
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With just one day to go before Floridas primary, Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich hopscotched around the state by bus and chartered jet on Monday, mostly along the vote-rich Interstate 4 corridor, as they sought to appear on as many television screens in major media markets as possible, hoping to give voters a last glimpse of their images and messages.

title: Talbots Reconsiders Sycamores Lifeline
description: Talbots may find a home with Sycamore Partners after all.

title: Polls Give Romney Commanding Lead
description: TAMPA, Fla.  What a difference a week makes, in a primary state like none before it.

title: Victory, Elusive in Nascar, Finds A.J. Allmendinger in Rolex 24 at Daytona
description: Having signed recently with Roger Penske Racing for the 2012 Nascar Sprint Cup season, A.J. Allmendinger might have been expected to pass the weeks before the Daytona 500, on Feb. 26, by visualizing races, holding conference calls with his pit crew and familiarizing himself with his new racecar. Instead, hes busy winning races in anything but a stock car.

title: The Rise of the Toilet Texter
description: We know where some of you are reading this.

title: Summertime, Rendered 25,000 Ways
description: Two Sunday Reviews ago, I wrote about the long history of Porgy and Bess as a prism through which African-Americans have viewed their own history. I am a relatively recent devotee of what I like to think of as the real Porgy and Bess, the full-length opera. (So far as I can tell, there is only one performance of the opera ever recorded on DVD  a 1993 Trevor Nunn production with Simon Rattle conducting, released in 2001.) Like most people, I came to Porgy and Bess through some of the many popular recordings of its famous songs. Indeed, I received several e-mails questioning my sanity for writing about the opera without mentioning two of the most famous recordings: the Ella Fitzgerald-Louis Armstrong version, and the equally sublime Miles Davis recording.

title: In Indianapolis, the Cute Wont Quit
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In a great article examining how this city landed (and then prepared to host) Super Bowl XLVI, my colleague John Branch described how local eighth-graders were involved in delivering bids to the N.F.L. owners. It was innovative, thoughtful and downright cute, and surely enhanced the citys proposal.

title: Really? The Claim: Never Go to Bed Angry
description: THE FACTS

title: Study Finds 50-Year Burst of Tropical Eruptions Spawned Enduring Little Ice Age
description: A remarkable paper coming in the Jan. 31 issue of Geophysical Research Letters has a title that says it all: Abrupt onset of the Little Ice Age triggered by volcanism and sustained by sea-ice/ocean feedbacks.

title: At Sundance, Kickstarter Resembled a Movie Studio, but Without the Egos
description: One night last week there was a late-night party at Sundance  one of many  this one hosted by an outfit that had helped finance 10 percent of the festivals slate, 17 movies in all, including four that were in competition.

title: Off-Duty Detective Fatally Shoots Robber, Police Say
description: Updated, 3:00 p.m. | An off-duty police detective fatally shot a teenager who tried to rob him Sunday night in Bushwick, Brooklyn, according to the police, who offered the following account:

title: Fewer Beds for Men Entering Nursing Homes
description: Searching for a nursing home for his hospitalized father in semirural Massachusetts, a friend of mine recently came up against an unexpected barrier. Its harder to find a bed for a man than for a woman.

title: Mother, Accused of Abandoning Children, Is Arrested
description: A woman who abandoned her 3-year-old and 5-year-old daughters in front of a Brooklyn housing project on Sunday afternoon has been arrested, the police said.

title: The Get | Dolce & Gabbana Bag
description: Often the attention to details makes all the difference, says the Dolce & Gabbana co-designer Stefano Gabbana, referring to the design of his and Domenico Dolces newest spring bag, which hits stores this week. Structured and clean, with a handle made for elbow-hooking and a padlock made of gold metal (speaking of details), the style comes in three sizes and is available in a variety of materials, from aluminum foil to straw and python, and in a range of gorgeous colors (pastels, primaries) and finishes (metallic and matte). For the minimalist, the classic leather style suits best. For the quirky carrier, a metallic picnic purse version is perfect. And, for the vintage-inspired, a dainty woven version like this one in dusty rose does the trick. Pick your poison.

title: Russia Says Syria Has Agreed to Talks
description: MOSCOWRussia announced on Monday that it had convinced Bashar al-Assads government in Syria to start informal negotiations in Moscow with representatives of the opposition in an effort to end a bloody uprising that has left thousands dead.

title: An Update on Sahar Gul
description: Some readers might remember the last time I visited Sahar Gul, when I managed to get past the bureaucracy of the hospital in Kabul where she was being treated and her relatives, doctors and supporters welcomed me to her bedside.

title: A Certified Grand Slam Classic
description: Normally, the weekend before the Super Bowl is a quiet one, the landscape cleared of meaningful football  the Pro Bowl not counting as meaningful or football  aided by the N.H.L. taking its season siesta at the same time for its All-Star game, but the Australian Open had other plans this year. Usually, its the Grand Slam that few in this hemisphere realizes is going on because A) its played in the American Insomniac Time Zone and B) doesnt tennis have an offseason and isnt it now? (Answer: it lasted three minutes and no).

title: Street Style: Houndstooth
description: The best of readers street style for the week of Jan. 23.

title: In a Departure, USA Network Plans a Washington Political Drama
description: This summer the cable network known for its sunny, feel-good shows is heading to a town famous for its shortage of good feelings: USA Network will take on Washington.

title: Honda Releases Super Bowl Ad for CR-V, Ferris Bueller Included
description: A 10-second teaser video for a Honda Super Bowl ad featuring Matthew Broderick, in a reprise of his fondly remembered title-character turn in 1986s Ferris Buellers Day Off, appeared on Jan. 26 and amassed more than 4 million views on YouTube by Monday.

title: Musical About Charlie Chaplin Heading to Broadway
description: A musical about the silent screen star Charlie Chaplin might seem like an oxymoron. But such a show is nevertheless Broadway bound, courtesy, in part, of the producers behind this seasons coming Broadway production of Jesus Christ Superstar  Bob and Mindy Rich and John and Claire Caudwell  along with the producer Roy Gabay.

title: Accepted at Vassar, for About Three Hours
description: For those of you who missed Matt Flegenheimers piece in The Times on Sunday about 122 early-decision applicants to Vassar College who viewed an errant test letter that led them to believe they had been accepted,  Mr. Flegenheimer details the heartbreak that ensued:

title: If Ritalin Has Gone Wrong, Whats the Right Way to Cope?
description: Perhaps the most easily drawn conclusion about L. Alan Sroufe, who wrote Ritalin Gone Wrong for the Jan. 29 Week in Review, is that he does not have a child who suffers from what he calls problems in focusing  or what most call attention deficit hyperactivity disorder  and who has benefited from Ritalin or one of the many other drug therapies available.

title: A Texan in Maine
description: Rep. Ron Paul of Texas has largely passed on the sunny campaigning in Florida in favor of spending time in Maine, which holds its Republican presidential caucus on Feb. 4.

title: Fighting Escalates in Syria as Opposition Rejects Russian Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS  As Syrian forces pushed rebels back from strongholds near Damascus on Monday, some of the worlds top diplomats converged on the United Nations to try to press President Bashar al-Assad to leave office through a Security Council resolution.

title: After a Year of Delays, the First Starbucks Is to Open in Tea-Loving India This Fall
description: MUMBAI, India  After years of studying the Indian market, Starbucks Coffee said Monday that it would open its first store here by September through a 50-50 joint venture with Tata Global Beverages, a unit of the largest business group in India.

title: Romney on the Campaign Trail in Florida
description: After the unexpected loss to Newt Gingrich in South Carolina, Mitt Romney and his team shifted focus to a state where he is gaining ground in the polls.

title: A Fresh Take on the World Food Problem
description: The global food crisis has dragged on so long now that is beginning to seem less like a crisis and more like a permanent state of affairs. Prices did take a dip late last year, owing to bumper harvests. But reserves remain tight, and the Food and Agriculture Organization reports that prices are still at some of the highest levels seen in decades.

title: Guns N Roses Plans Minitour, With Three Shows in New York
description: Guns N Roses will play three concerts at relatively small clubs in New York City in February as part of the run-up to its induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in April, a publicist announced on Monday morning.

title: Merger of Actors Unions Keeps Up the Momentum
description: LOS ANGELES  A planned merger between the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, which has been clearing hurdles of one sort or another for many months, cleared another on Saturday when the Aftra board gave its approval. The SAG board had already done so.

title: What the S.A.G. Awards May Portend for the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  Now its actually a race; now its actually going to be fun, one Oscar-watcher whispered after the Screen Actors Guild awards on Sunday, which scrambled predictions by picking The Help as the best movie of the year. The actors guild also chose the star of The Artist, Jean Dujardin, over the leading hopeful George Clooney (and others) for best actor, and Viola Davis of The Help for best actress. Octavia Spencer and Christopher Plummer continued their lockstep toward Oscar in the supporting categories.

title: Look of The Moment | Emma Stone
description: The Look: Black Rose. A glamorous tea-length dress with a hip-defining waistline and embroidered bustier needs only a heel with the skinniest ankle strap and a lip with the rosiest tint to make it feel finished.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Ronen Bergman on Whether Israel Will Attack Iran
description: Ronen Bergman is a political and military analyst for the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth and is currently at work on a history of the Mossad. He wrote this weeks cover story on the possibility of an Israeli attack on Iran in 2012 to prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear power.

title: Artists Development in Harlem Gets Final Financing
description: The construction of El Barrios Artspace (P.S. 109), a development of housing and work spaces for artists planned for East Harlem, will be aided by low-income housing tax credits from the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Artspace Projects has announced.

title: Segregation Curtailed in U.S. Cities, Study Finds
description: More than 40 years after the federal government enacted fair-housing legislation and the Great Migration of blacks from the South began to ebb, residential segregation in metropolitan America has been significantly curtailed, according to a study released Monday.

title: W.P.S. Suspends Operations
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated Less than a day after the United States womens national team won the regional qualifying tournament for this summers London Olympics, the top professional soccer league for women in the United States, the five-team Womens Professional Soccer, announced that it has suspended operations for the 2012 season and hoped to return to the field with eight teams in 2013.

title: New Sex Education Mandate Taking Effect
The 2012 Presidential Campaign, Week by Week
description: Every week during the 2012 presidential campaign, The Times posted a slide show recapping the events of the past seven days.

title: Bill to Prohibit Insider Trading by Members of Congress Advances in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to regain public trust, the Senate voted Monday to take up a bill that would prohibit members of Congress from trading stocks and other securities on the basis of confidential information they receive as lawmakers.

title: Lower-Income Families May Pay More for Auto Insurance
description: Updated | Jan. 31 Added information from industry trade groups.

title: Helen Gurley Brown Gives $30 Million for Media Innovation at Columbia and Stanford
description: With the backing of a $30 million donation from Helen Gurley Brown, the former editor of Cosmopolitan, the graduate school of journalism at Columbia University and the school of engineering at Stanford University on Monday said that they would create a center for media innovation.

title: Does Google+ Offer Businesses an Edge?
description: There was a lot of excitement last year when Google+  Googles answer to Facebook  was introduced, because, well, its Google. But according to everything Ive heard and can observe, the great majority of small businesses havent flocked to the service.

title: Applying for Scholarships, Designing a Prom Dress and Waiting
description: Yes! applications are finally all done, even U.S.C.! Now here comes the hard part: waiting.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Arik Air, Lagos, Nigeria, named C. Moore Media International Public Relations, New York, as its public relations agency of record. The airline had previously worked with the agency on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Travelers Say They Were Denied Entry to U.S. for Twitter Jokes
description: 3:55 p.m. | Updated  As American security agencies increasingly take to Twitter, Facebook and other social networking sites in search of potential threats, two European travelers say the system lacks one important quality: a sense of humor.

title: Scientists Challenging Climate Science Appear to Flunk Climate Economics
description: An op-ed article signed by 16 scientists rejecting the need for drastic action to decarbonize the worlds economy, published Friday by the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, has been widely and thoroughly fact-checked and challenged elsewhere.

title: TimesCast | January 30, 2012
description: The United States Embassy in Cairo shelters at least two Americans from potential arrest | Nate Silver on the Florida primary | A new release from the archives of the folklorist Alan Lomax.

title: Viola Davis on 'The Help'
description: At the Screen Actors Guild awards, Viola Davis discusses her role in The Help

title: After Rejection, Rutgers Taps Interim Coach
description: Kyle Flood, the interim coach at Rutgers, agreed Monday to permanently replace Greg Schiano as football coach after hours of discussions with Mario Cristobal of Florida International ended with him declining the job, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Will Curve Appeal Demonstrate Appeal?
description: A popular fragrance is being joined by a new variety that seeks to freshen the appeal of the brand franchise to younger consumers.

title: Kenneth Branagh at the SAG Awards
description: Kenneth Branagh discusses his role in "My Week With Marilyn" at the Screen Actors Guild awards.

title: The Cast of The Artist at SAG Awards
description: James Cromwell, Beth Grant and Malcom McDowell discuss their supporting roles in The Artist at the Screen Actors Guild awards.

title: Art-Sales Web Site Announces New Financing and Partnerships
description: Artspace.com, one of a wave of online art dealers that is starting to change the way contemporary art is bought and sold, said on Monday that it had raised $2.5 million from a group of investors. Additionally, it said, it had signed up several prominent museums and galleries  among them the New Museum, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia and the Mexico City gallery kurimanzutto  as partners that will offer works to buyers through the Web site.

title: Afghan Kin Are Accused of Killing Woman for Not Bearing a Son
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The young Afghan woman gave birth to a third girl three months ago  to a husband, the authorities say, who had been demanding a boy.

title: Michel Hazanavicius and Brnice Bejo
description: Michel Hazanavicius, the director of The Artist and Brnice Bejo, one of its stars, discuss the film.

title: Will President Obamas Blueprint Cut College Costs?
description: Mark Kantrowitz is the founder of the Web sites finaid.org, and fastweb.com. He regularly answers reader questions on The Choice. Readers can post comments of their own at the end of this essay.

title: East Haven Police Chief Retiring After Charges for Officers
description: The chief of the embattled Police Department in East Haven, Conn., announced on Monday that he was retiring after the arrest of four officers last week on federal charges of harassing and intimidating members of minority groups.

title: Ear Doctors Performing Face-Lifts? It Happens
description: After moving from New York to Los Angeles in 2010 to take a job with a financial services firm, Joan, now 59, believed she needed to freshen her look. So she got a face-lift and tummy tuck from a board-certified doctor in Beverly Hills.

title: Photos of the Moment | Sundance Film Festival
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Emptying the Pacific Ocean With a Thimble
description: I always like starting off the week with a good laugh. So I was delighted to learn that the Obama campaign is returning donations from five registered federal lobbyists because of its oh-so-high standards.

title: In Search of the Elusive Definition of Heterosexuality
description: Science generally succeeds in bringing some order to human existence  except when it does just the reverse, imposing a structure that never quite fits properly no matter how much it is tweaked. Then it just accentuates the underlying chaos.

title: Kenneth Branagh and the Red-Carpet Bazaar
description: Noting that fame has changed tremendously (and, also, not at all) in the past few decades, the Baggers pals at New York magazine have done an exhaustive study of the celebrity economy, from freebies to the cost of appearing wrinkle-free. Its worth a look.

title: NBC Pulls Fear Factor Episode Featuring Drinking of Donkey Semen
description: Back in December, when NBC was promoting the return of Fear Factor, the stunt and gross-out reality competition, there was one event that the producers and the host, Joe Rogan, would not discuss. It was extreme even by the standards of Fear Factor, they said at the time, and they didnt know if it would ever be broadcast.

title: Celebrate Digital Learning Day With 40 Years of Times EdTech Reporting
description: The New York Times has been covering technologys role in education since the paper first began publishing  from an 1872 editorial questioning whether to teach science or the classics to boys of ordinary abilities, (PDF) to Sputnik-era pieces demanding more technical education for American schoolchildren (PDF) to today, when you can hardly open, or click on, the paper without finding an article that references the impact of technology on schools, learning or thinking.

title: Image of the Day: January 30
Everything Indy: The Invasion of the Roman Numerals
description: Throughout the week, Mike Tanier will be out and about and filing dispatches from the Super Bowl city.

title: Envisioning a Perpetual Look for a Memorial AIDS Park
description: Updated, 6:11 p.m. | The winning design for a proposed AIDS memorial park opposite the former St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village was announced on Monday after a worldwide design competition.

title: Caucus Click: Romney the Flight Attendant
Long Wharf Cancels Stage Version of Sophies Choice
description: The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has replaced what it had billed as the world premiere of the play Sophies Choice with an adaption of Chaim Potoks 1972 novel My Name Is Asher Lev for the final slot of its 2011-12 season, the theater announced.

title: In Victory for the West, W.T.O. Orders China to Stop Export Taxes on Minerals
description: HONG KONG  The appeals panel of the World Trade Organization ruled on Monday that China must dismantle its system of export taxes and quotas for nine widely used industrial materials.

title: News Corp. Is Replacing Its Head of Communications
description: News Corporation will lose its head of communications next month, the company said Monday, as Teri Everett becomes the latest senior executive to depart the media conglomerate.

title: Home Court Advantage or Burden for the Underachieving Knicks?
description: Even in the leanest of years for the Knicks - an era in which theyre still arguably mired - they have enjoyed an impressive home-court advantage at Madison Square Garden. Whatever their on-court fortunes, the Knicks can count in their favor a fan base as knowledgeable, and as loud, as any in professional sports.

title: The Changing Meaning of Heterosexuality
description: In todays Science Times, Dr. Abigail Zuger takes a look at Straight: The Surprisingly Short History of Heterosexuality, a book by Hanne Blank, an expert on the history of sexuality. In Straight, Ms. Blank delves into the history of heterosexuality  a history that in at least one sense is surprisingly short. She notes, for example, that the word heterosexual didnt come into use until a little over a century ago. As Dr. Zuger writes:

title: Warm and Furry, but They Pack a Toxic Punch
description: Whats black and white, with a skunkish look to its cover,

title: The 2012 Republican Primaries in Pictures
description: The primary season of a presidential campaign offers a unique glance into the character of a state. Take a look back at key moments and scenes from the 2012 campaign, state by state.

title: More Middle-Income Borrowers Seek Debt Help
description: More middle-income consumers are seeking help through formal debt-reduction plans, according to an Atlanta-based credit counseling outfit.

title: All Kinds of Kale
description: On a recent Thursday at my neighborhood farmers market, one farmer had three different varieties of kale on offer  black kale (also known as cavolo nero, dinosaur kale, dragon tongue, lacinato or Tuscan kale), curly gray-green kale and red Russian kale, another ruffled variety that has red veins and a purplish color. I bought all three and had a lot of fun turning them into dinners over the next 6 days.

title: The Pros Tip Sheet: Adam Smith on Floridas Political Environment
description: Were not just The Villages, opined reporters for The Tampa Bay Times in a list of unconventional campaign stops for Republican candidates. Florida is so much more than retirees and snowbirds (though they are a big part of the equation, to be sure). Its the most populous primary state yet, mired in a housing bust after a population boom that drove the latest rotation of its exaggerated economic cycles. Its political campaigns are primarily waged over the air, while developers, farmers and corporations wage constant battles over the water, be they the Everglades or Floridas 1,197 miles of coastline.

title: Petula Clark: Downtown Uptown
description: Petula Clarks cloud-breaking voice first entered my life when, as a nursery schooler, I begged my parents to buy me her big new hit single, Downtown. So it seemed appropriate that I spent Friday night, the 47th anniversary of the songs run at No. 1, hearing her sing it at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, during her first extended New York engagement in decades. Appropriate, but also odd. As much of a pop milestone as Downtown was, who in 1965 would have imagined that Clark would still be singing it, at a swank Park Avenue cabaret no less, almost 50 years later? Probably not even Clark herself.

title: Lessons From ZocDoc, a Health Tech Start-Up That Works
description: ZocDoc, an oddly named Web service for scheduling appointments with doctors, started in New York in 2007 and has been growing at a torrid pace. Last week the company added Seattle, its 14th metropolitan market in the United States.

title: Britax Recalls 14,220 Child Restraints for Harness Flaw
description: Britax Child Safety is recalling 14,220 child restraints because the shoulder harness may not hold the child, according to a document posted Saturday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. A further 3,600 seats are being recalled in Canada.

title: Occupy D.C. Protesters Stay Put as Evacuation Deadline Passes
description: WASHINGTON  Demonstrators affiliated with the Occupy movement maintained a wary vigil here on Monday as a deadline from the National Park Service for campers to remove their gear or depart from two downtown parks came and went.

title: Stanford Fraud Case Puts Old Friends at Odds
description: HOUSTON  R. Allen Stanford and James M. Davis were roommates at Baylor University and trusted friends over three decades who together built an international financial empire. But this week they are scheduled to confront each other in federal court as indicted swindlers ready to cross swords.

title: Religious Giving and Its Critics
description: Since I used my Sunday column to write about the ways that government can crowd out  sometimes gently and subtly, and sometimes much more directly private efforts to serve the common good, I was struck by the way that The New Republics Alec MacGillis reacted to conservative praise for the millions of dollars that Mitt Romney has given away to private charity:

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 30
description: A view of the day in sports, from the Giants trip to Indianapolis for the Super Bowl to action from the African Cup of Nations.

title: In Honda Ad, Matthew Broderick Takes a Day Off
description: One of the most talked about commercials in the coming Super Bowl  on the basis of a 10-second teaser  features Matthew Broderick in a tribute to his long-remembered role in Ferris Buellers Day Off in an advertisement for the Honda CR-V. That clip has now been superseded by a nearly two-and-a-half-minute version, our friends at the Wheels blog reported. Unlike most viewers, perhaps, Jonathan Schultz was struck by the level of suspension compression that Honda would allow the cameras to capture in the jump sequence. Read more at the Wheels blog

title: New Jersey Symphony to Mark Jazz Age and Wagner Next Season
description: Jazz Age American music and a celebration of the 200th anniversary of Wagners birth will be among the highlights of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestras 201213 season. Jacques Lacombe, in his third year as music director, will lead 16 weeks of traditional classical programs, four pops programs in Newark and New Brunswick and three family concerts. Opening night, on Sept. 28, will feature the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and include Gershwins Rhapsody in Blue. The program also features Remembering Gatsby: Foxtrot for Orchestra, by John Harbison, a New Jersey native, that is part of the orchestras New Jersey Roots Project. During the season the orchestra will also perform music from Wagners Tristan und Isolde, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg and Parsifal. More information about the season is available here.

title: Polls Diverge, but All Point to a Romney Win
The Super Ad Bowl: Two Decades of Players
description: Compare commercials from year to year and watch some of the most memorable spots.

title: Communities Learn the Good Life Can Be a Killer
description: Developers in the last half-century called it progress when they built homes and shopping malls far from city centers throughout the country, sounding the death knell for many downtowns. But now an alarmed cadre of public health experts say these expanded metropolitan areas have had a far more serious impact on the people who live there by creating vehicle-dependent environments that foster obesity, poor health, social isolation, excessive stress and depression.

title: For Do-It-Yourself Nail Artists
description: WITH the rising popularity of salon nail art, companies have started to introduce affordable do-it-yourself versions. Impress Press-On Manicure by Broadway Nails is like an updated version of Lee Press-On Nails. More substantial than polish strips, the hard, nail-like adhesives are long and come in 18 trendy colors ($5.99 at drugstores, including Walgreens), and 18 patterns ($7.99). Once applied, there seemed to be too much space between the real and fake nails toward the cuticle, which made an irritating gathering spot for stray fibers. The adhesives looked decent and survived a multitude of weekend chores. But after 24 hours they were officially annoying me, so I pulled them off, which felt odd but not painful.

title: New Museum Lowers Entry Fee After Raising It
description: Museums often make news by raising their admission prices. (The Metropolitan Museum of Arts recommended admission went to $25 from $20 last year; the Museum of Modern Art, whose fee is not recommended but mandatory, also rose to $25 from $20.) Its much rarer  in fact, almost unheard of  for a museum to get attention by reducing its prices. But the New Museum for Contemporary Art  which raised its admission fee recently to cover higher operating costs for the highly participatory show of the work of Carsten Hller  has decided to lower it. Before the show the fee for adults was $12, which was raised to $16 for the Hller show. It has now been set at $14. The museum continues to offer free admission every Thursday evening from 7 to 9 p.m. and to anyone under 18 at all times. The museums next exhibition, its second Triennial, titled The Ungovernables, opens Feb. 15.

title: The Limits of Gingrichs Debate Skills
description: WASHINGTON  For months, Newt Gingrich has been making the case that he should be the Republican presidential nominee in part because he would destroy President Obama in one-on-one debates.

title: Restored Edison Records Revive Giants of 19th-Century Germany
description: Tucked away for decades in a cabinet in Thomas Edisons laboratory, just behind the cot in which the great inventor napped, a trove of wax cylinder phonograph records has been brought back to life after more than a century of silence.

title: Changed, but Not Defined, by Hemophilia
description: Hemophilia, which affects 20,000 Americans, is a genetic disorder in which the body lacks a clotting factor needed for blood to coagulate. Depending on severity, it can lead to life-threatening, seemingly unprovoked bleeding episodes  or it can go undetected for years, until a serious injury or a routine medical procedure suddenly touches off uncontrolled bleeding.

title: European Leaders Agree to New Budget Discipline Measures
description: BRUSSELS  All but two European Union countries agreed Monday to new and tougher measures to enforce budget discipline in the euro zone, but the bloc still showed few signs of producing a comprehensive solution for the sovereign debt crisis or a credible plan to revive fragile economies across Europes weakened Mediterranean tier.

title: Whats Not to Love About Acting in Silents?
description: There are a lot of theories about why The Artist has struck such a chord with critics and prize-givers (movie theater audiences are still just getting the message).

title: A New Honor for the Hatchet Job
description: 10:00 a.m. | Updated

title: O Say: How Fast Can Kelly Clarkson Sing the Anthem?
description: INDIANAPOLIS  While betting on the actual result of the Super Bowl is, obviously, a popular activity for many fans, the unusual prop, or proposition wagers, can often be more intriguing.

title: AIDS Prevention Inspires Ways to Make Circumcisions Easier
description: The day of the assembly-line circumcision is drawing closer.

title: Sizing Up the Top 25
description: Each week The Quad will analyze the top 25 N.C.A.A. teams (rankings and results are from The Associated Press).

title: The Most Expensive Colleges
description: Higher-ed affordability, or lack thereof, has been in the news, what with President Obamas proposed financial aid overhaul, and with the Occupy movement drawing attention to student-loan debt (now outpacing credit-card debt).

title: Helping Unlicensed Chinese Contractors by Bridging the Language Gap
description: If New York Citys licensing test for home improvement contractors were given in Chinese and included the finer points of bamboo scaffolding, contractors like Gary Lin, 42, of Queens would breathe much easier taking it.

title: Now Serving | Smile to Go
description: For a long time I have wanted to do takeaway food. Other cities have great takeaway, but I havent found it in Manhattan, explains Matt Kliegman, who with co-owner Carlos Quirarte and head chef Melia Marden, open their long-awaited Smile to Go today.

title: Pro Bowl Helps NBC in Ratings
description: NBCs coverage of the 2012 N.F.L. Pro Bowl drew a decent number of fans on Sunday as the American Football Conference defeated the National Football Conference 59-41, though not nearly enough to dominate the overall broadcast network ratings. NBC was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates, and it finished second in total viewers with 10.7 million, just behind CBS (11.4 million). Those two networks were close enough in total viewers that NBC might yet squeak by when the final numbers are released. Undercover Boss had the largest audience for CBS, at 13.1 million total viewers. On ABC, Once Upon a Time continued to perform well  especially for a freshman drama  with its highest audience total since November (10.8 million).

title: To Sell Home, Attaching Fame to Find Fortune
description: For more than 15 years, Michael A. Gales has lived in a cozy but serviceable studio apartment on 66th Street just off First Avenue in Manhattan. There is not a lot of glamour about the place  just enough room for a queen-sized bed, a puffy green sofa and a small, separate kitchen to the right of the front door.

title: Dudamel, Gergiev, Salonen and More Coming to Great Performers
description: Gustavo Dudamel and his orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, will give the first New York performance of the oratorio The Gospel According to the Other Mary composed by John Adams next season, Lincoln Center said on Monday. The concert was announced as part of the Great Performers 2012-13 lineup, which will include two concerts devoted to Brahms by Valery Gergiev and the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: The Caucus | The Florida Primary
description: January 30, 2012 - Nate Silver discusses the Florida primary and the race in February.

title: A Renewed Focus on a Financial Crisis Crackdown
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama promoted the creation of a new unit to investigate the abusive lending and packaging of risky mortgages that led to the housing crisis in order to hold accountable those who broke the law, speed assistance to homeowners, and help turn the page on an era of recklessness that hurt so many Americans. On Friday, Eric H. Holder Jr., the attorney general, announced the formation of the Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities Working Group, which will be staffed by 55 lawyers, agents and analysts, to implement the presidents program.

title: F.D.A. Approves Drug for an Advanced Skin Cancer
description: The first drug for an advanced form of the most common type of skin cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Monday.

title: Like Son, Like Father: Kyle and Ken Williams Face the Critics
description: CHICAGO  Ken Williams, the general manager of the Chicago White Sox, was at Candlestick Park in San Francisco for the N.F.C. championship game to watch his son, Kyle, a 49ers receiver, play in the biggest football game of his life.

title: Financial Improprieties Alleged at All-Girls Charter School Network
Injured Dancer Out for the Rest of City Ballet Season
description: Jennie Somogyi, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, tore the Achilles tendon in her right foot during a performance Saturday night and will be out for the rest of the season, the company said on Monday. It was the second major injury for Ms. Somogyi since early 2004, when she tore a tendon in her left foot during a show. She battled back then, undergoing reconstructive surgery and extensive physical therapy before returning to the stage after 18 months. Rob Daniels, a City Ballet spokesman, said Ms. Somogyi would have surgery on Tuesday.

title: In the Best of Times, Despairing the Giants
description: On Thursday nights from tiny WHDD-AM and FM in Sharon, Conn., David Kamp and Peter Richmonds love for the Giants battles their sense of inevitable doom. And love loses.

title: An Oil Minister, Plugging Renewables?
description: When you think of proponents of green energy, the Saudi oil minister may not be the first person who comes to mind. But in a speech on Monday in London, Ali al-Naimi, the minister from OPECs leading member nation, had a lot to say about renewable energy and global warming.

title: N.F.L. Super Bowl Ad Will Stress Safety
description: To the usual lineup of beer and car commercials on Super Bowl Sunday, add this: one about player safety.

title: Links for Januarys End
description: January 2010 was the warmest January ever. If you live in the Northeast youd have trouble believing that that record will not have been broken by Wednesday. Im going to ask Andy Revkin.

title: Todays Scuttlebot:   F.D.A.s Lack of Privacy and Facebook Ticker Symbols
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Eurozone Problems
description: Im giving a talk in Paris tomorrow. Here are some slides; they wont come as a shock to regular readers, but it may be useful to see them all in one place.

title: Joint Effort Announced Against Tropical Diseases
description: Thirteen drug companies, the governments of the United States, Britain and the United Arab Emirates, the World Bank, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the Lions Club and other smaller charitable organizations on Monday announced a joint effort to tackle 10 neglected tropical diseases in a coordinated fashion.

title: Feeling Strain When Violent Patients Need Care
description: I didnt know much about the patient  just that hed showed up on my floor the previous evening after some confusion about whether his room was ready. When I went into his room that morning, he was still asleep. I gently roused him while his doctor, who had followed me in, explained that he needed to do a physical exam.

title: Beverly Sills Artist Award Is Announced
description: The soprano Angela Meade won the Beverly Sills Artist Award, a $50,000 prize for singers from ages 25 to 40 who have already appeared in featured roles at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said on Monday. Ms. Meade, 34, made her Met debut as Elvira in Verdis Ernani four years ago and will appear again in the role on Thursday in a new run of the opera. The award was endowed by Agnes Varis, a Met managing director, and her husband, Karl Leichtman. Ms. Sills died in 2007. Previous winners include Nathan Gunn, Joyce DiDonato, Matthew Polenzani, John Relyea, Susanna Phillips and Isabel Leonard.

title: Access Hollywood | Inside the Directors Guild Awards
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Vote for African Unions Leader Hits Stalemate
description: JOHANNESBURG  A high-profile and bitterly fought race for the top post in the African Union ended inconclusively on Monday, with neither the incumbent, Jean Ping of Gabon, nor his main challenger, South Africas home minister, Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, securing enough votes to win.

title: Watch Out Dowager Countess, Shirley MacLaine to Join Downton Abbey Cast
