description: Attention all Downton fans: Shirley MacLaine is joining the popular Masterpiece Classic series for its coming third season, ITV and Carnival Films said on Monday.

title: TimesCast | Embassy Shields Americans
description: January 30, 2012  The American Embassy in Cairo is protecting at least two Americans from potential arrest by Egyptian authorities.

title: Super Bowl Playbook: The Patriots First-Down Edge
description: Throughout the week, Mike Tanier will be looking at the New York Giants and the New England Patriots by the numbers.

title: More City Principals Sign Letter Protesting Evaluation System
Plotting to Make Their Audience Laugh
description: In a recent sketch by Harvard Sailing Team, a family stages a teary intervention to inform its patriarch that he has a problem  with his sense of humor.

title: Viola Davis on How an Ensemble Helped The Help
description: LOS ANGELES  The Screen Actors Guild award for best actress is not the only prize Viola Davis picked up over the weekend. Ms. Davis, a star of The Help, was also honored by the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, which gave her its performer of the year award on Friday.

title: Japanese Auto Suppliers Are Fined, and Executives Agree to Prison, in a Price-Fixing Case
description: DETROIT  A Japanese auto supplier, the Yazaki Corporation, agreed to pay one of the largest ever antitrust fines, and four of its executives will serve up to two years in prison for price-fixing and bid-rigging, the Justice Department said Monday.

title: That Wide-Eyed Look
description: Q. Why do doctors dilate your eyes for an exam, and are there any drops to reverse the dilation?

title: London Ensemble Raises a Flute to Frederick the Great
description: On Playing the Flute, the manual written in 1752 by Johann Joachim Quantz, has long been a benchmark for flute players. But much of Quantzs vast collection of concertos and sonatas languished in the Berlin State Library until recently, when Rachel Brown, the Baroque flutist, sifted through the manuscripts, then edited and published a few, including the delightful Flute Sonata in B flat (No. 275).

title: What Should Vassar College Do About Its Admissions Mistake?
description: Electronic college admissions decisions make me nostalgic for the old slim letter/fat letter days. Waiting for a piece of paper in a stamped envelope was a rite of passage. Plus, sending word the old-fashioned way provided more opportunities to catch an error like the one that happened at Vassar College over the weekend.

title: A Tribute to Moon: The Man, the Machines and Those Eyes
description: POMONA, Calif.  Dean Moon, who died in 1987 at age 60, established a small production shop behind his fathers restaurant in the Los Angeles suburb of Norwalk in 1952. Moon Equipment would become one of the most recognized and respected names in the hot-rod and drag-racing cultures, in part for its unmistakable logo: two goggling eyes casting a sidelong glance, a design Mr. Moon first toyed with in his high school typing class.

title: The Art of Contrasts, as Small Strokes Unravel a Fierce, Complex Symmetry
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  In the past two years the young British choreographer Liam Scarlett has achieved the status of an important classical-ballet choreographer. The images, constructions and textures of Viscera, his new creation for Miami City Ballet, show why. I watched it with three different casts over the weekend at the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts here. Each time the audience proclaimed its excitement the moment it ended. Thats a natural response to the terrific control of physical energy in its elaborate finale; but in terms of architectural organization too, this is an impressive piece.

title: In the Spurs, a Model of How to Play
description: When Gregg Popovich is referred to as an exceptional coach, it refers as much to his coaching style as it does his overall effectiveness.

title: Romney Keeps the Heat on Gingrich
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  Mitt Romney kept up the attack on Newt Gingrich at his second stop of the day Monday, even as he seemed a bit more subdued and tired than in recent days, offering a more muted criticism of the former speaker of the House to the large crowd that had gathered here for an outdoor, afternoon rally.

title: Jumping Spiders Focus Like a Camera to Hunt
description: Jumping spiders do not weave webs. Instead, they jump about and then pounce on their prey. For this reason, depth perception is very important to their survival.

title: Looking for That Midnight Train to Jamaica?
description: Riders who find themselves on the New York City subways late at night know, or learn quickly, that their journeys might not follow the routes on the maps posted in stations or handed out at booths.

title: After 18 Albums, Rapper Gets a New York Stage
description: With Too Short, the numbers count. He is 45, and next month he will release No Trespassing (Dangerous/EMI), which by his count will be his 19th album in a career that has spanned 29 years.

title: Even With a Jonas, a Box-Office Drop for How to Succeed
description: After 11 months of strong ticket sales, the box-office receipts for the Broadway revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying fell sharply last week as the actor and musician Nick Jonas took over the starring role of the corporate schemer J. Pierrepont Finch, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League. The gross of $682,879 for the standard eight performances was the lowest amount for How to Succeed since early preview performances last March.

title: Black Feather May Have Helped Archaeopteryx Fly
description: The winged dinosaur Archaeopteryx is often proposed as an intermediate creature between reptiles and birds, but large uncertainties surround it. Could it even fly? Scientists are still unsure.

title: Apple Becomes Worlds Biggest Maker of Computers, Thanks to iPad
description: The company that proclaimed the post-PC era  Apple  is now the biggest maker of PCs in the world.

title: Marine Turtles Make Up for an Early Gender Gap
description: The sex of a baby marine turtle is determined by the eggs temperature at incubation. The warmer the weather, the more female baby turtles there are. (The phenomenon is called temperature-dependent sex determination.)

title: From Biden, a Vivid Account of Bin Laden Decision
description: In the anguished White House debates over the war in Afghanistan, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. argued consistently to stress counterterrorism over the more costly strategy of nation-building. It turns out, though, that Mr. Biden warned against the most sensational counterterrorism operation of the Obama presidency: the commando raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

title: How Riverdale Country School Spends Its Tuition Dollars
Gingrichs Five Stop Tour
description: Newt Gingrich flew to five different campaign stops in Florida on the day before voting began.

title: All They Hope for Is Survival
description: Zehrunisa Husain was a tear-factory even on good days; it was one of her chief ways of starting conversations, Katherine Boo writes in Behind the Beautiful Forevers, her exquisitely accomplished first book. Novelists dream of defining characters this swiftly and beautifully, but Ms. Boo is not a novelist. She is one of those rare, deep-digging journalists who can make truth surpass fiction, a documentarian with a superb sense of human drama. She makes it very easy to forget that this book is the work of a reporter.

title: A Long Journey to Immune System Insights
description: Ruslan M. Medzhitov loves scientific puzzles. And this penchant has led him to tackle some of the big questions of modern biology.

title: The Real Artists of Marfa | Adam Bork
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Teachers Learning Curve in Kabul
description: A few weeks ago, as I was sitting in the English department office at a university in Kabul, sipping coffee and talking to other professors about the end of my time in Afghanistan, I realized that Kabul had taught me patience. But it took a while to get here.

title: For Scientists, Hope Diamonds Blue May Offer Geology Lesson
description: The Hope Diamonds 45.52 sparkling, steely blue carats make it the most famous diamond in the world  shrouded in mystery and intrigue since it was pulled out of the ground in 17th-century India.

title: Santorum Daughters Illness a Test for Candidate
description: TAMPA  Isabella Santorum, the fragile 3-year-old daughter of Rick Santorum, has pulled through again.

title: A Prolific Composer Pauses, Briefly, for His Birthday
description: Philip Glasss friends had a reasonable excuse for jumping the gun and throwing him a 75th-birthday party two days early at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening. On the actual day, Tuesday, Mr. Glass will be at Carnegie Hall to hear the American premiere of his Ninth Symphony.

title: The sound of the 1880s; wolves versus moose in northern Michigan; and watch where you get that nose job.
description: The sound of the 1880s; wolves versus moose in northern Michigan; and watch where you get that nose job.

title: Blue Jackets Awarded All-Star Game as Fans Frustration Grows
description: From the hometown fans cheering wildly for the Senators representatives (and heartily booing the Maple Leafs) to the awestruck players videotaping the performance of the Toronto-born rapper Drake, Canadas capital city of Ottawa provided a nearly perfect backdrop for this past weekends All-Star festivities.

title: Royals Seeking Romance, Disguised (but Not as Frogs)
description: Undercover Princes: If the title makes you think of dashing Hohenzollerns trading secrets in romantic locales, think again.

title: A War on Religion?
description: TAMPA  Mitt Romney is comfortably ahead in Florida, according to several polls, and has begun to taunt Newt Gingrich about it, as he did this afternoon standing in the warm sun of Dunedin, a nearby Gulf town.

title: Text and Video From Nine State-of-the-State Addresses
description: Speeches from a coterie of new Republican governors show that they are adopting a decidedly more moderate tone the year after implementing aggressive agendas.

title: Weighing Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
description: The Commerce Department is scheduled to decide in a month whether Chinese solar panels should be subject to an import tariff, after fielding a complaint from domestic manufacturers that the Chinese are illegally subsidizing their solar export market. The department has not said how it will rule.

title: Second Year In, Republican Governors Moderate Tone
description: A year after a coterie of new Republican governors swept into the statehouses and put in place aggressive agendas to cut spending and curb union powers, sparking strong backlashes in many places, many of them are adopting decidedly more moderate tones as they begin their sophomore year in office.

title: A One-Man Studio Band and the Strength of Smooth Jazz
description: GOTYE

title: Theater Complex Raises Its Curtain
description: During the depths of the recession in 2009, leaders of Signature Theater Company had a showy selling point in their pitch to raise $38.5 million to build a new home: models of the 70,000-square-foot complex by a star architect, Frank Gehry. Yet Signature, a respected but frills-free Off Broadway nonprofit, lacked a grand space in which to show the models and to entertain prospective donors.

title: Fluoridation Pro and Con (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Marred Portrait of Disgust (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Signature Home
description: A look at the $66 million Signature Center, home of the Signature Theater Company.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington, D.C., and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, D.C., Nepal, Brazil and India.

title: Federal Pay vs. Private Sector Compensation
description: Are federal workers really overpaid?

title: Folklorists Global Jukebox Goes Digital
description: The folklorist and ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax was a prodigious collector of traditional music from all over the world and a tireless missionary for that cause. Long before the Internet existed, he envisioned a global jukebox to disseminate and analyze the material he had gathered during decades of fieldwork.

title: Listening to the Globe
description: Songs from the archive of the ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax to be included in the Global Jukebox project.

title: If Twitter Is Any Clue, Axelrod Thinks a Lot About Romney
description: David Axelrod has found his id. On Twitter.

title: DNA Turning Human Story Into a Tell-All
description: The tip of a girls 40,000-year-old pinky finger found in a cold Siberian cave, paired with faster and cheaper genetic sequencing technology, is helping scientists draw a surprisingly complex new picture of human origins.

title: Numberplay: Ordering in Circles
description: Take a look at the numbers in the inner black circle above. This clockwise arrangement of 1, 2, 3, 1, 3, and 4 has an interesting property. With it you can count all the numbers from one to seven in order in the following way. You go around the circle reading each number and if it is in counting sequence starting from one, you count it and move on. If it is not in counting sequence, you are allowed to add as many consecutive numbers as needed to make it so.

title: Unusual Problem: Rangers Have Too Many Forwards
description: Unlike the Devils, whom they visit at Prudential Center on Tuesday night for the first of five remaining games this season, the Rangers have a problem unique to N.H.L. teams as the calendar turns to February: a roster logjam.

title: Corzine Is Seeking $2.9 Million for Hoboken Penthouse
description: Nearly three months after MF Global filed for bankruptcy protection, many questions still surround the failed brokerage firm. Not among them, however, is what it will cost to live in the penthouse of its former chief executive.

title: App Smart Extra: Parenting Apps
description: Last weeks App Smart column highlighted a pair of apps for new parents, WebMD Baby (free on Apple) and Baby Connect ($5 on Apple and Android). Given WebMD Babyspedigree, its little surprise that the app offers a deep well of medically related information.

title: Massachusetts: Kennedys Transfer Hyannis Home
description: The Kennedy family transferred ownership of the main home in their compound in Hyannis Port, Mass., to the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate on Monday. The institute will use the 9,055-square-foot waterfront home for educational seminars and will create a plan to allow limited visits by the public, according to a statement. The Kennedy family, which still owns other homes in the compound, will continue to use the property on a limited basis. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who died in 2009, arranged for the home to be donated to the institute.

title: A Flying House of Fun, Ever Ready for Takeoff
description: If Italo Calvino, Douglas Adams and William Gibson had gotten together, maybe become a little drunk and decided to pull a literary all-nighter, the resulting collaboration might have had something of the flavor of John Jesuruns Stopped Bridge of Dreams.

title: New Fund Hopes to Prove Outspoken Analysts Thesis
description: R. Christopher Whalen doesnt mince words about the big banks.

title: A Travel Start-Up Raises Money for Planning Tourism Activities
description: For many travelers, planning the trip is almost as fun as taking it. Yet using the Web to plan a vacation can be frustrating because there are still few helpful resources online.

title: A Power Outlet With USB Ports Built In
description: There are a lot of approaches to getting rid of wall-warts, those blocky power transformers that let you plug your low-voltage, battery-powered USB products into the wall to charge.

title: General Withdraws From West Point Talk
description: Plans for a talk at West Point by a retired general known for his harshly anti-Muslim remarks were abruptly canceled on Monday after a growing list of liberal veterans groups, civil liberties advocates and Muslim organizations called on the Military Academy to rescind the invitation.

title: Super Bowl on a Whim? That Trip Will Cost You
description: AS of last Friday, you could still find a scarce hotel room for this weekend in Indianapolis, at the budget Best Inn  for $898.99 a night, according to Travelocity.com. That would put you in town for the Super Bowl on Sunday between the New York Giants and New England Patriots.

title: Colorado Lawsuit Challenges Wisdom of Ballot Box
description: DENVER  Few elected officials would ever dare say, at least within earshot of a microphone, that voters making public policy decisions through ballot-box referendums are less capable or wise than legislators deliberating under a capitol dome.

title: Obama and Romney Campaigns Adopt Square for Funding
description: Social media was agame-changing technology that helped alter the course of the 2008 presidential election. In 2012, mobile payments could be the transformational technology, as millions of political supporters are given the ability to collect money on smartphones for candidates.

title: Albany Redistricting Plan Faulted as Unfair to Minorities
description: ALBANY  A proposed redrawing of New York States political districts came under intense criticism on Monday, as civil rights leaders said the maps did not fairly represent blacks and Hispanics in an increasingly diverse state, and Democrats said they would file a lawsuit asking a judge to intervene.

title: A Police Training Film About Muslims: 2 Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur Remains Devils Gatekeeper
description: NEWARK  As if the Devils always need to be reminded of their glory days, replicas of their three Stanley Cup banners hang above their practice rink. It seems hard to believe the first of those Cups came nearly 17 years ago, the last almost nine years ago.

title: The Democrats Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Brooks, Who Refined Lord & Taylor, Dies at 84
description: Joseph E. Brooks, a retail executive who doubled the size of the Lord & Taylor chain and made its flagship New York store a showplace of spectacle, including elaborate retail stagecraft and a daily morning rendition of The Star-Spangled Banner, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Technology and Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Ritalin and the Hyperactive Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Burmese Civil War Turns Grimmer for a Guerrilla
description: DUMHPAWNG KAWNG, Myanmar  When the Burmese soldiers dumped the body of a young ethnic Kachin guerrilla fighter outside a jungle hut in front of his commander, he was still in his uniform. His right hand had been shredded with a knife. There was a large gunshot wound in his stomach.

title: Free Speech vs. Infringement in Suit on Alabama Artwork
description: In the specialized field of sports art, Daniel Moore is well known for his paintings of the University of Alabama football team in action. But he soon may become similarly recognizable in legal circles as his fight against the universitys charge of trademark infringement heads to the United States Court of Appeals.

title: F.T.C. Fines a Collector of Debt $2.5 Million
description: The Federal Trade Commission signaled on Monday that it would continue to crack down on debt collectors who harass consumers for money they may not even be legally obligated to pay.

title: Treasury Investigates Freddie Mac Investment
description: The Treasury Department is investigating a report that Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant, bet against homeowners ability to refinance their loans even as it was making it more difficult for them to do so, Jay Carney, a White House spokesman, said on Monday.

title: Volcker Rule Stirs Up Opposition Overseas
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Usually, it is the banks that are fighting efforts to impose new regulations on the industry. Now, it is foreign governments fighting against bank regulations in the United States.

title: The End of Health Insurance Companies
description: Heres a bold prediction for the new year. By 2020, the American health insurance industry will be extinct. Insurance companies will be replaced by accountable care organizations  groups of doctors, hospitals and other health care providers who come together to provide the full range of medical care for patients.

title: At the Century Mark, Its Not Just About the Cookies
description: ID like to drop out of high school and get a meaningless job that makes me feel bad about myself, says a young girl in a new public service announcement. Id like to fall victim to the old boys network, says another.

title: Trade Protest Is Planned on Eve of a Chinese Leaders Visit
description: HONG KONG  As the White House prepares for a Washington visit by the man who is expected to run China for the coming decade, trade tensions between the United States and Beijing are on the rise.

title: On Day Before Primary, Gingrich Hits Five Florida Cities
description: With Floridas Republican primary just a day away, Newt Gingrich plans a five-city rush on Monday  with stops in Jacksonville, Pensacola, Tampa, Fort Myers and Orlando. Here, reporters follow him on his hectic journey.

title: Gatekeepers Under Scrutiny
description: Lawmakers dissatisfied with the performance of the Transportation Security Administration are pushing to revive a proposal the agency has resisted  allowing airports to use screeners hired by private contractors  so the agency can focus more on its role as overseer, rather than operator, of airport security.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pregnant, and Pushed Out of a Job
description: FEW people realize that getting pregnant can mean losing your job. Imagine a woman who, seven months into her pregnancy, is fired from her position as a cashier because she needed a few extra bathroom breaks. Or imagine another pregnant employee who was fired from her retail job after giving her supervisors a doctors note requesting she be allowed to refrain from heavy lifting and climbing ladders during the month and a half before her maternity leave: thats what happened to Patricia Leahy. In 2008 a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that her firing was fair because her employers were not obligated to accommodate her needs.

title: Tunisia Faces a Balancing Act of Democracy and Religion
description: TUNIS  The insults were furious. Infidel! and Apostate! the religious protesters shouted at the two men who had come to the courthouse to show their support for a television director on trial on charges of blasphemy. Fists, then a head butt followed.

title: Drones for Human Rights
description: Washington

title: Giants Leave the Injured Back at Home, for Now
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Giants charter landed at Indianapolis International Airport at 2:49 p.m. Monday, according to flight records, and the requisite team flag was hung out the window as the plane taxied in from the runway. When the door opened, numerous coaches, assorted staff members and players stepped out, and the Giants had officially arrived at Super Bowl XLVI.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Primary Bounce
description: One of the maxims of past nomination campaigns is that a candidate should expect to receive a bounce in the polls after winning a major primary or caucus  particularly if he or she beat the expectations established by the polls and the news media while doing so.

title: Above Africa and Alaska, Awe Replaces Anxiety
description: CONSIDERING the fact that Im an author and Im telling people about places they need to see, its crazy that Im actually a nervous flier. Maybe people who dont like to fly can take some solace in that.

title: A Cheesebox on a Raft
description: A month before the first shots were fired at Fort Sumter, the Philadelphia Examiner editorialized, If we intend to have a national naval force worthy of our power and pretensions, we shall have to  build iron-cased vessels.  Before the end of the year, France will have eight and England six.  How many are we to have? At that moment, most of the countrys ranking naval officers would have answered none, for they were uniformly skeptical of both the need for and the practicality of ironclads. To John Lenthall, the Navys chief of construction, equipment and repair, the very idea was a humbug.

title: Can a Town Divided Against Itself Stand?
description: Abraham Lincoln, what does he know? A house divided against itself can stand, and will do so for decades, no sweat. Berlin, Nicosia, Jerusalem  heck, even Kansas City: all are cities that have been split in two by borders. All are still around. But if being split down the middle doesnt mean the end of the world, it aint fun either. A house divided is a house of pain, with degrees of inconvenience varying from administrative annoyance to frequent lethality.

title: After Mistake, a Mea Culpa From Vassar
description: After 76 applicants were mistakenly told they had been accepted to Vassar College, its president has apologized for the considerable confusion and hurt caused by the terribly upsetting event, and said the college would reimburse the students $65 application fees.

title: For Patriots and Giants, a Shared Priority
description: INDIANAPOLIS  From studying videotape of the Giants defense this season, the New England Patriots know they must protect Tom Brady on Sunday. This revelation was disclosed Monday by their center, Dan Connolly, who concluded that it will take work and effort to shield Brady from a pass rush from the team that pummeled him four years ago in Super Bowl XLII but, in what must be a relief to New England fans everywhere, yes, I think we can do it.

title: Buoyant Romney Speaks of Victory in Florida
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney swept through a final day of campaigning here on Monday, energized by more polls showing him with a commanding lead in the Florida primary. He even allowed himself to break superstition and proclaim, Im beginning to feel we might win.

title: The Great Divorce
description: Ill be shocked if theres another book this year as important as Charles Murrays Coming Apart. Ill be shocked if theres another book that so compellingly describes the most important trends in American society.

title: With Muslims, Using a Brush Far Too Broad
description: I stood last week on City Halls plaza, as a gray wet January day pressed in, and thought: How completely isolated they look.

title: Knicks, Short on Players and Time, Feel Urgency
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Ten men in blue and white jerseys ran full court in an early-afternoon scrimmage Monday, revealing a vivid, woeful picture of the Knicks.

title: Dont Stop the Debates
description: Senator John McCain spoke for many nervous Republicans on Sunday when he said its time to stop the debates. Theyve turned into mud-wrestling contests, he said on Meet the Press on NBC, and are driving up negative impressions of the partys presidential candidates.

title: Food Crisis as Drought and Cold Hit Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A drought that a government official called the most severe Mexico had ever faced has left two million people without access to water and, coupled with a cold snap, has devastated cropland in nearly half of the country.

title: Celebrity Guest Solver Alan Zweibel
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  One of the nice things about the Celebrity Guest Solver feature, other than giving me the opportunity to work with some truly brilliant minds, is that it gives me a bit of a break. A chance to put my feet up, if you will, and let someone else do the heavy crossword lifting for a change. Its asking a lot, because these are busy people who obligingly take the time out of their busy schedules to solve and write about the puzzle for your entertainment. And because they usually have a book to plug.

title: A Family Reunion, With a Chaser
description: The standup comic and sometime actress Janeane Garofalo drops the shtick, more or less, to play a stern Russian Jewish mother in Brooklyn in Russian Transport, by Erika Sheffer, a new play from the New Group that opened on Monday night at the Acorn Theater.

title: The Shortfall in Cancer Screening
description: A new federal study found that Americans are getting screened for three major cancers  breast, cervical and colorectal  at rates far below national targets. The shortfall is especially high among adults who lack insurance or regular access to a doctor, partly because the recession drove employers to lay off workers or cut health benefits.

title: Tom Coughlin
description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin spoke on Monday about the leadership qualities of his quarterback Eli Manning.

title: College Says It Exaggerated SAT Figures for Ratings
description: Claremont McKenna College, a small, prestigious California school, said Monday that for the past six years, it has submitted false SAT scores to publications like U.S. News & World Report that use the data in widely followed college rankings.

title: In Studios and Grand Halls, Feeling a Pinch From Italy
description: As Italys new government scrambles to stave off economic disaster, the budget cuts it has imposed are rippling through Italian institutions in New York City, slicing into paychecks and prompting plans to shut down a venerable state-owned television operation.

title: Deconstructing the Boatright Decision
description: In my column, I try to make sense of the decision on Ryan Boatright, the University of Connecticut freshman, who, until last Saturday, had been suspended from the mens basketball team. In handing down its ruling to reinstate him, the N.C.A.A. issued a press release so malicious in its intent that I could not let it pass. Longtime watchers of the N.C.A.A. tell me that they have never seen an athlete and his mother thrown under the bus the way Ryan and Tanesha Boatright were on Saturday. Below, Ive annotated the press release. Click here to see an enlarged version.

title: Hollywood Copyright Dispute: The Skirmishing Resumes
description: LOS ANGELES  Save the date: Monday, July 9, 2013.

title: UConn Wins on Road but Isnt There Yet
description: DURHAM, N.C.  In the post-Maya Moore era at Connecticut, the Huskies are no longer the alpha females of womens college basketball. Baylor and Notre Dame share that place now.

title: John F. Baker Jr., Who Saved 8 G.I.s in 1966, Dies at 66
description: John F. Baker Jr., who joined the Army after being deemed too short for the Marines and went on to receive the Medal of Honor for saving eight fellow soldiers during the Vietnam War while under heavy fire, died on Jan. 20 in Columbia, S.C. He was 66.

title: Afghan Officials Consider Own Talks With Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Concerned that it is being left out of potential peace talks between the United States and the Taliban, the Afghan government is pushing to open its own direct negotiations with the insurgent group in Saudi Arabia, Afghan officials said on Monday.

title: Saving Freshman Ryan
description: My plan had been to give the N.C.A.A. a rest this week; there are, after all, other problems in the world. But then, at 6:15 on Saturday evening, the N.C.A.A. announced that it was reinstating Ryan Boatright, the University of Connecticut freshman who had been suspended from the mens basketball team, and whose mother, Tanesha, had been the subject of a horrific investigation that I had previously written about.

title: Steve Jones and Nicole Scherzinger Wont Return to The X Factor
description: Steve Jones and Nicole Scherzinger, two of the people who helped start The X Factor in the United States, will not be sticking around for season two of the singing competition, the Fox network said Monday.

title: A Companion for the Journey
description: Tori Stitt, a former Navy officer who did a tour in Iraq, relies on the companionship of her golden retriever to aid her recovery.

title: Coughlin Not Worried About His Legacy
description: INDIANAPOLIS  One of the more popular story lines of the pre-Super Bowl XLVI coverage has been what a Giants victory would mean for the legacies of quarterback Eli Manning and Coach Tom Coughlin. Bill Pennington of The Times wrote recently about how Coughlin would compare to some of the more successful coaches in N.F.L. history if the Giants were to defeat the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl for the second time in four years.

title: Amid Ailments and Loss, a Mother Forges Ahead
description: Above Nelsy Peraltas bed is a photograph of a birthday cake amid baby pictures pasted together in a large collage. The cake has vanilla frosting with a bright blue trim. A message reads, Happy Birthday to Pedro and Nelson. They are Ms. Peraltas fraternal twin sons, born in 2007.

title: The Shock of Recognition
description: After nearly 30 operations, Joey Paulk began to resign himself to his appearance. But with help from a program that aids burned veterans, he received surgery that revived his self-confidence.

title: A Harder Squeeze on the Poor
description: House Republicans have hit upon a noxious scheme to help pay for an extension of the payroll tax cut: a tax increase on millions of poor working families. A bill passed by the House and now in conference seeks to deny cash refunds under the child tax credit to those who file tax returns using individual taxpayer identification numbers issued by the Internal Revenue Service. Only those using Social Security numbers would be eligible.

title: The Hard Road Back
description: A series of articles and videos chronicling the experiences of military veterans who have returned from Iraq and Afghanistan but continue to confront the medical and psychological scars of battle.

title: For Soldier Disfigured in War, a Way to Return to the World
description: Specialist Joey Paulk awoke from a coma in a Texas hospital three weeks after he was burned nearly to death in Afghanistan. Wrapped in bandages from head almost to toe, he immediately saw his girlfriend and mother, and felt comforted. Then he glanced at his hands, two balls of white gauze, and realized that he had no fingers.

title: Free Opinions at Firehouses
description: Some firefighters in the New York City Fire Department are actively opposing a federal judges order to reform the departments long history of bad employment practices. They have started a misguided campaign called Merit Matters to stop the judge and the city from creating new exams for potential applicants and have distributed materials to various stationhouses. Last month, the Fire Department, in what seems like a misguided response, tried to ban material presenting opinions or viewpoints anywhere in the citys firehouses.

title: What Is It About Mormons?
In Berlin, a Festival Focuses on the Contemporary Arts
description: This year is the 25th anniversary of Berlins alternative media arts festival, Transmediale. This five-day event, which starts on Tuesday at the Haus der Kulturen der Welt contemporary arts center, has a rich international program of artworks, installations, video screenings, workshops, performances and an interdisciplinary symposiums, all organized by various guest curators.

title: In a Political Ritual, Candidates Tour France in a Race for 500 Signatures
description: PARIS  In 1965, Marcel Barbu, a jeweler and philanthropist, ran for the French presidency as the candidate of battered dogs. In 2002, Pierre Rabhi, a farmer and philosopher of Algerian descent, built himself as the candidate of peaceful insurrection. Coluche, a well-known comedian, called for the lazy, the filthy, the drug addicts, the alcoholics, the pedophiles and other nonmainstream voters to elect him in 1981.

title: Money Cant Buy Him Love
description: Most polls predict a sizable victory for Mitt Romney in Florida. How did this happen? How did Newt Gingrich lose his grip on the state? Money, thats how.

title: Claremont McKenna in California Admits Exaggerating Students SAT Scores
description: Pamela B. Gann, the president of Claremont McKenna College, a small, selective liberal arts college in California, admitted on Monday that a senior administrator had been submitting inflated SAT data to ratings agencies since 2005, in an apparent effort to increase the colleges standing. My colleague Richard Prez-Pea and I report in Tuesdays Times that Richard C. Vos, vice president and dean of admissions, is believed to be the source of the false information, and the only individual involved.

title: Civilian Deaths Due to Drones Are Not Many, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday defended the use of drones to strike suspected terrorists in Pakistan and elsewhere, saying the clandestine program was kept on a very tight leash and enabled the United States to use pinpoint targeting to avoid more intrusive military action.

title: Gingrich Makes a Last-Minute Push in Florida
description: On the last day of campaigning, the candidate went on a five-city Florida Fly-Around tour to woo voters before the primary Tuesday.

title: Corrections: January 31
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cart Hurled at Bronx Mall Injures 2 Men
description: Two men were injured, one critically, on Monday after someone hurled a shopping cart off the third story of a parking garage at a Bronx megamall, slamming into both men, the police said.

title: After Rescinding Mistaken Acceptances, Vassar Delivers an Apology
description: Vassar Colleges president, Catharine Hill, apologized on Sunday night to 76 students who were mistakenly informed they had been accepted to the college. The apology came after Matt Flegenheimer reported that Vassar accidentally posted a test letter that led 122 early-decision students to think they had been admitted when only 46 of them had. Mr. Flegenheimer details the apology here:

title: Katherine Boos Behind the Beautiful Forevers
description: Half an acre. 335 huts. 3,000 people. And a concrete wall that is supposed to hide them from view: this is Annawadi, the Mumbai slum that comes vibrantly to life in Behind the Beautiful Forevers, Janet Maslin writes in this book review in The New York Times.

title: Clear Channel to Invest in Company Run by TVs Idol Host
description: Ryan Seacrest, who already is a host, producer and spokesman for Clear Channel, will soon be an investment partner as well.

title: Word of the Day | wince
description: wince \win(t)s\ noun and verb

title: Report by House Democrats Absolves Administration in Gun Trafficking Case
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Tuesday are expected to publish a report on the disputed gun trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious, concluding that agents in Arizona  not Obama administration officials  were responsible for the tactics used in the inquiry and for providing misleading information relayed to Congress.

title: Fatally Flawed: Five Years of Gun-walking in Arizona
description: Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee released a report on the disputed gun trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious.

title: Indias Chai Drinkers Embrace Coffee
description: For coffee-shop regulars across India, Starbucks plans to enter the Indian market will be hailed as a pleasant development.

title: Pakistan: Crusading TV Host Is Fired
description: A major television station fired a prominent journalist on Monday after she led a self-styled moral crusade against dating couples that set off a furious public outcry. Maya Khan, 31, the host of a breakfast show, led a group of women that chased young couples through a Karachi park on Jan. 17, accusing them of bad behavior and, in one case, demanding to see their wedding certificate. To many Pakistanis, the images evoked comparisons with the Taliban. The chairman of Samaa TV, Zafar Siddiqui, said Monday that he could not absolve such behavior irrespective of ratings the show was getting.

title: One Country, Two Systems? Not Lately
description: HONG KONG  It pretty much started with a little girl from mainland China spilling some noodles onto the floor of a Hong Kong subway car.

title: Fighting Intensifies in Syria
description: An anti-Assad group known as the Free Syrian Army, composed partly of army defectors, has attacked and violently resisted loyalist forces.

title: NYT Front Page for 01/31/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 01/31/2012

title: Colberts Super PAC Raises More Than $1 Million
description: Stephen Colberts quasi-satirical presidential bid has raised serious cash  over $1 million, as of Tuesday morning, the comedian announced.

title: News Quiz | Jan. 31, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Jan. 31, 1865 | House Passes 13th Amendment, Abolishing Slavery
description: On Jan. 31, 1865, the House of Representatives passed a constitutional amendment to abolish slavery. The amendment, which would become the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, read, Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.

title: Banking on the Future of Print
description: WHO is William R. Lynch?

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 31, 2012

What do you do when youre stressed out? Do you keep a blog? If so, does blogging seem to improve your mood or help you relax? If not, why not?

title: Kidnappings of Workers Put Pressure on China
description: BEIJING  Chinas government, grappling with the kidnapping of a construction crew in Sudan, is facing heightened pressure over the safety of the countrys citizens abroad after a group of cement plant employees in Egypt was briefly abducted by Bedouin tribesmen on Tuesday.

title: Atomic Agency Backs Safety Tests for Japans Reactors

title: The Early Word: Measured Steps

title: Sugar and Spice, and Something Sinister
description: LONDON  Smells like pre-teen spirit at the Cambridge Theater, where a throng of irresistibly fed-up boys and girls are storming the barricades of adult oppression. Revolting children they call themselves in the rousing final number of the musical Matilda, the fattest, sassiest hit of the season here. And the words have special savor for these kids because theyve been used before, in another way.

title: Smiles and Exclamation Points as College Decisions Arrive, But Not for Me
description: Never have I ever been so happy to see green triangles. When one appears next to each completed application on the common application Web site those shapes ensure that colleges see that I am here, asking to join them. However, that is just the beginning of the whole process. Before me still lies the long wait, shuffling through files of tax forms and applying to scholarships to help me survive through college.

title: Genie in a Bottle? Testing a Headlight-Lens Defogging Solution

description: LONDON  Two decades after the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia is regaining a reputation in international diplomacy as the country that likes to say nyet.

title: Diplomats Jockey Over Assads Future as Syrian Troops Press Attacks Near Capital
description: UNITED NATIONS  Syrian forces pushed rebels back from strongholds near Damascus on Tuesday in new spasms of fighting as some of the worlds top diplomats prepared at the United Nations to try to press President Bashar al-Assad to leave office through a Security Council resolution.

title: Running the Numbers: Controlling Labor Costs
description: I dont keep close track of the hours I spend at work, never have, and probably never will. I have, in the past, worked fairly long hours, but I rarely exceed 60 hours a week. Most days, I work about 10 hours, but Im not what you would call a steady worker  too many things to distract me, and no one looking over my shoulder. My people, though, work very hard and very steadily.

title: Santanders Profit Plunges on European Debt Crisis
description: LONDON  Banco Santander of Spain announced on Tuesday that its net profit fell nearly 98 percent, to 47 million euros, during the final three months of last year, as the bank dealt with the downturn in the Spanish real estate market and the European debt crisis.

description: Apache, a two-year-old German shepherd, tracked the suspect down a pitch-black passageway in the Brooklyn Bridge/City Hall subway station the other day, helped by the oldest of canine technology, his nose, and bearing the newest, an infrared camera harnessed to his back.

Even in January, thanks to the mild winter climate, scores of joggers, hikers, picnickers and the occasional horseback rider enjoy the five miles of trails and scenic spots.

The first two polls released after South Carolina showed Mr. Gingrich with a lead of 8 and 9 points, respectively. But the news has gotten worse for him almost every day, and he trails Mitt Romney by nearly 15 points in the final FiveThirtyEight forecast of the Florida primary.

title: Daily Report: A Global Jukebox Goes Digital
description: Technology has caught up to the imagination of Alan Lomax, the folklorist and ethnomusicologist whose lifes work was collecting traditional music from cultures across the world, Larry Rohter reports in Tuesdays New York Times. Long before the Internet existed, Lomax wanted to create a global jukebox for the material he had found. Now, 10 years after his death, his archive  amounting to about 5,000 hours of sound recordings, 400,000 feet of film, 3,000 videotapes, 5,000 photographs and piles of manuscripts  is being digitized so that it can be accessed online. About 17,000 music tracks will be available for free streaming by the end of February, and later some of that music may be for sale as CDs or digital downloads.

title: Removing a Truth, or Leg, for the Greater Good
description: Many years ago, a New York journalist wrote scathingly about City Hall, but found himself criticized for having committed serious factual errors. Well leave his name out of this because he is no longer with us. De mortuis, and all that. The point is that when the lapses became known, he shrugged them off, saying they did not undermine the larger truth he had conveyed.

title: The Giants History Countdown: Running Back Tandems
description: Throughout the week, we will be ranking the Giants 1934, 1938, 1956, 1986, 1990 and 2007 N.F.L. championship teams in various categories. The 1920s teams are not included because of severe differences in the game and the league. In this installment, we rank the running back tandems, whether they are rotations, committees, or old-fashioned three-back attacks. For the teams of yesteryear, tailbacks who acted as de facto quarterbacks are counted in the mix.6. 1934 Giants: Harry Newman had a short, modestly distinguished career as a 179-pound A-formation tailback (by todays standards, a Tebow). He led the league in nearly every passing category in 1933, but in 1934 he threw just one touchdown and 12 interceptions, statistics that were almost as bad then as they are today. Ken Strong was an All-Pro fullback/defensive back for both the Giants and the Staten Island Stapletons, then an N.F.L. team, and Strong rushed for 431 yards and 6 touchdowns. His best years were behind him by 1934, though he stayed with the Giants as a placekicker until after World War II. The third member of the backfield was Wee Willie Smith, who played just one season in the N.F.L. (He is not to be confused with the legendary basketball player of the same name.) You do not have to be an expert in 1930s football to realize that a backfield with one player who played just one season and another who played just three seasons belongs low on any all-time list.

title: London Theater Journal: Big Ideas in Small Spaces
description: LONDON  Some plays are worth defying claustrophobia for. As a capacity audience crowded onto the benches that surrounded the rectangular stage of the tiny black-box space of the Royal Court Jerwood Theater Upstairs, I could feel my chest tightening and my breath growing shorter. It didnt help that layers of white balloons covered (and lowered) the ceiling in molecular formations. I had to admonish myself, as I do in such circumstances, Theater critics do not faint on the job  except, on rare occasion, metaphorically.

title: Kitchen Tools for the Younger Chefs
description: When your child is ready to step out of the play kitchen and into a real one, tools scaled for diminutive chefs will make cooking tasks easier and safer. A sturdy skid-free cutting board provides a proper work surface. A step-stool should allow the budding cook to stand tall enough at a counter to wield a knife or rolling pin at the proper angle and with the correct pressure. And an array of well-made kitchenware is sold online. Ive taught childrens cooking classes and have four children of my own; here are some of the best products Ive found.

title: Divers Suspend Underwater Search of Stricken Italian Liner
description: FLORENCE, Italy  The Italian Civil Protection Agency said Tuesday that deteriorating safety conditions had forced divers to suspend the underwater search for missing people in a wrecked cruise ship off the island of Giglio. The ship, the Costa Concordia, struck a reef on Jan. 13, heeled over and foundered just offshore, with the loss of at least 17 lives.

title: Risotto With Red Kale and Red Beans
description: Im always on the lookout for vegetables with red pigments, a good sign of anthocyanins, those beneficial flavonoids that are known for antioxidant properties and are present in purple and red vegetables. When you cook the kale with the rice, the red in the kale dyes the rice pale pink (the kale goes to a kind of drab green). The first time I made it, without the red beans, the finished product reminded me of the way the rice looks when I make red beans with rice. So I decided to add red beans to the mix, which provide a healthy dose of protein and fiber, as well as color.

title: Demian Bichir on What It Means to Be American
description: The Help is not the only movie this Oscar season that deals with still-relevant issues of race, class and the political landscape. Theres also A Better Life, which earned its star, Demian Bichir, a surprise best actor nomination (and a fun, tequila-filled morning of celebration). In the film, directed by Chris Weitz (American Pie, About a Boy), Mr. Bichir plays an undocumented Mexican immigrant struggling to make a place for himself and his son by working as a gardener around Los Angeles.

title: College Life, Enlistment and the Real World
description: You? Take orders? You? The speaker, an English teacher Id had in junior high, stood and looked at me, shocked, a frozen smile of disbelief on her face. It was just one of the many responses Ive gotten to the sentence, Im joining the Army. A few others: Have you thought about the Peace Corps? You should be a Marine, I hear the Army trains them really well. Oh, like ROTC? Army band?

description: The Look: Natural Glow. A fresh face and simple upsweep echo the quiet elegance of this crimson keyhole dress.

title: Accommodating Pregnant Women at Work
description: Depending on your circumstances, being pregnant and needing just that little bit of extra accommodation at work  more bathroom breaks, a stool at the counter, a break from the requirement that all retail employees share in the lifting of boxes and climbing of ladders  could mean youre out of a job. Laws that ban discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace dont require that any special needs be accommodated, and the Americans With Disabilities Act, which would, doesnt apply to most pregnant women.

title: A Conservative Report Card, With Facts Disputed
description: In a last-minute effort to derail Mitt Romney, conservative evangelical groups say they e-mailed a report card on the candidates real positions on marriage and moral standards on Monday to 1.6 million Florida residents, mainly self-identified Christians and pastors. The message is signed by the American Family Association, which strongly opposes same-sex marriage and equal rights for homosexuals, and claims to list the candidates positions on 10 issues.

title: Is Your Building Gobbling Energy?
description: Want to know whos an energy hog?

title: Crown
description: Crown opened just after Labor Day, and already everyone looks as if they have been coming here forever.

title: Government Unions and Layoffs
description: As my colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote in Saturdays paper, the share of workers who are unionized fell again last year, to 11.8 percent.

title: The Comforts of Millionaires
description: IT looked as if fireflies had been released into the dining room.

title: Iowa G.O.P. Chairman Resigns in Wake of Caucus Controversy
description: DES MOINES  The chairman of the Republican Party of Iowa announced his resignation on Tuesday after mounting pressure over his handling of the results of the caucuses that kicked off the presidential nominating process this month.

title: HBO Renews Luck for Another Season
description: In what looked like a sure thing given the creative pedigree involved, HBO announced on Tuesday that it had renewed its new horse racing drama Luck, starring Dustin Hoffman and produced by Michael Mann and David Milch, for a 10-episode second season with a premiere date set for January 2013. The first episode has drawn 3.3 million total viewers over multiple airings including the 1.1 million viewers who tuned in on Sunday. The quick turnaround has become standard operating procedure for HBO; Game of Thrones, Boardwalk Empire and Treme were also renewed two days after their debuts.

title: Einhorn Case Highlights Britains Broader Definition of Insider Trading
description: The settlement of charges filed by the Financial Services Authority, Britains financial regulator, against David Einhorn and his hedge fund, Greenlight Capital, for trading on confidential information highlights how malleable the term insider trading can be.

title: HBO Renews Luck, Stronger in Reviews, So Far, Than Ratings
description: HBO, citing many favorable reviews, moved quickly to renew for a second season the new racetrack-based drama Luck.

title: And Now, Heres Ocho
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When the Patriots advanced to the Super Bowl, a scheduling conflict emerged for Chad Ochocinco. Instead of asking questions at Media Day, as he has done the last two years as the lead reporter for the Ochocinco News Network, he would be answering them.

title: Connecting the Dots: Mapping Apples Development and Manufacturing Process
description: March 19, 2012 | Updated

title: Giants Williams Says Foot Injury Not an Issue
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Actual news can be hard to come by on Media Day at the Super Bowl and this years version was, for the most part, no exception. There were people in costumes, a variety of folks using props as they conducted interviews and a slew of offbeat questions including one, which was posed to several players, about which famous actor would best portray Coach Tom Coughlin in a movie (my first thought: Jon Voight).

title: Time Warner Cable Campaign Focuses on Brand More Than Services
description: Time Warner Cable is continuing to promote services beyond conventional cable television with a new brand-image campaign that urges customers to Enjoy better.

title: At U.N., Pressure Is on Russia for Refusal to Condemn Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  The battle over Syria moved to the United Nations on Tuesday with Western powers and much of the Arab world confronting Russia and its allies in the Security Council over their refusal to condemn the Syrian government for its violent suppression of popular protests.

title: The Caucus | The Retiree Vote
description: Ashley Parker reports from the Romney event in The Villages, Fla., where many residents remained undecided in todays primary.

title: A Debt Markets Slow Recovery Is Burdened by New Regulation
description: Collateralized loan obligations may seem at first to be nothing but a throwback to private equitys golden era of enormous leveraged buyouts.

title: A Start-Up Rewards Savers, Not Spenders
description: We are accustomed to earning credit card points for spending money. A start-up called SaveUp wants to flip that idea on its head and give prizes for saving money instead.

title: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
description: In this edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Christopher Botta looks ahead to the second half of the season with Adam Rotter of SNYRangersBlog and John Forslund, the play-by-play announcer for the Hurricanes.

title: Caucus Video: The Retiree Vote
description: Ashley Parker reports from the Romney event in The Villages, Fla., where many residents remained undecided in todays primary.

title: Four N.F.L. Concussion Lawsuits Consolidated
description: A federal judicial panel has consolidated four lawsuits started by hundreds of former N.F.L. players who have sued the league and helmet makers, alleging that they deliberately hid critical information about the dangers of concussions and hits to the head. The combined case will be tried in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia before Judge Anita B. Brody.

title: Home Economics
description: Catherine Rampell, a business reporter, interviews Motoko Rich, a reporter, about how the continuing decline of housing prices weighs on the economy.

title: Indiana Legislation Could Create Awkward Situation for N.F.L. Players
description: INDIANAPOLIS  With the Indiana Senate poised to vote  and almost certainly pass  a right to work bill on Wednesday, the N.F.L. players union could find itself in an awkward position.

title: Eli Manning Talks About Peyton, but Not His Future
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Can you name all 12 schools in the SEC? Could you have done it when you were six years old and had your big brother rapping his knuckles on your chest?

title: Confident Rolle Is Out of the Prediction Game
description: It was a kinder, gentler Antrel Rolle at the Super Bowl media day, no matter how hard the contingent of reporters tried to push for something bolder.

title: Islanders to Play Devils in Preseason Game at New Arena in Brooklyn
description: Perhaps hinting that they are seriously considering alternatives to Nassau County, the Islanders will be the home team in the first N.H.L. game at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

title: Officer Accused of Stealing iPads
description: A New York City police officer was arrested on Monday and accused by prosecutors of committing a crime while he was arresting a suspect.

title: The Insider | Tricia Donegan
description: Tricia Donegan, 41, met Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta when Germanotta was a New York University student taking classes at Donegans Bikram yoga studio on Allen Street. Germanotta became Lady Gaga, and Donegan became her private teacher. As part of the Yoga Freedom Project, Donegan will teach at a yoga class tonight in New York City that benefits the Somaly Mam Foundation, an organization dedicated to fighting human trafficking. She told The Moment how she fell for Bikram, how yoga can change the world and what makes Lady Gaga a successful yogini.

title: Singapore, Point of Departure
description: CHILI crab may be the worlds messiest national dish. Dismantling a massive crustacean slathered in spicy sauce at one of Singapores street-food stalls can require more napkins than you have fingers. Its thrilling, as is much of the dining in Singapore, where dozens of vendors share a clamorous stage at one of the countrys government-run hawker centers.

title: In a First, a Woman Will Be Senate Parliamentarian
description: For the first time, a woman is going to be the parliamentarian for the Senate.

title: Faulk Has Fans in High Places
description: On the occasion of his fifth Super Bowl appearance, Patriots running back Kevin Faulk was awarded one of the fourteen main booths on the field of Lucas Oil Stadium for Media Day.

title: Charles Grassleys Curious Obsession
description: As the highest-ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Charles Grassley of Iowa should be obsessing over the Constitution, the rule of law, and other weighty matters. Instead, hes obsessing over Virginia Seitz, the assistant attorney general for the Office of Legal Counsel.

title: As Florida Votes, Paul Campaigns Elsewhere
description: LAS VEGAS  The only contest Representative Ron Paul is likely to win in Florida on Tuesday is this: highest ratio of votes to time spent campaigning there.

title: Breast Cancer Surgery Rules Are Called Unclear
description: Nearly half of women who had lumpectomies for breast cancer had second operations they may not have needed because surgeons have been unable to agree on guidelines for the most common operation for breast cancer, a new study finds. It also hints that some women who might benefit from further surgery may be missing out on it.

title: A Sign Law Spurs Investment in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  An influx of new residents, stores, restaurants and hotels in Center City has largely bypassed Market East, the blocks of Market Street east of City Hall to Independence Mall.

title: Five Dishes at Crown
description: Crown, an Upper East Side townhouse that has become a local joint for well-off neighbors, is the subject of my restaurant review this week. John DeLucies menu is all fairly familiar, which can lead to a bit of dullness around the edges, but a number of the dishes come together in ways that make you understand how classics get to be classics. Here are five that are worth ordering if you find yourself on East 81st Street with a spare hundred or two in your pocket.

title: It Starts With Lip Gloss
description: THE other day at Kimara Ahnerts makeup and skin care studio on Madison Avenue, Sloane Kratzman, 12, was sitting in a chair, having blush applied to her cheeks, her legs dangling above the floor. She had been driven in after school from Greenwich, Conn., by her mother, Teresa Kratzman, a longtime friend of Ms. Ahnerts, for her first makeup application lesson.

title: French Court to Review Genocide Bill
description: PARIS  Frances Constitutional Council said Tuesday that it would rule on the constitutionality of criminalizing the denial of a genocide of Armenians during World War I, after receiving appeals signed by dozens of lawmakers from across the political spectrum.

title: Assembly Investigating Transportation Group
description: ALBANY  The State Assembly has begun an investigation of a little-known government body that plays a major role in setting transportation policy in New York City and its suburbs.

title: Barnes & Noble Wont Sell Books From Amazon Publishing
description: In a sharp answer to Amazon and its expanding publishing efforts, Barnes & Noble said on Tuesday that it would not sell books released by Amazon Publishing in its bookstores.

title: Scene City: Famous Faces Who Posed for Sandro Kopp
description: Tilda Swinton, Frances McDormand, Michael Stipe and others celebrate artists gallery show.

title: Frankies vs. Deen
description: AFTER the hue and cry following Paula Deens announcement that she has Type 2 diabetes and would become a paid spokeswoman for a drug company, a question nags: Is the food that emerges from her kitchen really less healthy than the cuisine from other restaurants?

title: Party Is in New York; a Host Is on Skype
description: For an artist who lives in remote northern Scotland, Sandro Kopp is very well connected. But then, you would be, too, if Tilda Swinton was your girlfriend and you had a score of famous faces willing to pose for you.

description: A Visitor Who Cooks

title: To the Police, an Embezzler; to a Shop Owner, a Lovely Person
description: The woman first entered Mary-Annes Irish Gift Shop, in the Bronx, sometime in the 1990s, thrilled at having happened upon the boutique and its scarves and sweaters, pewter and pottery and Celtic photography.

title: Dan Burton to Leave House After 30 Years
description: Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, announced Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the year after three decades in the House.

description: Opening

title: A $1 Billion Model Employee Education Program
description: Big companies often seem to be conflicted  if not two-faced  when it comes to their workers. They pay lip service to their employees as their most cherished corporate assets, yet they routinely shed workers.

title: Will AT&T Get Rid of the Yellow Pages?
description: AT&T has hinted that it may sell off parts of its business that are performing poorly. Perhaps the most obvious candidate is the good old-fashioned Yellow Pages. Yes, the fat phone book that you probably toss into the recycling bin after it has been out on the porch for a few weeks.

title: Quakes and U.S. Reactors: An Analytic Tool
description: With the release of a computer model of all known geologic faults east of Denver, nearly all of the nuclear power plants in the United States are about to embark on a broad re-evaluation of their vulnerability to earthquakes. The new mapping is the first major update of the fault situation for plants since 1989.

title: Reviewing Masak
description: Some Singaporean food shouts for attention, some speaks more softly. Masak in the East Village, the subject of this weeks $25 and Under column, serves the latter. The small dining room is modestly decorated, free of gewgaws and garish bottles of hot sauce, and the spiciest and most pungent flavors of Singapores wildly diverse cuisine have been tempered. The bright open kitchen, however, offers an excitement all its own.

title: My Oscar Picks: Jeffrey Eugenides
description: Our Oscar ballot is online and more than 15,000 of you have filled it out so far. The Carpetbagger is asking a few notable names  authors, television and Broadway stars, newscasters  to join you and then talk to us about their Oscar picks.

description: Photographs from Florida, Myanmar, Egypt and China.

title: Modern Love  la Shaw, From His Life
description: In a Victorian London galvanized by A Dolls House, a rake is caught between the woman he loves and the woman who loves him. All are members of the Ibsen Club, where men and women may socialize, provided they are committed to more advanced, modern relationships. Eventually, though, all learn that each alternative  marriage or an idealized, unrealized courtship of equals  carries its own disappointments.

title: Federal Donuts
description: Doughnuts and fried chicken under one roof in Philadelphia.

title: Obama Campaign Releases Names of Bundlers
description: In keeping with his practice  and unlike any of the Republican candidates for president  President Obama on Tuesday volunteered an updated list of his bundlers, wealthy donors who gather checks from their networks of friends, family members and business associates.

description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Facebook Said to Be Planning for I.P.O. Filing on Wednesday
description: 6:02 p.m. | Updated Facebook plans to file the prospectus for its initial public offering on Wednesday, according to people briefed on the matter, finally kicking off one of the most anticipated stock sales of the social networking era.

title: Gronkowski Greets News Media Without a Boot
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski was wearing a sneaker and not a boot on his injured left ankle Tuesday when he met with the news media. Gronkowski, who was injured during the A.F.C. championship game against the Ravens, said it was not a gamesmanship ploy.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitter Humor and Rethinking the Car
description: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: Model in Anti-Obesity Ad Criticizes the Campaign
description: Another of the overweight models appearing in ads from New York Citys health department  one who did not have a limb edited off  criticized the campaign, saying that the ads will not have the desired effect.

title: For Top-Ranked Wisconsin Women, a Big Victory and a Big Crowd
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Chips, Translated From the Spanish
description: Dare we suggest elitist chips to go with workaday beer and dips? From Spain come uncommonly flavorful but light potato chips fried in olive oil. Their producer grows its own potatoes at high altitude east of Madrid and offers the chips in organic and conventional varieties, seasoned with sea salt. After tasting a third version, dusted with Spanish paprika, you may forswear barbecue-flavor chips.

title: New Condiments With Kick
description: Every Super Bowl spread needs a kick, and thats where the spreads and sauces come in. Saucy by Nature, a new line of condiments, makes some that can transform the usual fare.

title: A Rare Public Lament for Lost Earmarks
description: One of the things House Republicans are most proud of is banishing earmarks from their bills, including, notably, the current version of an infrastructure and transportation bill, which has traditionally been a veritable stew pot of pork for members districts.

title: The Ground Where Brady Sat
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Tom Bradys podium stood on hallowed ground Tuesday at Media Day  at least for Colts fans.

title: Students at Claremont McKenna More Worried About Reputation Than Rankings
description: CLAREMONT, Calif.  Students at Claremont McKenna College acknowledged on Tuesday that revelations that a senior administrator had inflated SAT scores submitted to college ranking guides was not the best way to make headlines. But they also defended their school, which has climbed to No. 9 among liberal arts colleges in the U.S. News & World Report.

title: In Last Quarter of 2011, Gingrich Rakes In Nearly $10 Million
description: Newt Gingrich raised nearly $10 million in the final three months of 2011, according to reports his campaign filed with the Federal Election Commission on Tuesday. That is roughly triple what he raised in the first six months of his campaign, and his spokesman, R.C. Hammond, said Mr. Gingrich had raised an additional $5 million in January.

title: The Hottest Item at the Super Bowl Is Hand Knit
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The must-have souvenir from the first few days of Super Bowl week is not a team jersey or a miniature helmet. And it is not for sale, although one person has offered $200 for one and players and team executives have clamored to get them for themselves and their wives.

title: A Gathering for Both Conversing and Playing
description: Among opportunities to hear music by the composer David Lang performed live, the best are those in which he is invited to talk about his works. Genial, droll and articulate, Mr. Lang has a knack for making the disparate impulses and methods that mingle in his music seem not just appropriate but also inevitable.

title: A Firing Offense
description: Last Friday, we ran an editorial about East Haven, Conn., a charming New England town where the police force harasses Latinos and the mayor is an incompetent fellow who makes racist jokes. The Federal Bureau of Investigation had arrested four police officers on charges of terrorizing the towns Hispanic neighborhoods, stopping and detaining people, searching businesses without cause, beating people in handcuffs, smashing a mans head into a wall.

title: Heroism and Hell: War as Told by Hollywood and by Soldiers
description: Whether you prefer your war stories low key or over the top, hesitant or harrowing, Gonna See a Movie Called Gunga Din has you covered.

title: Italian Marathon, Pretty and Challenging
description: The title of the marathon of guitar music presented by the New York Guitar Festival at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday was BellItalia, and there was not a moment in the three-and-a-half-hour evening session that was less than beautiful.

title: Chrysler Readies New Mopar Mods for Chicago Auto Show
description: CENTER LINE, Mich.  On Tuesday, the Chrysler Group commemorated the 75th anniversary of its Mopar performance parts division by showing four vehicles here at the divisions headquarters, to be introduced officially at the Chicago auto show next month.

title: Fox News Marks a Decade at No. 1 in Cable News
description: Fox News Channel has long surpassed its rivals in the cable news business and now it has an official round number to point to: Fox News has been No. 1 for a full decade.

title: Florida Benchmarks From 2008
description: As we did with South Carolina, here  courtesy of Matthew Bloch, a New York Times graphics editor  are county-by-county results from the 2008 Republican primary in Florida for you to follow along with as results are reported tonight.

title: Republican Chided Over Blog Says He Wont Run for Senate
description: Marc Cenedella, a wealthy Republican businessman who was laying the groundwork for a United States Senate campaign in New York, announced on Tuesday that he had decided not to run.

title: Hulu Returns to Super Bowl, as Ad Lineup Firms Up
description: 11:34 a.m. | Updated Five days before Super Bowl XLVI, the lineup of advertisers is being firmed up with the news on Tuesday that the video-streaming site Hulu will be buying commercial time.

title: Live Coverage of the Florida Primary
description: Welcome to FiveThirtyEights live blog of Floridas Republican primary. Polls in the state are closed, and well be bringing you the results, data-driven observations, exit poll information and some historical perspective.

title: Draft of Security Council Resolution on Syria
description: Following is a draft of the proposed United Nations Security Council resolution concerning Syria, as it was circulated among diplomats on Tuesday afternoon and provided to The New York Times.

title: Physical Flickers of Light and Motion Animate Film Pioneers
description: It is probably impossible to recreate in modern audiences the wonder that the very earliest films must have incited. For us the poetry and pathos of those rudimentary artifacts  brief slices of life  come mainly from their mere survival, while the people in them, and the people who made them, are long gone.

description: The last polls in Florida do not close until 8 p.m. ET, but were learning what we can about the Republican electorate from the early exit polls.

title: Spring Secrets | Finding the Seasons Staples
description: The subtext for the arrival of a new season of clothes in stores and online  brace yourself, itll happen any day now  is one riddled with tough decisions like cost-per-wear calculations and heart-wrenching explorations of need versus want. The pieces youve earmarked in all of your favorite magazines  the bandeau tops and hot-shorts as suit separates, perhaps?  arent always the most practical investments. Sure, theyre perfect on glossy paper, but watch what happens when applied to plastic.

title: Frustrated With Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen West to Switch Districts
description: Representative Allen West, Republican of Florida, will switch Congressional districts to greatly increase his chances of winning re-election.

title: The Hashtag Dresses Up
description: THE suit sections at most of New Yorks major department stores remind me of funeral homes. The dark wood. The austerity. The hands-offness of the sales clerks, who will assist when asked, but who otherwise consider respectful distance to be an effective marketing technique. If you can afford these suits, the theory seems to go, then you must understand them. And if you understand them, then you want to be left to your wandering, your fingering, your discerning.

title: Gupta Faces New Charges in Insider Trading Case
